query: How does the disease cycle of anthracnose typically progress in strawberry plants?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['From 2010 to 2016, we conducted surveys of anthracnose in strawberries in Miaoli County. More than 50% of diseased plants exhibited symptoms characteristic of anthracnose crown rot (ACR), as described by McInnes et al. (1992). ACR resulted in plant losses of up to 30-40% during the seedling stage and around 20% after transplanting. Initial symptoms in crown tissue included a marbled red and white appearance, which progressed to brown rot and eventual rapid wilting of the plant. Anthracnose symptoms also appeared on other parts of the plant, including leaves, petioles, runners, fruits, and roots. These symptoms manifested as circular black spots on leaves, withering and girdling on runners.', 0.9708572030067444]]
Context 1: [['In November 2021, anthracnose symptoms were observed on strawberries (cv. Kingsberry) in Nonsan, Chungnam Province. Early symptoms of anthracnose fruit rot (AFR) include blackening of specific tissues of the strawberry. These symptoms progress with the enlargement of lesions, which hinder proper fruit development and lead to the formation of orange-colored spores within the lesions. Similar symptoms were noted on the petioles, with sunken and blackened tissues similar to those on the fruit, accompanied by the formation of an orange conidial mass.', 0.9246243238449097]]
Context 2: [['Anthracnose is an important disease of strawberry caused by Colletotrichum spp., which affects foliage, runners, crowns, and fruits (Howard et al., 1992). Three primary fungal pathogens—C. acutatum sensu lato, C. gloeosporioides sensu lato, and C. fragariae—are known to cause anthracnose disease in strawberries (Freeman and Katan, 1997). The crown rot syndrome is characteristic of infections from C. gloeosporioides sensu lato and C. fragariae, while fruit rot is mainly attributed to C. acutatum sensu lato, leading to significant yield losses (Howard et al., 1992). Currently, numerous species are classified under what is now known as the C. acutatum complex, with six species—C. acutatum sensu stricto, C. fioriniae, C. godetiae, C. nymphaeae, C. salicis, and C. simmondsii—identified as associated with strawberry anthracnose worldwide (Damm et al., 2012). Among these, C. nymphaeae is the most prevalent pathogen causing strawberry anthracnose globally, including in Iran (Baroncelli et al., 2015; Karimi et al., 2017; Wang et al., 2019). Currently, no effective chemical control methods exist for managing strawberry anthracnose; available options are limited to preventive treatments applied before fruit production (Denoyes-Rothan et al., 1999). Additionally, concerns about the toxic effects of chemical fungicides on the environment and the development of resistance in fungal strains highlight the need for alternative control strategies. Consequently, utilizing resistant cultivars appears to be the most efficient and practical approach for suppressing anthracnose development. In light of recent anthracnose outbreaks in strawberry fields in the Kurdistan province of Iran (Karimi et al., 2017), and the necessity for appropriate strategies to address this issue, the aim of this study was to evaluate the resistance of several commercial strawberry cultivars to the anthracnose fruit rot caused by C. nymphaeae under in vivo and greenhouse conditions.', 0.803757905960083]]
Context 3: [['Hu, D. Y., Qian, C., and Liu, X. F. (2014). Research progress of strawberry anthracnose. Chin. Vegetables, 1:9-14.', 0.7897319197654724]]
Context 4: [['From May to September 1995, a severe outbreak of strawberry anthracnose was observed in several strawberry-growing nurseries in Israel. Following transplantation to production fields during September and October, entire beds of strawberry plants collapsed. Typical anthracnose symptoms observed from November 1995 to June 1996 included crown rot, flower blight, and green and ripe fruit rot. This marked the first record of strawberry anthracnose in Israel. Furthermore, in at least four production fields in the same region, hundreds of plants developed symptoms of stunting and chlorosis, which are atypical of strawberry anthracnose. When these plants were uprooted, most of their roots were dark brown and decayed. Colletotrichum was readily isolated from these samples.', 0.6818151473999023]]
Context 5: [["Anthracnose fungi can attack various parts of the strawberry plant, including crowns, petioles, leaves, fruit trusses, flowers, buds, and fruit. The fungi's ability to attack multiple plant parts, coupled with the involvement of several pathogen species, contributes to the complex nature of strawberry anthracnose. Brooks reported in 1931 that C. fragariae caused spotting and girdling of runners, and later indicated that it also caused spotting of petioles and crown rot in a summer nursery, leading to wilting and death of the plants. Researchers in Louisiana observed all these symptoms and noted that crown rot also occurred in the fruit production field.", 0.6788359880447388]]
Context 6: [['Howard CM, Albregts EE. Anthracnose. In: Compendium of Strawberry Diseases. American Phytopathological Society: Paul St, ed. Maas JL, USA; 1984. pp. 85-87.', 0.5691549181938171]]
Context 7: [['Numerous reports indicate that strawberry anthracnose pathogens may originate from weed species. For instance, C. fragariae was found attacking the weed Cassia obtusifolia L. (sicklepod, coffeweed) in Florida, causing typical disease symptoms. Inoculation of strawberry with the Cassia isolates resulted in typical anthracnose symptoms, while isolates from strawberry were equally virulent on Cassia. Similarly, inoculation of Duchesnea indica (Andr.) Focke (wild strawberry), F. virginiana Duch. (Virginia wild strawberry), and Potentilla canadensis L. with C. fragariae induced anthracnose disease on these hosts, suggesting that strawberry anthracnose pathogens have a broad host range.', 0.5394269824028015]]
Context 8: [['Smith, B. J. 1998. Anthracnose leaf spot, irregular spot, anthracnose fruit rot (black spot), and anthracnose crown rot. In: Compendium of Strawberry Diseases. J. L. Mass, ed. American Phytopathological Society, St. Paul, MN. Pages 24-25, 31-33, and 46-48.', 0.5189296007156372]]
Context 9: [['Smith, B. J. (1998). Anthracnose leaf spot, irregular leaf spot, anthracnose fruit rot, and anthracnose crown rot. In: Maas, J. L. (Ed.), Compendium of Strawberry Diseases (2nd Edn., pp. 24-25, 31-33, 46-48). American Phytopathological Society, St. Paul, MN.', 0.46668899059295654]]

query: What is the primary benefit of using resistant strawberry cultivars?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['The development of cultivars resistant to red stele has been a primary objective of the USDA program. Various resistant cultivars have been introduced, including ‘Surecrop’, ‘Midway’, ‘Sunrise’, ‘Guardian’, ‘Earliglow’, and more recently, ‘Scott’, ‘Allstar’, ‘Lester’, and ‘Lateglow’. In the Pacific Northwest, Waldo introduced ‘Siletz’ in 1955, marking the first red stele-resistant strawberry for this region. Since then, two other significant red stele-resistant cultivars, ‘Hood’ and ‘Benton’, have emerged from the cooperative USDA-Oregon State strawberry breeding program. Furthermore, the first day-neutral cultivars with multiple resistances to red stele, ‘Tristar’ and ‘Tribute’, were released from Beltsville in 1981 (Galletta et al., 1981).', 0.9850318431854248]]
Context 1: [['In this study, most commercial cultivars, including ‘Paros’, ‘Queen Eliza’, ‘N. Selva’, and ‘Camarosa’, commonly grown in strawberry fields in Iran, were categorized as susceptible. Therefore, deploying relatively resistant cultivars such as ‘Blackmore’, ‘Aliso’, ‘Mark’, ‘Diamant’, and ‘Yallova’ could be effective in preventing disease development in regions where the disease is endemic. Additionally, cultivars with relative resistance may be crossed with commercial cultivars in breeding programs to improve and develop resistant varieties. To the best of our knowledge, this study represents the first attempt to evaluate the reaction of certain commercial strawberry cultivars against Colletotrichum nymphaeae, which causes strawberry AFR.', 0.9768434762954712]]
Context 2: [['The modern strawberry, Fragaria × ananassa Duchesne, is of relatively recent origin. It was not until the North American F. virginiana and the South American F. chiloensis were brought together and hybridized in Europe around 1750 that the progenitor of the strawberry we know today was developed. The high degree of genetic heterozygosity in Fragaria spp. has facilitated the creation of strawberry cultivars adapted to a wide range of environmental conditions and resistant to several diseases and pests. Today, cultivars are available that can survive the bitterly cold winters of Alaska, as well as those that thrive in the long, hot seasons of Pretoria, South Africa.', 0.7304639220237732]]
Context 3: [['This study highlights the variability in resistance among strawberry cultivars to AFR and provides insights into cultivar selection for disease management.', 0.39820584654808044]]
Context 4: [['Ballington, J.R., J.L. Shuman, B.J. Smith, and S.C. Hokanson. 2002. Breeding strawberries (Fragaria × ananassa) for resistance to anthracnose caused by Colletotrichum acutatum. Acta Horticulturae 567:89–92.', 0.3317580819129944]]
Context 5: [['During the 1920s, more than 130 strawberry cultivars and 20 selections of Fragaria species were utilized in the breeding program, with 44 of these parents originating from Europe (Darrow et al., 1934). Thousands of seedlings were evaluated, resulting in the naming of several cultivars (Darrow, 1937). The two most significant cultivars from this early work were ‘Blakemore’ and ‘Fairfax’. ‘Blakemore’ quickly became a leading cultivar, setting a standard for firmness that allowed successful long-distance shipping of fruit. This cultivar demonstrated wide adaptability in the southern and south-central regions of the U.S. and continues to be commercially grown in some areas. Both ‘Blakemore’ and ‘Fairfax’, along with other USDA selections such as 253, 543, and 634, became widely used as parent plants in subsequent breeding programs (Darrow, 1966). ‘Fairfax’ was particularly valued for its excellent fruit quality and resistance to leaf spot (Darrow, 1962).', 0.33110126852989197]]
Context 6: [['Ballington, J.R., J.L. Shuman, B.J. Smith, and S.C. Hokanson. 2002. Breeding strawberries (Fragaria × ananassa) for resistance to anthracnose caused by Colletotrichum acutatum. Acta Hort. 567: 89—92.', 0.30740246176719666]]
Context 7: [['Scott, D.H., A.D. Draper, and G.J. Galletta. 1984. Breeding strawberries for red stele resistance. Plant Breeding Reviews 2:195-214.', 0.2818183898925781]]
Context 8: [['Howard, C. M., and Albregts, E. E. 1979. ‘Dover’: a firm-fruited strawberry with resistance to anthracnose. UF/IFAS Circ. S-267, Florida.', 0.25335660576820374]]
Context 9: [["Ongoing evaluation of strawberry seedlings and advanced breeding lines from state and private breeding programs continues. The USDA's anthracnose-resistance screening procedure has effectively identified resistant genotypes in seedling progenies from the North Carolina State University breeding program, with over 32,000 resistant strawberry seedlings identified between 1998 and 1999 (Ballington et al., 2002).", 0.19409315288066864]]

query: To what extent does climate change influence the development and spread of anthracnose in mangoes caused by Colletotrichum siamense in China?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['In our previous study, three Colletotrichum species causing mango anthracnose in Guangxi Province, China, were reported: C. asianum, C. fructicola, and C. siamense. The growing season and harvesting times of mango in seven provinces vary due to environmental factors, climatic conditions, and the varieties grown, which may lead to variations in the composition and distribution of causal agents of mango anthracnose. Genetic diversity is often related to evolutionary potential and adaptability to changing environmental conditions. Based on our understanding of the gene-for-gene hypothesis, resistance genes can lose their effectiveness when faced with complex and evolving pathogen populations. Understanding the population structure and species distribution of pathogens can provide insights into optimal breeding strategies for durable resistance to anthracnose in mangoes and improve cultural controls.', 0.966843843460083]]
Context 1: [['Jayasinghe, C. K., and Fernando, T. H. P. S. (2009). First report of Colletotrichum acutatum on Mangifera indica in Sri Lanka. Ceylon J. Sci. Biol. Sci., 38, 31-34. Li, R. W., Huang, G. D., Su, M. H., Zhou, J. A., and Chen, Y. S. (2013). Status and developmental strategies of the mango industry in China. J. South. Agric., 44, 875-878. Liu, L., Shu, J., Zhang, L., Hu, R., Chen, C., Yang, L. N., Lu, B. H., Liu, Y. N., Yu, L., Wang, X., and Li, Y. (2017). First report of post-harvest anthracnose on mango (Mangifera indica) caused by Colletotrichum siamense in China.', 0.9484176635742188]]
Context 2: [['In our previous study, three Colletotrichum species causing mango anthracnose in Guangxi province, China (C. asianum, C. fructicola, and C. siamense), were reported. The growing season and harvesting times of mango in seven provinces differ in environmental and climatic conditions, as well as in the varieties grown, which may lead to variations in the composition and distribution of causal agents of mango anthracnose. Genetic diversity is often related to evolutionary potential and the ability to adapt to variable environmental conditions. Based on our current understanding of the gene-for-gene hypothesis, resistance genes lose their effectiveness when faced with complex and evolving pathogen populations. An understanding of the population structure and species distribution of pathogens can provide insights into optimal breeding strategies for durable resistance to anthracnose in mangoes and improved cultural controls.', 0.9364071488380432]]
Context 3: [['Liu, L. P. et al. First Report of Post-Harvest Anthracnose on Mango (Mangifera indica) Caused by Colletotrichum siamense in China. Plant Disease 101(5), 833 (2017).', 0.9325290322303772]]
Context 4: [['Colletotrichum siamense has also been noted as a significant species causing mango anthracnose in China and eastern Australia. This species has a broad host range in tropical and subtropical regions, capable of infecting banana (Musa spp.), papaya (Carica papaya L.), dragon fruit (Hylocereus spp.), guava (Psidium guajava), and avocado. It was suggested by James et al. that C. siamense is likely a common and widespread saprophyte or endophyte, as the authors were able to isolate it from asymptomatic fruit of other plants, with the exception of mango and avocado. Similar to C. asianum, C. siamense has been reported to cause disease in coffee in Thailand, but not in mango until this study.', 0.928790807723999]]
Context 5: [['Qin, L. P., Huang, S. L., Lin, S. H. & Lin, C. H. First Report of Anthracnose of Mangifera indica Caused by Colletotrichum siamense in Sanya City, China. Plant Disease 101(6), 1038 (2017).', 0.8795313835144043]]
Context 6: [['Qin, L. P., Huang, S. L., Lin, S. H., and Lin, C. H. (2017). First report of anthracnose of Mangifera indica caused by Colletotrichum siamense in Sanya city, China. Plant Disease, 101:1038.', 0.8582035303115845]]
Context 7: [['The present study revealed a high diversity of Colletotrichum species associated with mango from the six major mango-growing areas in China. The Colletotrichum isolates examined showed significant diversity, which may correlate with varying environmental conditions such as temperature and rainfall, as well as the sample collection time and source. The major species identified associated with mango anthracnose in China were Colletotrichum asianum, C. fructicola, and C. siamense. This finding aligns with the report by Vieira et al. (2014), which indicated that C. asianum was the most common endophytic species found in mango trees.', 0.8141544461250305]]
Context 8: [['Mango (Mangifera indica) is regarded as one of the most significant tropical or subtropical fruit crops (Nelson 2008). In China, it is primarily cultivated in the southern and southwestern provinces, with a planted area of nearly 130,000 hectares, yielding approximately 900,000 tons in 2012 (Li et al. 2013). Guangxi province is the largest mango-producing area in China, significantly contributing to the local economy (Li et al. 2013). Anthracnose, caused by several Colletotrichum species, is recognized as the most critical disease affecting mango in China (Hong et al. 2016). While Colletotrichum gloeosporioides is the primary causal agent, Colletotrichum acutatum has also been reported (Freeman et al. 1998; Jayasinghe and Fernando 2009; Phoulivong et al. 2010). Symptoms of mango anthracnose include irregularly shaped, black necrotic spots on both the upper and lower sides of mango leaves, with lesions also appearing on stalks and flowers. The most significant damage occurs during ripening and postharvest stages, when black lesions develop on mango fruit surfaces (Arauz 2000; Freeman et al. 1998).', 0.7690344452857971]]
Context 9: [['Wu et al. (2020) reported on Colletotrichum spp. associated with mango anthracnose in Taiwan. They identified C. asianum, C. fructicola, C. siamense, C. tropicale, and C. scovillei, some of which were previously recognized by Li et al. (2019) in China. A comprehensive study of mango anthracnose was also conducted by Tovar-Pedraza et al. (2020) in Mexico. In this study, five species were identified using the mating type Mat1-20 (ApMat) marker: C. alienum, C. asianum, C. fructicola, C. siamense, and C. tropicale. In terms of virulence, C. alienum and C. fructicola were found to be the least virulent, while C. siamense and C. asianum exhibited the highest virulence. All identified species, except C. alienum, have been reported as causal pathogens of mango anthracnose. Notably, Colletotrichum alienum was the first species reported to be associated with mango anthracnose worldwide at the time of its discovery. Later, Ahmad et al. (2021) reported that C. alienum was associated with anthracnose in mango fruits of the Jin-Hwang cultivar in Beijing, China. To date, 17 species of Colletotrichum are known to be associated with mango anthracnose worldwide. With the application of multiple markers in phylogenetic analysis, it is likely that more new species will be identified from other mango-producing countries.', 0.6779667735099792]]

query: How do secondary metabolites correlate with the pathogenicity of Colletotrichum strains?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['García-Pajón, C.M., and Collado, I.G. (2003). Secondary metabolites isolated from Colletotrichum species. Natural Product Reports 20: 426-431.', 0.6979235410690308]]
Context 1: [['The genus Colletotrichum is considered one of the top ten important genera of fungal pathogens globally (Dean et al., 2012). Colletotrichum is an ancient fungus that has co-evolved with flowering plants. Plant microfossils of Protocolletotrichum preserved on angiosperm leaf cuticles suggest that the diverse pathogenic strategies of Colletotrichum spp. have been established since the Late Cretaceous period (Kar et al., 2004). Different complexes within the genus may have diverged between 4.8 and 32.2 million years ago (MYA) (Bhunjun et al., 2021). The emergence of agricultural cultivation and the intensive disturbance of natural environments have further driven the diversification of Colletotrichum species. These fungi have adapted to thousands of hosts and can be found as endophytes, pathogens, and saprobes (Freeman et al., 1998; Dean et al., 2012; Hirayama et al., 2018; da Silva et al., 2020; Jayawardena et al., 2020). Currently, a total of 257 Colletotrichum species grouped into 15 complexes and 13 additional singletons have been accepted in this genus.', 0.3790823817253113]]
Context 2: [['Citation: Cai, L., Hyde, K.D., Taylor, P.W.J., Weir, B.S., Waller, J., Abang, M.M., Zhang, J.Z., Yang, Y.L., Phoulivong, S., Liu, Z.Y., Prihastuti, H., Shivas, R.G., McKenzie, E.H.C., Johnston, P.R. (2009). A polyphasic approach for studying Colletotrichum. Fungal Diversity, 39: 183-204.', 0.37807878851890564]]

Context 4: [['Many species belonging to the genus Colletotrichum are associated with plant diseases, commonly referred to as anthracnose. Colletotrichum spp. can affect a wide range of hosts, and these pathogens are characterized by global distribution. Virtually every cultivated botanical family is susceptible to one or more species of Colletotrichum, making it one of the most studied plant pathogenic fungi (Prusky et al., 2000; Latunde-Dada, 2001; Dean et al., 2012). Common hosts include many dicotyledonous plants such as strawberry, apple, citrus, and stone fruits, as well as major cereals such as maize and sorghum. Members of this genus can cause crop losses of up to 100% in many staple foods (Bailey and Jeger, 1992; Prusky et al., 2000; Talhinhas et al., 2005; Cannon et al., 2012).', 0.294151246547699]]

query: What role does nitrogen form (ammonium vs. nitrate) play in plant health and disease resistance?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['The form of nitrogen significantly influenced both the severity of Fusarium crown and root rot and the growth of tomato seedlings in a soilless rockwool system (Fig. 1). Increasing concentrations of nitrate-N reduced disease severity and improved plant growth compared to ammonium forms. Both ammonium sulfate and ammonium chloride produced similar responses, indicating that NH4+ was the harmful component (Fig. 1). Ammonium nitrate has been reported to either have no effect on Fusarium diseases or to increase disease severity, similar to ammonium-N (Jones et al., 1989; Schneider, 1985). While this was generally true for Fusarium crown and root rot, testing a range of concentrations revealed that at low concentrations (10 to 100 mg·L–1 N), ammonium nitrate reduced disease similarly to nitrate-N (Figs. 1D, 2D). However, the negative influence of the NH4+ ion became apparent at concentrations above 125 mg·L–1 N (Figs. 1D, 2D). At higher concentrations, seedlings might have lacked sufficient available carbohydrates to convert the excess ammonium, which is toxic for tomato seedlings (Woltz et al., 1992), into nontoxic amino acids (Pate, 1973). Nitrates have long been recognized for their role in reducing seedling diseases caused by Rhizoctonia solani (Huber and Watson, 1974); however, contradictory results have been reported for Fusarium crown and root rot. Mihuta-Grimm et al. (1990) noted that nitrogen supplied as a 20N–20P–20K fertilizer had no effect on the growth of F. oxysporum f.sp. radicis-lycopersici in rockwool compared to non-fertilized treatments. Jarvis and Thorpe (1980) found no effect of nitrogen form (with total N applied unspecified) on disease or yield when adequate lime was provided to counteract potential pH effects. In fact, the differential effect of nitrogen form on pH is a significant mechanism for suppressing many soilborne pathogens (Huber and Watson, 1974). In contrast, Woltz et al. (1992) reported differences between nitrate and ammonium-N (each at 225 mg·L–1).', 0.9742597341537476]]
Context 1: [['Nitrogen is absorbed by plant roots in two forms: ammonium (NH4-N) and nitrate (NO3-N). Ammonium ions are produced in soils through the breakdown of organic matter (OM), manures, urea, or ammonium-containing fertilizers. Nitrate ions are the final form of nitrogen breakdown and reactions (excluding gaseous forms of nitrogen). They can also be supplied to the soil through fertilizers.', 0.8868284821510315]]
Context 2: [['The combination of ammonium (NH₄) and sodium chloride (NaCl) can provide a high degree of protection against crown rot disease. The data presented here for nitrogen sources do not differentiate between the effects of nitrate and ammonium but include the effects of calcium and sulfate. The effectiveness of fertilization practices in preventing diseases would likely be much greater under normal conditions of low inoculum potential, with no intentional wounding of roots, crowns, and hypocotyls. However, confirmation of these findings requires application in commercial practices.', 0.7501389384269714]]
Context 3: [['However, the effect of nitrogen on disease management can vary depending on the disease. Ammonium sulfate has been shown to be more suppressive of black root rot in strawberries than Ca(NO3)2. The objectives of these studies were to determine (i) the influence of N, P, and K levels, and (ii) the influence of N source and concentration on the severity of anthracnose crown rot.', 0.3156162202358246]]
Context 4: [['The organic fraction constitutes the majority of total nitrogen in soils (usually >95%). It is composed mainly of plant and microbial remains, varying in composition. The inorganic phase of soil nitrogen comprises ammonium (NH4), nitrate (NO3), and, to a lesser extent, nitrite (NO2) forms.', 0.21408361196517944]]
Context 5: [['Smiley, R.W. (1975). Forms of nitrogen and pH in the root zone and their importance to root infections. In G.W. Bruehl (Ed.), Biology and control of soil-borne plant pathogens (pp. 55–62). APS Press, St. Paul, MN.', 0.21170061826705933]]
Context 6: [['In water and wastewater, the forms of nitrogen (N) of greatest interest are nitrate nitrogen (NO3-N), nitrite nitrogen (NO2-N), ammonia (NH3), and organic forms of nitrogen. These nitrogen forms are interchangeable and are components of the nitrogen cycle. Ammonia is naturally present in surface water and wastewater, but its concentration is generally low in groundwater because it is adsorbed by soil particles and clay and is not readily leached from soils. Nitrate in groundwater poses a major environmental and public health concern, as nitrates are converted to nitrites in the intestines. Once absorbed into the bloodstream, nitrites prevent hemoglobin from transporting oxygen, though older children have an enzyme that can restore hemoglobin function. High levels of NO3-N in drinking water (greater than 10 ppm) are linked to health problems, such as methemoglobinemia. Thus, while water with high NO3-N levels should be avoided for human consumption, it can be suitable for irrigation as an additional source of nutrients.', 0.2049919217824936]]
Context 7: [['In the first study, the effects of nitrogen (N), phosphorus (P), and potassium (K) levels were evaluated using 16 treatments: eight N levels with either low or high P and K. Disease severity ratings and percent foliar N increased as N levels increased but were not influenced by the levels of P and K. In two other experiments, seven N sources were evaluated at three levels each. Plants receiving 160 ppm N had higher disease severity ratings than those receiving 0 or 40 ppm N. Among plants receiving 160 ppm N, those treated with calcium nitrate [Ca(NO3)2] had the least disease severity.', 0.20264162123203278]]

query: What are the key symptoms of crown rot caused by anthracnose in strawberries?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['From 2010 to 2016, we conducted surveys of anthracnose in strawberries in Miaoli County. More than 50% of diseased plants exhibited symptoms characteristic of anthracnose crown rot (ACR), as described by McInnes et al. (1992). ACR resulted in plant losses of up to 30-40% during the seedling stage and around 20% after transplanting. Initial symptoms in crown tissue included a marbled red and white appearance, which progressed to brown rot and eventual rapid wilting of the plant. Anthracnose symptoms also appeared on other parts of the plant, including leaves, petioles, runners, fruits, and roots. These symptoms manifested as circular black spots on leaves, withering and girdling on runners.', 0.99674391746521]]
Context 1: [['Species of the fungal plant pathogen Colletotrichum are responsible for strawberry (Fragaria × ananassa Duch.) anthracnose, one of the major diseases affecting this crop. Major species that cause strawberry anthracnose include C. acutatum J.H. Simmons, C. fragariae Brooks, and C. gloeosporioides (Penz.) Penz. & Sacc. Symptoms of the disease manifest in various phases. Infection of mother plants with anthracnose may result in the collapse of the entire plant due to crown rot. In the nursery, lesions form on stolons that eventually girdle the runners, leading to wilting and death of unrooted daughter plants distal to the lesion. Death of daughter plants in the nursery and in field transplants can also be caused by crown rot. Infected transplants are capable of spreading the disease from the nursery to the field, and entire crops can be destroyed by anthracnose in strawberry fruit production fields under conducive environmental conditions.', 0.9941658973693848]]
Context 2: [['Anthracnose is an important disease of strawberry caused by Colletotrichum spp., which affects foliage, runners, crowns, and fruits (Howard et al., 1992). Three primary fungal pathogens—C. acutatum sensu lato, C. gloeosporioides sensu lato, and C. fragariae—are known to cause anthracnose disease in strawberries (Freeman and Katan, 1997). The crown rot syndrome is characteristic of infections from C. gloeosporioides sensu lato and C. fragariae, while fruit rot is mainly attributed to C. acutatum sensu lato, leading to significant yield losses (Howard et al., 1992). Currently, numerous species are classified under what is now known as the C. acutatum complex, with six species—C. acutatum sensu stricto, C. fioriniae, C. godetiae, C. nymphaeae, C. salicis, and C. simmondsii—identified as associated with strawberry anthracnose worldwide (Damm et al., 2012). Among these, C. nymphaeae is the most prevalent pathogen causing strawberry anthracnose globally, including in Iran (Baroncelli et al., 2015; Karimi et al., 2017; Wang et al., 2019). Currently, no effective chemical control methods exist for managing strawberry anthracnose; available options are limited to preventive treatments applied before fruit production (Denoyes-Rothan et al., 1999). Additionally, concerns about the toxic effects of chemical fungicides on the environment and the development of resistance in fungal strains highlight the need for alternative control strategies. Consequently, utilizing resistant cultivars appears to be the most efficient and practical approach for suppressing anthracnose development. In light of recent anthracnose outbreaks in strawberry fields in the Kurdistan province of Iran (Karimi et al., 2017), and the necessity for appropriate strategies to address this issue, the aim of this study was to evaluate the resistance of several commercial strawberry cultivars to the anthracnose fruit rot caused by C. nymphaeae under in vivo and greenhouse conditions.', 0.9929847717285156]]
Context 3: [['From May to September 1995, a severe outbreak of strawberry anthracnose was observed in several strawberry-growing nurseries in Israel. Following transplantation to production fields during September and October, entire beds of strawberry plants collapsed. Typical anthracnose symptoms observed from November 1995 to June 1996 included crown rot, flower blight, and green and ripe fruit rot. This marked the first record of strawberry anthracnose in Israel. Furthermore, in at least four production fields in the same region, hundreds of plants developed symptoms of stunting and chlorosis, which are atypical of strawberry anthracnose. When these plants were uprooted, most of their roots were dark brown and decayed. Colletotrichum was readily isolated from these samples.', 0.9888068437576294]]
Context 4: [["The strawberry (Fragaria × ananassa), a small fruit crop, was introduced to Bangladesh in 1996 from Japan and the USA, gaining notable acceptance among both growers and consumers. However, as acreage expanded, anthracnose crown rot (ACR) has emerged as a significant challenge for strawberry producers. In March 2016, typical symptoms of ACR were observed in the 'Strawberry Festival' cultivar at a farmer's field in the Rajshahi district of Bangladesh. Symptoms were apparent in approximately 10% of the plants, manifesting as wilting of entire plants during the heat of the day and flagging of young leaves, resembling water deficiency.", 0.9864513874053955]]
Context 5: [["Anthracnose fungi can attack various parts of the strawberry plant, including crowns, petioles, leaves, fruit trusses, flowers, buds, and fruit. The fungi's ability to attack multiple plant parts, coupled with the involvement of several pathogen species, contributes to the complex nature of strawberry anthracnose. Brooks reported in 1931 that C. fragariae caused spotting and girdling of runners, and later indicated that it also caused spotting of petioles and crown rot in a summer nursery, leading to wilting and death of the plants. Researchers in Louisiana observed all these symptoms and noted that crown rot also occurred in the fruit production field.", 0.9862170219421387]]
Context 6: [['Colletotrichum species cause serious diseases in many fruit and vegetable crops worldwide, with C. fragariae, C. acutatum, and C. gloeosporioides being responsible for anthracnose diseases in strawberries (Smith and Black, 1990). Since the 1930s, anthracnose crown rot caused by C. fragariae and C. gloeosporioides has been a significant issue in strawberry nurseries and fruit production fields in the southeastern United States (Brooks, 1931). In 1986, the anthracnose fruit rot pathogen C. acutatum was first reported in U.S. strawberries (Smith and Black, 1986). The increase in anthracnose-related losses since the 1980s is likely due to the shift from matted-row culture to annual plasticulture systems and changes in cultivars. Anthracnose diseases are gaining importance, leading to major economic losses for strawberry growers globally. This report aims to summarize anthracnose-related research from the United States (excluding California and Florida) to enhance understanding of these diseases and their control.', 0.9861117601394653]]
Context 7: [['Anthracnose is a major disease of strawberry (Fragaria ananassa Duch.) in California nursery and fruit production (Gunnell and Gubler 1992; Smith 1998), an industry that represents 83% of fresh market fruit production in the United States and is estimated to have a value of over $1.8 billion annually (CDFA 2015-2016). All parts of the plant are susceptible to infection, resulting in significant yield loss from the various phases of the disease, including crown rot, root rot, flower blight, fruit rot (i.e., black spot), petiole lesions, and leaf spots (Daugovish et al. 2009; Howard et al. 1992; Smith 2008). Members of the fungal genus Colletotrichum are associated with strawberry anthracnose worldwide, with Colletotrichum gloeosporioides (Penz.) Penz. & Sacc. and occasionally C. fragariae A. N. Brooks most commonly causing crown rot and root rot, while C. acutatum J. H. Simmonds is most commonly responsible for foliar and fruit rot (Freeman and Rodriguez 1995; Howard et al. 1992; Smith and Black 1990). In California, however, C. acutatum is the most common causal agent for all above- and below-ground phases of the disease (Daugovish et al. 2009; Koike et al. 2008). More recently, C. gloeosporioides and C. acutatum have been considered to be species complexes (Damm et al. 2012; Weir et al. 2012).', 0.9851352572441101]]
Context 8: [['In November 2021, anthracnose symptoms were observed on strawberries (cv. Kingsberry) in Nonsan, Chungnam Province. Early symptoms of anthracnose fruit rot (AFR) include blackening of specific tissues of the strawberry. These symptoms progress with the enlargement of lesions, which hinder proper fruit development and lead to the formation of orange-colored spores within the lesions. Similar symptoms were noted on the petioles, with sunken and blackened tissues similar to those on the fruit, accompanied by the formation of an orange conidial mass.', 0.9667388796806335]]
Context 9: [['Anthracnose crown rot, to which all currently cultivated strawberry (Fragaria ananassa Duch.) varieties are susceptible, represents a major disease affecting over 30% of nurseries and the post-transplanting stage in Korea (Nam et al., 2009). The causal pathogen, Colletotrichum gloeosporioides, was first reported by Kim et al. (1992).', 0.9530370235443115]]

query: How do environmental conditions influence the expression of pathogenicity in Colletotrichum species?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['The genus Colletotrichum is considered one of the top ten important genera of fungal pathogens globally (Dean et al., 2012). Colletotrichum is an ancient fungus that has co-evolved with flowering plants. Plant microfossils of Protocolletotrichum preserved on angiosperm leaf cuticles suggest that the diverse pathogenic strategies of Colletotrichum spp. have been established since the Late Cretaceous period (Kar et al., 2004). Different complexes within the genus may have diverged between 4.8 and 32.2 million years ago (MYA) (Bhunjun et al., 2021). The emergence of agricultural cultivation and the intensive disturbance of natural environments have further driven the diversification of Colletotrichum species. These fungi have adapted to thousands of hosts and can be found as endophytes, pathogens, and saprobes (Freeman et al., 1998; Dean et al., 2012; Hirayama et al., 2018; da Silva et al., 2020; Jayawardena et al., 2020). Currently, a total of 257 Colletotrichum species grouped into 15 complexes and 13 additional singletons have been accepted in this genus.', 0.7754754424095154]]
Context 1: [['Many species belonging to the genus Colletotrichum are associated with plant diseases, commonly referred to as anthracnose. Colletotrichum spp. can affect a wide range of hosts, and these pathogens are characterized by global distribution. Virtually every cultivated botanical family is susceptible to one or more species of Colletotrichum, making it one of the most studied plant pathogenic fungi (Prusky et al., 2000; Latunde-Dada, 2001; Dean et al., 2012). Common hosts include many dicotyledonous plants such as strawberry, apple, citrus, and stone fruits, as well as major cereals such as maize and sorghum. Members of this genus can cause crop losses of up to 100% in many staple foods (Bailey and Jeger, 1992; Prusky et al., 2000; Talhinhas et al., 2005; Cannon et al., 2012).', 0.4915800988674164]]

Context 3: [['Strawberry (Fragaria × ananassa) is a major crop cultivated in China (Xie et al. 2010). The production of strawberries has rapidly expanded in recent years, positioning China as one of the world’s largest producers and exporters. As of 2013, strawberry cultivation covered 100.5 × 10^3 hectares, yielding 2.8 million tonnes (The Ministry of Agriculture of the People’s Republic of China 2014). However, with increased production, many fungal diseases have emerged as significant challenges, negatively impacting fruit yield and quality (Mass 1998, Smith 2008). Among these, anthracnose, caused by species of Colletotrichum, is one of the most critical diseases affecting strawberries.', 0.428571492433548]]
Context 4: [['Strawberries (Fragaria×ananassa Duch.) are a widely cultivated hybrid species within the Rosaceae family, renowned for their fruit. Various biotic and abiotic factors contribute to the decline in strawberry production globally. Context 6: [['Strawberry anthracnose can affect plants at any lifecycle stage, but plants are particularly susceptible at the seedling stage and immediately after planting (Wang et al. 2008). The disease primarily affects strawberry roots, petioles, and stolons, but can also infect flowers and fruit, leading to severe outbreaks (Mertely and Legard 2004). Symptoms include irregular ulcer-like lesions, reddish-brown stolons during initial stolon development, black spindle-shaped lesions on leaves and petioles, wilting, and dead roots (Debode et al. 2009; Freeman and Katan 1997). In Zhejiang, nearly 50% of seedling deaths and over 40% of production losses in nurseries are attributed to this disease (Xie et al. 2010). If environmental conditions are favorable, anthracnose can reduce strawberry yield by up to 80%. Transplants are considered the main source of primary inoculum, but the complete epidemiology of Colletotrichum spp. on strawberries in China remains unclear.', 0.28653499484062195]]

query: Why is it bad if fruit diseases happen before or after harvesting?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Two distinct types of diseases occur: those affecting developing fruit in the field (preharvest) and those damaging mature fruit during storage (postharvest). The ability to cause latent or quiescent infections has categorized Colletotrichum among the most important postharvest pathogens. Species of the pathogen predominantly appear on aboveground plant tissues; however, belowground organs, such as roots and tubers, may also be affected.', 0.8804330825805664]]
Context 1: [['On certain fruits, such as apple and blueberry (Vaccinium spp.), members of the C. acutatum species complex cause both pre-harvest and post-harvest diseases (Milholland, 1995; Jones et al., 1996; Shi et al., 1996). On these plants, asymptomatic, quiescent infections occur on unripe fruit, developing into necrotic lesions as the fruit ripens (Alkan et al., 2015). There are many other examples of post-harvest decay in fruits like peaches (Prunus persica), almonds (Prunus dulcis), avocado (Persea americana), mango (Mangifera indica), papaya (Carica papaya), and guava (Psidium guajava) that stem from quiescent infections that began in the field (Agostini et al., 1992; Freeman and Shabi, 1996; Smith, 1998; Afanador-Kafuri et al., 2003).', 0.873502254486084]]
Context 2: [['Coates, L.M.; Johnson, G.I.; Dale, M. Postharvest pathology of fruit and vegetables. In Plant Pathogens and Plant Diseases; Brown, J., Ogle, H., Eds.; Rockvale Publications: Burlington, MA, USA, 1997; pp. 533–547.', 0.34348130226135254]]
Context 3: [['Snowdon AL (1991). A Colour Atlas of Post-Harvest Diseases and Disorders of Fruit and Vegetables. Volume 2. Vegetables. Wolfe Scientific.', 0.2874987721443176]]

Context 5: [['The primary means to reduce the buildup of anthracnose fruit rot in the field is to harvest fruit frequently and remove all rotten fruit from the field. Following severe infections early in the fruiting season, all infected fruit should be stripped from the plants and removed from the field. Infected areas of a field should be harvested last in the day, or workers should wash up and change into clean clothes when they must enter uninfected areas of the field after harvesting areas where fruit rot is present.', 0.21532951295375824]]
Context 6: [['The plot calculations were conducted according to Shaner and Finney (1977). query: Is it possible to categorize Glomerella cingulata var. minor based solely on mycelial characteristics, and what challenges might arise in this classification?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [["Glomerella cingulata var. minor, categorized as C. gloeosporioides var. minor, is a fast-growing species with distinctly coarser mycelium compared to G. cingulata var. cingulata. Field isolations primarily yield conidial or sterile types. The aerial mycelium in these types is cottony or woolly, typically abundant and well elevated from the medium's surface, contrasting with the previously described variety. The coloration is usually white or varying shades of grey, while the substrate appears white to cream or varying densities of greyish olive or olive from below. Occasionally, forms with less abundant and elevated aerial mycelium emerge, which can be challenging to differentiate from the more elevated cultural types of C. gloeosporioides, unless conidia are present (as illustrated in Figures 2 and 3).", 0.9894044399261475]]
Context 1: [['Glomerella cingulata var. minor (stat. conid.) / Colletotrichum gloeosporioides var.: This specialized form has a broader host range and is commonly found in Queensland. It significantly impacts ripe fruit rot in papaw, avocado, mango, and apple. Notably quick-growing, it produces abundant aerial mycelium in culture, with characteristic normal spore sizes. However, some collections may require cultural examination for accurate identification, especially when spore sizes approach the lower range of typical C. gloeosporioides measurements.', 0.958723247051239]]
Context 2: [["Matthews (1953, 1955a, 1955b) investigated leaf spots occurring on a number of garden plants and weeds in the Brisbane district. In each case, the associated organism was isolated, and its cultural and morphological characteristics were described, followed by cross-inoculations. The causal organism was considered to be Glomerella cingulata (Stonem.) Spauld. & Schrenk, though no attempts were made to distinguish between varieties. However, based on Matthews' papers, separation into G. cingulata and G. cingulata var. minor can be made with reasonable accuracy. Isolates from azalea (Rhododendron indicum Sweet), Hoya australis R.Br. and H. carnosa R.Br., and a few from stock (Matthiola incana (L.) R.Br.) were likely G. cingulata. Context 3: [['Glomerella cingulata (stat. conid.) / Colletotrichum gloeosporioides: This species has a restricted host range as a fruit pathogen in Queensland, primarily causing ripe fruit rot in papaw and skin blemishes in passion-fruit hybrids. Context 4: [['Glomerella cingulata var. minor was described from Ficus in Germany, but Wollenweber & Hochapfel (1949) noted that the same fungus also occurred on other hosts in Europe, Africa, and America, including Malus and Coffea. Wollenweber & Hochapfel (1949) used the name Gloeosporium elasticae Cooke & Massee for the conidial state of G. cingulata var. minor, with type specimens for both names coming from Ficus.', 0.6124556660652161]]
Context 5: [['Simmonds (1965) considered C. gloeosporioides var. minus to be the conidial state of Glomerella cingulata var. minor Wollenw. Wollenweber & Hochapfel (1949) used the name Gloeosporium elasticae Cooke & Massee for the conidial state of G. cingulata var. minor, with the type specimens for both names originating from Ficus. Simmonds (1965) noted the impossibility of transferring G. elasticae to Colletotrichum because Colletotrichum elasticae had already been published for a different fungus. query: What are the key outcomes of phylogenetic analysis in studying Colletotrichum species?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['The shift towards multi-gene phylogenetic analysis has significantly changed the classification and species concepts within the Colletotrichum genus (Cannon et al. 2012, Damm et al. 2012a, b, 2013, 2014, Weir et al. 2012). Many Colletotrichum species are classified as latent plant pathogens, endophytes, epiphytes, or saprobes, and may adopt a pathogenic lifestyle when host plants are stressed (Damm et al. 2009, Cannon et al. 2012). Systematic studies of nearly all recognized species have identified several complexes, revealing that some Colletotrichum species historically considered as causal agents of significant plant diseases are actually different species. For example, C. alienum is now recognized as a key species in Proteaceae cultivation (Liu et al. 2013), while C. acutatum s.lat. was found in Mediterranean countries causing diseases in various hosts, such as Fragaria × ananassa (Garrido et al. 2008), Arbutus unedo (Polizzi et al. 2011), and Olea europaea (Talhinhas et al. 2011). Given the economic losses in citrus orchards, understanding these species interactions is crucial.', 0.9925456643104553]]
Context 1: [['The identification of Colletotrichum species has long been challenging due to limited morphological characteristics. Single-gene phylogenetic analyses have also proven unsuccessful in clearly delineating species, partly due to the high number of erroneous names in GenBank. This paper reviews the taxonomic problems associated with Colletotrichum and the difficulties in identifying taxa at the species level. We advocate for epitypification and the use of multi-locus phylogenetic methods to better delimit species and understand the genus.', 0.9594267010688782]]
Context 2: [['Discussion: Recent phylogenetic studies of the genus Colletotrichum have revealed clustering in 11 major clades, including significant species complexes such as C. acutatum, C. boninense, C. gloeosporioides, and C. truncatum. Context 5: [['Colletotrichum species are categorized into phylogenetic clades (also referred to as species complexes) based on multilocus molecular analysis. Species within a clade are closely related and share similar temperature requirements (Cannon et al., 2012; Vieira et al., 2020; Talhinhas and Baroncelli, 2021; Salotti et al., 2022). A recent systematic review identified 15 major clades of the genus, along with several smaller clusters and isolated species (Talhinhas and Baroncelli, 2021). Detailed descriptions of these major phylogenetic clades and the species within them have been provided by multiple studies (Cannon et al., 2012; Vieira et al., 2020; Talhinhas and Baroncelli, 2021; Damm et al., 2009, 2012, 2013, 2014; Weir et al., 2012).', 0.9508584141731262]]
Context 6: [['In the past, common identification systems for Colletotrichum included traditional morphological taxonomy, molecular classification based on ITS sequences, and the presence of secondary metabolites, among other traits. However, these methods alone or in combination were insufficient to fully resolve the species identity of individual Colletotrichum isolates. Additional characteristics, including other aspects of morphology and multi-gene phylogenetic analyses, are necessary for accurate identification of Colletotrichum species.', 0.8989885449409485]]

query: How does Colletotrichum interact with other pathogens?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Many species belonging to the genus Colletotrichum are associated with plant diseases, commonly referred to as anthracnose. Colletotrichum spp. can affect a wide range of hosts, and these pathogens are characterized by global distribution. Virtually every cultivated botanical family is susceptible to one or more species of Colletotrichum, making it one of the most studied plant pathogenic fungi (Prusky et al., 2000; Latunde-Dada, 2001; Dean et al., 2012). Common hosts include many dicotyledonous plants such as strawberry, apple, citrus, and stone fruits, as well as major cereals such as maize and sorghum. Members of this genus can cause crop losses of up to 100% in many staple foods (Bailey and Jeger, 1992; Prusky et al., 2000; Talhinhas et al., 2005; Cannon et al., 2012).', 0.9661749005317688]]
Context 1: [['Waller, J.M.; Bridge, P.D. "Recent advances in understanding Colletotrichum diseases of some tropical perennial crops." In Colletotrichum: Host Specificity, Pathology, and Host-Pathogen Interaction, Eds. Prusky, D., Freeman, S., Dickman, M.B.; APS Press: St. Paul, MN, USA, 2000; pp. 337–345.', 0.9660589694976807]]
Context 2: [['The genus Colletotrichum is considered one of the top ten important genera of fungal pathogens globally (Dean et al., 2012). Colletotrichum is an ancient fungus that has co-evolved with flowering plants. Plant microfossils of Protocolletotrichum preserved on angiosperm leaf cuticles suggest that the diverse pathogenic strategies of Colletotrichum spp. have been established since the Late Cretaceous period (Kar et al., 2004). Different complexes within the genus may have diverged between 4.8 and 32.2 million years ago (MYA) (Bhunjun et al., 2021). The emergence of agricultural cultivation and the intensive disturbance of natural environments have further driven the diversification of Colletotrichum species. These fungi have adapted to thousands of hosts and can be found as endophytes, pathogens, and saprobes (Freeman et al., 1998; Dean et al., 2012; Hirayama et al., 2018; da Silva et al., 2020; Jayawardena et al., 2020). Currently, a total of 257 Colletotrichum species grouped into 15 complexes and 13 additional singletons have been accepted in this genus.', 0.9494002461433411]]
Context 3: [['Perfect et al. (1999) described Colletotrichum as a model genus for studies on pathology and fungal-plant interactions.', 0.7116696238517761]]
Context 4: [['The name Colletotrichum was first introduced by Tode (1790) under the genus Vermicularia. The genus Colletotrichum itself was established by Corda (1831) and is now recognized as comprising “coelomycetes” with a Glomerella teleomorph stage (Sutton, 1992; Shenoy et al., 2007a; Hyde et al., 2009). This genus includes species with endophytic, epiphytic, saprobic, and phytopathogenic lifestyles (Kumar and Hyde, 2004; Photita et al., 2001a,b).', 0.5681460499763489]]
Context 5: [['Citation: Cai, L., Hyde, K.D., Taylor, P.W.J., Weir, B.S., Waller, J., Abang, M.M., Zhang, J.Z., Yang, Y.L., Phoulivong, S., Liu, Z.Y., Prihastuti, H., Shivas, R.G., McKenzie, E.H.C., Johnston, P.R. Context 6: [['These contributions reflect a diverse range of studies addressing the ecology and interactions of Colletotrichum, underscoring its significance in plant pathology.', 0.4529113173484802]]

query: How does the infection rate of C. fioriniae compare to that of C. gloeosporioides at 30 dpi on pear fruits?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Pathogenicity was also assessed on detached pear fruits of P. bretschneideri cv. Huangguan. Under unwounded conditions, all isolates from the fruits were pathogenic at 30 dpi, with infection rates ranging from 2/6 for C. fioriniae (PAFQ19) to 5/6 for C. gloeosporioides (PAFQ61). These isolates began to induce small brown or dark brown lesions at different time points post-inoculation: 28–30 dpi for C. aenigma, C. conoides, and C. fioriniae; 18–22 dpi for C. gloeosporioides; and 6–8 dpi for C. siamense. Over time, the small lesions expanded into larger brown or dark brown lesions and formed concentric rings of acervuli at 4–6 dpi, which exuded an orange conidium mass (Fig. 21b1, b4–b6, b8).', 0.9979540109634399]]
Context 1: [['For the isolates from pear leaves, only C. fructicola isolates (PAFQ31 and PAFQ32) were pathogenic to the inoculated fruits, with infection rates of 6/6 for isolate PAFQ31 and 5/6 for isolate PAFQ32 (Table 6). Notably, C. fructicola isolates PAFQ31 and PAFQ32 induced black spots (Fig. 21b2) and fruit rot symptoms (Fig. 21b3) at 30 dpi, similar to those observed on the leaves. This study revealed 12 species belonging to five Colletotrichum species complexes, including C. aenigma, C. conoides, C. fructicola, C. gloeosporioides, C. siamense, and C. wuxiense, along with other species, confirming the involvement of C. conoides, C. siamense, C. wuxiense, C. citricola, C. karstii, and C. plurivorum in pear anthracnose for the first time. Importantly, this research differentiated two new species responsible for pear anthracnose: C. jinshuiense and C. pyrifoliae.', 0.9856141209602356]]
Context 2: [['C. gloeosporioides, C. karstii, C. plurivorum, C. siamense, C. wuxiense, and two novel species, described here as C. jinshuiense and C. pyrifoliae, were identified. Among these, C. fructicola was the most dominant, occurring on P. pyrifolia and P. bretschneideri in all surveyed provinces except Shandong, where C. siamense was dominant. In contrast, only C. siamense and C. fioriniae were isolated from P. communis, with C. siamense being the more prevalent species. Pathogenicity tests conducted on pear leaves and fruits confirmed a broad diversity in pathogenicity and aggressiveness among the species and isolates. Notably, C. citricola, C. jinshuiense, C. pyrifoliae, and C. conoides showed organ-specific pathogenicity, affecting either leaves or fruits. This study also represents the first report of C. citricola, C. conoides, C. karstii, C. plurivorum, C. siamense, and C. wuxiense causing anthracnose on pear.', 0.915444016456604]]
Context 3: [['Differences in symptom development were observed among isolates from pear, particularly those from P. pyrifolia and P. bretschneideri. Most C. gloeosporioides isolates from pear had longer conidia (15.5–32 μm) compared to those from tea (11–15.5 μm) and citrus (11.3–14.7 μm). Geographical preference was also noted, as C. siamense was more frequently isolated in certain areas, particularly Shandong province, whereas C. aenigma and C. fioriniae were mainly found in Hubei province. Furthermore, C. jinshuiense, C. pyrifoliae, C. wuxiense, C. plurivorum, C. conoides, and C. citricola exhibited low prevalence and restricted distribution.', 0.7635084986686707]]
Context 4: [['Notes: Although C. gloeosporioides has been identified as responsible for pear anthracnose in China, these identifications were chiefly based on morphology and/or ITS sequence data (Wu et al. 2010, Liu et al. 2013b). In this study, 20 isolates of C. gloeosporioides, isolated from fruits and leaves of pear, were identified based on multi-loci phylogenetic analyses and confirmed as the cause of pear anthracnose following Koch’s postulates.', 0.469764769077301]]
Context 5: [['C. gloeosporioides isolates were very similar, except they formed the Glomerella cingulata ascigerous state in culture, and their conidia were usually rounded at both ends. Both C. fragariae and C. gloeosporioides produced dark black setae, which are visible with a hand lens, in acervuli in culture and on petiole, stolon, and fruit lesions. In contrast, C. acutatum isolates produced fusiform conidia that were tapered at both ends, developed colonies in white, pink, orange, rose, or beige, and did not form setae or the ascigerous state in culture. The growth rate of C. acutatum in culture was slower than that of the other two species at all tested temperatures, with the most significant difference noted at 32°C.', 0.36473461985588074]]
Context 6: [['Our study demonstrated that C. gloeosporioides isolates from almond, apple, avocado, and mango, as well as C. acutatum isolates from almond, anemone, apple, and peach, were able to infect detached fruits of other hosts, including two varieties of apple, avocado, almond, mango, and nectarine. These results indicated cross-infection potential between two species: C. gloeosporioides (including representatives of distinct subpopulations from almond, apple, avocado, and mango) and C. acutatum (from apple and peach), across a variety of fruit species. However, these experiments were conducted under extreme conditions typical of artificial inoculations, whereas isolations from naturally infected fruit provided no evidence of cross-infection occurring under field conditions.', 0.31255632638931274]]
Context 7: [['Setae were observed in isolates PAFQ78 and PAFQ74 on PDA; these setae were dark brown to black, opaque, with an acute tip and a cylindrical base, measuring 67–95 μm in length. C. citricola and C. conoides were also noted in this study.', 0.299666166305542]]
Context 8: [['Isolation from leaves and fruits revealed that C. aenigma, C. fructicola, C. gloeosporioides, C. fioriniae, and C. siamense were found in both leaves and fruits. In contrast, C. citricola, C. jinshuiense, C. karstii, C. plurivorum, and C. pyrifoliae were isolated only from leaves, while C. conoides was isolated exclusively from fruits.', 0.28292879462242126]]
Context 9: [['For C. citricola (isolate PAFQ13), small lesions quickly expanded into large dark brown to black lesions, with lesion lengths varying among the species (Fig. 20c1–c13). These lesions formed concentric rings of acervuli on the leaf tissues and exuded an orange conidia mass (6–10 dpi) at 25 °C under 99% relative humidity. It is worth mentioning that C. fructicola isolate PAFQ31, isolated from a leaf showing tip scorch (TS) symptoms in the field, induced similar symptoms around the brown necrotic leaf (BnL) on inoculated leaves (Fig. 20c2). No lesions were induced in the control fruits inoculated with sterile water.', 0.23784522712230682]]

query: How does the use of nitrification inhibitors help reduce fungal disease severity?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['There is a striking positive correlation between the effect of various cultural practices on nitrification and the severity of take-all. The use of a nitrification inhibitor with ammonium, along with conditions and crop sequences that inhibit nitrification, also reduces take-all (21, 22), and vice versa. However, some practices, such as planting oats before wheat in rotation, have little apparent effect on nitrification but provide some of the most effective control of take-all (3.12, 22). This suggests that the form of nitrogen, as influenced by the rate of nitrification, may act indirectly or in conjunction with other factors to influence the severity of take-all.', 0.9845172762870789]]
Context 1: [['Additional keywords: phosphonate fungicides, phosphorous acid.', 0.2304350882768631]]
Context 2: [['The form of nitrogen significantly influenced both the severity of Fusarium crown and root rot and the growth of tomato seedlings in a soilless rockwool system (Fig. 1). Increasing concentrations of nitrate-N reduced disease severity and improved plant growth compared to ammonium forms. Both ammonium sulfate and ammonium chloride produced similar responses, indicating that NH4+ was the harmful component (Fig. 1). Ammonium nitrate has been reported to either have no effect on Fusarium diseases or to increase disease severity, similar to ammonium-N (Jones et al., 1989; Schneider, 1985). While this was generally true for Fusarium crown and root rot, testing a range of concentrations revealed that at low concentrations (10 to 100 mg·L–1 N), ammonium nitrate reduced disease similarly to nitrate-N (Figs. 1D, 2D). However, the negative influence of the NH4+ ion became apparent at concentrations above 125 mg·L–1 N (Figs. 1D, 2D). At higher concentrations, seedlings might have lacked sufficient available carbohydrates to convert the excess ammonium, which is toxic for tomato seedlings (Woltz et al., 1992), into nontoxic amino acids (Pate, 1973). Nitrates have long been recognized for their role in reducing seedling diseases caused by Rhizoctonia solani (Huber and Watson, 1974); however, contradictory results have been reported for Fusarium crown and root rot. Mihuta-Grimm et al. (1990) noted that nitrogen supplied as a 20N–20P–20K fertilizer had no effect on the growth of F. oxysporum f.sp. radicis-lycopersici in rockwool compared to non-fertilized treatments. Jarvis and Thorpe (1980) found no effect of nitrogen form (with total N applied unspecified) on disease or yield when adequate lime was provided to counteract potential pH effects. In fact, the differential effect of nitrogen form on pH is a significant mechanism for suppressing many soilborne pathogens (Huber and Watson, 1974). In contrast, Woltz et al. (1992) reported differences between nitrate and ammonium-N (each at 225 mg·L–1).', 0.19181816279888153]]

query: What kind of plants does Colletotrichum infect?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Many species belonging to the genus Colletotrichum are associated with plant diseases, commonly referred to as anthracnose. Colletotrichum spp. can affect a wide range of hosts, and these pathogens are characterized by global distribution. Virtually every cultivated botanical family is susceptible to one or more species of Colletotrichum, making it one of the most studied plant pathogenic fungi (Prusky et al., 2000; Latunde-Dada, 2001; Dean et al., 2012). Common hosts include many dicotyledonous plants such as strawberry, apple, citrus, and stone fruits, as well as major cereals such as maize and sorghum. Members of this genus can cause crop losses of up to 100% in many staple foods (Bailey and Jeger, 1992; Prusky et al., 2000; Talhinhas et al., 2005; Cannon et al., 2012).', 0.9910339713096619]]
Context 1: [['The genus Colletotrichum is considered one of the top ten important genera of fungal pathogens globally (Dean et al., 2012). Colletotrichum is an ancient fungus that has co-evolved with flowering plants. Plant microfossils of Protocolletotrichum preserved on angiosperm leaf cuticles suggest that the diverse pathogenic strategies of Colletotrichum spp. have been established since the Late Cretaceous period (Kar et al., 2004). Different complexes within the genus may have diverged between 4.8 and 32.2 million years ago (MYA) (Bhunjun et al., 2021). The emergence of agricultural cultivation and the intensive disturbance of natural environments have further driven the diversification of Colletotrichum species. These fungi have adapted to thousands of hosts and can be found as endophytes, pathogens, and saprobes (Freeman et al., 1998; Dean et al., 2012; Hirayama et al., 2018; da Silva et al., 2020; Jayawardena et al., 2020). Currently, a total of 257 Colletotrichum species grouped into 15 complexes and 13 additional singletons have been accepted in this genus.', 0.9591434001922607]]
Context 2: [['Various studies highlight the significance of Colletotrichum species in agriculture. Crouch et al. (2009) discussed anthracnose disease caused by the novel species Colletotrichum navitas, while Damm et al. (2013) addressed the Colletotrichum orbiculare species complex, which affects field crops and weeds. Other works by Damm et al. Context 4: [['The name Colletotrichum was first introduced by Tode (1790) under the genus Vermicularia. Context 2: [['Anthracnose is an important disease of strawberry caused by Colletotrichum spp., which affects foliage, runners, crowns, and fruits (Howard et al., 1992). Three primary fungal pathogens—C. acutatum sensu lato, C. gloeosporioides sensu lato, and C. fragariae—are known to cause anthracnose disease in strawberries (Freeman and Katan, 1997). The crown rot syndrome is characteristic of infections from C. gloeosporioides sensu lato and C. fragariae, while fruit rot is mainly attributed to C. acutatum sensu lato, leading to significant yield losses (Howard et al., 1992). Currently, numerous species are classified under what is now known as the C. acutatum complex, with six species—C. acutatum sensu stricto, C. fioriniae, C. godetiae, C. nymphaeae, C. salicis, and C. simmondsii—identified as associated with strawberry anthracnose worldwide (Damm et al., 2012). Among these, C. nymphaeae is the most prevalent pathogen causing strawberry anthracnose globally, including in Iran (Baroncelli et al., 2015; Karimi et al., 2017; Wang et al., 2019). Currently, no effective chemical control methods exist for managing strawberry anthracnose; available options are limited to preventive treatments applied before fruit production (Denoyes-Rothan et al., 1999). Additionally, concerns about the toxic effects of chemical fungicides on the environment and the development of resistance in fungal strains highlight the need for alternative control strategies. Consequently, utilizing resistant cultivars appears to be the most efficient and practical approach for suppressing anthracnose development. In light of recent anthracnose outbreaks in strawberry fields in the Kurdistan province of Iran (Karimi et al., 2017), and the necessity for appropriate strategies to address this issue, the aim of this study was to evaluate the resistance of several commercial strawberry cultivars to the anthracnose fruit rot caused by C. nymphaeae under in vivo and greenhouse conditions.', 0.566711962223053]]

query: Could the method of comparative genomics outlined in the study be effective for distinguishing between other fungal pathogens in strawberries?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Using a comparative genomics strategy, we successfully developed a single marker to differentiate among three common pathogens of strawberry: C. fructicola, C. siamense, and C. aenigma. This marker flanks a short repeat that is expanded in C. fructicola compared to C. siamense and C. aenigma. It is likely that this sequence was acquired or expanded in C. fructicola because it was absent in closely related C. kahawae strains. The comparative genomics method employed in this study is considered a practical strategy that can be further used to develop markers for other distinguishing traits or species differences.', 0.9974121451377869]]
Context 1: [['Molecular tools have been successfully utilized to differentiate between the species of Colletotrichum responsible for strawberry anthracnose. Isolates of C. fragariae, C. acutatum, and C. gloeosporioides infecting strawberries were distinctly different in nuclear and A+T-rich DNA analyses, as well as in amplified fragment length polymorphism (AFLP) methods. Similarly, sequencing and restriction digest analyses of PCR-amplified ribosomal DNA (rDNA) have been used to differentiate between C. acutatum and other Colletotrichum species from strawberries. In populations of C. acutatum and C. fragariae from strawberries, little genomic variation was observed within each species using various molecular methods. In contrast, high diversity was observed in populations of C. gloeosporioides from strawberries, which possess the perfect stage. However, C. acutatum isolated from strawberries in Europe were distinct from American strawberry isolates. Likewise, isolates of C. acutatum from other hosts, such as peach and pecan, were separate from the strawberry pathogen, suggesting that C. acutatum is not a uniform group.', 0.9235154986381531]]
Context 2: [['The first formal report of strawberry anthracnose in China was made by Hu (1990) at the fifth annual conference of the Chinese Society of Plant Pathology, which took place in Jiangsu Province. In Shanghai, C. fragariae and C. acutatum were identified as strawberry pathogens (Shao 1992; Ye et al. 1997). Subsequently, fruit rot caused by C. acutatum was reported in Shanghai based on morphological identification (Dai et al. 2006). Molecular analysis using ITS sequences facilitated the identification of 16 C. gloeosporioides isolates and one C. acutatum isolate collected from 1996 to 2006 in Shanghai (Ren et al. 2008). Based on ITS sequences and restriction enzyme digestion, 31 Colletotrichum isolates collected from diseased strawberries between 2006 and 2007 in Shanghai and Zhejiang were identified as C. acutatum, C. gloeosporioides, and C. fragariae (Xie et al. 2010). Following this, C. gloeosporioides and C. fragariae were again reported as pathogens affecting strawberries in Zhejiang (Ren et al. 2011). A study collected 114 fungal isolates from the C. gloeosporioides complex from diseased strawberries during 2010 to 2013 in Zhejiang Province, though they were not distinguished at the species level (Lin et al. 2016).', 0.4634900689125061]]
Context 3: [['Martínez-Culebras PV, Querol A, Suárez-Fernández MB, García-López MD, Rojas EI, Rehner SA, Samuels GJ, Van Bael SA, Herre EA, Cannon P, et al. J Phytopathol. 2003; 151: 135–143. https://doi.org/10.1046/j.1439-0434.2003.00694.x.', 0.4619394540786743]]

Context 7: [['Bonde, M. R., Peterson, G. L., and Maas, J. L. (1991). Isozyme comparisons for identification of Colletotrichum species pathogenic to strawberry. Phytopathology, 81, 1523-1528.', 0.3642694056034088]]
