query: What are the typical symptoms of anthracnose on strawberry fruit?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['In November 2021, anthracnose symptoms were observed on strawberries (cv. Kingsberry) in Nonsan, Chungnam Province. Early symptoms of anthracnose fruit rot (AFR) include blackening of specific tissues of the strawberry. These symptoms progress with the enlargement of lesions, which hinder proper fruit development and lead to the formation of orange-colored spores within the lesions. Similar symptoms were noted on the petioles, with sunken and blackened tissues similar to those on the fruit, accompanied by the formation of an orange conidial mass.', 0.9950562715530396]]
Context 1: [['From May to September 1995, a severe outbreak of strawberry anthracnose was observed in several strawberry-growing nurseries in Israel. Following transplantation to production fields during September and October, entire beds of strawberry plants collapsed. Typical anthracnose symptoms observed from November 1995 to June 1996 included crown rot, flower blight, and green and ripe fruit rot. This marked the first record of strawberry anthracnose in Israel. Furthermore, in at least four production fields in the same region, hundreds of plants developed symptoms of stunting and chlorosis, which are atypical of strawberry anthracnose. When these plants were uprooted, most of their roots were dark brown and decayed. Colletotrichum was readily isolated from these samples.', 0.9941231608390808]]
Context 2: [['Numerous reports indicate that strawberry anthracnose pathogens may originate from weed species. For instance, C. fragariae was found attacking the weed Cassia obtusifolia L. (sicklepod, coffeweed) in Florida, causing typical disease symptoms. Inoculation of strawberry with the Cassia isolates resulted in typical anthracnose symptoms, while isolates from strawberry were equally virulent on Cassia. Similarly, inoculation of Duchesnea indica (Andr.) Focke (wild strawberry), F. virginiana Duch. (Virginia wild strawberry), and Potentilla canadensis L. with C. fragariae induced anthracnose disease on these hosts, suggesting that strawberry anthracnose pathogens have a broad host range.', 0.9924523234367371]]
Context 3: [["Anthracnose fungi can attack various parts of the strawberry plant, including crowns, petioles, leaves, fruit trusses, flowers, buds, and fruit. The fungi's ability to attack multiple plant parts, coupled with the involvement of several pathogen species, contributes to the complex nature of strawberry anthracnose. Brooks reported in 1931 that C. fragariae caused spotting and girdling of runners, and later indicated that it also caused spotting of petioles and crown rot in a summer nursery, leading to wilting and death of the plants. Researchers in Louisiana observed all these symptoms and noted that crown rot also occurred in the fruit production field.", 0.9804866909980774]]
Context 4: [['Anthracnose is an important disease of strawberry caused by Colletotrichum spp., which affects foliage, runners, crowns, and fruits (Howard et al., 1992). Three primary fungal pathogens—C. acutatum sensu lato, C. gloeosporioides sensu lato, and C. fragariae—are known to cause anthracnose disease in strawberries (Freeman and Katan, 1997). The crown rot syndrome is characteristic of infections from C. gloeosporioides sensu lato and C. fragariae, while fruit rot is mainly attributed to C. acutatum sensu lato, leading to significant yield losses (Howard et al., 1992). Currently, numerous species are classified under what is now known as the C. acutatum complex, with six species—C. acutatum sensu stricto, C. fioriniae, C. godetiae, C. nymphaeae, C. salicis, and C. simmondsii—identified as associated with strawberry anthracnose worldwide (Damm et al., 2012). Among these, C. nymphaeae is the most prevalent pathogen causing strawberry anthracnose globally, including in Iran (Baroncelli et al., 2015; Karimi et al., 2017; Wang et al., 2019). Currently, no effective chemical control methods exist for managing strawberry anthracnose; available options are limited to preventive treatments applied before fruit production (Denoyes-Rothan et al., 1999). Additionally, concerns about the toxic effects of chemical fungicides on the environment and the development of resistance in fungal strains highlight the need for alternative control strategies. Consequently, utilizing resistant cultivars appears to be the most efficient and practical approach for suppressing anthracnose development. In light of recent anthracnose outbreaks in strawberry fields in the Kurdistan province of Iran (Karimi et al., 2017), and the necessity for appropriate strategies to address this issue, the aim of this study was to evaluate the resistance of several commercial strawberry cultivars to the anthracnose fruit rot caused by C. nymphaeae under in vivo and greenhouse conditions.', 0.9662630558013916]]
Context 5: [['Smith, B. J. 1998. Anthracnose leaf spot, irregular spot, anthracnose fruit rot (black spot), and anthracnose crown rot. In: Compendium of Strawberry Diseases. J. L. Mass, ed. American Phytopathological Society, St. Paul, MN. Pages 24-25, 31-33, and 46-48.', 0.91010981798172]]
Context 6: [['The term "anthracnose" was first used to describe a new disease of strawberries caused by Colletotrichum fragariae Brooks. "Strawberry anthracnose" continues to be used as a general term to identify all diseases of strawberries caused by species of Colletotrichum. Strawberry anthracnose diseases have been reported to be caused by C. acutatum J.H. Simmonds, C. gloeosporioides (Penz.) Penz. & Sacc. in Penz. (the teleomorph of Cromereilla cingulata (Stoneman) Spauld. & H. Schrenk), and C. dematium (Pers.) Grove. The latter species only occasionally causes strawberry fruit rots and will not be discussed here.', 0.9052566885948181]]
Context 7: [['Howard CM, Albregts EE. Anthracnose. In: Compendium of Strawberry Diseases. American Phytopathological Society: Paul St, ed. Maas JL, USA; 1984. pp. 85-87.', 0.7064051628112793]]
Context 8: [['Brooks AN (1931). Anthracnose of strawberry caused by Colletotrichum fragariae n. sp. Phytopathology 21: 739–744.', 0.6613884568214417]]
Context 9: [['Brooks, A.N. 1931. Anthracnose of strawberry caused by Colletotrichum fragariae, n. sp. Phytopathology 21:739–744.', 0.6447129845619202]]

query: What are the common symptoms of Colletotrichum infection on strawberry leaves?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Colletotrichum spp. infect many other hosts, so it is sometimes assumed that the primary infection in strawberry fields comes from infected plants of these hosts growing nearby. To test the hypothesis that Colletotrichum spp. may move from other fruit or vegetable crops to strawberries, Smith (2002) wound-inoculated the leaves and stems of strawberry, blueberry, blackberry, muscadine grape, tomato, and pepper with 37 Colletotrichum isolates, representing nine species collected from 12 hosts. Isolates of Colletotrichum fragariae were the most aggressive, causing lesions at an average of 38% of inoculation sites on all hosts except pepper. The percentage of infection for the other eight Colletotrichum species ranged from 5% to 25%. Strawberry was the most susceptible host, with 58% of petiole and 14% of leaf infections resulting in lesion development from all isolates. Conversely, pepper was the most resistant host, showing no symptom development on leaves or stems following inoculation with any isolate. These results suggest that primary anthracnose infections in strawberry production fields most often arise from infected strawberry transplants and only rarely from anthracnose-infected fruit or vegetable crops adjacent to the strawberry fields. However, C. acutatum and C. gloeosporioides have both been shown to move from infected host plants near the fields to strawberry production fields (Freeman et al., 2000b).', 0.9900830984115601]]
Context 1: [['Species of the fungal plant pathogen Colletotrichum are responsible for strawberry (Fragaria × ananassa Duch.) anthracnose, one of the major diseases affecting this crop. Major species that cause strawberry anthracnose include C. acutatum J.H. Simmons, C. fragariae Brooks, and C. gloeosporioides (Penz.) Penz. & Sacc. Symptoms of the disease manifest in various phases. Infection of mother plants with anthracnose may result in the collapse of the entire plant due to crown rot. In the nursery, lesions form on stolons that eventually girdle the runners, leading to wilting and death of unrooted daughter plants distal to the lesion. Death of daughter plants in the nursery and in field transplants can also be caused by crown rot. Infected transplants are capable of spreading the disease from the nursery to the field, and entire crops can be destroyed by anthracnose in strawberry fruit production fields under conducive environmental conditions.', 0.9791974425315857]]
Context 2: [['Abstract: Three Colletotrichum species—Colletotrichum acutatum J.H. Simmonds (teleomorph Glomerella acutata J.C. Guerber & J.C. Correll), Colletotrichum fragariae A.N. Brooks, and Colletotrichum gloeosporioides (Penz.) Penz. & Sacc. in Penz. [teleomorph Glomerella cingulata (Stoneman) Spauld. & H. Schrenk]—are major pathogens of strawberry (Fragaria × ananassa). Strawberry anthracnose crown rot has been a destructive disease in commercial strawberry fields in the southeastern United States since the 1930s. The causal fungus, C. fragariae, can infect all aboveground plant parts; however, the disease is most severe when it infects the crown, leading to crown rot, wilt, and death.', 0.9667301774024963]]
Context 3: [['Since Colletotrichum spp. may infect many other hosts, primary infection in strawberry fields is sometimes assumed to come from these other hosts growing near the strawberry field. To test the hypothesis that Colletotrichum spp. may move from other fruit or vegetable hosts to strawberries, 37 Colletotrichum isolates, representing nine species collected from 12 hosts, were wound-inoculated onto the leaves and stems of strawberry, blueberry, blackberry, muscadine grape, tomato, and pepper (Smith, 2002). Colletotrichum fragariae isolates...', 0.9423284530639648]]
Context 4: [['The difficulty in controlling anthracnose crown rot arises from the fact that Colletotrichum spp. can kill strawberry plants after aggressively invading crown tissue, with a long latent period during which no symptoms are visible. Additionally, there are no long-term effective fungicides available, and the diverse origins of the causal agents are unpredictable (Peres et al., 2017; Forcelini and Peres, 2018; Hirayama et al., 2018). Furthermore, Colletotrichum spp. can be dispersed from asymptomatic plants over long distances, while relevant quarantine measures for strawberry trade are lacking in China. Recognizing the causal agents is a prerequisite for disease control. Initially, identification largely depended on morphological observation and virulence tests. Repeated in vitro subculturing of microbes can alter both their morphology and virulence. The fact that morphological characteristics can vary based on host choice or environmental conditions poses a significant concern for fungal identification. Strawberry anthracnose was first reported nearly a century ago (Brooks, 1931). Through PCR and DNA sequencing techniques, researchers have clarified the genetic distinctions among Colletotrichum spp. associated with strawberries, categorizing pathogens of worldwide origin into C. acutatum, C. fragariae, and C. gloeosporioides (Martínez-Culebras et al., 2000, 2003). However, ambiguously annotated data for Colletotrichum species frequently appear in GenBank, leading to confusion (Nilsson et al., 2006; Hyde et al., 2009). The emergence of multi-locus phylogeny has significantly aided in the identification of fungal species. Many pathologists and biologists have greatly expanded knowledge of Colletotrichum systematics (Cannon et al., 2012; Damm et al., 2012a, b; Weir et al., 2012), providing a solid foundation for future research. A landmark study corrected many synonymous names and offered a valuable reference for understanding Colletotrichum pathogens (Hyde et al., 2014). The delineation of Colletotrichum species and the description of new species continue to progress with the advent of novel technologies such as whole genome sequencing (Jayawardena et al., 2020, 2021; Bhunjun et al., 2021; Talhinhas and Baroncelli, 2021).', 0.9016035795211792]]
Context 5: [['Three species of Colletotrichum—Colletotrichum acutatum J.H. Simmonds (teleomorph: Glomerella acutata J.C. Guerber & J.C. Correll), Colletotrichum fragariae A.N. Brooks, and Colletotrichum gloeosporioides (Penz.) Penz. & Sacc. in Penz. (teleomorph: Glomerella cingulata (Stoneman) Spauld. & H. Schrenk)—are major pathogens of strawberry (Fragaria × ananassa). Strawberry anthracnose crown rot has been a destructive disease in commercial strawberry fields in the southeastern United States since the 1930s. The causal fungus, C. fragariae, can infect all aboveground plant parts; however, the disease is most severe when it infects the crown, leading to crown rot, wilting, and plant death.', 0.8853331804275513]]
Context 6: [['Species of the fungal plant pathogen Colletotrichum collectively cause anthracnose on strawberry (Fragaria × ananassa Duch.), which is a major disease of this crop worldwide. Principal pathogens responsible for the disease include Colletotrichum acutatum J. H. Simmonds, C. fragariae Brooks, and C. gloeosporioides (Penz.) Penz. & Sacc. in Penz. (teleomorph: Glomerella cingulata (Stoneman) Spauld. & H. Schrenk).', 0.8771185874938965]]
Context 7: [['Anthracnose caused by Colletotrichum species is one of the most destructive diseases affecting strawberry production worldwide. Fungi of the genus Colletotrichum, which are ancient and co-evolved with flowering plants, rank eighth among the ten most economically important fungal pathogens and have diversified to adapt to various hosts. Since its first report in the United States in 1931, strawberry anthracnose has spread globally, resulting in devastating economic, social, and ecological consequences. In many ways, producing organic strawberries is largely impractical because of this disease. Colletotrichum species pathogenic to strawberries have been extensively characterized. This review aims to provide an accurate inventory of these species by revisiting their discovery history over the past 90 years. A total of 23 Colletotrichum species, clustered into five species complexes and two singleton taxa, have been accepted as strawberry pathogens with a global occurrence illustrated. The relative prevalence of distinct Colletotrichum species associated with strawberries has been systematically analyzed in China. Finally, the host range of the two prevailing species, C. fructicola and C. siamense, which cause significant damage globally, is summarized, with the goal of improving diagnostic accuracy and anthracnose management in agricultural ecosystems.', 0.6194613575935364]]
Context 8: [['Garcia-Muñoz, J.-A., Súarez, M. B., Grondona, I., Monte, E., Buddie, A. G., Bridge, P. D., and Cannon, P. F. (2000). A physiological and biochemical approach to the systematics of Colletotrichum species pathogenic to strawberry. Mycologia, 92(3), 488-498.', 0.6156513690948486]]
Context 9: [['Smith BJ, Black LL. Morphological, cultural, and pathogenic variation in Colletotrichum species isolated from strawberry. Plant Dis. 1990;74(1):69–76. https://doi.org/10.1094/PD-74-0069.', 0.5299602746963501]]

query: What are some effective strategies for managing soilborne diseases in cereal crops?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [["The lack of genetic resistance and effective chemical controls for take-all imposes significant constraints on management practices, contributing to the disease's notorious reputation among cereal growers. Extensive research since the initial description of take-all 150 years ago in Australia has provided a wealth of information on all aspects of the disease (3, 17), making it an important model for studying other soilborne diseases. However, as with many soilborne diseases, the vast pool of information on take-all has often resulted in greater frustration due to its elusive control. Various hypotheses regarding the effects of cultural practices on survival, pathogenicity, and susceptibility have been proposed to explain the numerous anomalies associated with this disease.", 0.8968336582183838]]

query: What type of fungicides should I avoid using repeatedly to prevent resistance?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Past failures of fungicides to control anthracnose epidemics may have stemmed from the development of resistance in the Colletotrichum population. In the early 1970s, benomyl effectively reduced anthracnose crown rot incidence (Horn et al., 1972; Howard, 1971) and was widely used by strawberry growers for years. However, anthracnose pathogens developed resistance to it and other benzimidazole fungicides, rendering benomyl ineffective. In vitro and greenhouse trials have been conducted to identify fungicides to which Colletotrichum pathogens have developed resistance (LaMondia, 1993, 1995; McInnes et al., 1992a, 1992b; Smith and Black, 1991, 1992, 1993). Current fungicide labels address pathogen resistance by restricting the number of consecutive and total applications of a product per season. For instance, the fungicides Abound (azoxystrobin, Syngenta, Greensboro, NC), Cabrio (pyraclostrobin, BASF, Research Triangle Park, NC), and Pristine (pyraclostrobin and boscalid, BASF) are limited to four or five applications per season, with no more than two consecutive applications before alternating with a fungicide that has a different mode of action. Natural products have also been evaluated as alternative fungicides, offering different modes of action, lower toxicity, and increased efficacy (Abril et al., 2008).', 0.7338491678237915]]
Context 1: [['The document also references a study on the in vitro effectiveness of these fungicides, noting that Difenoconazole, Tebuconazole, and Mancozeb effectively inhibited fungal growth, likely due to their ability to interfere with sterol biosynthesis and enzyme activity. Furthermore, a negative cross-resistance phenomenon is discussed, indicating that the selection for resistance to one fungicide may lead to increased susceptibility to others with different mechanisms.', 0.3548201620578766]]
Context 2: [['Most nurseries surveyed adhered to product label recommendations, making five or fewer applications of QoI fungicides, including azoxystrobin and pyraclostrobin, or mixtures containing QoIs. However, one nursery in California, one in North Carolina, and another in Canada reported spraying QoI fungicides 10, 8, and 6 times, respectively, during one season. These applications involved alternating among azoxystrobin, pyraclostrobin, and a pyraclostrobin + boscalid premix. The collected isolate information (nursery of origin), the number of QoI sprays during the nursery phase, and the number of resistant isolates may be correlated. The majority of plants harboring QoI-resistant isolates originated from nurseries that exceeded recommended spray programs, suggesting a potential link between nursery spray practices and the frequency of resistance.', 0.32281994819641113]]
Context 3: [['Nursery surveys confirmed the intensive use of QoI fungicides. Single-site fungicides, such as QoIs, have frequently been used in nurseries to control anthracnose and other diseases, ensuring the delivery of symptom-free stock material. Along with commercial products containing only azoxystrobin or pyraclostrobin, premixes with QoI fungicides were also utilized. This has led to an increased selection rate for QoI-resistant populations as early as the nursery phase. Since transplants produced in large nurseries are sold to smaller ones, plants may be exposed to multiple QoI applications throughout each propagation phase. Consequently, during the fruit production phase, growers face challenges in controlling anthracnose outbreaks with limited effective chemical options.', 0.2977716624736786]]
Context 4: [['Mondino, P. (2012). Resistencia a fungicidas: Conceptos y manejo (diapositiva). Uruguay. 1 Diapositiva, 21 transparencias. Consultado el 13 mar. 2017. Disponible en https://studylib.es/doc/5743328/resistencia-a-fungicidas.', 0.2471449077129364]]
Context 5: [['Natamycin, also known as pimaricin, is a natural polyene macrolide derived from the fermentation of Streptomyces spp. (i.e., Streptomyces natalensis, S. chattanoogensis, S. gilvosporeus, and S. lydicus), and has been used as an antifungal additive in the food industry since the 1960s (Aparicio et al., 2016; Lu et al., 2008). Currently, it is registered in the United States as a biopesticide for use on mushroom beds and, more recently, as a postharvest treatment for stone fruit and citrus. Due to its unique mode of action and the fact that resistance has never been reported in filamentous fungi during its extensive use in the food industry (Aparicio et al., 2016), this fungicide could be valuable in strawberry production where QoI resistance has been reported in C. acutatum and where new rotational products are needed for dip treatments.', 0.24118392169475555]]
Context 6: [['For the management of anthracnose crown rot, water washing or fungicide treatments of bare-root transplants have been utilized in the nursery or immediately before planting in production fields (Daugovish et al., 2009; Freeman et al., 1997). Running water effectively removes soil from root and crown tissues, potentially eliminating inoculum, but it does not control any infections already present (Koike et al., 2008). Pre-plant fungicide dips have been shown to decrease anthracnose crown rot; however, only two products are currently registered for this use in the United States. The single-site mode of action quinone outside inhibitor (QoI), azoxystrobin, has been widely used as a preplant dip and as a foliar treatment for managing anthracnose and other fungal diseases (Bartlett et al., 2002; Koike et al., 2008; Turechek et al., 2006). Resistance has been reported against this fungicide group in Colletotrichum acutatum populations from strawberries in Florida (Forcelini et al., 2016). During the 2015-16 California nursery crown rot outbreak, growers reported reduced efficacy of azoxystrobin dips, suggesting that resistance may also be present in California (K. Ivors, unpublished). A premixed product of the anilinopyrimidine cyprodinil and the phenylpyrrole fludioxonil is also registered, but phytotoxicity and stunting of plants have been reported under certain environmental conditions or following off-label exposure (G. Holmes, unpublished).', 0.23282510042190552]]

query: How can I tell if my strawberries have anthracnose?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['The term "anthracnose" was first used to describe a new disease of strawberries caused by Colletotrichum fragariae Brooks. "Strawberry anthracnose" continues to be used as a general term to identify all diseases of strawberries caused by species of Colletotrichum. Strawberry anthracnose diseases have been reported to be caused by C. acutatum J.H. Simmonds, C. gloeosporioides (Penz.) Penz. & Sacc. in Penz. (the teleomorph of Cromereilla cingulata (Stoneman) Spauld. & H. Schrenk), and C. dematium (Pers.) Grove. The latter species only occasionally causes strawberry fruit rots and will not be discussed here.', 0.8828215003013611]]
Context 1: [['Anthracnose is an important disease of strawberry caused by Colletotrichum spp., which affects foliage, runners, crowns, and fruits (Howard et al., 1992). Three primary fungal pathogens—C. acutatum sensu lato, C. gloeosporioides sensu lato, and C. fragariae—are known to cause anthracnose disease in strawberries (Freeman and Katan, 1997). The crown rot syndrome is characteristic of infections from C. gloeosporioides sensu lato and C. fragariae, while fruit rot is mainly attributed to C. acutatum sensu lato, leading to significant yield losses (Howard et al., 1992). Currently, numerous species are classified under what is now known as the C. acutatum complex, with six species—C. acutatum sensu stricto, C. fioriniae, C. godetiae, C. nymphaeae, C. salicis, and C. simmondsii—identified as associated with strawberry anthracnose worldwide (Damm et al., 2012). Among these, C. nymphaeae is the most prevalent pathogen causing strawberry anthracnose globally, including in Iran (Baroncelli et al., 2015; Karimi et al., 2017; Wang et al., 2019). Currently, no effective chemical control methods exist for managing strawberry anthracnose; available options are limited to preventive treatments applied before fruit production (Denoyes-Rothan et al., 1999). Additionally, concerns about the toxic effects of chemical fungicides on the environment and the development of resistance in fungal strains highlight the need for alternative control strategies. Consequently, utilizing resistant cultivars appears to be the most efficient and practical approach for suppressing anthracnose development. In light of recent anthracnose outbreaks in strawberry fields in the Kurdistan province of Iran (Karimi et al., 2017), and the necessity for appropriate strategies to address this issue, the aim of this study was to evaluate the resistance of several commercial strawberry cultivars to the anthracnose fruit rot caused by C. nymphaeae under in vivo and greenhouse conditions.', 0.8798012137413025]]
Context 2: [['Smith, B. J. 1998. Anthracnose leaf spot, irregular spot, anthracnose fruit rot (black spot), and anthracnose crown rot. In: Compendium of Strawberry Diseases. J. L. Mass, ed. American Phytopathological Society, St. Paul, MN. Pages 24-25, 31-33, and 46-48.', 0.8511201739311218]]
Context 3: [['Howard CM, Albregts EE. Anthracnose. In: Compendium of Strawberry Diseases. American Phytopathological Society: Paul St, ed. Maas JL, USA; 1984. pp. 85-87.', 0.8311544060707092]]
Context 4: [['Numerous reports indicate that strawberry anthracnose pathogens may originate from weed species. For instance, C. fragariae was found attacking the weed Cassia obtusifolia L. (sicklepod, coffeweed) in Florida, causing typical disease symptoms. Inoculation of strawberry with the Cassia isolates resulted in typical anthracnose symptoms, while isolates from strawberry were equally virulent on Cassia. Similarly, inoculation of Duchesnea indica (Andr.) Focke (wild strawberry), F. virginiana Duch. (Virginia wild strawberry), and Potentilla canadensis L. with C. fragariae induced anthracnose disease on these hosts, suggesting that strawberry anthracnose pathogens have a broad host range.', 0.7603480815887451]]
Context 5: [['Smith, B.J. (1998c). Anthracnose leaf spot and irregular leaf spot. In J.L. Maas (Ed.), Compendium of Strawberry Diseases (2nd ed., pp. 24–25). American Phytopathological Society, St. Paul, MN.', 0.7094013094902039]]
Context 6: [['So far, anthracnose epidemics have affected strawberry nurseries and production fields worldwide. Reports on Colletotrichum spp. associated with strawberries, curated from literature in PubMed and Clarivate combined with fungal database searches (Farr and Rossman, 2022), were compiled to understand the global diversity and occurrence of the causal agents of strawberry anthracnose. From our findings, since 1931 until July 9, 2022, there have been over 220 citations and 310 records related to the identification of causal agents of strawberry anthracnose at the genus level of Colletotrichum in 36 countries across six continents, with 282 records providing pathogen identification at the species or species complex level.', 0.6938165426254272]]
Context 7: [['In November 2021, anthracnose symptoms were observed on strawberries (cv. Kingsberry) in Nonsan, Chungnam Province. Early symptoms of anthracnose fruit rot (AFR) include blackening of specific tissues of the strawberry. These symptoms progress with the enlargement of lesions, which hinder proper fruit development and lead to the formation of orange-colored spores within the lesions. Similar symptoms were noted on the petioles, with sunken and blackened tissues similar to those on the fruit, accompanied by the formation of an orange conidial mass.', 0.669257402420044]]
Context 8: [["Anthracnose fungi can attack various parts of the strawberry plant, including crowns, petioles, leaves, fruit trusses, flowers, buds, and fruit. The fungi's ability to attack multiple plant parts, coupled with the involvement of several pathogen species, contributes to the complex nature of strawberry anthracnose. Brooks reported in 1931 that C. fragariae caused spotting and girdling of runners, and later indicated that it also caused spotting of petioles and crown rot in a summer nursery, leading to wilting and death of the plants. Researchers in Louisiana observed all these symptoms and noted that crown rot also occurred in the fruit production field.", 0.6603619456291199]]
Context 9: [['Shao, X. H. (1992). New disease of strawberry: Strawberry anthracnose. Acta Agriculturae Shanghai.', 0.6461430191993713]]

query: Are there fungicides that work better and cost less for controlling strawberry diseases?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Additionally, multisite fungicides such as captan, thiram, and chlorothalonil, which have been available for many decades, remain effective in reducing strawberry anthracnose incidence (Mertely et al. 2018). Chlorothalonil is only registered for nonbearing nurseries when flowers and fruit are absent, yet our surveys indicated that its usage is significantly lower compared to newer single-site fungicides. Due to their efficacy and low resistance risk, multisite fungicides should be the mainstay for disease control in strawberry nurseries. Other non-chemical alternatives, such as heat (Wang et al. 2017) and ultraviolet treatments (Onofre et al. 2017), are currently under investigation and could serve as valuable tools for disease management, reducing the reliance on single-site fungicides.', 0.9909250736236572]]
Context 1: [['The application of fungicides to control strawberry anthracnose is limited due to restrictions on pesticide usage and the susceptibility of strawberry plants to Colletotrichum during all stages of development, including flowers, green, and ripe fruit. To reduce anthracnose infection in plant nurseries, it is essential to produce disease-free propagation material, which is a prerequisite for establishing disease-free nursery transplants. Control measures practiced in the United States involve frequent applications of fungicides.', 0.9560196995735168]]
Context 2: [['Strawberry anthracnose, caused mainly by the Colletotrichum acutatum species complex, is a significant disease affecting strawberry production. Surveys were conducted, and isolates were collected from affected areas, specifically strawberry nurseries and production fields in six states across the United States. The use of fungicides, particularly quinone outside inhibitors (QoIs), has been widely employed for controlling C. acutatum for the past 20 years. Resistance to QoIs was first reported in Florida in 2013, and subsequent anthracnose outbreaks occurred in strawberry nurseries and production fields throughout the U.S. in 2015. Fungicide use surveys indicated that, in certain locations, the number of QoI applications exceeded the recommended levels for this fungicide group. This situation necessitates immediate changes in anthracnose management strategies to incorporate other chemical and non-chemical approaches, aiming to limit the selection of resistant populations and prevent future outbreaks.', 0.9403496384620667]]
Context 3: [['In the southeastern United States, anthracnose crown rot and fruit rot can be particularly severe in strawberry production fields, especially during wet harvest seasons, which can lead to total crop loss. Fungicides are used to control anthracnose diseases; however, several have become ineffective due to the development of fungicide-resistant strains of the pathogens. Field observations in Florida indicated that growing strawberry plants in soils with low N levels reduced the severity of anthracnose, although this also severely limited fruit production. Both the form of nitrogen and calcium levels influence disease severity. For instance, calcium has been employed to manage soil-borne diseases caused by Pythium spp. on various crops, while nitrate forms of N have been shown to suppress Fusarium wilt in tomatoes, whereas ammonium forms increase disease severity.', 0.9115323424339294]]
Context 4: [['There is an urgent need for multi- and single-site fungicide alternatives effective against anthracnose in strawberry nurseries and production fields. The antifungal antibiotic natamycin, widely used as a natural mold inhibitor in food products, has shown promise in controlling anthracnose root and crown infections caused by C. acutatum on strawberry transplants (Cordova et al. 2017; Haack et al. 2018). Similarly, fluazinam, a single-site respiration inhibitor fungicide from FRAC group 29, has demonstrated significant control of anthracnose fruit rot (Mertely et al. 2018). A request has been submitted through the Interregional Research Project Number 4 for its registration for nursery use only. Reducing the overlap of the same modes of action used during nursery and fruit production phases could help extend the lifespan of single-site fungicides at high risk of resistance.', 0.8785298466682434]]
Context 5: [['Wedge, D. E., Smith, B. J., Constantin, R. J., and Quebedeaux, J. P. (2007). Fungicide management strategies for controlling strawberry fruit rot diseases in Louisiana and Mississippi. Crop Prot., 26:1449-1458.', 0.8711495399475098]]
Context 6: [['Smith, B.J. and L.L. Black. 1991. Greenhouse efficacy of fungicides for control of anthracnose crown rot of strawberry, p. 221-223. In: A. Dale and J. Luby (eds.). The Strawberry into the 21st Century. Timber Press, Portland, OR.', 0.8474298119544983]]

query: Is it correct to say that light intensity directly influences the infection success of Colletotrichum spp.?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['The genus Colletotrichum represents a large number of economically important Ascomycete fungi that collectively cause anthracnose disease or leaf blights on significant agricultural crops and ornamental plants worldwide. Colletotrichum spp. often serve as models in studies ranging from pathogenic development and differentiation to plant-microbe interactions. During establishment and colonization of host plants, members of this genus uniquely acquire nutrients via both biotrophy and necrotrophy. Thus, in a single interaction, these fungal pathogens exhibit two modes of nutrient acquisition: initially, nutrients are acquired from living cells, after which a necrotrophic phase is initiated, allowing the same fungus to obtain nutrients from dead cells killed by the fungus. A given species of this genus can exhibit both strategies separately or concurrently. Additionally, these fungi develop a series of specialized infection-related structures, including germ tubes, appressoria, primary intracellular hyphae, and secondary necrotrophic hyphae. Therefore, Colletotrichum species are experimentally attractive organisms for studying the molecular, biochemical, and cellular basis of fungal pathogenicity, development, and signal transduction (see Bailey and Jeger, 1992; Prusky et al., 1999).', 0.28207093477249146]]
Context 1: [['Colletotrichum species are primarily recognized as the causal agents of anthracnose, which occurs on various plant parts, including leaves, stems, flowers, and fruits. The disease cycles of anthracnose on different hosts exhibit similar components (Peres et al., 2005; De Silva et al., 2017); they are typically polycyclic, with splash-borne asexual spores (conidia) initiating and spreading epidemics. Other Colletotrichum-related diseases include crown rot in strawberries and black dot disease on the roots of tomatoes and potatoes (Dillard and Cobb, 1997; Dillard and Cobb, 1998; Waller et al., 2002). Additionally, Colletotrichum species can cause post-harvest diseases, particularly in avocado, almond, and citrus fruits (Prusky, 1996; Ismail and Zhang, 2004; Prusky et al., 2013). In these cases, the pathogens form infection structures (appressoria) on the host but remain dormant within the fruit until after harvest, during which symptoms may emerge (Ismail and Zhang, 2004; Prusky et al., 2013). Several studies have indicated that species within a clade exhibit similar colonization and infection behaviors, with the establishment of quiescence being host- and tissue-specific (Sanders and Korsten, 2003; Damm et al., 2012; Weir et al., 2012; Prusky et al., 2013; Jayawardena et al., 2016; Zakaria, 2021). Furthermore, species within clades have comparable temperature requirements for mycelial growth, conidial germination, infection, and spore production (Salotti et al., 2022). For example, species such as C. gloeosporioides, C. fragariae, C. gossypii, and C. musaebelonging to the gloeosporioides clade show optimum temperatures for mycelial growth, sporulation, conidial germination, and infection between 25 and 32°C (Salotti et al., 2022).', 0.26335710287094116]]
Context 2: [['Significant advancements in the taxonomy of the C. gloeosporioides and C. acutatum species complexes have been made by Weir et al. (2012) and Damm et al. (2012a). However, the biological characteristics, such as temperature preferences, host range, and pathogenicity of different Colletotrichum species, remain unclear. Many pathogens are sensitive to temperature, rainfall, and humidity (Harvell et al. 2002; Wilson et al. 1990). Temperature is a critical factor influencing plant disease epidemics, as it can affect spore germination, infection rates, latent periods, sporulation, spore survival, and host resistance to various pathogens (Bonde et al. 2012; Wilson et al. 1990). High temperatures and their frequency can delay or even prevent the onset of plant diseases (Bonde et al. 2012, 2013). Conversely, the adaptation of pathogens to temperature plays a vital role in disease emergence.', 0.24645085632801056]]

query: What were the observed phytotoxic effects of certain fungicides on treated strawberry plants?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Table 2 presents the effects of various fungicides and a heat treatment on the percent mortality of strawberry plants caused by Colletotrichum acutatum in a greenhouse setting. In the study, the control group had a mortality rate of 80.0%, while treatments with different fungicides showed varying levels of effectiveness: Difenoconazole had a mortality rate of 57.2%, Propiconazole 53.5%, Prochloraz-Zn/Folpet 39.5%, and Prochloraz-Zn resulted in only 11.5%. The heat treatment was notably effective, leading to just 19.5% mortality. The data was derived from experiments involving four replicates of 25 plants each per treatment, with mortality assessed six weeks after planting. The Least Significant Difference (LSD) was calculated at 13.5% (P < 0.05), indicating significant variations between treatments.', 0.9832023978233337]]
Context 1: [['Control of C. acutatum in Field Transplants: In field trials conducted in 1995 and 1996, mortality caused by C. acutatum in naturally infected strawberry transplants was significantly reduced by all fungicide treatments compared to the non-treated control. Prochloraz-Mn and prochloraz-Zn were the most effective in reducing transplant mortality. In 1995, prochloraz-Mn reduced mortality by 93.3%, while in 1996, reductions were 86.8% for prochloraz-Mn and 93.1% for prochloraz-Zn, with no significant differences between them. Prochloraz-Zn/folpet, propiconazole, and difenoconazole were less effective than prochloraz alone. In 1995, transplant mortality was reduced by 66.7% and 37.7% with prochloraz-Zn/folpet and propiconazole, respectively. In 1996, reductions were 52.9% and 29.1% with prochloraz-Zn/folpet and difenoconazole, respectively. Similar to the greenhouse experiments, prochloraz fungicides, difenoconazole, and propiconazole exhibited slight phytotoxicity.', 0.9791337251663208]]
Context 2: [['Transplants of all three strawberry cultivars inoculated with either QoI-sensitive or -resistant isolates and dip-treated with natamycin at both rates, or with the pydiflumetofen-fludioxonil or fludioxonil-cyprodinil premixes, showed significantly (P < 0.05) lower disease severity and plant mortality compared to controls. There were generally no significant (P > 0.05) differences among these four treatments, with the new fungicides providing similar control to the registered premix of fludioxonil and cyprodinil. Among the six cultivar-inoculum combinations, the 0.5 g/liter rate of natamycin was significantly (P > 0.05) less effective than the 1 g/liter rate only for Portola inoculated with QoI-resistant isolates. No stunting of plants or other signs of phytotoxicity were observed in any treatment during these trials.', 0.9743107557296753]]
Context 3: [['This study evaluated the fungicides prochloraz-Zn, prochloraz-Mn (both protectant sterol-biosynthesis inhibitors), captan, folpet, a combined formulation of prochloraz-Zn and folpet, propiconazole, difenoconazole, and a heat treatment for the control of C. acutatum in naturally infected strawberry plants under laboratory, greenhouse, and field conditions. Fungicides were applied at the transplant stage to determine whether a single-dip treatment is sufficient for disease control.', 0.9224971532821655]]
Context 4: [['Various fungicides and a heat treatment were assessed for their ability to control strawberry anthracnose caused by the fungus Colletotrichum acutatum under laboratory, greenhouse, and field conditions. The effective dose causing 50% inhibition of mycelial growth (ED50) was measured at 30.5, 12.2, 0.2, 0.15, 0.05, 0.07, and 0.05 µg/ml for the fungicides folpet, captan, propiconazole, difenoconazole, combined prochloraz-Zn/folpet, prochloraz-Zn, and prochloraz-Mn, respectively.', 0.8750258088111877]]
Context 5: [['The experimental fungicide pydiflumetofen was not effective against C. acutatum in our in vitro and field studies. However, this fungicide is very active against B. cinerea and has shown high efficacy in reducing powdery mildew in strawberries (J. E. Adaskaveg, unpublished). The pydiflumetofen-fludioxonil premixture was among the most effective of our preplant dip treatments for crown rot in strawberries, likely due to the fludioxonil component. Therefore, this premixture has potential as a broad-spectrum post-plant field fungicide for strawberries.', 0.8712549209594727]]
Context 6: [['Certain fungicides, including propiconazole, have been reported to successfully limit in vitro growth of C. fragariae, while fluazinam, a protectant fungicide, provides good control of strawberry anthracnose in post-harvest berries.', 0.812178909778595]]
Context 7: [['Anthracnose crown rot of strawberry, caused by Colletotrichum acutatum, is an important disease affecting California nursery and fruit production. Preplant dip treatments of transplants with fludioxonil-cyprodinil or azoxystrobin are industry standards for managing the disease and have been used extensively. Following reports of reduced efficacy of azoxystrobin in the field, high levels of quinone outside inhibitor (QoI) resistance were detected in California isolates of the pathogen. Resistance was associated with the G143A mutation in the cytochrome b gene, similar to a previous report from Florida, and there were no detected fitness penalties in pathogenicity or virulence. Therefore, several alternative fungicides were investigated in laboratory and field studies. Subsequently, the new biofungicide natamycin was identified. Baseline sensitivities of 74 isolates of C. acutatum to natamycin were determined to be unimodal, with a range from 0.526 to 1.996 mg/ml (mean 0.973 mg/ml).', 0.7784618735313416]]
Context 8: [['In laboratory experiments, infection in segments of strawberry runners treated with prochloraz-Zn reached 60%, which was significantly reduced compared to the combined prochloraz-Zn/folpet (90%), captan, folpet, and water controls (100%). In the greenhouse, the number of naturally infected transplants killed was significantly reduced by all fungicides and the heat treatment (5 minutes at 49°C) compared to the non-treated control. Prochloraz-Zn was the most effective chemical control treatment but did not differ significantly from the heat treatment.', 0.7620160579681396]]
Context 9: [['Mouden, N.; Chliyeh, M.; Benkirane, R.; Ouazzani, A.; Douira, T.; Douira, A. (2016). Chemical control of some strawberry fungal pathogens by foliar fungicides under in vitro and in vivo conditions. International Journal of Recent Scientific Research, 7(2), 9037-9051.', 0.7429369688034058]]

query: Can the environment change how Colletotrichum looks?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Citation: Cai, L., Hyde, K.D., Taylor, P.W.J., Weir, B.S., Waller, J., Abang, M.M., Zhang, J.Z., Yang, Y.L., Phoulivong, S., Liu, Z.Y., Prihastuti, H., Shivas, R.G., McKenzie, E.H.C., Johnston, P.R. (2009). A polyphasic approach for studying Colletotrichum. Fungal Diversity, 39: 183-204.', 0.3985919952392578]]
Context 1: [['The genus Colletotrichum is considered one of the top ten important genera of fungal pathogens globally (Dean et al., 2012). Colletotrichum is an ancient fungus that has co-evolved with flowering plants. Plant microfossils of Protocolletotrichum preserved on angiosperm leaf cuticles suggest that the diverse pathogenic strategies of Colletotrichum spp. have been established since the Late Cretaceous period (Kar et al., 2004). Different complexes within the genus may have diverged between 4.8 and 32.2 million years ago (MYA) (Bhunjun et al., 2021). The emergence of agricultural cultivation and the intensive disturbance of natural environments have further driven the diversification of Colletotrichum species. These fungi have adapted to thousands of hosts and can be found as endophytes, pathogens, and saprobes (Freeman et al., 1998; Dean et al., 2012; Hirayama et al., 2018; da Silva et al., 2020; Jayawardena et al., 2020). Currently, a total of 257 Colletotrichum species grouped into 15 complexes and 13 additional singletons have been accepted in this genus.', 0.38567879796028137]]
Context 2: [['Damm, U., Baroncelli, R., Cai, L., Kubo, Y., O’Connell, R., Weir, B., Yoshino, K., and Cannon, P. F. 2010. Colletotrichum: Species, ecology, and interactions. IMA Fungus 1:161-165.', 0.2793619930744171]]
Context 3: [['In Colletotrichum: Biology, Pathology and Control (eds. J.A. Bailey and M.J. Jeger). CAB International: Wallingford.', 0.2718198597431183]]
Context 4: [['Hyde, K. D., Cai, L., McKenzie, E. H. C., Yang, Y. L., Zhang, J. Z., and Prihastuti, H. (2009b). Colletotrichum: A catalogue of confusion. Fungal Divers., 39, 1-17.', 0.2622358202934265]]
Context 5: [['Cannon, P.F., Damm, U., Johnston, P.R., & Weir, B.S. (2012). Colletotrichum: Current status and future directions. Studies in Mycology, 73, 181–213.', 0.2582762539386749]]
Context 6: [['Cannon, P. F., Damm, U., Johnston, P. & Weir, B. S. Colletotrichum: Current Status and Future Directions. Studies in Mycology 73, 181–213 (2012).', 0.2567701041698456]]
Context 7: [['The genus Colletotrichum represents a large number of economically important Ascomycete fungi that collectively cause anthracnose disease or leaf blights on significant agricultural crops and ornamental plants worldwide. Colletotrichum spp. often serve as models in studies ranging from pathogenic development and differentiation to plant-microbe interactions. During establishment and colonization of host plants, members of this genus uniquely acquire nutrients via both biotrophy and necrotrophy. Thus, in a single interaction, these fungal pathogens exhibit two modes of nutrient acquisition: initially, nutrients are acquired from living cells, after which a necrotrophic phase is initiated, allowing the same fungus to obtain nutrients from dead cells killed by the fungus. A given species of this genus can exhibit both strategies separately or concurrently. Additionally, these fungi develop a series of specialized infection-related structures, including germ tubes, appressoria, primary intracellular hyphae, and secondary necrotrophic hyphae. Therefore, Colletotrichum species are experimentally attractive organisms for studying the molecular, biochemical, and cellular basis of fungal pathogenicity, development, and signal transduction (see Bailey and Jeger, 1992; Prusky et al., 1999).', 0.25535550713539124]]
Context 8: [['Cannon, P. F., Damm, U., Johnston, P. R., and Weir, B. S. (2012). Colletotrichum: Current status and future directions. Stud. Mycol., 73, 181-213.', 0.25201863050460815]]

query: Are there any known natural predators or antagonistic organisms that can help reduce the incidence of C. gloeosporioides Group A in fruit orchards?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Notes: Common on commercial fruit crops, this fungus was referred to as C. gloeosporioides Group A by Johnston & Jones (1997) and Johnston et al. (2005).', 0.5055245161056519]]
Context 1: [['The filamentous fungal plant pathogen Colletotrichum gloeosporioides (Penz.) Penz. & Sacc. in Penz. (teleomorph = Glomerella cingulata (Stoneman) Spauld. & H. Schrenk) causes anthracnose disease on various fruits, including peach (Bernstein et al. 1995; Kim and Hong 2008; Ramsey et al. 1951), blueberry (Hartung et al. 1981; Smith et al. 1996), strawberry (Denoyes and Baudry 1995; Freeman et al. 2002; Smith and Black 1990), almond (Ogawa and English 1991), avocado (Stanley et al. 1996), apple (Bernstein et al. 1995; Shi et al. 1996), papaya (Gamagae et al. 2003), and citrus (Alahakoon and Brown 1994; Liyanage et al. 1992). The disease can develop on stems, twigs, leaves, and fruit of host plants. On peach, the pathogen often occurs in areas and during seasons with high rainfall and warm temperatures (Ogawa et al. 1995). Symptoms include sunken lesions with circular rings, where conidia of the fungus are produced in acervuli. Anthracnose disease can occasionally cause yield loss in commercial peach orchards in the southeastern United States, especially during wet and warm summers.', 0.42759573459625244]]
Context 2: [['C. gloeosporioides s.str. is recognized as the most virulent species affecting fruits. This study enhances our understanding of the species associated with various disease symptoms in citrus fruits and plants, providing valuable information for effective disease management.', 0.31275394558906555]]

query: What role does host specificity play in classifying Colletotrichum species?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['In a drastic move, von Arx (1957) reduced the number of recognized Colletotrichum species from several hundred to 11 based on morphological characteristics, with many taxa treated as synonyms of C. gloeosporioides and C. dematium. Several additional species have since been accepted based on morphological criteria (Sutton, 1980; 1992). The difficulties in recognizing Colletotrichum species can be attributed to: 1) the limited and variable morphological characters; 2) an extensive host range and variability in pathogenicity (Bailey and Jeger, 1992; Freeman et al., 2000; Latunde-Dada, 2001; Du et al., 2005; Thaung, 2008); 3) type specimens that are often missing or in poor condition, making them unsuitable for molecular studies; and 4) numerous rDNA ITS sequences of Colletotrichum strains in NCBI that are often misidentified (Crouch et al., 2009d; Damm et al., 2009).', 0.9571138620376587]]
Context 1: [['The genus Colletotrichum is considered one of the top ten important genera of fungal pathogens globally (Dean et al., 2012). Colletotrichum is an ancient fungus that has co-evolved with flowering plants. Plant microfossils of Protocolletotrichum preserved on angiosperm leaf cuticles suggest that the diverse pathogenic strategies of Colletotrichum spp. have been established since the Late Cretaceous period (Kar et al., 2004). Different complexes within the genus may have diverged between 4.8 and 32.2 million years ago (MYA) (Bhunjun et al., 2021). The emergence of agricultural cultivation and the intensive disturbance of natural environments have further driven the diversification of Colletotrichum species. These fungi have adapted to thousands of hosts and can be found as endophytes, pathogens, and saprobes (Freeman et al., 1998; Dean et al., 2012; Hirayama et al., 2018; da Silva et al., 2020; Jayawardena et al., 2020). Currently, a total of 257 Colletotrichum species grouped into 15 complexes and 13 additional singletons have been accepted in this genus.', 0.8273658752441406]]
Context 2: [['Table 2 provides a comprehensive list of various species of the genus Colletotrichum, including their culture accession numbers and the host plants from which they were isolated. Each entry specifies the country of origin and includes corresponding GenBank accession numbers for the ITS, GAPDH, ACT, and CHS-1 genes. The species range from Colletotrichum aenigmay, isolated from Persea americana in Israel, to Colletotrichum boninense, derived from Crinum asiaticum in Japan. This detailed tabulation is essential for understanding the genetic diversity and distribution of Colletotrichum species in relation to their host plants.', 0.486357718706131]]
Context 3: [['Citation: Cai, L., Hyde, K.D., Taylor, P.W.J., Weir, B.S., Waller, J., Abang, M.M., Zhang, J.Z., Yang, Y.L., Phoulivong, S., Liu, Z.Y., Prihastuti, H., Shivas, R.G., McKenzie, E.H.C., Johnston, P.R. Context 4: [['The name Colletotrichum was first introduced by Tode (1790) under the genus Vermicularia. The genus Colletotrichum itself was established by Corda (1831) and is now recognized as comprising “coelomycetes” with a Glomerella teleomorph stage (Sutton, 1992; Shenoy et al., 2007a; Hyde et al., 2009). This genus includes species with endophytic, epiphytic, saprobic, and phytopathogenic lifestyles (Kumar and Hyde, 2004; Photita et al., 2001a,b).', 0.40026500821113586]]

query: How were the pathogenicity tests conducted to determine the virulence of Colletotrichum species?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['The virulence potential of Colletotrichum species depends on the interplay of various factors such as plant varieties, humidity, temperature, and the concentration of inoculum (Simmonds, 1965; Freeman et al., 1998). Thus, the pathogenicity and virulence of these new species require testing in vivo. The Amaryllidaceae comprises 51 genera with over 800 species and has a worldwide distribution (Meerow et al., 1998, 2000). A high diversity of Colletotrichum species, including many undocumented new species, can be expected if more hosts are studied.', 0.9936268329620361]]
Context 1: [['Pathogenicity testing is highlighted as a crucial step to determine whether a specific Colletotrichum species is host-specific or has a broader host range. Host-specific taxa may have limited distributions, which carry significant biosecurity implications. Conversely, species with a wide host range may be more cosmopolitan and potentially opportunistic pathogens. Koch’s postulates have been applied to confirm the pathogenicity of various Colletotrichum isolates. For instance, studies have shown that C. acutatum causes Rhododendron anthracnose, while C. boninense was implicated in leaf infections of Euonymus. New species descriptions occasionally include data on pathogenicity testing, although this is not always the case. Further pathogenicity research is encouraged to validate findings across verified Colletotrichum species.', 0.9916785955429077]]
Context 2: [['Species descriptions will become standardized, and if morphological characters prove to be totally inadequate, they may be eliminated altogether. Pathogenicity testing will become essential to establish the biological role of these fungi. Colletotrichum has particular biosecurity importance, and until the genus becomes better defined, we suggest that plant quarantine authorities delay taking imprudent action. Many Colletotrichum species are proving to be widespread on a broad range of hosts, with some functioning as endophytes as well as pathogens. Many recently described species (e.g., in Prihastuti et al., 2009; Yang et al., 2009) are found to be prevalent on a variety of unrelated hosts, acting as endophytes, epiphytes, pathogens, or weak and opportunistic pathogens.', 0.8716935515403748]]
Context 3: [['Bailey, J.A., et al. (1992). Infection strategies of Colletotrichum species. In: Colletotrichum: Biology, Pathology and Control (Eds. J.A. Bailey and M.J. Jeger). CAB International: Wallingford: 88-120.', 0.37353870272636414]]

query: How does C. acutatum cause fruit lesions in crops like almond and key lime, and what are the potential long-term effects on crop yield?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['C. acutatum infects susceptible cultivars, particularly almond, as a general necrotroph affecting young tissues, including leaves, twigs, flowers, and fruit (1,2,26). When rain occurs during warm weather, newly developing shoots and flowers may be severely blighted. A similar situation occurs with key lime, where all shoots and leaves can be killed by the pathogen (6,83). In both cases, destructive and disfiguring lesions appear on fruit.', 0.9716628193855286]]
Context 1: [['Strawberry anthracnose, primarily caused by C. nymphaeae within the C. acutatum complex, is a leading disease limiting fruit yields in the United States (Damm et al. 2012; Legard et al. 2003; Legard and MacKenzie 2003; Mertely et al. 2017a, b; Wang et al. 2018). Characteristic symptoms of C. acutatum infections include flower blight and fruit rot (Mertely et al. 2017b; Peres et al. 2005; Smith 1998). Infected flowers may display brown lesions on the petals, while infected fruits typically present dark, sunken lesions with orange mucilage on their surface, rendering them undesirable for consumption (Peres et al. 2005). During severe epidemics, crown and root infections can also occur in nurseries, leading to stunted growth and reduced fruit production (Mertely et al. 2017a; Peres et al. 2005).', 0.815068244934082]]
Context 2: [["Interestingly, all young tissues of key lime are susceptible and severely attacked by C. acutatum. However, on sweet orange and most other citrus crops, including Tahiti lime, only flower tissues are infected, leading to postbloom fruit drop; vegetative tissues remain immune. Isolates of C. acutatum from key lime induce symptoms of postbloom fruit drop on sweet orange, while isolates from affected sweet orange produce minimal anthracnose damage on key lime (6). This type of fruit drop is unique among diseases caused by C. acutatum, as symptoms are induced by plant hormones. Natural fruit abscission typically occurs at the peduncle base, but postbloom fruit drop results in abscission at the fruit's base, leaving persistent calyces and peduncles. Leaves surrounding infected inflorescences often become small and disfigured. Genes responsible for ethylene and jasmonic acid biosynthesis and indole-3-acetic acid regulation are highly induced by C. acutatum infection. Indole acetic acid levels can increase up to 140-fold in infected petals compared to healthy controls.", 0.7918847799301147]]
Context 3: [['Biotroph–Necrotroph Combination Lifestyle (Almond, Key Lime): There are several diseases where C. acutatum primarily functions as a necrotroph but can also act as a biotroph, exhibiting a combination of biotrophic and necrotrophic interactions. This lifestyle includes anthracnose of almond, key lime, and leatherleaf fern. In these instances, acervuli and conidia are abundantly produced on affected tissues. The conidia are splash-dispersed to healthy tissues, which become infected quickly. The fungus can survive as dried conidia in acervuli or as mycelia in dead tissues, including spurs and mummified almond fruit.', 0.7705163955688477]]
Context 4: [['C. acutatum manifests symptoms on flowers, leaves, petioles, and roots, but it is most significant as a fruit rot pathogen in strawberries. It also affects citrus, apples, mangoes, papayas, and avocados, alongside C. gloeosporioides. In citrus, C. gloeosporioides is a common saprophyte and can cause postharvest anthracnose due to preharvest quiescent infections. Although C. acutatum does not cause postharvest anthracnose in citrus, it leads to specific diseases like postbloom fruit drop and key lime anthracnose. On apples, C. gloeosporioides and C. acutatum both contribute to bitter rot, but C. acutatum is not known to infect apple leaves.', 0.6706421971321106]]
Context 5: [['Peres, N.A., MacKenzie, S.J., Peever, T.L., & Timmer, L.W. (2008). Postbloom fruit drop of citrus and key lime anthracnose are caused by distinct phylogenetic lineages of Colletotrichum acutatum. Phytopathology, 98, 345–352.', 0.6132689714431763]]
Context 6: [['Peres N, MacKenzie S, Peever T, et al. 2008. Postbloom fruit drop of citrus and key lime anthracnose are caused by distinct phylogenetic lineages of Colletotrichum acutatum. Phytopathology 98: 345–352.', 0.5637544989585876]]
Context 7: [['Colletotrichum acutatum isolates were obtained from anemone, apple, and peach, infecting detached fruit including two cultivars of apple, avocado, almond, mango, and nectarine. These results demonstrated the cross-infection potential of two species, C. gloeosporioides (including representatives from distinct subpopulations in almond, apple, avocado, and mango) and C. acutatum (from apple and peach), affecting several fruit species. C. acutatum is a known pathogen of the ornamental anemone, causing leaf curl disease. In cross-inoculation experiments involving anemone and strawberry, regardless of the isolate source (anemone or strawberry), all anemone plants died within 14 days of inoculation. Typical anthracnose symptoms were observed on strawberry plants artificially inoculated with isolates from both hosts, leading to eventual mortality.', 0.5270219445228577]]
Context 8: [['C. acutatum causing strawberry anthracnose is predominantly a pathogen of fruit, stolons, and crowns. However, as demonstrated in this work, under appropriate environmental, agrotechnical, and epidemiological conditions, the pathogen can cause severe stunting and mortality of plants by infecting the root system.', 0.39914393424987793]]
Context 9: [['Differences in pathogenicity among strains from different hosts have been observed in several studies. Some fruit diseases caused by the C. acutatum complex have been shown to arise from distinct phylogenetic lineages (Peres et al. 2008), with strawberry fruit rot, in particular, rarely attributed to isolates from heterogeneous hosts (Mackenzie et al. 2009). Cross-infection potential was tested in various studies, including those by Bernstein et al. (1995), Freeman and Shabi (1996), Freeman et al. (2001b), and Mackenzie et al. (2007). Cross-infection may occur both in the field and in laboratory settings (Afanador-Kafuri et al. 2003). Freeman et al. (2001a) found that C. acutatum from strawberry could cause lesions on various fruits, whether they were wounded or intact. In vitro infection studies by Whitelaw-Weckert et al. (2007) revealed low host specificity among isolates that can be assigned to C. acutatum, C. simmondsii, and C. fioriniae.', 0.29117023944854736]]

query: What role do protective fungicides like captan play in reducing post-harvest losses in berries like strawberries and blueberries?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Additionally, multisite fungicides such as captan, thiram, and chlorothalonil, which have been available for many decades, remain effective in reducing strawberry anthracnose incidence (Mertely et al. 2018). Chlorothalonil is only registered for nonbearing nurseries when flowers and fruit are absent, yet our surveys indicated that its usage is significantly lower compared to newer single-site fungicides. Due to their efficacy and low resistance risk, multisite fungicides should be the mainstay for disease control in strawberry nurseries. Other non-chemical alternatives, such as heat (Wang et al. 2017) and ultraviolet treatments (Onofre et al. 2017), are currently under investigation and could serve as valuable tools for disease management, reducing the reliance on single-site fungicides.', 0.9346567392349243]]
Context 1: [['Certain fungicides, including propiconazole, have been reported to successfully limit in vitro growth of C. fragariae, while fluazinam, a protectant fungicide, provides good control of strawberry anthracnose in post-harvest berries.', 0.7461243867874146]]
Context 2: [['The study concluded that captafol was the most effective fungicide against C. fragariae, providing adequate control at concentrations of 1.2-2.4 g a.i./L when applied every 7 days. The mixture of captan and benomyl offered some control but was less effective than captafol. The findings suggest that maintaining the application of fungicides at appropriate intervals is crucial for managing strawberry anthracnose effectively.', 0.5153966546058655]]
Context 3: [['In the southeastern United States, anthracnose crown rot and fruit rot can be particularly severe in strawberry production fields, especially during wet harvest seasons, which can lead to total crop loss. Fungicides are used to control anthracnose diseases; however, several have become ineffective due to the development of fungicide-resistant strains of the pathogens. Field observations in Florida indicated that growing strawberry plants in soils with low N levels reduced the severity of anthracnose, although this also severely limited fruit production. Both the form of nitrogen and calcium levels influence disease severity. For instance, calcium has been employed to manage soil-borne diseases caused by Pythium spp. on various crops, while nitrate forms of N have been shown to suppress Fusarium wilt in tomatoes, whereas ammonium forms increase disease severity.', 0.3339619040489197]]
Context 4: [['Based on field trials in Florida (Mertely et al., 2009), the recommendation for anthracnose control involves weekly applications of a broad-spectrum protectant fungicide (captan) at the lowest label rate early in the season when conditions are less favorable for anthracnose development. Later, when anthracnose-infected flowers and fruit may be present, it is recommended to increase the rate of the protectant fungicide to the highest label rate. Warm, rainy weather in early spring often leads to epidemics, during which additional fungicides may be necessary. Growers are encouraged to scout their fields regularly for anthracnose symptoms, such as blighted flowers or black spots on green fruit. If symptoms are detected, the application of a strobilurin fungicide (such as Abound or Cabrio) in conjunction with the protectant fungicide is recommended. During the main bloom period, in late January and early February, fungicides containing two active ingredients (one for anthracnose control and one for Botrytis fruit rot control), such as CaptEvate, Pristine, or Switch, are advised. Tank mixes or higher rates of protectant fungicides should be maintained until the end of the harvest season or until dry weather effectively suppresses the disease.', 0.3275611698627472]]
Context 5: [['Anthracnose fruit rot was observed on berries treated with pyraclostrobin + boscalid, cyprodinil + fludioxonil, azoxystrobin, pyraclostrobin, and captan + fenhexamid, as well as captan alone. Studies conducted in North Carolina indicated that a fungicide spray program consisting of only four applications—one application of a mixture of captan and Topsin M (thiophanate-methyl, Cerexagri-Nisso, King of Prussia, PA), two applications of Pristine, and one application of CaptEvate (fenhexamid and captan, Arysta, Cary, NC)—provided a similar level of disease control as a season-long spray program with eight applications (Rahman et al., 2009). Each application in the shorter program included two fungicides, as both Pristine and CaptEvate contain two active ingredients.', 0.31840261816978455]]
Context 6: [['MacKenzie, S. J.; Mertely, J. C.; Peres, N. A. (2009). Curative and protectant activity of fungicides for control of crown rot of strawberry caused by Colletotrichum gloeosporioides. Plant Disease, 93(8), 815-820.', 0.2425762414932251]]
Context 7: [['In summary, while captafol demonstrated fungicidal activity against strawberry anthracnose, other fungicides like benomyl and maneb have shown reduced effectiveness in recent years, necessitating the ongoing evaluation of control strategies for this pervasive disease.', 0.2350354641675949]]
Context 8: [['Legard, D. E., and MacKenzie, S. J. 2003. Evaluation of fungicides to control anthracnose fruit rot of strawberry, 2001-02. Fungicide and Nematocide Tests 58: SMF009.', 0.12399062514305115]]
Context 9: [['The experimental fungicide pydiflumetofen was not effective against C. acutatum in our in vitro and field studies. However, this fungicide is very active against B. cinerea and has shown high efficacy in reducing powdery mildew in strawberries (J. E. Adaskaveg, unpublished). The pydiflumetofen-fludioxonil premixture was among the most effective of our preplant dip treatments for crown rot in strawberries, likely due to the fludioxonil component. Therefore, this premixture has potential as a broad-spectrum post-plant field fungicide for strawberries.', 0.11896682530641556]]
