query: What challenges are associated with the use of fungicides in managing anthracnose?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Present and Future Management of Anthracnose: Fungicides, including chemicals such as benzimidazoles (e.g., thiabendazole, benomyl, and carbendazim) and sterol inhibitors (e.g., imazalil, prochloraz, and propiconazole), have been used effectively to control anthracnose disease in banana, mango, papaya, and avocado plants [140]. Benzimidazoles are commonly applied as dips or sprays to inhibit the anthracnose-causing fungus, Colletotrichum spp. [141], but the large-scale and continuous use of fungicides has led to the development of fungal resistance. For instance, benzimidazole-resistant Colletotrichum has been detected in mangoes and bananas [140]. Additionally, the excessive use of fungicides negatively impacts human health and the environment, as chemical residues often contaminate soil and water [142]. Biocontrol offers an alternative, non-toxic method for managing fruit crop anthracnose. Biocontrol agents, such as antagonistic microbes including yeast, bacteria, and filamentous fungi (particularly Trichoderma spp.), have shown promising results and are gaining popularity for their direct application to fruit surfaces post-harvest [143].', 0.993316650390625]]
Context 1: [['Nursery surveys confirmed the intensive use of QoI fungicides. Single-site fungicides, such as QoIs, have frequently been used in nurseries to control anthracnose and other diseases, ensuring the delivery of symptom-free stock material. Along with commercial products containing only azoxystrobin or pyraclostrobin, premixes with QoI fungicides were also utilized. This has led to an increased selection rate for QoI-resistant populations as early as the nursery phase. Since transplants produced in large nurseries are sold to smaller ones, plants may be exposed to multiple QoI applications throughout each propagation phase. Consequently, during the fruit production phase, growers face challenges in controlling anthracnose outbreaks with limited effective chemical options.', 0.9923279881477356]]
Context 2: [['For the management of anthracnose crown rot, water washing or fungicide treatments of bare-root transplants have been utilized in the nursery or immediately before planting in production fields (Daugovish et al., 2009; Freeman et al., 1997). Running water effectively removes soil from root and crown tissues, potentially eliminating inoculum, but it does not control any infections already present (Koike et al., 2008). Pre-plant fungicide dips have been shown to decrease anthracnose crown rot; however, only two products are currently registered for this use in the United States. The single-site mode of action quinone outside inhibitor (QoI), azoxystrobin, has been widely used as a preplant dip and as a foliar treatment for managing anthracnose and other fungal diseases (Bartlett et al., 2002; Koike et al., 2008; Turechek et al., 2006). Resistance has been reported against this fungicide group in Colletotrichum acutatum populations from strawberries in Florida (Forcelini et al., 2016). During the 2015-16 California nursery crown rot outbreak, growers reported reduced efficacy of azoxystrobin dips, suggesting that resistance may also be present in California (K. Ivors, unpublished). A premixed product of the anilinopyrimidine cyprodinil and the phenylpyrrole fludioxonil is also registered, but phytotoxicity and stunting of plants have been reported under certain environmental conditions or following off-label exposure (G. Holmes, unpublished).', 0.9625529050827026]]
Context 3: [['Until highly resistant cultivars are available, growers must rely on chemical applications and cultural practices to reduce losses due to anthracnose. The failure of fungicides to control anthracnose epidemics may be due to the development of fungicide resistance in the Colletotrichum spp. population. For example, benomyl effectively reduced the incidence of anthracnose crown rot (Horn et al., 1972; Howard, 1971) and was used intensively by strawberry growers for years to control anthracnose and other diseases. However, the anthracnose pathogens, C. acutatum and C. fragariae, developed resistance to it and other benzimidazole fungicides (LaMondia, 1995; McInnes et al., 1992a; Smith and Black, 1992, 1993), rendering benomyl ineffective for anthracnose control in strawberry fields.', 0.9338117241859436]]
Context 4: [['Until highly resistant cultivars are available, growers must rely on chemical applications and cultural practices to reduce losses due to anthracnose. The failure of fungicides to control anthracnose epidemics may be attributed to the development of fungicide resistance in the Colletotrichum species population. For example, benomyl was shown to effectively reduce the incidence of anthracnose crown rot (Horn et al., 1972; Howard, 1971) and was used intensively by strawberry growers for years to control anthracnose and other diseases. However, the anthracnose pathogens, C. acutatum and C. fragariae, developed resistance to it and other benzimidazole fungicides (LaMondia, 1995; McInnes et al., 1992a; Smith and Black, 1992, 1993), leading to the ineffectiveness of benomyl for anthracnose control in strawberry fields.', 0.9267059564590454]]
Context 5: [['Past failures of fungicides to control anthracnose epidemics may have stemmed from the development of resistance in the Colletotrichum population. In the early 1970s, benomyl effectively reduced anthracnose crown rot incidence (Horn et al., 1972; Howard, 1971) and was widely used by strawberry growers for years. However, anthracnose pathogens developed resistance to it and other benzimidazole fungicides, rendering benomyl ineffective. In vitro and greenhouse trials have been conducted to identify fungicides to which Colletotrichum pathogens have developed resistance (LaMondia, 1993, 1995; McInnes et al., 1992a, 1992b; Smith and Black, 1991, 1992, 1993). Current fungicide labels address pathogen resistance by restricting the number of consecutive and total applications of a product per season. For instance, the fungicides Abound (azoxystrobin, Syngenta, Greensboro, NC), Cabrio (pyraclostrobin, BASF, Research Triangle Park, NC), and Pristine (pyraclostrobin and boscalid, BASF) are limited to four or five applications per season, with no more than two consecutive applications before alternating with a fungicide that has a different mode of action. Natural products have also been evaluated as alternative fungicides, offering different modes of action, lower toxicity, and increased efficacy (Abril et al., 2008).', 0.9226183295249939]]
Context 6: [['There is an urgent need for multi- and single-site fungicide alternatives effective against anthracnose in strawberry nurseries and production fields. The antifungal antibiotic natamycin, widely used as a natural mold inhibitor in food products, has shown promise in controlling anthracnose root and crown infections caused by C. acutatum on strawberry transplants (Cordova et al. 2017; Haack et al. 2018). Similarly, fluazinam, a single-site respiration inhibitor fungicide from FRAC group 29, has demonstrated significant control of anthracnose fruit rot (Mertely et al. 2018). A request has been submitted through the Interregional Research Project Number 4 for its registration for nursery use only. Reducing the overlap of the same modes of action used during nursery and fruit production phases could help extend the lifespan of single-site fungicides at high risk of resistance.', 0.9031369686126709]]
Context 7: [['In-vitro trials have been used to screen fungicides for their ability to control anthracnose (LaMondia, 1993; McInnes et al., 1992b; Smith and Black, 1992). Smith and Black (1993) reported that all 16 C. acutatum, 14 out of 18 C. fragariae, and both C. gloeosporioides isolates tested in vitro were resistant to benomyl, and all benomyl-resistant isolates were also resistant to carbendazim, which belongs to the same class of fungicides as benomyl. In a greenhouse study, plants treated with propiconazole exhibited lower disease severity ratings than those treated with captafol or benomyl (Smith and Black, 1991). However, the propiconazole-treated plants were shorter, with dark green leaves that appeared thicker than the leaves of untreated plants.', 0.8380151391029358]]
Context 8: [['In-vitro trials have been used to screen fungicides for their ability to control anthracnose (LaMondia, 1993; McInnes et al., 1992b; Smith and Black, 1992). Smith and Black (1993) reported that all 16 C. acutatum, 14 out of 18 C. fragariae, and both C. gloeosporioides isolates tested in vitro were resistant to benomyl, and all benomyl-resistant isolates were also resistant to carbendazim, which is in the same class of fungicides as benomyl. In a greenhouse study, plants treated with propiconazole had lower disease severity ratings than did plants treated with captafol or benomyl (Smith and Black, 1991). However, the propiconazole-treated plants were shorter with dark green leaves that appeared thicker than the leaves of untreated plants.', 0.8304157257080078]]
Context 9: [['As our understanding of the anthracnose pathogens and the epidemiology of anthracnose diseases has improved, so has our capacity to control these diseases. Changes in cultural practices have led to reduced levels of disease. Additionally, the development and registration of more effective fungicides for use on strawberries have significantly decreased losses due to anthracnose crown rot and fruit rot. The introduction of partially resistant cultivars has also helped mitigate economic losses due to these diseases. Nonetheless, growers may still experience severe losses when environmental conditions are highly conducive to anthracnose development.', 0.8115288615226746]]

query: How does anthracnose affect strawberry plant vigor and longevity?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [["Anthracnose fungi can attack various parts of the strawberry plant, including crowns, petioles, leaves, fruit trusses, flowers, buds, and fruit. The fungi's ability to attack multiple plant parts, coupled with the involvement of several pathogen species, contributes to the complex nature of strawberry anthracnose. Brooks reported in 1931 that C. fragariae caused spotting and girdling of runners, and later indicated that it also caused spotting of petioles and crown rot in a summer nursery, leading to wilting and death of the plants. Researchers in Louisiana observed all these symptoms and noted that crown rot also occurred in the fruit production field.", 0.8953297734260559]]
Context 1: [['Anthracnose is an important disease of strawberry caused by Colletotrichum spp., which affects foliage, runners, crowns, and fruits (Howard et al., 1992). Three primary fungal pathogens—C. acutatum sensu lato, C. gloeosporioides sensu lato, and C. fragariae—are known to cause anthracnose disease in strawberries (Freeman and Katan, 1997). The crown rot syndrome is characteristic of infections from C. gloeosporioides sensu lato and C. fragariae, while fruit rot is mainly attributed to C. acutatum sensu lato, leading to significant yield losses (Howard et al., 1992). Currently, numerous species are classified under what is now known as the C. acutatum complex, with six species—C. acutatum sensu stricto, C. fioriniae, C. godetiae, C. nymphaeae, C. salicis, and C. simmondsii—identified as associated with strawberry anthracnose worldwide (Damm et al., 2012). Among these, C. nymphaeae is the most prevalent pathogen causing strawberry anthracnose globally, including in Iran (Baroncelli et al., 2015; Karimi et al., 2017; Wang et al., 2019). Currently, no effective chemical control methods exist for managing strawberry anthracnose; available options are limited to preventive treatments applied before fruit production (Denoyes-Rothan et al., 1999). Additionally, concerns about the toxic effects of chemical fungicides on the environment and the development of resistance in fungal strains highlight the need for alternative control strategies. Consequently, utilizing resistant cultivars appears to be the most efficient and practical approach for suppressing anthracnose development. In light of recent anthracnose outbreaks in strawberry fields in the Kurdistan province of Iran (Karimi et al., 2017), and the necessity for appropriate strategies to address this issue, the aim of this study was to evaluate the resistance of several commercial strawberry cultivars to the anthracnose fruit rot caused by C. nymphaeae under in vivo and greenhouse conditions.', 0.8652259707450867]]
Context 2: [['From 2010 to 2016, we conducted surveys of anthracnose in strawberries in Miaoli County. More than 50% of diseased plants exhibited symptoms characteristic of anthracnose crown rot (ACR), as described by McInnes et al. (1992). ACR resulted in plant losses of up to 30-40% during the seedling stage and around 20% after transplanting. Initial symptoms in crown tissue included a marbled red and white appearance, which progressed to brown rot and eventual rapid wilting of the plant. Anthracnose symptoms also appeared on other parts of the plant, including leaves, petioles, runners, fruits, and roots. These symptoms manifested as circular black spots on leaves, withering and girdling on runners.', 0.5565593838691711]]
Context 3: [['So far, anthracnose epidemics have affected strawberry nurseries and production fields worldwide. Reports on Colletotrichum spp. associated with strawberries, curated from literature in PubMed and Clarivate combined with fungal database searches (Farr and Rossman, 2022), were compiled to understand the global diversity and occurrence of the causal agents of strawberry anthracnose. From our findings, since 1931 until July 9, 2022, there have been over 220 citations and 310 records related to the identification of causal agents of strawberry anthracnose at the genus level of Colletotrichum in 36 countries across six continents, with 282 records providing pathogen identification at the species or species complex level.', 0.46493804454803467]]
Context 4: [['Howard CM, Albregts EE. Anthracnose. In: Compendium of Strawberry Diseases. American Phytopathological Society: Paul St, ed. Maas JL, USA; 1984. pp. 85-87.', 0.4597007930278778]]
Context 5: [['De los Santos, B., de Paredes, G., and Munoz, F. R. (2002). Influence of anthracnose epiphytotic development on strawberry fruit production in Huelva (Southwestern Spain). Acta Hortic., 567:623-626.', 0.4259432554244995]]
Context 6: [['Nam MH, Yoo JH, Yun TS, Kim HH, Kim HG. Anthracnose of strawberry: Etiological and ecological characteristics and management. Res Plant Dis 2023;29:205-19.', 0.4000651240348816]]
Context 7: [['Horn, N. L., and R. G. Carver. 1962. Anthracnose and powdery mildew on strawberry plants in Louisiana. Plant Disease Reporter 45:591-592.', 0.3781690001487732]]
Context 8: [['De los Santos, B., de Paredes, G., and Munoz, F. R. 2002. Influence of anthracnose epiphytotic development on strawberry fruit production in Huelva (Southwestern Spain). Acta Hortic. 567:623-626.', 0.3754218518733978]]
Context 9: [['In the early 1980s, anthracnose became a significant disease affecting strawberries in the southeastern United States. In response, the USDA-ARS established a breeding program to develop anthracnose-resistant cultivars suited to the strawberry-growing regions of this area. This initiative was conducted at the Small Fruit Research Station in Poplarville, MS, and the Fruit Laboratory in Beltsville, MD, in collaboration with state experiment stations in Florida, Louisiana, and North Carolina (Galletta et al., 1997; Smith and Spiers, 1982).', 0.3659529387950897]]

query: What are the key differences in the disease progression caused by C. gloeosporioides on almond, avocado, and strawberry?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Table Comparison Summary A comparison of Colletotrichum gloeosporioides isolates from almond and avocado reveals differences in morphology and compatibility. Notably, the optimal growth temperature and growth rate on potato dextrose agar varied between isolates. The infected plant parts included leaves, twigs, and both immature and mature fruit, with some isolates showing compatibility and others absent. Additionally, benomyl sensitivity differed among isolates, highlighting the importance of molecular characterization in disease management.', 0.9564521908760071]]
Context 1: [['In the case of almond, a deciduous crop, anthracnose pathogens typically infect during the early fruiting stages, but do not attack mature fruit or other plant parts. Conversely, avocado, an evergreen crop, experiences postharvest decay caused by latent or quiescent infections initiated in the field. Unlike almond and avocado, which are perennial, strawberry is primarily an annual crop. Strawberry anthracnose, caused by species such as C. gloeosporioides, C. acutatum, and C. fragariae, leads to significant damage to both foliar and fruiting parts, as well as root necrosis. The damage to strawberry crops is not confined to a specific growth period or storage conditions; anthracnose can appear throughout the season.', 0.9424192905426025]]
Context 2: [['In studies conducted in Israel, researchers aimed to determine whether avocado anthracnose was caused by the same subspecies of C. gloeosporioides responsible for almond anthracnose, particularly since almond groves are located alongside avocado plantations in certain cultivation areas. Similarly, other crops, such as anemone, apple, mango, and strawberry, are known to be susceptible to Colletotrichum in Israel. To evaluate the potential for cross-infection, isolates from different crops were cross-inoculated on various hosts.', 0.9321426153182983]]
Context 3: [["Figure Description Figure 1 illustrates typical anthracnose symptoms caused by C. gloeosporioides and C. acutatum. Symptoms include lesions on immature almond fruit, wilting of leaves due to infection, and signs on mature avocado and strawberry fruit. Arrows in the figure indicate areas of sporulation, demonstrating the pathogen's impact on the fruits.", 0.9257054924964905]]
Context 4: [['C. acutatum manifests symptoms on flowers, leaves, petioles, and roots, but it is most significant as a fruit rot pathogen in strawberries. It also affects citrus, apples, mangoes, papayas, and avocados, alongside C. gloeosporioides. In citrus, C. gloeosporioides is a common saprophyte and can cause postharvest anthracnose due to preharvest quiescent infections. Although C. acutatum does not cause postharvest anthracnose in citrus, it leads to specific diseases like postbloom fruit drop and key lime anthracnose. On apples, C. gloeosporioides and C. acutatum both contribute to bitter rot, but C. acutatum is not known to infect apple leaves.', 0.9182702302932739]]
Context 5: [['Over the past decade, various molecular techniques have been employed to enhance the reliable differentiation among Colletotrichum species. These methods include arbitrarily primed polymerase chain reaction (ap-PCR) and polymorphisms in nuclear DNA, ribosomal DNA (rDNA), mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA), and A+T-rich DNA. Although almond and avocado crops are grown in close proximity in Israel, where anthracnose from C. gloeosporioides affects both crops during the spring season, it remains uncertain whether cross-infection occurs in the field. Additionally, strawberry, which is also susceptible to C. acutatum, is cultivated in the same regions and climatic conditions as the avocado and almond crops.', 0.8255844712257385]]
Context 6: [['The characteristics of conidia, including color, size, and shape, as well as optimal temperature, growth rate, presence or absence of setae, and existence of the teleomorph Glomerella, play crucial roles in differentiating species of the Colletotrichum genus. This discussion focuses on three anthracnose pathosystems affecting the fruits of almond, avocado, and strawberry, which exhibit different disease patterns.', 0.7895702719688416]]
Context 7: [['Shabi, E., Katan, T., Gera, H., and Elisha, S. 1994. Taxonomic determination of pathogenic Colletotrichum gloeosporioides of almond, anemone, and avocado according to fungicide sensitivity. (Abstract) Phytoparasitica 21:130-131.', 0.753055989742279]]
Context 8: [['VCG studies were conducted with isolates of Colletotrichum from almond (from Israel and the United States), avocado (Israel), and strawberry (Israel) crops to determine genetic relatedness within and between populations. The Israeli isolates of C. gloeosporioides and Californian isolates of C. acutatum from almond belonged to single, distinct VCGs and formed complementary heterokaryons only between mutants from different isolates within each population. Notably, almond isolates from Israel were not compatible with local isolates of Colletotrichum from avocado, indicating that the almond population constitutes a distinct subspecific group within C. gloeosporioides.', 0.7476232051849365]]
Context 9: [['Freeman, S., Katan, T., and Shabi, E. 1996. Differentiation between Colletotrichum gloeosporioides from avocado and almond using molecular and pathogenicity tests. Applied and Environmental Microbiology 62:1014-1020.', 0.7452234625816345]]

query: What is the role of the GAPDH gene in identifying Colletotrichum species?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['A similar set of six genes (ITS, ACT, CHS, GPDH, histone 3, and beta-tubulin) was used by Damm et al. (2009) to study Colletotrichum species with curved conidia from herbaceous hosts, which included six different clades. The best separability of the species was observed using both GPDH and histone 3 genes, which were superior to ITS, ACT, CHS, and beta-tubulin. The most appropriate gene for barcoding Colletotrichum must be selected during the species delimitation process since we can only choose one or more barcoding genes when we know which taxa need to be distinguished. A good approach would be to test and establish a selection of loci used by different groups involved in Colletotrichum systematics to work towards identifying the best barcoding gene.', 0.9855925440788269]]
Context 1: [['A polyphasic approach combining multilocus phylogenetic analysis with recognizable phenotypic characteristics is recommended for accurate species identification within the Colletotrichum genus. According to Weir et al., internal transcribed spacer (ITS) sequences alone are not reliable for distinguishing different species within the C. gloeosporioides species complex. Additional loci recommended for identifying Colletotrichum species include actin (ACT), calmodulin (CAL), chitin synthase-1 (CHS-1), glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate dehydrogenase (GAPDH), and β-tubulin (TUB2).', 0.9786615371704102]]
Context 2: [['Repetitive DNA elements have proven useful for restriction fragment length polymorphism (RFLP) grouping of various Colletotrichum species. For instance, a repetitive nuclear DNA element (GcpR1), originally identified in the bean anthracnose pathogen C. lindemuthianum, was successfully used to differentiate among 10 species of Colletotrichum, producing unique polymorphic patterns for each species. When GcpR1 was employed to compare C. gloeosporioides isolates from almond and avocado in Israel, the band patterns of the almond isolates were uniform and distinct from those of the avocado isolates. Additionally, polymorphic fragments were observed within the avocado isolates, correlating with the morphological and VCG heterogeneity of this population.', 0.7869774103164673]]
Context 3: [['Table 2 provides a comprehensive list of various species of the genus Colletotrichum, including their culture accession numbers and the host plants from which they were isolated. Each entry specifies the country of origin and includes corresponding GenBank accession numbers for the ITS, GAPDH, ACT, and CHS-1 genes. The species range from Colletotrichum aenigmay, isolated from Persea americana in Israel, to Colletotrichum boninense, derived from Crinum asiaticum in Japan. This detailed tabulation is essential for understanding the genetic diversity and distribution of Colletotrichum species in relation to their host plants.', 0.7598555684089661]]
Context 4: [['Purpose: To amplify and sequence GAPDH in Colletotrichum spp.', 0.6501131057739258]]
Context 5: [['Purpose: Specific primer for Colletotrichum spp. from GAPDH.', 0.6384750008583069]]
Context 6: [['Sherriff, C., Whelan, M. J., Arnold, G. M., Lafay, J. F., Brygoo, Y., Bailey, J. A. (1994). Ribosomal DNA sequence analysis reveals new species groupings in the genus Colletotrichum. Experimental Mycology 18: 121–138.', 0.45681309700012207]]
Context 7: [['Sherriff, C., Whelan, M.J., Arnold, G.M., Lafay, J.F., Brygoo, Y., and Bailey, J.A. (1994). Ribosomal DNA sequence analysis reveals new species groupings in the genus Colletotrichum. Experimental Mycology 18: 121-138.', 0.44186824560165405]]
Context 8: [['HaeIII RFLPs of A+T-rich DNA were successfully used to characterize Colletotrichum isolates from 10 species, with each representative revealing unique restriction patterns. The results of this approach were similar to those obtained using the GcpR1 repetitive element, where C. gloeosporioides isolates from almond exhibited unique band patterns, in contrast to the polymorphic fragments observed for avocado isolates. This method also facilitated the grouping of C. acutatum isolates from apple and peach, as well as differentiation among C. gloeosporioides isolates from almond, apple, avocado, and mango.', 0.4250304102897644]]
Context 9: [['In recent years, genome sequences for 28 species of Colletotrichum have been published, and comparative genomic studies have concentrated on genes associated with pathogenicity (Gan et al., 2013), host specialization (Baroncelli et al., 2016; Gan et al., 2016), and transitions between biotrophic and necrotrophic lifestyles (O’Connell et al., 2012), as well as between endophytic and parasitic lifestyles (Hacquard et al., 2016; Hiruma et al., 2016). Comparative analyses of secretomes have revealed that most predicted secreted proteins possess enzymatic activity, with many identified as candidate effectors (O’Connell et al., 2012; Gan et al., 2013; Baroncelli et al., 2016; Sanz-Martín et al., 2016). The host range of Colletotrichum species seems to be linked to gene loss or gain in families encoding carbohydrate-active enzymes (CAZymes) and proteases (Baroncelli et al., 2016). Notably, gene families encoding proteases and carbohydrate-degrading enzymes are significantly expanded in Colletotrichum compared to other Sordariomycetes (Gan et al., 2013; Baroncelli et al., 2016), indicating the increased importance of these families in the infection processes of Colletotrichum species. Transcriptional profiling experiments have also shown that CAZymes, along with other classes of secreted proteins, are highly modulated during the infection process, further implicating them as critical players in pathogenicity (Kleemann et al., 2012; O’Connell et al., 2012).', 0.4180389940738678]]

query: How does the C. acutatum species complex contribute to our understanding of fungal evolution?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Recently, more focus has been placed on conidium morphology, particularly shape and dimensions. The acute conidial ends that contribute to the typical fusiform shape are considered critical morphological features of C. acutatum (Simmonds 1965). However, the name C. acutatum has been applied to various species exhibiting fusiform conidia, many of which are closely related to C. acutatum s. str. Moreover, conidial shape can show significant variation both within the species and among strains (Damm et al. 2012). Studies have shown that the fusiform conidial shape is not a consistent feature in the C. acutatum species complex. For instance, Talhinhas et al. (2002) noted that Colletotrichum isolates from Lupinus spp. (equivalent to C. lupini) displayed varying proportions of conidia with round ends or one round and one acute end, resulting in cylindrical or clavate shapes. In a recent investigation, many strains previously classified as C. gloeosporioides, based on typical cylindrical conidia (Cannon et al. 2008), were found to belong to different species within the C. acutatum complex (Damm et al. 2012). Additionally, there are species with acute-ended conidia that are phylogenetically distinct from the C. acutatum complex, such as C. pseudoacutatum and C. proteae (Cannon et al. 2012; Damm et al. 2012; Liu et al. 2013). The revision of the C. acutatum complex has recognized 31 species through a multilocus molecular approach, significantly advancing our understanding of these plant pathogens (Damm et al. 2012).', 0.9386253356933594]]
Context 1: [['Members of the C. acutatum species complex have been well-documented from agricultural and natural hosts worldwide (Perfect et al., 1999; Peres et al., 2005; Sreenivasaprasad and Talhinhas, 2005). The scientific community has long studied the biomolecular processes regulating this lifestyle, especially those related to the switch from biotrophy to necrotrophy. The species complex has a very wide host range. Meta-analyses have revealed that C. acutatum s.l. strains are associated with infections in hundreds of species from over 90 genera of plants (Magnoliophyta: monocotyledons and dicotyledons, Pinophyta, and Pteridophyta), along with at least two insect species (Dufresne et al., 2000; Thon et al., 2002; Wharton and Diéguez-Uribeondo, 2004; O’Connell et al., 2012; Marcelino et al., 2008; Mascarin et al., 2016). In a few cases, associations have been noted with marine ecosystems (Manire et al., 2002; Namikoshi et al., 2002). There appears to be little to no evidence of co-evolution between host and pathogen, particularly in cultivated fruit systems like strawberry and olive, which are susceptible to many members of this species complex (Jayawardena et al., 2016).', 0.9218937158584595]]
Context 2: [['Our research aims to present a comprehensive revision of the C. acutatum species complex. We thoroughly survey the constituent taxa and delineate additional species where needed. We have examined a large number of C. acutatum s. lat. strains, isolated from various hosts and geographic areas. Multi-locus molecular analysis serves as the basis for species recognition, although morphological and cultural characters allowing alternative means of species recognition are provided where possible.', 0.6945796608924866]]
Context 3: [['This Perspective article presents a review of the current knowledge on C. acutatum phylogeny, biology, and pathology. It also demonstrates the suitability of C. acutatum for the study of gene family evolution on a fine scale to uncover evolutionary events in the genome associated with the evolution of phenotypic characters important for host interactions.', 0.6892532706260681]]
Context 4: [['At this point, it was widely presumed that C. acutatum was a species complex containing several constituent taxa. However, there was substantial reluctance to recognize the clades involved as independent species due to the lack of distinctive morphological and cultural characters. For example, C. lupini was not formally recognized as separate from C. acutatum by Talhinhas et al. (2002) or by Sreenivasaprasad & Talhinhas (2005). Some attempts were made to address these concerns through the adoption of formae speciales, such as C. acutatum f. sp. pineum (Dingley & Gilmour 1972), C. acutatum f. sp. hakeae (Lubbe et al. 2004), and C. acutatum f. sp. fioriniae (Marcelino et al. 2008). However, this mechanism for recognizing pathology-related taxa is now rarely used.', 0.5827714204788208]]
Context 5: [['For example, Damm et al. (2012a, b, this issue) report members of the C. acutatum and C. boninense species complexes, with isolates Ku4 = ICMP 18575 and Ku8 = ICMP 18618 referred to as C. asianum by Hyde et al. (2009). However, these isolates are genetically distinct from C. simmondsii, C. fioriniae, and C. karstii, and belong to C. siamense based on our analyses.', 0.5793015360832214]]
Context 6: [['The holotype of Glomerella acutata is therefore an interspecific hybrid between C. acutatum and C. fioriniae. This may be construed as strong evidence that these two taxa constitute a single biological species, suggesting that the species concepts used in this paper are too narrow. However, the parent strains of the holotype originate from geographically distant populations, and there are instances in other fungal groups (e.g., Neurospora) where non-sympatric populations lose post-mating reproductive isolation barriers (Turner et al. 2010, 2011). Further research on population structures and mating-type barriers would be instructive.', 0.5742360353469849]]
Context 7: [['The C. acutatum species complex has undergone speciation more prolifically than previously suspected, indicating that it is likely still evolving rapidly. The emergence of new species is likely encouraged by modern global agricultural practices, which facilitate the mixing of gene pools, combined with imperfect phytosanitary regulations.', 0.5345438718795776]]
Context 8: [['Gradually, separate species began to be recognized as part of the C. acutatum species complex, such as C. lupini (Nirenberg et al. 2002) and C. phormii (Farr et al. 2006). In a study using two genes, ITS and TUB2, along with morphological data, Shivas & Tan (2009) recognized three distinct groups within C. acutatum strains from Australia and accepted two new species, C. simmondsii and C. fioriniae (formerly C. acutatum f. sp. fioriniae) for groups A2 and A3. Recently, a new species was described for group A4, C. clavatum (Faedda et al. 2011).', 0.44610580801963806]]
Context 9: [['Shivas, R.G., Tan, Y.P. (2009). A taxonomic re-assessment of Colletotrichum acutatum, introducing C. fioriniae comb. et stat. nov. and C. simmondsii sp. nov. Fungal Diversity, 39, 111–122.', 0.43097013235092163]]

query: What methods were used for pathogen isolation in this study?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Pathogens were isolated from diseased petiole, leaf, stolon, or root tissues. The diseased plant tissues were first cut into 5 × 5 mm pieces using sterilized scissors. Excised tissue pieces were rinsed in a 75% ethanol solution for 30 seconds, soaked in a 3% sodium hypochlorite solution (active chlorine: 6.8%) for 3 minutes, rinsed three times with sterile distilled water, and then dried on sterile filter paper. After drying, each sample was placed on a plate containing potato dextrose agar (PDA) medium supplemented with a final concentration of 50 mg/ml of kanamycin sulfate and streptomycin sulfate to inhibit bacterial growth. The plate was incubated in darkness at 25 °C for 3 to 5 days. Hyphal growth was aseptically transferred to a new PDA plate (Cai et al. 2009; Phoulivong et al. 2010). Anthracnose isolates were identified and selected based on the morphological characteristics of each species. Isolates were maintained on PDA slants at 4 °C.', 0.3099488317966461]]
Context 1: [['Over the course of this study, hundreds of isolates have been examined. Most conform to specific group characteristics with enough consistency for reasonable classification. However, some isolates are challenging to classify, and the lack of spore formation in many cases hampers identity verification. These unusual forms are not included in the following descriptions.', 0.27702996134757996]]
Context 2: [['Three representative isolates of each species from each host were selected for pathogenicity testing. The isolates studied included: C. acutatum from chili (Mj4, Mj5, Mj10), C. capsici from chili (R4, Ccmj10, Skp4), C. gloeosporioides from chili (Ku4, Ku5, Ku8), C. acutatum from strawberry (S2, S4, S5), and C. gloeosporioides from mango (M1, M2, M4). The isolates were cultured on PDA at 27 °C under continuous fluorescent light, and conidia from 7-day-old cultures were harvested.', 0.24087747931480408]]
Context 3: [['Additional keywords: host–pathogen interaction, major gene.', 0.2279287874698639]]
Context 4: [['Ex-type strains or authentic cultures are indicated in bold.', 0.20635926723480225]]
Context 5: [['Location: Geographic location where the isolate was collected.', 0.200152188539505]]
Context 6: [['No. of test: Indicates the number of inoculation experiments conducted.', 0.1930517703294754]]
Context 7: [['Isolate Number: A unique identifier for each isolate.', 0.1864655315876007]]
Context 8: [['Not all Colletotrichum isolates were able to sporulate on PDA supplemented with 0.2% yeast extract (PDAY). Therefore, one isolate from each species that could sporulate on PDAY was selected for pathogenicity assays. The isolates included C. murrayae (Nj-2), C. gloeosporioides (Jsh-7-1), C. fructicola (Lch-39-2), C. aenigma (Lbwuh-4-2), and C. nymphaeae (Lch-5). These isolates were maintained on PDA with lactic acid at 28 °C for 5 days, and then 5 mm agar plugs were placed in the center of PDAY plates. The fungal isolates were grown at 28 °C under mixed white and near-UV fluorescent light for 12 hours of light and 12 hours of darkness. They sporulated profusely after 7 to 10 days. Plates were then flooded with sterile distilled water, and the spore suspension was filtered through cheesecloth to remove dislodged mycelia (Mangandi et al. 2015). The suspension was adjusted to 2 × 10^6 conidia/ml.', 0.18276666104793549]]
Context 9: [['To examine the variation of isolates within and between regions.', 0.18129649758338928]]

query: What do the shapes of Colletotrichum spores tell us?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Observations and measurements of conidial size and shape have usually been made using conidial masses mounted in water, cotton blue, or lactic acid (Cannon et al., 2008). It should be noted that many species of Colletotrichum produce secondary conidia in culture directly from germinated primary conidia; these may vary morphologically when compared to those produced in conidiomata (Cannon et al., 2000). Conidial and mycelial appressoria (also referred to as hyphopodia) are often described in Colletotrichum species. Sutton (1980) characterized the mycelial appressoria formed in potato-carrot agar (PCA) using a slide culture technique, while others have used potato dextrose agar (PDA) with incubation in the dark (Johnston and Jones, 1997; Malloch, 1981) or have observed mycelial appressoria formed on the undersurface of SNA cultures (Damm et al., 2009). Conidial appressoria have been recorded when conidia are germinated in drops of deionized water on plastic cover slips in a moist chamber (Johnson et al., 1997; Chaky et al., 2001). Conidial appressoria are taxonomically uninformative and of little use for species diagnosis (Sutton, 1980, 1992). However, Du et al. (2005) noted that the shape of appressoria can differentiate C. acutatum (with rather smooth appressoria) from C. gloeosporioides (with more lobed appressoria). Crouch et al. (2009b) found that appressoria shape and size are useful for delimiting grass-associated Colletotrichum species but should be used in combination with host range. Yang et al. (2009) found that conidial appressoria can distinguish two species of Colletotrichum from Amaryllidaceae. The conidial appressoria of C. hippeastri are larger than those of C. hymenocallidis and are irregular, crenate, or lobed, occasionally becoming complex. In contrast, C. hymenocallidis appressoria are ovate or sometimes clavate.', 0.9004029035568237]]
Context 1: [['Corresponding to the taxonomic classification determined by multi-locus phylogenetic analyses, most Colletotrichum species exhibited characteristic morphological features, including colony colors, the density of aerial mycelium, and the shapes and sizes of conidia, ascospores, appressoria, and setae (Fig. 7–18). These morphological characteristics have been used in previous studies to delimit species (Damm et al. 2012a, b, 2014; Liu et al. 2013a, 2015; Hou et al. 2016; Guarnaccia et al. 2017). Notably, the Colletotrichum species associated with pear anthracnose produced pigments that varied in color among species and isolates. Additionally, these species differed in their ability to form a sexual morph in culture.', 0.8429360389709473]]
Context 2: [['Cultural characteristics on agar media have been applied for the diagnosis of some Colletotrichum species (von Arx, 1957). The conidial morphology of C. gloeosporioides and C. lindemuthianum is similar, but their cultural characters are distinctly different. Colletotrichum lindemuthianum produces dark pigmentation in media and grows consistently slower than C. gloeosporioides (Baxter et al., 1983; Sutton, 1992). Likewise, C. musae grows relatively fast, forming effuse colonies and glabrous conidiomata with many conidia, while C. destructivum forms large conidiogenous zones with scattered, relatively short setae and has limited conidial production (Baxter et al., 1983). The shape and size of conidia and appressoria, as well as cultural characteristics, should be evaluated and used with caution, as these traits are highly dependent on growth conditions. Erroneous diagnosis can largely be avoided if morphology is used in conjunction with other characters such as molecular sequence data, biochemical and physiological characteristics, and host range. Crouch et al. (2009b) demonstrated that falcate-spored, grass-associated Colletotrichum species could be distinguished by a combination of molecular data, appressorial morphology, and host range. However, for most Colletotrichum species, host range has not been determined, and available information should be considered with caution, as it is often based on wrongly identified species (Damm et al., 2009).', 0.7325176000595093]]
Context 3: [['Available morphological characters of Colletotrichum species include: 1) characters on natural substrates, such as size and shape of conidiomata (acervuli), conidia, conidiophores, and setae; 2) size and shape of conidia, conidiophores, and setae in culture; and 3) size and shape of appressoria. Acervuli, setae, and conidial characters (shape and dimensions) on natural substrates can vary due to environmental factors, and conidia may be absent from infected host tissues. Some Colletotrichum species, such as C. musae and C. gossypii, consistently fail to produce setae in conidiomata (Sutton and Waterston, 1970), and their presence on natural hosts is often inconsistent for species diagnosis (von Arx, 1957; Sutton, 1966). Morphological characters may vary with environmental factors, and incubation conditions, such as media and temperature, should be standardized (Cannon et al., 2000) for species comparison and identification. Unfortunately, there is no recommended standard for...', 0.6775355339050293]]
Context 4: [['Traditionally, Colletotrichum species have been identified based on morphological characteristics. Taxonomists have utilized several features, including the size and shape of conidia and appressoria, the presence or absence of setae, sclerotia, acervuli, and teleomorph states, as well as cultural characters such as colony color, growth rate, and texture (Simmonds, 1965; Smith and Black, 1990; Sutton, 1992; TeBeest et al., 1997; Photita et al., 2005; Than et al., 2008a-c; Thaung, 2008). However, these criteria alone are not always sufficient for reliable differentiation among Colletotrichum species due to variations in morphology and phenotype influenced by environmental factors.', 0.6593424081802368]]
Context 5: [['The table lists seven species of Colletotrichum, detailing the conidial measurements in micrometers (µm) as well as the general mean descriptions of the cultures. The measurements include ranges for length and width, with specific averages provided for each species. For example, C. gloeosporioides has a range of means from 11.9 to 17.0 by 3.6 to 5.8 µm, with a general mean of 13.8 by 4.8 µm. The descriptions provide insights into the morphology of the spores, such as whether they are oblong, slender, or crescent-shaped, highlighting distinctive features that aid in species recognition.', 0.6443097591400146]]
Context 6: [['Conidia are formed directly from the germ tube of a germinating primary conidium, and these are smaller and more irregular in form than those from which they are derived (Buddie et al. 1999). Additionally, older strains, especially if they have been frequently subcultured, may exhibit more variable conidia in appearance than those derived from recent stock. Nirenberg et al. (2002) observed that shapes differed among conidia formed in acervuli and in the aerial mycelium. The variation in conidial shape has led to species within the C. acutatum complex being incorrectly placed into synonymy with other Colletotrichum species, primarily C. gloeosporioides—this is a legacy of the revision of the genus by von Arx (1957). His work marked a new era in the understanding of Colletotrichum systematics (Cannon et al. 2012, this issue), but many of the synonymies proposed were inaccurate.', 0.5080100297927856]]
Context 7: [['Colletotrichum spp. are currently identified using morpho-taxonomic criteria, such as morphological characters, including conidial shape and size, appressorium morphology and size, and setae morphology, as well as temperature response on potato dextrose agar (PDA) medium. Recently, various molecular approaches have been employed to discriminate among different Colletotrichum spp. or to study the genetic diversity within these species. query: Can I replant strawberries in the same field after an anthracnose outbreak?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['From May to September 1995, a severe outbreak of strawberry anthracnose was observed in several strawberry-growing nurseries in Israel. Following transplantation to production fields during September and October, entire beds of strawberry plants collapsed. Typical anthracnose symptoms observed from November 1995 to June 1996 included crown rot, flower blight, and green and ripe fruit rot. This marked the first record of strawberry anthracnose in Israel. Furthermore, in at least four production fields in the same region, hundreds of plants developed symptoms of stunting and chlorosis, which are atypical of strawberry anthracnose. When these plants were uprooted, most of their roots were dark brown and decayed. Colletotrichum was readily isolated from these samples.', 0.6484130620956421]]
Context 1: [['Anthracnose is an important disease of strawberry caused by Colletotrichum spp., which affects foliage, runners, crowns, and fruits (Howard et al., 1992). Three primary fungal pathogens—C. acutatum sensu lato, C. gloeosporioides sensu lato, and C. fragariae—are known to cause anthracnose disease in strawberries (Freeman and Katan, 1997). The crown rot syndrome is characteristic of infections from C. gloeosporioides sensu lato and C. fragariae, while fruit rot is mainly attributed to C. acutatum sensu lato, leading to significant yield losses (Howard et al., 1992). Currently, numerous species are classified under what is now known as the C. acutatum complex, with six species—C. acutatum sensu stricto, C. fioriniae, C. godetiae, C. nymphaeae, C. salicis, and C. simmondsii—identified as associated with strawberry anthracnose worldwide (Damm et al., 2012). Among these, C. nymphaeae is the most prevalent pathogen causing strawberry anthracnose globally, including in Iran (Baroncelli et al., 2015; Karimi et al., 2017; Wang et al., 2019). Currently, no effective chemical control methods exist for managing strawberry anthracnose; available options are limited to preventive treatments applied before fruit production (Denoyes-Rothan et al., 1999). Additionally, concerns about the toxic effects of chemical fungicides on the environment and the development of resistance in fungal strains highlight the need for alternative control strategies. Consequently, utilizing resistant cultivars appears to be the most efficient and practical approach for suppressing anthracnose development. In light of recent anthracnose outbreaks in strawberry fields in the Kurdistan province of Iran (Karimi et al., 2017), and the necessity for appropriate strategies to address this issue, the aim of this study was to evaluate the resistance of several commercial strawberry cultivars to the anthracnose fruit rot caused by C. nymphaeae under in vivo and greenhouse conditions.', 0.5290126204490662]]

query: What do farmers do to protect their strawberries from getting sick?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Although strawberries are considered a minor crop, they provide a significant source of income for many fruit and nursery growers. In the United States, strawberries were cultivated on nearly 20,000 hectares in 1989, yielding a total production of 555,000 tons valued at $520 million. Florida ranks second only to California in the production of fresh-market strawberries. For U.S. winter production (December through March), strawberries are grown on approximately 2,400 hectares. The major cultural problems faced by the Florida strawberry industry include: 1) anthracnose diseases, 2) yearly infestations of the two-spotted spider mite (Tetranychus urticae Koch), and 3) variability in the quality of nursery transplants. Commercial fields are established annually, similar to California practices. Freshly dug transplants are sourced from nurseries in Florida or from northern states and Canada. The use of transplants from northern nurseries is crucial to avoid anthracnose disease issues and to ensure that plants have undergone sufficient natural chilling to induce floral bud initiation.', 0.27546337246894836]]

query: How do vegetative compatibility tests contribute to understanding pathogen populations?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Downloaded from https://academic.oup.com/mbe/article-abstract/35/6/1547/4990887.', 0.23255090415477753]]
Context 1: [['Horizontal resistance is effective against all isolates of a pathogen, while vertical resistance is effective against a subset of isolates. These terms are synonymous with race-non-specific and race-specific resistance, respectively. In pathosystems where race-specific resistance occurs, an incompatible interaction between the host and pathogen often requires a dominant host resistance gene and a dominant pathogen avirulence gene. Such interactions are described by the gene-for-gene hypothesis. Race-non-specific resistance is less understood but is believed to be governed by multiple host genes that incrementally contribute to the overall resistance of the plant. Vanderplank proposed using analysis of variance to determine the contribution of race-non-specific and/or race-specific resistance within a host population against a group of pathogen isolates. The absence of a cultivar by isolate interaction is evidence of race-non-specific resistance using this method. A cultivar by isolate interaction suggests that race-specific mechanisms contribute to the resistance observed within the host population, although deviations from additivity could be responsible for the statistical interaction. Deviations from additivity arise from the scale used to measure resistance, while rank changes are consistent with physiological responses.', 0.20092685520648956]]

query: Can plant nutrition affect the severity of anthracnose?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Anthracnose is a significant disease affecting grape crops (Dowling et al., 2020). Beyond causing severe yield losses, anthracnose epidemics can diminish the quality of the produce (Waller et al., 2002; Dowling et al., 2020). The most economically damaging symptoms often include blossom blight and fruit rots; however, necrotic lesions may also develop on leaves, stems, and twigs, leading to plant deterioration and reduced fruit quality (Dowling et al., 2020).', 0.4223747253417969]]
Context 1: [['Anthracnose spreads within a field by splashing water, and living mulches (such as wheat, rye, or ryegrass) in row middles have been shown to reduce disease spread within a field. Sublethal doses of grass-specific herbicides, such as sethoxydim, may be used to prevent excessive growth of ryegrass (Gupton, 2000). Organic mulches, such as wheat straw or pine needles, also reduce splash and result in a lower incidence of anthracnose compared to rows mulched with plastic (Madden, 1992; Smith and Spiers, 1986). Additionally, anthracnose is less severe when water is supplied to plants using drip irrigation rather than overhead irrigation (Madden, 1992; Smith and Spiers, 1986). Anthracnose crown rot was observed to be less severe in commercial fields when strawberries were grown in soils with low nitrogen fertility (Howard et al., 1992). In greenhouse studies, Smith (1987, 1989) determined that strawberries grown in soils with high levels of nitrogen, especially from ammonium sources, are more susceptible to anthracnose than plants grown in soils with lower nitrogen levels or those with high levels of calcium nitrate.', 0.3344186842441559]]
Context 2: [['Additional Keywords: anthracnose, disease spread, Fragaria × ananassa, models, quantitative epidemiology.', 0.23358745872974396]]

query: What are the primary hosts of C. acutatum in addition to strawberries?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['The role of alternative hosts in the disease cycles caused by C. acutatum is also not well understood. The fungus can infect both anemones and strawberries, suggesting potential spread between these crops. Research has shown that C. acutatum is capable of colonizing surrounding weeds, such as Vicia spp. and Conyza spp., and can survive for three months on the leaves of tomatoes, peppers, and eggplants. This indicates that the pathogen could spread from strawberries to adjacent weeds and then reinfest new strawberry fields in subsequent years. Molecular and vegetative compatibility studies have indicated that isolates from weeds, anemones, and strawberries form a single population in Israel. Further studies demonstrated that while C. acutatum initially fails to penetrate the tissues of peppers, eggplants, and tomatoes, intercellular penetration occurs later, suggesting the fungus may live as an endophyte on these hosts.', 0.9951646327972412]]
Context 1: [['Some host plants appear to be particularly susceptible to infection by multiple Colletotrichum taxa. The occurrence of species on strawberry has been well researched due to the former status of C. acutatum as a regulated quarantine pathogen. We found that strains from this host belong to six different clades within the C. acutatum species complex: C. simmondsii (three strains from Australia), C. nymphaeae (38 strains, mostly from Europe and the USA), C. fioriniae (seven strains from New Zealand, the UK, and the USA), C. godetiae (10 strains, all from Europe), C. acutatum s. str. (one strain from Australia), and C. salicis (four strains from New Zealand). A study by MacKenzie et al. (2009) demonstrated that strains from strawberry were more aggressive to strawberry than strains from Vaccinium. Based on TUB2 sequences generated by those authors, the strains from strawberry were assigned to C. nymphaeae, while the strains from Vaccinium were assigned to C. fioriniae. The apparent differences in pathogenicity may not stem from the different hosts but rather from the fact that the strains studied belong to different species. To our knowledge, C. acutatum s. str. has rarely been found in Europe, and then mostly on ornamental plants. So far, it has only been isolated from strawberry in Australia. In pathogenicity tests by Talhinhas et al. (2005), an isolate of C. acutatum s. str. from olive caused anthracnose symptoms on strawberry fruits; its virulence was comparable to that of group A2 (C. nymphaeae and related species), A3 (C. fioriniae), or A4 (C. godetiae). If further quarantine regulation is to be implemented, beyond the generalized prohibition of contamination by any members of the C. acutatum species complex, more rigorous diagnostic methods will be needed.', 0.993722140789032]]
Context 2: [['C. acutatum was first described as a separate species by Simmonds. Many isolates now identified as C. acutatum were either classified under C. gloeosporioides or considered species of Gloeo sporium. C. acutatum affects hosts that are also targeted by other Colletotrichum species, possibly leading to its earlier misidentification. For instance, strawberries can be affected by C. acutatum, C. gloeosporioides, and C. fragariae. The latter two typically cause petiole and stolon lesions, as well as crown rot on strawberries.', 0.9935407042503357]]
Context 3: [['On strawberry plants, C. acutatum primarily causes black spot disease on the fruit but can also affect crowns, roots, and leaves (Freeman & Katan 1997), making it one of the most serious diseases in commercial fruit production. The conidia are formed in acervuli on the host, while in culture, they can also be produced in the aerial mycelium (Johnston & Jones 1997). C. acutatum has been observed to form secondary conidia on living strawberry leaves, stimulated by extracts from the strawberry plant, especially flower extracts (Leandro et al. 2001; Leandro et al. 2003). According to Buddie et al. (1999), secondary conidia may be produced directly from germinating primary conidia, and these are generally smaller and more variable in shape, which can obscure the differences between taxa. Additionally, C. acutatum forms simple pigmented appressoria but has few or no setae (Simmonds 1965).', 0.9926853179931641]]
Context 4: [['In Israel, where strawberries are cultivated near crops such as tomato, eggplant, pepper, and other vegetables, as well as various weed species, the potential for cross-inoculation is of extreme importance. An identical genotype of C. acutatum was recovered from natural field infections of both strawberry and anemone in Israel. Therefore, the main objectives of this study were to assess the persistence and interactions of C. acutatum on its primary host, strawberry, and other plant species that may serve as potential inoculum sources for this pathogen under suitable conditions.', 0.9891195297241211]]
Context 5: [['In Israel, inoculation of isolates of C. acutatum from anemone and strawberry into each host resulted in typical anthracnose symptoms on both plant species. Molecular studies indicated that the isolates from the two hosts were similar and formed a single genetic subgroup. Isolates of C. acutatum were recovered from pepper, eggplant, tomato, bean, as well as from weeds of the genera Vicia and Conyza; however, disease symptoms occurred only on strawberry. C. acutatum isolates from tulip tree in Argentina were also pathogenic to strawberry fruit. Thus, strawberry isolates of C. acutatum can parasitize and cause disease on other hosts or, alternatively, survive on other crops and weeds without producing symptoms.', 0.9887222051620483]]
Context 6: [['Colletotrichum acutatum isolates produced fusiform conidia that were tapered at both ends, developed colonies in colors including white, pink, orange, rose, or beige, and did not produce setae or the ascigerous state in culture. The growth rate of C. acutatum in culture was slower than that of the other two species at all tested temperatures, with the greatest difference observed at 32°C. C. fragariae, the original anthracnose fungus, was first identified in Florida in 1931 (Brooks, 1931). It spread throughout the southeastern United States and was responsible for crown rot and the death of many plants in strawberry nurseries during the 1970s (Horn et al., 1972). This pathogen has a narrow host range, infecting only strawberries and a few weed hosts, and is rarely found outside the southeastern United States.', 0.9857739210128784]]
Context 7: [['While C. acutatum infections are frequently observed in strawberry production fields, it has been suggested that quiescently infected transplants from nurseries serve as the primary inoculum source for field infections (Howard et al. 1992; Peres et al. 2005). In Florida, strawberries are treated as annual crops and are cultivated throughout the winter. However, during the hot summer months, extreme temperatures negatively impact the survival of C. acutatum in soil and plant debris (Ureña-Padilla et al. 2001).', 0.9855508804321289]]
Context 8: [['C. acutatum was isolated from two weeds, Conyza spp. and Vicia spp., that infested strawberry fields. The weed isolates were similar to those from strawberry, as demonstrated by PCR analysis, and caused typical anthracnose symptoms on strawberry. Thus, not only crop plants but also weeds may be colonized by C. acutatum. This aligns with the detection of C. fragariae, pathogenic to strawberry, on weeds such as chickweed, coffeeweed, sicklepod, fiddleneck, and vetch, growing in containers and around nurseries in Florida. Similarly, strawberry and anemone cultivated in close proximity in Israel were found to be infected by an identical genotype of C. acutatum.', 0.9847692251205444]]
Context 9: [['Fungal isolates: The 62 isolates of C. acutatum isolated from strawberry were selected from various collections representing a range of isolation dates (1978 to 1998) and geographic regions worldwide. Nineteen C. acutatum isolates from other host plants were included in the study for comparison. Among these 81 isolates, 22 exhibiting pink chromogenic coloring in culture are referred to as C. acutatum chromogenic. Additionally, 13 isolates of C. gloeosporioides from strawberries originating from Europe and the United States, as well as one isolate from mango used as an outgroup, were studied. All isolates were single-conidia cultures. Stock cultures were maintained on silica gel at 4°C as described by Perkins. Cultures were initiated by transferring silica gel particles from the stock cultures to PDA (Potato Dextrose Agar) plates to produce fungal material for molecular analysis and pathogenicity tests. All isolates were identified using classical taxonomic criteria, such as conidial shape and growth on PDA.', 0.9840825796127319]]

query: What experimental findings suggest that 'Blakemore' and 'Kurdistan' are more disease-resistant compared to 'Camarosa' and 'Gaviota', and what does this mean for the future of strawberry farming?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [["Strawberry anthracnose fruit rot (AFR) is one of the main limiting factors for the strawberry production industry worldwide, including Iran. Due to restrictions associated with fungicide applications, their adverse environmental effects, and the potential development of resistance among fungal strains, the use of resistant cultivars is considered the most effective method for managing this disease. This study evaluated the reactions of 25 commercial strawberry cultivars against the fungus Colletotrichum nymphaeae, which causes AFR, using fruit, leaf, and crown-based assays. Results indicated that the cultivars exhibited varying reactions to the disease, depending on the inoculation of their leaves, fruits, and crowns with C. nymphaeae PET1 under in vivo and greenhouse conditions. The fruit-based assay was determined to be a better indicator of susceptibility to AFR due to the nature of the disease. Overall, 'Blakemore' and 'Kurdistan' cultivars showed significantly higher resistance compared to others, except for 'Aliso', 'Mrak', 'Diamant', 'Yallova', 'New Kurdistan', 'Mac Donance', and 'Ten Beauty'. Conversely, the 'Gaviota' cultivar was found to be significantly the most susceptible, aside from 'Camarosa'. The commonly grown commercial cultivars in Iran, including 'Camarosa', 'Paros', 'Pajaro', and 'Queen Eliza', were categorized as susceptible to highly susceptible in this study. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first study evaluating the reaction of commercial strawberry cultivars to C. nymphaeae causing strawberry AFR.", 0.9955708384513855]]
Context 1: [['Cultivars such as ‘Camarosa’ and ‘Gaviota’ showed high disease severity, while others like ‘Blakemore’ and ‘Kurdistan’ demonstrated significant resistance across the assays.', 0.9479016065597534]]
Context 2: [['In this study, most commercial cultivars, including ‘Paros’, ‘Queen Eliza’, ‘N. Selva’, and ‘Camarosa’, commonly grown in strawberry fields in Iran, were categorized as susceptible. Therefore, deploying relatively resistant cultivars such as ‘Blackmore’, ‘Aliso’, ‘Mark’, ‘Diamant’, and ‘Yallova’ could be effective in preventing disease development in regions where the disease is endemic. Additionally, cultivars with relative resistance may be crossed with commercial cultivars in breeding programs to improve and develop resistant varieties. To the best of our knowledge, this study represents the first attempt to evaluate the reaction of certain commercial strawberry cultivars against Colletotrichum nymphaeae, which causes strawberry AFR.', 0.39872899651527405]]
Context 3: [['Strawberries (Fragaria×ananassa Duch.) are a widely cultivated hybrid species within the Rosaceae family, renowned for their fruit. They are increasingly significant for the agricultural economic development of countries like Iran, particularly in the Kurdistan province, which leads in strawberry production, predominantly under open-field conditions (Tehranifar and Sarsaefi, 2002). Various biotic and abiotic factors contribute to the decline in strawberry production globally. Notably, over 100 fungal species can invade strawberry plants, with approximately one-third causing serious diseases on different plant parts (Martin and others).', 0.3404940366744995]]
Context 4: [['Additionally, all cultivars except ‘Gaviota’, FL 99-164, ‘Carmine’, and ‘Camino Real’ were tested in at least two seasons. ‘Treasure’ was identified as more resistant, while ‘Gaviota’ was found to be more susceptible than any of the other cultivars examined. ‘Strawberry Festival’ had an intermediate level of resistance, approximately the same as that of ‘Aromas’.', 0.25853055715560913]]

query: What unique genetic elements help differentiate Colletotrichum species?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Despite significant developments over the last ten years, the taxonomy of Colletotrichum is in a state of flux. Many uncertainties exist in the systematics of fungal pathogens from this genus; depending on the taxonomic "guides," the number of species can range from 29 to over 700 (von Arx, 1957; Sutton, 1992). One of the most confusing species is C. gloeosporioides. For example, 594 species of Colletotrichum were reclassified by von Arx as synonyms of C. gloeosporioides. Identification has primarily relied on morphological characteristics of conidia, vegetative and sexual structures, as well as host specificity and cultural characteristics (von Arx, 1957). Unfortunately, conidial morphology and colony characteristics vary even within isolates. Consequently, classical methods have been supplemented with biochemical and molecular technologies to differentiate Colletotrichum species (J. W. Kronstad, ed., Fungal Pathology, 127-148. © 2000 Kluwer Academic Publishers). For a more complete discussion of this topic, see Sherriff et al. (1994).', 0.9685924053192139]]
Context 1: [['The genus Colletotrichum is considered one of the top ten important genera of fungal pathogens globally (Dean et al., 2012). Colletotrichum is an ancient fungus that has co-evolved with flowering plants. Plant microfossils of Protocolletotrichum preserved on angiosperm leaf cuticles suggest that the diverse pathogenic strategies of Colletotrichum spp. have been established since the Late Cretaceous period (Kar et al., 2004). Different complexes within the genus may have diverged between 4.8 and 32.2 million years ago (MYA) (Bhunjun et al., 2021). The emergence of agricultural cultivation and the intensive disturbance of natural environments have further driven the diversification of Colletotrichum species. These fungi have adapted to thousands of hosts and can be found as endophytes, pathogens, and saprobes (Freeman et al., 1998; Dean et al., 2012; Hirayama et al., 2018; da Silva et al., 2020; Jayawardena et al., 2020). Currently, a total of 257 Colletotrichum species grouped into 15 complexes and 13 additional singletons have been accepted in this genus.', 0.8546173572540283]]
Context 2: [['In a drastic move, von Arx (1957) reduced the number of recognized Colletotrichum species from several hundred to 11 based on morphological characteristics, with many taxa treated as synonyms of C. gloeosporioides and C. dematium. Several additional species have since been accepted based on morphological criteria (Sutton, 1980; 1992). The difficulties in recognizing Colletotrichum species can be attributed to: 1) the limited and variable morphological characters; 2) an extensive host range and variability in pathogenicity (Bailey and Jeger, 1992; Freeman et al., 2000; Latunde-Dada, 2001; Du et al., 2005; Thaung, 2008); 3) type specimens that are often missing or in poor condition, making them unsuitable for molecular studies; and 4) numerous rDNA ITS sequences of Colletotrichum strains in NCBI that are often misidentified (Crouch et al., 2009d; Damm et al., 2009).', 0.7307919263839722]]
Context 3: [['The name Colletotrichum was first introduced by Tode (1790) under the genus Vermicularia. The genus Colletotrichum itself was established by Corda (1831) and is now recognized as comprising “coelomycetes” with a Glomerella teleomorph stage (Sutton, 1992; Shenoy et al., 2007a; Hyde et al., 2009). This genus includes species with endophytic, epiphytic, saprobic, and phytopathogenic lifestyles (Kumar and Hyde, 2004; Photita et al., 2001a,b).', 0.5461440086364746]]
Context 4: [['Citation: Cai, L., Hyde, K.D., Taylor, P.W.J., Weir, B.S., Waller, J., Abang, M.M., Zhang, J.Z., Yang, Y.L., Phoulivong, S., Liu, Z.Y., Prihastuti, H., Shivas, R.G., McKenzie, E.H.C., Johnston, P.R. (2009). A polyphasic approach for studying Colletotrichum. Fungal Diversity, 39: 183-204.', 0.4435059130191803]]
Context 5: [['Table 2 provides a comprehensive list of various species of the genus Colletotrichum, including their culture accession numbers and the host plants from which they were isolated. Each entry specifies the country of origin and includes corresponding GenBank accession numbers for the ITS, GAPDH, ACT, and CHS-1 genes. The species range from Colletotrichum aenigmay, isolated from Persea americana in Israel, to Colletotrichum boninense, derived from Crinum asiaticum in Japan. This detailed tabulation is essential for understanding the genetic diversity and distribution of Colletotrichum species in relation to their host plants.', 0.37330517172813416]]

Context 9: [['Hyde, K.D., Cai, L., Cannon, P.F., Crouch, J.A., Crous, P.W., Damm, U., Goodwin, P.H., Chen, H., Johnston, P.R., Jones, E.B.G., Liu, Z.Y., McKenzie, E.H.C., Moriwaki, J., Noireung, P., Pennycook, S.R., Pfenning, L.H., Prihastuti, H., Sato, T., Shivas, R.G., Tan, Y.P., Taylor, P.W.J., Weir, B.S., Yang, Y.L., Zhang, J.Z., 2009. query: What percentage of isolates were found to belong to the Colletotrichum boninense species complex?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['The 86 isolates studied are assigned to 18 species within the Colletotrichum boninense complex based on DNA sequence data and morphology, including 12 species that are new to science. Ten species form teleomorph stages in vitro, four species have known anamorphs described in Colletotrichum, while one species, G. phyllanthi, has a known teleomorph and is identified here as belonging to the Colletotrichum boninense species complex. All species studied in culture are characterized below.', 0.9961808919906616]]
Context 1: [["Table Description: The table in this context presents a list of 86 isolates assigned to the Colletotrichum boninense complex, detailing their distribution among 18 species based on DNA sequence data and morphological characteristics. It highlights that 12 of these species are newly identified. The table includes identifiers for various strains, indicating both their origins and the specific species classifications, thereby contributing to the understanding of the complex's diversity and the relationships between the species.", 0.9912142157554626]]
Context 2: [['Notes: The four isolates identified from Indonesia in the Colletotrichum boninense complex produced distinct short conidia compared to the ex-epitype culture of C. karsti (14.5–17 × 5–6.5 µm; Yang et al., 2011). However, high variability in conidia size among different strains of C. karsti was reported by Damm et al. (2012a, 2012b), where the conidia measurements of CBS 129833 were (11.5–)12.5–14(−14.5) × (5–)5.5–6(−6.5) µm, with mean ± SD = 13.1 ± 0.7 × 5.8 ± 0.4 µm. Additionally, CBS 111998 had a conidium length of up to 18.5 µm, with an L/W ratio of 2.8. These isolates did not form a sexual morph in culture. Although these four isolates formed a fully supported (100% bootstrap support / 1 posterior probability) subclade within C. karsti, all individual gene trees (data not shown) did not provide significant support to justify introducing a cryptic species for these isolates.', 0.9900360107421875]]
Context 3: [['Species of the C. boninense complex appear to be concentrated in certain regions of the world and prefer specific host plants. Isolates discussed in this paper and found through nucleotide BLAST searches of GenBank mainly originate from New Zealand/Australia, South and East Asia (Japan, China, Taiwan, Thailand, Vietnam, India), South and Central America (Colombia, Brazil, Panama, Mexico, Guyana), and South and East Africa (South Africa, Zimbabwe, Kenya). A number of isolates from Europe (Italy, Netherlands, Germany, and probably Hungary) have been associated with indoor/greenhouse plants (such as Dracaena, Hippeastrum, and Gossypium species, as well as several orchids) or air from greenhouses containing orchids (Magyar et al. 2011). A few samples from Coffea arabica and Leucospermum originated from the USA (Hawaii), and one sample from Protea obtusifolia was sourced from Madeira (Portugal).', 0.987643837928772]]
Context 4: [['Although recently described, Colletotrichum boninense is well established in the literature as an anthracnose pathogen or endophyte of various host plants worldwide. It is especially prominent on members of Amaryllidaceae, Orchidaceae, Proteaceae, and Solanaceae. Reports from literature and preliminary studies using ITS sequence data indicated that C. boninense represents a species complex. A multilocus molecular phylogenetic analysis (ITS, ACT, TUB2, CHS-1, GAPDH, HIS3, CAL) of 86 strains previously identified as C. boninense and other related strains revealed 18 clades. These clades are recognized here as separate species, including C. boninense s. str., C. hippeastri, C. karstii, and 12 previously undescribed species: C. annellatum, C. beeveri, C. brassicicola, C. brasiliense, C. colombiense, C. constrictum, C. cymbidiicola, C. dacrycarpi, C. novae-zelandiae, C. oncidii, C. parsonsiae, and C. torulosum. Seven of the new species are known only from New Zealand, possibly reflecting a sampling bias. The new combination C. phyllanthi was established, and C. dracaenae Petch was epitypified and renamed as C. petchii. Typical for species of the C. boninense species complex are conidiogenous cells with prominent periclinal thickening, which may extend to form a new conidiogenous locus or annellations, and conidia featuring a prominent basal scar. Many species in the C. boninense complex form teleomorphs in culture.', 0.9849270582199097]]
Context 5: [['None of the morphological characters of C. boninense allow for unequivocal identification, and misplacement of strains based solely on morphology is common. For instance, Lu et al. (2004) classified one isolate as C. gloeosporioides based on morphological features but re-identified it as C. boninense using molecular techniques. Colletotrichum dracaenae Petch (here epitypified and renamed as C. petchii) was considered a synonym of C. gloeosporioides by von Arx (1957). Our study indicates that C. petchii does not belong to C. gloeosporioides s. lat. but rather to the C. boninense species complex, although its conidia largely resemble those of C. gloeosporioides with their relatively large length/width ratio.', 0.9837046265602112]]
Context 6: [['Damm U, Cannon PF, Woudenberg JH, Johnston PR, and Weir BS et al. (2012) examined the Colletotrichum boninense species complex in Studies in Mycology (73: 1-36). Prihastuti H, Cai L, Chen H, McKenzie EHC, and Hyde KD (2009) characterized Colletotrichum species associated with coffee berries in northern Thailand, as discussed in Fungal Diversity (39: 89-109).', 0.9766358137130737]]
Context 7: [['In the C. boninense species complex, 13 isolates clustered with C. karstii, and one with C. citricola. For the remaining 11 isolates, one clustered with C. plurivorum, while five isolates formed a distinct clade as sister to Colletotrichum sp. isolate CGMCC3.15172 in the C. dematium species complex. Additionally, the remaining five isolates, which formed a distinct clade, clustered distantly from any known Colletotrichum species complex.', 0.954352855682373]]
Context 8: [['Damm, U. et al. The Colletotrichum boninense Species Complex. Studies in Mycology 73, 1–36 (2012b).', 0.9369106292724609]]
Context 9: [['Damm, U., Cannon, P. F., Woudenberg, J. H. C., Johnston, P. R., Weir, B. S., Tan, Y. P., Shivas, R. G., and Crous, P. W. (2012b). The Colletotrichum boninense species complex. Stud. Mycol., 73, 1-36.', 0.934917688369751]]
