query: Can diseases like anthracnose spread faster if it rains a lot?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Anthracnose spreads within a field through splashing water. Living mulches, such as wheat, rye, or rye grass, in row middles have been shown to reduce disease spread. Organic mulches like wheat straw or pine needles also reduce splash and result in a lower incidence of anthracnose compared to rows mulched with plastic (Coelho et al., 2008; Madden, 1992; Smith and Spiers, 1986). Additionally, anthracnose is less severe when water is supplied to plants using drip irrigation rather than overhead irrigation (Coelho et al., 2008; Madden, 1992; Smith and Spiers, 1986).', 0.25909608602523804]]
Context 1: [['Additional Keywords: anthracnose, disease spread, Fragaria × ananassa, models, quantitative epidemiology.', 0.25643619894981384]]
Context 2: [['Figure 1 illustrates the anthracnose disease cycle in tropical fruit crops, drawn by Latiffah Zakaria. Anthracnose pathogens infect not only fruits but also other plant organs, including leaves, flowers, twigs, and branches. The conidia and spores formed in these infected tissues are released and dispersed during rainy days or periods of high humidity, becoming the primary inoculum for fruit infection at the preharvest stage. The most visible anthracnose symptoms are black or dark brown sunken lesions that contain conidial masses on the surface of infected fruits. Small individual lesions can merge to form larger lesions. These dark lesions on the fruit surface are unattractive to consumers and significantly reduce the market value of the affected fruits. Figures 2A–E display anthracnose lesions on several tropical fruit crops.', 0.23948785662651062]]
Context 3: [['Danneberger, T. K., Vargas, J. M. Jr., and Jones, A. L. (1984). A model for weather-based forecasting of anthracnose on annual bluegrass. Phytopathology 74, 448–451. doi: 10.1094/Phyto-74-448.', 0.23785221576690674]]
Context 4: [['Anthracnose spreads within a field by splashing water, and living mulches (such as wheat, rye, or ryegrass) in row middles have been shown to reduce disease spread within a field. Sublethal doses of grass-specific herbicides, such as sethoxydim, may be used to prevent excessive growth of ryegrass (Gupton, 2000). Organic mulches, such as wheat straw or pine needles, also reduce splash and result in a lower incidence of anthracnose compared to rows mulched with plastic (Madden, 1992; Smith and Spiers, 1986). Additionally, anthracnose is less severe when water is supplied to plants using drip irrigation rather than overhead irrigation (Madden, 1992; Smith and Spiers, 1986). Anthracnose crown rot was observed to be less severe in commercial fields when strawberries were grown in soils with low nitrogen fertility (Howard et al., 1992). In greenhouse studies, Smith (1987, 1989) determined that strawberries grown in soils with high levels of nitrogen, especially from ammonium sources, are more susceptible to anthracnose than plants grown in soils with lower nitrogen levels or those with high levels of calcium nitrate.', 0.22112247347831726]]
Context 5: [['Anthracnose spreads within a field by splashing water, and living mulches (such as wheat, rye, or ryegrass) in row middles have been shown to reduce disease spread within a field. Sublethal doses of grass-specific herbicides, such as sethoxydim, may be used to prevent excessive growth of ryegrass (Gupton, 2000). Organic mulches, such as wheat straw or pine needles, also reduce splash and result in a lower incidence of anthracnose compared to rows mulched with plastic (Madden, 1992; Smith and Spiers, 1986). Anthracnose is less severe when water is supplied to plants using drip irrigation rather than overhead irrigation (Madden, 1992; Smith and Spiers, 1986).', 0.2092680037021637]]
Context 6: [['Additional keywords: anthracnose, microcyclic conidiation, phyllosphere ecology.', 0.17594489455223083]]
Context 7: [['In this research, we developed a general, weather-driven, mechanistic model for predicting anthracnose diseases caused by Colletotrichum spp. on the aerial parts of different host plants in the field. Previous models for anthracnose diseases were species- and crop-specific and considered only one component of the pathogen life cycle, mainly conidial infection (Dodd et al., 1991; Park et al., 1992; Monroe et al., 1997; Moral et al., 2012; Singh, 2020). To the best of our knowledge, this is the first time that such a model has been developed, calibrated for different clades and host plants, and evaluated to make predictions of anthracnose patterns across multiple crops.', 0.17266276478767395]]

query: How do you differentiate anthracnose from other common strawberry diseases?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['The term "anthracnose" was first used to describe a new disease of strawberries caused by Colletotrichum fragariae Brooks. "Strawberry anthracnose" continues to be used as a general term to identify all diseases of strawberries caused by species of Colletotrichum. Strawberry anthracnose diseases have been reported to be caused by C. acutatum J.H. Simmonds, C. gloeosporioides (Penz.) Penz. & Sacc. in Penz. (the teleomorph of Cromereilla cingulata (Stoneman) Spauld. & H. Schrenk), and C. dematium (Pers.) Grove. The latter species only occasionally causes strawberry fruit rots and will not be discussed here.', 0.9498551487922668]]
Context 1: [['Anthracnose is an important disease of strawberry caused by Colletotrichum spp., which affects foliage, runners, crowns, and fruits (Howard et al., 1992). Three primary fungal pathogens—C. acutatum sensu lato, C. gloeosporioides sensu lato, and C. fragariae—are known to cause anthracnose disease in strawberries (Freeman and Katan, 1997). The crown rot syndrome is characteristic of infections from C. gloeosporioides sensu lato and C. fragariae, while fruit rot is mainly attributed to C. acutatum sensu lato, leading to significant yield losses (Howard et al., 1992). Currently, numerous species are classified under what is now known as the C. acutatum complex, with six species—C. acutatum sensu stricto, C. fioriniae, C. godetiae, C. nymphaeae, C. salicis, and C. simmondsii—identified as associated with strawberry anthracnose worldwide (Damm et al., 2012). Among these, C. nymphaeae is the most prevalent pathogen causing strawberry anthracnose globally, including in Iran (Baroncelli et al., 2015; Karimi et al., 2017; Wang et al., 2019). Currently, no effective chemical control methods exist for managing strawberry anthracnose; available options are limited to preventive treatments applied before fruit production (Denoyes-Rothan et al., 1999). Additionally, concerns about the toxic effects of chemical fungicides on the environment and the development of resistance in fungal strains highlight the need for alternative control strategies. Consequently, utilizing resistant cultivars appears to be the most efficient and practical approach for suppressing anthracnose development. In light of recent anthracnose outbreaks in strawberry fields in the Kurdistan province of Iran (Karimi et al., 2017), and the necessity for appropriate strategies to address this issue, the aim of this study was to evaluate the resistance of several commercial strawberry cultivars to the anthracnose fruit rot caused by C. nymphaeae under in vivo and greenhouse conditions.', 0.9239203333854675]]
Context 2: [['Howard CM, Albregts EE. Anthracnose. In: Compendium of Strawberry Diseases. American Phytopathological Society: Paul St, ed. Maas JL, USA; 1984. pp. 85-87.', 0.8604814410209656]]
Context 3: [['Smith, B. J. 1998. Anthracnose leaf spot, irregular spot, anthracnose fruit rot (black spot), and anthracnose crown rot. In: Compendium of Strawberry Diseases. J. L. Mass, ed. American Phytopathological Society, St. Paul, MN. Pages 24-25, 31-33, and 46-48.', 0.8292757272720337]]
Context 4: [['Smith, B. J. (1998). Anthracnose leaf spot and irregular leaf spot. In J. L. Maas (Ed.), Compendium of Strawberry Diseases (2nd ed., pp. 46-48). The American Phytopathological Society, St. Paul, MN.', 0.5711156129837036]]
Context 5: [['Smith, B.J. (1998c). Anthracnose leaf spot and irregular leaf spot. In J.L. Maas (Ed.), Compendium of Strawberry Diseases (2nd ed., pp. 24–25). American Phytopathological Society, St. Paul, MN.', 0.5574888586997986]]
Context 6: [['Numerous reports indicate that strawberry anthracnose pathogens may originate from weed species. For instance, C. fragariae was found attacking the weed Cassia obtusifolia L. (sicklepod, coffeweed) in Florida, causing typical disease symptoms. Inoculation of strawberry with the Cassia isolates resulted in typical anthracnose symptoms, while isolates from strawberry were equally virulent on Cassia. Similarly, inoculation of Duchesnea indica (Andr.) Focke (wild strawberry), F. virginiana Duch. (Virginia wild strawberry), and Potentilla canadensis L. with C. fragariae induced anthracnose disease on these hosts, suggesting that strawberry anthracnose pathogens have a broad host range.', 0.5244180560112]]
Context 7: [['Smith, B. J. 1998. Anthracnose leaf spot and irregular leaf spot. Pages 46-48 in: Compendium of Strawberry Diseases. 2nd ed. J. L. Maas, ed. The American Phytopathological Society, St. Paul, MN.', 0.5081244111061096]]
Context 8: [['Nam MH, Yoo JH, Yun TS, Kim HH, Kim HG. Anthracnose of strawberry: Etiological and ecological characteristics and management. Res Plant Dis 2023;29:205-19.', 0.3646325170993805]]
Context 9: [['Howard, C.M., Maas, J.L., Chandler, C.K., & Albregts, E.E. (1992). Anthracnose of strawberry caused by the Colletotrichum complex in Florida. Plant Disease, 76, 976–981.', 0.3636929988861084]]

query: Why might Colletotrichum species be misidentified based on morphological traits alone?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['In a drastic move, von Arx (1957) reduced the number of recognized Colletotrichum species from several hundred to 11 based on morphological characteristics, with many taxa treated as synonyms of C. gloeosporioides and C. dematium. Several additional species have since been accepted based on morphological criteria (Sutton, 1980; 1992). The difficulties in recognizing Colletotrichum species can be attributed to: 1) the limited and variable morphological characters; 2) an extensive host range and variability in pathogenicity (Bailey and Jeger, 1992; Freeman et al., 2000; Latunde-Dada, 2001; Du et al., 2005; Thaung, 2008); 3) type specimens that are often missing or in poor condition, making them unsuitable for molecular studies; and 4) numerous rDNA ITS sequences of Colletotrichum strains in NCBI that are often misidentified (Crouch et al., 2009d; Damm et al., 2009).', 0.9976252913475037]]
Context 1: [['Traditionally, Colletotrichum species are identified based on morphological characteristics, including conidial and appressorial size and shape, the presence of acervuli, setae, or sclerotia, sexual structures, and cultural traits such as growth rate and colony color. Distinguishing Colletotrichum species morphologically has been challenging due to their phenotypic similarities and the influence of variable environmental factors on the expression of morphological traits. Consequently, all available morphological characteristics are often combined and used for systematic species discrimination.', 0.9965277314186096]]
Context 2: [['Traditional identification systems in Colletotrichum have heavily relied on morphological and cultural characteristics (von Arx, 1957; Sutton, 1980, 1992; Bailey and Jeger, 1992; Freeman et al., 1998). Sutton (1992) noted that morphology alone does not provide sufficient information for precise identification, especially for species within the C. gloeosporioides and C. dematium complexes. Crouch et al. (2009b) argued that conidial size and shape, along with conidial appressoria, were taxonomically uninformative and of limited use for species diagnosis in graminicolous Colletotrichum species. Species with similar morphological characteristics may exhibit considerable variation at the physiological and pathogenic levels, making this recognition crucial for biosecurity, plant breeding, and integrated disease management. Taxonomy based solely on morphology is likely to result in ambiguity. Recent studies have shown that morphological characters should be used in conjunction with other characters to establish species relationships within Colletotrichum (Crouch et al., 2009b; Prihastuti et al., 2009).', 0.9961329698562622]]
Context 3: [['Before the molecular era, the taxonomy of Colletotrichum species was primarily based on morphological and cultural characteristics, including conidia size and shape, presence or absence of setae, colony color, and growth rate (von Arx 1957; Sutton 1980, 1992). However, these characteristics can be unreliable for species differentiation due to variability under changing environmental conditions (Cai et al. 2009).', 0.9848021864891052]]
Context 4: [['Despite significant developments over the last ten years, the taxonomy of Colletotrichum is in a state of flux. Many uncertainties exist in the systematics of fungal pathogens from this genus; depending on the taxonomic "guides," the number of species can range from 29 to over 700 (von Arx, 1957; Sutton, 1992). One of the most confusing species is C. gloeosporioides. For example, 594 species of Colletotrichum were reclassified by von Arx as synonyms of C. gloeosporioides. Identification has primarily relied on morphological characteristics of conidia, vegetative and sexual structures, as well as host specificity and cultural characteristics (von Arx, 1957). Unfortunately, conidial morphology and colony characteristics vary even within isolates. Consequently, classical methods have been supplemented with biochemical and molecular technologies to differentiate Colletotrichum species (J. W. Kronstad, ed., Fungal Pathology, 127-148. © 2000 Kluwer Academic Publishers). For a more complete discussion of this topic, see Sherriff et al. (1994).', 0.9750276207923889]]
Context 5: [['Species concepts in Colletotrichum have evolved from the use of basic morphological data to a polyphasic approach that incorporates a significant molecular component. This evolution has made traditional classifications less practical, as holotypes and other types are not very useful since DNA cannot usually be extracted. It is recommended that future studies adopt a polyphasic approach before introducing new species of Colletotrichum or designating epitypes. This approach should integrate molecular, morphological, physiological, and pathogenic data.', 0.6920973658561707]]
Context 6: [['Cano, J., Guarro, J., and Gene, J. (2004). Molecular and morphological identification of Colletotrichum species of clinical interest. Journal of Clinical Microbiology 42: 2450-2454.', 0.6329132318496704]]
Context 7: [['Photita, W., Taylor, P. W., Ford, R., Hyde, K. D., and Lumyong, S. (2005). Morphological and molecular characterization of Colletotrichum species from...', 0.4875440001487732]]
Context 8: [['Noireung P, Phoulivong S, Liu F, et al. (2012). Novel species of Colletotrichum revealed by morphology and molecular analysis. Cryptogamie Mycologie, 33: 347–362.', 0.3829053044319153]]
Context 9: [['Citation: Cai, L., Hyde, K.D., Taylor, P.W.J., Weir, B.S., Waller, J., Abang, M.M., Zhang, J.Z., Yang, Y.L., Phoulivong, S., Liu, Z.Y., Prihastuti, H., Shivas, R.G., McKenzie, E.H.C., Johnston, P.R. (2009). A polyphasic approach for studying Colletotrichum. Fungal Diversity, 39: 183-204.', 0.36782106757164]]

query: What historical studies are referenced regarding anthracnose resistance in strawberries?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Anthracnose is an important disease of strawberry caused by Colletotrichum spp., which affects foliage, runners, crowns, and fruits (Howard et al., 1992). Three primary fungal pathogens—C. acutatum sensu lato, C. gloeosporioides sensu lato, and C. fragariae—are known to cause anthracnose disease in strawberries (Freeman and Katan, 1997). The crown rot syndrome is characteristic of infections from C. gloeosporioides sensu lato and C. fragariae, while fruit rot is mainly attributed to C. acutatum sensu lato, leading to significant yield losses (Howard et al., 1992). Currently, numerous species are classified under what is now known as the C. acutatum complex, with six species—C. acutatum sensu stricto, C. fioriniae, C. godetiae, C. nymphaeae, C. salicis, and C. simmondsii—identified as associated with strawberry anthracnose worldwide (Damm et al., 2012). Among these, C. nymphaeae is the most prevalent pathogen causing strawberry anthracnose globally, including in Iran (Baroncelli et al., 2015; Karimi et al., 2017; Wang et al., 2019). Currently, no effective chemical control methods exist for managing strawberry anthracnose; available options are limited to preventive treatments applied before fruit production (Denoyes-Rothan et al., 1999). Additionally, concerns about the toxic effects of chemical fungicides on the environment and the development of resistance in fungal strains highlight the need for alternative control strategies. Consequently, utilizing resistant cultivars appears to be the most efficient and practical approach for suppressing anthracnose development. In light of recent anthracnose outbreaks in strawberry fields in the Kurdistan province of Iran (Karimi et al., 2017), and the necessity for appropriate strategies to address this issue, the aim of this study was to evaluate the resistance of several commercial strawberry cultivars to the anthracnose fruit rot caused by C. nymphaeae under in vivo and greenhouse conditions.', 0.9646943807601929]]
Context 1: [['So far, anthracnose epidemics have affected strawberry nurseries and production fields worldwide. Reports on Colletotrichum spp. associated with strawberries, curated from literature in PubMed and Clarivate combined with fungal database searches (Farr and Rossman, 2022), were compiled to understand the global diversity and occurrence of the causal agents of strawberry anthracnose. From our findings, since 1931 until July 9, 2022, there have been over 220 citations and 310 records related to the identification of causal agents of strawberry anthracnose at the genus level of Colletotrichum in 36 countries across six continents, with 282 records providing pathogen identification at the species or species complex level.', 0.8729267716407776]]
Context 2: [['In the early 1980s, when anthracnose became a major disease affecting strawberries in the southeastern United States, the USDA-ARS initiated a breeding program aimed at developing anthracnose-resistant cultivars suitable for the region. This program was established at the Small Fruit Research Station in Poplarville, MS, and the Fruit Laboratory in Beltsville, MD, in collaboration with state experiment stations in Florida, Louisiana, and North Carolina (Galletta et al., 1997; Smith and Spiers, 1982). From 1976 to 1995, over 160,000 progeny from 448 crosses made primarily by G.J. Galletta at Beltsville were screened for anthracnose resistance in the greenhouse at Poplarville, MS.', 0.8393048048019409]]
Context 3: [['In the early 1980s, anthracnose became a significant disease affecting strawberries in the southeastern United States. In response, the USDA-ARS established a breeding program to develop anthracnose-resistant cultivars suited to the strawberry-growing regions of this area. This initiative was conducted at the Small Fruit Research Station in Poplarville, MS, and the Fruit Laboratory in Beltsville, MD, in collaboration with state experiment stations in Florida, Louisiana, and North Carolina (Galletta et al., 1997; Smith and Spiers, 1982).', 0.8325929641723633]]
Context 4: [['A total of 1,515 anthracnose-resistant selections were identified from the seedlings tested in Mississippi. Four of these resistant strawberry clones were released as breeding lines (Galletta et al., 1993) and have since been utilized as sources of anthracnose resistance in several breeding programs. Additionally, Smith et al. (1998) released the cultivar Pelican, which demonstrates high resistance to both anthracnose crown rot caused by C. fragariae and anthracnose fruit rot caused by C. acutatum. query: Can I control anthracnose without using chemicals?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Until highly resistant cultivars are available, growers must rely on chemical applications and cultural practices to reduce losses due to anthracnose. The failure of fungicides to control anthracnose epidemics may be due to the development of fungicide resistance in the Colletotrichum spp. population. For example, benomyl effectively reduced the incidence of anthracnose crown rot (Horn et al., 1972; Howard, 1971) and was used intensively by strawberry growers for years to control anthracnose and other diseases. However, the anthracnose pathogens, C. acutatum and C. fragariae, developed resistance to it and other benzimidazole fungicides (LaMondia, 1995; McInnes et al., 1992a; Smith and Black, 1992, 1993), rendering benomyl ineffective for anthracnose control in strawberry fields.', 0.9527092576026917]]
Context 1: [['Until highly resistant cultivars are available, growers must rely on chemical applications and cultural practices to reduce losses due to anthracnose. The failure of fungicides to control anthracnose epidemics may be attributed to the development of fungicide resistance in the Colletotrichum species population. For example, benomyl was shown to effectively reduce the incidence of anthracnose crown rot (Horn et al., 1972; Howard, 1971) and was used intensively by strawberry growers for years to control anthracnose and other diseases. However, the anthracnose pathogens, C. acutatum and C. fragariae, developed resistance to it and other benzimidazole fungicides (LaMondia, 1995; McInnes et al., 1992a; Smith and Black, 1992, 1993), leading to the ineffectiveness of benomyl for anthracnose control in strawberry fields.', 0.9378005266189575]]
Context 2: [['As our knowledge of the anthracnose pathogens and the epidemiology of anthracnose diseases has increased, so has our ability to control these diseases. Changes in cultural practices have resulted in reduced levels of disease. Additionally, the development and registration of more effective fungicides for use on strawberries have significantly reduced losses from both anthracnose crown rot and fruit rot. Anthracnose-resistant cultivars have also diminished economic losses due to these diseases. Nevertheless, growers may still experience severe losses when environmental factors are highly favorable for anthracnose development.', 0.4345676302909851]]
Context 3: [['As our understanding of the anthracnose pathogens and the epidemiology of anthracnose diseases has improved, so has our capacity to control these diseases. Changes in cultural practices have led to reduced levels of disease. Additionally, the development and registration of more effective fungicides for use on strawberries have significantly decreased losses due to anthracnose crown rot and fruit rot. The introduction of partially resistant cultivars has also helped mitigate economic losses due to these diseases. Nonetheless, growers may still experience severe losses when environmental conditions are highly conducive to anthracnose development.', 0.3963397145271301]]
Context 4: [['Increased losses due to anthracnose fruit and crown rots may be related to the shift from matted-row culture to the annual plasticulture production system in the United States. Breeding for genetic resistance to anthracnose and the development of resistant cultivars are primary means for reducing economic losses due to this disease. This approach is environmentally sound because it results in reduced fungicide use. As our knowledge of the anthracnose pathogens and the epidemiology of anthracnose diseases has increased, so has our ability to control these diseases. Changes in cultural practices have resulted in reduced levels of disease. Simultaneously, the development of more effective fungicides and their registration for use on strawberries have significantly reduced losses due to both anthracnose crown rot and fruit rot. Anthracnose-resistant cultivars have also decreased economic losses caused by these diseases. Nevertheless, growers may still face severe losses when environmental conditions are highly favorable for anthracnose development.', 0.32399672269821167]]
Context 5: [['Anthracnose spreads within a field by splashing water, and living mulches (such as wheat, rye, or ryegrass) in row middles have been shown to reduce disease spread within a field. Sublethal doses of grass-specific herbicides, such as sethoxydim, may be used to prevent excessive growth of ryegrass (Gupton, 2000). Organic mulches, such as wheat straw or pine needles, also reduce splash and result in a lower incidence of anthracnose compared to rows mulched with plastic (Madden, 1992; Smith and Spiers, 1986). Anthracnose is less severe when water is supplied to plants using drip irrigation rather than overhead irrigation (Madden, 1992; Smith and Spiers, 1986).', 0.22841215133666992]]
Context 6: [['Chung, W.H., Ishii, H., Nishimura, K., Fukaya, M., Yano, K., & Kajitani, Y. (2006). Fungicide sensitivity and phylogenetic relationships of anthracnose fungi isolated from various fruit crops in Japan. Plant Disease, 90, 506–512.', 0.2113260179758072]]
Context 7: [['Chung, W.S., Ishii, H., Nishimura, K., Fukaya, M., Yano, K., & Kajitani, Y. (2006). Fungicide sensitivity and phylogenetic relationships of anthracnose fungi isolated from various fruit crops in Japan. Plant Disease 90: 506–512.', 0.21049314737319946]]
Context 8: [['Anthracnose spreads within a field by splashing water, and living mulches (such as wheat, rye, or ryegrass) in row middles have been shown to reduce disease spread within a field. Sublethal doses of grass-specific herbicides, such as sethoxydim, may be used to prevent excessive growth of ryegrass (Gupton, 2000). Organic mulches, such as wheat straw or pine needles, also reduce splash and result in a lower incidence of anthracnose compared to rows mulched with plastic (Madden, 1992; Smith and Spiers, 1986). Additionally, anthracnose is less severe when water is supplied to plants using drip irrigation rather than overhead irrigation (Madden, 1992; Smith and Spiers, 1986). Anthracnose crown rot was observed to be less severe in commercial fields when strawberries were grown in soils with low nitrogen fertility (Howard et al., 1992). In greenhouse studies, Smith (1987, 1989) determined that strawberries grown in soils with high levels of nitrogen, especially from ammonium sources, are more susceptible to anthracnose than plants grown in soils with lower nitrogen levels or those with high levels of calcium nitrate.', 0.20876125991344452]]
Context 9: [['Based on field trials in Florida (Mertely et al., 2009), the recommendation for anthracnose control involves weekly applications of a broad-spectrum protectant fungicide (captan) at the lowest label rate early in the season when conditions are less favorable for anthracnose development. Later, when anthracnose-infected flowers and fruit may be present, it is recommended to increase the rate of the protectant fungicide to the highest label rate. Warm, rainy weather in early spring often leads to epidemics, during which additional fungicides may be necessary. Growers are encouraged to scout their fields regularly for anthracnose symptoms, such as blighted flowers or black spots on green fruit. If symptoms are detected, the application of a strobilurin fungicide (such as Abound or Cabrio) in conjunction with the protectant fungicide is recommended. During the main bloom period, in late January and early February, fungicides containing two active ingredients (one for anthracnose control and one for Botrytis fruit rot control), such as CaptEvate, Pristine, or Switch, are advised. Tank mixes or higher rates of protectant fungicides should be maintained until the end of the harvest season or until dry weather effectively suppresses the disease.', 0.18209995329380035]]

query: Can we create strawberries that are completely safe from diseases?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Strawberries (Fragaria×ananassa Duch.) are a widely cultivated hybrid species within the Rosaceae family, renowned for their fruit. They are increasingly significant for the agricultural economic development of countries like Iran, particularly in the Kurdistan province, which leads in strawberry production, predominantly under open-field conditions (Tehranifar and Sarsaefi, 2002). Various biotic and abiotic factors contribute to the decline in strawberry production globally. Notably, over 100 fungal species can invade strawberry plants, with approximately one-third causing serious diseases on different plant parts (Martin and others).', 0.334930419921875]]
Context 1: [['Strawberry (Fragaria × ananassa) is a major crop cultivated in China (Xie et al. 2010). The production of strawberries has rapidly expanded in recent years, positioning China as one of the world’s largest producers and exporters. As of 2013, strawberry cultivation covered 100.5 × 10^3 hectares, yielding 2.8 million tonnes (The Ministry of Agriculture of the People’s Republic of China 2014). However, with increased production, many fungal diseases have emerged as significant challenges, negatively impacting fruit yield and quality (Mass 1998, Smith 2008). Among these, anthracnose, caused by species of Colletotrichum, is one of the most critical diseases affecting strawberries.', 0.3199099600315094]]
Context 2: [['Although strawberries are considered a minor crop, they provide a significant source of income for many fruit and nursery growers. In the United States, strawberries were cultivated on nearly 20,000 hectares in 1989, yielding a total production of 555,000 tons valued at $520 million. Florida ranks second only to California in the production of fresh-market strawberries. For U.S. winter production (December through March), strawberries are grown on approximately 2,400 hectares. The major cultural problems faced by the Florida strawberry industry include: 1) anthracnose diseases, 2) yearly infestations of the two-spotted spider mite (Tetranychus urticae Koch), and 3) variability in the quality of nursery transplants. Commercial fields are established annually, similar to California practices. Freshly dug transplants are sourced from nurseries in Florida or from northern states and Canada. The use of transplants from northern nurseries is crucial to avoid anthracnose disease issues and to ensure that plants have undergone sufficient natural chilling to induce floral bud initiation.', 0.25813695788383484]]

query: What should I do if my strawberries are already showing symptoms caused by anthracnose?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Anthracnose is an important disease of strawberry caused by Colletotrichum spp., which affects foliage, runners, crowns, and fruits (Howard et al., 1992). Three primary fungal pathogens—C. acutatum sensu lato, C. gloeosporioides sensu lato, and C. fragariae—are known to cause anthracnose disease in strawberries (Freeman and Katan, 1997). The crown rot syndrome is characteristic of infections from C. gloeosporioides sensu lato and C. fragariae, while fruit rot is mainly attributed to C. acutatum sensu lato, leading to significant yield losses (Howard et al., 1992). Currently, numerous species are classified under what is now known as the C. acutatum complex, with six species—C. acutatum sensu stricto, C. fioriniae, C. godetiae, C. nymphaeae, C. salicis, and C. simmondsii—identified as associated with strawberry anthracnose worldwide (Damm et al., 2012). Among these, C. nymphaeae is the most prevalent pathogen causing strawberry anthracnose globally, including in Iran (Baroncelli et al., 2015; Karimi et al., 2017; Wang et al., 2019). Currently, no effective chemical control methods exist for managing strawberry anthracnose; available options are limited to preventive treatments applied before fruit production (Denoyes-Rothan et al., 1999). Additionally, concerns about the toxic effects of chemical fungicides on the environment and the development of resistance in fungal strains highlight the need for alternative control strategies. Consequently, utilizing resistant cultivars appears to be the most efficient and practical approach for suppressing anthracnose development. In light of recent anthracnose outbreaks in strawberry fields in the Kurdistan province of Iran (Karimi et al., 2017), and the necessity for appropriate strategies to address this issue, the aim of this study was to evaluate the resistance of several commercial strawberry cultivars to the anthracnose fruit rot caused by C. nymphaeae under in vivo and greenhouse conditions.', 0.8494832515716553]]
Context 1: [['From 2010 to 2016, we conducted surveys of anthracnose in strawberries in Miaoli County. More than 50% of diseased plants exhibited symptoms characteristic of anthracnose crown rot (ACR), as described by McInnes et al. (1992). ACR resulted in plant losses of up to 30-40% during the seedling stage and around 20% after transplanting. Initial symptoms in crown tissue included a marbled red and white appearance, which progressed to brown rot and eventual rapid wilting of the plant. Anthracnose symptoms also appeared on other parts of the plant, including leaves, petioles, runners, fruits, and roots. These symptoms manifested as circular black spots on leaves, withering and girdling on runners.', 0.7786917090415955]]
Context 2: [['In November 2021, anthracnose symptoms were observed on strawberries (cv. Kingsberry) in Nonsan, Chungnam Province. Early symptoms of anthracnose fruit rot (AFR) include blackening of specific tissues of the strawberry. These symptoms progress with the enlargement of lesions, which hinder proper fruit development and lead to the formation of orange-colored spores within the lesions. Similar symptoms were noted on the petioles, with sunken and blackened tissues similar to those on the fruit, accompanied by the formation of an orange conidial mass.', 0.7540948390960693]]
Context 3: [['The term "anthracnose" was first used to describe a new disease of strawberries caused by Colletotrichum fragariae Brooks. "Strawberry anthracnose" continues to be used as a general term to identify all diseases of strawberries caused by species of Colletotrichum. Strawberry anthracnose diseases have been reported to be caused by C. acutatum J.H. Simmonds, C. gloeosporioides (Penz.) Penz. & Sacc. in Penz. (the teleomorph of Cromereilla cingulata (Stoneman) Spauld. & H. Schrenk), and C. dematium (Pers.) Grove. The latter species only occasionally causes strawberry fruit rots and will not be discussed here.', 0.7383751273155212]]
Context 4: [['Numerous reports indicate that strawberry anthracnose pathogens may originate from weed species. For instance, C. fragariae was found attacking the weed Cassia obtusifolia L. (sicklepod, coffeweed) in Florida, causing typical disease symptoms. Inoculation of strawberry with the Cassia isolates resulted in typical anthracnose symptoms, while isolates from strawberry were equally virulent on Cassia. Similarly, inoculation of Duchesnea indica (Andr.) Focke (wild strawberry), F. virginiana Duch. (Virginia wild strawberry), and Potentilla canadensis L. with C. fragariae induced anthracnose disease on these hosts, suggesting that strawberry anthracnose pathogens have a broad host range.', 0.7378320693969727]]
Context 5: [["Anthracnose fungi can attack various parts of the strawberry plant, including crowns, petioles, leaves, fruit trusses, flowers, buds, and fruit. The fungi's ability to attack multiple plant parts, coupled with the involvement of several pathogen species, contributes to the complex nature of strawberry anthracnose. Brooks reported in 1931 that C. fragariae caused spotting and girdling of runners, and later indicated that it also caused spotting of petioles and crown rot in a summer nursery, leading to wilting and death of the plants. Researchers in Louisiana observed all these symptoms and noted that crown rot also occurred in the fruit production field.", 0.678008496761322]]
Context 6: [['Howard CM, Albregts EE. Anthracnose. In: Compendium of Strawberry Diseases. American Phytopathological Society: Paul St, ed. Maas JL, USA; 1984. pp. 85-87.', 0.5937931537628174]]
Context 7: [['Ballington, J.R., J.L. Shuman, B.J. Smith, and S.C. Hokanson. 2002. Breeding strawberries (Fragaria × ananassa) for resistance to anthracnose caused by Colletotrichum acutatum. Acta Horticulturae 567:89–92.', 0.5625770092010498]]
Context 8: [['Brooks AN (1931). Anthracnose of strawberry caused by Colletotrichum fragariae n. sp. Phytopathology 21: 739–744.', 0.5418896675109863]]
Context 9: [['Smith, B. J. 1998. Anthracnose leaf spot, irregular spot, anthracnose fruit rot (black spot), and anthracnose crown rot. In: Compendium of Strawberry Diseases. J. L. Mass, ed. American Phytopathological Society, St. Paul, MN. Pages 24-25, 31-33, and 46-48.', 0.5070476531982422]]

For isolates from the acutatum complex, concatenated datasets were created, comprising sequences of ITS, chs-1, act, gapdh, his3, and tub2 genes. In the case of isolates from the gloeosporioides complex, two concatenated datasets were generated, one including ITS, chs-1, act, gapdh, and tub2 gene sequences, and another with ApMat and gs gene sequences. For isolates from the boninense and orchidearum complexes, concatenated datasets were generated comprising ITS, gapdh, act, and tub2 gene sequences. Context 7: [["The total combined dataset was analyzed using the species-tree approach implemented in BEST (Liu 2008), incorporating the signals from each developed marker while excluding overlapping segments. The ApMAT intergenic region had the highest nucleotide diversity (p = 0.1282), exceeding the diversity of b-tub2 and GS fragments by more than twofold. query: How can understanding the genetic diversity of Colletotrichum spp improve strawberry disease management?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Despite intensive research that has contributed to the understanding of the Colletotrichum genus pathogenic to strawberries, there is still a lack of an accurate inventory of these causal agents. The population and prevalence of strawberry-virulent Colletotrichum species have not been systematically investigated in major producers such as China. To address these gaps, this review aims to summarize the biodiversity of Colletotrichum species pathogenic to strawberries by examining the global discovery history. Subsequently, the prevalence of Colletotrichum species pathogenic to strawberries in China was analyzed using available data. Finally, we categorized the host range of the two predominant species responsible for strawberry crown rot. This knowledge has important applications for biosecurity risk management (e.g., proper risk estimation in strawberry seedling trade), accurate diagnosis, and anthracnose control. It further lays the groundwork for systematically managing Colletotrichum genera in agricultural ecosystems, not only for the strawberry industry.', 0.9161883592605591]]

query: Why is Colletotrichum siamense considered a significant pathogen in Taiwan's strawberry production?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['C. siamense and C. fructicola are recognized as the primary pathogens responsible for strawberry anthracnose crown rot in the Asia-Pacific region (Nam et al. 2013; Han et al. 2016; Jayawardena et al. 2016a; Gan et al. 2017; Hirayama et al. 2018; Gupta et al. 2019; Chen et al. 2020; Chung et al. 2020; Zhang et al. 2020; Jian et al. 2021; Zhong et al. 2021; Oliveira et al. 2022; Wang et al. 2022). These two species are the most frequently occurring Colletotrichum species worldwide (Talhinhas and Baroncelli 2021). Both are cosmopolitan fungi that can adapt to a diverse array of host plants, with higher occurrences reported in tropical and subtropical regions, particularly in Asia compared to other continents.', 0.9944218993186951]]
Context 1: [['Colletotrichum siamense, part of the gloeosporioides complex, was also notable, representing 11% of total isolates causing anthracnose in chili fruit in Indonesia, Sri Lanka, and Thailand, but it was not detected in Malaysia and Taiwan. Nonetheless, Noor and Zakaria (2018) reported the identification of C. siamense in Malaysia, likely due to a larger sampling size of infected chili across various states. Within the C. siamense clade, small subclades were observed that corresponded with different geographical regions from which the isolates were collected. C. siamense has been reported to infect chili in Asia, Australia, and Brazil, and is a common pathogen of many other plant species (Weir et al. 2012; James et al. 2014; Sharma and Shenoy 2014; Liu et al. 2016a, 2016b; de Oliveira et al. 2017; De Silva et al. 2017a; Diao et al. 2017; Suwannarat et al. 2017).', 0.992745041847229]]
Context 2: [['Independent experiments have shown that Colletotrichum siamense is a significant pathogen affecting blueberries in the southeastern United States. This study, along with previous research (Hu et al. 2015), supports their role as fruit pathogens in this region.', 0.9918811917304993]]
Context 3: [['Colletotrichum siamense has also been noted as a significant species causing mango anthracnose in China and eastern Australia. This species has a broad host range in tropical and subtropical regions, capable of infecting banana (Musa spp.), papaya (Carica papaya L.), dragon fruit (Hylocereus spp.), guava (Psidium guajava), and avocado. It was suggested by James et al. that C. siamense is likely a common and widespread saprophyte or endophyte, as the authors were able to isolate it from asymptomatic fruit of other plants, with the exception of mango and avocado. Similar to C. asianum, C. siamense has been reported to cause disease in coffee in Thailand, but not in mango until this study.', 0.9838670492172241]]
Context 4: [['Chung, P. C., Wu, H. Y., Ariyawansa, H. A., Tzean, S. S., & Chung, C. L. First report of anthracnose crown rot of strawberry caused by Colletotrichum siamense in Taiwan. Plant Disease 103, 1775-1776 (2019).', 0.9767974019050598]]
Context 5: [['In a study conducted in Zhejiang province, China, the pathogenicity of various Colletotrichum isolates was assessed on wounded and non-wounded strawberry leaves. Most isolates, such as ZJE-3, exhibited strong pathogenicity on wounded leaves but weak pathogenicity on non-wounded leaves (Supplementary Fig. S3). A phylogenetic analysis was performed using five genes (GAPDH, CAL, CHS-1, ACT, and ITS) to identify 91 different isolates from strawberry anthracnose samples. The species identified were C. fructicola, C. gloeosporioides, C. aenigma, and C. siamense, all belonging to the C. gloeosporioides species complex. This is the first report of C. siamense causing strawberry anthracnose in Zhejiang, where it was found to be the second most common species. Although originally described from coffee plantations in Thailand, C. siamense has a wide geographical distribution and diverse host range. The study noted variability in its morphological characteristics, suggesting environmental conditions may influence mycelial growth. Different colony types were observed, with a generally grayish-white appearance and slow hyphal growth under the tested culture conditions. The pathogenicity varied among C. siamense isolates, indicating a need for further research on their pathogenesis.', 0.9274196624755859]]
Context 6: [['Colletotrichum asianum and C. siamense have been reported as pathogens affecting a wide variety of hosts, including Coffea arabica, Carica papaya, and Mangifera indica. Our study demonstrated that a single host species could be attacked by several Colletotrichum species, a phenomenon previously noted by Phoulivong et al. C. fructicola was initially reported on coffee berries and also exhibits a broad host range, affecting species such as Arachis sp., Citrus bergamia, and M. indica, along with a wide geographical distribution. Similarly, C. tropicale has been documented on Annona muricata, Viola surinamensis, and M. indica in Brazil.', 0.8772329688072205]]
Context 7: [["Among the five Colletotrichum species identified in this study, C. siamense exhibited greater mycelial growth rates on PDA, particularly at higher temperatures. The fitness advantage of C. siamense in warm weather may explain its current geographical distribution. In the literature, C. siamense has been most frequently reported in tropical and subtropical regions, while C. boninense, C. fructicola, and C. karstii have been documented across a wide range of latitudes. Temperature is a key environmental factor affecting a pathogen's survival. A recent study based on published observations of 612 crop pests and pathogens from 1960 onward revealed significant positive latitudinal shifts of many important pests and pathogens under climate change. More research on the genetic and biological characteristics of different Colletotrichum species from diverse geographical areas is necessary to understand the emergence and spread of anthracnose diseases. With rising global temperatures, it will be particularly important to monitor the expansion of the heat-adapted C. siamense toward higher latitudes.", 0.7287352085113525]]
Context 8: [['Colletotrichum siamense, as described by Prihastuti et al. (2009) in "Fungal Diversity 39," has been examined in various regions. In China, collections were made from Shandong Province, Yantai City, on fruits of P. communis cv. Gyuiot on 27 Aug. 2016 (cultures PAFQ67, PAFQ68, PAFQ71, PAFQ73, PAFQ74) and from Zhejiang Province, Hangzhou City, on leaves of P. pyrifolia cv. Guanyangxueli on 18 Aug. 2016 (PAFQ78), and on leaves of P. pyrifolia cv. Cuiguan on the same date (PAFQ85). Notably, C. siamense was first reported on Coffea arabica in Thailand (Prihastuti et al., 2009) and has since been documented on a wide range of hosts (e.g., Yang et al., 2009; Wikee et al., 2011; Wei et al., 2012; Wang et al., 2016; Liu et al., 2016b). This study marks the first report and characterization of C. siamense causing anthracnose on P. pyrifolia and P. communis.', 0.54875648021698]]
Context 9: [['Ni, H. F. et al. First report of pepper spot disease of lychee caused by Colletotrichum siamense in Taiwan. J. Plant Pathol. 99, 808–808 (2017).', 0.4649137258529663]]

query: What kinds of crops are hurt the most by Colletotrichum?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Many species belonging to the genus Colletotrichum are associated with plant diseases, commonly referred to as anthracnose. Colletotrichum spp. can affect a wide range of hosts, and these pathogens are characterized by global distribution. Virtually every cultivated botanical family is susceptible to one or more species of Colletotrichum, making it one of the most studied plant pathogenic fungi (Prusky et al., 2000; Latunde-Dada, 2001; Dean et al., 2012). Common hosts include many dicotyledonous plants such as strawberry, apple, citrus, and stone fruits, as well as major cereals such as maize and sorghum. Members of this genus can cause crop losses of up to 100% in many staple foods (Bailey and Jeger, 1992; Prusky et al., 2000; Talhinhas et al., 2005; Cannon et al., 2012).', 0.9329959750175476]]
Context 1: [['Waller, J.M.; Bridge, P.D. "Recent advances in understanding Colletotrichum diseases of some tropical perennial crops." Context 2: [['Yang, Y.L., Liu, Z.Y., Cai, L., Hyde, K.D., Yu, Z.N., & McKenzie, E.H.C. (2009). Colletotrichum.', 0.421461820602417]]
Context 3: [['The genus Colletotrichum is considered one of the top ten important genera of fungal pathogens globally (Dean et al., 2012). Colletotrichum is an ancient fungus that has co-evolved with flowering plants. Plant microfossils of Protocolletotrichum preserved on angiosperm leaf cuticles suggest that the diverse pathogenic strategies of Colletotrichum spp. have been established since the Late Cretaceous period (Kar et al., 2004). Different complexes within the genus may have diverged between 4.8 and 32.2 million years ago (MYA) (Bhunjun et al., 2021). The emergence of agricultural cultivation and the intensive disturbance of natural environments have further driven the diversification of Colletotrichum species. These fungi have adapted to thousands of hosts and can be found as endophytes, pathogens, and saprobes (Freeman et al., 1998; Dean et al., 2012; Hirayama et al., 2018; da Silva et al., 2020; Jayawardena et al., 2020). Currently, a total of 257 Colletotrichum species grouped into 15 complexes and 13 additional singletons have been accepted in this genus.', 0.3582914471626282]]

query: How can advancements in genetics help overcome the challenges of disease resistance in strawberries?

Context 0: [['The modern strawberry, Fragaria × ananassa Duchesne, is of relatively recent origin. It was not until the North American F. virginiana and the South American F. chiloensis were brought together and hybridized in Europe around 1750 that the progenitor of the strawberry we know today was developed. The high degree of genetic heterozygosity in Fragaria spp. has facilitated the creation of strawberry cultivars adapted to a wide range of environmental conditions and resistant to several diseases and pests. Today, cultivars are available that can survive the bitterly cold winters of Alaska, as well as those that thrive in the long, hot seasons of Pretoria, South Africa.', 0.4540758430957794]]

query: Can anthracnose affect other crops besides strawberries?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Anthracnose is an important disease of strawberry caused by Colletotrichum spp., which affects foliage, runners, crowns, and fruits (Howard et al., 1992). Three primary fungal pathogens—C. acutatum sensu lato, C. gloeosporioides sensu lato, and C. fragariae—are known to cause anthracnose disease in strawberries (Freeman and Katan, 1997). The crown rot syndrome is characteristic of infections from C. gloeosporioides sensu lato and C. fragariae, while fruit rot is mainly attributed to C. acutatum sensu lato, leading to significant yield losses (Howard et al., 1992). Currently, numerous species are classified under what is now known as the C. acutatum complex, with six species—C. acutatum sensu stricto, C. fioriniae, C. godetiae, C. nymphaeae, C. salicis, and C. simmondsii—identified as associated with strawberry anthracnose worldwide (Damm et al., 2012). Among these, C. nymphaeae is the most prevalent pathogen causing strawberry anthracnose globally, including in Iran (Baroncelli et al., 2015; Karimi et al., 2017; Wang et al., 2019). Currently, no effective chemical control methods exist for managing strawberry anthracnose; available options are limited to preventive treatments applied before fruit production (Denoyes-Rothan et al., 1999). Additionally, concerns about the toxic effects of chemical fungicides on the environment and the development of resistance in fungal strains highlight the need for alternative control strategies. Consequently, utilizing resistant cultivars appears to be the most efficient and practical approach for suppressing anthracnose development. In light of recent anthracnose outbreaks in strawberry fields in the Kurdistan province of Iran (Karimi et al., 2017), and the necessity for appropriate strategies to address this issue, the aim of this study was to evaluate the resistance of several commercial strawberry cultivars to the anthracnose fruit rot caused by C. nymphaeae under in vivo and greenhouse conditions.', 0.980258584022522]]
Context 1: [["Anthracnose fungi can attack various parts of the strawberry plant, including crowns, petioles, leaves, fruit trusses, flowers, buds, and fruit. The fungi's ability to attack multiple plant parts, coupled with the involvement of several pathogen species, contributes to the complex nature of strawberry anthracnose. Brooks reported in 1931 that C. fragariae caused spotting and girdling of runners, and later indicated that it also caused spotting of petioles and crown rot in a summer nursery, leading to wilting and death of the plants. Researchers in Louisiana observed all these symptoms and noted that crown rot also occurred in the fruit production field.", 0.9782975316047668]]
Context 2: [['Anthracnose caused by Colletotrichum spp. (Milholland, 1981; Gupton and Smith, 1991) is one of the most important factors limiting strawberry production in many southeastern regions (Horn et al., 1972; Smith and Black, 1985; 1987, 1990).', 0.7728128433227539]]
Context 3: [['From 2010 to 2016, we conducted surveys of anthracnose in strawberries in Miaoli County. More than 50% of diseased plants exhibited symptoms characteristic of anthracnose crown rot (ACR), as described by McInnes et al. (1992). ACR resulted in plant losses of up to 30-40% during the seedling stage and around 20% after transplanting. Initial symptoms in crown tissue included a marbled red and white appearance, which progressed to brown rot and eventual rapid wilting of the plant. Anthracnose symptoms also appeared on other parts of the plant, including leaves, petioles, runners, fruits, and roots. These symptoms manifested as circular black spots on leaves, withering and girdling on runners.', 0.7538474798202515]]
Context 4: [['As our knowledge of the anthracnose pathogens and the epidemiology of anthracnose diseases has increased, so has our ability to control these diseases. Changes in cultural practices have resulted in reduced levels of disease. Additionally, the development and registration of more effective fungicides for use on strawberries have significantly reduced losses from both anthracnose crown rot and fruit rot. Anthracnose-resistant cultivars have also diminished economic losses due to these diseases. Nevertheless, growers may still experience severe losses when environmental factors are highly favorable for anthracnose development.', 0.7307815551757812]]
Context 5: [['The term "anthracnose" was first used to describe a new disease of strawberries caused by Colletotrichum fragariae Brooks. "Strawberry anthracnose" continues to be used as a general term to identify all diseases of strawberries caused by species of Colletotrichum. Strawberry anthracnose diseases have been reported to be caused by C. acutatum J.H. Simmonds, C. gloeosporioides (Penz.) Penz. & Sacc. in Penz. (the teleomorph of Cromereilla cingulata (Stoneman) Spauld. & H. Schrenk), and C. dematium (Pers.) Grove. The latter species only occasionally causes strawberry fruit rots and will not be discussed here.', 0.716303825378418]]
Context 6: [['As our understanding of the anthracnose pathogens and the epidemiology of anthracnose diseases has improved, so has our capacity to control these diseases. Changes in cultural practices have led to reduced levels of disease. Additionally, the development and registration of more effective fungicides for use on strawberries have significantly decreased losses due to anthracnose crown rot and fruit rot. The introduction of partially resistant cultivars has also helped mitigate economic losses due to these diseases. Nonetheless, growers may still experience severe losses when environmental conditions are highly conducive to anthracnose development.', 0.6835806369781494]]
Context 7: [['Howard CM, Albregts EE. Anthracnose. In: Compendium of Strawberry Diseases. American Phytopathological Society: Paul St, ed. Maas JL, USA; 1984. pp. 85-87.', 0.6790145039558411]]
Context 8: [['ABSTRACT: Strawberry anthracnose, caused by Colletotrichum fragariae, is a serious problem in the southeastern United States, resulting in significant losses in strawberry nurseries. Control measures using fungicides are crucial, particularly with recommended applications of captafol, benomyl, captan, and maneb.', 0.6595892310142517]]
Context 9: [['Introduction: The spread of strawberry anthracnose can be exacerbated by the use of infected runner plantlets (Hirayama et al. 2010). Effective management strategies must consider these factors to mitigate disease outbreaks.', 0.6580630540847778]]

query: What is the role of gene family evolution in the adaptation of Colletotrichum species to diverse hosts?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['The genus Colletotrichum is considered one of the top ten important genera of fungal pathogens globally (Dean et al., 2012). Colletotrichum is an ancient fungus that has co-evolved with flowering plants. Plant microfossils of Protocolletotrichum preserved on angiosperm leaf cuticles suggest that the diverse pathogenic strategies of Colletotrichum spp. have been established since the Late Cretaceous period (Kar et al., 2004). Different complexes within the genus may have diverged between 4.8 and 32.2 million years ago (MYA) (Bhunjun et al., 2021). The emergence of agricultural cultivation and the intensive disturbance of natural environments have further driven the diversification of Colletotrichum species. These fungi have adapted to thousands of hosts and can be found as endophytes, pathogens, and saprobes (Freeman et al., 1998; Dean et al., 2012; Hirayama et al., 2018; da Silva et al., 2020; Jayawardena et al., 2020). Currently, a total of 257 Colletotrichum species grouped into 15 complexes and 13 additional singletons have been accepted in this genus.', 0.9770916104316711]]
Context 1: [['Citation: Cai, L., Hyde, K.D., Taylor, P.W.J., Weir, B.S., Waller, J., Abang, M.M., Zhang, J.Z., Yang, Y.L., Phoulivong, S., Liu, Z.Y., Prihastuti, H., Shivas, R.G., McKenzie, E.H.C., Johnston, P.R. Context 2: [['In a drastic move, von Arx (1957) reduced the number of recognized Colletotrichum species from several hundred to 11 based on morphological characteristics, with many taxa treated as synonyms of C. gloeosporioides and C. dematium. Several additional species have since been accepted based on morphological criteria (Sutton, 1980; 1992). The difficulties in recognizing Colletotrichum species can be attributed to: 1) the limited and variable morphological characters; 2) an extensive host range and variability in pathogenicity (Bailey and Jeger, 1992; Freeman et al., 2000; Latunde-Dada, 2001; Du et al., 2005; Thaung, 2008); 3) type specimens that are often missing or in poor condition, making them unsuitable for molecular studies; and 4) numerous rDNA ITS sequences of Colletotrichum strains in NCBI that are often misidentified (Crouch et al., 2009d; Damm et al., 2009).', 0.38752803206443787]]
Context 3: [['Table 2 provides a comprehensive list of various species of the genus Colletotrichum, including their culture accession numbers and the host plants from which they were isolated. Each entry specifies the country of origin and includes corresponding GenBank accession numbers for the ITS, GAPDH, ACT, and CHS-1 genes. The species range from Colletotrichum aenigmay, isolated from Persea americana in Israel, to Colletotrichum boninense, derived from Crinum asiaticum in Japan. This detailed tabulation is essential for understanding the genetic diversity and distribution of Colletotrichum species in relation to their host plants.', 0.3574773371219635]]

query: How might advancements in primer development for the Apn2/MAT locus influence future research in mycology?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [["The Apn2/MAT locus has been explored in various studies (Du et al. 2005, Crouch et al. 2009a, Rojas et al. 2010). Our primer sets successfully generated orthologous sequences to those previously published, including the 3' end of the Apn2 gene and the intergenic region between MAT1-2-1 (Crouch et al. 2009a, Rojas et al. 2010), as well as the intron in the HMG region of the MAT1-2-1 gene (Du et al. 2005). Additionally, we obtained the complete sequence of the Apn2 gene and the entire MAT1-2-1 gene, along with a portion of the 5' intergenic region, totaling approximately 2,700 bp of novel sequence data from this locus. Our analyses demonstrated the potential of this genomic region to significantly enhance phylogenetic informativeness, addressing the taxonomic challenges of the C. gloeosporioides complex.", 0.7442403435707092]]
Context 1: [["A total of 22 sequences were obtained for each of the seven nuclear markers. The newly developed set of primers (ITS, b-tub2, GS, ApMAT, Apn25L, MAT1-2-1, and MAT5L) allowed the amplification of 4,061 bp, producing a total of 4,676 bp of sequence data from the Apn2/MAT locus for each studied isolate. Each primer pair generated partially overlapping fragments that, in combination, spanned all but the first 21 codons of Apn2, the intergenic region between Apn2 and MAT1-2-1, the complete MAT1-2-1 gene, and a small intergenic region adjacent to the 3' end of MAT1-2-1 (FIG. 1).", 0.4903833270072937]]
Context 2: [['Note: Restriction sites are indicated in bold lowercase letters.', 0.23136459290981293]]
Context 3: [['Table 1: List of primers used in the study.', 0.19318841397762299]]
Context 4: [["A representative sample of 10 isolates (see Table I), comprising six species, was used to amplify and sequence the full portion of the locus. Primers were designed using PerlPrimer 1.1.18 (Marshall 2004). The first two sets of specific primers were AM-F (5'-TCATTCTACG-TATGTGCCCG-3') / AM-R (5'-CCAGAAATACACCGAA-CTTGC-3') and M5L-F (5'-ATCTTTGCGGTAGAGAAT-GAAGG-3') / M5L-R (5'-GACCCTTCTATGAACGAGCC-3'), designed within and flanking the conserved HMG domain of MAT1-2-1 (see Figure 1). The PCR amplification conditions were as follows: 3 minutes at 94°C, followed by 30 cycles of 45 seconds at 94°C, 45 seconds at 62°C, and 1 minute at 72°C, with a final extension of 7 minutes at 72°C. The amplification products were sequenced and used as templates, along with the C. gloeosporioides accession, for further primer design. Based on these sequences, primer pairs CM-F (5'-TCTACCTCATCGACG-CTGCT-3') / CM-R (5'-CATGTGGGCAAAGGATGGC-3') and A5L-F (5'-CAAGCGACGAAGTATACGAG-3') / A5L-R (5'-GCATCACGGGAATAACTAGG-3') were designed to amplify the remainder of the MAT1-2-1 gene and the 5' end of the Apn2 gene, respectively (see Figure 1). The PCR conditions remained identical, except that a 66°C annealing temperature was used for the CM-F/CM-R pair.", 0.173675537109375]]
Context 5: [["For molecular data, using the complete taxa sampling from this study (see Table I), five nuclear genes and two intergenic regions were sequenced. From the Apn2/MAT locus (see Figure 1), the two intergenic regions (ApMAT and MAT5L) were selected, along with the MAT1-2-1 gene and the Apn25L gene fragment, considering their informative potential and sequence length. The ITS nuclear region (Brown et al. 1996) and two gene fragments from β-tub2 (O'Donnell and Cigelnik 1997) and glutamine synthetase (GS) (Prihastuti et al. 2009) were also analyzed using previously described primers and PCR conditions. PCR products were verified by electrophoresis on a 1.2% w/v agarose gel stained with ethidium bromide and purified using SureClean (Bioline, London, UK). Sequencing reactions were performed using BigDye 3.1 chemistry (Applied Biosystems, USA) on an ABI Prism 310 automated sequencer. Amplicons were sequenced in both directions, and chromatograms were manually verified for errors using Sequencher 4.0.5 (Gene Codes Corp., Ann Arbor, Michigan).", 0.17036494612693787]]
Context 6: [["Using the sequences obtained from the 5' end of Apn2 as templates, primers AEx3-F (5'-CTCATCGGCACCTACAGC-3') / AEx3-R (5'-CAAGATGTCTCCGAGCGTC-3') and subsequently primers A3L-F (5'-TGACATGGAACGGTGAGTG-3') / A3L-R (5'-TTCCAGTCCTCGACCGTCA-3') were designed to amplify the remaining portion of the Apn2 gene (see Figure 1). The amplification reactions were performed as follows: 3 minutes at 94°C, followed by 30 cycles with 45 seconds at 94°C, a touchdown annealing step for 45 seconds starting at 62°C and decreasing by 0.5°C per cycle until stabilizing at 57°C for the remaining 20 cycles, and 1 minute at 72°C with a final extension of 7 minutes at 72°C. query: Which stages of crop development are most affected by Colletotrichum species?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Many species belonging to the genus Colletotrichum are associated with plant diseases, commonly referred to as anthracnose. Colletotrichum spp. can affect a wide range of hosts, and these pathogens are characterized by global distribution. Virtually every cultivated botanical family is susceptible to one or more species of Colletotrichum, making it one of the most studied plant pathogenic fungi (Prusky et al., 2000; Latunde-Dada, 2001; Dean et al., 2012). Common hosts include many dicotyledonous plants such as strawberry, apple, citrus, and stone fruits, as well as major cereals such as maize and sorghum. Members of this genus can cause crop losses of up to 100% in many staple foods (Bailey and Jeger, 1992; Prusky et al., 2000; Talhinhas et al., 2005; Cannon et al., 2012).', 0.9251551032066345]]

query: Can companion planting help reduce the risk of anthracnose?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Additional Keywords: anthracnose, disease spread, Fragaria × ananassa, models, quantitative epidemiology.', 0.2164076417684555]]
Context 1: [['Anthracnose spreads within a field through splashing water. Living mulches, such as wheat, rye, or rye grass, in row middles have been shown to reduce disease spread. Organic mulches like wheat straw or pine needles also reduce splash and result in a lower incidence of anthracnose compared to rows mulched with plastic (Coelho et al., 2008; Madden, 1992; Smith and Spiers, 1986). Additionally, anthracnose is less severe when water is supplied to plants using drip irrigation rather than overhead irrigation (Coelho et al., 2008; Madden, 1992; Smith and Spiers, 1986).', 0.17796087265014648]]
Context 2: [['Anthracnose spreads within a field by splashing water, and living mulches (such as wheat, rye, or ryegrass) in row middles have been shown to reduce disease spread within a field. Sublethal doses of grass-specific herbicides, such as sethoxydim, may be used to prevent excessive growth of ryegrass (Gupton, 2000). Organic mulches, such as wheat straw or pine needles, also reduce splash and result in a lower incidence of anthracnose compared to rows mulched with plastic (Madden, 1992; Smith and Spiers, 1986). Additionally, anthracnose is less severe when water is supplied to plants using drip irrigation rather than overhead irrigation (Madden, 1992; Smith and Spiers, 1986). Anthracnose crown rot was observed to be less severe in commercial fields when strawberries were grown in soils with low nitrogen fertility (Howard et al., 1992). In greenhouse studies, Smith (1987, 1989) determined that strawberries grown in soils with high levels of nitrogen, especially from ammonium sources, are more susceptible to anthracnose than plants grown in soils with lower nitrogen levels or those with high levels of calcium nitrate.', 0.171474888920784]]
Context 3: [['Anthracnose is a significant disease affecting grape crops (Dowling et al., 2020). Beyond causing severe yield losses, anthracnose epidemics can diminish the quality of the produce (Waller et al., 2002; Dowling et al., 2020). The most economically damaging symptoms often include blossom blight and fruit rots; however, necrotic lesions may also develop on leaves, stems, and twigs, leading to plant deterioration and reduced fruit quality (Dowling et al., 2020).', 0.16515961289405823]]
Context 4: [['Key words: anthracnose, Ascomycota, Colletotrichum acutatum, Gloeosporium, Glomerella, phylogeny, systematics.', 0.1489459127187729]]

query: How did von Arx’s contributions to the classification of Colletotrichum fungi influence the development of diagnostic tools for plant disease identification?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['In a drastic move, von Arx (1957) reduced the number of recognized Colletotrichum species from several hundred to 11 based on morphological characteristics, with many taxa treated as synonyms of C. gloeosporioides and C. dematium. Several additional species have since been accepted based on morphological criteria (Sutton, 1980; 1992). The difficulties in recognizing Colletotrichum species can be attributed to: 1) the limited and variable morphological characters; 2) an extensive host range and variability in pathogenicity (Bailey and Jeger, 1992; Freeman et al., 2000; Latunde-Dada, 2001; Du et al., 2005; Thaung, 2008); 3) type specimens that are often missing or in poor condition, making them unsuitable for molecular studies; and 4) numerous rDNA ITS sequences of Colletotrichum strains in NCBI that are often misidentified (Crouch et al., 2009d; Damm et al., 2009).', 0.699093759059906]]

query: How do the morphological variations of Colletotrichum species affect their identification and classification?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Despite significant developments over the last ten years, the taxonomy of Colletotrichum is in a state of flux. Many uncertainties exist in the systematics of fungal pathogens from this genus; depending on the taxonomic "guides," the number of species can range from 29 to over 700 (von Arx, 1957; Sutton, 1992). One of the most confusing species is C. gloeosporioides. For example, 594 species of Colletotrichum were reclassified by von Arx as synonyms of C. gloeosporioides. Identification has primarily relied on morphological characteristics of conidia, vegetative and sexual structures, as well as host specificity and cultural characteristics (von Arx, 1957). Unfortunately, conidial morphology and colony characteristics vary even within isolates. Consequently, classical methods have been supplemented with biochemical and molecular technologies to differentiate Colletotrichum species (J. W. Kronstad, ed., Fungal Pathology, 127-148. © 2000 Kluwer Academic Publishers). For a more complete discussion of this topic, see Sherriff et al. (1994).', 0.9619703888893127]]
Context 1: [['In a drastic move, von Arx (1957) reduced the number of recognized Colletotrichum species from several hundred to 11 based on morphological characteristics, with many taxa treated as synonyms of C. gloeosporioides and C. dematium. Several additional species have since been accepted based on morphological criteria (Sutton, 1980; 1992). The difficulties in recognizing Colletotrichum species can be attributed to: 1) the limited and variable morphological characters; 2) an extensive host range and variability in pathogenicity (Bailey and Jeger, 1992; Freeman et al., 2000; Latunde-Dada, 2001; Du et al., 2005; Thaung, 2008); 3) type specimens that are often missing or in poor condition, making them unsuitable for molecular studies; and 4) numerous rDNA ITS sequences of Colletotrichum strains in NCBI that are often misidentified (Crouch et al., 2009d; Damm et al., 2009).', 0.9361674785614014]]

(2009). A polyphasic approach for studying Colletotrichum. Fungal Diversity, 39: 183-204.', 0.4387614130973816]]

Context 6: [['To validate the taxonomy of Colletotrichum species through morphological characteristics and DNA phylogenetic analysis.', 0.3528487980365753]]
Context 7: [['The genus Colletotrichum is considered one of the top ten important genera of fungal pathogens globally (Dean et al., 2012). Colletotrichum is an ancient fungus that has co-evolved with flowering plants. Plant microfossils of Protocolletotrichum preserved on angiosperm leaf cuticles suggest that the diverse pathogenic strategies of Colletotrichum spp. have been established since the Late Cretaceous period (Kar et al., 2004). Different complexes within the genus may have diverged between 4.8 and 32.2 million years ago (MYA) (Bhunjun et al., 2021). The emergence of agricultural cultivation and the intensive disturbance of natural environments have further driven the diversification of Colletotrichum species. These fungi have adapted to thousands of hosts and can be found as endophytes, pathogens, and saprobes (Freeman et al., 1998; Dean et al., 2012; Hirayama et al., 2018; da Silva et al., 2020; Jayawardena et al., 2020). Currently, a total of 257 Colletotrichum species grouped into 15 complexes and 13 additional singletons have been accepted in this genus.', 0.33454522490501404]]
Context 8: [['Jayawardena, R. S., Hyde, K. D., Damm, U., Cai, L., Liu, M., Li, X. H., Zhang, W., Zhao, W. S., and Yan, J. Y. (2016). Notes on currently accepted species of Colletotrichum. Mycosphere, 7, 1192-1260.', 0.31869038939476013]]
