query: How might the findings from this study on C. truncatum pathotypes influence future research into fungal diseases in chili pepper cultivation?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['The phytopathogenic fungus Colletotrichum truncatum infects and colonizes chili fruit through direct penetration of the cuticle. The cutinase gene of C. truncatum (CtCut1), a cutin-degrading enzyme, was identified, cloned, and shown to be essential for breaching the cuticle of chili fruit. The expression of the CtCut1 gene was studied through RNA-mediated gene silencing, and its impact on fungal pathogenicity was demonstrated. A vector, pAA1, encoding a hairpin RNA of GFP and CtCut1 was constructed and transformed into the virulent strain of C. truncatum, pathotype F8-3B. The F8-3B-pAA1 transformants exhibited reduced patterns of infection, with one isolate showing a 45.8% reduction in cutinase activity (reduction in CtCut1 transcript) compared to the wild type. Importantly, CtCut1-deficient strains were unable to infect detached chili and soybean hosts as efficiently as the wild type, showing a delay in the infection period. However, artificial wounding of the cuticle allowed these F8-3B-pAA1 transformants to infect and colonize host tissues, resulting in typical anthracnose disease lesions. Coupled with microscopy, these data suggested that the defect in pathogenicity was likely due to a failure in penetrating the host cutin. This research contributes to the understanding of plant-fungal interactions through the development of a fungal transformation system for C. truncatum and the implementation of RNAi technology, which provides an alternative genetic tool for studies of gene function, particularly for essential pathogenicity genes.', 0.9469877481460571]]
Context 1: [['The ex-type strain was included in the study by Nirenberg et al. (2002) as C. acutatum, and strain CBS 120708 was part of research on Colletotrichum diseases of chili in Thailand (Than et al. 2008a), where ITS and TUB2 sequences were generated, identifying it as C. acutatum, a representative of one of two clades of that species complex associated with chili. In drop inoculation tests, strains from this clade were observed to cause typical anthracnose symptoms on chili fruits. Other species (or species complexes) causing chili diseases were reported by Than et al. (2008a), identifying isolates as C. gloeosporioides and C. capsici. The latter taxon was subsequently synonymized with C. truncatum by Damm et al. (2009). Additionally, other Colletotrichum species were reported from the C. boninese species complex, including C. novae-zelandiae and C. karstii from New Zealand.', 0.7171730399131775]]
Context 2: [['Anthracnose, caused by Colletotrichum species, is a serious disease affecting over 30 plant genera. Several DNA phylogenetic studies have identified Colletotrichum species that infect chili in various countries. Despite China being the largest producer of chili, with significant multi-gene analysis, little is known about the species affecting local crops. In this study, samples of diseased chili were collected from 29 provinces in China, resulting in the isolation of 1,285 strains. We observed and compared the morphological characteristics of all strains, and performed multi-locus phylogenetic analyses (ITS, ACT, CAL, CHS-1, GAPDH, TUB2, and HIS3) on selected representative strains. Fifteen Colletotrichum species were identified, with C. fioriniae, C. fructicola, C. gloeosporioides, C. scovillei, and C. truncatum being the most prevalent. Additionally, three new species, C. conoides, C. grossum, and C. liaoningense, are described in this paper. Colletotrichum aenigma, C. cliviae, C. endophytica, C. hymenocallidis, C. incanum, C. karstii, and C. viniferum were reported for the first time in chili. Pathogenicity was confirmed for all species isolated from chili, except for C. endophytica. This study enhances our understanding of the species responsible for anthracnose in chili and provides valuable information for effective disease management in China.', 0.6820220351219177]]
Context 3: [['Diao, Y.Z., Zhang, C., Xu, J.P., et al. (2015). Genetic differentiation and recombination among geographic populations of the fungal pathogen Colletotrichum truncatum from chili peppers in China. Evolutionary Applications, 8, 108–118.', 0.6404599547386169]]
Context 4: [['Mongkolporn et al. (2010) identified pathotypes of C. truncatum, C. scovillei (formerly C. acutatum), and C. siamense (formerly C. gloeosporioides) within isolates of each species from Thailand. Pathotypes were identified by inoculating wounded fruits of Capsicum baccatum and C. chinense genotypes. All isolates identified as C. gloeosporioides and C. acutatum by Mongkolporn et al. (2010) were subsequently re-identified as C. siamense and C. scovillei, respectively, except for isolate UOM 1137 (F5-2D), which was classified as C. endophyticum. Isolate UOM 1137 was pathogenic in both wound and non-wound bioassays and was classified in the most virulent C. siamense pathotype group (PCg1-R) in Mongkolporn et al. (2010). This contrasts with the study by Manamgoda et al. (2013), where C. endophyticum was described as an endophyte of Pennisetum purpureum. The severity of infection in chili may indicate that Capsicum annuum is the preferred host for C. endophyticum, while P. purpureum is a less favored host, where the pathogen can infect but exists in an endophytic lifestyle. Additionally, isolate UOM 1137 has shorter spores than the type isolate of C. endophyticum, indicating that further isolates of this species need to be collected from chili plants and P. purpureum in Thailand to confirm taxonomy and pathogenicity.', 0.6165298819541931]]
Context 5: [['Colletotrichum truncatum was the most prevalent species causing anthracnose in chili across Asia. This supports previous reports of C. truncatum being widely distributed on chili fruit throughout Asia, Australia, and South America (Sharma et al. 2014; De Silva et al. 2017a; Diao et al. 2017; Mongkolporn and Taylor 2018). C. truncatum has a broad host range, infecting many crop species (https://nt.ars-grin.gov/fungaldatabases/; Ranathunge and Hewa Bajjamage 2016).', 0.45973214507102966]]
Context 6: [['Wild type and transformed Colletotrichum truncatum pathotype F8-3B were studied on Capsicum annuum genotype Bangchang. The fruit surface of non-wounded chili was inoculated with 14-day-old C. truncatum transformants F2, F4, and F8. The wild type (FW) was used as the control. The samples were taken from Bangchang leaves 6 hours after inoculation (HAI). Different letters above the transformants indicated significant differences based on analysis of variance (ANOVA). The scores next to the infected fruit indicated the area of anthracnose sunken lesions. The least significant difference (LSD) was calculated at p<0.05 (n=3).', 0.38905856013298035]]
Context 7: [['Pathogenicity tests on chili fruit were conducted using only Colletotrichum isolates with straight conidia, as previous studies have extensively examined the pathogenicity of C. truncatum in chili (Mongkolporn et al. 2010; Ranathunge et al. 2012). The study included 15 representative isolates of C. scovillei from Indonesia, Thailand, and Taiwan, 10 isolates of C. siamense from Indonesia and Thailand, and one isolate each from the other eight species with straight conidia. Detached mature red chili fruits (Capsicum annuum, genotype Bangchang) were used for the pathogenicity assay, following the methodology outlined by De Silva et al. (2017a). The pathogenicity of each isolate was tested using both non-wound and wound inoculation methods. Three replicate fruits were tested per isolate, and the experiments were repeated three times.', 0.3617207109928131]]
Context 8: [['Auyong, A.S.M., Ford, R., & Taylor, P.W.J. (2011). Genetic transformation of Colletotrichum truncatum associated with anthracnose disease of chili by random insertional mutagenesis. Journal of Basic Microbiology, 52, 372-382.', 0.3610196113586426]]
Context 9: [['Auyong et al. (2015) investigated the role of cutinase and its impact on the pathogenicity of Colletotrichum truncatum (Journal of Plant Pathology and Microbiology 6:259-269). Mongkolporn et al. (2010) documented differential reactions on mature green and ripe chili fruit infected by three Colletotrichum species (Plant Disease 94:306-310). Mongkolporn and Taylor (2018) provided an overview of chili anthracnose, discussing Colletotrichum taxonomy and pathogenicity (Plant Pathology 67:1255-1263).', 0.3409797251224518]]

query: How do scientists study the shape and size of Colletotrichum?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Traditionally, Colletotrichum species have been identified based on morphological characteristics. Taxonomists have utilized several features, including the size and shape of conidia and appressoria, the presence or absence of setae, sclerotia, acervuli, and teleomorph states, as well as cultural characters such as colony color, growth rate, and texture (Simmonds, 1965; Smith and Black, 1990; Sutton, 1992; TeBeest et al., 1997; Photita et al., 2005; Than et al., 2008a-c; Thaung, 2008). However, these criteria alone are not always sufficient for reliable differentiation among Colletotrichum species due to variations in morphology and phenotype influenced by environmental factors.', 0.9814573526382446]]
Context 1: [['Traditionally, Colletotrichum species are identified based on morphological characteristics, including conidial and appressorial size and shape, the presence of acervuli, setae, or sclerotia, sexual structures, and cultural traits such as growth rate and colony color. Distinguishing Colletotrichum species morphologically has been challenging due to their phenotypic similarities and the influence of variable environmental factors on the expression of morphological traits. Consequently, all available morphological characteristics are often combined and used for systematic species discrimination.', 0.8544980883598328]]
Context 2: [['Citation: Cai, L., Hyde, K.D., Taylor, P.W.J., Weir, B.S., Waller, J., Abang, M.M., Zhang, J.Z., Yang, Y.L., Phoulivong, S., Liu, Z.Y., Prihastuti, H., Shivas, R.G., McKenzie, E.H.C., Johnston, P.R. (2009). A polyphasic approach for studying Colletotrichum. Fungal Diversity, 39: 183-204.', 0.8415788412094116]]
Context 3: [['Before the molecular era, the taxonomy of Colletotrichum species was primarily based on morphological and cultural characteristics, including conidia size and shape, presence or absence of setae, colony color, and growth rate (von Arx 1957; Sutton 1980, 1992). However, these characteristics can be unreliable for species differentiation due to variability under changing environmental conditions (Cai et al. 2009).', 0.7838033437728882]]
Context 4: [['The genus Colletotrichum represents a large number of economically important Ascomycete fungi that collectively cause anthracnose disease or leaf blights on significant agricultural crops and ornamental plants worldwide. Colletotrichum spp. often serve as models in studies ranging from pathogenic development and differentiation to plant-microbe interactions. During establishment and colonization of host plants, members of this genus uniquely acquire nutrients via both biotrophy and necrotrophy. Thus, in a single interaction, these fungal pathogens exhibit two modes of nutrient acquisition: initially, nutrients are acquired from living cells, after which a necrotrophic phase is initiated, allowing the same fungus to obtain nutrients from dead cells killed by the fungus. A given species of this genus can exhibit both strategies separately or concurrently. Additionally, these fungi develop a series of specialized infection-related structures, including germ tubes, appressoria, primary intracellular hyphae, and secondary necrotrophic hyphae. Therefore, Colletotrichum species are experimentally attractive organisms for studying the molecular, biochemical, and cellular basis of fungal pathogenicity, development, and signal transduction (see Bailey and Jeger, 1992; Prusky et al., 1999).', 0.5832602977752686]]
Context 5: [['Table 5 (continued): The continuation of Table 5 provides further details about additional Colletotrichum species. It outlines their shapes, sizes, and characteristics, such as C. hymenocallidis, which has fusiform shapes measuring 14-18.5(-20) × 5-6.5 µm, and C. truncatum, which is falcate and fusiform with a size range of (15-)21.5-29(-32) × 3-4 µm.', 0.5280983448028564]]
Context 6: [['J. Z., Yang, Y. L., Phoulivong, S., and Liu, Z. Y. (2009). A polyphasic approach for studying Colletotrichum. Fungal Divers., 39, 183-204.', 0.4524387717247009]]

query: What are the primary sources of inoculum for anthracnose in strawberry fields?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Anthracnose is an important disease of strawberry caused by Colletotrichum spp., which affects foliage, runners, crowns, and fruits (Howard et al., 1992). Three primary fungal pathogens—C. acutatum sensu lato, C. gloeosporioides sensu lato, and C. fragariae—are known to cause anthracnose disease in strawberries (Freeman and Katan, 1997). The crown rot syndrome is characteristic of infections from C. gloeosporioides sensu lato and C. fragariae, while fruit rot is mainly attributed to C. acutatum sensu lato, leading to significant yield losses (Howard et al., 1992). Currently, numerous species are classified under what is now known as the C. acutatum complex, with six species—C. acutatum sensu stricto, C. fioriniae, C. godetiae, C. nymphaeae, C. salicis, and C. simmondsii—identified as associated with strawberry anthracnose worldwide (Damm et al., 2012). Among these, C. nymphaeae is the most prevalent pathogen causing strawberry anthracnose globally, including in Iran (Baroncelli et al., 2015; Karimi et al., 2017; Wang et al., 2019). Currently, no effective chemical control methods exist for managing strawberry anthracnose; available options are limited to preventive treatments applied before fruit production (Denoyes-Rothan et al., 1999). Additionally, concerns about the toxic effects of chemical fungicides on the environment and the development of resistance in fungal strains highlight the need for alternative control strategies. Consequently, utilizing resistant cultivars appears to be the most efficient and practical approach for suppressing anthracnose development. In light of recent anthracnose outbreaks in strawberry fields in the Kurdistan province of Iran (Karimi et al., 2017), and the necessity for appropriate strategies to address this issue, the aim of this study was to evaluate the resistance of several commercial strawberry cultivars to the anthracnose fruit rot caused by C. nymphaeae under in vivo and greenhouse conditions.', 0.9833609461784363]]
Context 1: [['Numerous reports indicate that strawberry anthracnose pathogens may originate from weed species. For instance, C. fragariae was found attacking the weed Cassia obtusifolia L. (sicklepod, coffeweed) in Florida, causing typical disease symptoms. Inoculation of strawberry with the Cassia isolates resulted in typical anthracnose symptoms, while isolates from strawberry were equally virulent on Cassia. Similarly, inoculation of Duchesnea indica (Andr.) Focke (wild strawberry), F. virginiana Duch. (Virginia wild strawberry), and Potentilla canadensis L. with C. fragariae induced anthracnose disease on these hosts, suggesting that strawberry anthracnose pathogens have a broad host range.', 0.8156552314758301]]
Context 2: [['So far, anthracnose epidemics have affected strawberry nurseries and production fields worldwide. Reports on Colletotrichum spp. associated with strawberries, curated from literature in PubMed and Clarivate combined with fungal database searches (Farr and Rossman, 2022), were compiled to understand the global diversity and occurrence of the causal agents of strawberry anthracnose. From our findings, since 1931 until July 9, 2022, there have been over 220 citations and 310 records related to the identification of causal agents of strawberry anthracnose at the genus level of Colletotrichum in 36 countries across six continents, with 282 records providing pathogen identification at the species or species complex level.', 0.7637637257575989]]
Context 3: [["Anthracnose fungi can attack various parts of the strawberry plant, including crowns, petioles, leaves, fruit trusses, flowers, buds, and fruit. The fungi's ability to attack multiple plant parts, coupled with the involvement of several pathogen species, contributes to the complex nature of strawberry anthracnose. Brooks reported in 1931 that C. fragariae caused spotting and girdling of runners, and later indicated that it also caused spotting of petioles and crown rot in a summer nursery, leading to wilting and death of the plants. Researchers in Louisiana observed all these symptoms and noted that crown rot also occurred in the fruit production field.", 0.5061087012290955]]
Context 4: [['The term "anthracnose" was first used to describe a new disease of strawberries caused by Colletotrichum fragariae Brooks. "Strawberry anthracnose" continues to be used as a general term to identify all diseases of strawberries caused by species of Colletotrichum. Strawberry anthracnose diseases have been reported to be caused by C. acutatum J.H. Simmonds, C. gloeosporioides (Penz.) Penz. & Sacc. in Penz. (the teleomorph of Cromereilla cingulata (Stoneman) Spauld. & H. Schrenk), and C. dematium (Pers.) Grove. The latter species only occasionally causes strawberry fruit rots and will not be discussed here.', 0.47317013144493103]]

Context 7: [['From May to September 1995, a severe outbreak of strawberry anthracnose was observed in several strawberry-growing nurseries in Israel. Following transplantation to production fields during September and October, entire beds of strawberry plants collapsed. Typical anthracnose symptoms observed from November 1995 to June 1996 included crown rot, flower blight, and green and ripe fruit rot. This marked the first record of strawberry anthracnose in Israel. Furthermore, in at least four production fields in the same region, hundreds of plants developed symptoms of stunting and chlorosis, which are atypical of strawberry anthracnose. When these plants were uprooted, most of their roots were dark brown and decayed. Colletotrichum was readily isolated from these samples.', 0.4024795889854431]]

query: How does Colletotrichum survive between growing seasons?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Citation: Cai, L., Hyde, K.D., Taylor, P.W.J., Weir, B.S., Waller, J., Abang, M.M., Zhang, J.Z., Yang, Y.L., Phoulivong, S., Liu, Z.Y., Prihastuti, H., Shivas, R.G., McKenzie, E.H.C., Johnston, P.R. (2009). A polyphasic approach for studying Colletotrichum. Fungal Diversity, 39: 183-204.', 0.40100207924842834]]
Context 1: [['The genus Colletotrichum represents a large number of economically important Ascomycete fungi that collectively cause anthracnose disease or leaf blights on significant agricultural crops and ornamental plants worldwide. Colletotrichum spp. often serve as models in studies ranging from pathogenic development and differentiation to plant-microbe interactions. During establishment and colonization of host plants, members of this genus uniquely acquire nutrients via both biotrophy and necrotrophy. Thus, in a single interaction, these fungal pathogens exhibit two modes of nutrient acquisition: initially, nutrients are acquired from living cells, after which a necrotrophic phase is initiated, allowing the same fungus to obtain nutrients from dead cells killed by the fungus. A given species of this genus can exhibit both strategies separately or concurrently. Additionally, these fungi develop a series of specialized infection-related structures, including germ tubes, appressoria, primary intracellular hyphae, and secondary necrotrophic hyphae. Therefore, Colletotrichum species are experimentally attractive organisms for studying the molecular, biochemical, and cellular basis of fungal pathogenicity, development, and signal transduction (see Bailey and Jeger, 1992; Prusky et al., 1999).', 0.3988313674926758]]
Context 2: [['Yang, Y.L., Liu, Z.Y., Cai, L., Hyde, K.D., Yu, Z.N., & McKenzie, E.H.C. (2009). Colletotrichum.', 0.32454144954681396]]

Context 5: [['Bailey, J.A., and Jeger, M.J. (1992). Colletotrichum: Biology, Pathology and Control. Wallingford: CAB International.', 0.2611664831638336]]
Context 6: [['Many species belonging to the genus Colletotrichum are associated with plant diseases, commonly referred to as anthracnose. Colletotrichum spp. can affect a wide range of hosts, and these pathogens are characterized by global distribution. Virtually every cultivated botanical family is susceptible to one or more species of Colletotrichum, making it one of the most studied plant pathogenic fungi (Prusky et al., 2000; Latunde-Dada, 2001; Dean et al., 2012). Common hosts include many dicotyledonous plants such as strawberry, apple, citrus, and stone fruits, as well as major cereals such as maize and sorghum. Members of this genus can cause crop losses of up to 100% in many staple foods (Bailey and Jeger, 1992; Prusky et al., 2000; Talhinhas et al., 2005; Cannon et al., 2012).', 0.2609259784221649]]

Context 1: [['Compared to Ca(NO3)2, the (NH4)2SO4 treatment reduced the percentage of blackened roots. The influence of the cover crops on growth and disease was more pronounced with (NH4)2SO4 fertilization than with Ca(NO3)2. Combining ‘Saia’ oats or sorgho-sudangrass rotation with (NH4)2SO4 fertilization led to a reduction in lesion nematode (Pratylenchus penetrans) numbers in subsequent strawberry roots compared to controls. Furthermore, the combination of ‘Saia’ or ‘Garry’ oats as a precrop with applications of (NH4)2SO4 reduced black root rot severity relative to controls. Only the ‘Garry’ oat rotation reduced strawberry root colonization by Rhizoctonia fragariae when compared to controls. Additional effects associated with (NH4)2SO4 treatment included a decrease in rhizosphere soil pH by 0.2 units, a reduction in fluorescent pseudomonads in the rhizosphere by 10- to 15-fold, and leaves with higher concentrations of nitrogen, potassium, sulfur, manganese, and zinc compared to plants treated with Ca(NO3)2. query: How does ap-PCR assist in Colletotrichum identification?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Random Amplified Polymorphic DNA (RAPD), or ap-PCR, has been extensively utilized for the identification and characterization of isolates in Colletotrichum. We employed ap-PCR using primers derived from minisatellite or repeat sequences (CAGCAGCAGCAGCAG, TGTCTGTCTGTCTGTC, GACACGACACGACAC, GACAGACAGACAGACA) to compare Colletotrichum species from almond, avocado, strawberry, and other fruits. Unique band patterns were observed among the clonal populations of C. acutatum from strawberry and C. gloeosporioides from almond, while avocado isolates exhibited polymorphisms.', 0.9959824085235596]]
Context 1: [['Traditional methods may not accurately differentiate between species and subspecies of Colletotrichum. Consequently, various molecular methods have been used to characterize populations. Arbitrarily primed polymerase chain reaction (ap-PCR) and limited restriction digest analyses of PCR-amplified ribosomal DNA (rDNA) have been employed to differentiate representative isolates of C. gloeosporioides and C. acutatum from diverse hosts, including strawberry.', 0.9456502199172974]]
Context 2: [['Development of a molecular tool to distinguish Colletotrichum species affecting peach: A two-step multiplex PCR method was developed to differentiate Colletotrichum species affecting peach in South Carolina. The first PCR amplified a 359-bp fragment from the GAPDH gene using primer pair GDF1/C-GAPDH-R from all Colletotrichum species. The cocktail also contained forward primer CALF1 and reverse primers Cg-R and Ca-R1, which produced amplicons of 649 bp or 491 bp in length from the C. gloeosporioides species complex (C. siamense and C. fructicola) or C. acutatum, respectively (see Fig. 5A). In the second PCR, primer pair G3F1/C-GAPDH-R generated a 280-bp fragment from the GAPDH gene from both C. siamense and C. fructicola, while primer pair CL1C/CALR1 generated a 550-bp fragment from the CAL gene from C. fructicola, but not from C. siamense (see Fig. 5B). All isolates used in this study for phylogenetic analysis and pathogenicity tests were subjected to this test and produced the expected amplicon sizes with this new multiplex PCR tool.', 0.8925333619117737]]
Context 3: [['Sreenivasaprasad, S., Mills, P. R., and Brown, P. E. 1994. Nucleotide sequence of the rDNA spacer 1 enables identification of isolates of Colletotrichum as C. acutatum. Mycol. Res. 98:186-188.', 0.8807651400566101]]

Context 7: [['Comparison of Colletotrichum isolates by ap-PCR. The Israeli isolates were categorized based on site, plot, cultivar, and strawberry tissue origins (refer to Table 1). Genomic DNA from 121 Israeli isolates obtained from crown, fruit, and stolons was amplified via ap-PCR using four oligonucleotide primers: (CAG)5, (GACA)4, (TGTC)4, and (GACAC)3. The resulting amplicons for each primer were nearly identical.', 0.8391949534416199]]
Context 8: [['rDNA genes exist as multiple copies in the genome. Due to the lesser conservation of sequence, the non-transcribed and internal transcribed spacer (ITS) regions between the small and large nuclear rDNA subunits are suitable for detecting recent evolutionary divergence within Colletotrichum. In our study, limited restriction digest analyses of PCR-amplified rDNA were utilized to differentiate representative isolates of C. gloeosporioides from a diverse range of hosts, as well as from rDNA of C. acutatum sourced from strawberry. Species-specific primers have been designed based on the dissimilarities in the sequences of the ITS regions from various Colletotrichum species. We employed such primers to differentiate between C. acutatum and C. gloeosporioides. As shown in Figure 5A, a single PCR-amplified fragment of 490 bp was evident in isolates of C. acutatum from a broad host range but was absent in C. gloeosporioides isolates. Similarly, primers specific for C. gloeosporioides and C. fragariae amplified a specific 450-bp fragment, allowing these two species to be distinguished from C. acutatum. This method also facilitated the differentiation between C. acutatum from almond, apple, peach, and strawberry, and C. gloeosporioides from papaya and citrus. These findings indicate that rDNA analysis serves as an effective taxonomic tool for species identification and diagnostic pathogen detection in plants, although it may not reveal subpopulations within a species.', 0.8252989649772644]]
Context 9: [['Fig. 7. Interspecies band patterns of arbitrarily primed polymerase chain reaction (AP-PCR) amplified genomic DNA from isolates of Colletotrichum obtained from various hosts using primers (A) (CAG)5 and (B) (GACA)4, represented as follows: CA (C. acutatum from strawberry, California); CF (C. fragariae from strawberry, Mississippi); CG-1 and CG-2 (C. gloeosporioides from strawberry, Florida); PCN-3 and PCN-4 (C. gloeosporioides from pecan, Louisiana); PCN-5 (C. acutatum from pecan, Alabama); PCH-13 (C. gloeosporioides from peach, South Carolina); SF-7 (C. acutatum from peach, South Carolina); STR-2 and STR-3 (C. acutatum from strawberry, South Carolina); APL-7 (C. gloeosporioides from apple, North Carolina); ALM-B, ALM-G, ALM-I, and ALM-K (C. gloeosporioides from almond, Israel); and AVO-1 and AVO-5 (C. gloeosporioides from avocado, Israel). query: How does clade-based calibration improve the accuracy of disease models?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Clade-based calibration has its limitations. For instance, the acutatum clade, which impacts multiple hosts such as strawberry, almond, olive, and lupin, displayed significant variability in incubation and latency periods based on the host. At 15°C, the latency period was 5 days on strawberry fruits (King et al., 1997), 19 days on olive fruits (Moral et al., 2012), and about 10 days on lupin (Diggle et al., 2002). This variability resulted in equations for these polyphagous clades generally yielding lower CCC values, higher RMSE values, and CRM values further from zero. The effects of high within-clade variability were also reflected in the model validation results, which indicated better predictions for clades with fewer species and hosts. The acutatum and gloeosporioides clades, encompassing multiple species and hosts, had overall CCC values of 0.895 and 0.910, respectively. In contrast, the graminicola clade, a well-defined monophyletic group mainly associated with grasses (Talhinhas and Baroncelli, 2021), achieved the highest CCC value of 0.973.', 0.8945708274841309]]

query: How can we tell if a fruit has a disease?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Two distinct types of diseases occur: those affecting developing fruit in the field (preharvest) and those damaging mature fruit during storage (postharvest). The ability to cause latent or quiescent infections has categorized Colletotrichum among the most important postharvest pathogens. Species of the pathogen predominantly appear on aboveground plant tissues; however, belowground organs, such as roots and tubers, may also be affected.', 0.29202908277511597]]
Context 1: [['On certain fruits, such as apple and blueberry (Vaccinium spp.), members of the C. acutatum species complex cause both pre-harvest and post-harvest diseases (Milholland, 1995; Jones et al., 1996; Shi et al., 1996). On these plants, asymptomatic, quiescent infections occur on unripe fruit, developing into necrotic lesions as the fruit ripens (Alkan et al., 2015). There are many other examples of post-harvest decay in fruits like peaches (Prunus persica), almonds (Prunus dulcis), avocado (Persea americana), mango (Mangifera indica), papaya (Carica papaya), and guava (Psidium guajava) that stem from quiescent infections that began in the field (Agostini et al., 1992; Freeman and Shabi, 1996; Smith, 1998; Afanador-Kafuri et al., 2003).', 0.2607690989971161]]

query: What preventive measures can farmers take to reduce the spread of anthracnose in their fields?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Anthracnose spreads within a field by splashing water, and living mulches (such as wheat, rye, or ryegrass) in row middles have been shown to reduce disease spread within a field. Sublethal doses of grass-specific herbicides, such as sethoxydim, may be used to prevent excessive growth of ryegrass (Gupton, 2000). Organic mulches, such as wheat straw or pine needles, also reduce splash and result in a lower incidence of anthracnose compared to rows mulched with plastic (Madden, 1992; Smith and Spiers, 1986). Additionally, anthracnose is less severe when water is supplied to plants using drip irrigation rather than overhead irrigation (Madden, 1992; Smith and Spiers, 1986). Anthracnose crown rot was observed to be less severe in commercial fields when strawberries were grown in soils with low nitrogen fertility (Howard et al., 1992). In greenhouse studies, Smith (1987, 1989) determined that strawberries grown in soils with high levels of nitrogen, especially from ammonium sources, are more susceptible to anthracnose than plants grown in soils with lower nitrogen levels or those with high levels of calcium nitrate.', 0.9697760939598083]]
Context 1: [['Anthracnose spreads within a field through splashing water. Living mulches, such as wheat, rye, or rye grass, in row middles have been shown to reduce disease spread. Organic mulches like wheat straw or pine needles also reduce splash and result in a lower incidence of anthracnose compared to rows mulched with plastic (Coelho et al., 2008; Madden, 1992; Smith and Spiers, 1986). Additionally, anthracnose is less severe when water is supplied to plants using drip irrigation rather than overhead irrigation (Coelho et al., 2008; Madden, 1992; Smith and Spiers, 1986).', 0.8346567749977112]]
Context 2: [['Until highly resistant cultivars are available, growers must rely on chemical applications and cultural practices to reduce losses due to anthracnose. The failure of fungicides to control anthracnose epidemics may be attributed to the development of fungicide resistance in the Colletotrichum species population. For example, benomyl was shown to effectively reduce the incidence of anthracnose crown rot (Horn et al., 1972; Howard, 1971) and was used intensively by strawberry growers for years to control anthracnose and other diseases. However, the anthracnose pathogens, C. acutatum and C. fragariae, developed resistance to it and other benzimidazole fungicides (LaMondia, 1995; McInnes et al., 1992a; Smith and Black, 1992, 1993), leading to the ineffectiveness of benomyl for anthracnose control in strawberry fields.', 0.809452474117279]]
Context 3: [['Until highly resistant cultivars are available, growers must rely on chemical applications and cultural practices to reduce losses due to anthracnose. The failure of fungicides to control anthracnose epidemics may be due to the development of fungicide resistance in the Colletotrichum spp. population. For example, benomyl effectively reduced the incidence of anthracnose crown rot (Horn et al., 1972; Howard, 1971) and was used intensively by strawberry growers for years to control anthracnose and other diseases. However, the anthracnose pathogens, C. acutatum and C. fragariae, developed resistance to it and other benzimidazole fungicides (LaMondia, 1995; McInnes et al., 1992a; Smith and Black, 1992, 1993), rendering benomyl ineffective for anthracnose control in strawberry fields.', 0.8088865280151367]]
Context 4: [['As our understanding of the anthracnose pathogens and the epidemiology of anthracnose diseases has improved, so has our capacity to control these diseases. Changes in cultural practices have led to reduced levels of disease. Additionally, the development and registration of more effective fungicides for use on strawberries have significantly decreased losses due to anthracnose crown rot and fruit rot. The introduction of partially resistant cultivars has also helped mitigate economic losses due to these diseases. Nonetheless, growers may still experience severe losses when environmental conditions are highly conducive to anthracnose development.', 0.24276426434516907]]
Context 5: [['Urdaneta, L., Sanabria, M., Rodríguez, D., & Pérez de Camacaro, M. (2013). Antracnosis causada por Colletotrichum spp. Investigación Agraria, 20(1), 38-50.', 0.22457687556743622]]
Context 6: [['Increased losses due to anthracnose fruit and crown rots may be related to the shift from matted-row culture to the annual plasticulture production system in the United States. Breeding for genetic resistance to anthracnose and the development of resistant cultivars are primary means for reducing economic losses due to this disease. This approach is environmentally sound because it results in reduced fungicide use. As our knowledge of the anthracnose pathogens and the epidemiology of anthracnose diseases has increased, so has our ability to control these diseases. Changes in cultural practices have resulted in reduced levels of disease. Simultaneously, the development of more effective fungicides and their registration for use on strawberries have significantly reduced losses due to both anthracnose crown rot and fruit rot. Anthracnose-resistant cultivars have also decreased economic losses caused by these diseases. Nevertheless, growers may still face severe losses when environmental conditions are highly favorable for anthracnose development.', 0.2231176346540451]]
Context 7: [['Additional Keywords: anthracnose, disease spread, Fragaria × ananassa, models, quantitative epidemiology.', 0.2138330191373825]]
Context 8: [['As our knowledge of the anthracnose pathogens and the epidemiology of anthracnose diseases has increased, so has our ability to control these diseases. Anthracnose-resistant cultivars have also diminished economic losses due to these diseases. Nevertheless, growers may still experience severe losses when environmental factors are highly favorable for anthracnose development.', 0.2122754007577896]]
Context 9: [['Strandberg, J. O., Stamps, R. H., and Norman, D. J. 1996. Fern Anthracnose: A Guide for Effective Disease Management. University of Florida, Agricultural Experiment Station Technical Bulletin 900.', 0.21178005635738373]]

query: How do protective fungicides like propiconazole and systemic ones like prochloraz differ in their modes of action against pathogens such as Colletotrichum?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Past failures of fungicides to control anthracnose epidemics may have stemmed from the development of resistance in the Colletotrichum population. In the early 1970s, benomyl effectively reduced anthracnose crown rot incidence (Horn et al., 1972; Howard, 1971) and was widely used by strawberry growers for years. However, anthracnose pathogens developed resistance to it and other benzimidazole fungicides, rendering benomyl ineffective. In vitro and greenhouse trials have been conducted to identify fungicides to which Colletotrichum pathogens have developed resistance (LaMondia, 1993, 1995; McInnes et al., 1992a, 1992b; Smith and Black, 1991, 1992, 1993). Current fungicide labels address pathogen resistance by restricting the number of consecutive and total applications of a product per season. For instance, the fungicides Abound (azoxystrobin, Syngenta, Greensboro, NC), Cabrio (pyraclostrobin, BASF, Research Triangle Park, NC), and Pristine (pyraclostrobin and boscalid, BASF) are limited to four or five applications per season, with no more than two consecutive applications before alternating with a fungicide that has a different mode of action. Natural products have also been evaluated as alternative fungicides, offering different modes of action, lower toxicity, and increased efficacy (Abril et al., 2008).', 0.9138763546943665]]
Context 1: [['Table 1 presents the effective doses of various fungicides that resulted in 50% inhibition (ED50) of Colletotrichum acutatum in vitro. The table includes entries for captan, propiconazole, difenoconazole, prochloraz-Zn combined with folpet, prochloraz-Zn alone, and prochloraz-Mn, listing the specific concentrations needed for each to achieve the inhibition. This data highlights the comparative efficacy of these fungicides in controlling the pathogen in laboratory settings.', 0.6484850645065308]]
Context 2: [['This study evaluated the fungicides prochloraz-Zn, prochloraz-Mn (both protectant sterol-biosynthesis inhibitors), captan, folpet, a combined formulation of prochloraz-Zn and folpet, propiconazole, difenoconazole, and a heat treatment for the control of C. acutatum in naturally infected strawberry plants under laboratory, greenhouse, and field conditions. Fungicides were applied at the transplant stage to determine whether a single-dip treatment is sufficient for disease control.', 0.2902132272720337]]
Context 3: [['Certain fungicides, including propiconazole, have been reported to successfully limit in vitro growth of C. fragariae, while fluazinam, a protectant fungicide, provides good control of strawberry anthracnose in post-harvest berries.', 0.2065034657716751]]
Context 4: [['Additional keywords: phosphonate fungicides, phosphorous acid.', 0.19304533302783966]]
Context 5: [['Los resultados in vitro indicaron que los fungicidas triazoles, estrobilurinas en mezclas, y el mancozeb inhibieron el 100% de Colletotrichum fragariae. En condiciones in vivo, el efecto de los productos Tebuconazole+Trifloxystrobin, Trifloxystrobin+Cyproconazole, Mancozeb y Azoxystrobin+Propiconazole+Difenoconazole sobre la incidencia fue moderado, reduciendo la severidad en un 51-63% y la intensidad de daño de la antracnosis en un 60-77%. Las plantas tratadas con Tebuconazole+Trifloxystrobin mostraron un mayor contenido de clorofila.', 0.1825505942106247]]
Context 6: [['The sensitivity ranges of the isolates to various fungicides were 0.2 to 1.6 mg/ml and 0.002 to 0.2 mg/ml, respectively, with average values of 6.5 to 6.9 mg/ml, 1.5 to 0.6 mg/ml, 0.9 to 0.4 mg/ml, and 0.1 to 0.05 mg/ml, respectively. All isolates were more sensitive to difenoconazole, flusilazole, and carbendazim than to tebuconazole (P < 0.01). However, sensitivities to the same fungicide varied among isolates. Specifically, isolates SL-31 and TS-09 were the least sensitive to carbendazim and tebuconazole, with resistance ratios of 87.3 and 51.6, respectively. Sensitivities to difenoconazole and flusilazole were largely consistent across all isolates, with resistance ratios ranging from 1 to 4.6 and from 1 to 7, respectively. Therefore, difenoconazole and flusilazole could be recommended for disease control. Notably, differences in pathogenicity and fungicide sensitivity were not correlated with geographic regions. These findings indicate a high level of intraspecific diversity within the populations of Colletotrichum gloeosporioides s.s. responsible for walnut anthracnose. For effective management, a targeted control strategy should be developed based on different geographic regions.', 0.1823989897966385]]
Context 7: [["This table presents the toxicity data of four fungicides against Colletotrichum gloeosporioides sensu stricto. It includes the median effective concentration (EC50) values measured in mg/ml and the corresponding 95% confidence intervals (CI). The fungicides tested are Tebuconazole, Difenoconazole, Flusilazole, and Carbendazim. Tebuconazole showed an EC50 value ranging between 6.5 and 6.9 mg/ml, while Difenoconazole had a lower value between 1.5 and 0.6 mg/ml. Flusilazole had an EC50 value ranging from 0.9 to 0.4 mg/ml, and Carbendazim demonstrated the lowest toxicity with an EC50 value between 0.1 and 0.05 mg/ml. The table also notes that means sharing a common letter in the same column are not significantly different according to Tukey's Honestly Significant Difference (HSD) test (P < 0.01).", 0.18233086168766022]]
Context 8: [['Fungicide-amended petri plates (9-cm diameter) were used to assess the in vitro activity of several fungicides, including captan (Marpan, 50WP), folpet (Folpan, 50WP), prochloraz-Zn (Mirage, 50WP), prochloraz-Mn (Octave, 50WP), a combination of prochloraz-Zn and folpet (Mirage-F, 15 and 60WP), propiconazole (Tilt, 25% EC), and difenoconazole (Score, 25% EC) against C. acutatum. Mycelial disks (5 mm in diameter, removed from the margins of 4- to 5-day-old cultures) were transferred to MS amended with the tested fungicides at various concentrations, ranging from 0 to 500 µg/ml. The radial growth of the mycelium was measured.', 0.14651107788085938]]

retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['To address the limitations of profile alignment, we implemented an option called —add in 2010, allowing the addition of unaligned sequences to an existing multiple sequence alignment (MSA). This option assumes that each new sequence is derived from a branch in the tree of an existing alignment, as illustrated in Figure 1D. The —add option works similarly to the standard progressive method, except that the alignment calculation is skipped at the nodes whose children are all part of the existing alignment.', 0.49045315384864807]]

Context 3: [['The last two lines in Table 2 (Cases 2 and 3) display the performance of the fast option (—-6merpair —addfragments) for a larger number (138,210) of fragmentary sequences. The existing alignment contains 1,000 sequences in Case 2 and 13,822 in Case 3. This fast option provides a reasonable quality of results within a reasonable computation time. Currently, the default option (—-multipair —addfragments) cannot manage Cases 2 and 3. Simulation-based benchmarks in Katoh and Frith (2012) suggested that, for cases with more divergent sequences, the accuracy of the default option is superior to that of the fast option. We are actively working to enhance the scalability of the default option.', 0.17515957355499268]]
Context 4: [['The method is suitable for aligning distantly related sequences. We selected default parameters based on the expectation that if the program works well for difficult (distantly related) cases, it should also perform well for easier cases. However, further studies using actual sequence data will be necessary before implementing extensions such as using different scoring matrices and gap penalties based on the divergence level, similar to ClustalW (Thompson et al. 1994). It remains unclear whether this expectation holds true in all scenarios. For instance, a benchmark using simulated protein sequences (Lo‹ytynoja et al. 2012), generated by INDELiBLE (Fletcher and Yang 2009), showed that employing a more stringent scoring matrix, JTT 1PAM (Jones et al. 1992), with weaker gap penalties than the defaults, significantly improved benchmark scores. Context 5: [['In particular, the new options to add sequences into an existing alignment, as listed in Table 1, require careful consideration of this tradeoff, as discussed later. query: What is the significance of the 57-bp intron from CtCut1 in the pAA1 cassette's gene silencing mechanism?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Figure 1: a) Schematic representation map of the pAA1 cassette expressing cut hairpin RNA, targeting the cutinase gene in Colletotrichum truncatum. The pAA1 recombinant silencing plasmid was derived from pJF1_ShhGFP, which is a derivative of plasmid pJF1. Arrows indicate the direction of the Cut gene fragment. The "in" indicates the 57-bp intron from CtCut1. ToxA represents the Pyrenophora tritici-repentis ToxA promoter, and Nos represents the Nos terminator. Restriction enzyme sites are indicated as follows: H for HindIII, S for SmaI, Xb for XbaI, B for BamHI, and E for EcoRI. The nucleotide sequence of the cutinase gene is available from the NCBI database (Accession no. HQ406775). b) Plasmid map of pAA1.', 0.9854206442832947]]
Context 1: [['Figure 3 illustrates the nucleotide sequence of a cloned genomic DNA for the Colletotrichum truncatum isolate F8-3B CtCut1 gene (accession no. HQ406775). The deduced amino acid sequence is shown above the open reading frame. The untranslated sequence gap beginning at nucleotide 868 is a 57-bp intron. The CAAT and TAAATA boxes for transcription, as well as the potential polyadenylation site (TAAA), are underlined. The three potential AATs are italicized. The ‘*’ indicates the stop codon of the ORF (represented by the amino acid sequences), while ‘˚’ represents the false stop codon in the intron region. Translation was carried out using SIXFRAME (Biology Workbench 3.2, University of California San Diego, 1999). Primer sites used to amplify the gene are shaded in grey. The bolded nucleotide sequence was used as a probe in Southern analysis. The cutinase cDNA fragment was also used to generate the hairpin transcriptional unit for RNAi silencing.', 0.9362274408340454]]
Context 2: [['Two binary vectors, designated as pJF1_ShhGFP and pAA1, were created for RNA-mediated gene silencing. The sGFP cassette driven by the ToxA promoter from the pJF1 plasmid was removed by digestion at the HindIII-EcoRI site, resulting in an open plasmid for cloning the desired fragment. A 1354-bp DNA fragment containing regulatory sequences, along with the sense and antisense of GFP interrupted by the C. truncatum cutinase (Accession number HQ406775) intron to form a hairpin structure, was synthesized and cloned into the HindIII-EcoRI digested site of pJF1, producing the pJF1_ShhGFP fungal silencing plasmid (DNA2.0, USA). The second fungal silencing vector, pAA1, was constructed by cloning the sense and antisense strands of the cutinase cDNA into SmaI-XhoI and BamHI-XbaI sites of the pJF1_ShhGFP plasmid. The internal cutinase fragment (from 17 bp to 532 bp) was amplified with primers SmaI-CutS-F and XbaI-CutS-R to generate the sense (540 bp) and with primers BamHI-CutAS-F and XhoI-CutAS-R to generate the antisense (541 bp). Amplifications were performed in two separate reactions using 20 ng/µl C. truncatum cutinase DNA previously cloned into the pCRfi4-TOPOfi vector (Invitrogen, Australia) as a template.', 0.9114914536476135]]
Context 3: [['The intron sequence used to form the hairpin in the pAA1 plasmid derived from the cutinase gene of C. truncatum, which likely reduced the possibility of organism rejection. Proper regulation of RNA-silencing machinery, enabling high levels of gene silencing, was anticipated. In contrast, Praveen et al. reported that the use of intron sequences from non-related organisms might yield lower gene silencing efficacy.', 0.8126713037490845]]
Context 4: [['In contrast, Skamnioti et al. [53] reported the existence of multiple cutinase families in Magnaporthe grisea, Fusarium graminearum, Botrytis cinerea, Aspergillus nidulans, and Neurospora crassa. They achieved RNA-mediated gene silencing in C. truncatum using a hairpin plasmid, specifically pAA1, which incorporated a short fragment of sGFP along with CtCut1 as the silencing target. This method allowed for variable but efficient knockdown of the cutinase gene in C. truncatum.', 0.7936906814575195]]
Context 5: [['In addition, the transformed strains exhibited resilience through multiple rounds of subculture on selective media, indicating stable integration of the pAA1 cassette into the genomes of all transformed strains of C. truncatum. Southern blot analysis confirmed this ectopic integration. Interestingly, the hairpin construct that initiated the gene silencing of CtCut1 resulted in minimal off-target effects in C. truncatum, despite the number of T-DNA copies harboring the pAA1 cassette in the genome. A notable reduction in the mRNA levels of CtCut1 (ranging from 14.9% to 72%) was observed across the transformed strains, with no significant changes in morphology, growth rate, or conidiospore production. Such variability among transformants using this technique has been reported in other fungal studies.', 0.7769684195518494]]
Context 6: [['The wild-type copy of the endogenous cutinase gene, CtCut1, was visible in all genomes as a hybridizing band at approximately 8 kb (Figure 4b). As HindIII and EcoRI cut within the T-DNA insert and outside of the exogenous cutinase silencing transcriptional unit, a band of 2386 bp corresponding to the intact pAA1 cassette was expected and observed (Figure 4b). Undigested and/or partially digested pAA1 plasmid was also seen hybridizing at approximately 10 kb (Figure 4b).', 0.7194681167602539]]
Context 7: [['A 1936-bp cutinase genomic DNA fragment from Colletotrichum truncatum pathotype F8-3B was obtained and designated as CtCut1. The primer binding sites of the sequence were identified. The predicted molecular weight for CtCut1 DNA was 1196.35 kDa. The nucleotide sequence contained portions identical to the partial gene obtained previously from RT-PCR results (data not shown). Sequence analysis of the gene revealed an open reading frame (ORF) of 684 nucleotides with a stop codon (TGA), interrupted by a single 57-bp intron. The predicted ORF encoded a polypeptide of 228 amino acids with a predicted molecular weight of 23.81 kDa and a predicted protein isoelectric point (pI) of 7.82. The nucleotide and predicted amino acid sequences showed significant 99% identity to the cutinase of C. capsici isolated from papaya, and 85% and 84% identity to G. cingulata and C. gloeosporioides, respectively.', 0.6244551539421082]]
Context 8: [['The pAA1 plasmid was stably transformed into C. truncatum through Agrobacterium tumefaciens-mediated transformation, effectively suppressing the entire gene family (homologous genes) and avoiding gene compensation issues. Baulcombe [54] demonstrated that co-suppression of gene families occurred during the disruption of the quelling defective (qde-1) gene mutation, resulting in silencing of a tomato RNA-dependent RNA polymerase homologue in N. crassa. The incorporation of the hairpin cassette into the fungal genome activated the endogenous RNA interference machinery within the pathogen, leading to the silencing of homologues as seen with the OsRac gene in Oryza sativa.', 0.48548874258995056]]

query: What are the advantages of using Life Science Identifiers (LSIDs) in fungal taxonomy and classification as seen in the Index of Fungi?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Currently, the biological community benefits significantly from central institutions that generate indexes, such as the Index of Fungi, which is published biannually. This index compiles names and associated Life Science Identifiers (LSIDs) and covers all nomenclatural novelties published for fungi, both extant and extinct. It is an indispensable source of information, with content assessed for validity, legitimacy, and orthography. Another related initiative is the online database Index Fungorum, maintained by the Index Fungorum Partnership, which includes CABI Bioscience (UK), the Centraalbureau voor Schimmelcultures (the Netherlands), and Landcare Research (New Zealand). This index is accessible on the Internet at http://www.indexfungorum.org.', 0.9874131679534912]]
Context 1: [['Abstract: An online database, MycoBank (http://www.MycoBank.org), has been launched with the aim of documenting mycological nomenclatural novelties along with their associated descriptions and illustrations. Each nomenclatural novelty will be assigned a unique accession number that can be cited in the publication where the novelty is introduced. These accession numbers will also be incorporated into Life Science Identifiers (LSIDs) (http://www-124.ibm.com/developerworks/oss/lsid) allocated by the nomenclatural database Index Fungorum (http://www.IndexFungorum.org), with which MycoBank is associated. Nomenclatural experts will be available to check the validity, legitimacy, and linguistic correctness of the proposed names; nomenclatural errors will thus be detected before publication, although no censorship (either nomenclatural or taxonomic) will be exerted by MycoBank. When applicable, MycoBank will provide onward links to other databases containing, for example, living cultures, DNA data, reference specimens, and pleomorphic names linked to the same holomorph. Names will remain strictly confidential until after publication, at which point they will be accessible in MycoBank, Index Fungorum, GBIF, and other international biodiversity initiatives, where they will further be linked to other databases to create a species bank that eventually connects all databases of life. Authors intending to publish nomenclatural novelties are encouraged to contribute to this new initiative.', 0.9580733776092529]]
Context 2: [['As names and associated data are accessed into MycoBank, LSIDs will subsequently be available from Index Fungorum, and these will be associated with the basic nomenclatural data. Names entering Index Fungorum via the quarterly updates from the Index of Fungi will also receive associated LSIDs; however, they will only appear in Index Fungorum. It will be the responsibility of authors to submit names with accompanying data to MycoBank. The Index Fungorum Partnership has a Memorandum of Cooperation with GBIF to supply nomenclatural data to the ECAT (http://www.gbif.org/prog/ecat), and as such, all data will be accessible through the GBIF portal (http://www.gbif.net), where they will be further linked with other databases.', 0.4212755560874939]]
Context 3: [['Key Words: fungal systematics, Index Fungorum, Index of Fungi, International Code of Botanical Nomenclature, MycoBank, mycology, online database.', 0.30558058619499207]]

query: What are the primary genetic markers used in the phylogenetic analysis of Colletotrichum species?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['A polyphasic approach combining multilocus phylogenetic analysis with recognizable phenotypic characteristics is recommended for accurate species identification within the Colletotrichum genus. According to Weir et al., internal transcribed spacer (ITS) sequences alone are not reliable for distinguishing different species within the C. gloeosporioides species complex. Additional loci recommended for identifying Colletotrichum species include actin (ACT), calmodulin (CAL), chitin synthase-1 (CHS-1), glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate dehydrogenase (GAPDH), and β-tubulin (TUB2).', 0.9548028111457825]]
Context 1: [['The identification of Colletotrichum species has long been challenging due to limited morphological characteristics. Single-gene phylogenetic analyses have also proven unsuccessful in clearly delineating species, partly due to the high number of erroneous names in GenBank. This paper reviews the taxonomic problems associated with Colletotrichum and the difficulties in identifying taxa at the species level. We advocate for epitypification and the use of multi-locus phylogenetic methods to better delimit species and understand the genus.', 0.9197512865066528]]
Context 2: [['Colletotrichum species are categorized into phylogenetic clades (also referred to as species complexes) based on multilocus molecular analysis. Species within a clade are closely related and share similar temperature requirements (Cannon et al., 2012; Vieira et al., 2020; Talhinhas and Baroncelli, 2021; Salotti et al., 2022). A recent systematic review identified 15 major clades of the genus, along with several smaller clusters and isolated species (Talhinhas and Baroncelli, 2021). Detailed descriptions of these major phylogenetic clades and the species within them have been provided by multiple studies (Cannon et al., 2012; Vieira et al., 2020; Talhinhas and Baroncelli, 2021; Damm et al., 2009, 2012, 2013, 2014; Weir et al., 2012).', 0.9021278619766235]]
Context 3: [['Discussion: Recent phylogenetic studies of the genus Colletotrichum have revealed clustering in 11 major clades, including significant species complexes such as C. acutatum, C. boninense, C. gloeosporioides, and C. truncatum. These studies facilitate the differentiation and description of numerous taxa.', 0.8153965473175049]]
Context 4: [['Table Description: Table 1 provides details on the various Colletotrichum strains used in this study, including isolation details and GenBank accession numbers. Each row of the table lists a strain code, along with the corresponding genus and species names, genetic markers (ITS, TUB, MAT1-2, GAPDH), the country of isolation, host organism, and the associated GenBank accession numbers for each genetic marker. The table showcases multiple isolates from Colletotrichum nymphaeae and Colletotrichum godetiae, with their respective accession numbers indicating the specific sequences submitted to GenBank, which are crucial for understanding the genetic diversity and distribution of these strains associated with strawberries in the UK.', 0.8120957612991333]]
Context 5: [['Ulrike Damm provided an overview of her ongoing collaboration with Paul Cannon regarding the phylogeny of three species complexes. The project aims to delimit species within these complexes, characterize known and new species, and designate epitypes to support accurate identifications of Colletotrichum species. So far, this goal has been achieved for species with curved conidia from herbaceous hosts (Damm et al. 2009), which were previously identified primarily as C. dematium. Multi-gene analyses and morphological characterizations have revealed several diverse and distantly related species, including four new species.', 0.8036015033721924]]
Context 6: [['Du, M., Schardl, C.L., & Vaillancourt, L.J. (2005). Using mating-type gene sequences for improved phylogenetic resolution of Colletotrichum species complexes. Mycologia, 97, 641–58.', 0.7805271744728088]]

Context 8: [['Du, M., Schardl, C.L., Nuckles, E.M., & Vaillancourt, L. (2005). Using mating-type gene sequences for improved phylogenetic resolution of Colletotrichum species complexes. Mycologia 97: 641–658.', 0.7632778286933899]]
Context 9: [['This table summarizes the GenBank accession numbers associated with various species of Colletotrichum isolates utilized in the phylogenetic analyses. It includes entries for the following species: C. siamense, C. fructicola, C. aenigma, C. aeschynomenes, C. alienum, C. asianum, C. gloeosporioides, C. musae, C. nupharicola, C. queenslandicum, C. salsolae, and C. tropicale.', 0.752856433391571]]

query: What distinguishes monophyletic lineages within the C. acutatum species complex from other fungal pathogens?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Considering the frequency with which strains from the C. acutatum species complex are encountered and their pathogenicity to a wide range of crop plants, it would be surprising if earlier names for C. acutatum did not exist. Walker et al. (1991) found that C. xanthii (Halsted 1893) was synonymous with C. acutatum based on morphological criteria, but no authentic sequences are available, and it is currently unclear which clade this species fits into. At that time, there was no interest among Colletotrichum researchers to replace the name C. acutatum, and now the name is so widely used that a change would likely not gain recognition. Other older taxa have been recognized as belonging to the C. acutatum complex, but as close relatives rather than formal synonyms. Colletotrichum lupini was found to be an independent taxon within the C. acutatum complex by Nirenberg et al. (2002), rather than belonging to the C. gloeosporioides aggregate, as assumed by Yang & Sweetingham (1998) and Elmer et al. (2001). Farr et al. (2006) found C. phormii (based on Fusarium phormii, Hennings 1898) to be closely related to C. acutatum and noted that older reports of C. gloeosporioides as pathogens of Phormium could actually refer to C. phormii as well.', 0.9212689399719238]]
Context 1: [['Recently, more focus has been placed on conidium morphology, particularly shape and dimensions. The acute conidial ends that contribute to the typical fusiform shape are considered critical morphological features of C. acutatum (Simmonds 1965). However, the name C. acutatum has been applied to various species exhibiting fusiform conidia, many of which are closely related to C. acutatum s. str. Moreover, conidial shape can show significant variation both within the species and among strains (Damm et al. 2012). Studies have shown that the fusiform conidial shape is not a consistent feature in the C. acutatum species complex. For instance, Talhinhas et al. (2002) noted that Colletotrichum isolates from Lupinus spp. (equivalent to C. lupini) displayed varying proportions of conidia with round ends or one round and one acute end, resulting in cylindrical or clavate shapes. In a recent investigation, many strains previously classified as C. gloeosporioides, based on typical cylindrical conidia (Cannon et al. 2008), were found to belong to different species within the C. acutatum complex (Damm et al. 2012). Additionally, there are species with acute-ended conidia that are phylogenetically distinct from the C. acutatum complex, such as C. pseudoacutatum and C. proteae (Cannon et al. 2012; Damm et al. 2012; Liu et al. 2013). The revision of the C. acutatum complex has recognized 31 species through a multilocus molecular approach, significantly advancing our understanding of these plant pathogens (Damm et al. 2012).', 0.8433723449707031]]
Context 2: [['At this point, it was widely presumed that C. acutatum was a species complex containing several constituent taxa. However, there was substantial reluctance to recognize the clades involved as independent species due to the lack of distinctive morphological and cultural characters. For example, C. lupini was not formally recognized as separate from C. acutatum by Talhinhas et al. (2002) or by Sreenivasaprasad & Talhinhas (2005). Some attempts were made to address these concerns through the adoption of formae speciales, such as C. acutatum f. sp. pineum (Dingley & Gilmour 1972), C. acutatum f. sp. hakeae (Lubbe et al. 2004), and C. acutatum f. sp. fioriniae (Marcelino et al. 2008). However, this mechanism for recognizing pathology-related taxa is now rarely used.', 0.6509078741073608]]
Context 3: [['For example, Damm et al. (2012a, b, this issue) report members of the C. acutatum and C. boninense species complexes, with isolates Ku4 = ICMP 18575 and Ku8 = ICMP 18618 referred to as C. asianum by Hyde et al. (2009). However, these isolates are genetically distinct from C. simmondsii, C. fioriniae, and C. karstii, and belong to C. siamense based on our analyses.', 0.6332365274429321]]
Context 4: [['These subclades show few base pair differences. We refrain from describing further species within C. nymphaeae. While the majority of the strains were identified as C. nymphaeae, other strains, including the newly described species C. paranaense and C. melonis, are part of a main clade within the C. acutatum species complex (indicated as main clade 1 in Damm et al. 2012). This clade comprises closely related species predominantly found on various hosts in Central and South America, distinguished primarily by GAPDH and TUB2 sequences. For instance, C. lupini was originally described as G. sorghicola. Some strains from apple in this study were identified as C. melonis and the new species, C. paranaense. ITS sequences place the remaining strains from apple in Brazil, as noted in Giaretta et al. (2012), in the same main clade, though species-level identification is not possible based solely on this data. No species in this clade was previously associated with diseases of apple, peach, or guava fruits, and none of the other four species of the C. acutatum complex reported by Damm et al. (2012) from other regions were found associated with apples in Brazil. The species composition of the C. acutatum complex linked to apple bitter rot in Brazil appears distinct from other global regions, which may be significant for plant quarantine.', 0.584669828414917]]
Context 5: [['The holotype of Glomerella acutata is therefore an interspecific hybrid between C. acutatum and C. fioriniae. This may be construed as strong evidence that these two taxa constitute a single biological species, suggesting that the species concepts used in this paper are too narrow. However, the parent strains of the holotype originate from geographically distant populations, and there are instances in other fungal groups (e.g., Neurospora) where non-sympatric populations lose post-mating reproductive isolation barriers (Turner et al. 2010, 2011). Further research on population structures and mating-type barriers would be instructive.', 0.4786633551120758]]
Context 6: [['Intraspecific relationships of C. acutatum sensu lato may be considered as a group species, and the relationships among populations from different host plants remain unclear. Two subspecific forms or physiological taxa of C. acutatum have been described: C. acutatum f. sp. pineum and C. acutatum f. sp. chromogenum. The former was not separated morphologically from C. acutatum, being designated primarily based on its pathogenicity to pines. C. acutatum f. sp. chromogenum was distinguished based on pink and red pigments in the agar medium during culture. Although several studies have characterized isolates, there are currently no formally accepted subspecific nomenclatural designations within C. acutatum.', 0.4598942697048187]]
Context 7: [['Fungal isolates: The 62 isolates of C. acutatum isolated from strawberry were selected from various collections representing a range of isolation dates (1978 to 1998) and geographic regions worldwide. Nineteen C. acutatum isolates from other host plants were included in the study for comparison. Among these 81 isolates, 22 exhibiting pink chromogenic coloring in culture are referred to as C. acutatum chromogenic. Additionally, 13 isolates of C. gloeosporioides from strawberries originating from Europe and the United States, as well as one isolate from mango used as an outgroup, were studied. All isolates were single-conidia cultures. Stock cultures were maintained on silica gel at 4°C as described by Perkins. Cultures were initiated by transferring silica gel particles from the stock cultures to PDA (Potato Dextrose Agar) plates to produce fungal material for molecular analysis and pathogenicity tests. All isolates were identified using classical taxonomic criteria, such as conidial shape and growth on PDA.', 0.3424014449119568]]
Context 8: [['FIGURE 1: Phylogenetic analysis of the 42 strains of the Colletotrichum acutatum species complex listed in Supplementary Table S1 is based on a multilocus concatenated alignment of the ITS, GAPDH, CHS-1, HIS3, ACT, and TUB2 genes. Accepted species (Jayawardena et al., 2016) are highlighted in black, while isolates that do not fit those criteria are reported in gray. Colletotrichum orchidophilum was used as an outgroup.', 0.32943668961524963]]
Context 9: [['Colletotrichum pseudoacutatum is only distantly related to the C. acutatum complex and is therefore not included in the phylogeny, while C. orchidophilum was found to be more closely related and was used as an outgroup. The phylogenetic positions of these and all other species included here are illustrated in Figures 1 and 2 of Cannon et al. (2012, this issue).', 0.32899191975593567]]
