Context 0: [['Integrated pest management (IPM) strategies for Colletotrichum spp. encompass cultural, biological, and chemical control measures. Cultural control practices include producing disease-free propagating materials, avoiding overhead irrigation, minimizing rain splashing through mulching, and managing weeds (Coelho et al., 2008; Saxena et al., 2016). It is also recommended to remove infected crop residues and any mummified or rotten fruits to reduce inoculum sources and disease spread.', 0.6127331256866455]]
Context 1: [['Colletotrichum species are economically important plant pathogens, particularly in tropical, subtropical, and temperate regions, where they affect a wide range of plant hosts (Sutton 1992). The typical symptoms of Colletotrichum infections include sunken necrotic lesions, often bearing orange conidial masses, referred to as anthracnose (Freeman et al. 1998). The impact of these pathogens on fruit crops is significant, causing severe yield losses; for example, bitter rot is one of the most critical diseases affecting apple fruit, potentially leading to yield losses of up to 50% (Sutton 1990).', 0.5104309916496277]]
Context 2: [['Colletotrichum is one of the most important genera of plant pathogenic fungi, with many of the 200 plus species known to cause disease in crop plants worldwide (Alahakoon et al. 1994; Rojas et al. 2010; Cannon et al. 2012; Damm et al. 2012a, 2012b; Udayanga et al. 2013; Shivas et al. 2016; De Silva et al. 2017a).', 0.43772268295288086]]
Context 3: [['Many species belonging to the genus Colletotrichum are associated with plant diseases, commonly referred to as anthracnose. Colletotrichum spp. can affect a wide range of hosts, and these pathogens are characterized by global distribution. Virtually every cultivated botanical family is susceptible to one or more species of Colletotrichum, making it one of the most studied plant pathogenic fungi (Prusky et al., 2000; Latunde-Dada, 2001; Dean et al., 2012). Common hosts include many dicotyledonous plants such as strawberry, apple, citrus, and stone fruits, as well as major cereals such as maize and sorghum. Members of this genus can cause crop losses of up to 100% in many staple foods (Bailey and Jeger, 1992; Prusky et al., 2000; Talhinhas et al., 2005; Cannon et al., 2012).', 0.39099785685539246]]
Context 4: [['Waller, J.M.; Bridge, P.D. "Recent advances in understanding Colletotrichum diseases of some tropical perennial crops." query: How does C. acutatum differ from C. gloeosporioides in cultural morphology?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Morphology of C. acutatum. C. acutatum is an Ascomycete classified in the Pyrenomycetes and included in the family Phyllachoraceae. Colonies of C. acutatum are usually white initially but later become covered with pink to orange conidial masses. Cultures from certain hosts are highly chromogenic and excrete red and pink pigments into the culture media. The primary production of conidia occurs in acervuli; however, C. acutatum can also form secondary conidia on the surfaces of living leaves. Conidia are typically ellipsoid and fusiform at least at one end, differing from C. gloeosporioides, which generally has both ends rounded. Setae are usually sparse or not produced at all. Pigmented appressoria form upon germination of the conidia and vary in shape and size.', 0.9956550598144531]]
Context 1: [['C. acutatum, as noted by various studies (Peres et al. 2008; Lee et al. 2007; Talhinhas et al. 2011; Polashock et al. 2009; Wharton & Schilder 2008), has a well-known morphological feature: the shape of its conidia, which are characterized by acute ends (Simmonds 1965). However, other conidial shapes are frequently encountered, particularly cylindrical forms with only one acute end. These variations are often observed in strains that have been repeatedly subcultured, as well as in the “terminal crook” disease of pine (Dingley & Gilmour 1972) and in the anthracnose affecting leather leaf fern (Schiller et al. 2006). There are also reports of disseminated infections in sea turtles (Manire et al. 2002) and infections in scale insects (Marcelino et al. 2008). Differentiating between C. acutatum (s. lat.) and C. gloeosporioides (s. lat.) is challenging due to the existence of many intermediate strains that exhibit a limited number of typical fusiform conidia alongside numerous cylindrical ones (Van der Aa et al. 1990).', 0.993974506855011]]
Context 2: [['Recently, more focus has been placed on conidium morphology, particularly shape and dimensions. The acute conidial ends that contribute to the typical fusiform shape are considered critical morphological features of C. acutatum (Simmonds 1965). However, the name C. acutatum has been applied to various species exhibiting fusiform conidia, many of which are closely related to C. acutatum s. str. Moreover, conidial shape can show significant variation both within the species and among strains (Damm et al. 2012). Studies have shown that the fusiform conidial shape is not a consistent feature in the C. acutatum species complex. For instance, Talhinhas et al. (2002) noted that Colletotrichum isolates from Lupinus spp. (equivalent to C. lupini) displayed varying proportions of conidia with round ends or one round and one acute end, resulting in cylindrical or clavate shapes. In a recent investigation, many strains previously classified as C. gloeosporioides, based on typical cylindrical conidia (Cannon et al. 2008), were found to belong to different species within the C. acutatum complex (Damm et al. 2012). Additionally, there are species with acute-ended conidia that are phylogenetically distinct from the C. acutatum complex, such as C. pseudoacutatum and C. proteae (Cannon et al. 2012; Damm et al. 2012; Liu et al. 2013). The revision of the C. acutatum complex has recognized 31 species through a multilocus molecular approach, significantly advancing our understanding of these plant pathogens (Damm et al. 2012).', 0.9907773733139038]]
Context 3: [['C. gloeosporioides isolates were very similar, except they formed the Glomerella cingulata ascigerous state in culture, and their conidia were usually rounded at both ends. Both C. fragariae and C. gloeosporioides produced dark black setae, which are visible with a hand lens, in acervuli in culture and on petiole, stolon, and fruit lesions. In contrast, C. acutatum isolates produced fusiform conidia that were tapered at both ends, developed colonies in white, pink, orange, rose, or beige, and did not form setae or the ascigerous state in culture. The growth rate of C. acutatum in culture was slower than that of the other two species at all tested temperatures, with the most significant difference noted at 32°C.', 0.9876694083213806]]
Context 4: [['Colony shape and color of cultures may vary considerably within and between species. For instance, most isolates of C. acutatum (including the almond pathogen from California) show red-salmon pigmentation in reverse culture, whereas the coloration of C. gloeosporioides cultures varies from white to dark gray. Several morphological types have been observed within a population of C. gloeosporioides from avocado grown in culture (T. Katan, unpublished): (i) conidial type, with masses of conidia and no aerial mycelium; (ii) flat mycelial type, with very little aerial mycelium or conidia; (iii) mycelial type, with dense aerial mycelium; (iv) conidial-mycelial type, with dense aerial mycelium and masses of conidia; (v) protoperithecial type, similar to type iv but also producing dark protoperithecia-like hyphal aggregates; and (vi) perithecial type, with simple or complex perithecia.', 0.9874628186225891]]
Context 5: [['Generally, conidia of C. acutatum are elliptic-fusiform in shape, whereas conidia of C. gloeosporioides are oblong with obtuse ends. However, this criterion, as well as the size of conidia, is not consistent enough for discerning species. Numerous reports suggest that isolates of C. acutatum grew at a significantly slower rate than isolates of C. gloeosporioides (5, 50, 52). However, the growth rate of C. gloeosporioides isolates from almond in Israel was slow and did not differ significantly from that of C. acutatum from strawberry. In fact, growth rate and optimal temperature have been useful for differentiating between subpopulations of C. gloeosporioides from avocado and almond crops.', 0.9735271334648132]]
Context 6: [['Fungal isolates: The 62 isolates of C. acutatum isolated from strawberry were selected from various collections representing a range of isolation dates (1978 to 1998) and geographic regions worldwide. Nineteen C. acutatum isolates from other host plants were included in the study for comparison. Among these 81 isolates, 22 exhibiting pink chromogenic coloring in culture are referred to as C. acutatum chromogenic. Additionally, 13 isolates of C. gloeosporioides from strawberries originating from Europe and the United States, as well as one isolate from mango used as an outgroup, were studied. All isolates were single-conidia cultures. Stock cultures were maintained on silica gel at 4°C as described by Perkins. Cultures were initiated by transferring silica gel particles from the stock cultures to PDA (Potato Dextrose Agar) plates to produce fungal material for molecular analysis and pathogenicity tests. All isolates were identified using classical taxonomic criteria, such as conidial shape and growth on PDA.', 0.9512364268302917]]
Context 7: [['C. acutatum was first described as a separate species by Simmonds. Many isolates now identified as C. acutatum were either classified under C. gloeosporioides or considered species of Gloeo sporium. C. acutatum affects hosts that are also targeted by other Colletotrichum species, possibly leading to its earlier misidentification. For instance, strawberries can be affected by C. acutatum, C. gloeosporioides, and C. fragariae. The latter two typically cause petiole and stolon lesions, as well as crown rot on strawberries.', 0.9079568386077881]]
Context 8: [['A sexual morph was described for C. acutatum (Guerber & Correll 1997, 2001), based on mating-compatible strains in the laboratory. The cross designated as the type of Glomerella acutata was based on two cultures, ATCC 56816 and ATCC MYA-662. The first of these is derived from one of Simmonds’ original Queensland collections from papaya, IMI 117620, which is here designated as the epitype of C. acutatum. However, there is ongoing confusion regarding the provenance of this strain; Guerber & Correll (2001) and Than et al. (2008b) incorrectly equated ATCC 56816 with IMI 117617, the holotype, and this congruence is recorded as such in the ATCC catalog. The second strain, ATCC MYA-662, was isolated from apple in Louisiana, USA (Guerber & Correll 2001), and is assigned here to C. fioriniae in clade 3. Fertile sexual morphs were also produced by Guerber & Correll (2001) and Guerber et al. (2003) by mating a series of different strains, including crosses between parents both assigned to C. fioriniae. None of the strains tested was self-fertile.', 0.8610506057739258]]
Context 9: [['Morphologically, C. pseudoacutatum mainly differs from species in the C. acutatum complex by the formation of pale brown, verruculose, irregularly shaped appressoria and the more abundant formation of setae.', 0.7948076128959656]]

query: How can vegetative compatibility and molecular techniques complement traditional morphological methods in Colletotrichum species identification?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Despite significant developments over the last ten years, the taxonomy of Colletotrichum is in a state of flux. Many uncertainties exist in the systematics of fungal pathogens from this genus; depending on the taxonomic "guides," the number of species can range from 29 to over 700 (von Arx, 1957; Sutton, 1992). One of the most confusing species is C. gloeosporioides. For example, 594 species of Colletotrichum were reclassified by von Arx as synonyms of C. gloeosporioides. Identification has primarily relied on morphological characteristics of conidia, vegetative and sexual structures, as well as host specificity and cultural characteristics (von Arx, 1957). Unfortunately, conidial morphology and colony characteristics vary even within isolates. Consequently, classical methods have been supplemented with biochemical and molecular technologies to differentiate Colletotrichum species (J. W. Kronstad, ed., Fungal Pathology, 127-148. © 2000 Kluwer Academic Publishers). For a more complete discussion of this topic, see Sherriff et al. (1994).', 0.9883290529251099]]
Context 1: [['Cano, J., Guarro, J., and Gene, J. (2004). Molecular and morphological identification of Colletotrichum species of clinical interest. Journal of Clinical Microbiology 42: 2450-2454.', 0.6613837480545044]]
Context 2: [['Photita, W., Taylor, P. W., Ford, R., Hyde, K. D., and Lumyong, S. (2005). Morphological and molecular characterization of Colletotrichum species from...', 0.5789934396743774]]
Context 3: [['In a drastic move, von Arx (1957) reduced the number of recognized Colletotrichum species from several hundred to 11 based on morphological characteristics, with many taxa treated as synonyms of C. gloeosporioides and C. dematium. Several additional species have since been accepted based on morphological criteria (Sutton, 1980; 1992). The difficulties in recognizing Colletotrichum species can be attributed to: 1) the limited and variable morphological characters; 2) an extensive host range and variability in pathogenicity (Bailey and Jeger, 1992; Freeman et al., 2000; Latunde-Dada, 2001; Du et al., 2005; Thaung, 2008); 3) type specimens that are often missing or in poor condition, making them unsuitable for molecular studies; and 4) numerous rDNA ITS sequences of Colletotrichum strains in NCBI that are often misidentified (Crouch et al., 2009d; Damm et al., 2009).', 0.5224315524101257]]

query: Were the measurements of colony diameter consistent across all isolates during the morphological characterization process?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Morphological Characterization: Before morphological examination, isolates were cultured under continuous fluorescent light on PDA for one week at 25°C. Mycelial plugs (5 mm in diameter) were cut from colony margins and placed in 9-cm diameter Petri dishes, with four plates per isolate. The colony characteristics (color of upper and lower surfaces) and growth rate (measured in two perpendicular directions) were recorded after 3, 5, 7, and 10 days. Hyphal growth rate (cm/day) was calculated based on colony diameter. Conidial production, shape, and size were examined up to three weeks on PDA incubated at 25°C. Conidia (120 per isolate) from three-week-old PDA cultures were measured for length and width. Appressoria were produced from conidia placed on glass slides inside moist chambers. They were also produced from hyphae using a slide culture technique described by Cai et al. PDA plugs (1 cm × 1 cm) were placed in clean Petri dishes, treated with conidia, and covered with a cover slip. After 7 days, the shape and size of the appressoria were recorded. For each isolate, at least 30 appressoria were examined, and photographs were taken using a Nikon Eclipse Ni-E microscope.', 0.9717195630073547]]
Context 1: [['Morphological Characterization: Isolates were cultured on PDA plates at 25 °C under continuous fluorescent light for 5 days. Plugs (6 mm in diameter) from colony margins were placed in the center of each 90-mm-diameter plate, with four replications. Colony color and culture diameters (measured in two perpendicular directions) were recorded after 3, 7, and 10 days at 25 °C. These diameters were used to calculate the hyphal growth rate (mm/day). Isolates were incubated at 25 °C for 21 days on PDA plates to assess conidial production, as well as the shape and size of conidia. The length and width of 150 conidia per isolate were measured.', 0.9360672831535339]]
Context 2: [['Morphological and cultural characterizations were performed according to the methods described by Cai et al. (2009). Context 3: [['Morphological and Cultural Characteristics: The isolates were measured for colony characteristics, including shape and size of conidia and appressoria, as well as growth rate.', 0.758138120174408]]
Context 4: [['Starter cultures were prepared by plating each isolate directly onto potato dextrose agar (PDA) at room temperature (25 °C). Each plug was then placed onto new PDA plates and incubated under the same conditions as the starter cultures. Three cultures of every isolate were investigated. The cultures were incubated at room temperature (25 °C) for 7 days, during which the size and shape of 20 conidia harvested from each culture were recorded. The colony diameter was measured daily over the 7-day period, and the growth rate was calculated as the 7-day average of mean daily growth (mm per day). Context 5: [['Mycelial plugs (5 mm) were transferred from the edge of actively growing cultures to fresh potato dextrose agar (PDA, 1.5%, Difco) plates. Microscopic examination was conducted with a Carl Zeiss Imager A2 microscope after one month of cultivation. Among the 1,285 obtained isolates (as shown in Table 1), 121 representative isolates were selected for further multilocus phylogenetic analyses based on geographical location, morphology (including colony shape, color, and characteristics of aerial mycelia and conidia).', 0.49294474720954895]]
Context 6: [['Initially, colonies of the isolates on PDA appeared white and then developed a grey to dark grey color at the center over time, showing a growth rate of 9.98 ± 1.8 mm per day. Prihastuti et al. (2009) noted that the colony characteristics and conidial shape and size of C. fructicola were similar to those of C. gloeosporioides, although the appressoria of C. fructicola were ovoid and sometimes clavate.', 0.4610658288002014]]
Context 7: [['Each fungal plug was placed on a 90 mm diameter Petri dish filled with 20 mL of PDA and grown at 25°C in the dark. Three replicate cultures for each isolate were evaluated. The colony diameter was measured daily for at least five days to calculate the growth rate in millimeters per day. For appressorial formation, two drops of a conidial suspension (20 µL at 10^5 conidia/mL) were placed on a microscope slide and incubated on moist filter paper in Petri dishes at 25°C in darkness for two days. The sizes and shapes of appressoria formed from germ tubes were also measured, and mean and standard deviation values were calculated for mycelial growth rate, conidia size, and appressoria.', 0.36114686727523804]]
Context 8: [['Starter cultures were prepared by plating each isolate onto PDA at 25°C. Five 4 mm plugs were aseptically cut from actively sporulating areas near the growing edge of a 5-day-old culture of each isolate using a sterile cork borer. Each plug was placed onto PDA plates (90 × 15 mm Petri dishes) and grown in an alternating light cycle of 12 hours near UV and 12 hours of darkness at 25ºC (Sutton, 1980). Colony diameters were measured on day six (or day four for the fastest-growing cultures). Growth rates were calculated as the average daily growth over six or four days (mm per day). query: What are the main host plants affected by Colletotrichum species, and what economic impact do they have?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Many species belonging to the genus Colletotrichum are associated with plant diseases, commonly referred to as anthracnose. Colletotrichum spp. can affect a wide range of hosts, and these pathogens are characterized by global distribution. Virtually every cultivated botanical family is susceptible to one or more species of Colletotrichum, making it one of the most studied plant pathogenic fungi (Prusky et al., 2000; Latunde-Dada, 2001; Dean et al., 2012). Common hosts include many dicotyledonous plants such as strawberry, apple, citrus, and stone fruits, as well as major cereals such as maize and sorghum. Members of this genus can cause crop losses of up to 100% in many staple foods (Bailey and Jeger, 1992; Prusky et al., 2000; Talhinhas et al., 2005; Cannon et al., 2012).', 0.982999861240387]]
Context 1: [['The genus Colletotrichum is considered one of the top ten important genera of fungal pathogens globally (Dean et al., 2012). Colletotrichum is an ancient fungus that has co-evolved with flowering plants. Plant microfossils of Protocolletotrichum preserved on angiosperm leaf cuticles suggest that the diverse pathogenic strategies of Colletotrichum spp. have been established since the Late Cretaceous period (Kar et al., 2004). Different complexes within the genus may have diverged between 4.8 and 32.2 million years ago (MYA) (Bhunjun et al., 2021). The emergence of agricultural cultivation and the intensive disturbance of natural environments have further driven the diversification of Colletotrichum species. These fungi have adapted to thousands of hosts and can be found as endophytes, pathogens, and saprobes (Freeman et al., 1998; Dean et al., 2012; Hirayama et al., 2018; da Silva et al., 2020; Jayawardena et al., 2020). Currently, a total of 257 Colletotrichum species grouped into 15 complexes and 13 additional singletons have been accepted in this genus.', 0.7919965982437134]]
Context 2: [['Various studies highlight the significance of Colletotrichum species in agriculture. Crouch et al. query: How were detached fruits prepared for inoculation in this study?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Infection Post-deposition: A study was conducted to determine if the micro-environment within the canopies varied in terms of favorableness for fruit infection. The effect of plant density treatment on fruit infection post-deposition was assessed by determining the disease incidence of inoculated, detached fruit placed within each treatment row canopy and in unsheltered areas adjacent to the plot site. Greenhouse-grown fruit (‘Midway’) at the white stage were collected with the pedicels and inoculated in the laboratory as previously described (43), using a concentration of 1 × 10³ conidia/ml. This inoculum density produces a fruit disease incidence of approximately 0.5 with 12 hours of wetness at 25°C in controlled-environment chambers (41).', 0.8966732621192932]]
Context 1: [['Subsequent pathogenicity bioassays were carried out using a wild type and two or three F8-3B-pAA1 transformants (F2, F4, and F8), comparing wound versus non-wound inoculation methods. Wound inoculation of the detached chili fruit involved pricking the surface to penetrate the cuticle to a depth of 1 to 2 mm with a sterile needle, then placing agar plugs of actively growing mycelium from 14 to 21-day-old cultures of transformed strains and a wild type over the wound site. Fruits were placed in a plastic box on a tray containing 900 ml of water, sealed to provide humidity, and incubated at 28°C with a 12-hour photoperiod. Three fruit replicates for each treatment were used, and the experiment was replicated twice.', 0.8825007081031799]]
Context 2: [['Detached untreated fruits of each cultivar were inoculated with the conidial suspension of C. nymphaeae PET1 at a concentration of 1 × 10^6 conidia mL^-1, containing Tween 80 (0.1%; v/v), as described in the pathogenicity test. Six fruits were inoculated for each cultivar. After 7 days, disease incidence and severity were calculated based on the previously mentioned index.', 0.8429360389709473]]
Context 3: [['In order to test the pathogenicity of the new species, detached fruits and leaf inoculations were conducted. To determine whether this new species can infect the rhizome (crown), seedling inoculations were also carried out.', 0.6324483752250671]]
Context 4: [['Inoculum for fruit inoculations was prepared by scraping plates and suspending conidia in 20 ml of deionized water. The spore suspensions were vortexed for 1.5 minutes and then adjusted to 2.5 × 10^4 conidia/ml using a hemacytometer. Based on preliminary experiments, this was the lowest spore density that resulted in 100% fruit infection.', 0.5084332227706909]]
Context 5: [['In a second set of experiments, fruits were prepared as described above and then inoculated with varying concentrations of conidia ranging from 1 × 10³ to 1 × 10⁵ conidia per ml. This experiment was conducted four times. The first trial took place in 1996 with the cultivar Nittany, while the remaining trials were conducted in 1997 using the cultivar Golden Delicious. Data on disease incidence and lesion diameter were subjected to analysis of variance, and means were separated using the Waller-Duncan k-ratio t test (SAS).', 0.5078590512275696]]
Context 6: [['Inoculation and Assessment: Plots were infested by placing five infected fruit with abundant conidia, prepared as previously described (31, 44), midway between the south and middle rows at the east end of each plot. This method was similar to that used by Madden et al. (see Fig. 1 in literature citation 30), except that they placed their inoculum 30 cm from the end of the rows. Inoculum placement occurred when susceptible (white-colored) fruit were abundant and immediately prior to a rain event, specifically on 14 June 1992 and 7 June 1993. Ripe fruit were manually removed from all plants before infestation, and the inoculum source fruit were removed after 24 hours.', 0.48065704107284546]]
Context 7: [['For pathogenicity testing, fruits from two sweet orange (Citrus sinensis) clones (‘Tarocco Scirè’ and ‘Tarocco Nucellare’) were collected in Sicily during the veraison stage and used for artificial inoculation. A total of 174 monosporic isolates resembling Colletotrichum were collected from different locations across Europe (Greece, Italy, Malta, Spain, and Portugal). Among them, 67 isolates were obtained from leaves, 72 from twigs, 28 from fruits, and seven from petals. Eight fruits for each isolate/clone combination were inoculated. The fruits were surface-disinfected with 70% ethanol and rinsed with sterilized water. Inoculation was performed by injuring the fruits at six points with a sterile pipette tip and injecting a spore suspension (1.0 × 10^5 conidia/mL) into each point.', 0.46698787808418274]]
Context 8: [['The inoculation method described by Than et al. (2008a) involved a wound/drop inoculation technique, where a pin was used to prick the leaf or fruit wall to a depth of 1 mm, and then 6 µl of conidia suspension (10^6 conidia/ml) was placed onto the wound or non-wound areas. Control samples were inoculated with 6 µl of sterilized distilled water. Each plant was inoculated with four replicates per selected strain. The inoculated fruits and leaves were incubated at 25°C for 24 hours, followed by incubation at room temperature (22-27°C). After 6-7 days and 14-15 days of incubation, leaves and fruits were examined for lesions using a stereo-microscope on a superclean bench. Spore masses or acervuli on the leaves or fruits were observed with a compound microscope. Spores were transferred to PDA medium and distilled water, which was then gently swirled to dislodge the conidia before being incubated at 25°C to check for colony and spore characteristics. All infected leaves or fruits were sterilized and disposed of.', 0.3991152346134186]]
Context 9: [["Artificial inoculations were conducted periodically using a small range of fruit. query: How does anthracnose affect fruit quality in preharvest and postharvest stages?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Abstract: In tropical fruit crops, anthracnose is primarily caused by species of the fungal genus Colletotrichum. These phytopathogens can infect various parts of the fruit crops; however, infections occurring during postharvest or ripening stages lead to significant economic losses. The disease manifests as black to dark brown sunken lesions on the fruit surface, which diminishes fruit quality and marketability. Common tropical fruit crops susceptible to anthracnose include mango, papaya, banana, avocado, guava, and dragon fruit, all of which are economically important in many developing countries. It is essential to note that newly identified Colletotrichum species associated with fruit anthracnose can infect multiple hosts, though some species may exhibit host specificity. Utilizing multiple markers, many phylogenetic species of Colletotrichum have been recognized as anthracnose-causing pathogens. Given that effective disease management strategies depend on a comprehensive understanding of the causative agents, up-to-date information regarding Colletotrichum species and the risks posed by newly identified species in tropical fruit plantations and harvested fruits is crucial. Furthermore, these newly recorded species may be significant for biosecurity and should be classified as quarantine pathogens, particularly as tropical fruits are traded globally.', 0.986487090587616]]
Context 1: [['Anthracnose is a significant disease affecting grape crops (Dowling et al., 2020). Beyond causing severe yield losses, anthracnose epidemics can diminish the quality of the produce (Waller et al., 2002; Dowling et al., 2020). The most economically damaging symptoms often include blossom blight and fruit rots; however, necrotic lesions may also develop on leaves, stems, and twigs, leading to plant deterioration and reduced fruit quality (Dowling et al., 2020).', 0.8088220953941345]]
Context 2: [['Figure 1 illustrates the anthracnose disease cycle in tropical fruit crops, drawn by Latiffah Zakaria. Anthracnose pathogens infect not only fruits but also other plant organs, including leaves, flowers, twigs, and branches. The conidia and spores formed in these infected tissues are released and dispersed during rainy days or periods of high humidity, becoming the primary inoculum for fruit infection at the preharvest stage. The most visible anthracnose symptoms are black or dark brown sunken lesions that contain conidial masses on the surface of infected fruits. Small individual lesions can merge to form larger lesions. These dark lesions on the fruit surface are unattractive to consumers and significantly reduce the market value of the affected fruits. Figures 2A–E display anthracnose lesions on several tropical fruit crops.', 0.7103703618049622]]
Context 3: [['Anthracnose fruit rot (AFR) has been observed in greenhouses during the harvesting period in Chungnam Province, South Korea. Infected fruits show black or brown spots, orange conidial masses, and in some areas, white fungal growths are visible. The size of these spots gradually expands, leading to necrosis of the fruits and flowers. Three isolates obtained from infected fruits were identified as strains of the Colletotrichum acutatum species complex based on morphological characteristics. Multilocus sequence analysis of actin, chitin synthase, glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate dehydrogenase genes, and internal transcribed spacer (ITS) rDNA regions revealed that the isolates belong to a monophyletic group with the type strain of C. nymphaeae. This is the first confirmation of C. nymphaeae on strawberry fruits in Korea.', 0.253566175699234]]
Context 4: [['Smith, B. J. (1998). Anthracnose fruit rot (black spot). In J. L. Maas (Ed.), Compendium of Strawberry Diseases (2nd ed., pp. 31-33). The American Phytopathological Society, St. Paul, MN.', 0.25086820125579834]]

Context 6: [['Smith, B.J. (1998b). Anthracnose fruit rot (black spot), pp. 31–33. In J.L. Maas (Ed.), Compendium of strawberry diseases (2nd ed.). American Phytopathological Society, St. Paul, MN.', 0.22690720856189728]]

Context 8: [['Milholland, R. D. 1995. Anthracnose fruit rot (ripe rot). In: Compendium of Blueberry and Cranberry Diseases. F. L. Caruso and D. C. Ramsdell, eds. American Phytopathological Society, St. Paul, MN. Page 17.', 0.2228301614522934]]

query: What are the long-term implications of not managing anthracnose effectively?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Until highly resistant cultivars are available, growers must rely on chemical applications and cultural practices to reduce losses due to anthracnose. The failure of fungicides to control anthracnose epidemics may be due to the development of fungicide resistance in the Colletotrichum spp. population. For example, benomyl effectively reduced the incidence of anthracnose crown rot (Horn et al., 1972; Howard, 1971) and was used intensively by strawberry growers for years to control anthracnose and other diseases. However, the anthracnose pathogens, C. acutatum and C. fragariae, developed resistance to it and other benzimidazole fungicides (LaMondia, 1995; McInnes et al., 1992a; Smith and Black, 1992, 1993), rendering benomyl ineffective for anthracnose control in strawberry fields.', 0.4548422694206238]]
Context 1: [['Until highly resistant cultivars are available, growers must rely on chemical applications and cultural practices to reduce losses due to anthracnose. The failure of fungicides to control anthracnose epidemics may be attributed to the development of fungicide resistance in the Colletotrichum species population. For example, benomyl was shown to effectively reduce the incidence of anthracnose crown rot (Horn et al., 1972; Howard, 1971) and was used intensively by strawberry growers for years to control anthracnose and other diseases. However, the anthracnose pathogens, C. acutatum and C. fragariae, developed resistance to it and other benzimidazole fungicides (LaMondia, 1995; McInnes et al., 1992a; Smith and Black, 1992, 1993), leading to the ineffectiveness of benomyl for anthracnose control in strawberry fields.', 0.36632442474365234]]

Context 3: [['Anthracnose is a significant disease affecting grape crops (Dowling et al., 2020). Context 4: [['Bergstrom, G. C., and Nicholson, R. L. 1999. The biology of corn anthracnose: Knowledge to exploit for improved management. Plant Dis. 83:596-608.', 0.2411215901374817]]
Context 5: [['Accurate identification and scientific naming of anthracnose pathogens are crucial because precise taxonomic information allows us to classify a given species as a pathogen, saprophyte, or endophyte. The species involved in anthracnose affecting tropical fruits may exhibit different characteristics, emphasizing the importance of proper identification of the causative pathogen for effective disease management.', 0.235739067196846]]
Context 6: [['Additional Keywords: anthracnose, disease spread, Fragaria × ananassa, models, quantitative epidemiology.', 0.21353211998939514]]
Context 7: [['As our understanding of the anthracnose pathogens and the epidemiology of anthracnose diseases has improved, so has our capacity to control these diseases. Changes in cultural practices have led to reduced levels of disease. Additionally, the development and registration of more effective fungicides for use on strawberries have significantly decreased losses due to anthracnose crown rot and fruit rot. The introduction of partially resistant cultivars has also helped mitigate economic losses due to these diseases. Nonetheless, growers may still experience severe losses when environmental conditions are highly conducive to anthracnose development.', 0.21067655086517334]]
Context 8: [['As our knowledge of the anthracnose pathogens and the epidemiology of anthracnose diseases has increased, so has our ability to control these diseases. Changes in cultural practices have resulted in reduced levels of disease. Additionally, the development and registration of more effective fungicides for use on strawberries have significantly reduced losses from both anthracnose crown rot and fruit rot. Anthracnose-resistant cultivars have also diminished economic losses due to these diseases. Nevertheless, growers may still experience severe losses when environmental factors are highly favorable for anthracnose development.', 0.20794589817523956]]
Context 9: [['Increased losses due to anthracnose fruit and crown rots may be related to the shift from matted-row culture to the annual plasticulture production system in the United States. Breeding for genetic resistance to anthracnose and the development of resistant cultivars are primary means for reducing economic losses due to this disease. This approach is environmentally sound because it results in reduced fungicide use. As our knowledge of the anthracnose pathogens and the epidemiology of anthracnose diseases has increased, so has our ability to control these diseases. Changes in cultural practices have resulted in reduced levels of disease. Simultaneously, the development of more effective fungicides and their registration for use on strawberries have significantly reduced losses due to both anthracnose crown rot and fruit rot. Anthracnose-resistant cultivars have also decreased economic losses caused by these diseases. Nevertheless, growers may still face severe losses when environmental conditions are highly favorable for anthracnose development.', 0.18032526969909668]]

query: How do the phytotoxic effects observed in strawberries treated with prochloraz compare to effects on crops like wheat treated with azole fungicides?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Control of C. acutatum in Field Transplants: In field trials conducted in 1995 and 1996, mortality caused by C. acutatum in naturally infected strawberry transplants was significantly reduced by all fungicide treatments compared to the non-treated control. Prochloraz-Mn and prochloraz-Zn were the most effective in reducing transplant mortality. In 1995, prochloraz-Mn reduced mortality by 93.3%, while in 1996, reductions were 86.8% for prochloraz-Mn and 93.1% for prochloraz-Zn, with no significant differences between them. Prochloraz-Zn/folpet, propiconazole, and difenoconazole were less effective than prochloraz alone. In 1995, transplant mortality was reduced by 66.7% and 37.7% with prochloraz-Zn/folpet and propiconazole, respectively. In 1996, reductions were 52.9% and 29.1% with prochloraz-Zn/folpet and difenoconazole, respectively. Similar to the greenhouse experiments, prochloraz fungicides, difenoconazole, and propiconazole exhibited slight phytotoxicity.', 0.9483979940414429]]
Context 1: [['Despite the effectiveness of Prochloraz, it should be thoroughly tested before widespread application in strawberry fruiting fields due to potential resistance or tolerance of C. acutatum and other Colletotrichum species. Isolates of C. kahawae, typically highly sensitive to Prochloraz, have demonstrated acquired tolerance in culture. Similarly, isolates of C. acutatum from various hosts, including strawberries, have shown resistance to benzimidazole fungicides compared to C. gloeosporioides isolates.', 0.902795135974884]]
Context 2: [['In laboratory experiments, infection in segments of strawberry runners treated with prochloraz-Zn reached 60%, which was significantly reduced compared to the combined prochloraz-Zn/folpet (90%), captan, folpet, and water controls (100%). In the greenhouse, the number of naturally infected transplants killed was significantly reduced by all fungicides and the heat treatment (5 minutes at 49°C) compared to the non-treated control. Prochloraz-Zn was the most effective chemical control treatment but did not differ significantly from the heat treatment.', 0.8390247225761414]]
Context 3: [['This study evaluated the fungicides prochloraz-Zn, prochloraz-Mn (both protectant sterol-biosynthesis inhibitors), captan, folpet, a combined formulation of prochloraz-Zn and folpet, propiconazole, difenoconazole, and a heat treatment for the control of C. acutatum in naturally infected strawberry plants under laboratory, greenhouse, and field conditions. Fungicides were applied at the transplant stage to determine whether a single-dip treatment is sufficient for disease control.', 0.6901816725730896]]
Context 4: [['Various fungicides and a heat treatment were assessed for their ability to control strawberry anthracnose caused by the fungus Colletotrichum acutatum under laboratory, greenhouse, and field conditions. The effective dose causing 50% inhibition of mycelial growth (ED50) was measured at 30.5, 12.2, 0.2, 0.15, 0.05, 0.07, and 0.05 µg/ml for the fungicides folpet, captan, propiconazole, difenoconazole, combined prochloraz-Zn/folpet, prochloraz-Zn, and prochloraz-Mn, respectively.', 0.6654434204101562]]
Context 5: [['In field experiments conducted during 1995 and 1996, the number of naturally infected strawberry transplants killed was significantly reduced by all fungicide treatments relative to the non-treated control. The percent reduction of transplant mortality in the field was 93.3%, 93.1%, 66.7%, 37.7%, and 29.1% for prochloraz-Mn, prochloraz-Zn, combined prochloraz-Zn/folpet, propiconazole, and difenoconazole, respectively.', 0.5774314403533936]]
Context 6: [['Prochloraz was effective in controlling strawberry anthracnose under all tested conditions; however, the current formulation of this fungicide resulted in a residual taste.', 0.4737759530544281]]
Context 7: [['Transplants of all three strawberry cultivars inoculated with either QoI-sensitive or -resistant isolates and dip-treated with natamycin at both rates, or with the pydiflumetofen-fludioxonil or fludioxonil-cyprodinil premixes, showed significantly (P < 0.05) lower disease severity and plant mortality compared to controls. There were generally no significant (P > 0.05) differences among these four treatments, with the new fungicides providing similar control to the registered premix of fludioxonil and cyprodinil. Among the six cultivar-inoculum combinations, the 0.5 g/liter rate of natamycin was significantly (P > 0.05) less effective than the 1 g/liter rate only for Portola inoculated with QoI-resistant isolates. Context 8: [['Investigaciones Agrarias. 2018; 20(1):38-50. query: How might findings regarding the genetic structure of C. acutatum influence future research on plant pathogens?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Abstract: Colletotrichum acutatum is recognized as a significant anthracnose pathogen affecting a broad range of host plants globally. Numerous studies have reported subgroups within the C. acutatum species complex. A multilocus molecular phylogenetic analysis (ITS, ACT, TUB2, CHS-1, GAPDH, HIS3) involving 331 strains previously identified as C. acutatum and related taxa—spanning various hosts across diverse geographic regions—confirmed the previously recognized molecular groups and identified several novel taxa. Thirty-one species are accepted, of which 21 have not been previously recognized. Colletotrichum orchidophilum clusters basal to the C. acutatum species complex. This complex exhibits high phenotypic diversity, with some species showing preferences for specific hosts or geographic regions, while others are plurivorous and found in multiple areas. In this study, only C. salicis and C. rhombiforme formed sexual morphs in culture; however, sexual morphs have been documented from other taxa, particularly in laboratory crosses, with evidence of hybridization between different species. A new species, C. pseudoacutatum, was also described, resembling C. acutatum but not belonging to its species complex.', 0.6365334987640381]]
Context 1: [['Colletotrichum acutatum has been regarded as a pathogen of countless host plant species and is thought to occur everywhere. Sreenivasaprasad & Talhinhas (2005) discovered that C. acutatum group A5, accepted here as C. acutatum s. str., occurs only on certain hosts, primarily in the southern hemisphere. This study confirms that C. acutatum s. str. does indeed have multiple hosts, but the known host spectrum is much smaller than previously accepted.', 0.4981650710105896]]
Context 2: [['Few investigations into cross-pathogenicity and the host range of C. acutatum isolates in nature have been conducted. If this pathogen truly has a broad host range and can move freely between hosts, it is intriguing that it has formed unique relationships with each plant species. Many researchers face limitations due to narrow crop responsibilities, inadequate facilities for handling temperate or tropical crops, or restrictions imposed by biosecurity regulations, which have hindered studies of host ranges using large numbers of isolates. With innovation and cooperative efforts, it may be possible to conduct some of these studies, ultimately enhancing our understanding of pathogen movement and host interactions.', 0.486349493265152]]
Context 3: [['The holotype of Glomerella acutata is therefore an interspecific hybrid between C. acutatum and C. fioriniae. This may be construed as strong evidence that these two taxa constitute a single biological species, suggesting that the species concepts used in this paper are too narrow. However, the parent strains of the holotype originate from geographically distant populations, and there are instances in other fungal groups (e.g., Neurospora) where non-sympatric populations lose post-mating reproductive isolation barriers (Turner et al. 2010, 2011). Further research on population structures and mating-type barriers would be instructive.', 0.4365829825401306]]
Context 4: [['Considering the frequency with which strains from the C. acutatum species complex are encountered and their pathogenicity to a wide range of crop plants, it would be surprising if earlier names for C. acutatum did not exist. Walker et al. (1991) found that C. xanthii (Halsted 1893) was synonymous with C. acutatum based on morphological criteria, but no authentic sequences are available, and it is currently unclear which clade this species fits into. At that time, there was no interest among Colletotrichum researchers to replace the name C. acutatum, and now the name is so widely used that a change would likely not gain recognition. Other older taxa have been recognized as belonging to the C. acutatum complex, but as close relatives rather than formal synonyms. Colletotrichum lupini was found to be an independent taxon within the C. acutatum complex by Nirenberg et al. (2002), rather than belonging to the C. gloeosporioides aggregate, as assumed by Yang & Sweetingham (1998) and Elmer et al. (2001). Farr et al. (2006) found C. phormii (based on Fusarium phormii, Hennings 1898) to be closely related to C. acutatum and noted that older reports of C. gloeosporioides as pathogens of Phormium could actually refer to C. phormii as well.', 0.40276995301246643]]
Context 5: [['Members of the C. acutatum species complex have been well-documented from agricultural and natural hosts worldwide (Perfect et al., 1999; Peres et al., 2005; Sreenivasaprasad and Talhinhas, 2005). The scientific community has long studied the biomolecular processes regulating this lifestyle, especially those related to the switch from biotrophy to necrotrophy. The species complex has a very wide host range. Meta-analyses have revealed that C. acutatum s.l. strains are associated with infections in hundreds of species from over 90 genera of plants (Magnoliophyta: monocotyledons and dicotyledons, Pinophyta, and Pteridophyta), along with at least two insect species (Dufresne et al., 2000; Thon et al., 2002; Wharton and Diéguez-Uribeondo, 2004; O’Connell et al., 2012; Marcelino et al., 2008; Mascarin et al., 2016). In a few cases, associations have been noted with marine ecosystems (Manire et al., 2002; Namikoshi et al., 2002). There appears to be little to no evidence of co-evolution between host and pathogen, particularly in cultivated fruit systems like strawberry and olive, which are susceptible to many members of this species complex (Jayawardena et al., 2016).', 0.3856354355812073]]
Context 6: [['Almost all homothallic isolates capable of sexual reproduction belong to a single genetic group, A7. In contrast, isolates that represent populations capable of heterothallic sexual reproduction are divided into two distinct genetic groups, A3 and A5. Molecular characterization of C. acutatum populations, particularly regarding the introduction and spread of the pathogen in UK strawberry production systems, identified the presence of three genetic groups (A2, A3, and A4). These findings suggest the potential speciation processes within C. acutatum populations, related to their reproductive behaviors and host associations.', 0.35278305411338806]]
Context 7: [['This Perspective article presents a review of the current knowledge on C. acutatum phylogeny, biology, and pathology. It also demonstrates the suitability of C. acutatum for the study of gene family evolution on a fine scale to uncover evolutionary events in the genome associated with the evolution of phenotypic characters important for host interactions.', 0.3207840621471405]]
Context 8: [['In Israel, inoculation of isolates of C. acutatum from anemone and strawberry into each host resulted in typical anthracnose symptoms on both plant species. Molecular studies indicated that the isolates from the two hosts were similar and formed a single genetic subgroup. Isolates of C. acutatum were recovered from pepper, eggplant, tomato, bean, as well as from weeds of the genera Vicia and Conyza; however, disease symptoms occurred only on strawberry. C. acutatum isolates from tulip tree in Argentina were also pathogenic to strawberry fruit. Thus, strawberry isolates of C. acutatum can parasitize and cause disease on other hosts or, alternatively, survive on other crops and weeds without producing symptoms.', 0.30729568004608154]]
Context 9: [['Although C. acutatum usually produces necrotic symptoms of various types on most hosts, the host–pathogen interaction appears to be more biotrophic compared to some other species, such as C. gloeosporioides. C. acutatum survives and competes poorly as a saprophyte in most cases. Nevertheless, it has been isolated from many plant species and is not always associated with disease. This species may colonize the surface of plant tissues as an epiphyte or endophyte under certain circumstances, on both hosts and non-hosts, without producing symptoms.', 0.30186453461647034]]

query: What factors contribute to the heterogeneity of Colletotrichum populations?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['The genus Colletotrichum is considered one of the top ten important genera of fungal pathogens globally (Dean et al., 2012). Colletotrichum is an ancient fungus that has co-evolved with flowering plants. Plant microfossils of Protocolletotrichum preserved on angiosperm leaf cuticles suggest that the diverse pathogenic strategies of Colletotrichum spp. have been established since the Late Cretaceous period (Kar et al., 2004). Different complexes within the genus may have diverged between 4.8 and 32.2 million years ago (MYA) (Bhunjun et al., 2021). The emergence of agricultural cultivation and the intensive disturbance of natural environments have further driven the diversification of Colletotrichum species. These fungi have adapted to thousands of hosts and can be found as endophytes, pathogens, and saprobes (Freeman et al., 1998; Dean et al., 2012; Hirayama et al., 2018; da Silva et al., 2020; Jayawardena et al., 2020). Currently, a total of 257 Colletotrichum species grouped into 15 complexes and 13 additional singletons have been accepted in this genus.', 0.4302297532558441]]

query: What are the challenges in species classification within the Colletotrichum genus, and how have they been addressed?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['In a drastic move, von Arx (1957) reduced the number of recognized Colletotrichum species from several hundred to 11 based on morphological characteristics, with many taxa treated as synonyms of C. gloeosporioides and C. dematium. Several additional species have since been accepted based on morphological criteria (Sutton, 1980; 1992). The difficulties in recognizing Colletotrichum species can be attributed to: 1) the limited and variable morphological characters; 2) an extensive host range and variability in pathogenicity (Bailey and Jeger, 1992; Freeman et al., 2000; Latunde-Dada, 2001; Du et al., 2005; Thaung, 2008); 3) type specimens that are often missing or in poor condition, making them unsuitable for molecular studies; and 4) numerous rDNA ITS sequences of Colletotrichum strains in NCBI that are often misidentified (Crouch et al., 2009d; Damm et al., 2009).', 0.8826466202735901]]
Context 1: [['Despite significant developments over the last ten years, the taxonomy of Colletotrichum is in a state of flux. Many uncertainties exist in the systematics of fungal pathogens from this genus; depending on the taxonomic "guides," the number of species can range from 29 to over 700 (von Arx, 1957; Sutton, 1992). One of the most confusing species is C. gloeosporioides. For example, 594 species of Colletotrichum were reclassified by von Arx as synonyms of C. gloeosporioides. Identification has primarily relied on morphological characteristics of conidia, vegetative and sexual structures, as well as host specificity and cultural characteristics (von Arx, 1957). Unfortunately, conidial morphology and colony characteristics vary even within isolates. Consequently, classical methods have been supplemented with biochemical and molecular technologies to differentiate Colletotrichum species (J. W. Kronstad, ed., Fungal Pathology, 127-148. © 2000 Kluwer Academic Publishers). For a more complete discussion of this topic, see Sherriff et al. (1994).', 0.6865959763526917]]
Context 2: [['The genus Colletotrichum is considered one of the top ten important genera of fungal pathogens globally (Dean et al., 2012). Colletotrichum is an ancient fungus that has co-evolved with flowering plants. Plant microfossils of Protocolletotrichum preserved on angiosperm leaf cuticles suggest that the diverse pathogenic strategies of Colletotrichum spp. have been established since the Late Cretaceous period (Kar et al., 2004). Different complexes within the genus may have diverged between 4.8 and 32.2 million years ago (MYA) (Bhunjun et al., 2021). The emergence of agricultural cultivation and the intensive disturbance of natural environments have further driven the diversification of Colletotrichum species. These fungi have adapted to thousands of hosts and can be found as endophytes, pathogens, and saprobes (Freeman et al., 1998; Dean et al., 2012; Hirayama et al., 2018; da Silva et al., 2020; Jayawardena et al., 2020). Currently, a total of 257 Colletotrichum species grouped into 15 complexes and 13 additional singletons have been accepted in this genus.', 0.4470093250274658]]
Context 3: [['The name Colletotrichum was first introduced by Tode (1790) under the genus Vermicularia. The genus Colletotrichum itself was established by Corda (1831) and is now recognized as comprising “coelomycetes” with a Glomerella teleomorph stage (Sutton, 1992; Shenoy et al., 2007a; Hyde et al., 2009). This genus includes species with endophytic, epiphytic, saprobic, and phytopathogenic lifestyles (Kumar and Hyde, 2004; Photita et al., 2001a,b).', 0.37708064913749695]]
Context 4: [['Much has been written about various individual species of Colletotrichum, yet in many cases, the name used represents a species complex, and it is unclear which actual species is involved. In the following section, we review three species of Colletotrichum to highlight the problems associated with inadequate knowledge of the species and potential incorrect or inaccurate naming.', 0.3326980471611023]]
Context 5: [['Hyde, K.D., Cai, L., Cannon, P.F., Crouch, J.A., Crous, P.W., Damm, U., Goodwin, P.H., Chen, H., Johnston, P.R., Jones, E.B.G., Liu, Z.Y., McKenzie, E.H.C., Moriwaki, J., Noireung, P., Pennycook, S.R., Pfenning, L.H., Prihastuti, H., Sato, T., Shivas, R.G., Tan, Y.P., Taylor, P.W.J., Weir, B.S., Yang, Y.L., Zhang, J.Z., 2009. query: Is there a likelihood that additional varieties will be recognized within the Colletotrichum genus in future studies?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Although the numerous name changes within the genus Colletotrichum over the next few years may be confusing, establishing a long-term stable taxonomic framework is necessary. The examples provided illustrate many cases where we have no idea whether the correct names were used. The situation is exacerbated by the fact that approximately 86% of names on GenBank under C. gloeosporioides appear to be misidentified. It is impossible to repeat or extend scientific work and compare findings with existing published work if the names applied to species in publications are erroneous. We have no choice but to restudy, revise, and clarify the genus so that the naming of Colletotrichum species will, in the future, be reproducible and precise.', 0.8973307013511658]]
Context 1: [['In a drastic move, von Arx (1957) reduced the number of recognized Colletotrichum species from several hundred to 11 based on morphological characteristics, with many taxa treated as synonyms of C. gloeosporioides and C. dematium. Several additional species have since been accepted based on morphological criteria (Sutton, 1980; 1992). The difficulties in recognizing Colletotrichum species can be attributed to: 1) the limited and variable morphological characters; 2) an extensive host range and variability in pathogenicity (Bailey and Jeger, 1992; Freeman et al., 2000; Latunde-Dada, 2001; Du et al., 2005; Thaung, 2008); 3) type specimens that are often missing or in poor condition, making them unsuitable for molecular studies; and 4) numerous rDNA ITS sequences of Colletotrichum strains in NCBI that are often misidentified (Crouch et al., 2009d; Damm et al., 2009).', 0.8905066251754761]]
Context 2: [['Additional studies revealed a variety of Colletotrichum species, including C. aenigma, C. karstii, and others in different regions by Sharma et al. (2017) [91] and others through 2020.', 0.7709140777587891]]
Context 3: [['Infraspecific groups within Colletotrichum species are poorly understood and have largely been omitted from discussions on current nomenclature (Hyde et al., 2009). The current Code of Botanical Nomenclature outlines a few formal infraspecific categories: subspecies, variety, and form. Categories like forma specialis and pathotype have also been employed by plant pathologists to classify infraspecific groups that exhibit distinct host specializations or behaviors (Cannon, 2000). The use of subspecies, varieties, and forms within Colletotrichum has varied, with 33 introductions recorded between 1940 and 2000. The intermittent application of forma species or varieties seems to have depended as much on individual authors as on established rules. Until there is a clear understanding of what constitutes a Colletotrichum species, it may be unwise to further consider subspecies, forms, and varieties.', 0.6762620806694031]]
Context 4: [['Species concepts in Colletotrichum have evolved from the use of basic morphological data to a polyphasic approach that incorporates a significant molecular component. This evolution has made traditional classifications less practical, as holotypes and other types are not very useful since DNA cannot usually be extracted. It is recommended that future studies adopt a polyphasic approach before introducing new species of Colletotrichum or designating epitypes. This approach should integrate molecular, morphological, physiological, and pathogenic data.', 0.6603401303291321]]
Context 5: [['Cannon, P.F., Bridge, P.D., and Monte, E. (2000). Linking the past, present, and future of Colletotrichum systematics. query: What types of fertilizers should be avoided to prevent worsening Colletotrichum infections?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Colletotrichum is one of the most important genera of plant pathogenic fungi, with many of the 200 plus species known to cause disease in crop plants worldwide (Alahakoon et al. 1994; Rojas et al. 2010; Cannon et al. 2012; Damm et al. 2012a, 2012b; Udayanga et al. 2013; Shivas et al. 2016; De Silva et al. 2017a).', 0.33814695477485657]]
Context 1: [['Colletotrichum species are economically important plant pathogens, particularly in tropical, subtropical, and temperate regions, where they affect a wide range of plant hosts (Sutton 1992). The typical symptoms of Colletotrichum infections include sunken necrotic lesions, often bearing orange conidial masses, referred to as anthracnose (Freeman et al. 1998). The impact of these pathogens on fruit crops is significant, causing severe yield losses; for example, bitter rot is one of the most critical diseases affecting apple fruit, potentially leading to yield losses of up to 50% (Sutton 1990).', 0.2935318946838379]]
Context 2: [['Integrated pest management (IPM) strategies for Colletotrichum spp. encompass cultural, biological, and chemical control measures. Cultural control practices include producing disease-free propagating materials, avoiding overhead irrigation, minimizing rain splashing through mulching, and managing weeds (Coelho et al., 2008; Saxena et al., 2016). It is also recommended to remove infected crop residues and any mummified or rotten fruits to reduce inoculum sources and disease spread.', 0.26737961173057556]]
Context 3: [['In Colletotrichum: Biology, Pathology and Control (eds. J.A. Bailey and M.J. Jeger). CAB International: Wallingford.', 0.2500031292438507]]
Context 4: [['Bailey, J.A., & Jeger, M.J. (1992). Colletotrichum: biology, pathology, and control. Tropical Plant Pathology, 40, 265–274.', 0.23049898445606232]]
Context 5: [['Bailey, J.A., et al. (1992). Infection strategies of Colletotrichum species. In: Colletotrichum: Biology, Pathology and Control (Eds. J.A. Bailey and M.J. Jeger). CAB International: Wallingford: 88-120.', 0.2177199423313141]]
Context 6: [['Many species belonging to the genus Colletotrichum are associated with plant diseases, commonly referred to as anthracnose. Colletotrichum spp. can affect a wide range of hosts, and these pathogens are characterized by global distribution. Virtually every cultivated botanical family is susceptible to one or more species of Colletotrichum, making it one of the most studied plant pathogenic fungi (Prusky et al., 2000; Latunde-Dada, 2001; Dean et al., 2012). Common hosts include many dicotyledonous plants such as strawberry, apple, citrus, and stone fruits, as well as major cereals such as maize and sorghum. Members of this genus can cause crop losses of up to 100% in many staple foods (Bailey and Jeger, 1992; Prusky et al., 2000; Talhinhas et al., 2005; Cannon et al., 2012).', 0.21103353798389435]]
Context 7: [['Latunde-Dada, A. O. 2001. Colletotrichum: Tales of forcible entry, stealth, transient confinement, and breakout. Mol. Plant Pathol. 2:187-198.', 0.211014524102211]]
Context 8: [['The genus Colletotrichum represents a large number of economically important Ascomycete fungi that collectively cause anthracnose disease or leaf blights on significant agricultural crops and ornamental plants worldwide. Colletotrichum spp. often serve as models in studies ranging from pathogenic development and differentiation to plant-microbe interactions. During establishment and colonization of host plants, members of this genus uniquely acquire nutrients via both biotrophy and necrotrophy. Thus, in a single interaction, these fungal pathogens exhibit two modes of nutrient acquisition: initially, nutrients are acquired from living cells, after which a necrotrophic phase is initiated, allowing the same fungus to obtain nutrients from dead cells killed by the fungus. A given species of this genus can exhibit both strategies separately or concurrently. Additionally, these fungi develop a series of specialized infection-related structures, including germ tubes, appressoria, primary intracellular hyphae, and secondary necrotrophic hyphae. Therefore, Colletotrichum species are experimentally attractive organisms for studying the molecular, biochemical, and cellular basis of fungal pathogenicity, development, and signal transduction (see Bailey and Jeger, 1992; Prusky et al., 1999).', 0.200016587972641]]
Context 9: [['Bailey, J.A., and Jeger, M.J. (1992). Colletotrichum: Biology, Pathology and Control. Wallingford: CAB International.', 0.19941768050193787]]

query: Which Colletotrichum species complex did the majority of the isolates belong to?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Despite significant developments over the last ten years, the taxonomy of Colletotrichum is in a state of flux. Many uncertainties exist in the systematics of fungal pathogens from this genus; depending on the taxonomic "guides," the number of species can range from 29 to over 700 (von Arx, 1957; Sutton, 1992). One of the most confusing species is C. gloeosporioides. For example, 594 species of Colletotrichum were reclassified by von Arx as synonyms of C. gloeosporioides. Identification has primarily relied on morphological characteristics of conidia, vegetative and sexual structures, as well as host specificity and cultural characteristics (von Arx, 1957). Unfortunately, conidial morphology and colony characteristics vary even within isolates. Consequently, classical methods have been supplemented with biochemical and molecular technologies to differentiate Colletotrichum species (J. W. Kronstad, ed., Fungal Pathology, 127-148. © 2000 Kluwer Academic Publishers). For a more complete discussion of this topic, see Sherriff et al. (1994).', 0.7716822624206543]]
Context 1: [['The same specimen, when grown in the lab under different growth conditions, highlights the need for molecular techniques to separate species of Colletotrichum and to examine genetic variation within and between species and populations (Cai et al. 2009; Hyde et al. 2009; Phoulivong et al. 2010). Recent studies on the systematics of Colletotrichum species have categorized them into nine major clades, along with small clusters and isolated species, which may represent species complexes (Cannon et al. 2012).', 0.6822161674499512]]
Context 2: [['Much has been written about various individual species of Colletotrichum, yet in many cases, the name used represents a species complex, and it is unclear which actual species is involved. In the following section, we review three species of Colletotrichum to highlight the problems associated with inadequate knowledge of the species and potential incorrect or inaccurate naming.', 0.43928220868110657]]
Context 3: [['In the past, common identification systems for Colletotrichum included traditional morphological taxonomy, molecular classification based on ITS sequences, and the presence of secondary metabolites, among other traits. However, these methods alone or in combination were insufficient to fully resolve the species identity of individual Colletotrichum isolates. Additional characteristics, including other aspects of morphology and multi-gene phylogenetic analyses, are necessary for accurate identification of Colletotrichum species.', 0.43757373094558716]]
Context 4: [['Table 2 lists the details of various Colletotrichum isolates, including their GenBank accession numbers, species, specific isolates, substrate, locality of collection, and date of collection. Each entry corresponds to a particular isolate, detailing its associated species and other relevant data, which helps in understanding the diversity and geographical distribution of these isolates.', 0.2342638224363327]]
Context 5: [['Hyde KD, Cai L, McKenzie E, Yang YL, Zhang JZ, Prihastuti H. Colletotrichum: A catalogue of confusion. Fungal Divers. 2009;39:1-17. https://www.researchgate.net/publication/274385803.', 0.2199300080537796]]

query: How does ap-PCR contribute to understanding pathogen diversity?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['PCR Amplification: For arbitrarily primed PCR (ap-PCR), primers were derived from minisatellite or repeat sequences as follows: CAGCAGCAGCAGCAG (26), GACACGACACGACAC (17), and GACAGACAGACAGACA (32). In the text, these primers have been designated as (CAG)5, (GACAC)3, and (GACA)4, respectively. PCR primers for the detection of the pathogen in planta included the ITS4 primer (TCCTCCGCTTATTGATATGC) coupled with the specific primer for C. acutatum (CaInt2) (GGGGAAGCCTCTCGCGG) (5). PCR reactions were performed in a total volume of 20 µl, containing 10 to 100 ng of genomic DNA, 50 mM KCl, 10 mM Tris-HCl, 0.2 mM each of dATP, dCTP, dGTP, and dTTP, 1.5 mM MgCl2, 1 unit of Taq DNA polymerase (Promega Corp., Madison, WI), and 1 µM primer. The reactions were incubated in a PTC-100 thermocycler (MJ Research Inc., Watertown, MA), starting with 5 minutes of denaturation at 95°C. For ap-PCR, this was followed by 30 cycles consisting of 30 seconds at 95°C, 30 seconds at either 60°C (for (CAG)5) or 48°C (for (GACA)4 and (GACAC)3), and 1.5 minutes at 72°C. C. acutatum-specific PCR reactions were performed under conditions for primer (CAG)5 with 0.5 µM ITS4 primer coupled with 0.5 µM primer CaInt2. Amplification products were separated in agarose gels (1.8% wt/vol; 15 × 10 cm, WXL) in Tris-acetate-EDTA buffer, electrophoresed at 80 V for 2 hours, stained with ethidium bromide, and viewed under UV light for detection of amplification products.', 0.4497701823711395]]
Context 1: [['Table 1: List of primers used in the study.', 0.21455323696136475]]

Context 8: [['PCR Amplification: The PCR amplification mixtures were set up in 0.25-ml tubes containing 60 ml of reaction mixture, which included 1 ml of each primer solution (50 mM), 2 ml of dNTP mix solution (2.5 mM), 1 ml of gDNA solution (approximately 50 ng per reaction), 1 ml of Taq DNA polymerase (5 U per reaction; TAKARA Biotechnology Co., Ltd., Dalian, China), 6 ml of PCR buffer, and 49 ml of PCR-grade water. The PCR was performed in a thermal cycler (PTC-100 TMPeltier Thermal Cycler; Hercules, CA).', 0.06457674503326416]]
Context 9: [["All PCR products were purified using the QIAquick PCR Purification kit (QIAGEN, Australia) according to the manufacturer's instructions. DNA sequence analysis of the PCR products was conducted at either the Australian Genome Research Facility (AGRF, Melbourne) or the Westerdijk Fungal Biodiversity Institute, Utrecht, the Netherlands. The purified PCR products were sequenced in both forward and reverse directions, and consensus sequences were generated by alignment using Geneious Pro v. 11.1.4 (Kearse et al. 2012). These consensus sequences were deposited in GenBank (as detailed in Table 2), with taxonomic novelties also recorded in MycoBank (Crous et al. 2004b). The sequences for each locus were assembled using MEGA v. 6 (Tamura et al. 2013). The GenBank accession numbers for all isolates utilized in the phylogenetic analyses are listed in Table 2.", 0.06298788636922836]]

query: Can fungi spread in the rain or wind?

Context 1: [['Plant pathogens have evolved various dispersal mechanisms, utilizing biotic or abiotic vectors, or a combination of both. Rain splash dispersal is well-documented in numerous fungi and can be an efficient driver of crop epidemics, allowing infectious strains to propagate rapidly among genetically homogenous neighboring plants. query: What scientific evidence supports the claim that Ca(NO3)2 is beneficial for strawberry growers dealing with diseases like anthracnose?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['In a related study, the severity of anthracnose fruit rot, caused by Colletotrichum acutatum, was also reduced with the application of Ca(NO3)2 on greenhouse-grown strawberries. Similar findings were reported regarding the control of Fusarium diseases in tomatoes and chrysanthemums. Notably, there was a significant variation in foliar N levels among different strawberry clones, suggesting that N applications should be customized for each cultivar. Nonetheless, the trend of decreased anthracnose severity with nitrate fertilizers was consistent across five strawberry clones tested, indicating that other cultivars may respond similarly.', 0.993073046207428]]
Context 1: [['These results indicate that strawberry growers can adjust their fertilizer practices by opting for Ca(NO3)2 as their N source. This adjustment can help reduce the severity of anthracnose crown rot while ensuring adequate foliar N levels necessary for optimal growth and production. As anticipated, foliar N levels increased with higher treatment N levels, while P and K levels did not influence foliar N.', 0.9921212196350098]]
Context 2: [['When N fertilizer is applied to strawberry plants as Ca(NO3)2, anthracnose crown rot severity should be less than when N is applied in ammonium forms. Anthracnose crown rot, caused by the fungus Colletotrichum fragariae, can infect all above-ground parts of the strawberry plant. Petiole and stolon infections are characterized by dark, sunken lesions, while leaf infections present as small black spots. When the crown is infected, it can lead to wilting and rapid plant death. An internal symptom of a crown infection is red discoloration, typically extending in a “V” shape from the side of the crown toward the center. Other pathogens such as Colletotrichum gloeosporioides and C. acutatum also cause anthracnose diseases in strawberries.', 0.9720646739006042]]
Context 3: [['Additionally, prior studies have indicated correlations between nitrogen concentration and anthracnose severity, similar to findings in cotton (Huber & Watson, 1974). Choi et al. (2000) noted that as tissue nitrogen content decreased, calcium and manganese contents, which directly impact phenolic metabolism, increased in strawberries. Manganese may enhance the synthesis of host defense products, potentially reducing disease incidence and severity. Phosphorus supplied as phosphite effectively reduced phytophthora root and crown rot in tomato and pepper plants, while calcium has been shown to inhibit anthracnose caused by Colletotrichum gloeosporioides (Froster et al., 1998).', 0.7645819783210754]]
Context 4: [['Nam, M.H., S.K. Jeong, Y.S. Lee, J.M. Choi, and H.G. Kim. 2006. Effects of nitrogen, phosphorus, potassium, and calcium nutrition on strawberry anthracnose. Plant Pathol. 55:246–249.', 0.6656880378723145]]
Context 5: [['Nam, M. H., Jung, S. K., Lee, Y. S., Choi, J. M., and Kim, H. G. 2006. Effects of nitrogen, phosphorus, potassium, and calcium nutrition on strawberry anthracnose. Plant Pathology 55:246–249.', 0.6604722738265991]]
Context 6: [['Smith, B.J. 2009b. Nitrogen fertilizer affects the severity of anthracnose crown rot disease of greenhouse-grown strawberries. Online. Plant Health Progress. DOI:10.1094/PHP-2009-0609-01-RS.', 0.5327205657958984]]
Context 7: [['Smith, B. J. 2009. Nitrogen fertilizer affects the severity of anthracnose crown rot disease of greenhouse-grown strawberries. Online. Plant Health Progress. doi:10.1094/PHP-2009-0609-01-RS.', 0.530013918876648]]
Context 8: [['Seven nitrogen sources [(NH4)2SO4, NH4Cl, (NH4)2HPO4, NH4NO3, NaNO3, KNO3, and Ca(NO3)2] were evaluated at three levels (0, 40, and 160 ppm N) on three strawberry clones (MSUS 37, MSUS 70, and MSUS 98) with five replications in Nitrogen Source Study I. The same seven nitrogen sources were evaluated at three levels (0, 40, and 120 ppm N) on four strawberry clones (Tangi, MSUS 70, MSUS 74, and MSUS 98) with four replications in Nitrogen Source Study II.', 0.38124939799308777]]

query: What are the primary methods used for characterizing genetic diversity in Colletotrichum species?

Context 0: [['Overall, the study investigates the genetic diversity and specificity of Colletotrichum species through molecular techniques, contributing to a better understanding of their phylogenetic relationships.', 0.8709623217582703]]

(2009). A polyphasic approach for studying Colletotrichum. Fungal Diversity, 39: 183-204.', 0.7535709142684937]]
Context 2: [['The genus Colletotrichum is considered one of the top ten important genera of fungal pathogens globally (Dean et al., 2012). Colletotrichum is an ancient fungus that has co-evolved with flowering plants. Plant microfossils of Protocolletotrichum preserved on angiosperm leaf cuticles suggest that the diverse pathogenic strategies of Colletotrichum spp. have been established since the Late Cretaceous period (Kar et al., 2004). Different complexes within the genus may have diverged between 4.8 and 32.2 million years ago (MYA) (Bhunjun et al., 2021). The emergence of agricultural cultivation and the intensive disturbance of natural environments have further driven the diversification of Colletotrichum species. These fungi have adapted to thousands of hosts and can be found as endophytes, pathogens, and saprobes (Freeman et al., 1998; Dean et al., 2012; Hirayama et al., 2018; da Silva et al., 2020; Jayawardena et al., 2020). Currently, a total of 257 Colletotrichum species grouped into 15 complexes and 13 additional singletons have been accepted in this genus.', 0.605006992816925]]
Context 3: [['Table 2 provides a comprehensive list of various species of the genus Colletotrichum, including their culture accession numbers and the host plants from which they were isolated. Each entry specifies the country of origin and includes corresponding GenBank accession numbers for the ITS, GAPDH, ACT, and CHS-1 genes. The species range from Colletotrichum aenigmay, isolated from Persea americana in Israel, to Colletotrichum boninense, derived from Crinum asiaticum in Japan. This detailed tabulation is essential for understanding the genetic diversity and distribution of Colletotrichum species in relation to their host plants.', 0.6020656824111938]]
Context 4: [['In a drastic move, von Arx (1957) reduced the number of recognized Colletotrichum species from several hundred to 11 based on morphological characteristics, with many taxa treated as synonyms of C. gloeosporioides and C. dematium. Several additional species have since been accepted based on morphological criteria (Sutton, 1980; 1992). The difficulties in recognizing Colletotrichum species can be attributed to: 1) the limited and variable morphological characters; 2) an extensive host range and variability in pathogenicity (Bailey and Jeger, 1992; Freeman et al., 2000; Latunde-Dada, 2001; Du et al., 2005; Thaung, 2008); 3) type specimens that are often missing or in poor condition, making them unsuitable for molecular studies; and 4) numerous rDNA ITS sequences of Colletotrichum strains in NCBI that are often misidentified (Crouch et al., 2009d; Damm et al., 2009).', 0.48851752281188965]]
Context 5: [['Photita, W., Taylor, P. W., Ford, R., Hyde, K. D., and Lumyong, S. (2005). Morphological and molecular characterization of Colletotrichum species from...', 0.4480462372303009]]
