query: How do fungicides contribute to the management of anthracnose in strawberries?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Strawberry anthracnose, caused mainly by the Colletotrichum acutatum species complex, is a significant disease affecting strawberry production. Surveys were conducted, and isolates were collected from affected areas, specifically strawberry nurseries and production fields in six states across the United States. The use of fungicides, particularly quinone outside inhibitors (QoIs), has been widely employed for controlling C. acutatum for the past 20 years. Resistance to QoIs was first reported in Florida in 2013, and subsequent anthracnose outbreaks occurred in strawberry nurseries and production fields throughout the U.S. in 2015. Fungicide use surveys indicated that, in certain locations, the number of QoI applications exceeded the recommended levels for this fungicide group. This situation necessitates immediate changes in anthracnose management strategies to incorporate other chemical and non-chemical approaches, aiming to limit the selection of resistant populations and prevent future outbreaks.', 0.9910125136375427]]
Context 1: [['Additionally, multisite fungicides such as captan, thiram, and chlorothalonil, which have been available for many decades, remain effective in reducing strawberry anthracnose incidence (Mertely et al. 2018). Chlorothalonil is only registered for nonbearing nurseries when flowers and fruit are absent, yet our surveys indicated that its usage is significantly lower compared to newer single-site fungicides. Due to their efficacy and low resistance risk, multisite fungicides should be the mainstay for disease control in strawberry nurseries. Other non-chemical alternatives, such as heat (Wang et al. 2017) and ultraviolet treatments (Onofre et al. 2017), are currently under investigation and could serve as valuable tools for disease management, reducing the reliance on single-site fungicides.', 0.9888896942138672]]
Context 2: [['Until highly resistant cultivars are available, growers must rely on chemical applications and cultural practices to reduce losses due to anthracnose. The failure of fungicides to control anthracnose epidemics may be attributed to the development of fungicide resistance in the Colletotrichum species population. For example, benomyl was shown to effectively reduce the incidence of anthracnose crown rot (Horn et al., 1972; Howard, 1971) and was used intensively by strawberry growers for years to control anthracnose and other diseases. However, the anthracnose pathogens, C. acutatum and C. fragariae, developed resistance to it and other benzimidazole fungicides (LaMondia, 1995; McInnes et al., 1992a; Smith and Black, 1992, 1993), leading to the ineffectiveness of benomyl for anthracnose control in strawberry fields.', 0.988569438457489]]
Context 3: [['Until highly resistant cultivars are available, growers must rely on chemical applications and cultural practices to reduce losses due to anthracnose. The failure of fungicides to control anthracnose epidemics may be due to the development of fungicide resistance in the Colletotrichum spp. population. For example, benomyl effectively reduced the incidence of anthracnose crown rot (Horn et al., 1972; Howard, 1971) and was used intensively by strawberry growers for years to control anthracnose and other diseases. However, the anthracnose pathogens, C. acutatum and C. fragariae, developed resistance to it and other benzimidazole fungicides (LaMondia, 1995; McInnes et al., 1992a; Smith and Black, 1992, 1993), rendering benomyl ineffective for anthracnose control in strawberry fields.', 0.9885359406471252]]
Context 4: [['The application of fungicides to control strawberry anthracnose is limited due to restrictions on pesticide usage and the susceptibility of strawberry plants to Colletotrichum during all stages of development, including flowers, green, and ripe fruit. To reduce anthracnose infection in plant nurseries, it is essential to produce disease-free propagation material, which is a prerequisite for establishing disease-free nursery transplants. Control measures practiced in the United States involve frequent applications of fungicides.', 0.988304615020752]]
Context 5: [['In the southeastern United States, anthracnose crown rot and fruit rot can be particularly severe in strawberry production fields, especially during wet harvest seasons, which can lead to total crop loss. Fungicides are used to control anthracnose diseases; however, several have become ineffective due to the development of fungicide-resistant strains of the pathogens. Field observations in Florida indicated that growing strawberry plants in soils with low N levels reduced the severity of anthracnose, although this also severely limited fruit production. Both the form of nitrogen and calcium levels influence disease severity. For instance, calcium has been employed to manage soil-borne diseases caused by Pythium spp. on various crops, while nitrate forms of N have been shown to suppress Fusarium wilt in tomatoes, whereas ammonium forms increase disease severity.', 0.9882203340530396]]
Context 6: [['Anthracnose is an important disease of strawberry caused by Colletotrichum spp., which affects foliage, runners, crowns, and fruits (Howard et al., 1992). Three primary fungal pathogens—C. acutatum sensu lato, C. gloeosporioides sensu lato, and C. fragariae—are known to cause anthracnose disease in strawberries (Freeman and Katan, 1997). The crown rot syndrome is characteristic of infections from C. gloeosporioides sensu lato and C. fragariae, while fruit rot is mainly attributed to C. acutatum sensu lato, leading to significant yield losses (Howard et al., 1992). Currently, numerous species are classified under what is now known as the C. acutatum complex, with six species—C. acutatum sensu stricto, C. fioriniae, C. godetiae, C. nymphaeae, C. salicis, and C. simmondsii—identified as associated with strawberry anthracnose worldwide (Damm et al., 2012). Among these, C. nymphaeae is the most prevalent pathogen causing strawberry anthracnose globally, including in Iran (Baroncelli et al., 2015; Karimi et al., 2017; Wang et al., 2019). Currently, no effective chemical control methods exist for managing strawberry anthracnose; available options are limited to preventive treatments applied before fruit production (Denoyes-Rothan et al., 1999). Additionally, concerns about the toxic effects of chemical fungicides on the environment and the development of resistance in fungal strains highlight the need for alternative control strategies. Consequently, utilizing resistant cultivars appears to be the most efficient and practical approach for suppressing anthracnose development. In light of recent anthracnose outbreaks in strawberry fields in the Kurdistan province of Iran (Karimi et al., 2017), and the necessity for appropriate strategies to address this issue, the aim of this study was to evaluate the resistance of several commercial strawberry cultivars to the anthracnose fruit rot caused by C. nymphaeae under in vivo and greenhouse conditions.', 0.9878437519073486]]
Context 7: [['ABSTRACT: Strawberry anthracnose, caused by Colletotrichum fragariae, is a serious problem in the southeastern United States, resulting in significant losses in strawberry nurseries. Control measures using fungicides are crucial, particularly with recommended applications of captafol, benomyl, captan, and maneb.', 0.9875697493553162]]
Context 8: [['There is an urgent need for multi- and single-site fungicide alternatives effective against anthracnose in strawberry nurseries and production fields. The antifungal antibiotic natamycin, widely used as a natural mold inhibitor in food products, has shown promise in controlling anthracnose root and crown infections caused by C. acutatum on strawberry transplants (Cordova et al. 2017; Haack et al. 2018). Similarly, fluazinam, a single-site respiration inhibitor fungicide from FRAC group 29, has demonstrated significant control of anthracnose fruit rot (Mertely et al. 2018). A request has been submitted through the Interregional Research Project Number 4 for its registration for nursery use only. Reducing the overlap of the same modes of action used during nursery and fruit production phases could help extend the lifespan of single-site fungicides at high risk of resistance.', 0.986594557762146]]
Context 9: [['Smith, B.J. and L.L. Black. 1991. Greenhouse efficacy of fungicides for control of anthracnose crown rot of strawberry, p. 221-223. In: A. Dale and J. Luby (eds.). The Strawberry into the 21st Century. Timber Press, Portland, OR.', 0.9863460659980774]]

Three primary fungal pathogens—C. acutatum sensu lato, C. gloeosporioides sensu lato, and C. fragariae—are known to cause anthracnose disease in strawberries (Freeman and Katan, 1997). The crown rot syndrome is characteristic of infections from C. gloeosporioides sensu lato and C. fragariae, while fruit rot is mainly attributed to C. acutatum sensu lato, leading to significant yield losses (Howard et al., 1992). Currently, numerous species are classified under what is now known as the C. acutatum complex, with six species—C. acutatum sensu stricto, C. fioriniae, C. godetiae, C. nymphaeae, C. salicis, and C. simmondsii—identified as associated with strawberry anthracnose worldwide (Damm et al., 2012). Among these, C. nymphaeae is the most prevalent pathogen causing strawberry anthracnose globally, including in Iran (Baroncelli et al., 2015; Karimi et al., 2017; Wang et al., 2019). Currently, no effective chemical control methods exist for managing strawberry anthracnose; available options are limited to preventive treatments applied before fruit production (Denoyes-Rothan et al., 1999). In light of recent anthracnose outbreaks in strawberry fields in the Kurdistan province of Iran (Karimi et al., 2017), and the necessity for appropriate strategies to address this issue, the aim of this study was to evaluate the resistance of several commercial strawberry cultivars to the anthracnose fruit rot caused by C. nymphaeae under in vivo and greenhouse conditions.', 0.9830213785171509]]
Context 1: [['Madden, L.V., Wilson, L.L., Ellis, M.A. 1993. Field spread of anthracnose in strawberry. Plant Disease. 77:861–866.', 0.9499629735946655]]
Context 2: [["Anthracnose fungi can attack various parts of the strawberry plant, including crowns, petioles, leaves, fruit trusses, flowers, buds, and fruit. The fungi's ability to attack multiple plant parts, coupled with the involvement of several pathogen species, contributes to the complex nature of strawberry anthracnose. Brooks reported in 1931 that C. fragariae caused spotting and girdling of runners, and later indicated that it also caused spotting of petioles and crown rot in a summer nursery, leading to wilting and death of the plants. Researchers in Louisiana observed all these symptoms and noted that crown rot also occurred in the fruit production field.", 0.5872370004653931]]
Context 3: [['So far, anthracnose epidemics have affected strawberry nurseries and production fields worldwide. Reports on Colletotrichum spp. associated with strawberries, curated from literature in PubMed and Clarivate combined with fungal database searches (Farr and Rossman, 2022), were compiled to understand the global diversity and occurrence of the causal agents of strawberry anthracnose. From our findings, since 1931 until July 9, 2022, there have been over 220 citations and 310 records related to the identification of causal agents of strawberry anthracnose at the genus level of Colletotrichum in 36 countries across six continents, with 282 records providing pathogen identification at the species or species complex level.', 0.541426420211792]]
Context 4: [['From May to September 1995, a severe outbreak of strawberry anthracnose was observed in several strawberry-growing nurseries in Israel. Following transplantation to production fields during September and October, entire beds of strawberry plants collapsed. Typical anthracnose symptoms observed from November 1995 to June 1996 included crown rot, flower blight, and green and ripe fruit rot. This marked the first record of strawberry anthracnose in Israel. Furthermore, in at least four production fields in the same region, hundreds of plants developed symptoms of stunting and chlorosis, which are atypical of strawberry anthracnose. When these plants were uprooted, most of their roots were dark brown and decayed. Colletotrichum was readily isolated from these samples.', 0.4988595247268677]]
Context 5: [['Howard CM, Albregts EE. Anthracnose. In: Compendium of Strawberry Diseases. American Phytopathological Society: Paul St, ed. Maas JL, USA; 1984. pp. 85-87.', 0.4030110239982605]]
Context 6: [['In the early 1980s, anthracnose became a significant disease affecting strawberries in the southeastern United States. This initiative was conducted at the Small Fruit Research Station in Poplarville, MS, and the Fruit Laboratory in Beltsville, MD, in collaboration with state experiment stations in Florida, Louisiana, and North Carolina (Galletta et al., 1997; Smith and Spiers, 1982).', 0.39329981803894043]]

query: What role does field sanitation play in controlling anthracnose?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Additional Keywords: anthracnose, disease spread, Fragaria × ananassa, models, quantitative epidemiology.', 0.191636323928833]]
Context 1: [['Anthracnose spreads within a field by splashing water, and living mulches (such as wheat, rye, or ryegrass) in row middles have been shown to reduce disease spread within a field. Sublethal doses of grass-specific herbicides, such as sethoxydim, may be used to prevent excessive growth of ryegrass (Gupton, 2000). Organic mulches, such as wheat straw or pine needles, also reduce splash and result in a lower incidence of anthracnose compared to rows mulched with plastic (Madden, 1992; Smith and Spiers, 1986). Anthracnose is less severe when water is supplied to plants using drip irrigation rather than overhead irrigation (Madden, 1992; Smith and Spiers, 1986).', 0.17415772378444672]]

Organic mulches like wheat straw or pine needles also reduce splash and result in a lower incidence of anthracnose compared to rows mulched with plastic (Coelho et al., 2008; Madden, 1992; Smith and Spiers, 1986). For example, benomyl effectively reduced the incidence of anthracnose crown rot (Horn et al., 1972; Howard, 1971) and was used intensively by strawberry growers for years to control anthracnose and other diseases. However, the anthracnose pathogens, C. acutatum and C. fragariae, developed resistance to it and other benzimidazole fungicides (LaMondia, 1995; McInnes et al., 1992a; Smith and Black, 1992, 1993), rendering benomyl ineffective for anthracnose control in strawberry fields.', 0.13577421009540558]]

query: What are the most common symptoms of Colletotrichum infections on different parts of strawberry plants?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Abstract: Three Colletotrichum species—Colletotrichum acutatum J.H. Simmonds (teleomorph Glomerella acutata J.C. Guerber & J.C. Correll), Colletotrichum fragariae A.N. Brooks, and Colletotrichum gloeosporioides (Penz.) Penz. & Sacc. in Penz. [teleomorph Glomerella cingulata (Stoneman) Spauld. & H. Schrenk]—are major pathogens of strawberry (Fragaria × ananassa). Strawberry anthracnose crown rot has been a destructive disease in commercial strawberry fields in the southeastern United States since the 1930s. The causal fungus, C. fragariae, can infect all aboveground plant parts; however, the disease is most severe when it infects the crown, leading to crown rot, wilt, and death.', 0.9876345992088318]]
Context 1: [['Three species of Colletotrichum—Colletotrichum acutatum J.H. Simmonds (teleomorph: Glomerella acutata J.C. Guerber & J.C. Correll), Colletotrichum fragariae A.N. Brooks, and Colletotrichum gloeosporioides (Penz.) Penz. & Sacc. in Penz. (teleomorph: Glomerella cingulata (Stoneman) Spauld. & H. Schrenk)—are major pathogens of strawberry (Fragaria × ananassa). Strawberry anthracnose crown rot has been a destructive disease in commercial strawberry fields in the southeastern United States since the 1930s. The causal fungus, C. fragariae, can infect all aboveground plant parts; however, the disease is most severe when it infects the crown, leading to crown rot, wilting, and plant death.', 0.9581081867218018]]
Context 2: [['Species of the fungal plant pathogen Colletotrichum collectively cause anthracnose on strawberry (Fragaria × ananassa Duch.), which is a major disease of this crop worldwide. Principal pathogens responsible for the disease include Colletotrichum acutatum J. H. Simmonds, C. fragariae Brooks, and C. gloeosporioides (Penz.) Penz. & Sacc. in Penz. (teleomorph: Glomerella cingulata (Stoneman) Spauld. & H. Schrenk).', 0.7657414674758911]]
Context 3: [['Anthracnose caused by Colletotrichum species is one of the most destructive diseases affecting strawberry production worldwide. Fungi of the genus Colletotrichum, which are ancient and co-evolved with flowering plants, rank eighth among the ten most economically important fungal pathogens and have diversified to adapt to various hosts. Since its first report in the United States in 1931, strawberry anthracnose has spread globally, resulting in devastating economic, social, and ecological consequences. In many ways, producing organic strawberries is largely impractical because of this disease. Colletotrichum species pathogenic to strawberries have been extensively characterized. This review aims to provide an accurate inventory of these species by revisiting their discovery history over the past 90 years. A total of 23 Colletotrichum species, clustered into five species complexes and two singleton taxa, have been accepted as strawberry pathogens with a global occurrence illustrated. The relative prevalence of distinct Colletotrichum species associated with strawberries has been systematically analyzed in China. Finally, the host range of the two prevailing species, C. fructicola and C. siamense, which cause significant damage globally, is summarized, with the goal of improving diagnostic accuracy and anthracnose management in agricultural ecosystems.', 0.6690900325775146]]
Context 4: [['Smith BJ, Black LL. Morphological, cultural, and pathogenic variation in Colletotrichum species isolated from strawberry. Plant Dis. 1990;74(1):69–76. https://doi.org/10.1094/PD-74-0069.', 0.41831621527671814]]
Context 5: [['Smith, B.J. and L.L. Black. 1990. Morphological, cultural, and pathogenic variation among Colletotrichum species isolated from strawberry. Plant Dis.', 0.39354488253593445]]
Context 6: [['Garcia-Muñoz, J.-A., Súarez, M. B., Grondona, I., Monte, E., Buddie, A. G., Bridge, P. D., and Cannon, P. F. (2000). A physiological and biochemical approach to the systematics of Colletotrichum species pathogenic to strawberry. Mycologia, 92(3), 488-498.', 0.3899083733558655]]
Context 7: [['Smith, B.J. & Black, L.L. (1990). Morphological, cultural, and pathogenic variation among Colletotrichum species isolated from strawberry. Plant Dis., 74, 69–76.', 0.3340546786785126]]
Context 8: [['Based on published data, we discussed the prevalence of Colletotrichum species in strawberry fields in China. C. siamense and C. fructicola from the C. gloeosporioides sensu lato complex are currently the most prevalent. The prevalence of certain Colletotrichum species in strawberry fields in specific regions is influenced by the entire agricultural ecosystem, particularly through interconnections with neighboring plants and climate changes. The relative prevalence of different Colletotrichum species varies with geographic region and changes dynamically in certain areas. For example, in Shanghai, C. acutatum was identified before 2005 (Dai et al. 2006) but has not been detected since 2016 (Zhang et al. 2020). Similarly, an early report indicated that strawberry anthracnose caused by C. gloeosporioides was incidental, while C. acutatum was frequently detected (Kikuchi et al. 2010). However, a later study identified C. fructicola as the dominant virulent species on strawberries in Japan (Gan et al. 2017). Such shifts have also occurred in Korea (Nam et al. 2008, 2013). This shift in the prevailing Colletotrichum species associated with strawberries in various regions may be linked to global warming, changes in cultivation patterns—from open fields to protected cultivation or soilless elevated cultivation—and the substitution of strawberry varieties.', 0.3298884630203247]]
Context 9: [['Smith, B.J. and L.L. Black. 1990. Morphological, cultural, and pathogenic variation among Colletotrichum species isolated from strawberry. Plant Dis. 74:69-76.', 0.3250195384025574]]

The population and prevalence of strawberry-virulent Colletotrichum species have not been systematically investigated in major producers such as China. To address these gaps, this review aims to summarize the biodiversity of Colletotrichum species pathogenic to strawberries by examining the global discovery history. Subsequently, the prevalence of Colletotrichum species pathogenic to strawberries in China was analyzed using available data. Finally, we categorized the host range of the two predominant species responsible for strawberry crown rot. This knowledge has important applications for biosecurity risk management (e.g., proper risk estimation in strawberry seedling trade), accurate diagnosis, and anthracnose control. query: How does environmental variation impact the morphological traits of Colletotrichum species?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['In a drastic move, von Arx (1957) reduced the number of recognized Colletotrichum species from several hundred to 11 based on morphological characteristics, with many taxa treated as synonyms of C. gloeosporioides and C. dematium. Several additional species have since been accepted based on morphological criteria (Sutton, 1980; 1992). The difficulties in recognizing Colletotrichum species can be attributed to: 1) the limited and variable morphological characters; 2) an extensive host range and variability in pathogenicity (Bailey and Jeger, 1992; Freeman et al., 2000; Latunde-Dada, 2001; Du et al., 2005; Thaung, 2008); 3) type specimens that are often missing or in poor condition, making them unsuitable for molecular studies; and 4) numerous rDNA ITS sequences of Colletotrichum strains in NCBI that are often misidentified (Crouch et al., 2009d; Damm et al., 2009).', 0.8541168570518494]]
Context 1: [['Despite significant developments over the last ten years, the taxonomy of Colletotrichum is in a state of flux. Many uncertainties exist in the systematics of fungal pathogens from this genus; depending on the taxonomic "guides," the number of species can range from 29 to over 700 (von Arx, 1957; Sutton, 1992). One of the most confusing species is C. gloeosporioides. For example, 594 species of Colletotrichum were reclassified by von Arx as synonyms of C. gloeosporioides. Identification has primarily relied on morphological characteristics of conidia, vegetative and sexual structures, as well as host specificity and cultural characteristics (von Arx, 1957). Unfortunately, conidial morphology and colony characteristics vary even within isolates. Consequently, classical methods have been supplemented with biochemical and molecular technologies to differentiate Colletotrichum species (J. W. Kronstad, ed., Fungal Pathology, 127-148. © 2000 Kluwer Academic Publishers). For a more complete discussion of this topic, see Sherriff et al. (1994).', 0.7524520754814148]]
Context 2: [['Photita, W., Taylor, P. W., Ford, R., Hyde, K. D., and Lumyong, S. (2005). Morphological and molecular characterization of Colletotrichum species from...', 0.47526484727859497]]
Context 3: [['The genus Colletotrichum is considered one of the top ten important genera of fungal pathogens globally (Dean et al., 2012). Colletotrichum is an ancient fungus that has co-evolved with flowering plants. Plant microfossils of Protocolletotrichum preserved on angiosperm leaf cuticles suggest that the diverse pathogenic strategies of Colletotrichum spp. have been established since the Late Cretaceous period (Kar et al., 2004). Different complexes within the genus may have diverged between 4.8 and 32.2 million years ago (MYA) (Bhunjun et al., 2021). The emergence of agricultural cultivation and the intensive disturbance of natural environments have further driven the diversification of Colletotrichum species. These fungi have adapted to thousands of hosts and can be found as endophytes, pathogens, and saprobes (Freeman et al., 1998; Dean et al., 2012; Hirayama et al., 2018; da Silva et al., 2020; Jayawardena et al., 2020). Currently, a total of 257 Colletotrichum species grouped into 15 complexes and 13 additional singletons have been accepted in this genus.', 0.45345020294189453]]

query: Why is chemical fungicide application limited in strawberry fields?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Strawberry anthracnose, caused mainly by the Colletotrichum acutatum species complex, is a significant disease affecting strawberry production. Surveys were conducted, and isolates were collected from affected areas, specifically strawberry nurseries and production fields in six states across the United States. The use of fungicides, particularly quinone outside inhibitors (QoIs), has been widely employed for controlling C. acutatum for the past 20 years. Resistance to QoIs was first reported in Florida in 2013, and subsequent anthracnose outbreaks occurred in strawberry nurseries and production fields throughout the U.S. in 2015. Fungicide use surveys indicated that, in certain locations, the number of QoI applications exceeded the recommended levels for this fungicide group. This situation necessitates immediate changes in anthracnose management strategies to incorporate other chemical and non-chemical approaches, aiming to limit the selection of resistant populations and prevent future outbreaks.', 0.9823761582374573]]
Context 1: [['Past failures of fungicides to control anthracnose epidemics may have stemmed from the development of resistance in the Colletotrichum population. In the early 1970s, benomyl effectively reduced anthracnose crown rot incidence (Horn et al., 1972; Howard, 1971) and was widely used by strawberry growers for years. However, anthracnose pathogens developed resistance to it and other benzimidazole fungicides, rendering benomyl ineffective. In vitro and greenhouse trials have been conducted to identify fungicides to which Colletotrichum pathogens have developed resistance (LaMondia, 1993, 1995; McInnes et al., 1992a, 1992b; Smith and Black, 1991, 1992, 1993). Current fungicide labels address pathogen resistance by restricting the number of consecutive and total applications of a product per season. For instance, the fungicides Abound (azoxystrobin, Syngenta, Greensboro, NC), Cabrio (pyraclostrobin, BASF, Research Triangle Park, NC), and Pristine (pyraclostrobin and boscalid, BASF) are limited to four or five applications per season, with no more than two consecutive applications before alternating with a fungicide that has a different mode of action. Natural products have also been evaluated as alternative fungicides, offering different modes of action, lower toxicity, and increased efficacy (Abril et al., 2008).', 0.9591162204742432]]
Context 2: [['Finally, it is important to emphasize that strawberry production in Brazil remains heavily dependent on fungicide applications, which are not completely effective for anthracnose control and raise consumer concerns about food safety. Our study indicates that managing flower blight can be quite effective through a combination of cultural choices, which could potentially reduce dependency on chemical controls.', 0.9419234395027161]]
Context 3: [['There is an urgent need for multi- and single-site fungicide alternatives effective against anthracnose in strawberry nurseries and production fields. The antifungal antibiotic natamycin, widely used as a natural mold inhibitor in food products, has shown promise in controlling anthracnose root and crown infections caused by C. acutatum on strawberry transplants (Cordova et al. 2017; Haack et al. 2018). Similarly, fluazinam, a single-site respiration inhibitor fungicide from FRAC group 29, has demonstrated significant control of anthracnose fruit rot (Mertely et al. 2018). A request has been submitted through the Interregional Research Project Number 4 for its registration for nursery use only. Reducing the overlap of the same modes of action used during nursery and fruit production phases could help extend the lifespan of single-site fungicides at high risk of resistance.', 0.9111414551734924]]
Context 4: [['Additionally, multisite fungicides such as captan, thiram, and chlorothalonil, which have been available for many decades, remain effective in reducing strawberry anthracnose incidence (Mertely et al. 2018). Chlorothalonil is only registered for nonbearing nurseries when flowers and fruit are absent, yet our surveys indicated that its usage is significantly lower compared to newer single-site fungicides. Due to their efficacy and low resistance risk, multisite fungicides should be the mainstay for disease control in strawberry nurseries. Other non-chemical alternatives, such as heat (Wang et al. 2017) and ultraviolet treatments (Onofre et al. 2017), are currently under investigation and could serve as valuable tools for disease management, reducing the reliance on single-site fungicides.', 0.8939453363418579]]
Context 5: [['Nam, M. H.; Kim, H. S.; Nam, Y. G.; Peres, N. A.; Kim, H. G. (2011). Fungicide spray program to reduce application in anthracnose of strawberry. Research Plant Disease, 17(3), 295-301.', 0.8912181854248047]]
Context 6: [['Wang, N. Y., Turechek, W. W., and Peres, N. A. (2017) explored heat treatment as an alternative to fungicide application for the control of strawberry anthracnose caused by Colletotrichum acutatum, which is noted in the abstract of Phytopathology, volume 107, page S5.50.', 0.8411340713500977]]
Context 7: [['Pavan, W., C.W. Fraisse, and N.A. Peres. 2009. A web-based decision support tool for timing fungicide applications in strawberry. University of Florida Publication AE450, Agricultural and Biological Engineering Department, Florida Cooperative Extension Service, IFAS, University of Florida, Gainesville, FL.', 0.8047853112220764]]
Context 8: [['The experimental fungicide pydiflumetofen was not effective against C. acutatum in our in vitro and field studies. However, this fungicide is very active against B. cinerea and has shown high efficacy in reducing powdery mildew in strawberries (J. E. Adaskaveg, unpublished). The pydiflumetofen-fludioxonil premixture was among the most effective of our preplant dip treatments for crown rot in strawberries, likely due to the fludioxonil component. Therefore, this premixture has potential as a broad-spectrum post-plant field fungicide for strawberries.', 0.7495247721672058]]
Context 9: [['QoI fungicides target the cytochrome b (cytb) gene, inhibiting fungal mitochondrial respiration (Bartlett et al. 2002; Sauter et al. 1999; Ypema and Gold 1999). Azoxystrobin is a QoI fungicide that has been registered for anthracnose control in strawberries for several decades (Mertely et al. 2017a, b). However, the intensive use of such fungicides has led to the emergence of C. acutatum populations resistant to QoIs (Forcelini et al. 2016). Resistance to QoIs was first identified during the 2013 to 2014 strawberry production season in Florida. Resistant C. acutatum isolates exhibited either the F129L or G143A mutations in the cytb gene, which were associated with moderate and complete resistance to QoIs, respectively. During the 2015 to 2016 strawberry season, anthracnose outbreaks were reported in strawberry nurseries and production fields across the United States.', 0.7344064712524414]]

query: How does climate change impact the epidemiology of fungal diseases like anthracnose in strawberries?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Anthracnose is an important disease of strawberry caused by Colletotrichum spp., which affects foliage, runners, crowns, and fruits (Howard et al., 1992). Three primary fungal pathogens—C. acutatum sensu lato, C. gloeosporioides sensu lato, and C. fragariae—are known to cause anthracnose disease in strawberries (Freeman and Katan, 1997). The crown rot syndrome is characteristic of infections from C. gloeosporioides sensu lato and C. fragariae, while fruit rot is mainly attributed to C. acutatum sensu lato, leading to significant yield losses (Howard et al., 1992). Currently, numerous species are classified under what is now known as the C. acutatum complex, with six species—C. acutatum sensu stricto, C. fioriniae, C. godetiae, C. nymphaeae, C. salicis, and C. simmondsii—identified as associated with strawberry anthracnose worldwide (Damm et al., 2012). Among these, C. nymphaeae is the most prevalent pathogen causing strawberry anthracnose globally, including in Iran (Baroncelli et al., 2015; Karimi et al., 2017; Wang et al., 2019). Currently, no effective chemical control methods exist for managing strawberry anthracnose; available options are limited to preventive treatments applied before fruit production (Denoyes-Rothan et al., 1999). Additionally, concerns about the toxic effects of chemical fungicides on the environment and the development of resistance in fungal strains highlight the need for alternative control strategies. Consequently, utilizing resistant cultivars appears to be the most efficient and practical approach for suppressing anthracnose development. In light of recent anthracnose outbreaks in strawberry fields in the Kurdistan province of Iran (Karimi et al., 2017), and the necessity for appropriate strategies to address this issue, the aim of this study was to evaluate the resistance of several commercial strawberry cultivars to the anthracnose fruit rot caused by C. nymphaeae under in vivo and greenhouse conditions.', 0.6689209342002869]]
Context 1: [['Smith, B.J. 2007. Developmental stage and temperature affect strawberry flower and fruit susceptibility to anthracnose, p. 55–57. In: F. Takeda, D.T. Handley, and E.B. Poling (eds.). Proc. 2007 North American Strawberry Symposium. North American Strawberry Growers Association, Kemptville, ON, Canada.', 0.4275926649570465]]
Context 2: [['So far, anthracnose epidemics have affected strawberry nurseries and production fields worldwide. Reports on Colletotrichum spp. associated with strawberries, curated from literature in PubMed and Clarivate combined with fungal database searches (Farr and Rossman, 2022), were compiled to understand the global diversity and occurrence of the causal agents of strawberry anthracnose. From our findings, since 1931 until July 9, 2022, there have been over 220 citations and 310 records related to the identification of causal agents of strawberry anthracnose at the genus level of Colletotrichum in 36 countries across six continents, with 282 records providing pathogen identification at the species or species complex level.', 0.3969574570655823]]
Context 3: [['Howard CM, Albregts EE. Anthracnose. In: Compendium of Strawberry Diseases. American Phytopathological Society: Paul St, ed. Maas JL, USA; 1984. pp. 85-87.', 0.3467918038368225]]

Context 7: [['Smith, B. J. 1998. Anthracnose leaf spot, irregular spot, anthracnose fruit rot (black spot), and anthracnose crown rot. In: Compendium of Strawberry Diseases. J. L. Mass, ed. American Phytopathological Society, St. Paul, MN. Pages 24-25, 31-33, and 46-48.', 0.2579622268676758]]
Context 8: [['Strawberries (Fragaria×ananassa Duch.) are a widely cultivated hybrid species within the Rosaceae family, renowned for their fruit. They are increasingly significant for the agricultural economic development of countries like Iran, particularly in the Kurdistan province, which leads in strawberry production, predominantly under open-field conditions (Tehranifar and Sarsaefi, 2002). Various biotic and abiotic factors contribute to the decline in strawberry production globally. Notably, over 100 fungal species can invade strawberry plants, with approximately one-third causing serious diseases on different plant parts (Martin and others).', 0.25145936012268066]]

query: How might the discovery of Colletotrichum cradwickii on T. cacao branches in Jamaica influence research into fungal pathogens in cacao cultivation globally?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Colletotrichum cradwickii, described from branches of T. cacao in Jamaica, produces hyaline (red in mass), elongate conidia that are constricted in the middle, measuring 14–17 × 5 µm. It also has straight, rigid, acute setae that are 2–3-septate, purplish, and measure 70–100 × 4–6 µm (Saccardo & Trotter 1913). Colletotrichum luxificum was collected from branches, buds, and fruits of T. cacao in Surinam and Demerara (now Guyana). It forms ovoid-oblong conidia, sometimes slightly constricted in the center, both sides rounded, smooth, measuring 13–19 × 4–5 µm. Setae formed are described as 2–4-septate, measuring 50–120 × 3.5–4.5 µm (Saccardo & Trotter 1913). Despite some size discrepancies, the constriction of the conidia and formation of setae for these two species are reminiscent of those in the C. gloeosporioides complex.', 0.9127196073532104]]
Context 1: [['Additionally, further Colletotrichum species have been described from T. cacao, including C. brachytrichum, found on leaves of T. cacao in Trinidad. This species has conidia that are ovoid-cylindrical with an attenuated base and a round apex, measuring 10–13.5 × 3–3.7 µm. It produces sparse setae that are dark brown, aseptate, slightly flexuous, and measure 40 × 3.5 µm, as well as conidiogenous cells measuring 4 × 2 µm (Saccardo 1906). In contrast, C. sloanei forms larger conidia, averaging 14.4 × 3.7 µm on SNA and 13.4 × 3.9 µm on Anthriscus stem. No setae were found in cultures of C. sloanei (though these may only form on host material), and its conidiogenous cells are much longer than those of C. brachytrichum.', 0.22875753045082092]]
Context 2: [['Mejía LC, Enith I, Rojas EI, Maynard Z, Van Bael S, Arnold AE, Hebbar P, Samuels GJ, Robbins N, Herre EA (2008). Endophytic fungi as biocontrol agents of Theobroma cacao pathogens. Biological Control 46: 4–14.', 0.15376806259155273]]

Mycologia 102: 1318–1338.', 0.12791751325130463]]
Context 4: [['C. ignotum, C. theobromicola, and C. tropicale were identified as endophytes of T. cacao by Rojas et al. (2010). Context 6: [['Etymology: Named in honor of J.M. Waller, a distinguished tropical pathologist and a key contributor to the understanding of the most significant Colletotrichum pathogen of coffee.', 0.09326869249343872]]
Context 7: [['Colletotrichum theobromae forms oblong, straight conidia with obtuse ends, measuring 9–12 × 3–5 µm, and dark-brown, pluriseptate, acute setae measuring 60–75 × 3 µm (Saccardo 1906). It was found on fruits of T. cacao in Cameroon and does not align with the characteristics of C. sloanei. Gloeosporium theobromicola (as "theobromicolum"), found on fruits of T. cacao in Brazil, forms hyaline, fusoid conidia measuring 6–9 × 2–2.5 µm (Saccardo et al. 1931). These conidia are considerably smaller than those of C. sloanei and may not belong to the genus Colletotrichum.', 0.08846327662467957]]
Context 8: [['Etymology: This species is named in honor of Sir Hans Sloane (1660–1753), a physician and prominent natural history collector. His specimens significantly contributed to the original collections of the Natural History Museum in London. His Jamaican material of the host plant became Linnaeus’s type for Theobroma cacao, and his recipe for a milk chocolate drink was commercialized by the Cadbury brothers (Natural History Museum, 2011).', 0.0868617594242096]]

query: How does plant density affect disease spread?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Even directly adjacent to the source, density effects are uncertain. As noted previously, while increasing density might lead to more units becoming infected, the rising total number of units could result in a constant or even decreasing proportion of diseased units. There is clear evidence from certain systems that the dispersal of spores or other microscopic particles, such as pollen, diminishes as plant density increases. Interestingly, recent studies showing no correlation between plant density and disease in natural systems have focused on heteroecious rusts, which do not have secondary spread. Therefore, any observed effects would likely be due to altered dispersal dynamics associated with increased density or changes in environmental conditions.', 0.9101009368896484]]
Context 1: [['The effects of plant density treatment (Ti; i = 1 [highest density], 2, 3, or 4 [lowest density]), row side (Sj; j = 1 [near] or 2 [far]), distance from the inoculum source (d; a continuous variable), and their interactions on fruit disease incidence (y; ranging from 0 to 1) were determined using a generalized linear model (GLM) with the GLIM program. Treatment and row side were treated as categorical (or class) variables, with four levels for treatment and two levels for row side, rather than as continuous variables. This approach was deemed more appropriate since increasing plant density affects more than just leaf area or the number of leaves (or fruit) per unit area of crop row.', 0.8530097007751465]]
Context 2: [['The treatment of plant density was significant (P ≤ 0.01) at each assessment time, indicating that it affected disease incidence (see Table 1). An analysis of the Ti deviance into orthogonal components revealed a nonlinear change in disease incidence (P ≤ 0.01) with plant density at three out of four assessment times. This nonlinear effect is evidenced by the low and approximately equal mean values of y for the two higher densities (e.g., y ≈ 0.19 for the third assessment) and the higher mean values of y for the two lower densities (e.g., y ≈ 0.41 for the third assessment) (refer to Fig. 2).', 0.848913311958313]]
Context 3: [['Plant density also affected dispersal in the field, and there was a nonlinear change in disease incidence (y) with plant density (Madden and Boudreau, unpublished; Table 2), which aligns with the rain simulator results (Boudreau & Madden, 1995). Although y generally decreased with increasing density, the highest y was associated with an intermediate plant density (Table 2). The distance at which v declined to 0.10 (jt₁₀), an inverse measure of gradient steepness, generally decreased with increasing crop density. For example, in 1992, x₀ was approximately 2 m with the lowest density and 1.6 m with the highest density. A stronger indication of plant density effects is the higher mean disease incidence on the near side (closest to the inoculum) than on the far side of plant rows at the same distance from the inoculum source (example in Fig. 5).', 0.825630784034729]]
Context 4: [['The role of host density in disease dynamics is poorly understood, yet it may be crucial in regulating spatial and temporal aspects of epidemics in both natural and agricultural ecosystems. In unmanaged or minimally managed communities, density-dependent plant mortality mediated by pathogen activity has been suggested in some studies. However, confounding variables in these systems have hindered a clear demonstration of a causal relationship between density and disease.', 0.7574617862701416]]
Context 5: [['Burdon, J. J., and Chilvers, G. A. 1982. Host density as a factor in plant disease ecology. Annu. Rev. Phytopathol. 20:143-166.', 0.5945850014686584]]
Context 6: [['Burdon and Chilvers reviewed studies involving over 40 host-pathogen combinations, with the majority (62%) indicating positive correlations between plant density and disease intensity. Nevertheless, some pathosystems have shown negative correlations, inconsistent results, or a lack of relationship between plant density and disease intensity. Differences in disease cycles, assessment techniques, and the occurrence of complicating variables (e.g., changes in host patterns as density changes) complicate comparisons among these studies.', 0.5090715885162354]]
Context 7: [['Furthermore, the plant density treatment influenced the steepness of the disease gradients, as shown by the significant interaction between Ti and d (i.e., [bT]id; P ≤ 0.05). However, this effect was also nonlinear. For example, Figure 3 illustrates the different slopes for treatment 1 (3A) and treatment 4 (3B) on the same row side. Additionally, the interaction between Sj and Ti indicated that the influence of row side varied across plant density treatments. Specifically, during the first assessment, the near row side exhibited a higher y value than the far row side, except for the third treatment, where both sides had nearly identical disease incidence (Fig. 2). Notably, a significant three-way interaction was present only at the first assessment time.', 0.36765530705451965]]
Context 8: [['In 1992, the mean disease incidence was low and similar for the two highest plant density treatments, while it was high and comparable for the two lower densities. By 1993, the mean disease incidence at the highest density (treatment 1) remained low but reached its maximum at the next to lowest density (treatment 3). Notably, d10 reached its largest value at this same plant density (treatment 3). Unlike the rain simulation studies, this field investigation focused on disease development rather than solely on spore dispersal. Nonetheless, we suspect that variations in dispersal significantly contribute to the observed effects.', 0.2803995907306671]]
Context 9: [['The epidemiological models of Anderson and May, which emphasize animal systems, suggest that increasing host density will enhance the likelihood of contact between an infectious unit (e.g., spores in transport or spores on a lesion) and a healthy unit (e.g., leaf or fruit), thereby increasing the rates of disease development. This forms part of the intuitive basis for speculating that disease incidence will rise with host density, which assigns pathogen dispersal a primary role in the system. However, with a few exceptions, there is limited empirical evaluation of density effects on pathogen dispersal.', 0.22441229224205017]]

query: What are the primary mechanisms that allow Colletotrichum acutatum and C. fragariae to resist copper and benomyl, and how might these mechanisms evolve over time?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Pedroso, C., Café-Filho, A.C. 2005. In vitro reaction of Brazilian isolates of Colletotrichum acutatum and C. fragariae to copper and benomyl. Fungicide & Nematocide Tests. 60: SMF042. www.apsnet.org/online/FNtests/ (electronic publication).', 0.969167947769165]]
Context 1: [['LaMondia, J.A. (1995). Inhibition of growth in vitro of Colletotrichum acutatum and C. fragariae by benomyl and strawberry fruit infection by benomyl-resistant isolates of Colletotrichum acutatum. Advances in Strawberry Research, 14, 25–30.', 0.874723494052887]]
Context 2: [['LaMondia, J.A. 1995. Inhibition of growth in vitro of Colletotrichum acutatum and C. fragariae, and strawberry fruit infection by benomyl-resistant isolates of Colletotrichum acutatum. Adv. Strawberry Res. 14:25–30.', 0.833729088306427]]
Context 3: [['Colletotrichum gloeosporioides and C. acutatum are common causal agents of anthracnose in various fruits (Adaskaveg and Hartin 1997; Bernstein et al. 1995; Kim and Hong 2008; Phoulivong et al. 2010). Bernstein et al. (1995) identified most isolates collected from peaches in South Carolina as C. acutatum, with only one out of 19 being C. gloeosporioides. This sharply contrasts with our findings, as we only identified two C. acutatum isolates from the locations sampled (data not shown). This discrepancy may stem from our small sample size; however, a more plausible explanation is the inherent differences in fungicide sensitivity between C. acutatum and C. gloeosporioides. Bernstein et al. (1995) found that C. acutatum strains were more resistant to benzimidazole fungicides (also known as MBC). The relative growth of C. acutatum isolates ranged from 17% to 47% at a discriminatory dose of 2 mg/ml benomyl, while none of the C. gloeosporioides isolates from peaches grew at that dose. MBC fungicides were more commonly used at the time of the Bernstein study for controlling various fruit diseases, which may have given C. acutatum a selective advantage. However, over the past two to three decades, MBC fungicides have gradually been replaced by new site-specific fungicides for disease management due to concerns over benzimidazole resistance in the major target pathogen, Monilinia fructicola (Zehr et al. 1991).', 0.7489690780639648]]
Context 4: [['Nakaune R, Nakano M (2007). Benomyl resistance of Colletotrichum acutatum is caused by enhanced expression of the beta-tubulin 1 gene regulated by putative leucine zipper protein CaBEN1. Fungal Genetics and Biology 44: 1324–1335.', 0.6114164590835571]]
Context 5: [['Tanaka, M.A.S., Passos, F.A. 2002. Pathogenic characterization of Colletotrichum acutatum and C. fragariae associated with anthracnose in strawberries. Fitopatologia Brasileira. 27:484–488.', 0.2865905165672302]]
Context 6: [['Maltoni, M. L., Mazzara, M., and Mezzetti, B. 1995. Aspetti patologici, fisiologici e genetici della resistenza a Colletotrichum acutatum e Phytophthora cactorum della fragola. Frutticoltura 7-8:59-66.', 0.25577929615974426]]
Context 7: [['Colletotrichum acutatum is particularly significant in Europe, where it is subject to statutory quarantine requirements. Symptoms manifest on various parts of the plant, especially on stolons, flowers, and fruits. Currently, there are no effective chemical control methods available. Cultural techniques, such as drip irrigation and cultivation under plastic tunnels, significantly limit the dispersal of inoculum, thereby reducing fruit losses. Utilizing pathogen-free plants produced through certification schemes can provide a level of disease control; however, latent infections in apparently healthy plants can still lead to anthracnose losses in production fields. Thus, developing strawberry cultivars resistant to C. acutatum is a promising approach for managing anthracnose, offering an economical and environmentally friendly solution. Screening methods evaluating the overall plant reaction have identified accessions resistant to C. acutatum within F. × ananassa. Previous studies on the inheritance of anthracnose resistance have described various modes of resistance. Research by Denoyes and Baudry has suggested that resistance to C. acutatum may exhibit different inheritance modes, depending on the pathogenicity group of the isolate and the resistance level.', 0.244398295879364]]
Context 8: [['Additional Index Words: Colletotrichum acutatum, C. fragariae, C. gloeosporioides, Fragaria × ananassa, disease control, fungicides.', 0.23144446313381195]]
Context 9: [['Leandro, L.F.S.; Gleason, M.L.; Wegulo, S.N.; Nutter, F.W. 2002. Supervivencia y esporulación de Colletotrichum acutatum en hojas de fresa asintomáticas. Acta Horticulturae 567:627-629.', 0.1851550042629242]]

query: How is crop rotation used to maintain soil health in strawberry farms?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['The combined effects of rotation crops and nitrogen fertilizers were examined on the strawberry black root rot disease complex. In July 1995, microplots were filled with soil that had a history of strawberry black root rot and seeded with two types of oats (Avena strigosa ‘Saia oats’ or A. sativa ‘Garry oats’) or with sorgho-sudangrass (Sorghum bicolor × S. sudanense ‘Triple S’). Microplots planted with 1-year-old ‘Honeoye’ strawberry crowns served as controls. In May 1996, the crops were chopped and incorporated into the soil. The soil was then replanted with 1-year-old ‘Honeoye’ strawberry crowns and fertilized with (NH4)2SO4 or Ca(NO3)2 at equivalent nitrogen rates. Two months later, (NH4)2SO4-treated plants exhibited 36% more leaf area and 41% more runners than strawberries treated with Ca(NO3)2. Strawberries that had been precropped with ‘Saia’ oats produced 135% more runners and 38% more early fruit yield compared to those grown in control microplots. Total fruit yield was not affected by the treatments.', 0.3320939540863037]]

query: Can strawberries get better if they catch a disease?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Strawberry anthracnose can affect plants at any lifecycle stage, but plants are particularly susceptible at the seedling stage and immediately after planting (Wang et al. 2008). The disease primarily affects strawberry roots, petioles, and stolons, but can also infect flowers and fruit, leading to severe outbreaks (Mertely and Legard 2004). Symptoms include irregular ulcer-like lesions, reddish-brown stolons during initial stolon development, black spindle-shaped lesions on leaves and petioles, wilting, and dead roots (Debode et al. 2009; Freeman and Katan 1997). In Zhejiang, nearly 50% of seedling deaths and over 40% of production losses in nurseries are attributed to this disease (Xie et al. 2010). If environmental conditions are favorable, anthracnose can reduce strawberry yield by up to 80%. Transplants are considered the main source of primary inoculum, but the complete epidemiology of Colletotrichum spp. on strawberries in China remains unclear.', 0.5254901051521301]]
Context 1: [['Strawberry (Fragaria × ananassa) is a major crop cultivated in China (Xie et al. 2010). The production of strawberries has rapidly expanded in recent years, positioning China as one of the world’s largest producers and exporters. As of 2013, strawberry cultivation covered 100.5 × 10^3 hectares, yielding 2.8 million tonnes (The Ministry of Agriculture of the People’s Republic of China 2014). However, with increased production, many fungal diseases have emerged as significant challenges, negatively impacting fruit yield and quality (Mass 1998, Smith 2008). Among these, anthracnose, caused by species of Colletotrichum, is one of the most critical diseases affecting strawberries.', 0.31972354650497437]]
Context 2: [['Strawberries (Fragaria×ananassa Duch.) are a widely cultivated hybrid species within the Rosaceae family, renowned for their fruit. They are increasingly significant for the agricultural economic development of countries like Iran, particularly in the Kurdistan province, which leads in strawberry production, predominantly under open-field conditions (Tehranifar and Sarsaefi, 2002). Various biotic and abiotic factors contribute to the decline in strawberry production globally. Notably, over 100 fungal species can invade strawberry plants, with approximately one-third causing serious diseases on different plant parts (Martin and others).', 0.313710480928421]]

query: What is the significance of trade in the introduction of C. acutatum into the UK?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['The first record of C. acutatum s.l. in the UK was in 1978, found on Anemone sp. grown in Jersey. In 1982, the first incidence of anthracnose disease in strawberries caused by C. acutatum s.l. was recorded in the UK, attributed to the importation of infected strawberry runners from the USA. DNA sequences in public databases suggest that two UK isolates (CBS198.35 and CBS199.35), collected in 1935 from Phormium spp. (New Zealand flax), belong to C. acutatum s.l. CABI database records from 1978 to 1983 show the incidence of the pathogen on various hosts and in different UK locations. However, it seems improbable that the initial outbreak on strawberries led to widespread dispersal of the pathogen. In 1993, Lovelidge proposed that continued introduction of infected strawberry material from abroad made the disease likely to become endemic in the UK. Subsequent years saw further outbreaks on strawberries linked to the importation of infected propagation material, mainly from mainland Europe, as well as on other important crop hosts.', 0.857723593711853]]
Context 1: [['Clonal isolates were analyzed to confirm or reject the hypothesis of host specialization of CA-clonal isolates on strawberry. Sreenivasaprasad et al. (26) suggested that European isolates of C. acutatum infecting strawberry are distinct from U.S. C. acutatum isolates found in a variety of hosts. In this study, no correlation was found between the genetic grouping and geographical origin of C. acutatum isolates from strawberry. This may be attributed to the large number of C. acutatum isolates from strawberry analyzed in our work. The absence of correlation between genetic grouping and geographical origin suggests that the pathogen may have recently spread worldwide from one or a few sources of origin. Since significant numbers of everbearing strawberry plants were imported from the southwestern United States in the early 1980s (5), the introduction of C. acutatum into Europe may have occurred through contamination of traded plant material. This hypothesis is further supported by the occurrence of North American and European isolates from strawberry that exhibit identical RAPD patterns and ITS sequence data within both subgroups, CA-clonal and CA-variable. Furthermore, C. acutatum on strawberry is prevalent in Europe and various parts of the United States, including California. Freeman and Katan (7) also observed identical RAPD patterns in pathogen isolates from both countries, suggesting that C. acutatum was introduced from the United States into Israel.', 0.6571211814880371]]
Context 2: [['Colletotrichum acutatum s.l. was first described as a strawberry pathogen in California in 1983 and has since spread worldwide, including the UK, through runners and propagating material. An extensive genetic characterization of C. acutatum s.l., representing the global diversity of the pathogen, led to its subdivision into genetic groups named A1 to A9. More recently, C. acutatum s.l. has been subdivided into over 30 species based on multilocus phylogeny.', 0.6549201607704163]]
Context 3: [['The results from this study, along with previous research, may explain the increasing significance of C. acutatum in northern regions (15, 20). Once introduced in an area, C. acutatum could possess distinct advantages over other strawberry-infecting species of Colletotrichum at cooler temperatures, which are typical for northern climates. Two of these advantages include a shorter latent period for C. acutatum and a greater production of spores at lower temperatures.', 0.6381768584251404]]
Context 4: [['Dyko, B. J., and Mordue, J. E. M. (1979). CMI descriptions of pathogenic fungi and bacteria. No. 630, Colletotrichum acutatum. Commonwealth Mycological Institute, Kew, Surrey, England.', 0.198379248380661]]
Context 5: [['Thirty-four Colletotrichum acutatum sensu lato (s.l.) isolates were selected for pathogenicity tests on fruits and plants. This included six representative isolates from each of the three species associated with strawberry production in the UK (highlighted in Table 1 and in bold in Fig. 1) and one or more isolates representative of all the major species in the C. acutatum complex. Four C. gloeosporioides s.l. isolates, obtained from strawberry-infected tissues in the UK (CSL 780 and CSL 869, C. aenigma) and the USA (CSL 311 and CSL 386, C. fruticola), were included as an out-group.', 0.1551271229982376]]
Context 6: [['INTRODUCTION: As a significant pathogen, C. acutatum has been treated as a regulated organism for many years.', 0.13470953702926636]]
Context 7: [['Morphology of C. acutatum. C. acutatum is an Ascomycete classified in the Pyrenomycetes and included in the family Phyllachoraceae. Colonies of C. acutatum are usually white initially but later become covered with pink to orange conidial masses. Cultures from certain hosts are highly chromogenic and excrete red and pink pigments into the culture media. The primary production of conidia occurs in acervuli; however, C. acutatum can also form secondary conidia on the surfaces of living leaves. Conidia are typically ellipsoid and fusiform at least at one end, differing from C. gloeosporioides, which generally has both ends rounded. Setae are usually sparse or not produced at all. Pigmented appressoria form upon germination of the conidia and vary in shape and size.', 0.1264755129814148]]
Context 8: [['The C. acutatum species complex has undergone speciation more prolifically than previously suspected, indicating that it is likely still evolving rapidly. The emergence of new species is likely encouraged by modern global agricultural practices, which facilitate the mixing of gene pools, combined with imperfect phytosanitary regulations.', 0.10946471244096756]]
Context 9: [['Abstract: Colletotrichum acutatum is recognized as a significant anthracnose pathogen affecting a broad range of host plants globally. Numerous studies have reported subgroups within the C. acutatum species complex. A multilocus molecular phylogenetic analysis (ITS, ACT, TUB2, CHS-1, GAPDH, HIS3) involving 331 strains previously identified as C. acutatum and related taxa—spanning various hosts across diverse geographic regions—confirmed the previously recognized molecular groups and identified several novel taxa. Thirty-one species are accepted, of which 21 have not been previously recognized. Colletotrichum orchidophilum clusters basal to the C. acutatum species complex. This complex exhibits high phenotypic diversity, with some species showing preferences for specific hosts or geographic regions, while others are plurivorous and found in multiple areas. In this study, only C. salicis and C. rhombiforme formed sexual morphs in culture; however, sexual morphs have been documented from other taxa, particularly in laboratory crosses, with evidence of hybridization between different species. A new species, C. pseudoacutatum, was also described, resembling C. acutatum but not belonging to its species complex.', 0.10648158192634583]]

query: How can integrated pest management (IPM) strategies be adapted to control anthracnose in strawberries?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Anthracnose is an important disease of strawberry caused by Colletotrichum spp., which affects foliage, runners, crowns, and fruits (Howard et al., 1992). Three primary fungal pathogens—C. acutatum sensu lato, C. gloeosporioides sensu lato, and C. fragariae—are known to cause anthracnose disease in strawberries (Freeman and Katan, 1997). The crown rot syndrome is characteristic of infections from C. gloeosporioides sensu lato and C. fragariae, while fruit rot is mainly attributed to C. acutatum sensu lato, leading to significant yield losses (Howard et al., 1992). Currently, numerous species are classified under what is now known as the C. acutatum complex, with six species—C. acutatum sensu stricto, C. fioriniae, C. godetiae, C. nymphaeae, C. salicis, and C. simmondsii—identified as associated with strawberry anthracnose worldwide (Damm et al., 2012). Among these, C. nymphaeae is the most prevalent pathogen causing strawberry anthracnose globally, including in Iran (Baroncelli et al., 2015; Karimi et al., 2017; Wang et al., 2019). Currently, no effective chemical control methods exist for managing strawberry anthracnose; available options are limited to preventive treatments applied before fruit production (Denoyes-Rothan et al., 1999). Additionally, concerns about the toxic effects of chemical fungicides on the environment and the development of resistance in fungal strains highlight the need for alternative control strategies. Consequently, utilizing resistant cultivars appears to be the most efficient and practical approach for suppressing anthracnose development. In light of recent anthracnose outbreaks in strawberry fields in the Kurdistan province of Iran (Karimi et al., 2017), and the necessity for appropriate strategies to address this issue, the aim of this study was to evaluate the resistance of several commercial strawberry cultivars to the anthracnose fruit rot caused by C. nymphaeae under in vivo and greenhouse conditions.', 0.8355491757392883]]

query: How does C. acutatum spread in agricultural environments?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Colletotrichum acutatum J.H. Simmonds is a common pathogen affecting a wide range of crops and non-cultivated plant species. The fungus is cosmopolitan and causes significant crop losses annually. Symptoms of the disease can include fruit rots, as well as shoot, leaf, and flower blights. Common hosts encompass many dicotyledonous plants, including strawberries, apples, citrus, and stone fruits; serious diseases have also been reported on leatherleaf ferns and pines. Notably, there are no known reports of C. acutatum affecting grasses. While well-documented from agricultural hosts, recent findings of C. acutatum in a moribund sea turtle and a native forest suggest it may inhabit other less-studied niches.', 0.9509510397911072]]
Context 1: [['The role of alternative hosts in the disease cycles caused by C. acutatum is also not well understood. The fungus can infect both anemones and strawberries, suggesting potential spread between these crops. Research has shown that C. acutatum is capable of colonizing surrounding weeds, such as Vicia spp. and Conyza spp., and can survive for three months on the leaves of tomatoes, peppers, and eggplants. This indicates that the pathogen could spread from strawberries to adjacent weeds and then reinfest new strawberry fields in subsequent years. Molecular and vegetative compatibility studies have indicated that isolates from weeds, anemones, and strawberries form a single population in Israel. Further studies demonstrated that while C. acutatum initially fails to penetrate the tissues of peppers, eggplants, and tomatoes, intercellular penetration occurs later, suggesting the fungus may live as an endophyte on these hosts.', 0.9485364556312561]]
Context 2: [['Members of the C. acutatum species complex have been well-documented from agricultural and natural hosts worldwide (Perfect et al., 1999; Peres et al., 2005; Sreenivasaprasad and Talhinhas, 2005). The scientific community has long studied the biomolecular processes regulating this lifestyle, especially those related to the switch from biotrophy to necrotrophy. The species complex has a very wide host range. Meta-analyses have revealed that C. acutatum s.l. strains are associated with infections in hundreds of species from over 90 genera of plants (Magnoliophyta: monocotyledons and dicotyledons, Pinophyta, and Pteridophyta), along with at least two insect species (Dufresne et al., 2000; Thon et al., 2002; Wharton and Diéguez-Uribeondo, 2004; O’Connell et al., 2012; Marcelino et al., 2008; Mascarin et al., 2016). In a few cases, associations have been noted with marine ecosystems (Manire et al., 2002; Namikoshi et al., 2002). There appears to be little to no evidence of co-evolution between host and pathogen, particularly in cultivated fruit systems like strawberry and olive, which are susceptible to many members of this species complex (Jayawardena et al., 2016).', 0.9134120345115662]]
Context 3: [['Colletotrichum acutatum s.l. was first described as a strawberry pathogen in California in 1983 and has since spread worldwide, including the UK, through runners and propagating material. An extensive genetic characterization of C. acutatum s.l., representing the global diversity of the pathogen, led to its subdivision into genetic groups named A1 to A9. More recently, C. acutatum s.l. has been subdivided into over 30 species based on multilocus phylogeny.', 0.8345396518707275]]
Context 4: [['Although C. acutatum survives in soil, on plant debris, and in fumigated field soil, it is assumed that the main source of inoculum usually originates from infected strawberry plant material from the nursery. However, in nurseries or production fields, the pathogen may be introduced through contaminated soil, on field equipment, or may be splash-dispersed or blown in from surrounding vegetation that may carry the fungus without visible symptoms. This work has shown that C. acutatum from strawberries can survive and colonize many other plant species under controlled greenhouse conditions without causing disease, exhibiting epiphytic, endophytic, and non-pathogenic lifestyles. These findings emphasize that various crop plants, including weeds, may serve as potential inoculum sources of C. acutatum. Further investigation is needed to understand the contribution of inoculum from such plants to the development of anthracnose disease in strawberries under field conditions and in the dispersal of the pathogen from season to season.', 0.7526315450668335]]
Context 5: [['Alternative lifestyles? Most reports of the natural recovery of C. acutatum have come from agricultural hosts. However, recent findings suggest that C. acutatum may inhabit a variety of unexplored niches. For instance, it has been isolated from an immunocompromised sea turtle. Additionally, a single isolate was found colonizing the leaves of a tree species in a native forest. Whether these isolates originated from agricultural ecosystems or represent a new source of pathogens remains largely unexamined.', 0.7373754978179932]]
Context 6: [['In strawberries, C. acutatum is typically introduced into production fields from nurseries. While some plants may exhibit symptoms, often the pathogen is introduced through asymptomatic leaves or petioles, likely as appressoria or quiescent infections. It remains unclear whether quiescent infections develop into lesions or if appressoria germinate to produce conidia. However, conidia of C. acutatum can generate several secondary conidia from each deposited conidium on the leaf surface. This suggests that the fungus is reproducing by utilizing nutrients on the leaf surface rather than relying on reserves from the original conidium. In these instances, it appears that the fungus is growing as an epiphyte rather than producing quiescent infections.', 0.6560254693031311]]
Context 7: [['C. acutatum was isolated from two weeds, Conyza spp. and Vicia spp., that infested strawberry fields. The weed isolates were similar to those from strawberry, as demonstrated by PCR analysis, and caused typical anthracnose symptoms on strawberry. Thus, not only crop plants but also weeds may be colonized by C. acutatum. This aligns with the detection of C. fragariae, pathogenic to strawberry, on weeds such as chickweed, coffeeweed, sicklepod, fiddleneck, and vetch, growing in containers and around nurseries in Florida. Similarly, strawberry and anemone cultivated in close proximity in Israel were found to be infected by an identical genotype of C. acutatum.', 0.46848350763320923]]
Context 8: [['Considerable progress has been made in recent years in delineating anthracnose diseases and their causal agents. Molecular tools have effectively distinguished Colletotrichum species, clearly separating C. acutatum from C. gloeosporioides and identifying genetically distinct subgroups within C. acutatum. Nonetheless, the disease cycles of C. acutatum in many host-pathogen systems remain poorly understood, even in economically important crops. This pathogen can reproduce on various tissue types across different hosts and can exist as a necrotroph, biotroph, endophyte, or epiphyte, depending on the plant species and tissue involved. The tissues affected are very specific for each host combination, and the pathogen develops a highly specialized relationship at the cellular level that is evident in the disease cycle for each host. Further investigation is needed into the biotrophic and epiphytic phases of the pathogen and the means by which C. acutatum reproduces in the absence of pathogenesis. The tissue specificity and life cycles of C. acutatum are likely under genetic control, and it may be possible to induce mutants that are no longer pathogenic to certain hosts or tissues, thereby elucidating the genetic basis for tissue or host specificity, as seen in other Colletotrichum species.', 0.4501304626464844]]
Context 9: [['The C. acutatum species complex has undergone speciation more prolifically than previously suspected, indicating that it is likely still evolving rapidly. The emergence of new species is likely encouraged by modern global agricultural practices, which facilitate the mixing of gene pools, combined with imperfect phytosanitary regulations.', 0.44184255599975586]]
