query: How do different Colletotrichum species contribute to the overall impact of anthracnose diseases?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [["Three species have been documented as causal agents of strawberry anthracnose: Colletotrichum gloeosporioides, C. fragariae, and C. acutatum (Denoyes-Rothan et al. 2003). The anthracnose disease caused by Colletotrichum spp. impacts a wide variety of woody and herbaceous plants, particularly tropical and subtropical crops and fruit trees (Cannon et al. 2012; Freeman et al. 1998; Hyde et al. 2009; Sutton 1992; Wikee et al. 2011). The genus has recently been recognized as the world's eighth most important group of plant-pathogenic fungi due to its scientific and economic significance (Dean et al. 2012). However, the identification of Colletotrichum spp. has historically been challenging. Single-gene phylogenetic analyses have often failed to accurately delineate species (Hyde et al. 2009). Ko Ko et al. (2011) emphasized the need to resurvey plant pathogens like Colletotrichum spp. using molecular methods, as previous morphological and internal transcribed spacer data are likely to be incorrect. Understanding of Colletotrichum spp. has significantly advanced through these molecular approaches.", 0.9933086633682251]]
Context 1: [['Abstract: In tropical fruit crops, anthracnose is primarily caused by species of the fungal genus Colletotrichum. These phytopathogens can infect various parts of the fruit crops; however, infections occurring during postharvest or ripening stages lead to significant economic losses. The disease manifests as black to dark brown sunken lesions on the fruit surface, which diminishes fruit quality and marketability. Common tropical fruit crops susceptible to anthracnose include mango, papaya, banana, avocado, guava, and dragon fruit, all of which are economically important in many developing countries. It is essential to note that newly identified Colletotrichum species associated with fruit anthracnose can infect multiple hosts, though some species may exhibit host specificity. Utilizing multiple markers, many phylogenetic species of Colletotrichum have been recognized as anthracnose-causing pathogens. Given that effective disease management strategies depend on a comprehensive understanding of the causative agents, up-to-date information regarding Colletotrichum species and the risks posed by newly identified species in tropical fruit plantations and harvested fruits is crucial. Furthermore, these newly recorded species may be significant for biosecurity and should be classified as quarantine pathogens, particularly as tropical fruits are traded globally.', 0.9914880990982056]]
Context 2: [['Many species belonging to the genus Colletotrichum are associated with plant diseases, commonly referred to as anthracnose. Colletotrichum spp. can affect a wide range of hosts, and these pathogens are characterized by global distribution. Virtually every cultivated botanical family is susceptible to one or more species of Colletotrichum, making it one of the most studied plant pathogenic fungi (Prusky et al., 2000; Latunde-Dada, 2001; Dean et al., 2012). Common hosts include many dicotyledonous plants such as strawberry, apple, citrus, and stone fruits, as well as major cereals such as maize and sorghum. Members of this genus can cause crop losses of up to 100% in many staple foods (Bailey and Jeger, 1992; Prusky et al., 2000; Talhinhas et al., 2005; Cannon et al., 2012).', 0.9909023642539978]]
Context 3: [['Various studies highlight the significance of Colletotrichum species in agriculture. Crouch et al. (2009) discussed anthracnose disease caused by the novel species Colletotrichum navitas, while Damm et al. (2013) addressed the Colletotrichum orbiculare species complex, which affects field crops and weeds. Other works by Damm et al. (2012) explored the Colletotrichum acutatum and Colletotrichum boninense species complexes.', 0.9882025122642517]]
Context 4: [['A significant effort has been dedicated to identifying which species of Colletotrichum are involved in various anthracnose-type diseases of plants and developing tools for their identification and differentiation. Multiple hosts can be affected by a single species, while multiple species can impact a single host. Simmonds was the first to describe C. acutatum as a new species, distinct from others.', 0.9862064719200134]]
Context 5: [['The genus Colletotrichum represents a large number of economically important Ascomycete fungi that collectively cause anthracnose disease or leaf blights on significant agricultural crops and ornamental plants worldwide. Colletotrichum spp. often serve as models in studies ranging from pathogenic development and differentiation to plant-microbe interactions. During establishment and colonization of host plants, members of this genus uniquely acquire nutrients via both biotrophy and necrotrophy. Thus, in a single interaction, these fungal pathogens exhibit two modes of nutrient acquisition: initially, nutrients are acquired from living cells, after which a necrotrophic phase is initiated, allowing the same fungus to obtain nutrients from dead cells killed by the fungus. A given species of this genus can exhibit both strategies separately or concurrently. Additionally, these fungi develop a series of specialized infection-related structures, including germ tubes, appressoria, primary intracellular hyphae, and secondary necrotrophic hyphae. Therefore, Colletotrichum species are experimentally attractive organisms for studying the molecular, biochemical, and cellular basis of fungal pathogenicity, development, and signal transduction (see Bailey and Jeger, 1992; Prusky et al., 1999).', 0.9849313497543335]]
Context 6: [['Colletotrichum spp. often cause anthracnose disease in herbaceous or woody plants in tropical and subtropical regions (Cannon et al. 2012). The genus Colletotrichum is one of the eight major plant pathogens worldwide (Dean et al. 2012). Three species or species complexes of Colletotrichum have been reported to cause anthracnose in strawberries: the Colletotrichum gloeosporioides complex, Colletotrichum fragariae, and the Colletotrichum acutatum complex (Denoyes-Rothan et al. 2003). The C. gloeosporioides complex is found worldwide and has a wide range of hosts, whereas C. acutatum and C. fragariae have narrower host ranges (MacKenzie et al. 2008). Although a few C. acutatum infections in Chinese strawberries have been reported, the primary species affecting strawberries in China are believed to be C. gloeosporioides and C. fragariae (Buddie et al. 1999; Han et al. 2016).', 0.9818411469459534]]
Context 7: [['Colletotrichum is one of the most important genera of plant pathogenic fungi worldwide, causing disease symptoms commonly known as anthracnose on a wide range of important crops, fruits, and ornamental plants (Bailey et al., 1992). Notable species include Colletotrichum lindemuthianum, C. gloeosporioides, C. acutatum, C. falcatum, C. nupharicola, and C. nymphaeae. Some plant pathogenic species are significant for quarantine because they could be introduced into regions where the disease is not present (Farr et al., 2006). The taxonomy and phylogeny of the genus Colletotrichum remain confusing (Hyde et al., 2009; Cai et al., 2009). Historically, if anthracnose was found on a host for which there were no prior records of that fungus-host relationship, the species was interpreted as new and formally described (Cannon et al., 2000). This practice was later rejected (von Arx, 1957; Sutton, 1980; Baxter et al., 1983), yet new species are still occasionally described in Colletotrichum (Sivanesan et al., 1993; Nakanura et al., 2006; Liu et al., 2007). Currently, more than 688 epithets are listed in Index Fungorum (www.indexfungorum.org/names/names.asp). Based on a morphological study, von Arx (1957) included more than 600 synonyms under C. gloeosporioides and 84 synonyms under C. dematium. Sutton (1992) listed 39 accepted species in Colletotrichum, each with a brief description. In recent years, molecular tools have been used to infer the evolutionary relationships of Colletotrichum species. Some species have been segregated from the C. gloeosporioides complex based on nu-rDNA ITS sequence data and morphological characteristics, such as C. boninense.', 0.9645947813987732]]
Context 8: [['Freeman, S., Katan, T., Shabi, E., 1998. Characterization of Colletotrichum species responsible for anthracnose diseases of various fruits. Plant Disease 82: 596–605.', 0.9530748128890991]]
Context 9: [['Freeman, S., Katan, T., and Shabi, E. 1998. Characterization of Colletotrichum species responsible for anthracnose diseases of various fruits. Plant Disease 82:596-605.', 0.9503601789474487]]

query: What steps should I take after a heavy rainfall to prevent anthracnose spread?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Anthracnose spreads within a field by splashing water, and living mulches (such as wheat, rye, or ryegrass) in row middles have been shown to reduce disease spread within a field. Sublethal doses of grass-specific herbicides, such as sethoxydim, may be used to prevent excessive growth of ryegrass (Gupton, 2000). Organic mulches, such as wheat straw or pine needles, also reduce splash and result in a lower incidence of anthracnose compared to rows mulched with plastic (Madden, 1992; Smith and Spiers, 1986). Anthracnose is less severe when water is supplied to plants using drip irrigation rather than overhead irrigation (Madden, 1992; Smith and Spiers, 1986).', 0.3070618212223053]]
Context 1: [['Anthracnose spreads within a field by splashing water, and living mulches (such as wheat, rye, or ryegrass) in row middles have been shown to reduce disease spread within a field. Sublethal doses of grass-specific herbicides, such as sethoxydim, may be used to prevent excessive growth of ryegrass (Gupton, 2000). Organic mulches, such as wheat straw or pine needles, also reduce splash and result in a lower incidence of anthracnose compared to rows mulched with plastic (Madden, 1992; Smith and Spiers, 1986). Additionally, anthracnose is less severe when water is supplied to plants using drip irrigation rather than overhead irrigation (Madden, 1992; Smith and Spiers, 1986). Anthracnose crown rot was observed to be less severe in commercial fields when strawberries were grown in soils with low nitrogen fertility (Howard et al., 1992). In greenhouse studies, Smith (1987, 1989) determined that strawberries grown in soils with high levels of nitrogen, especially from ammonium sources, are more susceptible to anthracnose than plants grown in soils with lower nitrogen levels or those with high levels of calcium nitrate.', 0.29865288734436035]]
Context 2: [['Anthracnose spreads within a field through splashing water. Living mulches, such as wheat, rye, or rye grass, in row middles have been shown to reduce disease spread. Organic mulches like wheat straw or pine needles also reduce splash and result in a lower incidence of anthracnose compared to rows mulched with plastic (Coelho et al., 2008; Madden, 1992; Smith and Spiers, 1986). Additionally, anthracnose is less severe when water is supplied to plants using drip irrigation rather than overhead irrigation (Coelho et al., 2008; Madden, 1992; Smith and Spiers, 1986).', 0.26642799377441406]]

Context 0: [['The anthracnose pathogen, Colletotrichum acutatum J. H. Simmonds, poses a serious threat to strawberry production worldwide. All parts of the strawberry plant are susceptible to infection; however, fruit rot is particularly damaging in production fields, leading to significant yield losses. Anthracnose development in strawberry nurseries not only reduces daughter plant production but also has serious consequences for pathogen dissemination on contaminated transplants. Once C. acutatum is introduced into production fields, managing disease outbreaks becomes challenging, as available control measures are only partially effective. query: How effective are traditional fungicides, such as captan and thiram, in managing strawberry anthracnose?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Additionally, multisite fungicides such as captan, thiram, and chlorothalonil, which have been available for many decades, remain effective in reducing strawberry anthracnose incidence (Mertely et al. 2018). Chlorothalonil is only registered for nonbearing nurseries when flowers and fruit are absent, yet our surveys indicated that its usage is significantly lower compared to newer single-site fungicides. Due to their efficacy and low resistance risk, multisite fungicides should be the mainstay for disease control in strawberry nurseries. Other non-chemical alternatives, such as heat (Wang et al. 2017) and ultraviolet treatments (Onofre et al. 2017), are currently under investigation and could serve as valuable tools for disease management, reducing the reliance on single-site fungicides.', 0.9982709884643555]]
Context 1: [['Various fungicides and a heat treatment were assessed for their ability to control strawberry anthracnose caused by the fungus Colletotrichum acutatum under laboratory, greenhouse, and field conditions. The effective dose causing 50% inhibition of mycelial growth (ED50) was measured at 30.5, 12.2, 0.2, 0.15, 0.05, 0.07, and 0.05 µg/ml for the fungicides folpet, captan, propiconazole, difenoconazole, combined prochloraz-Zn/folpet, prochloraz-Zn, and prochloraz-Mn, respectively.', 0.989622950553894]]
Context 2: [['ABSTRACT: Strawberry anthracnose, caused by Colletotrichum fragariae, is a serious problem in the southeastern United States, resulting in significant losses in strawberry nurseries. Control measures using fungicides are crucial, particularly with recommended applications of captafol, benomyl, captan, and maneb.', 0.9895558953285217]]
Context 3: [['Anthracnose is an important disease of strawberry caused by Colletotrichum spp., which affects foliage, runners, crowns, and fruits (Howard et al., 1992). Three primary fungal pathogens—C. acutatum sensu lato, C. gloeosporioides sensu lato, and C. fragariae—are known to cause anthracnose disease in strawberries (Freeman and Katan, 1997). The crown rot syndrome is characteristic of infections from C. gloeosporioides sensu lato and C. fragariae, while fruit rot is mainly attributed to C. acutatum sensu lato, leading to significant yield losses (Howard et al., 1992). Currently, numerous species are classified under what is now known as the C. acutatum complex, with six species—C. acutatum sensu stricto, C. fioriniae, C. godetiae, C. nymphaeae, C. salicis, and C. simmondsii—identified as associated with strawberry anthracnose worldwide (Damm et al., 2012). Among these, C. nymphaeae is the most prevalent pathogen causing strawberry anthracnose globally, including in Iran (Baroncelli et al., 2015; Karimi et al., 2017; Wang et al., 2019). Currently, no effective chemical control methods exist for managing strawberry anthracnose; available options are limited to preventive treatments applied before fruit production (Denoyes-Rothan et al., 1999). Additionally, concerns about the toxic effects of chemical fungicides on the environment and the development of resistance in fungal strains highlight the need for alternative control strategies. Consequently, utilizing resistant cultivars appears to be the most efficient and practical approach for suppressing anthracnose development. In light of recent anthracnose outbreaks in strawberry fields in the Kurdistan province of Iran (Karimi et al., 2017), and the necessity for appropriate strategies to address this issue, the aim of this study was to evaluate the resistance of several commercial strawberry cultivars to the anthracnose fruit rot caused by C. nymphaeae under in vivo and greenhouse conditions.', 0.9679285287857056]]
Context 4: [['In summary, while captafol demonstrated fungicidal activity against strawberry anthracnose, other fungicides like benomyl and maneb have shown reduced effectiveness in recent years, necessitating the ongoing evaluation of control strategies for this pervasive disease.', 0.9653075933456421]]
Context 5: [['The application of fungicides to control strawberry anthracnose is limited due to restrictions on pesticide usage and the susceptibility of strawberry plants to Colletotrichum during all stages of development, including flowers, green, and ripe fruit. To reduce anthracnose infection in plant nurseries, it is essential to produce disease-free propagation material, which is a prerequisite for establishing disease-free nursery transplants. Control measures practiced in the United States involve frequent applications of fungicides.', 0.9414137005805969]]
Context 6: [['There is an urgent need for multi- and single-site fungicide alternatives effective against anthracnose in strawberry nurseries and production fields. The antifungal antibiotic natamycin, widely used as a natural mold inhibitor in food products, has shown promise in controlling anthracnose root and crown infections caused by C. acutatum on strawberry transplants (Cordova et al. 2017; Haack et al. 2018). Similarly, fluazinam, a single-site respiration inhibitor fungicide from FRAC group 29, has demonstrated significant control of anthracnose fruit rot (Mertely et al. 2018). A request has been submitted through the Interregional Research Project Number 4 for its registration for nursery use only. Reducing the overlap of the same modes of action used during nursery and fruit production phases could help extend the lifespan of single-site fungicides at high risk of resistance.', 0.9409133791923523]]
Context 7: [['Strawberry anthracnose, caused mainly by the Colletotrichum acutatum species complex, is a significant disease affecting strawberry production. Surveys were conducted, and isolates were collected from affected areas, specifically strawberry nurseries and production fields in six states across the United States. The use of fungicides, particularly quinone outside inhibitors (QoIs), has been widely employed for controlling C. acutatum for the past 20 years. Resistance to QoIs was first reported in Florida in 2013, and subsequent anthracnose outbreaks occurred in strawberry nurseries and production fields throughout the U.S. in 2015. Fungicide use surveys indicated that, in certain locations, the number of QoI applications exceeded the recommended levels for this fungicide group. This situation necessitates immediate changes in anthracnose management strategies to incorporate other chemical and non-chemical approaches, aiming to limit the selection of resistant populations and prevent future outbreaks.', 0.930204451084137]]
Context 8: [['Finally, it is important to emphasize that strawberry production in Brazil remains heavily dependent on fungicide applications, which are not completely effective for anthracnose control and raise consumer concerns about food safety. Our study indicates that managing flower blight can be quite effective through a combination of cultural choices, which could potentially reduce dependency on chemical controls.', 0.9106888175010681]]

query: How can research on pathogen gene families inform the development of targeted fungicides or resistance traits?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['QoI resistance was first described in C. acutatum from strawberries in Florida in 2013 (Forcelini et al. 2016). The G143A and F129L mutations in cytb were identified, conferring high and moderate resistance levels, respectively. In our study of California isolates, only the G143A mutation was detected, although only 11 resistant isolates were sequenced out of a total of 29 identified. All resistant isolates had EC50 values for azoxystrobin of >40 mg/ml, indicating high resistance; thus, other resistance genotypes may not be present in California at this time. Diseased plants that yielded resistant isolates originated from two of five California nursery sources and were collected in three of eight sampled counties. Resistance may currently be limited in distribution but could spread quickly with frequent movement of plant material. Population genetic analyses of isolates may provide insight into whether resistance developed independently in the two nurseries and in Florida. Resistance can be managed by using treatments with different modes of action. The availability of alternative fungicides is important, as resistance conferred by the G143A mutation typically cannot be mitigated using higher, off-label application rates of QoI compounds in the field (Bartlett et al. 2002; Fernández-Ortuño et al. 2012; Kim et al. 2003; Lesniak et al. 2011). Additionally, this mutation has been shown to be stable in C. acutatum populations and did not result in a fitness penalty in laboratory assays (Forcelini et al. 2018). In our study, QoI-resistant and -sensitive isolates were similarly pathogenic; however, disease severity and mortality after inoculation with resistant isolates were higher than those for QoI-sensitive isolates. Several studies on other fungal pathogens have indicated that resistant isolates harboring the G143A mutation did not exhibit reduced fitness compared to wild-type sensitive isolates (Corio-Costet et al. 2011; Karaoglanidis et al. 2011; Rallos et al. 2014). In contrast, the fitness of resistant isolates of Magnaporthe oryzae was reduced (Ma and Uddin 2009).', 0.25250476598739624]]
Context 1: [['Fungicide efficacy has been evaluated through in vitro, greenhouse, and field studies, with some pathogens showing resistance to specific fungicides. Developing anthracnose-resistant cultivars remains a primary objective for most strawberry breeding programs in the southern United States.', 0.21920043230056763]]
Context 2: [['The sensitivity ranges of the isolates to various fungicides were 0.2 to 1.6 mg/ml and 0.002 to 0.2 mg/ml, respectively, with average values of 6.5 to 6.9 mg/ml, 1.5 to 0.6 mg/ml, 0.9 to 0.4 mg/ml, and 0.1 to 0.05 mg/ml, respectively. All isolates were more sensitive to difenoconazole, flusilazole, and carbendazim than to tebuconazole (P < 0.01). However, sensitivities to the same fungicide varied among isolates. Specifically, isolates SL-31 and TS-09 were the least sensitive to carbendazim and tebuconazole, with resistance ratios of 87.3 and 51.6, respectively. Sensitivities to difenoconazole and flusilazole were largely consistent across all isolates, with resistance ratios ranging from 1 to 4.6 and from 1 to 7, respectively. Therefore, difenoconazole and flusilazole could be recommended for disease control. Notably, differences in pathogenicity and fungicide sensitivity were not correlated with geographic regions. These findings indicate a high level of intraspecific diversity within the populations of Colletotrichum gloeosporioides s.s. responsible for walnut anthracnose. For effective management, a targeted control strategy should be developed based on different geographic regions.', 0.2032400220632553]]

Context 6: [['QoI fungicides target the cytochrome b (cytb) gene, inhibiting fungal mitochondrial respiration (Bartlett et al. 2002; Sauter et al. 1999; Ypema and Gold 1999). Azoxystrobin is a QoI fungicide that has been registered for anthracnose control in strawberries for several decades (Mertely et al. 2017a, b). However, the intensive use of such fungicides has led to the emergence of C. acutatum populations resistant to QoIs (Forcelini et al. 2016). Resistance to QoIs was first identified during the 2013 to 2014 strawberry production season in Florida. Resistant C. acutatum isolates exhibited either the F129L or G143A mutations in the cytb gene, which were associated with moderate and complete resistance to QoIs, respectively. query: Can a fungus that infects strawberries also infect other plants?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['The difficulty in controlling anthracnose crown rot arises from the fact that Colletotrichum spp. can kill strawberry plants after aggressively invading crown tissue, with a long latent period during which no symptoms are visible. Additionally, there are no long-term effective fungicides available, and the diverse origins of the causal agents are unpredictable (Peres et al., 2017; Forcelini and Peres, 2018; Hirayama et al., 2018). Furthermore, Colletotrichum spp. can be dispersed from asymptomatic plants over long distances, while relevant quarantine measures for strawberry trade are lacking in China. Recognizing the causal agents is a prerequisite for disease control. Initially, identification largely depended on morphological observation and virulence tests. Repeated in vitro subculturing of microbes can alter both their morphology and virulence. The fact that morphological characteristics can vary based on host choice or environmental conditions poses a significant concern for fungal identification. Strawberry anthracnose was first reported nearly a century ago (Brooks, 1931). Through PCR and DNA sequencing techniques, researchers have clarified the genetic distinctions among Colletotrichum spp. associated with strawberries, categorizing pathogens of worldwide origin into C. acutatum, C. fragariae, and C. gloeosporioides (Martínez-Culebras et al., 2000, 2003). However, ambiguously annotated data for Colletotrichum species frequently appear in GenBank, leading to confusion (Nilsson et al., 2006; Hyde et al., 2009). The emergence of multi-locus phylogeny has significantly aided in the identification of fungal species. Many pathologists and biologists have greatly expanded knowledge of Colletotrichum systematics (Cannon et al., 2012; Damm et al., 2012a, b; Weir et al., 2012), providing a solid foundation for future research. A landmark study corrected many synonymous names and offered a valuable reference for understanding Colletotrichum pathogens (Hyde et al., 2014). The delineation of Colletotrichum species and the description of new species continue to progress with the advent of novel technologies such as whole genome sequencing (Jayawardena et al., 2020, 2021; Bhunjun et al., 2021; Talhinhas and Baroncelli, 2021).', 0.9455569982528687]]
Context 1: [['Strawberries (Fragaria×ananassa Duch.) are a widely cultivated hybrid species within the Rosaceae family, renowned for their fruit. They are increasingly significant for the agricultural economic development of countries like Iran, particularly in the Kurdistan province, which leads in strawberry production, predominantly under open-field conditions (Tehranifar and Sarsaefi, 2002). Various biotic and abiotic factors contribute to the decline in strawberry production globally. Notably, over 100 fungal species can invade strawberry plants, with approximately one-third causing serious diseases on different plant parts (Martin and others).', 0.8669647574424744]]
Context 2: [['Abstract: Fragaria ananassa (common name: strawberry) is a globally cultivated hybrid species belonging to the Rosaceae family. Colletotrichum acutatum sensu lato (s.l.) is considered the second most economically important pathogen worldwide affecting strawberries. A collection of 148 Colletotrichum spp. isolates, including 67 C. acutatum s.l. isolates associated with the phytosanitary history of UK strawberry production, was used to characterize multilocus genetic variation of this pathogen in the UK, relative to additional reference isolates representing a worldwide sampling of the fungus diversity. Evidence indicates that three different species—C. nymphaeae, C. godetiae, and C. fioriniae—are associated with strawberry production in the UK, corresponding to previously designated genetic groups A2, A4, and A3, respectively. Among these species, 12 distinct haplotypes were identified, suggesting multiple introductions into the country. A subset of isolates was also used to assess aggressiveness in causing disease on strawberry plants and fruits. Isolates belonging to C. nymphaeae, C. godetiae, and C. fioriniae, representative of the UK anthracnose pathogen populations, showed variation in their aggressiveness. Among the three species, C. nymphaeae and C. fioriniae appeared to be more aggressive compared to C. godetiae. This study highlights the genetic and pathogenic heterogeneity of the C. acutatum s.l. populations introduced into the UK linked to strawberry production.', 0.8418015241622925]]
Context 3: [['Anthracnose caused by Colletotrichum species is one of the most destructive diseases affecting strawberry production worldwide. Fungi of the genus Colletotrichum, which are ancient and co-evolved with flowering plants, rank eighth among the ten most economically important fungal pathogens and have diversified to adapt to various hosts. Since its first report in the United States in 1931, strawberry anthracnose has spread globally, resulting in devastating economic, social, and ecological consequences. In many ways, producing organic strawberries is largely impractical because of this disease. Colletotrichum species pathogenic to strawberries have been extensively characterized. This review aims to provide an accurate inventory of these species by revisiting their discovery history over the past 90 years. A total of 23 Colletotrichum species, clustered into five species complexes and two singleton taxa, have been accepted as strawberry pathogens with a global occurrence illustrated. The relative prevalence of distinct Colletotrichum species associated with strawberries has been systematically analyzed in China. Finally, the host range of the two prevailing species, C. fructicola and C. siamense, which cause significant damage globally, is summarized, with the goal of improving diagnostic accuracy and anthracnose management in agricultural ecosystems.', 0.6588901877403259]]
Context 4: [['Anthracnose is an important disease of strawberry caused by Colletotrichum spp., which affects foliage, runners, crowns, and fruits (Howard et al., 1992). Three primary fungal pathogens—C. acutatum sensu lato, C. gloeosporioides sensu lato, and C. fragariae—are known to cause anthracnose disease in strawberries (Freeman and Katan, 1997). The crown rot syndrome is characteristic of infections from C. gloeosporioides sensu lato and C. fragariae, while fruit rot is mainly attributed to C. acutatum sensu lato, leading to significant yield losses (Howard et al., 1992). Currently, numerous species are classified under what is now known as the C. acutatum complex, with six species—C. acutatum sensu stricto, C. fioriniae, C. godetiae, C. nymphaeae, C. salicis, and C. simmondsii—identified as associated with strawberry anthracnose worldwide (Damm et al., 2012). Among these, C. nymphaeae is the most prevalent pathogen causing strawberry anthracnose globally, including in Iran (Baroncelli et al., 2015; Karimi et al., 2017; Wang et al., 2019). Currently, no effective chemical control methods exist for managing strawberry anthracnose; available options are limited to preventive treatments applied before fruit production (Denoyes-Rothan et al., 1999). Additionally, concerns about the toxic effects of chemical fungicides on the environment and the development of resistance in fungal strains highlight the need for alternative control strategies. Consequently, utilizing resistant cultivars appears to be the most efficient and practical approach for suppressing anthracnose development. In light of recent anthracnose outbreaks in strawberry fields in the Kurdistan province of Iran (Karimi et al., 2017), and the necessity for appropriate strategies to address this issue, the aim of this study was to evaluate the resistance of several commercial strawberry cultivars to the anthracnose fruit rot caused by C. nymphaeae under in vivo and greenhouse conditions.', 0.4680938720703125]]

Context 9: [['Strawberry (Fragaria × ananassa) is a major crop cultivated in China (Xie et al. 2010). The production of strawberries has rapidly expanded in recent years, positioning China as one of the world’s largest producers and exporters. As of 2013, strawberry cultivation covered 100.5 × 10^3 hectares, yielding 2.8 million tonnes (The Ministry of Agriculture of the People’s Republic of China 2014). Among these, anthracnose, caused by species of Colletotrichum, is one of the most critical diseases affecting strawberries.', 0.19786910712718964]]

query: What specific conditions in the experiment are most responsible for the loss of C. acutatum infectivity over time?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['The ability of flower extracts to stimulate C. acutatum conidiation decreased with increasing durations of dry periods, possibly due to rising fungal mortality over time. In contrast, appressoria tended to persist on leaves and coverslips both before and after treatment applications, consistent with their role as survival structures. The fact that C. acutatum could be stimulated to multiply on coverslips and leaves even after two weeks of exposure to dry conditions clearly indicates the durability of C. acutatum propagules and demonstrates that survival does not depend on the presence of a host. C. acutatum survival on inert material has also been shown on the clothing of fern field workers, where conidia survived for over four weeks.', 0.8076028823852539]]
Context 1: [['In inoculations conducted under controlled greenhouse conditions, C. acutatum from strawberry was isolated from inoculated plants that did not exhibit disease symptoms but maintained virulence on strawberry. The fungus was detected by a plating method both on and inside inoculated leaves at various time points after plant inoculation. The authenticity of the isolates as C. acutatum was validated by PCR using C. acutatum-specific primers. The PCR technique proved accurate and sensitive enough to detect the pathogen in inoculated tissues within 24 hours post-inoculation. This method is valuable for detecting C. acutatum in the tissues of various plant species, indicating that the fungus can exhibit both epiphytic and endophytic lifestyles without causing visible disease symptoms. PCR and fungal isolation data indicate that the pathogen can remain viable for extended periods within the tissues of various plant species without inducing disease symptoms. Although the experiments were concluded after three months for technical reasons, the final levels of inoculum in the examined tissues and the decay curves suggest that the pathogen had the potential to inhabit the infected plants for much longer periods. Furthermore, it has been shown that C. acutatum from strawberry can survive for nine months within plant debris in soil.', 0.7293375730514526]]
Context 2: [['Survival of C. acutatum in Soil and Leaf Debris: Populations of C. acutatum conidia recovered from laboratory soil tests decreased steadily, especially under moist or saturated conditions. Within 1 week, detectable populations decreased by more than 30% across all treatments. By 4 weeks, the number of viable conidia fell below 100 conidia per gram of soil when soil moisture was above 6%. In contrast, under dry conditions (1% moisture), it took 105 days for populations to fall below 100 conidia per gram of soil.', 0.5293919444084167]]
Context 3: [['Sporulation of C. acutatum OH and MS, C. fragariae MS, and C. gloeosporioides FL was virtually constant over time at both 5 and 10°C (Figs. 2 and 3). As temperatures increased (≥15°C), sporulation increased over time for the tested isolates. The C. acutatum isolates produced more spores at lower temperatures (Fig. 2A,D) than the isolates of the other two species (Fig. 3A,C). After sporulation began, maximum sporulation during the first four days occurred around 25°C. With longer incubation times (at least 14 days), maximum sporulation occurred at 15°C for C. acutatum CT and MS (Fig. 2B,D), C. gloeosporioides FL (Fig. 3A), and C. fragariae MS and NC (Fig. 3C,D). However, these longer durations could not be tested at higher temperatures due to fruit degradation.', 0.39464497566223145]]
Context 4: [['Survival of C. acutatum on Clothing: The number of viable conidia recovered from denim fabric held at 25°C and low humidity decreased at a steady rate. Sufficient numbers of conidia to cause infection (100 CFU/ml) were recovered for up to 4 weeks after placement on the fabric, although some viable conidia were still recovered for up to 42 days post-treatment.', 0.3428874909877777]]
Context 5: [['Sclerotia of C. acutatum added to soil under laboratory conditions maintained high viability (≥ 100 sclerotia per gram of soil) under dry conditions for 26 weeks; however, under moist conditions (≥ 12% moisture), populations declined to very low levels by day 56. Viable sclerotia were consistently recovered from the soil for up to 47 weeks after incorporation.', 0.3329257071018219]]
Context 6: [['This study provides strong evidence that C. acutatum can become established, persist, and produce inoculum on symptomless strawberry leaves under a range of temperatures and intermittent wetness periods. In addition to our previous work at 26°C under continuous wetness (19), we have now shown that secondary conidia and appressoria may be produced under environmental conditions typical of many temperate strawberry-producing areas in the world. The survival of C. acutatum on strawberry leaves has implications for long-distance dissemination on transplants, as well as the proliferation and dissemination of the fungus within production fields. Furthermore, asymptomatic foliage of other plant species, including weeds, has been recently suggested as an additional inoculum source for C. acutatum (12). The environmental biology of C. acutatum on symptomless foliage should therefore be considered when developing management practices for strawberry anthracnose.', 0.3117677569389343]]
Context 7: [['Fig. 4: Survival of C. acutatum in leaf debris when added to soil and incubated under controlled conditions, showing an initial increase in detectable conidia followed by a steady decline over five months.', 0.3050033450126648]]
Context 8: [['INTRODUCTION: As a significant pathogen, C. acutatum has been treated as a regulated organism for many years.', 0.2563933730125427]]
Context 9: [['Survival in Leaf Debris: Survival of C. acutatum in leaf debris was examined in 1-g portions of chopped, infected leatherleaf fronds placed in plastic Magenta vessels. Three replicate vessels were prepared for this analysis.', 0.24173375964164734]]

query: What should I do if anthracnose is already widespread in my field?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Anthracnose spreads within a field by splashing water, and living mulches (such as wheat, rye, or ryegrass) in row middles have been shown to reduce disease spread within a field. Sublethal doses of grass-specific herbicides, such as sethoxydim, may be used to prevent excessive growth of ryegrass (Gupton, 2000). Organic mulches, such as wheat straw or pine needles, also reduce splash and result in a lower incidence of anthracnose compared to rows mulched with plastic (Madden, 1992; Smith and Spiers, 1986). Additionally, anthracnose is less severe when water is supplied to plants using drip irrigation rather than overhead irrigation (Madden, 1992; Smith and Spiers, 1986). Anthracnose crown rot was observed to be less severe in commercial fields when strawberries were grown in soils with low nitrogen fertility (Howard et al., 1992). In greenhouse studies, Smith (1987, 1989) determined that strawberries grown in soils with high levels of nitrogen, especially from ammonium sources, are more susceptible to anthracnose than plants grown in soils with lower nitrogen levels or those with high levels of calcium nitrate.', 0.5099267959594727]]
Context 1: [['Anthracnose spreads within a field by splashing water, and living mulches (such as wheat, rye, or ryegrass) in row middles have been shown to reduce disease spread within a field. Sublethal doses of grass-specific herbicides, such as sethoxydim, may be used to prevent excessive growth of ryegrass (Gupton, 2000). Organic mulches, such as wheat straw or pine needles, also reduce splash and result in a lower incidence of anthracnose compared to rows mulched with plastic (Madden, 1992; Smith and Spiers, 1986). Anthracnose is less severe when water is supplied to plants using drip irrigation rather than overhead irrigation (Madden, 1992; Smith and Spiers, 1986).', 0.49260061979293823]]
Context 2: [['Anthracnose spreads within a field through splashing water. Living mulches, such as wheat, rye, or rye grass, in row middles have been shown to reduce disease spread. Organic mulches like wheat straw or pine needles also reduce splash and result in a lower incidence of anthracnose compared to rows mulched with plastic (Coelho et al., 2008; Madden, 1992; Smith and Spiers, 1986). Additionally, anthracnose is less severe when water is supplied to plants using drip irrigation rather than overhead irrigation (Coelho et al., 2008; Madden, 1992; Smith and Spiers, 1986).', 0.403696745634079]]
Context 3: [['Additional Keywords: anthracnose, disease spread, Fragaria × ananassa, models, quantitative epidemiology.', 0.23715654015541077]]
Context 4: [['Until highly resistant cultivars are available, growers must rely on chemical applications and cultural practices to reduce losses due to anthracnose. The failure of fungicides to control anthracnose epidemics may be due to the development of fungicide resistance in the Colletotrichum spp. population. For example, benomyl effectively reduced the incidence of anthracnose crown rot (Horn et al., 1972; Howard, 1971) and was used intensively by strawberry growers for years to control anthracnose and other diseases. However, the anthracnose pathogens, C. acutatum and C. fragariae, developed resistance to it and other benzimidazole fungicides (LaMondia, 1995; McInnes et al., 1992a; Smith and Black, 1992, 1993), rendering benomyl ineffective for anthracnose control in strawberry fields.', 0.20891693234443665]]
Context 5: [['Until highly resistant cultivars are available, growers must rely on chemical applications and cultural practices to reduce losses due to anthracnose. The failure of fungicides to control anthracnose epidemics may be attributed to the development of fungicide resistance in the Colletotrichum species population. For example, benomyl was shown to effectively reduce the incidence of anthracnose crown rot (Horn et al., 1972; Howard, 1971) and was used intensively by strawberry growers for years to control anthracnose and other diseases. However, the anthracnose pathogens, C. acutatum and C. fragariae, developed resistance to it and other benzimidazole fungicides (LaMondia, 1995; McInnes et al., 1992a; Smith and Black, 1992, 1993), leading to the ineffectiveness of benomyl for anthracnose control in strawberry fields.', 0.20827554166316986]]
Context 6: [['Bergstrom, G. C., and Nicholson, R. L. 1999. The biology of corn anthracnose: Knowledge to exploit for improved management. Plant Dis. 83:596-608.', 0.20787407457828522]]
Context 7: [['Key words: anthracnose, Ascomycota, Colletotrichum acutatum, Gloeosporium, Glomerella, phylogeny, systematics.', 0.195437490940094]]
Context 8: [['Anthracnose is a significant disease affecting grape crops (Dowling et al., 2020). Beyond causing severe yield losses, anthracnose epidemics can diminish the quality of the produce (Waller et al., 2002; Dowling et al., 2020). The most economically damaging symptoms often include blossom blight and fruit rots; however, necrotic lesions may also develop on leaves, stems, and twigs, leading to plant deterioration and reduced fruit quality (Dowling et al., 2020).', 0.18921159207820892]]
Context 9: [['Crouch J, Beirn LA. 2009. Anthracnose of cereals and grasses. Fungal Diversity 39:19–44.', 0.18866923451423645]]

query: In what ways might the regional differences in strawberry fruit infection influence the fungal isolates' characteristics?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['In a study conducted in Zhejiang province, China, the pathogenicity of various Colletotrichum isolates was assessed on wounded and non-wounded strawberry leaves. Most isolates, such as ZJE-3, exhibited strong pathogenicity on wounded leaves but weak pathogenicity on non-wounded leaves (Supplementary Fig. S3). A phylogenetic analysis was performed using five genes (GAPDH, CAL, CHS-1, ACT, and ITS) to identify 91 different isolates from strawberry anthracnose samples. The species identified were C. fructicola, C. gloeosporioides, C. aenigma, and C. siamense, all belonging to the C. gloeosporioides species complex. This is the first report of C. siamense causing strawberry anthracnose in Zhejiang, where it was found to be the second most common species. Although originally described from coffee plantations in Thailand, C. siamense has a wide geographical distribution and diverse host range. The study noted variability in its morphological characteristics, suggesting environmental conditions may influence mycelial growth. Different colony types were observed, with a generally grayish-white appearance and slow hyphal growth under the tested culture conditions. The pathogenicity varied among C. siamense isolates, indicating a need for further research on their pathogenesis.', 0.31759026646614075]]
Context 1: [['Wilson, L. L., Madden, L. V., and Ellis, M. A. 1994. Effect of temperature on strawberry fruit infection by geographic isolates of three Colletotrichum species. (Abstr.) Phytopathology 84:1071.', 0.31183940172195435]]
Context 2: [['The first formal report of strawberry anthracnose in China was made by Hu (1990) at the fifth annual conference of the Chinese Society of Plant Pathology, which took place in Jiangsu Province. In Shanghai, C. fragariae and C. acutatum were identified as strawberry pathogens (Shao 1992; Ye et al. 1997). Subsequently, fruit rot caused by C. acutatum was reported in Shanghai based on morphological identification (Dai et al. 2006). Molecular analysis using ITS sequences facilitated the identification of 16 C. gloeosporioides isolates and one C. acutatum isolate collected from 1996 to 2006 in Shanghai (Ren et al. 2008). Based on ITS sequences and restriction enzyme digestion, 31 Colletotrichum isolates collected from diseased strawberries between 2006 and 2007 in Shanghai and Zhejiang were identified as C. acutatum, C. gloeosporioides, and C. fragariae (Xie et al. 2010). Following this, C. gloeosporioides and C. fragariae were again reported as pathogens affecting strawberries in Zhejiang (Ren et al. 2011). A study collected 114 fungal isolates from the C. gloeosporioides complex from diseased strawberries during 2010 to 2013 in Zhejiang Province, though they were not distinguished at the species level (Lin et al. 2016).', 0.21395838260650635]]
Context 3: [['Strawberry fruits were inoculated with isolates of C. acutatum and C. gloeosporioides, both from strawberry and C. gloeosporioides from Limonium spp., either through wounding or non-wounding methods. Generally, no significant differences (P < 0.05) were detected in lesion size caused by the strawberry pathogens on fruit compared to those from the C. gloeosporioides Limonium isolate L-12, 9 days after either type of inoculation (Fig. 5).', 0.21102404594421387]]
Context 4: [['Molecular tools have been successfully utilized to differentiate between the species of Colletotrichum responsible for strawberry anthracnose. Isolates of C. fragariae, C. acutatum, and C. gloeosporioides infecting strawberries were distinctly different in nuclear and A+T-rich DNA analyses, as well as in amplified fragment length polymorphism (AFLP) methods. Similarly, sequencing and restriction digest analyses of PCR-amplified ribosomal DNA (rDNA) have been used to differentiate between C. acutatum and other Colletotrichum species from strawberries. In populations of C. acutatum and C. fragariae from strawberries, little genomic variation was observed within each species using various molecular methods. In contrast, high diversity was observed in populations of C. gloeosporioides from strawberries, which possess the perfect stage. However, C. acutatum isolated from strawberries in Europe were distinct from American strawberry isolates. Likewise, isolates of C. acutatum from other hosts, such as peach and pecan, were separate from the strawberry pathogen, suggesting that C. acutatum is not a uniform group.', 0.21083079278469086]]
Context 5: [['On inoculated strawberry plants, isolates of C. fructicola and C. murrayae exhibited strong pathogenicity, affecting both leaves and petioles, with plant mortality observed 30 days post-inoculation. Strawberries (Fragaria ananassa) are a globally important small fruit crop, and the area dedicated to strawberry cultivation in China has rapidly increased in recent years. Under suitable environmental conditions, anthracnose can lead to significant yield losses (Henz et al. 1992). Infected strawberries may develop lesions on the petiole and crown, potentially resulting in plant collapse and death. In nurseries, lesions can form on stolons, leading to the wilting and death of unrooted daughter plants (Freeman and Katan 1997). Infected transplants can spread the disease from the nursery to the field, where typical symptoms of anthracnose manifest as irregular black leaf spots, crown rot, flower blight, and fruit rot (Howard et al. 1992).', 0.20107591152191162]]
Context 6: [['Strawberry is a small fruit crop with high economic value. Anthracnose caused by Colletotrichum spp. poses a serious threat to strawberry production, particularly in warm and humid climates; however, knowledge of pathogen populations in tropical and subtropical regions is limited. To investigate the diversity of infectious agents causing strawberry anthracnose in Taiwan, a disease survey was conducted from 2010 to 2018. Colletotrichum spp. were identified through morphological characterization and multilocus phylogenetic analysis, utilizing internal transcribed spacer, glyceraldehyde 3-phosphate dehydrogenase, chitin synthase, actin, beta-tubulin, calmodulin, and the intergenic region between Apn2 and MAT1-2-1 (ApMAT). Among 52 isolates collected from 24 farms and nurseries in Taiwan, a new species, Colletotrichum miaoliense sp. nov. (6% of all isolates), a species not previously known to be associated with strawberry, Colletotrichum karstii (6%), and three known species, Colletotrichum siamense (75%), Colletotrichum fructicola (11%), and Colletotrichum boninense (2%), were identified. The predominant species, C. siamense and C. fructicola, exhibited higher mycelial growth rates on potato dextrose agar and caused larger lesions on both wounded and non-wounded detached strawberry leaves. Colletotrichum boninense, C. karstii, and C. miaoliense only caused lesions on wounded leaves. Understanding the composition and biology of the pathogen population will assist in disease management and resistance breeding.', 0.1982966661453247]]
Context 7: [['The pathogenicity assays conducted in this study were based on research from Belgium, given the similar molecular diversity of anthracnose pathogen populations associated with strawberry production. These assays, using isolates representing this molecular diversity, revealed variability in aggressiveness among different species within C. acutatum sensu lato, as well as complex patterns both between and within species. For example, isolates of C. fioriniae and C. nymphaeae originating from strawberries appeared equally aggressive, with C. nymphaeae showing a degree of host preference. Isolates of both C. fioriniae and C. godetiae included those from other hosts that exhibited comparable levels of aggressiveness to strawberry isolates. Similar patterns were noted with some non-strawberry isolates from species such as C. acutatum sensu stricto and C. simmondsii. Moreover, at least one isolate of C. godetiae from strawberries was significantly less aggressive than others. These observations suggest that certain Colletotrichum species, like C. fioriniae and C. godetiae, contain populations capable of infecting a broader range of hosts, which may be influenced by environmental conditions. Further studies, utilizing a more extensive set of isolates from these three species alongside appropriate pathological and biological assays, are essential for gaining deeper insights into the evolution of pathogenicity, field symptoms, and the differential responses to host varieties and fungicides used in UK strawberry production systems.', 0.196184903383255]]
Context 8: [['Maas, J. L. 1987. Compendium of Strawberry Diseases. The American Phytopathological Society, St. Paul, MN.', 0.19168393313884735]]
Context 9: [['Smith, B. J. (2008). Epidemiology and pathology of strawberry anthracnose: A North American perspective. HortScience, 43, 69–73.', 0.1907886415719986]]

query: How does nitrogen fertilization influence Colletotrichum disease severity?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['The form of nitrogen significantly influenced both the severity of Fusarium crown and root rot and the growth of tomato seedlings in a soilless rockwool system (Fig. 1). Increasing concentrations of nitrate-N reduced disease severity and improved plant growth compared to ammonium forms. Both ammonium sulfate and ammonium chloride produced similar responses, indicating that NH4+ was the harmful component (Fig. 1). Ammonium nitrate has been reported to either have no effect on Fusarium diseases or to increase disease severity, similar to ammonium-N (Jones et al., 1989; Schneider, 1985). While this was generally true for Fusarium crown and root rot, testing a range of concentrations revealed that at low concentrations (10 to 100 mg·L–1 N), ammonium nitrate reduced disease similarly to nitrate-N (Figs. 1D, 2D). However, the negative influence of the NH4+ ion became apparent at concentrations above 125 mg·L–1 N (Figs. 1D, 2D). At higher concentrations, seedlings might have lacked sufficient available carbohydrates to convert the excess ammonium, which is toxic for tomato seedlings (Woltz et al., 1992), into nontoxic amino acids (Pate, 1973). Nitrates have long been recognized for their role in reducing seedling diseases caused by Rhizoctonia solani (Huber and Watson, 1974); however, contradictory results have been reported for Fusarium crown and root rot. Mihuta-Grimm et al. (1990) noted that nitrogen supplied as a 20N–20P–20K fertilizer had no effect on the growth of F. oxysporum f.sp. radicis-lycopersici in rockwool compared to non-fertilized treatments. Jarvis and Thorpe (1980) found no effect of nitrogen form (with total N applied unspecified) on disease or yield when adequate lime was provided to counteract potential pH effects. In fact, the differential effect of nitrogen form on pH is a significant mechanism for suppressing many soilborne pathogens (Huber and Watson, 1974). In contrast, Woltz et al. (1992) reported differences between nitrate and ammonium-N (each at 225 mg·L–1).', 0.6714501976966858]]
Context 1: [['However, the effect of nitrogen on disease management can vary depending on the disease. Ammonium sulfate has been shown to be more suppressive of black root rot in strawberries than Ca(NO3)2. The objectives of these studies were to determine (i) the influence of N, P, and K levels, and (ii) the influence of N source and concentration on the severity of anthracnose crown rot.', 0.21224039793014526]]
Context 2: [['Jones, Jr., J.B. 1991. Kjeldahl Method for Nitrogen Determination. Micro-Macro Publishing Inc., Athens, GA, USA.', 0.14088058471679688]]
Context 3: [['There is a striking positive correlation between the effect of various cultural practices on nitrification and the severity of take-all. The use of a nitrification inhibitor with ammonium, along with conditions and crop sequences that inhibit nitrification, also reduces take-all (21, 22), and vice versa. However, some practices, such as planting oats before wheat in rotation, have little apparent effect on nitrification but provide some of the most effective control of take-all (3.12, 22). This suggests that the form of nitrogen, as influenced by the rate of nitrification, may act indirectly or in conjunction with other factors to influence the severity of take-all.', 0.1306966245174408]]
Context 4: [['Determining whether applied nutrients have been absorbed by the plant.', 0.1279323399066925]]
Context 5: [["Brooker et al.'s study on nitrate non-utilizing mutants of Colletotrichum (Phytopathology 81:672-677).", 0.12076281756162643]]
Context 6: [['Smith, B.J. (1987). Effect of nitrogen, phosphorus...', 0.11765684932470322]]
Context 7: [['The results from Nitrogen Source Study II mirrored those of the first study. Plants of ‘Tangi’ and ‘MSUS 74’ displayed higher disease severity ratings than those of ‘MSUS 70’ and ‘MSUS 98’. Notably, plants receiving no nitrogen had lower disease severity ratings than those treated with 40 ppm N or 120 ppm N. The lowest disease ratings associated with nitrogen source were found in plants treated with Ca(NO3)2, KNO3, and NH4NO3.', 0.09670812636613846]]

query: What long-term implications do the findings about strawberry anthracnose pathogens have for sustainable agriculture in Europe?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Anthracnose is an important disease of strawberry caused by Colletotrichum spp., which affects foliage, runners, crowns, and fruits (Howard et al., 1992). Three primary fungal pathogens—C. acutatum sensu lato, C. gloeosporioides sensu lato, and C. fragariae—are known to cause anthracnose disease in strawberries (Freeman and Katan, 1997). The crown rot syndrome is characteristic of infections from C. gloeosporioides sensu lato and C. fragariae, while fruit rot is mainly attributed to C. acutatum sensu lato, leading to significant yield losses (Howard et al., 1992). Currently, numerous species are classified under what is now known as the C. acutatum complex, with six species—C. acutatum sensu stricto, C. fioriniae, C. godetiae, C. nymphaeae, C. salicis, and C. simmondsii—identified as associated with strawberry anthracnose worldwide (Damm et al., 2012). Among these, C. nymphaeae is the most prevalent pathogen causing strawberry anthracnose globally, including in Iran (Baroncelli et al., 2015; Karimi et al., 2017; Wang et al., 2019). Currently, no effective chemical control methods exist for managing strawberry anthracnose; available options are limited to preventive treatments applied before fruit production (Denoyes-Rothan et al., 1999). Additionally, concerns about the toxic effects of chemical fungicides on the environment and the development of resistance in fungal strains highlight the need for alternative control strategies. Consequently, utilizing resistant cultivars appears to be the most efficient and practical approach for suppressing anthracnose development. In light of recent anthracnose outbreaks in strawberry fields in the Kurdistan province of Iran (Karimi et al., 2017), and the necessity for appropriate strategies to address this issue, the aim of this study was to evaluate the resistance of several commercial strawberry cultivars to the anthracnose fruit rot caused by C. nymphaeae under in vivo and greenhouse conditions.', 0.345916748046875]]

query: What are the environmental implications of using fungicides in strawberry fields compared to ornamental plants like roses?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['ABSTRACT: Strawberry anthracnose, caused by Colletotrichum fragariae, is a serious problem in the southeastern United States, resulting in significant losses in strawberry nurseries. Control measures using fungicides are crucial, particularly with recommended applications of captafol, benomyl, captan, and maneb.', 0.6290894150733948]]
Context 1: [['The application of fungicides to control strawberry anthracnose is limited due to restrictions on pesticide usage and the susceptibility of strawberry plants to Colletotrichum during all stages of development, including flowers, green, and ripe fruit. To reduce anthracnose infection in plant nurseries, it is essential to produce disease-free propagation material, which is a prerequisite for establishing disease-free nursery transplants. Control measures practiced in the United States involve frequent applications of fungicides.', 0.5940939784049988]]
Context 2: [['In the southeastern United States, anthracnose crown rot and fruit rot can be particularly severe in strawberry production fields, especially during wet harvest seasons, which can lead to total crop loss. Fungicides are used to control anthracnose diseases; however, several have become ineffective due to the development of fungicide-resistant strains of the pathogens. Field observations in Florida indicated that growing strawberry plants in soils with low N levels reduced the severity of anthracnose, although this also severely limited fruit production. Both the form of nitrogen and calcium levels influence disease severity. For instance, calcium has been employed to manage soil-borne diseases caused by Pythium spp. on various crops, while nitrate forms of N have been shown to suppress Fusarium wilt in tomatoes, whereas ammonium forms increase disease severity.', 0.5725357532501221]]
Context 3: [['Strawberry anthracnose, caused mainly by the Colletotrichum acutatum species complex, is a significant disease affecting strawberry production. Surveys were conducted, and isolates were collected from affected areas, specifically strawberry nurseries and production fields in six states across the United States. The use of fungicides, particularly quinone outside inhibitors (QoIs), has been widely employed for controlling C. acutatum for the past 20 years. Resistance to QoIs was first reported in Florida in 2013, and subsequent anthracnose outbreaks occurred in strawberry nurseries and production fields throughout the U.S. in 2015. Fungicide use surveys indicated that, in certain locations, the number of QoI applications exceeded the recommended levels for this fungicide group. This situation necessitates immediate changes in anthracnose management strategies to incorporate other chemical and non-chemical approaches, aiming to limit the selection of resistant populations and prevent future outbreaks.', 0.5522065758705139]]
Context 4: [['Economic losses due to strawberry anthracnose have been significant. Additionally, complete host resistance is not commercially available, and there is known fungal resistance to 155 fungicides. Consumer and environmental concerns about fungicide use are also increasing.', 0.25305020809173584]]
Context 5: [['Smith, B.J., & Black, L.L. (1991). Greenhouse efficacy of fungicides for control of anthracnose crown rot of strawberry. In A. Dale & J. Lubby (Eds.), The Strawberry into the 21st Century (pp. 221–223). Timber Press, Portland, OR.', 0.25266575813293457]]

query: What are the comparative benefits of heat treatment versus chemical treatments for managing plant diseases?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['In addition to chemical treatments, heat treatment of transplants may reduce mortality from anthracnose, but this practice is not widely used due to its potential to reduce plant vigor (Freeman et al., 1997). In-season fungicide spray applications are common to prevent foliar and fruit infections (Koike et al., 2008; MacKenzie and Peres, 2012), but these are ineffective against crown rot and root necrosis (Daugovish et al., 2009).', 0.9481650590896606]]
Context 1: [['In the United States, a standard heat treatment (5 minutes at 49°C) is practiced for bare-rooted transplants to control foliar nematodes and anthracnose. In this study, the heat treatment did not visibly harm transplants and significantly reduced mortality caused by C. acutatum. However, it may adversely affect plant vigor, especially for transplants meant for production fields. While this treatment could serve as an alternative to chemical fungicides, its long-term impacts on plant development and yield require further investigation. Nonchemical control methods might help minimize the emergence of fungicide-tolerant or resistant fungal strains.', 0.9114125967025757]]

Context 2: [['Although strawberries are considered a minor crop, they provide a significant source of income for many fruit and nursery growers. Florida ranks second only to California in the production of fresh-market strawberries. For U.S. winter production (December through March), strawberries are grown on approximately 2,400 hectares. The major cultural problems faced by the Florida strawberry industry include: 1) anthracnose diseases, 2) yearly infestations of the two-spotted spider mite (Tetranychus urticae Koch), and 3) variability in the quality of nursery transplants. Commercial fields are established annually, similar to California practices. Freshly dug transplants are sourced from nurseries in Florida or from northern states and Canada. Context 1: [['Increased losses due to anthracnose fruit and crown rots may be related to the shift from matted-row culture to the annual plasticulture production system in the United States. Context 5: [['Until highly resistant cultivars are available, growers must rely on chemical applications and cultural practices to reduce losses due to anthracnose. However, the anthracnose pathogens, C. acutatum and C. fragariae, developed resistance to it and other benzimidazole fungicides (LaMondia, 1995; McInnes et al., 1992a; Smith and Black, 1992, 1993), rendering benomyl ineffective for anthracnose control in strawberry fields.', 0.1533382683992386]]

query: How does MAFFT address the problem of sequence alignment in the context of evolutionary models, particularly in species with distant common ancestors?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Multiple sequence alignment (MSA) plays a crucial role in the evolutionary analysis of biological sequences. MAFFT is an MSA program first released in 2002 (Katoh et al. 2002). Due to its high performance (Nuin et al. 2006; Golubchik et al. 2007; Dessimoz and Gil 2010; Letsch et al. 2010; Sahraeian and Yoon 2011; Sievers et al. 2011), MAFFT has gained popularity in recent years. Following the review of the previous version (version 6) by Katoh and Toh (2008b), we have continuously enhanced its accuracy, speed, and utility in practical applications. These improvements and techniques have been documented in various papers (Katoh et al. 2009; Katoh and Toh 2010; Katoh and Frith 2012; Katoh and Standley 2013).', 0.893145740032196]]
Context 1: [['All options in MAFFT assume that the input sequences are homologous, meaning they are derived from a common ancestor during evolution. Consequently, all characters in the input data are aligned. The software does not account for genomic rearrangements or domain shuffling, ensuring that the order of characters in each sequence is preserved, although sequences can be reordered based on similarity. Most MAFFT options presume that nearly all pairs in the input sequences can be aligned, either locally or globally, which introduces a tradeoff between accuracy and speed. For instance, the PartTree option (Katoh and Toh 2007) is a quick but less precise method, while L-INS-i and G-INS-i are slower yet more accurate. RNA structural alignment methods are typically more accurate but computationally more demanding due to additional calculations required.', 0.8312987089157104]]
Context 2: [['Katoh K, Standley DM. MAFFT Multiple Sequence Alignment Software Version 7: Improvements in performance and usability. Mol Biol Evol 30: 772-780. Article in Molecular Biology and Evolution, January 2013. DOI: 10.1093/molbev/mst010. Source: PubMed.', 0.6090271472930908]]
Context 3: [['According to a recent comparative study based on the MetAl metric (Blackburne and Whelan 2012a, 2012b), there are two significantly different classes of multiple sequence alignment (MSA) methods: similarity-based and profile-based methods. MAFFT has a subprogram, mafft-profile, to align two existing alignments. This method separately converts the first alignment (alignment1) and the second alignment (alignment2) into profiles and then aligns the two profiles. This means that the two input alignments are assumed to be phylogenetically isolated from each other, as shown in Figure 1A. Careless application of this method can result in serious misalignments, as discussed in a later section.', 0.46544817090034485]]
Context 4: [['Katoh K, Misawa K, Kuma K, Miyata T. 2002. MAFFT: a novel method for rapid multiple sequence alignment based on fast Fourier transform. Nucleic Acids Res. 30:3059–3066.', 0.44043418765068054]]
Context 5: [['Katoh, K., Misawa, K., Kuma, K., Miyata, T. (2002). MAFFT: a novel method for rapid multiple sequence alignment on fast Fourier transform. Nucleic Acids Research, 30:3059–3066.', 0.43225914239883423]]
Context 6: [['We have discussed potential improvements in multiple sequence alignments (MSAs) of closely related sequences earlier. However, MSAs of distantly related sequences remain a challenging problem.', 0.40325191617012024]]
Context 7: [['The MAFFT profile program is not suitable for certain applications. There are two types of misapplications to consider. The first type involves the following steps: 1) convert an existing alignment to a profile, 2) align new sequences and convert them to a profile, and 3) align the two profiles. This procedure is inappropriate for adding new sequences because it assumes a phylogenetic relationship, as illustrated in Figure 1A.', 0.3889155983924866]]
Context 8: [['We report a major update of the MAFFT multiple sequence alignment program. This version introduces several new features, including options for adding unaligned sequences into an existing alignment, adjusting the direction of nucleotide alignment, performing constrained alignments, and utilizing parallel processing. These features were implemented following the previous major update. This report provides actual examples to illustrate how these features operate, both individually and in combination. Additionally, some examples of sequences incorrectly aligned by MAFFT are presented to highlight its limitations. We discuss strategies to avoid misalignments and our ongoing efforts to address these challenges.', 0.3773733675479889]]
Context 9: [['Katoh K, Toh H. (2008). Recent Developments in the MAFFT Multiple Sequence Alignment Program. Briefings in Bioinformatics 9, 276–285.', 0.3231428265571594]]

query: How do researchers utilize the morphological features of Colletotrichum to differentiate between species in their studies?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Traditionally, Colletotrichum species are identified based on morphological characteristics, including conidial and appressorial size and shape, the presence of acervuli, setae, or sclerotia, sexual structures, and cultural traits such as growth rate and colony color. Distinguishing Colletotrichum species morphologically has been challenging due to their phenotypic similarities and the influence of variable environmental factors on the expression of morphological traits. Consequently, all available morphological characteristics are often combined and used for systematic species discrimination.', 0.9763897657394409]]
Context 1: [['Traditional identification systems in Colletotrichum have heavily relied on morphological and cultural characteristics (von Arx, 1957; Sutton, 1980, 1992; Bailey and Jeger, 1992; Freeman et al., 1998). Sutton (1992) noted that morphology alone does not provide sufficient information for precise identification, especially for species within the C. gloeosporioides and C. dematium complexes. Crouch et al. (2009b) argued that conidial size and shape, along with conidial appressoria, were taxonomically uninformative and of limited use for species diagnosis in graminicolous Colletotrichum species. Species with similar morphological characteristics may exhibit considerable variation at the physiological and pathogenic levels, making this recognition crucial for biosecurity, plant breeding, and integrated disease management. Taxonomy based solely on morphology is likely to result in ambiguity. Recent studies have shown that morphological characters should be used in conjunction with other characters to establish species relationships within Colletotrichum (Crouch et al., 2009b; Prihastuti et al., 2009).', 0.972989559173584]]
Context 2: [['Despite significant developments over the last ten years, the taxonomy of Colletotrichum is in a state of flux. Many uncertainties exist in the systematics of fungal pathogens from this genus; depending on the taxonomic "guides," the number of species can range from 29 to over 700 (von Arx, 1957; Sutton, 1992). One of the most confusing species is C. gloeosporioides. For example, 594 species of Colletotrichum were reclassified by von Arx as synonyms of C. gloeosporioides. Identification has primarily relied on morphological characteristics of conidia, vegetative and sexual structures, as well as host specificity and cultural characteristics (von Arx, 1957). Unfortunately, conidial morphology and colony characteristics vary even within isolates. Consequently, classical methods have been supplemented with biochemical and molecular technologies to differentiate Colletotrichum species (J. W. Kronstad, ed., Fungal Pathology, 127-148. © 2000 Kluwer Academic Publishers). For a more complete discussion of this topic, see Sherriff et al. (1994).', 0.9711933732032776]]
Context 3: [['Species concepts in Colletotrichum have evolved from the use of basic morphological data to a polyphasic approach that incorporates a significant molecular component. This evolution has made traditional classifications less practical, as holotypes and other types are not very useful since DNA cannot usually be extracted. It is recommended that future studies adopt a polyphasic approach before introducing new species of Colletotrichum or designating epitypes. This approach should integrate molecular, morphological, physiological, and pathogenic data.', 0.9436565041542053]]
Context 4: [['Before the molecular era, the taxonomy of Colletotrichum species was primarily based on morphological and cultural characteristics, including conidia size and shape, presence or absence of setae, colony color, and growth rate (von Arx 1957; Sutton 1980, 1992). However, these characteristics can be unreliable for species differentiation due to variability under changing environmental conditions (Cai et al. 2009).', 0.8961560726165771]]
Context 5: [['In a drastic move, von Arx (1957) reduced the number of recognized Colletotrichum species from several hundred to 11 based on morphological characteristics, with many taxa treated as synonyms of C. gloeosporioides and C. dematium. Several additional species have since been accepted based on morphological criteria (Sutton, 1980; 1992). The difficulties in recognizing Colletotrichum species can be attributed to: 1) the limited and variable morphological characters; 2) an extensive host range and variability in pathogenicity (Bailey and Jeger, 1992; Freeman et al., 2000; Latunde-Dada, 2001; Du et al., 2005; Thaung, 2008); 3) type specimens that are often missing or in poor condition, making them unsuitable for molecular studies; and 4) numerous rDNA ITS sequences of Colletotrichum strains in NCBI that are often misidentified (Crouch et al., 2009d; Damm et al., 2009).', 0.8767247796058655]]
Context 6: [['Citation: Cai, L., Hyde, K.D., Taylor, P.W.J., Weir, B.S., Waller, J., Abang, M.M., Zhang, J.Z., Yang, Y.L., Phoulivong, S., Liu, Z.Y., Prihastuti, H., Shivas, R.G., McKenzie, E.H.C., Johnston, P.R. (2009). A polyphasic approach for studying Colletotrichum. Fungal Diversity, 39: 183-204.', 0.6979819536209106]]
Context 7: [['Photita, W., Taylor, P. W., Ford, R., Hyde, K. D., and Lumyong, S. (2005). Morphological and molecular characterization of Colletotrichum species from...', 0.5493339896202087]]
Context 8: [['Cano, J., Guarro, J., and Gene, J. (2004). Molecular and morphological identification of Colletotrichum species of clinical interest. Journal of Clinical Microbiology 42: 2450-2454.', 0.5232288837432861]]
Context 9: [['To validate the taxonomy of Colletotrichum species through morphological characteristics and DNA phylogenetic analysis.', 0.5108005404472351]]

Context 1: [['Notes: Sequence comparisons with six genes (ITS, GAPDH, ACT, CAL, TUB2, CHS-1) indicate that 46 of the isolates in this study group with C. karstii (not shown). Colletotrichum karstii was recently described from a leaf of Vanda sp. (Orchidaceae) in China and has been reported on several other orchids (Yang et al. 2011). It is known to occur on many host plants and is the most common and geographically diverse species in the C. boninense complex. Previously, Colletotrichum karstii was referred to as C. gloeosporioides groups F and G by Johnston & Jones (1997), who also listed Persea americana and Cucurbita spp. as host plants. Earlier works have cited isolates of C. boninense that are now identified as C. karstii, including those detailed in the original description (Morikawi et al. 2003), some in Farr et al. (2006), and all in Lubbe et al. (2004). Additionally, some isolates from Passiflora edulis in Brazil that caused anthracnose on passion fruits (Tozze et al. 2010) were identified as C. karstii based on GAPDH sequences (GenBank accessions FJ949450 and FJ949452, not included in the phylogeny).', 0.953472375869751]]

Context 5: [['Although four isolates from Indonesia were identified as C. karsti in the boninense complex, they formed a subclade within the C. karsti species clade and exhibited different conidial sizes compared to the ex-type strain of C. karsti (Yang et al. 2011), suggesting the possibility of a new species. However, insufficient phylogenetic support was observed in the individual gene trees to justify the introduction of a novel species. Additionally, Damm et al. (2012a, 2012b) reported that the conidium size of C. karsti is quite variable. Colletotrichum karsti has been reported from China and India, causing anthracnose disease in Capsicum spp. (Liu et al. 2016b; Saini et al. 2016; Diao et al. 2017). It has the widest known host range and distribution of all species in the boninense complex (Damm et al. 2012b). Most C. karsti strains have been isolated as endophytes, although a few were derived from diseased plant tissues.
