query: Can you identify specific crops that might benefit from the higher cation exchange capacity (CEC) of organic matter in soils with a certain pH range?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Many minerals in soils are negatively charged and can attract and retain cations such as potassium (K), sodium (Na), calcium (Ca), magnesium (Mg), and ammonium (NH₄). Cation exchange is a reversible process, allowing nutrients to be held in the soil and not lost through leaching, with the potential for subsequent release for crop uptake. Certain organic compounds contribute to cation exchange capacity (CEC). The presence of high concentrations of Ca, especially in the form of gypsum, can interfere with the determination of CEC, which is crucial for soil fertility and mineralogical characterization. Additionally, CEC is influenced by soil pH. A certain portion of the total negative charge is permanent, while a variable portion is pH-dependent.', 0.9538535475730896]]
Context 1: [['The significance of pH lies in its influence on the availability of soil nutrients, solubility of toxic nutrient elements, physical breakdown of root cells, and cation exchange capacity (CEC) in soils where colloids (clay/humus) are pH-dependent, as well as biological activity. At high pH values, the availability of phosphorus and most micronutrients (except boron and molybdenum) tends to decrease.', 0.6128547787666321]]
Context 2: [['Rhoades, J. D. 1982. Cation Exchange Capacity. In A. L. Page (ed.), Methods of Soil Analysis, Agronomy No. 9, Part 2: Chemical and Mineralogical Properties. American Society of Agronomy, Madison, WI, USA, pp. 149–157.', 0.37138962745666504]]
Context 3: [['We initially present analyses that are routinely performed to characterize a soil sample or type, including background information such as pH, salinity, calcium carbonate (CaCO3), organic matter (OM), cation exchange capacity (CEC), and gypsum (CaSO4·2H2O). Regarding nitrogen, the dominant fertility factor in soils, we discuss the most convenient methods for measuring various forms or fractions of nitrogen. This is followed by procedures for phosphorus, soluble and exchangeable cations, soluble anions, and micronutrients. Guidelines for interpreting the data produced from the analytical procedures are provided where appropriate (see Appendix 9).', 0.3165554404258728]]
Context 4: [['Rhoades, J. D., and Polemio, M. 1977. Determining Cation Exchange Capacity: A New Procedure for Calcareous and Gypsiferous Soils. Soil Science Society of America Journal 41: 524–530.', 0.2523235082626343]]
Context 5: [["The soil's ability to supply these nutrients to plants.", 0.19414162635803223]]
Context 6: [['Cation exchange capacity is reported as centimoles per kilogram of soil.', 0.17936989665031433]]
Context 7: [['Soil testing has become an intrinsic part of modern farming practices in the West and in many developing countries. These tests primarily focus on the essential nutrients demanded by crops, which are typically supplied by fertilizers: nitrogen (N), phosphorus (P), and potassium (K). In some regions, particularly based on soil types, tests may also include secondary nutrients like calcium (Ca), magnesium (Mg), and sulfur (S). In arid areas, micronutrients such as iron (Fe), zinc (Zn), manganese (Mn), copper (Cu), and boron (B) are frequently measured, as deficiencies of these elements are often associated with calcareous soils. Furthermore, such regions may experience excessive or toxic levels of certain elements, such as boron (B) or high concentrations of sodium (Na) and magnesium (Mg), which can adversely affect soil physical properties. Because nutrient behavior in soils is influenced by soil properties and environmental conditions, measuring these properties is essential. Key measurements include pH, salinity, organic matter (OM), calcium carbonate (CaCO3), as well as texture and aggregate stability. In drier regions, the presence of gypsum (CaSO4·2H2O) is also a concern.', 0.17929679155349731]]
Context 8: [['Soil cation exchange capacity is near 100% base saturation.', 0.17139069736003876]]
Context 9: [['It is important to emphasize that a soil test, even if reliable and accurate, is only one factor in making fertilization decisions. Numerous other factors affect crop growth and yield, including soil type and environmental conditions such as moisture and temperature. Due to the varying forms of nutrients in soils (e.g., calcareous vs. acidic soils), soil tests can be quite diverse, particularly for available phosphorus and micronutrients, and to a lesser extent for nitrogen (Walsh and Beaton, 1973; Page et al., 1982; Sparks et al., 1966). Nitrogen, being mobile in soils and subject to mineralization and immobilization, presents specific challenges in establishing a reliable test. In contrast, tests for potassium (K), pH, organic matter (OM), and calcium carbonate (CaCO3) are more straightforward.', 0.1536858230829239]]

query: What can I do if my current fungicides are not working on my strawberries?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Past failures of fungicides to control anthracnose epidemics may have stemmed from the development of resistance in the Colletotrichum population. In the early 1970s, benomyl effectively reduced anthracnose crown rot incidence (Horn et al., 1972; Howard, 1971) and was widely used by strawberry growers for years. However, anthracnose pathogens developed resistance to it and other benzimidazole fungicides, rendering benomyl ineffective. In vitro and greenhouse trials have been conducted to identify fungicides to which Colletotrichum pathogens have developed resistance (LaMondia, 1993, 1995; McInnes et al., 1992a, 1992b; Smith and Black, 1991, 1992, 1993). Current fungicide labels address pathogen resistance by restricting the number of consecutive and total applications of a product per season. For instance, the fungicides Abound (azoxystrobin, Syngenta, Greensboro, NC), Cabrio (pyraclostrobin, BASF, Research Triangle Park, NC), and Pristine (pyraclostrobin and boscalid, BASF) are limited to four or five applications per season, with no more than two consecutive applications before alternating with a fungicide that has a different mode of action. Natural products have also been evaluated as alternative fungicides, offering different modes of action, lower toxicity, and increased efficacy (Abril et al., 2008).', 0.7114839553833008]]
Context 1: [['Additionally, multisite fungicides such as captan, thiram, and chlorothalonil, which have been available for many decades, remain effective in reducing strawberry anthracnose incidence (Mertely et al. 2018). Chlorothalonil is only registered for nonbearing nurseries when flowers and fruit are absent, yet our surveys indicated that its usage is significantly lower compared to newer single-site fungicides. Due to their efficacy and low resistance risk, multisite fungicides should be the mainstay for disease control in strawberry nurseries. Other non-chemical alternatives, such as heat (Wang et al. 2017) and ultraviolet treatments (Onofre et al. 2017), are currently under investigation and could serve as valuable tools for disease management, reducing the reliance on single-site fungicides.', 0.6694579720497131]]
Context 2: [['Finally, it is important to emphasize that strawberry production in Brazil remains heavily dependent on fungicide applications, which are not completely effective for anthracnose control and raise consumer concerns about food safety. Our study indicates that managing flower blight can be quite effective through a combination of cultural choices, which could potentially reduce dependency on chemical controls.', 0.5787334442138672]]
Context 3: [['The experimental fungicide pydiflumetofen was not effective against C. acutatum in our in vitro and field studies. However, this fungicide is very active against B. cinerea and has shown high efficacy in reducing powdery mildew in strawberries (J. E. Adaskaveg, unpublished). The pydiflumetofen-fludioxonil premixture was among the most effective of our preplant dip treatments for crown rot in strawberries, likely due to the fludioxonil component. Therefore, this premixture has potential as a broad-spectrum post-plant field fungicide for strawberries.', 0.562638521194458]]
Context 4: [['Strawberry anthracnose, caused mainly by the Colletotrichum acutatum species complex, is a significant disease affecting strawberry production. Surveys were conducted, and isolates were collected from affected areas, specifically strawberry nurseries and production fields in six states across the United States. The use of fungicides, particularly quinone outside inhibitors (QoIs), has been widely employed for controlling C. acutatum for the past 20 years. Resistance to QoIs was first reported in Florida in 2013, and subsequent anthracnose outbreaks occurred in strawberry nurseries and production fields throughout the U.S. in 2015. Fungicide use surveys indicated that, in certain locations, the number of QoI applications exceeded the recommended levels for this fungicide group. This situation necessitates immediate changes in anthracnose management strategies to incorporate other chemical and non-chemical approaches, aiming to limit the selection of resistant populations and prevent future outbreaks.', 0.5153902173042297]]
Context 5: [['Smith, B.J. and L.L. Black. 1991. Greenhouse efficacy of fungicides for control of anthracnose crown rot of strawberry, p. 221-223. In: A. Dale and J. Luby (eds.). The Strawberry into the 21st Century. Timber Press, Portland, OR.', 0.4247809946537018]]
Context 6: [['Smith, B.J., & Black, L.L. (1991). Greenhouse efficacy of fungicides for control of anthracnose crown rot of strawberry. In A. Dale & J. Lubby (Eds.), The Strawberry into the 21st Century (pp. 221–223). Timber Press, Portland, OR.', 0.4110794961452484]]
Context 7: [['Smith, B.J., & Black, L.L. (1991). Greenhouse efficacy of fungicides for control of anthracnose crown rot of strawberry, pp. 221–223. In A. Dale & J. Lubby (Eds.), The strawberry into the 21st century. Timber Press, Portland, OR.', 0.40066012740135193]]
Context 8: [['In summary, while captafol demonstrated fungicidal activity against strawberry anthracnose, other fungicides like benomyl and maneb have shown reduced effectiveness in recent years, necessitating the ongoing evaluation of control strategies for this pervasive disease.', 0.39581552147865295]]
Context 9: [['Nam, M. H.; Kim, H. S.; Nam, Y. G.; Peres, N. A.; Kim, H. G. (2011). Fungicide spray program to reduce application in anthracnose of strawberry. Research Plant Disease, 17(3), 295-301.', 0.3766964375972748]]

query: How was Colletotrichum boninense identified?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['None of the morphological characters of C. boninense allow for unequivocal identification, and misplacement of strains based solely on morphology is common. For instance, Lu et al. (2004) classified one isolate as C. gloeosporioides based on morphological features but re-identified it as C. boninense using molecular techniques. Colletotrichum dracaenae Petch (here epitypified and renamed as C. petchii) was considered a synonym of C. gloeosporioides by von Arx (1957). Our study indicates that C. petchii does not belong to C. gloeosporioides s. lat. but rather to the C. boninense species complex, although its conidia largely resemble those of C. gloeosporioides with their relatively large length/width ratio.', 0.9834040999412537]]
Context 1: [['Lee, H.B., Park, J.Y., and Jung, H.S. (2005). Identification, growth, and pathogenicity of Colletotrichum boninense causing leaf anthracnose on Japanese spindle tree. Plant Pathology Journal 21: 27-32.', 0.9788082838058472]]
Context 2: [['Damm U, Cannon PF, Woudenberg JH, Johnston PR, and Weir BS et al. (2012) examined the Colletotrichum boninense species complex in Studies in Mycology (73: 1-36). Prihastuti H, Cai L, Chen H, McKenzie EHC, and Hyde KD (2009) characterized Colletotrichum species associated with coffee berries in northern Thailand, as discussed in Fungal Diversity (39: 89-109).', 0.9692848920822144]]
Context 3: [['Although recently described, Colletotrichum boninense is well established in the literature as an anthracnose pathogen or endophyte of various host plants worldwide. It is especially prominent on members of Amaryllidaceae, Orchidaceae, Proteaceae, and Solanaceae. Reports from literature and preliminary studies using ITS sequence data indicated that C. boninense represents a species complex. A multilocus molecular phylogenetic analysis (ITS, ACT, TUB2, CHS-1, GAPDH, HIS3, CAL) of 86 strains previously identified as C. boninense and other related strains revealed 18 clades. These clades are recognized here as separate species, including C. boninense s. str., C. hippeastri, C. karstii, and 12 previously undescribed species: C. annellatum, C. beeveri, C. brassicicola, C. brasiliense, C. colombiense, C. constrictum, C. cymbidiicola, C. dacrycarpi, C. novae-zelandiae, C. oncidii, C. parsonsiae, and C. torulosum. Seven of the new species are known only from New Zealand, possibly reflecting a sampling bias. The new combination C. phyllanthi was established, and C. dracaenae Petch was epitypified and renamed as C. petchii. Typical for species of the C. boninense species complex are conidiogenous cells with prominent periclinal thickening, which may extend to form a new conidiogenous locus or annellations, and conidia featuring a prominent basal scar. Many species in the C. boninense complex form teleomorphs in culture.', 0.9592188000679016]]
Context 4: [['Molecular identities at the ITS, GPDH, β-tubulin, CAL, Actin, and CHS I loci have been studied for the species of Colletotrichum on Amaryllidaceae. Previously recorded species include Colletotrichum boninense (MAFF 3060 94, CBS 119185, CBS 241.78), C. capsici (IMI 233426; synonymy with C. truncatum), C. crassipes (IMI 165604, IMI 304052, IMI 259839), and C. dematium (IMI 208403, IMI 124329) associated with anthracnose in Amaryllidaceae. Notably, C. boninense has been documented as the causal agent of anthracnose on Dracaena sanderiana and Euonymus japonica, as well as an endophyte in various hosts worldwide. Recent research suggests that C. boninense may represent a species complex.', 0.9336372017860413]]
Context 5: [['Notes: The four isolates identified from Indonesia in the Colletotrichum boninense complex produced distinct short conidia compared to the ex-epitype culture of C. karsti (14.5–17 × 5–6.5 µm; Yang et al., 2011). However, high variability in conidia size among different strains of C. karsti was reported by Damm et al. (2012a, 2012b), where the conidia measurements of CBS 129833 were (11.5–)12.5–14(−14.5) × (5–)5.5–6(−6.5) µm, with mean ± SD = 13.1 ± 0.7 × 5.8 ± 0.4 µm. Additionally, CBS 111998 had a conidium length of up to 18.5 µm, with an L/W ratio of 2.8. These isolates did not form a sexual morph in culture. Although these four isolates formed a fully supported (100% bootstrap support / 1 posterior probability) subclade within C. karsti, all individual gene trees (data not shown) did not provide significant support to justify introducing a cryptic species for these isolates.', 0.9186702966690063]]
Context 6: [['Damm, U., Cannon, P. F., Woudenberg, J. H. C., Johnston, P. R., Weir, B. S., Tan, Y. P., Shivas, R. G., and Crous, P. W. (2012b). The Colletotrichum boninense species complex. Stud. Mycol., 73, 1-36.', 0.9128950238227844]]
Context 7: [['Colletotrichum boninense Moriwaki, Toy. Sato & Tsukib. This species occurs on the leaves of Crinum asiaticum, presenting as reddish-brown, ellipsoid to irregular spots and forming pink conidial masses with rare setae (Fig. 6A). In this study, although the conidia of C. boninense (CSSN1 and CSSX8) are wider than those of the holotype and paratype, their shape and cultural characteristics are similar, and they cluster in one clade with high bootstrap support (there is one base difference in the ITS sequence among them and the holotype). Additionally, the holotype and paratype of C. boninense were collected from Crinum asiaticum var. sinicum in Japan.', 0.9089139699935913]]
Context 8: [['Moriwaki J, Sato T, Tsukiboshi T. Morphological and molecular characterization of Colletotrichum boninense sp. nov. from Japan. Mycoscience. 2003; 44: 47–53. https://doi.org/10.1007/S10267-002-0079-7.', 0.9078399538993835]]
Context 9: [['A detailed study of the C. boninense complex has revealed that even recently recognized species of Colletotrichum may obscure extensive molecular variation and may contain multiple taxa with distinct evolutionary origins. The ongoing debate regarding whether these segregate taxa should be classified at the species or infraspecific level (Cannon et al. 2008) remains unresolved. However, recent trends favor recognizing them as independent species. This approach simplifies nomenclature but may limit practical value for applied mycologists and plant pathologists, as the names do not necessarily indicate host specificity or nutritional/biological strategies. Unfortunately, many of these species cannot currently be reliably identified using single diagnostic (barcoding) sequences, making this aspect of their systematics a high priority for future research. On a positive note, there is now significantly more information regarding the phylogenetic components of the C. boninense complex.', 0.9009729027748108]]

Context 1: [['Colletotrichum acutatum J.H. Simmonds is a common pathogen affecting a wide range of crops and non-cultivated plant species. The fungus is cosmopolitan and causes significant crop losses annually. Symptoms of the disease can include fruit rots, as well as shoot, leaf, and flower blights. Common hosts encompass many dicotyledonous plants, including strawberries, apples, citrus, and stone fruits; serious diseases have also been reported on leatherleaf ferns and pines. Notably, there are no known reports of C. acutatum affecting grasses. While well-documented from agricultural hosts, recent findings of C. acutatum in a moribund sea turtle and a native forest suggest it may inhabit other less-studied niches.', 0.44512948393821716]]

query: How do the methods of data analysis employed in this study compare to traditional approaches in phylogenetic research?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['An overview of the Apn2/MAT locus map is provided in FIG. 3, alongside the phylogenetic informativeness profiles on a per-site basis for the seven molecular markers employed in this study (in arbitrary units). The parsimony informative percentages for the new markers were 35% for ApMAT, 19% for Apn25L, 20% for MAT5L, and 17% for MAT1-2-1. In contrast, traditional markers yielded lower values: 3% for ITS, 13% for b-tub2, and 16% for GS. Regarding the combined datasets, even when excluding MAT1-2-1 to balance the sequence lengths, the Apn-MAT dataset exhibited 478 parsimony informative characters from a total of 1,886 (25%), while traditional markers contributed only 232 informative characters from a total of 1,965 (12%).', 0.42346376180648804]]
Context 1: [['Table II presents key metrics for each dataset, including the length in base pairs (bp), the number and percentage of parsimony informative sites (PI; %PI), estimated nucleotide diversity (p), and the model of sequence evolution. This information highlights the comparative performance of the newly developed markers against traditional markers, providing insight into their utility in phylogenetic analysis.', 0.3558560013771057]]
Context 2: [['Consensus sequences from the sequences generated using forward and reverse primers were obtained using DNAStar v.5.1 and SeqMan v.5.00 (Burland, 2000). A combined dataset of the five gene regions was prepared using Clustal X v.1.81 (Thompson et al., 1997). Further alignment of sequences was achieved using default settings in MAFFT v.7 (Katoh & Toh, 2008, http://mafft.cbrc.jp/alignment/server/), and manual adjustments were made using BioEdit v.7.0.9.0 (Hall, 1999) where necessary. Two separate phylogenetic trees were constructed: one for the acutatum species complex and another for the gloeosporioides species complex. Maximum Parsimony analysis (MP) was performed using PAUP v. 4.0b10 (Swofford, 2002) to obtain the most parsimonious trees. Gaps were treated as missing data, and ambiguously aligned regions were excluded. Trees were inferred using the heuristic search option with Tree Bisection Reconnection (TBR) branch swapping and 1,000 random sequence additions. A maximum of 5,000 trees were set up, branches of zero length were collapsed, and all multiple parsimonious trees were saved. Descriptive tree statistics for parsimony—Tree Length (TL), Consistency Index (CI), Retention Index (RI), Rescaled Consistency Index (RC), and Homoplasy Index (HI)—were calculated for trees generated under different optimality criteria. The robustness of the most parsimonious trees was evaluated by 1,000 bootstrap replications resulting from the maximum parsimony analysis (Hillis & Bull, 1993). Kishino-Hasegawa tests (KHT) (Kishino & Hasegawa, 1989) were performed to determine whether the trees were significantly different. Bayesian inference (BI) was also employed to construct the phylogenies using MrBayes v.3.1.2 (Ronquist et al., 2003). MrModeltest v.2.3 (Nylander, 2004) was used to select the best-fit model of nucleotide substitution. The HYK+I model was selected for ITS, a HKY+G model for GAPDH and β-tubulin, a K80+I+G model for CHS-1, and a GTR+G model for ACT were incorporated into the analysis. Six simultaneous Markov chains were run for 1,000,000 generations, and trees were sampled every 100th generation. The 2,000 trees representing the burn-in phase of the analyses were discarded, and the remaining 8,000 trees were used to calculate posterior probabilities (PP) in the majority rule consensus tree. The alignments and trees are deposited in TreeBASE (Sanderson et al., 1994) under accession number S20238.', 0.2238209843635559]]
Context 3: [['The species we accept are based on a phylogenetic species concept, with all species forming strongly supported, monophyletic clades within our multigene phylogenies. However, not all terminal clades are recognized as named species. In most cases, any well-supported within-species phylogenetic structure evident in the multigene phylogeny is not resolved consistently across all gene trees. This lack of congruence between gene trees indicates that the diversity being sampled is below the species level, according to the logic of the genealogical concordance phylogenetic species recognition (GCPSR) concept (Taylor et al. 2000). Although concatenating gene sequences is a convenient way to present multigene data, it can mask discordance between individual gene phylogenies. An alternative method, using a species-tree approach (Figs. 3, 4B, 5B), combines multi-gene data from multiple isolates hypothesized to represent a single species, allowing for the estimation of the evolutionary history of the species rather than that of individual isolates. Fig. 3 shows the results of such an analysis for the C. gloeosporioides complex, while Figs. 4B and 5B illustrate relationships within the Musae and Kahawae clades, respectively, at an expanded scale. Posterior probabilities for some of the speciation events are low, particularly within the Musae and Kahawae clades. This may be because, while species-tree algorithms account for incomplete lineage sorting (Heled & Drummond 2010, Chung & Ané 2011), most do not compensate for horizontal gene transfer, reassortment, or introgression. Hybridization could also result in discordant gene phylogenies. Hybrids are known in the C. acutatum complex, such as Glomerella acutata, a hybrid formed by crossing C. acutatum and C. fioriniae strains in the laboratory, as well as a putative hybrid strain collected from terminal crook disease on Pinus in New Zealand, where both species coexist in nature (Damm et al. 2012a, this issue). Hybrids also form in the C. gloeosporioides complex, such as the Carya and Aeschynomene populations discussed by Cisar et al. (1994), which are more or less genetically equivalent to our species within the C. gloeosporioides complex.', 0.20386365056037903]]
Context 4: [['Huson, D.H., & Bryant, D. (2006). Application of phylogenetic networks in evolutionary studies. Molecular Biology and Evolution, 23, 254–267.', 0.20186254382133484]]

query: Why is it important to study the phylogenetic relationships among Colletotrichum species?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Jayawardena RS, Hyde KD, Jeewon R, Liu XH, Liu M, Yan JY. (2016). Why is it Important to Correctly Name Colletotrichum Species? Mycosphere (This issue - [http://doi 10.5943/mycosphere/si/1c/1](http://doi 10.5943/mycosphere/si/1c/1)).', 0.9887579679489136]]
Context 1: [['Overall, the study investigates the genetic diversity and specificity of Colletotrichum species through molecular techniques, contributing to a better understanding of their phylogenetic relationships.', 0.980923056602478]]
Context 2: [['The identification of Colletotrichum species has long been challenging due to limited morphological characteristics. Single-gene phylogenetic analyses have also proven unsuccessful in clearly delineating species, partly due to the high number of erroneous names in GenBank. This paper reviews the taxonomic problems associated with Colletotrichum and the difficulties in identifying taxa at the species level. We advocate for epitypification and the use of multi-locus phylogenetic methods to better delimit species and understand the genus.', 0.9141420722007751]]
Context 3: [['Disentangling species complexes within the Colletotrichum genus presents a significant challenge for taxonomists. Given the global importance of this genus, primarily consisting of plant pathogens, it is critical to accurately identify species and/or pathotypes to enhance biosecurity and disease control efforts. Traditional methods of species identification have relied on morphological, cultural, and host-preference criteria. However, these methods often prove unreliable, leading to unresolved taxonomic issues. As stated by Sutton (1992), relying solely on morphology is insufficient for improving the systematics of species complexes like C. gloeosporioides.', 0.8480571508407593]]
Context 4: [['The same specimen, when grown in the lab under different growth conditions, highlights the need for molecular techniques to separate species of Colletotrichum and to examine genetic variation within and between species and populations (Cai et al. 2009; Hyde et al. 2009; Phoulivong et al. 2010). Recent studies on the systematics of Colletotrichum species have categorized them into nine major clades, along with small clusters and isolated species, which may represent species complexes (Cannon et al. 2012).', 0.8263326287269592]]
Context 5: [['The table presented a detailed overview of several Colletotrichum species, showing their corresponding isolate codes, and highlighted various attributes such as Bayesian posterior probabilities and bootstrap support values from phylogenetic analyses. These metrics provided insight into the phylogenetic relationships and reliability of the species classification within the C. gloeosporioides species complex.', 0.8175975680351257]]
Context 6: [['Although the numerous name changes within the genus Colletotrichum over the next few years may be confusing, establishing a long-term stable taxonomic framework is necessary. The examples provided illustrate many cases where we have no idea whether the correct names were used. The situation is exacerbated by the fact that approximately 86% of names on GenBank under C. gloeosporioides appear to be misidentified. It is impossible to repeat or extend scientific work and compare findings with existing published work if the names applied to species in publications are erroneous. We have no choice but to restudy, revise, and clarify the genus so that the naming of Colletotrichum species will, in the future, be reproducible and precise.', 0.7239846587181091]]
Context 7: [['The Colletotrichum isolates used in this study are listed in Table 3. A total of twenty strains of Colletotrichum were isolated from anthracnose associated with Clivia, Crinum, Hippeastrum, and Hymenocallis (Amaryllidaceae). Morphological examination classified these twenty isolates into six morphogroups, while analysis of the ITS sequence revealed eight phylogenetic lineages (details provided below). For comparison, reference strains of several important Colletotrichum species were included, such as Colletotrichum simmondsii R.G. Shivas & Y.P. Tan (holotype, BRIP 28519), C. truncatum (Schwein.) Andrus & W.D. Moore (CBS 120709), C. coccodes (Wallr.) S. Hughes (CPOS1), C. gloeosporioides (epitype, CBS 953.97), and C. trichellum (Fr.) Duke (HKUCC 10378).', 0.6939218640327454]]
Context 8: [['Based on morphological traits and multilocus phylogenetic analysis, the 52 isolates were assigned to five Colletotrichum species, which included one new taxon (C. miaoliense sp. nov.) (Fig. 4; described in detail below), one newly recorded taxon in strawberry (C. karstii), and three species known to be associated with strawberry anthracnose.', 0.625582218170166]]
Context 9: [['Additionally, we review the clinical aspects of the genus and the use of Colletotrichum species in biotransformations. We emphasize the importance of accurate identification, achievable through comparisons with type specimens and molecular data. We propose the need for consensus on protocols for the description and naming of Colletotrichum species and make predictions for developments in the next five years. This review highlights the critical need for correct strain identification prior to commencing scholarly research.', 0.6217769384384155]]

query: What are the challenges of using ITS sequences for species discrimination in Colletotrichum?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['One of the problems with accurately identifying Colletotrichum species using multigene analysis or barcoding is that many existing sequences in GenBank are incorrectly named. Crouch et al. (2009) revealed a high frequency of misidentification (86%) based on rDNA-ITS sequence similarity comparisons in GenBank within the C. graminicola species complex. Cai et al. (2009) analyzed 343 rDNA-ITS sequences of C. gloeosporioides in GenBank (accessed September 6, 2009) and found that an astounding 86% of these sequences showed considerable evolutionary divergence from the epitype of C. gloeosporioides, most likely representing other species. These error rates are remarkably high and indicate that accurate identification of Colletotrichum species using rDNA-ITS sequence data currently available in GenBank is impossible.', 0.9890134334564209]]
Context 1: [['The ITS (Internal Transcribed Spacer) region is the most widely sequenced area, but concerns exist regarding whether ITS sequence data can provide adequate resolution to differentiate Colletotrichum species. Crouch et al. (2009) revealed a high error rate and a frequency of misidentification (86%) based on ITS sequence similarity comparisons within the C. graminicola species complex. ITS sequence data in the public domain can create significant confusion for end users; sequences are often entered under incorrect specific names and may represent several cryptic species. Identical sequences have frequently been recorded under different names.', 0.9873052835464478]]
Context 2: [['A polyphasic approach combining multilocus phylogenetic analysis with recognizable phenotypic characteristics is recommended for accurate species identification within the Colletotrichum genus. query: What environmental conditions favor the spread of Colletotrichum?

Context 0: [['The genus Colletotrichum is considered one of the top ten important genera of fungal pathogens globally (Dean et al., 2012). Colletotrichum is an ancient fungus that has co-evolved with flowering plants. Plant microfossils of Protocolletotrichum preserved on angiosperm leaf cuticles suggest that the diverse pathogenic strategies of Colletotrichum spp. have been established since the Late Cretaceous period (Kar et al., 2004). Different complexes within the genus may have diverged between 4.8 and 32.2 million years ago (MYA) (Bhunjun et al., 2021). The emergence of agricultural cultivation and the intensive disturbance of natural environments have further driven the diversification of Colletotrichum species. These fungi have adapted to thousands of hosts and can be found as endophytes, pathogens, and saprobes (Freeman et al., 1998; Dean et al., 2012; Hirayama et al., 2018; da Silva et al., 2020; Jayawardena et al., 2020). Currently, a total of 257 Colletotrichum species grouped into 15 complexes and 13 additional singletons have been accepted in this genus.', 0.5543460249900818]]

query: How does anthracnose impact the post-harvest quality of strawberries?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Anthracnose is an important disease of strawberry caused by Colletotrichum spp., which affects foliage, runners, crowns, and fruits (Howard et al., 1992). Three primary fungal pathogens—C. acutatum sensu lato, C. gloeosporioides sensu lato, and C. fragariae—are known to cause anthracnose disease in strawberries (Freeman and Katan, 1997). The crown rot syndrome is characteristic of infections from C. gloeosporioides sensu lato and C. fragariae, while fruit rot is mainly attributed to C. acutatum sensu lato, leading to significant yield losses (Howard et al., 1992). Currently, numerous species are classified under what is now known as the C. acutatum complex, with six species—C. acutatum sensu stricto, C. fioriniae, C. godetiae, C. nymphaeae, C. salicis, and C. simmondsii—identified as associated with strawberry anthracnose worldwide (Damm et al., 2012). Among these, C. nymphaeae is the most prevalent pathogen causing strawberry anthracnose globally, including in Iran (Baroncelli et al., 2015; Karimi et al., 2017; Wang et al., 2019). Currently, no effective chemical control methods exist for managing strawberry anthracnose; available options are limited to preventive treatments applied before fruit production (Denoyes-Rothan et al., 1999). Additionally, concerns about the toxic effects of chemical fungicides on the environment and the development of resistance in fungal strains highlight the need for alternative control strategies. Consequently, utilizing resistant cultivars appears to be the most efficient and practical approach for suppressing anthracnose development. In light of recent anthracnose outbreaks in strawberry fields in the Kurdistan province of Iran (Karimi et al., 2017), and the necessity for appropriate strategies to address this issue, the aim of this study was to evaluate the resistance of several commercial strawberry cultivars to the anthracnose fruit rot caused by C. nymphaeae under in vivo and greenhouse conditions.', 0.8709966540336609]]
Context 1: [["Anthracnose fungi can attack various parts of the strawberry plant, including crowns, petioles, leaves, fruit trusses, flowers, buds, and fruit. The fungi's ability to attack multiple plant parts, coupled with the involvement of several pathogen species, contributes to the complex nature of strawberry anthracnose. Brooks reported in 1931 that C. fragariae caused spotting and girdling of runners, and later indicated that it also caused spotting of petioles and crown rot in a summer nursery, leading to wilting and death of the plants. Researchers in Louisiana observed all these symptoms and noted that crown rot also occurred in the fruit production field.", 0.7094603180885315]]
Context 2: [['De los Santos, B., de Paredes, G., and Munoz, F. R. (2002). Influence of anthracnose epiphytotic development on strawberry fruit production in Huelva (Southwestern Spain). Acta Hortic., 567:623-626.', 0.5965614318847656]]
Context 3: [['De los Santos, B., de Paredes, G., and Munoz, F. R. 2002. Influence of anthracnose epiphytotic development on strawberry fruit production in Huelva (Southwestern Spain). Acta Hortic. 567:623-626.', 0.5524470210075378]]
Context 4: [['Howard CM, Albregts EE. Anthracnose. In: Compendium of Strawberry Diseases. American Phytopathological Society: Paul St, ed. Maas JL, USA; 1984. pp. 85-87.', 0.5370217561721802]]
Context 5: [['So far, anthracnose epidemics have affected strawberry nurseries and production fields worldwide. Reports on Colletotrichum spp. associated with strawberries, curated from literature in PubMed and Clarivate combined with fungal database searches (Farr and Rossman, 2022), were compiled to understand the global diversity and occurrence of the causal agents of strawberry anthracnose. From our findings, since 1931 until July 9, 2022, there have been over 220 citations and 310 records related to the identification of causal agents of strawberry anthracnose at the genus level of Colletotrichum in 36 countries across six continents, with 282 records providing pathogen identification at the species or species complex level.', 0.5061121582984924]]
Context 6: [['Nam MH, Yoo JH, Yun TS, Kim HH, Kim HG. Anthracnose of strawberry: Etiological and ecological characteristics and management. Res Plant Dis 2023;29:205-19.', 0.4793685972690582]]
Context 7: [['From 2010 to 2016, we conducted surveys of anthracnose in strawberries in Miaoli County. More than 50% of diseased plants exhibited symptoms characteristic of anthracnose crown rot (ACR), as described by McInnes et al. (1992). ACR resulted in plant losses of up to 30-40% during the seedling stage and around 20% after transplanting. Initial symptoms in crown tissue included a marbled red and white appearance, which progressed to brown rot and eventual rapid wilting of the plant. Anthracnose symptoms also appeared on other parts of the plant, including leaves, petioles, runners, fruits, and roots. These symptoms manifested as circular black spots on leaves, withering and girdling on runners.', 0.4610441029071808]]

query: What is the role of appressoria in the infection process of Colletotrichum species?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Appressoria serve as infection and survival structures in Colletotrichum spp. The development of appressoria in this group of fungi is influenced by several factors, including nutrient stress, host surface characteristics, phylloplane microorganisms, temperature, and light intensity. In our study, appressorial production was favored by cooler temperatures and was severely impaired at 35°C. Similar results have been obtained on agar.', 0.9911443591117859]]
Context 1: [['The genus Colletotrichum represents a large number of economically important Ascomycete fungi that collectively cause anthracnose disease or leaf blights on significant agricultural crops and ornamental plants worldwide. Colletotrichum spp. often serve as models in studies ranging from pathogenic development and differentiation to plant-microbe interactions. During establishment and colonization of host plants, members of this genus uniquely acquire nutrients via both biotrophy and necrotrophy. Thus, in a single interaction, these fungal pathogens exhibit two modes of nutrient acquisition: initially, nutrients are acquired from living cells, after which a necrotrophic phase is initiated, allowing the same fungus to obtain nutrients from dead cells killed by the fungus. A given species of this genus can exhibit both strategies separately or concurrently. Additionally, these fungi develop a series of specialized infection-related structures, including germ tubes, appressoria, primary intracellular hyphae, and secondary necrotrophic hyphae. Therefore, Colletotrichum species are experimentally attractive organisms for studying the molecular, biochemical, and cellular basis of fungal pathogenicity, development, and signal transduction (see Bailey and Jeger, 1992; Prusky et al., 1999).', 0.9822708964347839]]
Context 2: [['The histology of infection by Colletotrichum spp. has been studied thoroughly on several hosts. Conidia germinate either by producing germ tubes and terminal appressoria or by forming sessile appressoria. Appressoria become melanized and develop pores from which host penetration occurs. Two types of infections can develop: (i) intracellular hemibiotrophic, in which infection vesicles or swollen hyphae form within epidermal cells (e.g., on Pinus needles), and (ii) subcuticular, intramural necrotrophic, where cuticular penetration is followed by hyphal proliferation within the cuticle and epidermal cell walls.', 0.9756366610527039]]
Context 3: [['This review focuses on current research into the infection process of Colletotrichum species, with an overall emphasis on how signal transduction influences pre-penetration morphogenesis, including conidiation, conidial attachment, conidial germination, germ tube formation, and appressorial differentiation. Post-penetration biotrophic and necrotrophic growth patterns will also be described. Additionally, intriguing studies involving host specificity and chromosome transfer will be summarized.', 0.9687965512275696]]
Context 4: [['Observations and measurements of conidial size and shape have usually been made using conidial masses mounted in water, cotton blue, or lactic acid (Cannon et al., 2008). It should be noted that many species of Colletotrichum produce secondary conidia in culture directly from germinated primary conidia; these may vary morphologically when compared to those produced in conidiomata (Cannon et al., 2000). Conidial and mycelial appressoria (also referred to as hyphopodia) are often described in Colletotrichum species. Sutton (1980) characterized the mycelial appressoria formed in potato-carrot agar (PCA) using a slide culture technique, while others have used potato dextrose agar (PDA) with incubation in the dark (Johnston and Jones, 1997; Malloch, 1981) or have observed mycelial appressoria formed on the undersurface of SNA cultures (Damm et al., 2009). Conidial appressoria have been recorded when conidia are germinated in drops of deionized water on plastic cover slips in a moist chamber (Johnson et al., 1997; Chaky et al., 2001). Conidial appressoria are taxonomically uninformative and of little use for species diagnosis (Sutton, 1980, 1992). However, Du et al. (2005) noted that the shape of appressoria can differentiate C. acutatum (with rather smooth appressoria) from C. gloeosporioides (with more lobed appressoria). Crouch et al. (2009b) found that appressoria shape and size are useful for delimiting grass-associated Colletotrichum species but should be used in combination with host range. Yang et al. (2009) found that conidial appressoria can distinguish two species of Colletotrichum from Amaryllidaceae. The conidial appressoria of C. hippeastri are larger than those of C. hymenocallidis and are irregular, crenate, or lobed, occasionally becoming complex. In contrast, C. hymenocallidis appressoria are ovate or sometimes clavate.', 0.9663538932800293]]
Context 5: [['Stress conditions or postharvest storage can lead to the development of appressoria from germinating spores. Colletotrichum is one of the most important genera of plant pathogenic fungi, responsible for numerous diseases across a variety of crops worldwide (Sutton 1992, Cannon et al. 2000, 2012, Cai et al. 2009, Udayanga et al. 2013). Recently, Colletotrichum species have been included in the list of the ten most significant plant pathogenic fungi globally, based on their scientific and economic importance (Dean et al. 2012).', 0.9339759945869446]]
Context 6: [['Available morphological characters of Colletotrichum species include: 1) characters on natural substrates, such as size and shape of conidiomata (acervuli), conidia, conidiophores, and setae; 2) size and shape of conidia, conidiophores, and setae in culture; and 3) size and shape of appressoria. Acervuli, setae, and conidial characters (shape and dimensions) on natural substrates can vary due to environmental factors, and conidia may be absent from infected host tissues. Some Colletotrichum species, such as C. musae and C. gossypii, consistently fail to produce setae in conidiomata (Sutton and Waterston, 1970), and their presence on natural hosts is often inconsistent for species diagnosis (von Arx, 1957; Sutton, 1966). Morphological characters may vary with environmental factors, and incubation conditions, such as media and temperature, should be standardized (Cannon et al., 2000) for species comparison and identification. Unfortunately, there is no recommended standard for...', 0.9002957940101624]]
Context 7: [['Traditionally, Colletotrichum species have been identified based on morphological characteristics. Taxonomists have utilized several features, including the size and shape of conidia and appressoria, the presence or absence of setae, sclerotia, acervuli, and teleomorph states, as well as cultural characters such as colony color, growth rate, and texture (Simmonds, 1965; Smith and Black, 1990; Sutton, 1992; TeBeest et al., 1997; Photita et al., 2005; Than et al., 2008a-c; Thaung, 2008). However, these criteria alone are not always sufficient for reliable differentiation among Colletotrichum species due to variations in morphology and phenotype influenced by environmental factors.', 0.8684588074684143]]
Context 8: [['(d) Yellow. A yellow isolate, similar to the one produced by G. cingulata, is occasionally obtained, although this is not found in field isolates. Some authors (Sutton, 1962) have suggested using the characteristics of the appressorium as one criterion for separating species of Colletotrichum. The size and shape of the appressoria formed by the species discussed here were briefly investigated, but the differences did not appear to be sufficient to warrant a more detailed examination. The mean length of the appressoria mostly ranged between 8 and 9 µm, with a mean breadth between 6.0 and 6.5 µm. The appressoria of C. atramentarium were somewhat larger, with a mean length of 11.3 µm, while those of C. musae were shorter, averaging 7.7 µm. The majority examined were more or less obovate, but in all species, a varying number of individuals were definitely lobed or angular. The appressoria of C. acutatum were generally more regular, whereas those of C. musae were less so.', 0.8654243350028992]]
Context 9: [['Traditional identification systems in Colletotrichum have heavily relied on morphological and cultural characteristics (von Arx, 1957; Sutton, 1980, 1992; Bailey and Jeger, 1992; Freeman et al., 1998). Sutton (1992) noted that morphology alone does not provide sufficient information for precise identification, especially for species within the C. gloeosporioides and C. dematium complexes. Crouch et al. (2009b) argued that conidial size and shape, along with conidial appressoria, were taxonomically uninformative and of limited use for species diagnosis in graminicolous Colletotrichum species. Species with similar morphological characteristics may exhibit considerable variation at the physiological and pathogenic levels, making this recognition crucial for biosecurity, plant breeding, and integrated disease management. Taxonomy based solely on morphology is likely to result in ambiguity. Recent studies have shown that morphological characters should be used in conjunction with other characters to establish species relationships within Colletotrichum (Crouch et al., 2009b; Prihastuti et al., 2009).', 0.7830712795257568]]

query: How does multi-locus phylogeny contribute to understanding Colletotrichum diversity?

Context 0: [['The identification of Colletotrichum species has long been challenging due to limited morphological characteristics. Single-gene phylogenetic analyses have also proven unsuccessful in clearly delineating species, partly due to the high number of erroneous names in GenBank. Additional loci recommended for identifying Colletotrichum species include actin (ACT), calmodulin (CAL), chitin synthase-1 (CHS-1), glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate dehydrogenase (GAPDH), and β-tubulin (TUB2).', 0.9412133097648621]]
Context 4: [['Colletotrichum systematics should utilize a multiple-gene phylogeny alongside a study of type specimens to establish correlations between genotype and phenotype. The phenotype should be broadened to encompass a polyphasic approach, including morphology, physiology, pathogenicity, infection processes, cultural characteristics, and secondary metabolites (Frisvad, 2004; Samson and Varga, 2007). The genotypes within Colletotrichum appear to correlate with a combination of traits rather than a single characteristic. These criteria are clearly demonstrated by Crouch et al. (2009b), Damm et al. (2009), and Prihastuti et al. (2009). Crouch et al. (2009b) correlated well-defined phylogenetic groupings with a combination of appressoria and host ranges. Prihastuti et al. (2009) established new taxa within the C. gloeosporioides complex that form distinct phylogenetic lineages with unique morphological, cultural, and physiological characteristics.', 0.9279384613037109]]
Context 5: [['Overall, the study investigates the genetic diversity and specificity of Colletotrichum species through molecular techniques, contributing to a better understanding of their phylogenetic relationships.', 0.9190995693206787]]
Context 6: [['Colletotrichum species are categorized into phylogenetic clades (also referred to as species complexes) based on multilocus molecular analysis. Species within a clade are closely related and share similar temperature requirements (Cannon et al., 2012; Vieira et al., 2020; Talhinhas and Baroncelli, 2021; Salotti et al., 2022). A recent systematic review identified 15 major clades of the genus, along with several smaller clusters and isolated species (Talhinhas and Baroncelli, 2021). Detailed descriptions of these major phylogenetic clades and the species within them have been provided by multiple studies (Cannon et al., 2012; Vieira et al., 2020; Talhinhas and Baroncelli, 2021; Damm et al., 2009, 2012, 2013, 2014; Weir et al., 2012).', 0.8575488328933716]]
Context 7: [['Ulrike Damm provided an overview of her ongoing collaboration with Paul Cannon regarding the phylogeny of three species complexes. The project aims to delimit species within these complexes, characterize known and new species, and designate epitypes to support accurate identifications of Colletotrichum species. So far, this goal has been achieved for species with curved conidia from herbaceous hosts (Damm et al. 2009), which were previously identified primarily as C. dematium. Multi-gene analyses and morphological characterizations have revealed several diverse and distantly related species, including four new species.', 0.8166021108627319]]
Context 8: [['Discussion: Recent phylogenetic studies of the genus Colletotrichum have revealed clustering in 11 major clades, including significant species complexes such as C. acutatum, C. boninense, C. gloeosporioides, and C. truncatum. These studies facilitate the differentiation and description of numerous taxa.', 0.6649289727210999]]
Context 9: [['Molecular phylogeny has become increasingly important due to the inadequacies and plasticity of morphological characters. Nucleic acid sequence analysis is regarded as more reliable for Colletotrichum classification (Sutton, 1992; Cannon et al., 2000; Crouch et al., 2009a,b; Damm et al., 2009; Prihastuti et al., 2009). A major drawback in the reliance on a small proportion of the genome to understand...', 0.5954409837722778]]

query: Does the observed matrix formation in living host cells by C. acutatum and C. fragariae resemble typical biotrophic behavior found in other fungal pathogens?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['C. acutatum and C. fragariae underwent a very brief biotrophic phase (less than 12 hours) before entering their extended necrotrophic phase. Representatives of both species of fungi were observed entering living host cells and developing a matrix comparable to that described in reported biotrophic systems, but they killed the host cells within a few hours. Previous descriptions for other Colletotrichum species cited biotrophy as occurring at a minimum of "less than 24 hours." However, a scenario where a living cell is entered and quickly killed might be considered a modification of necrotrophy, rather than biotrophy or hemibiotrophy.', 0.9946834444999695]]
Context 1: [['C. acutatum and C. fragariae underwent a very brief biotrophic phase (less than 12 hours) before entering their extended necrotrophic phase. Representatives of both species were observed entering living host cells and developing a matrix comparable to that described in reported biotrophic systems, but they killed the host cells within a few hours. Previous descriptions for other Colletotrichum species cite biotrophy at a minimum of “less than 24 hours.” However, a situation in which a living cell is entered and quickly killed might be considered a modification of necrotrophy rather than biotrophy or hemibiotrophy.', 0.9924675822257996]]
Context 2: [['C. acutatum was isolated from two weeds, Conyza spp. and Vicia spp., that infested strawberry fields. The weed isolates were similar to those from strawberry, as demonstrated by PCR analysis, and caused typical anthracnose symptoms on strawberry. Thus, not only crop plants but also weeds may be colonized by C. acutatum. This aligns with the detection of C. fragariae, pathogenic to strawberry, on weeds such as chickweed, coffeeweed, sicklepod, fiddleneck, and vetch, growing in containers and around nurseries in Florida. Similarly, strawberry and anemone cultivated in close proximity in Israel were found to be infected by an identical genotype of C. acutatum.', 0.2179422527551651]]
Context 3: [['The ontogeny of the infection processes of C. acutatum and C. fragariae on inoculated plants were similar (as detailed in Table 1) at the light or electron microscopic levels. Lesions most commonly developed on stolon tips and the upper portion of the youngest petiole with fully expanded leaflets. Lesions were first observed 2 days after inoculation as lenticular brown spots that progressed into dark, sunken, and leathery lesions typical of anthracnose, which eventually girdled the stolon or petiole.', 0.19364161789417267]]
Context 4: [['Fungal isolates: The 62 isolates of C. acutatum isolated from strawberry were selected from various collections representing a range of isolation dates (1978 to 1998) and geographic regions worldwide. Nineteen C. acutatum isolates from other host plants were included in the study for comparison. Among these 81 isolates, 22 exhibiting pink chromogenic coloring in culture are referred to as C. acutatum chromogenic. Additionally, 13 isolates of C. gloeosporioides from strawberries originating from Europe and the United States, as well as one isolate from mango used as an outgroup, were studied. All isolates were single-conidia cultures. Stock cultures were maintained on silica gel at 4°C as described by Perkins. Cultures were initiated by transferring silica gel particles from the stock cultures to PDA (Potato Dextrose Agar) plates to produce fungal material for molecular analysis and pathogenicity tests. All isolates were identified using classical taxonomic criteria, such as conidial shape and growth on PDA.', 0.18792179226875305]]
Context 5: [['The ontogeny of the infection processes of C. acutatum and C. fragariae on inoculated plants were similar (as indicated in Table 1) at both the light and electron microscopic levels. Lesions most commonly developed on stolon tips and the upper portion of the youngest petiole with fully expanded leaflets. Lesions were first observed 2 days after inoculation as lenticular brown spots that developed into dark, sunken, and leathery lesions typical of anthracnose, which eventually girdled the stolon or petiole.', 0.18494093418121338]]
Context 6: [['INTRODUCTION: As a significant pathogen, C. acutatum has been treated as a regulated organism for many years.', 0.16878575086593628]]
Context 7: [['Inoculum Production: Isolates of C. acutatum, C. fragariae, and C. gloeosporioides were obtained from infected strawberry fruit collected from various regions of the United States. All cultures were maintained on potato dextrose agar (PDA) in 100 × 15 mm petri dishes. Conidia from 2-week-old cultures were streaked onto new PDA plates weekly using a sterilized probe. To ensure the pathogenicity of the isolates, conidia from previously inoculated fruit were streaked onto new PDA plates every two weeks. Cultures were maintained at 26°C with 12 hours of light (51 µE s–1 m–2) daily.', 0.14048273861408234]]
Context 8: [['The general disease cycles of C. acutatum from different hosts often share common attributes. All produce acervuli with abundant conidia on one or more host tissues, and conidia are splash-dispersed, serving as the primary inoculum source for most infections. Conidia can survive in a gelatinous matrix if conditions are appropriate; however, they typically germinate to produce appressoria and quiescent infections. The tissues on which sporulation and reproduction occur differ among various hosts, and the fate of appressoria and quiescent infections varies greatly. As far as is known, the sexual stage plays only a minor role in the life cycle of C. acutatum. Although the pathogen exhibits overlapping survival strategies, the disease cycles of C. acutatum on different hosts can be grouped according to four general lifestyles.', 0.14013081789016724]]
Context 9: [['Moreover, no correlation between genetic polymorphism and the two groups of pathogenicity has been studied. The purpose of this work was (i) to investigate genetic polymorphism and pathogenicity of C. acutatum, the major pathogen isolated from strawberry in Europe, and (ii) to determine the genetic relatedness of this pathogen to representative isolates of C. acutatum obtained from strawberry and other hosts from various countries worldwide. Additionally, isolates of C. gloeosporioides, which are occasionally observed on strawberry in Europe, were included in this work.', 0.1260591596364975]]

query: What is anthracnose, and how does it harm plants?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Anthracnose is a significant disease affecting grape crops (Dowling et al., 2020). Beyond causing severe yield losses, anthracnose epidemics can diminish the quality of the produce (Waller et al., 2002; Dowling et al., 2020). The most economically damaging symptoms often include blossom blight and fruit rots; however, necrotic lesions may also develop on leaves, stems, and twigs, leading to plant deterioration and reduced fruit quality (Dowling et al., 2020).', 0.8356992602348328]]
Context 1: [['Hemmi, T. (1920). Kurze Mitteilung über drei Fälle von Anthracnose auf Pflanzen. Annals of the Phytopathological Society of Japan, 1(3), 13–21.', 0.407044380903244]]
Context 2: [['Anthracnose spreads within a field by splashing water, and living mulches (such as wheat, rye, or ryegrass) in row middles have been shown to reduce disease spread within a field. Sublethal doses of grass-specific herbicides, such as sethoxydim, may be used to prevent excessive growth of ryegrass (Gupton, 2000). Organic mulches, such as wheat straw or pine needles, also reduce splash and result in a lower incidence of anthracnose compared to rows mulched with plastic (Madden, 1992; Smith and Spiers, 1986). Additionally, anthracnose is less severe when water is supplied to plants using drip irrigation rather than overhead irrigation (Madden, 1992; Smith and Spiers, 1986). Anthracnose crown rot was observed to be less severe in commercial fields when strawberries were grown in soils with low nitrogen fertility (Howard et al., 1992). In greenhouse studies, Smith (1987, 1989) determined that strawberries grown in soils with high levels of nitrogen, especially from ammonium sources, are more susceptible to anthracnose than plants grown in soils with lower nitrogen levels or those with high levels of calcium nitrate.', 0.3189949095249176]]
Context 3: [['From 2010 to 2016, we conducted surveys of anthracnose in strawberries in Miaoli County. More than 50% of diseased plants exhibited symptoms characteristic of anthracnose crown rot (ACR), as described by McInnes et al. (1992). ACR resulted in plant losses of up to 30-40% during the seedling stage and around 20% after transplanting. Initial symptoms in crown tissue included a marbled red and white appearance, which progressed to brown rot and eventual rapid wilting of the plant. Anthracnose symptoms also appeared on other parts of the plant, including leaves, petioles, runners, fruits, and roots. These symptoms manifested as circular black spots on leaves, withering and girdling on runners.', 0.28770172595977783]]
Context 4: [['Anthracnose spreads within a field by splashing water, and living mulches (such as wheat, rye, or ryegrass) in row middles have been shown to reduce disease spread within a field. Context 5: [['Anthracnose spreads within a field through splashing water. Living mulches, such as wheat, rye, or rye grass, in row middles have been shown to reduce disease spread. Context 1: [['Many species belonging to the genus Colletotrichum are associated with plant diseases, commonly referred to as anthracnose. query: Which species were found to cause lesions on wounded strawberry leaves?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Three species have been reported as causal agents of strawberry anthracnose: Colletotrichum acutatum J.H. Simmonds, C. fragariae Brooks, and C. gloeosporioides (Penz.) Penz. & Sacc. (teleomorph Glomerella cingulata (Stoneman) Spauld. & H. Schrenk). These species cause similar symptoms on strawberries, including crown rot, fruit rot, and stolon lesions. In Europe, C. acutatum is the most prevalent species causing anthracnose, while C. gloeosporioides is found only occasionally, and C. fragariae has not yet been observed.', 0.9595189690589905]]
Context 1: [['Black leaf spot, typically caused by C. fragariae and C. gloeosporioides, is characterized by gray or light black spots scattered across the top surface of strawberry leaflets. These spots usually are not necrotic. In contrast, C. acutatum more typically causes irregular leaf spots, with necrotic black lesions at the tips of the leaflets. It also causes root lesions. All three Colletotrichum species can incite flower blights and fruit rots (Smith, 1998b). Fully open flowers are much more susceptible than closed buds (Smith, 2007). Infected green fruit are often hard, brown, and mummified rather than ripened. Anthracnose lesions on ripe fruit are firm, slightly sunken, and covered with pink spore masses.', 0.932549774646759]]
Context 2: [['Species of the fungal plant pathogen Colletotrichum are responsible for strawberry (Fragaria × ananassa Duch.) anthracnose, one of the major diseases affecting this crop. Major species that cause strawberry anthracnose include C. acutatum J.H. Simmons, C. fragariae Brooks, and C. gloeosporioides (Penz.) Penz. & Sacc. Symptoms of the disease manifest in various phases. Infection of mother plants with anthracnose may result in the collapse of the entire plant due to crown rot. In the nursery, lesions form on stolons that eventually girdle the runners, leading to wilting and death of unrooted daughter plants distal to the lesion. Death of daughter plants in the nursery and in field transplants can also be caused by crown rot. Infected transplants are capable of spreading the disease from the nursery to the field, and entire crops can be destroyed by anthracnose in strawberry fruit production fields under conducive environmental conditions.', 0.9243087768554688]]
Context 3: [['The ontogeny of the invasion process by Colletotrichum acutatum and C. fragariae was studied on the petioles and stolons of the strawberry cultivar Chandler using light and electron microscopy. The invasion of host tissue by each fungal species was similar; however, the invasion occurred more rapidly with C. fragariae than with C. acutatum. Following cuticular penetration via an appressorium, subsequent steps of invasion involved hyphal growth within the cuticle and within the cell walls of epidermal, subepidermal, and subtending cells. Both species of fungi are responsible for anthracnose diseases of strawberry (Fragaria × ananassa Duch.) caused by the fungal pathogens Colletotrichum acutatum Simmonds, C. fragariae Brooks, and C. gloeosporioides (Penz.) Penz. & Sacc. (teleomorph Glomerella cingulata (Stonem.) Spauld. & Schrenk). All three species incite diseases that cannot be distinguished in the field by symptoms alone. Petiole and stolon lesions occur on plants grown worldwide but may go undetected in cool, dry areas where they cause little injury. C. fragariae is most often associated with anthracnose crown rot of strawberries grown in hot, humid regions such as the southeastern United States. Its host range is limited to strawberries and a few weeds. C. acutatum, on the other hand, is the primary causal agent of anthracnose fruit rot and has a broader geographic and host range than C. fragariae. It is increasingly important as a cause of petiole, stolon, crown, and root infections.', 0.9209555983543396]]
Context 4: [['Strawberry fruits were inoculated with isolates of C. acutatum and C. gloeosporioides, both from strawberry and C. gloeosporioides from Limonium spp., either through wounding or non-wounding methods. Generally, no significant differences (P < 0.05) were detected in lesion size caused by the strawberry pathogens on fruit compared to those from the C. gloeosporioides Limonium isolate L-12, 9 days after either type of inoculation (Fig. 5).', 0.9111517667770386]]
Context 5: [['On inoculated strawberry plants, isolates of C. fructicola and C. murrayae exhibited strong pathogenicity, affecting both leaves and petioles, with plant mortality observed 30 days post-inoculation. Strawberries (Fragaria ananassa) are a globally important small fruit crop, and the area dedicated to strawberry cultivation in China has rapidly increased in recent years. Under suitable environmental conditions, anthracnose can lead to significant yield losses (Henz et al. 1992). Infected strawberries may develop lesions on the petiole and crown, potentially resulting in plant collapse and death. In nurseries, lesions can form on stolons, leading to the wilting and death of unrooted daughter plants (Freeman and Katan 1997). Infected transplants can spread the disease from the nursery to the field, where typical symptoms of anthracnose manifest as irregular black leaf spots, crown rot, flower blight, and fruit rot (Howard et al. 1992).', 0.8716120719909668]]
Context 6: [['Strawberry anthracnose symptoms from the two Colletotrichum species complexes are similar and can appear on all parts of the plant. Flower blight and fruit rot are common symptoms in the field, while lesions on stolons, petioles, and leaves are typically found in plant nurseries. Crown symptomatology is characterized by reddish-brown necrotic areas, and in some cases, stunting and chlorosis have been associated with root necrosis.', 0.7010344862937927]]
Context 7: [['Anthracnose caused by Colletotrichum spp. is a significant threat to strawberry production, particularly in warm and humid climates. Rain-splashed conidia of Colletotrichum spp. serve as the primary inoculum that initiates epidemics of strawberry anthracnose disease. After landing on the plant surface, the conidia germinate, form appressoria, and then penetrate the epidermal cells. Colletotrichum spp. can infect various strawberry tissues, resulting in black or irregular spots on leaves, sunken black spots or necrotic lesions on petioles, stolons, and fruits, as well as wilting of the entire plant due to crown rot. Under high humidity, concentric rings of acervuli with orange conidial masses can be observed on necrotic tissues. In Florida, USA, anthracnose can lead to the death of up to 80% of seedlings in nurseries and yield losses exceeding 50% in fields. In Taiwan, strawberry seedlings are propagated from March to September, during which high temperatures, humidity, and heavy rainfall are prevalent.', 0.6884761452674866]]
Context 8: [['Strawberry anthracnose can affect plants at any lifecycle stage, but plants are particularly susceptible at the seedling stage and immediately after planting (Wang et al. 2008). The disease primarily affects strawberry roots, petioles, and stolons, but can also infect flowers and fruit, leading to severe outbreaks (Mertely and Legard 2004). Symptoms include irregular ulcer-like lesions, reddish-brown stolons during initial stolon development, black spindle-shaped lesions on leaves and petioles, wilting, and dead roots (Debode et al. 2009; Freeman and Katan 1997). In Zhejiang, nearly 50% of seedling deaths and over 40% of production losses in nurseries are attributed to this disease (Xie et al. 2010). If environmental conditions are favorable, anthracnose can reduce strawberry yield by up to 80%. Transplants are considered the main source of primary inoculum, but the complete epidemiology of Colletotrichum spp. on strawberries in China remains unclear.', 0.4173400402069092]]
Context 9: [['Pathogenicity Test: Each isolated pathogen was prepared at a concentration of 1 × 10^5 conidia/mL, and 1 mL was sprayed per plant on the Seolhyang cultivar of strawberry plants. Six plants per isolate were used for testing. The inoculated plants were incubated in a dew chamber at 27°C and 100% relative humidity (RH) for 2 days before being moved to a plastic house maintained between 24°C and 30°C. After 60 days, the disease index of each plant was rated on a scale of 0 to 4: 0, healthy; 1, < 50% of petioles affected; 2, > 50% of petioles affected; 3, wilted; 4, necrosis formed on the entire plant (Nam et al., 2006). The disease index data from isolates were analyzed for means and standard error using the Costat program (CoHort Software, Berkeley, CA). All isolates caused anthracnose symptoms on the Seolhyang strawberry cultivar. The disease index for the isolates was highest (DI > 3) for CGF071204, CGF100713, and CGF110101. Smith and Black (1990) showed that the pathogenicity of C. gloeosporioides, C. acutatum, and C. fragariae can be differentiated by factors such as strawberry tissue and cultivars. C. gloeosporioides and C. acutatum were reported to have a wide host range, while C. fragariae was restricted to strawberry plants (Freeman et al., 1998; Hyde et al., 2009b). Colletotrichum isolated from strawberries in Korea and Japan was pathogenic to both strawberry and apple fruit (Nam et al., 1998), as well as to avocado, broad bean, common sowthistle, cyclamen, pea, and strawberry under non-wound inoculation conditions (Okayama and Tsujimoto, 1994).', 0.3782557547092438]]

query: How does phylogenetic analysis contribute to resolving Colletotrichum species complexes?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Du, M., Schardl, C.L., & Vaillancourt, L.J. (2005). Using mating-type gene sequences for improved phylogenetic resolution of Colletotrichum species complexes. Mycologia, 97, 641–58.', 0.9944337010383606]]
