Context 3: [['Du, M.Z., Schardl, C.L., and Vaillancourt, L.J. (2005). Using mating-type gene sequences for improved phylogenetic resolution of Colletotrichum species complexes. Mycologia 97: 641-658.', 0.9942776560783386]]
Context 4: [['Du, M., Schardl, C.L., and Vaillancourt, L.J. (2005). Using mating-type gene sequences for improved phylogenetic resolution of Colletotrichum species complexes. Mycologia 97: 641-658.', 0.9938965439796448]]
Context 5: [['Colletotrichum species are categorized into phylogenetic clades (also referred to as species complexes) based on multilocus molecular analysis. Species within a clade are closely related and share similar temperature requirements (Cannon et al., 2012; Vieira et al., 2020; Talhinhas and Baroncelli, 2021; Salotti et al., 2022). A recent systematic review identified 15 major clades of the genus, along with several smaller clusters and isolated species (Talhinhas and Baroncelli, 2021). Detailed descriptions of these major phylogenetic clades and the species within them have been provided by multiple studies (Cannon et al., 2012; Vieira et al., 2020; Talhinhas and Baroncelli, 2021; Damm et al., 2009, 2012, 2013, 2014; Weir et al., 2012).', 0.9899965524673462]]
Context 6: [['Discussion: Recent phylogenetic studies of the genus Colletotrichum have revealed clustering in 11 major clades, including significant species complexes such as C. acutatum, C. boninense, C. gloeosporioides, and C. truncatum. These studies facilitate the differentiation and description of numerous taxa.', 0.9863752722740173]]
Context 7: [['Ulrike Damm provided an overview of her ongoing collaboration with Paul Cannon regarding the phylogeny of three species complexes. The project aims to delimit species within these complexes, characterize known and new species, and designate epitypes to support accurate identifications of Colletotrichum species. So far, this goal has been achieved for species with curved conidia from herbaceous hosts (Damm et al. 2009), which were previously identified primarily as C. dematium. Multi-gene analyses and morphological characterizations have revealed several diverse and distantly related species, including four new species.', 0.9717944264411926]]
Context 8: [['Disentangling species complexes within the Colletotrichum genus presents a significant challenge for taxonomists. Given the global importance of this genus, primarily consisting of plant pathogens, it is critical to accurately identify species and/or pathotypes to enhance biosecurity and disease control efforts. Traditional methods of species identification have relied on morphological, cultural, and host-preference criteria. However, these methods often prove unreliable, leading to unresolved taxonomic issues. As stated by Sutton (1992), relying solely on morphology is insufficient for improving the systematics of species complexes like C. gloeosporioides.', 0.9587740898132324]]
Context 9: [['The identification of Colletotrichum species has long been challenging due to limited morphological characteristics. Single-gene phylogenetic analyses have also proven unsuccessful in clearly delineating species, partly due to the high number of erroneous names in GenBank. This paper reviews the taxonomic problems associated with Colletotrichum and the difficulties in identifying taxa at the species level. We advocate for epitypification and the use of multi-locus phylogenetic methods to better delimit species and understand the genus.', 0.9169021248817444]]

query: How do molecular techniques such as ribosomal DNA analysis and RFLP contribute to understanding the genetic diversity within C. gloeosporioides populations?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['This paper aims to clarify the genetic and taxonomic relationships within the C. gloeosporioides species complex using a diverse set of isolates that samples its genetic, biological, and geographic diversity. Type specimens or cultures derived from type specimens have been examined whenever possible. Although we do not treat all names placed in synonymy with C. gloeosporioides or Glomerella cingulata by von Arx & Müller (1954) and von Arx (1957, 1970), we do include all names that have been suggested to have a close relationship with C. gloeosporioides in recent literature, along with all subspecific taxa and formae speciales within C. gloeosporioides and G. cingulata.', 0.7219436168670654]]
Context 1: [['The Colletotrichum gloeosporioides species complex contains taxa with significant biological, morphological, and genetic diversity (Sutton, 1992; Hyde et al., 2009). Some of these taxa have been designated as separate species, such as C. fragariae (Johnston et al., 2008). The ITS region has a limited ability to discriminate clades within this group; hence, a more appropriate biomarker is required for barcoding. The ideal locus for use in barcoding should have low heterogeneity within species, yet enough variation to allow maximum separation of different species. The first requirement facilitates easy grouping and identification of strains from the same species, while the second minimizes misidentifications. It is also important that the gene can be easily sequenced for all species and does not require specific primers for each group (Seifert, 2009; Gilmore et al., 2009; Chen et al., 2009).', 0.709615170955658]]
Context 2: [['The recent epitypification of C. gloeosporioides marked an important milestone for taxonomic studies of the complex (Cannon et al., 2008). Since then, the availability of living ex-type strains and sequence data has provided a solid reference for comparison with isolates. However, criteria for species delimitation have been debated over the years, with Colletotrichum serving as a notable example (Cannon et al., 2008). Until recently, single-locus phylogenies dominated the molecular systematics of the C. gloeosporioides complex, despite their limited resolving ability (Sreenivasaprasad et al., 1993, 1996; Johnston and Jones, 1997; Nguyen et al., 2009; Polashock et al., 2009). Specifically, the internal transcribed spacers (ITS) flanking the 5.8S ribosomal RNA represent the most widely sequenced region in Colletotrichum phylogenetic studies. Consequently, ITS-based C. gloeosporioides specific primers (Mills et al., 1992) have been extensively utilized for identifying Colletotrichum fungi over the past 10 to 15 years. However, there are significant concerns regarding the resolving power of ITS for closely related species (Cai et al., 2009; Crouch et al., 2009b). Recognizing the limitations of ITS and similar markers has led to an increasing necessity for the development and use of more informative loci. Molecular phylogenetic analyses using multilocus datasets are now providing an objective approach to determining species boundaries.', 0.6014100909233093]]
Context 3: [['Cannon et al. (2008) used a C. gloeosporioides isolate from an Italian orange as an epitype. Living strains and sequence data are available from this epitype, allowing for comparison of Colletotrichum isolates through DNA sequence analyses, which helps overcome the limitations of traditional morphological identification (Cai et al., 2009; Hyde et al., 2009a). More than 86% of the ITS sequences from isolates designated as C. gloeosporioides in GenBank were not conspecific with the C. gloeosporioides epitype (Cai et al., 2009; Hyde et al., 2009b). Consequently, multiple gene loci, which offer more informative sites compared to the ribosomal ITS regions, along with morphological analyses, were utilized to distinguish Colletotrichum species (Cai et al., 2009; Prihastuti et al., 2009; Yang et al., 2009). Recently, Weir et al. (2012) systematically described the C. gloeosporioides species complex based on phylogenetic analyses of up to eight genes. They reported 22 species plus one subspecies within the C. gloeosporioides species complex. All taxa accepted within this clade were morphologically similar to the broadly defined C. gloeosporioides, as it has been referenced in the literature for the past 50 years (Weir et al., 2012).', 0.5754113793373108]]
Context 4: [['Munaut, F., Hamaide, N., Stappen, J.V., & Maraite, H. (1998). Genetic relationships among isolates of Colletotrichum gloeosporioides from Stylosanthes spp. in Africa and Australia using RAPD and ribosomal DNA markers. Plant Pathology, 47, 641–648. doi:10.1046/j.1365-3059.1998.00287.x.', 0.5311561822891235]]
Context 5: [['Munaut, F., Hamaide, N., Vander Stappen, J., & Maraite, H. (1998). Genetic relationships among isolates of Colletotrichum gloeosporioides from Stylosanthes spp. in Africa and Australia using RAPD and ribosomal DNA markers. Plant Pathology, 47, 641–648.', 0.48644933104515076]]
Context 6: [['The regional nature of most studies, along with often restricted genetic sampling across the global diversity of C. gloeosporioides, and minimal overlap between isolates treated and gene regions targeted, means that the relationships among newly described species are frequently poorly understood. While some authors have adopted a genetically restricted concept for C. gloeosporioides, many applied researchers continue to use the name broadly (e.g., Bogo et al. 2012; Deng et al. 2012; Kenny et al. 2012; Parvin et al. 2012; Zhang et al. 2012). In this paper, we accept both concepts as useful and valid. When used in a broad sense, we refer to the taxon as the C. gloeosporioides species complex or C. gloeosporioides s. lat.', 0.47011008858680725]]
Context 7: [['An attempt was made to sample the genetic diversity of Colletotrichum gloeosporioides as broadly as possible. Isolates from diverse hosts around the world were selected for more intensive study. A BLAST search of GenBank using the ITS sequence of the epitype culture of C. gloeosporioides (Cannon et al. 2008) provided a coarse estimate for the genetic limits of the C. gloeosporioides complex. The ITS diversity across the complex was utilized to select a genetically diverse set of isolates. Voucher cultures were obtained from the research groups that deposited the GenBank records. In addition to these, isolates representing the known genetic and morphological diversity of C. gloeosporioides from New Zealand were included. These isolates were collected from rots of both native and introduced fruits, from diseased exotic weeds, and as endophytes from the leaves of native podocarps. Additional isolates, representing ex-type and authentic cultures of as many named taxa and formae speciales within the C. gloeosporioides complex as possible, were sourced from international culture collections. Approximately 400 isolates belonging to the C. gloeosporioides complex were obtained. GAPDH gene sequences were generated for all isolates as an initial measure of genetic diversity. A subset of 156 isolates, selected to represent a range of genetic, geographic, and host plant diversity, was used in this research (see Table 1).', 0.4644309878349304]]
Context 8: [['Hosdson, A., Mills, P. R., & Brown, A. E. (1993). Ribosomal and mitochondrial DNA polymorphisms in Colletotrichum gloeosporioides isolated from tropical fruits. Mycological Research, 97, 329–335.', 0.43941783905029297]]
Context 9: [['Notes: Killgore et al. (1999) reported that the isolates they recognized as C. gloeosporioides “f. sp. miconiae” were highly specialized pathogens of Miconia calvescens, unable to infect the closely related Clidemia hirta. The original voucher cultures are no longer available (pers. comm., Robert Barreto). Recently collected isolates from Miconia at the type locality in Brazil have proven to be genetically diverse within the C. gloeosporioides species complex, with isolates belonging to both the Kahawae and Musae clades (unpubl. data). For now, the genetic position of this pathogen remains unresolved.', 0.42610985040664673]]

query: How do I know if a plant variety is resistant to anthracnose?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Two cultivars with different resistance levels to anthracnose were compared: (a) cv. Campinas IAC 2712 (susceptible) and (b) cv. Dover (partially resistant). Although ‘Dover’ is reported to be resistant to Colletotrichum acutatum (Howard et al. 1992; Denoyes-Rothan et al. 1999), the resistance is not complete, and significant losses due to anthracnose have been noted in Brasília for this genotype (Furlanetto et al. 1996). The incidence of flower blight and diseased fruits (%) was recorded weekly at 23, 29, 37, and 44 days after infection (DAI). AUDPCs were calculated as previously described.', 0.7150481939315796]]
Context 1: [['A total of 1,515 anthracnose-resistant selections were identified from the seedlings tested in Mississippi. Four of these resistant strawberry clones were released as breeding lines (Galletta et al., 1993) and have since been utilized as sources of anthracnose resistance in several breeding programs. Additionally, Smith et al. (1998) released the cultivar Pelican, which demonstrates high resistance to both anthracnose crown rot caused by C. fragariae and anthracnose fruit rot caused by C. acutatum. Pelican is also resistant to varieties of red stele caused by Phytophthora fragariae.', 0.6490262150764465]]
Context 2: [['Chakroborty, S., Cameron, D. F., Irwin, J. A. G., & Edye, L. A. (1988). Quantitatively expressed resistance to anthracnose (Colletotrichum gloeosporioides) in Stylosanthes scabra. Plant Pathology, 37, 529-537.', 0.48134252429008484]]
Context 3: [['Until highly resistant cultivars are available, growers must rely on chemical applications and cultural practices to reduce losses due to anthracnose. The failure of fungicides to control anthracnose epidemics may be attributed to the development of fungicide resistance in the Colletotrichum species population. For example, benomyl was shown to effectively reduce the incidence of anthracnose crown rot (Horn et al., 1972; Howard, 1971) and was used intensively by strawberry growers for years to control anthracnose and other diseases. However, the anthracnose pathogens, C. acutatum and C. fragariae, developed resistance to it and other benzimidazole fungicides (LaMondia, 1995; McInnes et al., 1992a; Smith and Black, 1992, 1993), leading to the ineffectiveness of benomyl for anthracnose control in strawberry fields.', 0.40818002820014954]]
Context 4: [['Until highly resistant cultivars are available, growers must rely on chemical applications and cultural practices to reduce losses due to anthracnose. The failure of fungicides to control anthracnose epidemics may be due to the development of fungicide resistance in the Colletotrichum spp. population. For example, benomyl effectively reduced the incidence of anthracnose crown rot (Horn et al., 1972; Howard, 1971) and was used intensively by strawberry growers for years to control anthracnose and other diseases. However, the anthracnose pathogens, C. acutatum and C. fragariae, developed resistance to it and other benzimidazole fungicides (LaMondia, 1995; McInnes et al., 1992a; Smith and Black, 1992, 1993), rendering benomyl ineffective for anthracnose control in strawberry fields.', 0.4043358266353607]]
Context 5: [['Ye Z, Zheng H, Tong Y, Noguchi Y, Sugiyama K, Sakata Y, et al. Anthracnose pathogen in Shanghai suburbs and resistance of some strawberry varieties.', 0.35778871178627014]]
Context 6: [['Increased losses due to anthracnose fruit and crown rots may be related to the shift from matted-row culture to the annual plasticulture production system in the United States. Breeding for genetic resistance to anthracnose and the development of resistant cultivars are primary means for reducing economic losses due to this disease. This approach is environmentally sound because it results in reduced fungicide use. As our knowledge of the anthracnose pathogens and the epidemiology of anthracnose diseases has increased, so has our ability to control these diseases. Changes in cultural practices have resulted in reduced levels of disease. Simultaneously, the development of more effective fungicides and their registration for use on strawberries have significantly reduced losses due to both anthracnose crown rot and fruit rot. Anthracnose-resistant cultivars have also decreased economic losses caused by these diseases. Nevertheless, growers may still face severe losses when environmental conditions are highly favorable for anthracnose development.', 0.32907137274742126]]
Context 7: [['As our knowledge of the anthracnose pathogens and the epidemiology of anthracnose diseases has increased, so has our ability to control these diseases. Changes in cultural practices have resulted in reduced levels of disease. Additionally, the development and registration of more effective fungicides for use on strawberries have significantly reduced losses from both anthracnose crown rot and fruit rot. Anthracnose-resistant cultivars have also diminished economic losses due to these diseases. Nevertheless, growers may still experience severe losses when environmental factors are highly favorable for anthracnose development.', 0.30257606506347656]]
Context 8: [['As our understanding of the anthracnose pathogens and the epidemiology of anthracnose diseases has improved, so has our capacity to control these diseases. Changes in cultural practices have led to reduced levels of disease. Additionally, the development and registration of more effective fungicides for use on strawberries have significantly decreased losses due to anthracnose crown rot and fruit rot. The introduction of partially resistant cultivars has also helped mitigate economic losses due to these diseases. Nonetheless, growers may still experience severe losses when environmental conditions are highly conducive to anthracnose development.', 0.28332075476646423]]
Context 9: [['The presence of anthracnose resistance to pathogenicity group 2 was evaluated by inoculating 26 accessions, including 23 F. × ananassa genotypes of various geographic origins, one F. moschata genotype (FM1), and two F. vesca genotypes (Reine des Vallées and Rodluvan). Finally, the presence of identical or different genes controlling anthracnose resistance in cvs. Capitola and Chandler was analyzed by studying families derived from the complex cross [(Capitola × Chandler) × Pajaro].', 0.26736682653427124]]

query: Can soil amendments help reduce the severity of anthracnose?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Anthracnose spreads within a field by splashing water, and living mulches (such as wheat, rye, or ryegrass) in row middles have been shown to reduce disease spread within a field. Sublethal doses of grass-specific herbicides, such as sethoxydim, may be used to prevent excessive growth of ryegrass (Gupton, 2000). Organic mulches, such as wheat straw or pine needles, also reduce splash and result in a lower incidence of anthracnose compared to rows mulched with plastic (Madden, 1992; Smith and Spiers, 1986). Additionally, anthracnose is less severe when water is supplied to plants using drip irrigation rather than overhead irrigation (Madden, 1992; Smith and Spiers, 1986). Anthracnose crown rot was observed to be less severe in commercial fields when strawberries were grown in soils with low nitrogen fertility (Howard et al., 1992). In greenhouse studies, Smith (1987, 1989) determined that strawberries grown in soils with high levels of nitrogen, especially from ammonium sources, are more susceptible to anthracnose than plants grown in soils with lower nitrogen levels or those with high levels of calcium nitrate.', 0.8078414797782898]]
Context 1: [['Anthracnose spreads within a field by splashing water, and living mulches (such as wheat, rye, or ryegrass) in row middles have been shown to reduce disease spread within a field. Additionally, anthracnose is less severe when water is supplied to plants using drip irrigation rather than overhead irrigation (Coelho et al., 2008; Madden, 1992; Smith and Spiers, 1986).', 0.3704383373260498]]
Context 3: [['As our understanding of the anthracnose pathogens and the epidemiology of anthracnose diseases has improved, so has our capacity to control these diseases. Changes in cultural practices have led to reduced levels of disease. Additionally, the development and registration of more effective fungicides for use on strawberries have significantly decreased losses due to anthracnose crown rot and fruit rot. The introduction of partially resistant cultivars has also helped mitigate economic losses due to these diseases. Nonetheless, growers may still experience severe losses when environmental conditions are highly conducive to anthracnose development.', 0.24878287315368652]]

Context 9: [['Increased losses due to anthracnose fruit and crown rots may be related to the shift from matted-row culture to the annual plasticulture production system in the United States. Breeding for genetic resistance to anthracnose and the development of resistant cultivars are primary means for reducing economic losses due to this disease. This approach is environmentally sound because it results in reduced fungicide use. As our knowledge of the anthracnose pathogens and the epidemiology of anthracnose diseases has increased, so has our ability to control these diseases. Changes in cultural practices have resulted in reduced levels of disease. Simultaneously, the development of more effective fungicides and their registration for use on strawberries have significantly reduced losses due to both anthracnose crown rot and fruit rot. Anthracnose-resistant cultivars have also decreased economic losses caused by these diseases. retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Smith, B.J. 2007. Developmental stage and temperature affect strawberry flower and fruit susceptibility to anthracnose, p. 55–57. In: F. Takeda, D.T. Handley, and E.B. Poling (eds.). Proc. 2007 North American Strawberry Symposium. North American Strawberry Growers Association, Kemptville, ON, Canada.', 0.7316364049911499]]
Context 1: [['Madden, L.V., Wilson, L.L., Ellis, M.A. 1993. Field spread of anthracnose in strawberry. Plant Disease. 77:861–866.', 0.5832853317260742]]
Context 2: [['Introduction: The spread of strawberry anthracnose can be exacerbated by the use of infected runner plantlets (Hirayama et al. 2010). Effective management strategies must consider these factors to mitigate disease outbreaks.', 0.5233322381973267]]
Context 3: [['Anthracnose is an important disease of strawberry caused by Colletotrichum spp., which affects foliage, runners, crowns, and fruits (Howard et al., 1992). Three primary fungal pathogens—C. acutatum sensu lato, C. gloeosporioides sensu lato, and C. fragariae—are known to cause anthracnose disease in strawberries (Freeman and Katan, 1997). The crown rot syndrome is characteristic of infections from C. gloeosporioides sensu lato and C. fragariae, while fruit rot is mainly attributed to C. acutatum sensu lato, leading to significant yield losses (Howard et al., 1992). Currently, numerous species are classified under what is now known as the C. acutatum complex, with six species—C. acutatum sensu stricto, C. fioriniae, C. godetiae, C. nymphaeae, C. salicis, and C. simmondsii—identified as associated with strawberry anthracnose worldwide (Damm et al., 2012). Among these, C. nymphaeae is the most prevalent pathogen causing strawberry anthracnose globally, including in Iran (Baroncelli et al., 2015; Karimi et al., 2017; Wang et al., 2019). Currently, no effective chemical control methods exist for managing strawberry anthracnose; available options are limited to preventive treatments applied before fruit production (Denoyes-Rothan et al., 1999). Additionally, concerns about the toxic effects of chemical fungicides on the environment and the development of resistance in fungal strains highlight the need for alternative control strategies. Consequently, utilizing resistant cultivars appears to be the most efficient and practical approach for suppressing anthracnose development. In light of recent anthracnose outbreaks in strawberry fields in the Kurdistan province of Iran (Karimi et al., 2017), and the necessity for appropriate strategies to address this issue, the aim of this study was to evaluate the resistance of several commercial strawberry cultivars to the anthracnose fruit rot caused by C. nymphaeae under in vivo and greenhouse conditions.', 0.5182308554649353]]
Context 4: [['So far, anthracnose epidemics have affected strawberry nurseries and production fields worldwide. Reports on Colletotrichum spp. associated with strawberries, curated from literature in PubMed and Clarivate combined with fungal database searches (Farr and Rossman, 2022), were compiled to understand the global diversity and occurrence of the causal agents of strawberry anthracnose. From our findings, since 1931 until July 9, 2022, there have been over 220 citations and 310 records related to the identification of causal agents of strawberry anthracnose at the genus level of Colletotrichum in 36 countries across six continents, with 282 records providing pathogen identification at the species or species complex level.', 0.4130333662033081]]
Context 5: [['From May to September 1995, a severe outbreak of strawberry anthracnose was observed in several strawberry-growing nurseries in Israel. Following transplantation to production fields during September and October, entire beds of strawberry plants collapsed. Typical anthracnose symptoms observed from November 1995 to June 1996 included crown rot, flower blight, and green and ripe fruit rot. This marked the first record of strawberry anthracnose in Israel. Furthermore, in at least four production fields in the same region, hundreds of plants developed symptoms of stunting and chlorosis, which are atypical of strawberry anthracnose. When these plants were uprooted, most of their roots were dark brown and decayed. Colletotrichum was readily isolated from these samples.', 0.37860408425331116]]
Context 6: [['Howard CM, Albregts EE. Anthracnose. In: Compendium of Strawberry Diseases. American Phytopathological Society: Paul St, ed. Maas JL, USA; 1984. pp. 85-87.', 0.3611363470554352]]
Context 7: [['Hartman, J. (2001). Anthracnose of greenhouse and outdoor strawberries. Kentucky Pest News, 908, 5-6.', 0.3012506663799286]]
Context 8: [['Howard, C. M., Maas, J., Chandler, C., and Albregts, E. 1992. Anthracnose of strawberry caused by the Colletotrichum complex in Florida. Plant Disease 76: [page number not provided].', 0.30038541555404663]]
Context 9: [['From 2010 to 2016, we conducted surveys of anthracnose in strawberries in Miaoli County. More than 50% of diseased plants exhibited symptoms characteristic of anthracnose crown rot (ACR), as described by McInnes et al. (1992). ACR resulted in plant losses of up to 30-40% during the seedling stage and around 20% after transplanting. Initial symptoms in crown tissue included a marbled red and white appearance, which progressed to brown rot and eventual rapid wilting of the plant. Anthracnose symptoms also appeared on other parts of the plant, including leaves, petioles, runners, fruits, and roots. These symptoms manifested as circular black spots on leaves, withering and girdling on runners.', 0.300152063369751]]

query: How can I test if my plants are infected with Colletotrichum spp.?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Many species belonging to the genus Colletotrichum are associated with plant diseases, commonly referred to as anthracnose. Colletotrichum spp. can affect a wide range of hosts, and these pathogens are characterized by global distribution. Virtually every cultivated botanical family is susceptible to one or more species of Colletotrichum, making it one of the most studied plant pathogenic fungi (Prusky et al., 2000; Latunde-Dada, 2001; Dean et al., 2012). Common hosts include many dicotyledonous plants such as strawberry, apple, citrus, and stone fruits, as well as major cereals such as maize and sorghum. Members of this genus can cause crop losses of up to 100% in many staple foods (Bailey and Jeger, 1992; Prusky et al., 2000; Talhinhas et al., 2005; Cannon et al., 2012).', 0.8284348845481873]]
Context 1: [['The genus Colletotrichum is considered one of the top ten important genera of fungal pathogens globally (Dean et al., 2012). Colletotrichum is an ancient fungus that has co-evolved with flowering plants. Plant microfossils of Protocolletotrichum preserved on angiosperm leaf cuticles suggest that the diverse pathogenic strategies of Colletotrichum spp. have been established since the Late Cretaceous period (Kar et al., 2004). Different complexes within the genus may have diverged between 4.8 and 32.2 million years ago (MYA) (Bhunjun et al., 2021). The emergence of agricultural cultivation and the intensive disturbance of natural environments have further driven the diversification of Colletotrichum species. These fungi have adapted to thousands of hosts and can be found as endophytes, pathogens, and saprobes (Freeman et al., 1998; Dean et al., 2012; Hirayama et al., 2018; da Silva et al., 2020; Jayawardena et al., 2020). Currently, a total of 257 Colletotrichum species grouped into 15 complexes and 13 additional singletons have been accepted in this genus.', 0.6021906137466431]]
Context 2: [['Bailey, J.A., et al. (1992). Infection strategies of Colletotrichum species. In: Colletotrichum: Biology, Pathology and Control (Eds. J.A. Bailey and M.J. Jeger). CAB International: Wallingford: 88-120.', 0.4521166980266571]]

query: How was Colletotrichum miaoliense characterized?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Colletotrichum miaoliense sp. nov. P. C. Chung & H. Y. Wu. MycoBank number MB835424. Etymology: The epithet "miaoliense" specifically refers to Miaoli County, Taiwan, where the new taxon was discovered.', 0.9023571610450745]]
Context 1: [['Three isolates of C. miaoliense were collected from Miaoli County and Nantou County, Taiwan. Multi-locus analysis revealed that C. miaoliense forms a robust clade distinct from other known species in the C. acutatum species complex. Among the six Colletotrichum species in this complex (C. acutatum, C. fioriniae, C. godetiae, C. nymphaeae, C. salicis, and C. simmondsii) identified as anthracnose pathogens of strawberry, C. miaoliense is most closely related phylogenetically to C. nymphaeae and C. simmondsii. Morphologically, C. miaoliense differs from C. nymphaeae (CBS 515.78) in conidial size (16.1 × 2.3 – 4.9 × 0.7 μm versus 14.2 × 1.1 – 4.1 × 0.34 μm), conidial shape (one end round and the other rounded to acute, contrasting with the new species where both ends are acute), and appressoria size (8.7 × 2.5 – 5.5 × 1.0 μm versus 7.5 × 1.0 μm).', 0.8889206051826477]]

query: How do environmental factors affect the lifestyle and pathogenicity of C. acutatum species complex members?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Members of the C. acutatum species complex have been well-documented from agricultural and natural hosts worldwide (Perfect et al., 1999; Peres et al., 2005; Sreenivasaprasad and Talhinhas, 2005). The scientific community has long studied the biomolecular processes regulating this lifestyle, especially those related to the switch from biotrophy to necrotrophy. The species complex has a very wide host range. Meta-analyses have revealed that C. acutatum s.l. strains are associated with infections in hundreds of species from over 90 genera of plants (Magnoliophyta: monocotyledons and dicotyledons, Pinophyta, and Pteridophyta), along with at least two insect species (Dufresne et al., 2000; Thon et al., 2002; Wharton and Diéguez-Uribeondo, 2004; O’Connell et al., 2012; Marcelino et al., 2008; Mascarin et al., 2016). In a few cases, associations have been noted with marine ecosystems (Manire et al., 2002; Namikoshi et al., 2002). There appears to be little to no evidence of co-evolution between host and pathogen, particularly in cultivated fruit systems like strawberry and olive, which are susceptible to many members of this species complex (Jayawardena et al., 2016).', 0.9819502830505371]]
Context 1: [['Abstract: Colletotrichum acutatum is recognized as a significant anthracnose pathogen affecting a broad range of host plants globally. Numerous studies have reported subgroups within the C. acutatum species complex. A multilocus molecular phylogenetic analysis (ITS, ACT, TUB2, CHS-1, GAPDH, HIS3) involving 331 strains previously identified as C. acutatum and related taxa—spanning various hosts across diverse geographic regions—confirmed the previously recognized molecular groups and identified several novel taxa. Thirty-one species are accepted, of which 21 have not been previously recognized. Colletotrichum orchidophilum clusters basal to the C. acutatum species complex. This complex exhibits high phenotypic diversity, with some species showing preferences for specific hosts or geographic regions, while others are plurivorous and found in multiple areas. In this study, only C. salicis and C. rhombiforme formed sexual morphs in culture; however, sexual morphs have been documented from other taxa, particularly in laboratory crosses, with evidence of hybridization between different species. A new species, C. pseudoacutatum, was also described, resembling C. acutatum but not belonging to its species complex.', 0.8502962589263916]]
Context 2: [['Damm, U., Cannon, P.F., Woudenberg, J.K.C., and Crous, P.W. 2012. The Colletotrichum acutatum Species Complex. Stud. Mycol., 73: 37-113.', 0.5555148124694824]]
Context 3: [['Damm, U., Cannon, P.F., Woudenberg, J.H.C., Crous, P.W., 2012. The Colletotrichum acutatum species complex. Studies in Mycology 73: 37–113.', 0.5099761486053467]]
Context 4: [['Damm, U., Cannon, P. F., Woudenberg, J. H. C., and Crous, P. W. 2012. The Colletotrichum acutatum species complex. Studia Mycologica 73: 37-113.', 0.49982112646102905]]
Context 5: [['Damm, U., Cannon, P.F., Woudenberg, J.H.C., et al. (2012a). The Colletotrichum acutatum species complex. Studies in Mycology, 73, 37–113.', 0.4693382680416107]]
Context 6: [['Damm, U., Cannon, P.F., Woudenberg, J.H.C., & Crous, P.W. (2012). The Colletotrichum acutatum species complex. Studies in Mycology, 73: 37–113.', 0.4665377140045166]]
Context 7: [['Considering the frequency with which strains from the C. acutatum species complex are encountered and their pathogenicity to a wide range of crop plants, it would be surprising if earlier names for C. acutatum did not exist. Walker et al. (1991) found that C. xanthii (Halsted 1893) was synonymous with C. acutatum based on morphological criteria, but no authentic sequences are available, and it is currently unclear which clade this species fits into. At that time, there was no interest among Colletotrichum researchers to replace the name C. acutatum, and now the name is so widely used that a change would likely not gain recognition. Other older taxa have been recognized as belonging to the C. acutatum complex, but as close relatives rather than formal synonyms. Colletotrichum lupini was found to be an independent taxon within the C. acutatum complex by Nirenberg et al. (2002), rather than belonging to the C. gloeosporioides aggregate, as assumed by Yang & Sweetingham (1998) and Elmer et al. (2001). Farr et al. (2006) found C. phormii (based on Fusarium phormii, Hennings 1898) to be closely related to C. acutatum and noted that older reports of C. gloeosporioides as pathogens of Phormium could actually refer to C. phormii as well.', 0.4647778570652008]]

retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Citation: Cai, L., Hyde, K.D., Taylor, P.W.J., Weir, B.S., Waller, J., Abang, M.M., Zhang, J.Z., Yang, Y.L., Phoulivong, S., Liu, Z.Y., Prihastuti, H., Shivas, R.G., McKenzie, E.H.C., Johnston, P.R. (2009). A polyphasic approach for studying Colletotrichum. Fungal Diversity, 39: 183-204.', 0.6937784552574158]]
Context 1: [['In a drastic move, von Arx (1957) reduced the number of recognized Colletotrichum species from several hundred to 11 based on morphological characteristics, with many taxa treated as synonyms of C. gloeosporioides and C. dematium. Several additional species have since been accepted based on morphological criteria (Sutton, 1980; 1992). The difficulties in recognizing Colletotrichum species can be attributed to: 1) the limited and variable morphological characters; 2) an extensive host range and variability in pathogenicity (Bailey and Jeger, 1992; Freeman et al., 2000; Latunde-Dada, 2001; Du et al., 2005; Thaung, 2008); 3) type specimens that are often missing or in poor condition, making them unsuitable for molecular studies; and 4) numerous rDNA ITS sequences of Colletotrichum strains in NCBI that are often misidentified (Crouch et al., 2009d; Damm et al., 2009).', 0.5026229619979858]]
Context 2: [['The genus Colletotrichum is considered one of the top ten important genera of fungal pathogens globally (Dean et al., 2012). Colletotrichum is an ancient fungus that has co-evolved with flowering plants. Plant microfossils of Protocolletotrichum preserved on angiosperm leaf cuticles suggest that the diverse pathogenic strategies of Colletotrichum spp. have been established since the Late Cretaceous period (Kar et al., 2004). Different complexes within the genus may have diverged between 4.8 and 32.2 million years ago (MYA) (Bhunjun et al., 2021). The emergence of agricultural cultivation and the intensive disturbance of natural environments have further driven the diversification of Colletotrichum species. These fungi have adapted to thousands of hosts and can be found as endophytes, pathogens, and saprobes (Freeman et al., 1998; Dean et al., 2012; Hirayama et al., 2018; da Silva et al., 2020; Jayawardena et al., 2020). Currently, a total of 257 Colletotrichum species grouped into 15 complexes and 13 additional singletons have been accepted in this genus.', 0.42207157611846924]]

Context 8: [['The name Colletotrichum was first introduced by Tode (1790) under the genus Vermicularia. Context 9: [['Much has been written about various individual species of Colletotrichum, yet in many cases, the name used represents a species complex, and it is unclear which actual species is involved. query: What is the role of host resistance in managing strawberry anthracnose?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Anthracnose is an important disease of strawberry caused by Colletotrichum spp., which affects foliage, runners, crowns, and fruits (Howard et al., 1992). Three primary fungal pathogens—C. acutatum sensu lato, C. gloeosporioides sensu lato, and C. fragariae—are known to cause anthracnose disease in strawberries (Freeman and Katan, 1997). The crown rot syndrome is characteristic of infections from C. gloeosporioides sensu lato and C. fragariae, while fruit rot is mainly attributed to C. acutatum sensu lato, leading to significant yield losses (Howard et al., 1992). Currently, numerous species are classified under what is now known as the C. acutatum complex, with six species—C. acutatum sensu stricto, C. fioriniae, C. godetiae, C. nymphaeae, C. salicis, and C. simmondsii—identified as associated with strawberry anthracnose worldwide (Damm et al., 2012). Among these, C. nymphaeae is the most prevalent pathogen causing strawberry anthracnose globally, including in Iran (Baroncelli et al., 2015; Karimi et al., 2017; Wang et al., 2019). Currently, no effective chemical control methods exist for managing strawberry anthracnose; available options are limited to preventive treatments applied before fruit production (Denoyes-Rothan et al., 1999). Additionally, concerns about the toxic effects of chemical fungicides on the environment and the development of resistance in fungal strains highlight the need for alternative control strategies. Consequently, utilizing resistant cultivars appears to be the most efficient and practical approach for suppressing anthracnose development. In light of recent anthracnose outbreaks in strawberry fields in the Kurdistan province of Iran (Karimi et al., 2017), and the necessity for appropriate strategies to address this issue, the aim of this study was to evaluate the resistance of several commercial strawberry cultivars to the anthracnose fruit rot caused by C. nymphaeae under in vivo and greenhouse conditions.', 0.9420921206474304]]
Context 1: [['Overall, the study highlights the importance of cultural practices and genetic resistance in managing strawberry anthracnose effectively.', 0.8529131412506104]]
Context 2: [['Ballington, J.R., J.L. Shuman, B.J. Smith, and S.C. Hokanson. 2002. Breeding strawberries (Fragaria × ananassa) for resistance to anthracnose caused by Colletotrichum acutatum. Acta Horticulturae 567:89–92.', 0.5152714848518372]]
Context 3: [['Ballington, J.R., J.L. Shuman, B.J. Smith, and S.C. Hokanson. 2002. Breeding strawberries (Fragaria × ananassa) for resistance to anthracnose caused by Colletotrichum acutatum. Acta Hort. 567: 89—92.', 0.48799264430999756]]
Context 4: [['Ye, Z. W., Zheng, H. Q., & Tong, Y. M. (1997). First report on species of strawberry anthracnose pathogen in Shanghai suburbs and resistance of some strawberry cultivars to anthracnose. Acta Agriculturae Shanghai, 13, 75–80.', 0.44596633315086365]]
Context 5: [['Introduction: The spread of strawberry anthracnose can be exacerbated by the use of infected runner plantlets (Hirayama et al. 2010). Effective management strategies must consider these factors to mitigate disease outbreaks.', 0.4147590100765228]]
Context 6: [['Numerous reports indicate that strawberry anthracnose pathogens may originate from weed species. For instance, C. fragariae was found attacking the weed Cassia obtusifolia L. (sicklepod, coffeweed) in Florida, causing typical disease symptoms. Inoculation of strawberry with the Cassia isolates resulted in typical anthracnose symptoms, while isolates from strawberry were equally virulent on Cassia. Similarly, inoculation of Duchesnea indica (Andr.) Focke (wild strawberry), F. virginiana Duch. (Virginia wild strawberry), and Potentilla canadensis L. with C. fragariae induced anthracnose disease on these hosts, suggesting that strawberry anthracnose pathogens have a broad host range.', 0.33985596895217896]]
Context 7: [['Shao, X. H. (1992). New disease of strawberry: Strawberry anthracnose. Acta Agriculturae Shanghai.', 0.29253777861595154]]
Context 8: [['Howard, C. M., and Albregts, E. E. 1979. ‘Dover’: a firm-fruited strawberry with resistance to anthracnose. UF/IFAS Circ. S-267, Florida.', 0.28820011019706726]]

query: What are the environmental impacts of large-scale strawberry farming?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Strawberry (Fragaria × ananassa) is a major crop cultivated in China (Xie et al. 2010). The production of strawberries has rapidly expanded in recent years, positioning China as one of the world’s largest producers and exporters. As of 2013, strawberry cultivation covered 100.5 × 10^3 hectares, yielding 2.8 million tonnes (The Ministry of Agriculture of the People’s Republic of China 2014). However, with increased production, many fungal diseases have emerged as significant challenges, negatively impacting fruit yield and quality (Mass 1998, Smith 2008). Among these, anthracnose, caused by species of Colletotrichum, is one of the most critical diseases affecting strawberries.', 0.47241324186325073]]
Context 1: [['Strawberries (Fragaria×ananassa Duch.) are a widely cultivated hybrid species within the Rosaceae family, renowned for their fruit. They are increasingly significant for the agricultural economic development of countries like Iran, particularly in the Kurdistan province, which leads in strawberry production, predominantly under open-field conditions (Tehranifar and Sarsaefi, 2002). Various biotic and abiotic factors contribute to the decline in strawberry production globally. Notably, over 100 fungal species can invade strawberry plants, with approximately one-third causing serious diseases on different plant parts (Martin and others).', 0.2751569449901581]]
Context 2: [['Strawberry (Fragaria ananassa Duch.) is a popular small fruit crop known for its high economic and nutritive value, and it is in high demand globally. From 2008 to 2018, the annual worldwide cultivation of strawberries increased from approximately 400 to 483 thousand hectares. Although strawberries are native to temperate regions, they can also be grown in tropical and subtropical regions, sometimes under high-altitude conditions. The land areas devoted to strawberry cultivation in Colombia, Peru, Guatemala, Bolivia, and Taiwan in 2018 were 1,482 ha, 1,453 ha, 690 ha, 522 ha, and 506 ha, respectively.', 0.20398913323879242]]
Context 3: [['Although strawberries are considered a minor crop, they provide a significant source of income for many fruit and nursery growers. In the United States, strawberries were cultivated on nearly 20,000 hectares in 1989, yielding a total production of 555,000 tons valued at $520 million. Florida ranks second only to California in the production of fresh-market strawberries. For U.S. winter production (December through March), strawberries are grown on approximately 2,400 hectares. The major cultural problems faced by the Florida strawberry industry include: 1) anthracnose diseases, 2) yearly infestations of the two-spotted spider mite (Tetranychus urticae Koch), and 3) variability in the quality of nursery transplants. Commercial fields are established annually, similar to California practices. Freshly dug transplants are sourced from nurseries in Florida or from northern states and Canada. The use of transplants from northern nurseries is crucial to avoid anthracnose disease issues and to ensure that plants have undergone sufficient natural chilling to induce floral bud initiation.', 0.20182378590106964]]

Context 8: [['In February 1999, it was reported that rotating with oats and fertilizing with NH4-N can suppress take-all disease in wheat. Both oat cultivars suppressed black root rot under the (NH4)2SO4 regime but differed in their effects on the two main pathogens. Saia oats reduced the number of root lesion nematodes but did not affect root colonization by Rhizoctonia spp. In contrast, Garry oats reduced root colonization by Rhizoctonia spp. but did not affect the numbers of lesion nematodes. Furthermore, the Saia oat pre-crop increased early berry yield, whereas Garry oats had no significant effect. The yield increase following rotation with Saia oats may have been due to its unsuitability as a host for the lesion nematode, which, in these soils, may have been a more yield-reducing pathogen. In other experiments, we found that Saia oats were similar to Garry oats in reducing R. fragariae recovery from soil (14; J. A. LaMondia, unpublished research). Therefore, the failure of Garry oats to affect yield may be attributed to its high susceptibility to the lesion nematode. The resistance of Saia oats to the lesion nematode was first recognized by Colbran (3), who noted its utility in suppressing re-plant problems in apple orchards. Townsend (24) later demonstrated that Saia oats were resistant to Pratylenchus neglectus Rensch and P. penetrans. However, the resistance to the lesion nematode does not entirely explain the effects of Saia oats on disease and yield, as sorgho-sudangrass also reduced lesion nematodes but had no significant impact on disease severity or yield. The reduction in nematode densities by sorgho-sudangrass may have been insufficient to affect yield. Additionally, it is possible that oat straw residues have specific effects on the disease. Papavizas (18) reported that oat (presumably A. sativa) straw residues increased the number of antagonistic bacteria to R. solani and other fungal pathogens in soil. Since we did not examine antagonism, it is unclear whether the residues of Avena spp. act differently toward soil microbes compared to those of sorgho-sudangrass.', 0.10330899059772491]]

query: How does anthracnose affect the overall quality and yield of strawberries?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Anthracnose is an important disease of strawberry caused by Colletotrichum spp., which affects foliage, runners, crowns, and fruits (Howard et al., 1992). Three primary fungal pathogens—C. acutatum sensu lato, C. gloeosporioides sensu lato, and C. fragariae—are known to cause anthracnose disease in strawberries (Freeman and Katan, 1997). The crown rot syndrome is characteristic of infections from C. gloeosporioides sensu lato and C. fragariae, while fruit rot is mainly attributed to C. acutatum sensu lato, leading to significant yield losses (Howard et al., 1992). Currently, numerous species are classified under what is now known as the C. acutatum complex, with six species—C. acutatum sensu stricto, C. fioriniae, C. godetiae, C. nymphaeae, C. salicis, and C. simmondsii—identified as associated with strawberry anthracnose worldwide (Damm et al., 2012). Among these, C. nymphaeae is the most prevalent pathogen causing strawberry anthracnose globally, including in Iran (Baroncelli et al., 2015; Karimi et al., 2017; Wang et al., 2019). Currently, no effective chemical control methods exist for managing strawberry anthracnose; available options are limited to preventive treatments applied before fruit production (Denoyes-Rothan et al., 1999). Additionally, concerns about the toxic effects of chemical fungicides on the environment and the development of resistance in fungal strains highlight the need for alternative control strategies. Consequently, utilizing resistant cultivars appears to be the most efficient and practical approach for suppressing anthracnose development. In light of recent anthracnose outbreaks in strawberry fields in the Kurdistan province of Iran (Karimi et al., 2017), and the necessity for appropriate strategies to address this issue, the aim of this study was to evaluate the resistance of several commercial strawberry cultivars to the anthracnose fruit rot caused by C. nymphaeae under in vivo and greenhouse conditions.', 0.9883072972297668]]
Context 1: [['So far, anthracnose epidemics have affected strawberry nurseries and production fields worldwide. Reports on Colletotrichum spp. associated with strawberries, curated from literature in PubMed and Clarivate combined with fungal database searches (Farr and Rossman, 2022), were compiled to understand the global diversity and occurrence of the causal agents of strawberry anthracnose. From our findings, since 1931 until July 9, 2022, there have been over 220 citations and 310 records related to the identification of causal agents of strawberry anthracnose at the genus level of Colletotrichum in 36 countries across six continents, with 282 records providing pathogen identification at the species or species complex level.', 0.8825084567070007]]
Context 2: [["Anthracnose fungi can attack various parts of the strawberry plant, including crowns, petioles, leaves, fruit trusses, flowers, buds, and fruit. The fungi's ability to attack multiple plant parts, coupled with the involvement of several pathogen species, contributes to the complex nature of strawberry anthracnose. Brooks reported in 1931 that C. fragariae caused spotting and girdling of runners, and later indicated that it also caused spotting of petioles and crown rot in a summer nursery, leading to wilting and death of the plants. Researchers in Louisiana observed all these symptoms and noted that crown rot also occurred in the fruit production field.", 0.8497103452682495]]
Context 3: [['In the early 1980s, anthracnose became a significant disease affecting strawberries in the southeastern United States. In response, the USDA-ARS established a breeding program to develop anthracnose-resistant cultivars suited to the strawberry-growing regions of this area. This initiative was conducted at the Small Fruit Research Station in Poplarville, MS, and the Fruit Laboratory in Beltsville, MD, in collaboration with state experiment stations in Florida, Louisiana, and North Carolina (Galletta et al., 1997; Smith and Spiers, 1982).', 0.7267126441001892]]

Context 6: [['De los Santos, B., de Paredes, G., and Munoz, F. R. 2002. Influence of anthracnose epiphytotic development on strawberry fruit production in Huelva (Southwestern Spain). Acta Hortic. 567:623-626.', 0.6127492189407349]]
Context 7: [['From 2010 to 2016, we conducted surveys of anthracnose in strawberries in Miaoli County. More than 50% of diseased plants exhibited symptoms characteristic of anthracnose crown rot (ACR), as described by McInnes et al. (1992). ACR resulted in plant losses of up to 30-40% during the seedling stage and around 20% after transplanting. Initial symptoms in crown tissue included a marbled red and white appearance, which progressed to brown rot and eventual rapid wilting of the plant. Anthracnose symptoms also appeared on other parts of the plant, including leaves, petioles, runners, fruits, and roots. These symptoms manifested as circular black spots on leaves, withering and girdling on runners.', 0.5818958878517151]]
Context 8: [['Nam MH, Yoo JH, Yun TS, Kim HH, Kim HG. Anthracnose of strawberry: Etiological and ecological characteristics and management. Res Plant Dis 2023;29:205-19.', 0.5737307071685791]]
Context 9: [['The term "anthracnose" was first used to describe a new disease of strawberries caused by Colletotrichum fragariae Brooks. "Strawberry anthracnose" continues to be used as a general term to identify all diseases of strawberries caused by species of Colletotrichum. Strawberry anthracnose diseases have been reported to be caused by C. acutatum J.H. Simmonds, C. gloeosporioides (Penz.) Penz. & Sacc. in Penz. (the teleomorph of Cromereilla cingulata (Stoneman) Spauld. & H. Schrenk), and C. dematium (Pers.) Grove. The latter species only occasionally causes strawberry fruit rots and will not be discussed here.', 0.5114415287971497]]

query: What are the advantages of combining fungicides like prochloraz-Zn and folpet for managing diseases in fruits like strawberries or apples?

Fungicides were applied at the transplant stage to determine whether a single-dip treatment is sufficient for disease control.', 0.989240825176239]]
Context 1: [['Various fungicides and a heat treatment were assessed for their ability to control strawberry anthracnose caused by the fungus Colletotrichum acutatum under laboratory, greenhouse, and field conditions. The effective dose causing 50% inhibition of mycelial growth (ED50) was measured at 30.5, 12.2, 0.2, 0.15, 0.05, 0.07, and 0.05 µg/ml for the fungicides folpet, captan, propiconazole, difenoconazole, combined prochloraz-Zn/folpet, prochloraz-Zn, and prochloraz-Mn, respectively.', 0.9255509376525879]]
Context 2: [['In laboratory experiments, infection in segments of strawberry runners treated with prochloraz-Zn reached 60%, which was significantly reduced compared to the combined prochloraz-Zn/folpet (90%), captan, folpet, and water controls (100%). In the greenhouse, the number of naturally infected transplants killed was significantly reduced by all fungicides and the heat treatment (5 minutes at 49°C) compared to the non-treated control. Prochloraz-Zn was the most effective chemical control treatment but did not differ significantly from the heat treatment.', 0.8871843218803406]]
Context 3: [['In field experiments conducted during 1995 and 1996, the number of naturally infected strawberry transplants killed was significantly reduced by all fungicide treatments relative to the non-treated control. The percent reduction of transplant mortality in the field was 93.3%, 93.1%, 66.7%, 37.7%, and 29.1% for prochloraz-Mn, prochloraz-Zn, combined prochloraz-Zn/folpet, propiconazole, and difenoconazole, respectively.', 0.7352920770645142]]

Context 6: [['Additionally, multisite fungicides such as captan, thiram, and chlorothalonil, which have been available for many decades, remain effective in reducing strawberry anthracnose incidence (Mertely et al. 2018). Chlorothalonil is only registered for nonbearing nurseries when flowers and fruit are absent, yet our surveys indicated that its usage is significantly lower compared to newer single-site fungicides. Due to their efficacy and low resistance risk, multisite fungicides should be the mainstay for disease control in strawberry nurseries. Context 9: [['In the southeastern United States, anthracnose crown rot and fruit rot can be particularly severe in strawberry production fields, especially during wet harvest seasons, which can lead to total crop loss. Fungicides are used to control anthracnose diseases; however, several have become ineffective due to the development of fungicide-resistant strains of the pathogens. Field observations in Florida indicated that growing strawberry plants in soils with low N levels reduced the severity of anthracnose, although this also severely limited fruit production. Both the form of nitrogen and calcium levels influence disease severity. For instance, calcium has been employed to manage soil-borne diseases caused by Pythium spp. on various crops, while nitrate forms of N have been shown to suppress Fusarium wilt in tomatoes, whereas ammonium forms increase disease severity.', 0.20357108116149902]]

query: How can farmers manage plant diseases caused by Colletotrichum?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Many species belonging to the genus Colletotrichum are associated with plant diseases, commonly referred to as anthracnose. Colletotrichum spp. can affect a wide range of hosts, and these pathogens are characterized by global distribution. Virtually every cultivated botanical family is susceptible to one or more species of Colletotrichum, making it one of the most studied plant pathogenic fungi (Prusky et al., 2000; Latunde-Dada, 2001; Dean et al., 2012). Common hosts include many dicotyledonous plants such as strawberry, apple, citrus, and stone fruits, as well as major cereals such as maize and sorghum. Members of this genus can cause crop losses of up to 100% in many staple foods (Bailey and Jeger, 1992; Prusky et al., 2000; Talhinhas et al., 2005; Cannon et al., 2012).', 0.9126880168914795]]
Context 1: [['Various studies highlight the significance of Colletotrichum species in agriculture. Crouch et al. (2009) discussed anthracnose disease caused by the novel species Colletotrichum navitas, while Damm et al. (2013) addressed the Colletotrichum orbiculare species complex, which affects field crops and weeds. Other works by Damm et al. (2012) explored the Colletotrichum acutatum and Colletotrichum boninense species complexes.', 0.8168554306030273]]
Context 2: [['Although Colletotrichum species are primarily responsible for plant diseases, several species have been reported to cause human diseases as opportunistic pathogens. Cano et al. (2004) identified five species of clinical importance, while Damm et al. (2009) confirmed, using molecular data, that Colletotrichum truncatum was isolated from a corneal ulcer in a human eye. Colletotrichum dematium was also reported to cause eye keratitis (Giaconi et al., 2006) and fungal endophthalmitis, a potentially devastating ocular disease that can lead to poor visual outcomes (Chakrabarti et al., 2008).', 0.5700238943099976]]
Context 3: [['Waller, J.M.; Bridge, P.D. "Recent advances in understanding Colletotrichum diseases of some tropical perennial crops." In Colletotrichum: Host Specificity, Pathology, and Host-Pathogen Interaction, Eds. Prusky, D., Freeman, S., Dickman, M.B.; APS Press: St. Paul, MN, USA, 2000; pp. 337–345.', 0.4498482346534729]]
Context 4: [['The genus Colletotrichum is considered one of the top ten important genera of fungal pathogens globally (Dean et al., 2012). Colletotrichum is an ancient fungus that has co-evolved with flowering plants. Plant microfossils of Protocolletotrichum preserved on angiosperm leaf cuticles suggest that the diverse pathogenic strategies of Colletotrichum spp. have been established since the Late Cretaceous period (Kar et al., 2004). Different complexes within the genus may have diverged between 4.8 and 32.2 million years ago (MYA) (Bhunjun et al., 2021). The emergence of agricultural cultivation and the intensive disturbance of natural environments have further driven the diversification of Colletotrichum species. These fungi have adapted to thousands of hosts and can be found as endophytes, pathogens, and saprobes (Freeman et al., 1998; Dean et al., 2012; Hirayama et al., 2018; da Silva et al., 2020; Jayawardena et al., 2020). Currently, a total of 257 Colletotrichum species grouped into 15 complexes and 13 additional singletons have been accepted in this genus.', 0.36958247423171997]]

query: How do environmental conditions affect the severity of anthracnose?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['As our understanding of the anthracnose pathogens and the epidemiology of anthracnose diseases has improved, so has our capacity to control these diseases. Changes in cultural practices have led to reduced levels of disease. Additionally, the development and registration of more effective fungicides for use on strawberries have significantly decreased losses due to anthracnose crown rot and fruit rot. The introduction of partially resistant cultivars has also helped mitigate economic losses due to these diseases. Nonetheless, growers may still experience severe losses when environmental conditions are highly conducive to anthracnose development.', 0.8543485999107361]]
Context 1: [['Increased losses due to anthracnose fruit and crown rots may be related to the shift from matted-row culture to the annual plasticulture production system in the United States. Breeding for genetic resistance to anthracnose and the development of resistant cultivars are primary means for reducing economic losses due to this disease. This approach is environmentally sound because it results in reduced fungicide use. As our knowledge of the anthracnose pathogens and the epidemiology of anthracnose diseases has increased, so has our ability to control these diseases. Changes in cultural practices have resulted in reduced levels of disease. Simultaneously, the development of more effective fungicides and their registration for use on strawberries have significantly reduced losses due to both anthracnose crown rot and fruit rot. Anthracnose-resistant cultivars have also decreased economic losses caused by these diseases. Nevertheless, growers may still face severe losses when environmental conditions are highly favorable for anthracnose development.', 0.7018697261810303]]

query: Why does Colletotrichum sometimes look different under different conditions?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['In a drastic move, von Arx (1957) reduced the number of recognized Colletotrichum species from several hundred to 11 based on morphological characteristics, with many taxa treated as synonyms of C. gloeosporioides and C. dematium. Several additional species have since been accepted based on morphological criteria (Sutton, 1980; 1992). The difficulties in recognizing Colletotrichum species can be attributed to: 1) the limited and variable morphological characters; 2) an extensive host range and variability in pathogenicity (Bailey and Jeger, 1992; Freeman et al., 2000; Latunde-Dada, 2001; Du et al., 2005; Thaung, 2008); 3) type specimens that are often missing or in poor condition, making them unsuitable for molecular studies; and 4) numerous rDNA ITS sequences of Colletotrichum strains in NCBI that are often misidentified (Crouch et al., 2009d; Damm et al., 2009).', 0.46395158767700195]]
Context 1: [['Citation: Cai, L., Hyde, K.D., Taylor, P.W.J., Weir, B.S., Waller, J., Abang, M.M., Zhang, J.Z., Yang, Y.L., Phoulivong, S., Liu, Z.Y., Prihastuti, H., Shivas, R.G., McKenzie, E.H.C., Johnston, P.R. (2009). A polyphasic approach for studying Colletotrichum. Fungal Diversity, 39: 183-204.', 0.4592193067073822]]
Context 2: [['The genus Colletotrichum is considered one of the top ten important genera of fungal pathogens globally (Dean et al., 2012). Colletotrichum is an ancient fungus that has co-evolved with flowering plants. Plant microfossils of Protocolletotrichum preserved on angiosperm leaf cuticles suggest that the diverse pathogenic strategies of Colletotrichum spp. have been established since the Late Cretaceous period (Kar et al., 2004). Different complexes within the genus may have diverged between 4.8 and 32.2 million years ago (MYA) (Bhunjun et al., 2021). The emergence of agricultural cultivation and the intensive disturbance of natural environments have further driven the diversification of Colletotrichum species. These fungi have adapted to thousands of hosts and can be found as endophytes, pathogens, and saprobes (Freeman et al., 1998; Dean et al., 2012; Hirayama et al., 2018; da Silva et al., 2020; Jayawardena et al., 2020). Currently, a total of 257 Colletotrichum species grouped into 15 complexes and 13 additional singletons have been accepted in this genus.', 0.33981189131736755]]
Context 3: [['Despite significant developments over the last ten years, the taxonomy of Colletotrichum is in a state of flux. Many uncertainties exist in the systematics of fungal pathogens from this genus; depending on the taxonomic "guides," the number of species can range from 29 to over 700 (von Arx, 1957; Sutton, 1992). One of the most confusing species is C. gloeosporioides. For example, 594 species of Colletotrichum were reclassified by von Arx as synonyms of C. gloeosporioides. Identification has primarily relied on morphological characteristics of conidia, vegetative and sexual structures, as well as host specificity and cultural characteristics (von Arx, 1957). Unfortunately, conidial morphology and colony characteristics vary even within isolates. query: What is the potential for applying the genetic findings from the 1993 study to develop new disease-resistant coffee varieties?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Sreenivasaprasad, S., Brown, A.R., & Mills, P. (1993). Coffee berry disease pathogen in Africa: genetic structure and relationship to the group species Colletotrichum gloeosporioides. Mycological Research, 87, 995–1000. doi:10.1016/S0953-7562(09)80868-X.', 0.5104010701179504]]
Context 1: [['Sreenivasaprasad, S., Brown, A. E., and Mills, P. R. 1993. Coffee berry disease pathogen in Africa: Genetic structure and relationship to the group species Colletotrichum gloeosporioides. Mycological Research 97:995-1000.', 0.4822617769241333]]
Context 2: [['Species within the C. gloeosporioides species complex are well-known pathogens of Coffea, particularly the African coffee berry disease pathogen C. kahawae (Waller et al. 1993). Additional Coffea-associated components from this species complex in Vietnam and Thailand were studied by Nguyen et al. (2009) and Prihastuti et al. (2009); see Weir et al. (2012, this issue) for further review. Masaba & Waller (1992) noted that strains identified as C. acutatum may cause minor disease in ripening coffee berries. Kenny et al. (2006) and Nguyen et al. (2010) isolated taxa from this species complex in Papua New Guinea and Vietnam, respectively, from coffee leaves, twigs, and fruits. Notably, none of the Vietnamese isolates could infect undamaged coffee berries (Nguyen et al. 2010). One of the C. acutatum cultures studied by Nguyen et al. (BMT(HL)19) was sent to CBS, and a dried sample of this strain is designated here as the holotype of C. walleri. This study identifies it as the only coffee isolate from Asia, while six other isolates from coffee, originating in Africa and Central America, belong to three other species within the C. acutatum species complex (C. fioriniae, C. acutatum s. str., and C. costaricense). Two of these strains were included in the study by Waller et al. (1993).', 0.1742345094680786]]
Context 3: [['Colletotrichum coffeanum F. Noak, Z. Pflanzenkrankh. 11: 202. 1901.', 0.1671299785375595]]
Context 4: [['Malawi: on Coffea arabica (IMI 301220 = ICMP 17811).', 0.1652027815580368]]
Context 5: [['In this paper, C. kahawae sensu Waller et al. (1993) is reduced to subspecies. Based on sequences from the ACT, CAL, CHS-1, GAPDH, TUB2, SOD2, and ITS genes, the coffee berry pathogen cannot be distinguished from isolates derived from a wide range of other hosts that are not pathogenic to coffee. These other isolates are referred to here as C. kahawae subsp. ciggaro. We retain a distinct taxonomic label for the coffee berry pathogen to reflect its biosecurity importance. Besides its biology, C. kahawae subsp. kahawae can be distinguished metabolically and genetically using GS gene sequences. Waller et al. (1993) employed a metabolic test to demonstrate an inability to utilize either citrate or tartrate as a sole carbon source, which helped characterize isolates as C. kahawae. None of our C. kahawae subsp. kahawae isolates were able to utilize either citrate or tartrate, whereas all of the C. kahawae subsp. ciggaro isolates were capable of utilizing one or both of these carbon sources (Weir & Johnston 2009). All C. kahawae subsp. kahawae isolates share a 22 bp deletion in the glutamine synthetase gene, which is absent in the C. kahawae subsp. ciggaro isolates. Note that one of the isolates, CBS 982.69, which is metabolically and genetically typical of C. kahawae subsp. kahawae, was reported by Gielink & Vermeulen (1983) to be non-pathogenic to coffee, though we have not independently verified this result.', 0.15978169441223145]]
Context 6: [['Cameroon: on Coffea arabica (IMI 361501 = ICMP 17905).', 0.15256570279598236]]
Context 7: [['Notes: Waller et al. (1993) discussed the use of the names Colletotrichum coffeanum and Gloeosporium coffeanum Delacr., highlighting geographic and biological differences between these species and the coffee berry pathogen C. kahawae. The relationships between C. coffeanum and G. coffeanum within the C. gloeosporioides species complex remain unclear. The two species were distinguished by Noak (1901) based on the presence or absence of setae in the acervuli. There is a broad range of C. gloeosporioides-like species found on coffee plants (see Waller et al.).', 0.1437552571296692]]

Context 7: [['Forcelini, B. B. & Peres, N. A. Widespread resistance to QoI fungicides in Colletotrichum acutatum from strawberry nurseries and production fields. Plant Health Prog. 19, 338–341 (2018).', 0.6829013228416443]]
Context 8: [['In a study on the control of Colletotrichum acutatum in infected strawberry plants, it was found that a 200- to 500-fold concentration of captan and folpet, along with a 750-fold concentration of azole fungicides, was necessary to achieve 50% fungal growth inhibition compared to prochloraz fungicides.', 0.6746729612350464]]
Context 9: [['Control of Colletotrichum acutatum is highly dependent on frequent applications of both multi-site and single-site fungicides (Mertely et al. 2017a, b). Multi-site fungicides, such as captan, provide satisfactory control of C. acutatum, but they lack a curative effect, necessitating weekly applications throughout the season (Mertely et al. 2017b). Single-site fungicides, particularly the quinone outside inhibitors (QoIs), exhibit a post-infection effect on anthracnose; however, growers are limited in the number of applications permitted during the strawberry production season (Mertely et al. 2017b; Turechek et al. 2006). Given the limited QoI applications allowed during the fruit production phase, the use of broad-spectrum multi-site fungicides is recommended during the vegetative phase. Nevertheless, to ensure symptom-free transplants, single-site fungicides have frequently been used in nurseries, resulting in the selection of fungicide-resistant populations of Botrytis cinerea, another significant strawberry pathogen (Oliveira et al. 2017).', 0.657453179359436]]

Context 2: [['PCR Amplification: For arbitrarily primed PCR (ap-PCR), primers were derived from minisatellite or repeat sequences as follows: CAGCAGCAGCAGCAG (26), GACACGACACGACAC (17), and GACAGACAGACAGACA (32). In the text, these primers have been designated as (CAG)5, (GACAC)3, and (GACA)4, respectively. PCR primers for the detection of the pathogen in planta included the ITS4 primer (TCCTCCGCTTATTGATATGC) coupled with the specific primer for C. acutatum (CaInt2) (GGGGAAGCCTCTCGCGG) (5). PCR reactions were performed in a total volume of 20 µl, containing 10 to 100 ng of genomic DNA, 50 mM KCl, 10 mM Tris-HCl, 0.2 mM each of dATP, dCTP, dGTP, and dTTP, 1.5 mM MgCl2, 1 unit of Taq DNA polymerase (Promega Corp., Madison, WI), and 1 µM primer. The reactions were incubated in a PTC-100 thermocycler (MJ Research Inc., Watertown, MA), starting with 5 minutes of denaturation at 95°C. For ap-PCR, this was followed by 30 cycles consisting of 30 seconds at 95°C, 30 seconds at either 60°C (for (CAG)5) or 48°C (for (GACA)4 and (GACAC)3), and 1.5 minutes at 72°C. C. acutatum-specific PCR reactions were performed under conditions for primer (CAG)5 with 0.5 µM ITS4 primer coupled with 0.5 µM primer CaInt2. Amplification products were separated in agarose gels (1.8% wt/vol; 15 × 10 cm, WXL) in Tris-acetate-EDTA buffer, electrophoresed at 80 V for 2 hours, stained with ethidium bromide, and viewed under UV light for detection of amplification products.', 0.26770851016044617]]

Context 4: [['All amplifications were performed using the T100 Bio-Rad thermal cycler (Bio-Rad Laboratories Inc., Hercules, CA) in a total volume of 25 ml.
