Context 0: [['Chen et al. (2005) identified the KLAP1 gene, which is necessary for causing KLA, particularly for the infection of key lime leaves, but not for flower petals.', 0.9955543875694275]]
Context 1: [['Colletotrichum strains from anthracnose on Key lime leaves in Florida (KLA-Anderson, HM-1, Ss) and MTR-KLA-A1 (Belize) included in the studies by Peres et al. (2008) and MacKenzie et al. (2009) share the same ITS and GAPDH sequences as strain CBS 114.14. Additionally, the ITS sequences of isolates DPI from Citrus aurantifolia in Florida (FN566877, Ramos et al. 2006) and c2 from Citrus sp. in Brazil (EU008878, Giaretta et al. 2010) match that of CBS 114.14 with 100% identity. Probable C. limetticola strains are also included in Guerber et al. (2003) as mtDNA RFLP haplotype J3; the GAPDH sequences of two Key lime strains (MD33, MD15) are nearly identical to that of CBS 114.14. The closest match with the TUB2 sequence of strain CBS 114.14, with 100% identity, is GenBank accession FN611029 from isolate DPI as well (Ramos et al. 2006). In their study on Citrus in Portugal, Ramos et al. (2006) did not find any C. acutatum s. lat.; instead, C. gloeosporioides (s. lat.) seems to be the major anthracnose pathogen.', 0.34203022718429565]]
Context 2: [["Interestingly, all young tissues of key lime are susceptible and severely attacked by C. acutatum. However, on sweet orange and most other citrus crops, including Tahiti lime, only flower tissues are infected, leading to postbloom fruit drop; vegetative tissues remain immune. Isolates of C. acutatum from key lime induce symptoms of postbloom fruit drop on sweet orange, while isolates from affected sweet orange produce minimal anthracnose damage on key lime (6). This type of fruit drop is unique among diseases caused by C. acutatum, as symptoms are induced by plant hormones. Natural fruit abscission typically occurs at the peduncle base, but postbloom fruit drop results in abscission at the fruit's base, leaving persistent calyces and peduncles. Leaves surrounding infected inflorescences often become small and disfigured. Genes responsible for ethylene and jasmonic acid biosynthesis and indole-3-acetic acid regulation are highly induced by C. acutatum infection. Indole acetic acid levels can increase up to 140-fold in infected petals compared to healthy controls.", 0.30597424507141113]]
Context 3: [['The wither tip disease of Citrus aurantifolia appears to be identical to Key lime anthracnose (KLA), a specific disease affecting the leaves, twigs, flowers, and fruits of Key lime (Citrus aurantifolia), which has been well studied in recent years (Brown et al. 1996, Agostini et al. 1992, Timmer & Brown 2000, Peres et al. 2008, MacKenzie et al. 2009). While Agostini et al. (1992) identified the causal organism of KLA as C. gloeosporioides, following von Arx (1957), who listed the fungus as a synonym of that taxon, Brown et al. (1996) assigned the fungus to C. acutatum based on ITS sequence data. According to Farr & Rossman (2012), Gm. limetticola has been reported from Citrus aurantifolia in Barbados, California, Cuba, Fiji, Florida, Hawaii, India, Jamaica, the Philippines, and Tanzania.', 0.30460095405578613]]
Context 4: [['The sequence and nature of the infection process, including the initial penetration phase—which may involve a biotrophic or quiescent relationship—and the subsequent development of infection hyphae and colonization of the host varies and is not well understood in most cases. With citrus postbloom fruit drop, the infection strategy on leaves is presumably biotrophic. After the end of the bloom period, conidia germinate to form appressoria, establishing quiescent infections that are likely intracellular (6, 92). The tissues where quiescent infections develop are never colonized, and necrotrophy does not occur on leaves; rather, conidia and secondary conidia are produced following the germination of the appressorium on the surface. However, on flower petals, the pathogen behaves as a necrotroph. For key lime and strawberries, the biotrophic phase is very short. The pathogen produces appressoria, penetrates the host, and forms a subcuticular intramural necrotrophic association almost immediately (16). Curry et al. (16) regarded this strategy as a modification of necrotrophy rather than bio- or hemibiotrophy due to the brief biotrophic phase.', 0.14374364912509918]]
Context 5: [['Pathogenicity tests conducted by MacKenzie et al. (2009) yielded results similar to those by Clausen (1912); only Colletotrichum isolates from key lime caused leaf necrosis on key lime, whereas isolates from PFD, strawberry (identified as C. nymphaeae in this study), blueberry (identified as C. fioriniae), and leatherleaf fern did not. Key lime isolates also caused necrosis in flowers of Orlando tangelo flower clusters, but the percentage of affected flowers was lower compared to those inoculated with PFD isolates.', 0.07584360986948013]]
Context 6: [['Penzig AGO contributed to the study of parasitic fungi in citrus (Michelia, 1882; 2: 385-508). The publication can be found at https://www.researchgate.net/publication/281224191.', 0.07034709304571152]]
Context 7: [['Brown, A.E., Sreenivasaprasad, S., & Timmer, L.W. (1996). Molecular characterization of slow-growing orange and key lime anthracnose strains of Colletotrichum from citrus as C. acutatum. Phytopathology, 86, 523–527.', 0.04666893184185028]]
Context 8: [['Brown, A. E., Sreenivasaprasad, S., and Timmer, L. W. (1996). Molecular characterization of slow-growing orange and key lime anthracnose strains of Colletotrichum from citrus as C. acutatum. Phytopathology, 86, 523-527.', 0.046397991478443146]]
Context 9: [['Brown, A. E., Sreenivasaprasad, S., and Timmer, L. W. 1996. Molecular characterization of slow-growing orange and key lime anthracnose strains of Colletotrichum from citrus as C. acutatum. Phytopathology 86:523-527.', 0.04466713219881058]]

query: What challenges exist in Colletotrichum taxonomy?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Despite significant developments over the last ten years, the taxonomy of Colletotrichum is in a state of flux. Many uncertainties exist in the systematics of fungal pathogens from this genus; depending on the taxonomic "guides," the number of species can range from 29 to over 700 (von Arx, 1957; Sutton, 1992). One of the most confusing species is C. gloeosporioides. For example, 594 species of Colletotrichum were reclassified by von Arx as synonyms of C. gloeosporioides. Identification has primarily relied on morphological characteristics of conidia, vegetative and sexual structures, as well as host specificity and cultural characteristics (von Arx, 1957). Unfortunately, conidial morphology and colony characteristics vary even within isolates. Consequently, classical methods have been supplemented with biochemical and molecular technologies to differentiate Colletotrichum species (J. W. Kronstad, ed., Fungal Pathology, 127-148. © 2000 Kluwer Academic Publishers). For a more complete discussion of this topic, see Sherriff et al. (1994).', 0.9339419603347778]]
Context 1: [['In a drastic move, von Arx (1957) reduced the number of recognized Colletotrichum species from several hundred to 11 based on morphological characteristics, with many taxa treated as synonyms of C. gloeosporioides and C. dematium. Several additional species have since been accepted based on morphological criteria (Sutton, 1980; 1992). The difficulties in recognizing Colletotrichum species can be attributed to: 1) the limited and variable morphological characters; 2) an extensive host range and variability in pathogenicity (Bailey and Jeger, 1992; Freeman et al., 2000; Latunde-Dada, 2001; Du et al., 2005; Thaung, 2008); 3) type specimens that are often missing or in poor condition, making them unsuitable for molecular studies; and 4) numerous rDNA ITS sequences of Colletotrichum strains in NCBI that are often misidentified (Crouch et al., 2009d; Damm et al., 2009).', 0.9128637313842773]]
Context 2: [['The genus Colletotrichum is considered one of the top ten important genera of fungal pathogens globally (Dean et al., 2012). Colletotrichum is an ancient fungus that has co-evolved with flowering plants. Plant microfossils of Protocolletotrichum preserved on angiosperm leaf cuticles suggest that the diverse pathogenic strategies of Colletotrichum spp. have been established since the Late Cretaceous period (Kar et al., 2004). Different complexes within the genus may have diverged between 4.8 and 32.2 million years ago (MYA) (Bhunjun et al., 2021). The emergence of agricultural cultivation and the intensive disturbance of natural environments have further driven the diversification of Colletotrichum species. These fungi have adapted to thousands of hosts and can be found as endophytes, pathogens, and saprobes (Freeman et al., 1998; Dean et al., 2012; Hirayama et al., 2018; da Silva et al., 2020; Jayawardena et al., 2020). Currently, a total of 257 Colletotrichum species grouped into 15 complexes and 13 additional singletons have been accepted in this genus.', 0.3819197714328766]]
Context 3: [['The name Colletotrichum was first introduced by Tode (1790) under the genus Vermicularia. The genus Colletotrichum itself was established by Corda (1831) and is now recognized as comprising “coelomycetes” with a Glomerella teleomorph stage (Sutton, 1992; Shenoy et al., 2007a; Hyde et al., 2009). This genus includes species with endophytic, epiphytic, saprobic, and phytopathogenic lifestyles (Kumar and Hyde, 2004; Photita et al., 2001a,b).', 0.3794349431991577]]
Context 4: [['Hyde, K.D., Cai, L., Cannon, P.F., Crouch, J.A., Crous, P.W., Damm, U., Goodwin, P.H., Chen, H., Johnston, P.R., Jones, E.B.G., Liu, Z.Y., McKenzie, E.H.C., Moriwaki, J., Noireung, P., Pennycook, S.R., Pfenning, L.H., Prihastuti, H., Sato, T., Shivas, R.G., Tan, Y.P., Taylor, P.W.J., Weir, B.S., Yang, Y.L., Zhang, J.Z., 2009. Colletotrichum – names in current use. Fungal Diversity 39: 147–182.', 0.3432373106479645]]
Context 5: [['Much has been written about various individual species of Colletotrichum, yet in many cases, the name used represents a species complex, and it is unclear which actual species is involved. In the following section, we review three species of Colletotrichum to highlight the problems associated with inadequate knowledge of the species and potential incorrect or inaccurate naming.', 0.3305649161338806]]
Context 6: [['Lenné, J. M. 1977. A study of the biology and taxonomy of the genus Colletotrichum. Ph.D. thesis. University of Melbourne, Australia.', 0.3254019021987915]]
Context 7: [['Yang, Y.L., Liu, Z.Y., Cai, L., Hyde, K.D., Yu, Z.N., & McKenzie, E.H.C. (2009). Colletotrichum.', 0.31816917657852173]]
Context 8: [['Hyde, K.D., Cai, L., Cannon, P.F., Crouch, J.A., Crous, P.W., Damm, U., Goodwin, P.H., Chen, H., Johnston, P.R., Jones, E.B.G., Liu, Z.Y., McKenzie, E.H.C., Moriwaki, J., Noireung, P., Pennycook, S.R., Pfenning, L.H., Prihastuti, H., Sato, T., Shivas, R.G., Tan, Y.P., Taylor, P.W.J., Weir, B.S., Yang, Y.L., and Zhang, J.Z. Context 9: [['Hyde, K., Cai, L., Cannon, P., Crouch, J.A., Crous, P.W., Damm, U., Goodwin, P.H., Chen, H., Johnston, P.R., Jones, E.B.G., Liu, Z.Y., McKenzie, E.H.C., Moriwaki, J., Norieung, P., Pennycook, S.R., Pfenning, L.H., Prihastuti, H., Sato, T., Shivas, R.G., Tan, Y.P., Taylor, P.W.J., Weir, B.S., Yang, Y.L., Zhang, J.Z. query: How does temperature influence the spread and severity of anthracnose in strawberries?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Smith, B.J. 2007. Developmental stage and temperature affect strawberry flower and fruit susceptibility to anthracnose, p. 55–57. In: F. Takeda, D.T. Handley, and E.B. Poling (eds.). Proc. 2007 North American Strawberry Symposium. North American Strawberry Growers Association, Kemptville, ON, Canada.', 0.9263942241668701]]
Context 1: [['Anthracnose is an important disease of strawberry caused by Colletotrichum spp., which affects foliage, runners, crowns, and fruits (Howard et al., 1992). Three primary fungal pathogens—C. acutatum sensu lato, C. gloeosporioides sensu lato, and C. fragariae—are known to cause anthracnose disease in strawberries (Freeman and Katan, 1997). The crown rot syndrome is characteristic of infections from C. gloeosporioides sensu lato and C. fragariae, while fruit rot is mainly attributed to C. acutatum sensu lato, leading to significant yield losses (Howard et al., 1992). Currently, numerous species are classified under what is now known as the C. acutatum complex, with six species—C. acutatum sensu stricto, C. fioriniae, C. godetiae, C. nymphaeae, C. salicis, and C. simmondsii—identified as associated with strawberry anthracnose worldwide (Damm et al., 2012). Among these, C. nymphaeae is the most prevalent pathogen causing strawberry anthracnose globally, including in Iran (Baroncelli et al., 2015; Karimi et al., 2017; Wang et al., 2019). Currently, no effective chemical control methods exist for managing strawberry anthracnose; available options are limited to preventive treatments applied before fruit production (Denoyes-Rothan et al., 1999). Additionally, concerns about the toxic effects of chemical fungicides on the environment and the development of resistance in fungal strains highlight the need for alternative control strategies. Consequently, utilizing resistant cultivars appears to be the most efficient and practical approach for suppressing anthracnose development. In light of recent anthracnose outbreaks in strawberry fields in the Kurdistan province of Iran (Karimi et al., 2017), and the necessity for appropriate strategies to address this issue, the aim of this study was to evaluate the resistance of several commercial strawberry cultivars to the anthracnose fruit rot caused by C. nymphaeae under in vivo and greenhouse conditions.', 0.5101475119590759]]

Context 4: [['Many species belonging to the genus Colletotrichum are associated with plant diseases, commonly referred to as anthracnose. Colletotrichum spp. can affect a wide range of hosts, and these pathogens are characterized by global distribution. Virtually every cultivated botanical family is susceptible to one or more species of Colletotrichum, making it one of the most studied plant pathogenic fungi (Prusky et al., 2000; Latunde-Dada, 2001; Dean et al., 2012). Common hosts include many dicotyledonous plants such as strawberry, apple, citrus, and stone fruits, as well as major cereals such as maize and sorghum. Members of this genus can cause crop losses of up to 100% in many staple foods (Bailey and Jeger, 1992; Prusky et al., 2000; Talhinhas et al., 2005; Cannon et al., 2012).', 0.3080025613307953]]

query: How do PCR-based techniques facilitate the study of fungal pathogens?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['PCR Amplification: For arbitrarily primed PCR (ap-PCR), primers were derived from minisatellite or repeat sequences as follows: CAGCAGCAGCAGCAG (26), GACACGACACGACAC (17), and GACAGACAGACAGACA (32). In the text, these primers have been designated as (CAG)5, (GACAC)3, and (GACA)4, respectively. PCR primers for the detection of the pathogen in planta included the ITS4 primer (TCCTCCGCTTATTGATATGC) coupled with the specific primer for C. acutatum (CaInt2) (GGGGAAGCCTCTCGCGG) (5). PCR reactions were performed in a total volume of 20 µl, containing 10 to 100 ng of genomic DNA, 50 mM KCl, 10 mM Tris-HCl, 0.2 mM each of dATP, dCTP, dGTP, and dTTP, 1.5 mM MgCl2, 1 unit of Taq DNA polymerase (Promega Corp., Madison, WI), and 1 µM primer. The reactions were incubated in a PTC-100 thermocycler (MJ Research Inc., Watertown, MA), starting with 5 minutes of denaturation at 95°C. For ap-PCR, this was followed by 30 cycles consisting of 30 seconds at 95°C, 30 seconds at either 60°C (for (CAG)5) or 48°C (for (GACA)4 and (GACAC)3), and 1.5 minutes at 72°C. C. acutatum-specific PCR reactions were performed under conditions for primer (CAG)5 with 0.5 µM ITS4 primer coupled with 0.5 µM primer CaInt2. Amplification products were separated in agarose gels (1.8% wt/vol; 15 × 10 cm, WXL) in Tris-acetate-EDTA buffer, electrophoresed at 80 V for 2 hours, stained with ethidium bromide, and viewed under UV light for detection of amplification products.', 0.2189326137304306]]

query: How is pathogenicity testing used to validate the identity of Colletotrichum isolates?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Pathogenicity testing is highlighted as a crucial step to determine whether a specific Colletotrichum species is host-specific or has a broader host range. Host-specific taxa may have limited distributions, which carry significant biosecurity implications. Conversely, species with a wide host range may be more cosmopolitan and potentially opportunistic pathogens. Koch’s postulates have been applied to confirm the pathogenicity of various Colletotrichum isolates. For instance, studies have shown that C. acutatum causes Rhododendron anthracnose, while C. boninense was implicated in leaf infections of Euonymus. New species descriptions occasionally include data on pathogenicity testing, although this is not always the case. Further pathogenicity research is encouraged to validate findings across verified Colletotrichum species.', 0.9966779947280884]]
Context 1: [['Colletotrichum spp. are currently identified using morpho-taxonomic criteria, such as morphological characters, including conidial shape and size, appressorium morphology and size, and setae morphology, as well as temperature response on potato dextrose agar (PDA) medium. Recently, various molecular approaches have been employed to discriminate among different Colletotrichum spp. or to study the genetic diversity within these species. Some of these studies have focused on Colletotrichum spp. isolated from strawberry, distinguishing the three species pathogenic to strawberries.', 0.8816148042678833]]
Context 2: [["The table presents the origin and characteristics of various Colletotrichum isolates used in the study, including species, isolate identifiers, geographic origin (state or country), site/plot information, cultivar details, molecular analysis results, vegetative compatibility grouping (VCG), and pathogenicity assays. For example, C. fragariae isolate CF-63-1 is from Mississippi, U.S., while C. gloeosporioides isolate CG-272-1 originates from Florida, U.S. The table details each isolate's specific host tissue, such as crown, leaf, fruit, or root, and indicates which isolates were tested positive for molecular analysis, VCG, and pathogenicity. This comprehensive overview aids in understanding the diversity and pathogenic potential of the isolates.", 0.8544641733169556]]
Context 3: [['Species descriptions will become standardized, and if morphological characters prove to be totally inadequate, they may be eliminated altogether. Pathogenicity testing will become essential to establish the biological role of these fungi. Colletotrichum has particular biosecurity importance, and until the genus becomes better defined, we suggest that plant quarantine authorities delay taking imprudent action. Many Colletotrichum species are proving to be widespread on a broad range of hosts, with some functioning as endophytes as well as pathogens. Many recently described species (e.g., in Prihastuti et al., 2009; Yang et al., 2009) are found to be prevalent on a variety of unrelated hosts, acting as endophytes, epiphytes, pathogens, or weak and opportunistic pathogens.', 0.8178624510765076]]
Context 4: [['In the past, common identification systems for Colletotrichum included traditional morphological taxonomy, molecular classification based on ITS sequences, and the presence of secondary metabolites, among other traits. However, these methods alone or in combination were insufficient to fully resolve the species identity of individual Colletotrichum isolates. Additional characteristics, including other aspects of morphology and multi-gene phylogenetic analyses, are necessary for accurate identification of Colletotrichum species.', 0.5884333252906799]]
Context 5: [['The Colletotrichum isolates used in this study are listed in Table 3. Morphological examination classified these twenty isolates into six morphogroups, while analysis of the ITS sequence revealed eight phylogenetic lineages (details provided below). For comparison, reference strains of several important Colletotrichum species were included, such as Colletotrichum simmondsii R.G. Shivas & Y.P. Tan (holotype, BRIP 28519), C. truncatum (Schwein.) Andrus & W.D. Moore (CBS 120709), C. coccodes (Wallr.) S. Hughes (CPOS1), C. gloeosporioides (epitype, CBS 953.97), and C. trichellum (Fr.) Duke (HKUCC 10378).', 0.37939193844795227]]

query: What are the advantages of using multi-gene phylogenetic analysis for studying fungi?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Phylogenetic trees constructed from ApMat and gs gene sequences exhibited similar topologies to the multigene phylogenetic tree, confirming that the ApMat and gs loci are highly informative and distinguish most species in the Gloeosporioides species complex (Silva et al. 2012; Sharma et al. 2013; Liu et al. 2015). However, some recently described species (Diao et al. 2017; Marin-Felix et al. 2017) could not be placed within the ApMat and gs phylogenetic trees due to the absence of ApMat gene sequence data. Although previous reports indicated that the gs gene alone is not a reliable marker for differentiating C. siamense isolates (Weir et al. 2012), our data showed multiple base pair differences in the gene sequences of the gs loci of C. siamense, similar to those observed in the ApMat locus. Additionally, the lack of noticeable subclading in C. siamense in the 5-gene tree, compared to the ApMat and gs tree, confirmed that the ApMat and gs loci are more informative than the other five gene loci. The ApMat gene has been shown to enhance the systematics of the Gloeosporioides species complex, providing complementary phylogenetic information compared to other loci (Silva et al. 2012). Liu et al. (2015) also employed the ApMAT gene in recent molecular phylogenetic analyses of species in this complex and discussed the advantages of using ApMat in conjunction with gs to resolve phylogeny.', 0.7986657023429871]]
Context 1: [['The species we accept are based on a phylogenetic species concept, with all species forming strongly supported, monophyletic clades within our multigene phylogenies. However, not all terminal clades are recognized as named species. In most cases, any well-supported within-species phylogenetic structure evident in the multigene phylogeny is not resolved consistently across all gene trees. This lack of congruence between gene trees indicates that the diversity being sampled is below the species level, according to the logic of the genealogical concordance phylogenetic species recognition (GCPSR) concept (Taylor et al. 2000). Although concatenating gene sequences is a convenient way to present multigene data, it can mask discordance between individual gene phylogenies. An alternative method, using a species-tree approach (Figs. 3, 4B, 5B), combines multi-gene data from multiple isolates hypothesized to represent a single species, allowing for the estimation of the evolutionary history of the species rather than that of individual isolates. Fig. 3 shows the results of such an analysis for the C. gloeosporioides complex, while Figs. 4B and 5B illustrate relationships within the Musae and Kahawae clades, respectively, at an expanded scale. Posterior probabilities for some of the speciation events are low, particularly within the Musae and Kahawae clades. This may be because, while species-tree algorithms account for incomplete lineage sorting (Heled & Drummond 2010, Chung & Ané 2011), most do not compensate for horizontal gene transfer, reassortment, or introgression. Hybridization could also result in discordant gene phylogenies. Hybrids are known in the C. acutatum complex, such as Glomerella acutata, a hybrid formed by crossing C. acutatum and C. fioriniae strains in the laboratory, as well as a putative hybrid strain collected from terminal crook disease on Pinus in New Zealand, where both species coexist in nature (Damm et al. 2012a, this issue). Hybrids also form in the C. gloeosporioides complex, such as the Carya and Aeschynomene populations discussed by Cisar et al. (1994), which are more or less genetically equivalent to our species within the C. gloeosporioides complex.', 0.4592745006084442]]
Context 2: [['Taylor, J. W. et al. Phylogenetic species recognition and species concepts in fungi. Fungal Genet. Biol. 31, 21–32 (2000).', 0.33934465050697327]]
Context 3: [['Taylor, J.W., Jacobson, D.J., Kroken, S., Kasuga, T., Geiser, D.M., Hibbett, D.S., and Fisher, M.C. (2000). Phylogenetic species recognition and species concepts in fungi. Fungal Genetics and Biology, 31: 21-32.', 0.3369543254375458]]
Context 4: [['Taylor, J.W., Jacobson, D.J., Kroken, S., Kasuga, T., Geiser, D.M., Hibbett, D.S., and Fisher, M.C. (2000). Phylogenetic species recognition and species concepts in fungi. Fungal Genetics and Biology 31: 21-32.', 0.3284122347831726]]
Context 5: [['Taylor, J.W., Jacobson, D.J., Kroken, S., Kasuga, T., Geiser, D.M., et al. (2000). Phylogenetic species recognition and species concepts in fungi. Fungal Genetics and Biology 31: 21–32.', 0.3210289180278778]]

query: How do the disease management practices for strawberries in Israel compare to those used in Brazil, especially for diseases like anthracnose?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Anthracnose is an important disease of strawberry caused by Colletotrichum spp., which affects foliage, runners, crowns, and fruits (Howard et al., 1992). Three primary fungal pathogens—C. acutatum sensu lato, C. gloeosporioides sensu lato, and C. fragariae—are known to cause anthracnose disease in strawberries (Freeman and Katan, 1997). The crown rot syndrome is characteristic of infections from C. gloeosporioides sensu lato and C. fragariae, while fruit rot is mainly attributed to C. acutatum sensu lato, leading to significant yield losses (Howard et al., 1992). Currently, numerous species are classified under what is now known as the C. acutatum complex, with six species—C. acutatum sensu stricto, C. fioriniae, C. godetiae, C. nymphaeae, C. salicis, and C. simmondsii—identified as associated with strawberry anthracnose worldwide (Damm et al., 2012). Among these, C. nymphaeae is the most prevalent pathogen causing strawberry anthracnose globally, including in Iran (Baroncelli et al., 2015; Karimi et al., 2017; Wang et al., 2019). Currently, no effective chemical control methods exist for managing strawberry anthracnose; available options are limited to preventive treatments applied before fruit production (Denoyes-Rothan et al., 1999). Additionally, concerns about the toxic effects of chemical fungicides on the environment and the development of resistance in fungal strains highlight the need for alternative control strategies. Consequently, utilizing resistant cultivars appears to be the most efficient and practical approach for suppressing anthracnose development. In light of recent anthracnose outbreaks in strawberry fields in the Kurdistan province of Iran (Karimi et al., 2017), and the necessity for appropriate strategies to address this issue, the aim of this study was to evaluate the resistance of several commercial strawberry cultivars to the anthracnose fruit rot caused by C. nymphaeae under in vivo and greenhouse conditions.', 0.6250969171524048]]
Context 1: [['From May to September 1995, a severe outbreak of strawberry anthracnose was observed in several strawberry-growing nurseries in Israel. Following transplantation to production fields during September and October, entire beds of strawberry plants collapsed. Typical anthracnose symptoms observed from November 1995 to June 1996 included crown rot, flower blight, and green and ripe fruit rot. This marked the first record of strawberry anthracnose in Israel. Furthermore, in at least four production fields in the same region, hundreds of plants developed symptoms of stunting and chlorosis, which are atypical of strawberry anthracnose. When these plants were uprooted, most of their roots were dark brown and decayed. Colletotrichum was readily isolated from these samples.', 0.3341250717639923]]
Context 2: [['Overall, the study highlights the importance of cultural practices and genetic resistance in managing strawberry anthracnose effectively.', 0.28033602237701416]]
Context 3: [['Ballington, J.R., J.L. Shuman, B.J. Smith, and S.C. Hokanson. 2002. Breeding strawberries (Fragaria × ananassa) for resistance to anthracnose caused by Colletotrichum acutatum. Acta Horticulturae 567:89–92.', 0.26007315516471863]]
Context 4: [['The establishment of transplants in the field is a critical phase in strawberry production in Israel. Plants affected by strawberry anthracnose during this stage face significant mortality rates.', 0.23850862681865692]]
Context 5: [['Ballington, J.R., J.L. Shuman, B.J. Smith, and S.C. Hokanson. 2002. Breeding strawberries (Fragaria × ananassa) for resistance to anthracnose caused by Colletotrichum acutatum. Acta Hort. 567: 89—92.', 0.22994659841060638]]
Context 6: [['Strawberry (Fragaria × ananassa) is a major crop cultivated in China (Xie et al. 2010). The production of strawberries has rapidly expanded in recent years, positioning China as one of the world’s largest producers and exporters. As of 2013, strawberry cultivation covered 100.5 × 10^3 hectares, yielding 2.8 million tonnes (The Ministry of Agriculture of the People’s Republic of China 2014). However, with increased production, many fungal diseases have emerged as significant challenges, negatively impacting fruit yield and quality (Mass 1998, Smith 2008). Among these, anthracnose, caused by species of Colletotrichum, is one of the most critical diseases affecting strawberries.', 0.21484260261058807]]
Context 7: [['The term "anthracnose" was first used to describe a new disease of strawberries caused by Colletotrichum fragariae Brooks. "Strawberry anthracnose" continues to be used as a general term to identify all diseases of strawberries caused by species of Colletotrichum. Strawberry anthracnose diseases have been reported to be caused by C. acutatum J.H. Simmonds, C. gloeosporioides (Penz.) Penz. & Sacc. in Penz. (the teleomorph of Cromereilla cingulata (Stoneman) Spauld. & H. Schrenk), and C. dematium (Pers.) Grove. The latter species only occasionally causes strawberry fruit rots and will not be discussed here.', 0.2146083414554596]]
Context 8: [['Shao, X. H. (1992). New disease of strawberry: Strawberry anthracnose. Acta Agriculturae Shanghai.', 0.19625188410282135]]
Context 9: [['Maas, J.L. 1998. Compendium of Strawberry Diseases. 2nd ed. Saint Paul: The American Phytopathological Society.', 0.18071554601192474]]

query: Are there any biological agents that can suppress Colletotrichum in the soil?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Many species belonging to the genus Colletotrichum are associated with plant diseases, commonly referred to as anthracnose. Colletotrichum spp. can affect a wide range of hosts, and these pathogens are characterized by global distribution. Virtually every cultivated botanical family is susceptible to one or more species of Colletotrichum, making it one of the most studied plant pathogenic fungi (Prusky et al., 2000; Latunde-Dada, 2001; Dean et al., 2012). Common hosts include many dicotyledonous plants such as strawberry, apple, citrus, and stone fruits, as well as major cereals such as maize and sorghum. Members of this genus can cause crop losses of up to 100% in many staple foods (Bailey and Jeger, 1992; Prusky et al., 2000; Talhinhas et al., 2005; Cannon et al., 2012).', 0.3788747787475586]]

Colletotrichum – names in current use. Fungal Diversity 39: 147–182.', 0.2717483639717102]]

Context 8: [['Waller, J.M.; Bridge, P.D. "Recent advances in understanding Colletotrichum diseases of some tropical perennial crops." In Colletotrichum: Host Specificity, Pathology, and Host-Pathogen Interaction, Eds. Prusky, D., Freeman, S., Dickman, M.B.; APS Press: St. Paul, MN, USA, 2000; pp. 337–345.', 0.24635016918182373]]
Context 9: [['The genus Colletotrichum is considered one of the top ten important genera of fungal pathogens globally (Dean et al., 2012). Colletotrichum is an ancient fungus that has co-evolved with flowering plants. Plant microfossils of Protocolletotrichum preserved on angiosperm leaf cuticles suggest that the diverse pathogenic strategies of Colletotrichum spp. have been established since the Late Cretaceous period (Kar et al., 2004). Different complexes within the genus may have diverged between 4.8 and 32.2 million years ago (MYA) (Bhunjun et al., 2021). The emergence of agricultural cultivation and the intensive disturbance of natural environments have further driven the diversification of Colletotrichum species. These fungi have adapted to thousands of hosts and can be found as endophytes, pathogens, and saprobes (Freeman et al., 1998; Dean et al., 2012; Hirayama et al., 2018; da Silva et al., 2020; Jayawardena et al., 2020). Currently, a total of 257 Colletotrichum species grouped into 15 complexes and 13 additional singletons have been accepted in this genus.', 0.24547700583934784]]

query: What are the symptoms of anthracnose caused by C. acutatum?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Strawberry anthracnose, primarily caused by C. nymphaeae within the C. acutatum complex, is a leading disease limiting fruit yields in the United States (Damm et al. 2012; Legard et al. 2003; Legard and MacKenzie 2003; Mertely et al. 2017a, b; Wang et al. 2018). Characteristic symptoms of C. acutatum infections include flower blight and fruit rot (Mertely et al. 2017b; Peres et al. 2005; Smith 1998). Infected flowers may display brown lesions on the petals, while infected fruits typically present dark, sunken lesions with orange mucilage on their surface, rendering them undesirable for consumption (Peres et al. 2005). During severe epidemics, crown and root infections can also occur in nurseries, leading to stunted growth and reduced fruit production (Mertely et al. 2017a; Peres et al. 2005).', 0.9976931214332581]]
Context 1: [['In Israel, inoculation of isolates of C. acutatum from anemone and strawberry into each host resulted in typical anthracnose symptoms on both plant species. Molecular studies indicated that the isolates from the two hosts were similar and formed a single genetic subgroup. Isolates of C. acutatum were recovered from pepper, eggplant, tomato, bean, as well as from weeds of the genera Vicia and Conyza; however, disease symptoms occurred only on strawberry. C. acutatum isolates from tulip tree in Argentina were also pathogenic to strawberry fruit. Thus, strawberry isolates of C. acutatum can parasitize and cause disease on other hosts or, alternatively, survive on other crops and weeds without producing symptoms.', 0.9961666464805603]]
Context 2: [['C. acutatum was isolated from two weeds, Conyza spp. and Vicia spp., that infested strawberry fields. The weed isolates were similar to those from strawberry, as demonstrated by PCR analysis, and caused typical anthracnose symptoms on strawberry. Thus, not only crop plants but also weeds may be colonized by C. acutatum. This aligns with the detection of C. fragariae, pathogenic to strawberry, on weeds such as chickweed, coffeeweed, sicklepod, fiddleneck, and vetch, growing in containers and around nurseries in Florida. Similarly, strawberry and anemone cultivated in close proximity in Israel were found to be infected by an identical genotype of C. acutatum.', 0.9956938028335571]]
Context 3: [['The epiphytic behavior of C. acutatum on symptomless foliage may play a critical role in the strawberry anthracnose disease cycle. Recent studies have shown that C. acutatum can produce secondary conidia on strawberry leaves without visible symptom development and can persist on symptomless foliage of strawberries and weeds for several weeks. As a result, symptomless leaves may act as a source of inoculum for strawberry anthracnose. Similarly, symptomless foliage of tomato and citrus has been reported to provide inoculum for diseases caused by C. coccodes and C. acutatum, respectively.', 0.9917028546333313]]
Context 4: [['Four C. acutatum isolates from fruits and roots were used to inoculate the foliage and roots of strawberry plants to determine whether symptom development could be affected by the source of the isolate. The tested isolates, regardless of their origin, caused typical anthracnose symptoms on petioles, leaves, and stolons of both Chandler and Sharon cultivars 7 to 10 days after inoculation. After 30 days, 100% mortality was observed in all foliar-inoculated plants, compared to 0% mortality in the water control plants, which remained healthy thereafter.', 0.9910605549812317]]
Context 5: [['Colletotrichum acutatum isolates were obtained from anemone, apple, and peach, infecting detached fruit including two cultivars of apple, avocado, almond, mango, and nectarine. These results demonstrated the cross-infection potential of two species, C. gloeosporioides (including representatives from distinct subpopulations in almond, apple, avocado, and mango) and C. acutatum (from apple and peach), affecting several fruit species. C. acutatum is a known pathogen of the ornamental anemone, causing leaf curl disease. In cross-inoculation experiments involving anemone and strawberry, regardless of the isolate source (anemone or strawberry), all anemone plants died within 14 days of inoculation. Typical anthracnose symptoms were observed on strawberry plants artificially inoculated with isolates from both hosts, leading to eventual mortality.', 0.9903731346130371]]
Context 6: [['Colletotrichum acutatum is particularly significant in Europe, where it is subject to statutory quarantine requirements. Symptoms manifest on various parts of the plant, especially on stolons, flowers, and fruits. Currently, there are no effective chemical control methods available. Cultural techniques, such as drip irrigation and cultivation under plastic tunnels, significantly limit the dispersal of inoculum, thereby reducing fruit losses. Utilizing pathogen-free plants produced through certification schemes can provide a level of disease control; however, latent infections in apparently healthy plants can still lead to anthracnose losses in production fields. Thus, developing strawberry cultivars resistant to C. acutatum is a promising approach for managing anthracnose, offering an economical and environmentally friendly solution. Screening methods evaluating the overall plant reaction have identified accessions resistant to C. acutatum within F. × ananassa. Previous studies on the inheritance of anthracnose resistance have described various modes of resistance. Research by Denoyes and Baudry has suggested that resistance to C. acutatum may exhibit different inheritance modes, depending on the pathogenicity group of the isolate and the resistance level.', 0.9894184470176697]]
Context 7: [['The greatest economic losses due to anthracnose in strawberries are attributed to fruit rot caused by C. acutatum, which also infects many other fruit and vegetable crops, including apples, tomatoes, peppers, peaches, blueberries, blackberries, and grapes (Bernstein et al., 1995; Howard et al., 1992; Smith, 2002). The presence of the pathogen has been reported on strawberries in nearly all areas where they are grown. Crown infections of strawberry plants by C. acutatum often result in stunted plants rather than death. Infected plants typically do not thrive after transplantation and yield few berries at harvest.', 0.9781620502471924]]
Context 8: [['Although C. acutatum survives in soil, on plant debris, and in fumigated field soil, it is assumed that the main source of inoculum usually originates from infected strawberry plant material from the nursery. However, in nurseries or production fields, the pathogen may be introduced through contaminated soil, on field equipment, or may be splash-dispersed or blown in from surrounding vegetation that may carry the fungus without visible symptoms. This work has shown that C. acutatum from strawberries can survive and colonize many other plant species under controlled greenhouse conditions without causing disease, exhibiting epiphytic, endophytic, and non-pathogenic lifestyles. These findings emphasize that various crop plants, including weeds, may serve as potential inoculum sources of C. acutatum. Further investigation is needed to understand the contribution of inoculum from such plants to the development of anthracnose disease in strawberries under field conditions and in the dispersal of the pathogen from season to season.', 0.9724993109703064]]
Context 9: [['This study provides strong evidence that C. acutatum can become established, persist, and produce inoculum on symptomless strawberry leaves under a range of temperatures and intermittent wetness periods. In addition to our previous work at 26°C under continuous wetness (19), we have now shown that secondary conidia and appressoria may be produced under environmental conditions typical of many temperate strawberry-producing areas in the world. The survival of C. acutatum on strawberry leaves has implications for long-distance dissemination on transplants, as well as the proliferation and dissemination of the fungus within production fields. Furthermore, asymptomatic foliage of other plant species, including weeds, has been recently suggested as an additional inoculum source for C. acutatum (12). The environmental biology of C. acutatum on symptomless foliage should therefore be considered when developing management practices for strawberry anthracnose.', 0.971831202507019]]

query: What are the symptoms of anthracnose on strawberries?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['In November 2021, anthracnose symptoms were observed on strawberries (cv. Kingsberry) in Nonsan, Chungnam Province. Early symptoms of anthracnose fruit rot (AFR) include blackening of specific tissues of the strawberry. These symptoms progress with the enlargement of lesions, which hinder proper fruit development and lead to the formation of orange-colored spores within the lesions. Similar symptoms were noted on the petioles, with sunken and blackened tissues similar to those on the fruit, accompanied by the formation of an orange conidial mass.', 0.9938898086547852]]
Context 1: [['Numerous reports indicate that strawberry anthracnose pathogens may originate from weed species. For instance, C. fragariae was found attacking the weed Cassia obtusifolia L. (sicklepod, coffeweed) in Florida, causing typical disease symptoms. Inoculation of strawberry with the Cassia isolates resulted in typical anthracnose symptoms, while isolates from strawberry were equally virulent on Cassia. Similarly, inoculation of Duchesnea indica (Andr.) Focke (wild strawberry), F. virginiana Duch. (Virginia wild strawberry), and Potentilla canadensis L. with C. fragariae induced anthracnose disease on these hosts, suggesting that strawberry anthracnose pathogens have a broad host range.', 0.9769895076751709]]
Context 2: [["Anthracnose fungi can attack various parts of the strawberry plant, including crowns, petioles, leaves, fruit trusses, flowers, buds, and fruit. The fungi's ability to attack multiple plant parts, coupled with the involvement of several pathogen species, contributes to the complex nature of strawberry anthracnose. Brooks reported in 1931 that C. fragariae caused spotting and girdling of runners, and later indicated that it also caused spotting of petioles and crown rot in a summer nursery, leading to wilting and death of the plants. Researchers in Louisiana observed all these symptoms and noted that crown rot also occurred in the fruit production field.", 0.9696232080459595]]
Context 3: [['From May to September 1995, a severe outbreak of strawberry anthracnose was observed in several strawberry-growing nurseries in Israel. Following transplantation to production fields during September and October, entire beds of strawberry plants collapsed. Typical anthracnose symptoms observed from November 1995 to June 1996 included crown rot, flower blight, and green and ripe fruit rot. This marked the first record of strawberry anthracnose in Israel. Furthermore, in at least four production fields in the same region, hundreds of plants developed symptoms of stunting and chlorosis, which are atypical of strawberry anthracnose. When these plants were uprooted, most of their roots were dark brown and decayed. Colletotrichum was readily isolated from these samples.', 0.9668363928794861]]
Context 4: [['Anthracnose is an important disease of strawberry caused by Colletotrichum spp., which affects foliage, runners, crowns, and fruits (Howard et al., 1992). Three primary fungal pathogens—C. acutatum sensu lato, C. gloeosporioides sensu lato, and C. fragariae—are known to cause anthracnose disease in strawberries (Freeman and Katan, 1997). The crown rot syndrome is characteristic of infections from C. gloeosporioides sensu lato and C. fragariae, while fruit rot is mainly attributed to C. acutatum sensu lato, leading to significant yield losses (Howard et al., 1992). Currently, numerous species are classified under what is now known as the C. acutatum complex, with six species—C. acutatum sensu stricto, C. fioriniae, C. godetiae, C. nymphaeae, C. salicis, and C. simmondsii—identified as associated with strawberry anthracnose worldwide (Damm et al., 2012). Among these, C. nymphaeae is the most prevalent pathogen causing strawberry anthracnose globally, including in Iran (Baroncelli et al., 2015; Karimi et al., 2017; Wang et al., 2019). Currently, no effective chemical control methods exist for managing strawberry anthracnose; available options are limited to preventive treatments applied before fruit production (Denoyes-Rothan et al., 1999). Additionally, concerns about the toxic effects of chemical fungicides on the environment and the development of resistance in fungal strains highlight the need for alternative control strategies. Consequently, utilizing resistant cultivars appears to be the most efficient and practical approach for suppressing anthracnose development. In light of recent anthracnose outbreaks in strawberry fields in the Kurdistan province of Iran (Karimi et al., 2017), and the necessity for appropriate strategies to address this issue, the aim of this study was to evaluate the resistance of several commercial strawberry cultivars to the anthracnose fruit rot caused by C. nymphaeae under in vivo and greenhouse conditions.', 0.9573349356651306]]
Context 5: [['Smith, B. J. 1998. Anthracnose leaf spot, irregular spot, anthracnose fruit rot (black spot), and anthracnose crown rot. In: Compendium of Strawberry Diseases. J. L. Mass, ed. American Phytopathological Society, St. Paul, MN. Pages 24-25, 31-33, and 46-48.', 0.911086916923523]]
Context 6: [['The term "anthracnose" was first used to describe a new disease of strawberries caused by Colletotrichum fragariae Brooks. "Strawberry anthracnose" continues to be used as a general term to identify all diseases of strawberries caused by species of Colletotrichum. Strawberry anthracnose diseases have been reported to be caused by C. acutatum J.H. Simmonds, C. gloeosporioides (Penz.) Penz. & Sacc. in Penz. (the teleomorph of Cromereilla cingulata (Stoneman) Spauld. & H. Schrenk), and C. dematium (Pers.) Grove. The latter species only occasionally causes strawberry fruit rots and will not be discussed here.', 0.8983243107795715]]
Context 7: [['Howard CM, Albregts EE. Anthracnose. In: Compendium of Strawberry Diseases. American Phytopathological Society: Paul St, ed. Maas JL, USA; 1984. pp. 85-87.', 0.887492299079895]]

query: Why do researchers grow Colletotrichum in the lab?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['The genus Colletotrichum represents a large number of economically important Ascomycete fungi that collectively cause anthracnose disease or leaf blights on significant agricultural crops and ornamental plants worldwide. Colletotrichum spp. often serve as models in studies ranging from pathogenic development and differentiation to plant-microbe interactions. During establishment and colonization of host plants, members of this genus uniquely acquire nutrients via both biotrophy and necrotrophy. Thus, in a single interaction, these fungal pathogens exhibit two modes of nutrient acquisition: initially, nutrients are acquired from living cells, after which a necrotrophic phase is initiated, allowing the same fungus to obtain nutrients from dead cells killed by the fungus. A given species of this genus can exhibit both strategies separately or concurrently. Additionally, these fungi develop a series of specialized infection-related structures, including germ tubes, appressoria, primary intracellular hyphae, and secondary necrotrophic hyphae. Therefore, Colletotrichum species are experimentally attractive organisms for studying the molecular, biochemical, and cellular basis of fungal pathogenicity, development, and signal transduction (see Bailey and Jeger, 1992; Prusky et al., 1999).', 0.8943505883216858]]
Context 1: [['Citation: Cai, L., Hyde, K.D., Taylor, P.W.J., Weir, B.S., Waller, J., Abang, M.M., Zhang, J.Z., Yang, Y.L., Phoulivong, S., Liu, Z.Y., Prihastuti, H., Shivas, R.G., McKenzie, E.H.C., Johnston, P.R. query: What is the sexual morph associated with C. acutatum?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['A sexual morph was described for C. acutatum (Guerber & Correll 1997, 2001), based on mating-compatible strains in the laboratory. The cross designated as the type of Glomerella acutata was based on two cultures, ATCC 56816 and ATCC MYA-662. The first of these is derived from one of Simmonds’ original Queensland collections from papaya, IMI 117620, which is here designated as the epitype of C. acutatum. However, there is ongoing confusion regarding the provenance of this strain; Guerber & Correll (2001) and Than et al. (2008b) incorrectly equated ATCC 56816 with IMI 117617, the holotype, and this congruence is recorded as such in the ATCC catalog. The second strain, ATCC MYA-662, was isolated from apple in Louisiana, USA (Guerber & Correll 2001), and is assigned here to C. fioriniae in clade 3. Fertile sexual morphs were also produced by Guerber & Correll (2001) and Guerber et al. (2003) by mating a series of different strains, including crosses between parents both assigned to C. fioriniae. None of the strains tested was self-fertile.', 0.9974330067634583]]
Context 1: [['C. acutatum, as noted by various studies (Peres et al. 2008; Lee et al. 2007; Talhinhas et al. 2011; Polashock et al. 2009; Wharton & Schilder 2008), has a well-known morphological feature: the shape of its conidia, which are characterized by acute ends (Simmonds 1965). However, other conidial shapes are frequently encountered, particularly cylindrical forms with only one acute end. These variations are often observed in strains that have been repeatedly subcultured, as well as in the “terminal crook” disease of pine (Dingley & Gilmour 1972) and in the anthracnose affecting leather leaf fern (Schiller et al. 2006). There are also reports of disseminated infections in sea turtles (Manire et al. 2002) and infections in scale insects (Marcelino et al. 2008). Differentiating between C. acutatum (s. lat.) and C. gloeosporioides (s. lat.) is challenging due to the existence of many intermediate strains that exhibit a limited number of typical fusiform conidia alongside numerous cylindrical ones (Van der Aa et al. 1990).', 0.957663357257843]]
Context 2: [['Morphology of C. acutatum. C. acutatum is an Ascomycete classified in the Pyrenomycetes and included in the family Phyllachoraceae. Colonies of C. acutatum are usually white initially but later become covered with pink to orange conidial masses. Cultures from certain hosts are highly chromogenic and excrete red and pink pigments into the culture media. The primary production of conidia occurs in acervuli; however, C. acutatum can also form secondary conidia on the surfaces of living leaves. Conidia are typically ellipsoid and fusiform at least at one end, differing from C. gloeosporioides, which generally has both ends rounded. Setae are usually sparse or not produced at all. Pigmented appressoria form upon germination of the conidia and vary in shape and size.', 0.9156555533409119]]
Context 3: [['Recently, more focus has been placed on conidium morphology, particularly shape and dimensions. The acute conidial ends that contribute to the typical fusiform shape are considered critical morphological features of C. acutatum (Simmonds 1965). However, the name C. acutatum has been applied to various species exhibiting fusiform conidia, many of which are closely related to C. acutatum s. str. Moreover, conidial shape can show significant variation both within the species and among strains (Damm et al. 2012). Studies have shown that the fusiform conidial shape is not a consistent feature in the C. acutatum species complex. For instance, Talhinhas et al. (2002) noted that Colletotrichum isolates from Lupinus spp. (equivalent to C. lupini) displayed varying proportions of conidia with round ends or one round and one acute end, resulting in cylindrical or clavate shapes. In a recent investigation, many strains previously classified as C. gloeosporioides, based on typical cylindrical conidia (Cannon et al. 2008), were found to belong to different species within the C. acutatum complex (Damm et al. 2012). Additionally, there are species with acute-ended conidia that are phylogenetically distinct from the C. acutatum complex, such as C. pseudoacutatum and C. proteae (Cannon et al. 2012; Damm et al. 2012; Liu et al. 2013). The revision of the C. acutatum complex has recognized 31 species through a multilocus molecular approach, significantly advancing our understanding of these plant pathogens (Damm et al. 2012).', 0.8804123997688293]]
Context 4: [['The sexual stage of certain genetic subgroups of C. acutatum has been characterized under laboratory conditions and designated as Glomerella acutata. Research indicates that many isolates from diverse hosts can mate and form mature perithecia in culture. Crosses within isolates in group C, as well as some intergroup crosses, exhibit high fertility, while others show weak fertility or infertility. However, mating compatibility in C. acutatum and other Colletotrichum species is complex.', 0.8542688488960266]]
Context 5: [['Etymology: The name refers to the morphology that is similar to C. acutatum, which is not closely related.', 0.5575076341629028]]
Context 6: [['Intraspecific relationships of C. acutatum sensu lato may be considered as a group species, and the relationships among populations from different host plants remain unclear. Two subspecific forms or physiological taxa of C. acutatum have been described: C. acutatum f. sp. pineum and C. acutatum f. sp. chromogenum. The former was not separated morphologically from C. acutatum, being designated primarily based on its pathogenicity to pines. C. acutatum f. sp. chromogenum was distinguished based on pink and red pigments in the agar medium during culture. Although several studies have characterized isolates, there are currently no formally accepted subspecific nomenclatural designations within C. acutatum.', 0.5022551417350769]]
Context 7: [['The general disease cycles of C. acutatum from different hosts often share common attributes. All produce acervuli with abundant conidia on one or more host tissues, and conidia are splash-dispersed, serving as the primary inoculum source for most infections. Conidia can survive in a gelatinous matrix if conditions are appropriate; however, they typically germinate to produce appressoria and quiescent infections. The tissues on which sporulation and reproduction occur differ among various hosts, and the fate of appressoria and quiescent infections varies greatly. As far as is known, the sexual stage plays only a minor role in the life cycle of C. acutatum. Although the pathogen exhibits overlapping survival strategies, the disease cycles of C. acutatum on different hosts can be grouped according to four general lifestyles.', 0.46087679266929626]]
Context 8: [['Members of the C. acutatum species complex have been well-documented from agricultural and natural hosts worldwide (Perfect et al., 1999; Peres et al., 2005; Sreenivasaprasad and Talhinhas, 2005). The scientific community has long studied the biomolecular processes regulating this lifestyle, especially those related to the switch from biotrophy to necrotrophy. The species complex has a very wide host range. Meta-analyses have revealed that C. acutatum s.l. strains are associated with infections in hundreds of species from over 90 genera of plants (Magnoliophyta: monocotyledons and dicotyledons, Pinophyta, and Pteridophyta), along with at least two insect species (Dufresne et al., 2000; Thon et al., 2002; Wharton and Diéguez-Uribeondo, 2004; O’Connell et al., 2012; Marcelino et al., 2008; Mascarin et al., 2016). In a few cases, associations have been noted with marine ecosystems (Manire et al., 2002; Namikoshi et al., 2002). There appears to be little to no evidence of co-evolution between host and pathogen, particularly in cultivated fruit systems like strawberry and olive, which are susceptible to many members of this species complex (Jayawardena et al., 2016).', 0.3798188269138336]]
Context 9: [['Often, C. acutatum sensu Simmonds from fruit crops is distinguished from other groups of isolates from diverse crop species. Research by Lardner et al. has identified several groups of isolates based on morphology, supported by RAPD analysis and vegetative compatibility. They found that C. acutatum f. sp. pineum from New Zealand and Australia formed two separate groups. According to Guerber et al., isolates from pine in New Zealand were categorized into three groups (A, B, and C) which included isolates from diseased fruit, while two additional groups (D and E) were from lupine.', 0.3549433946609497]]

query: Can the presence of C. novae-zelandiae on grapefruit in New Zealand lead to increased vigilance among citrus growers worldwide?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['C. acutatum is known as a common pathogen of various crops, including citrus, globally (Damm et al. 2012a). In Europe, it has been detected on hosts such as strawberry (Garrido et al. 2008), strawberry tree (Polizzi et al. 2011), and olives (Moral et al. 2008), but not on citrus until now. Furthermore, C. novae-zelandiae was previously reported from grapefruit and chili in New Zealand (Damm et al. 2012b). This study marks the first report of C. acutatum associated with citrus in Europe and the first detection of C. novae-zelandiae outside of New Zealand. C. karstii, part of the C. boninense species complex, has a wide geographical distribution and has been reported on citrus in South Africa, New Zealand, and China (Damm et al. 2012b, Peng et al. 2012, Huang et al. 2013).', 0.9709514379501343]]
Context 1: [['Notes: Colletotrichum novae-zelandiae is morphologically indistinguishable from other species in the C. boninense species complex. It forms a separate lineage or cluster in all single-gene phylogenies, sister to a group including C. karstii, C. petchii, C. annellatum, and C. phyllanthi. This species is known only from New Zealand, where it has been isolated from ripe fruit of Capsicum and Citrus. Johnston & Jones (1997) identified this species as part of the C. gloeosporioides group E, indicating that it was frequently isolated from Citrus fruits and also found on Passiflora edulis, although there was no molecular confirmation.', 0.6769654750823975]]

query: How can the C. acutatum species complex serve as a model for studying broader evolutionary patterns in fungal plant pathogens?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Members of the C. acutatum species complex have been well-documented from agricultural and natural hosts worldwide (Perfect et al., 1999; Peres et al., 2005; Sreenivasaprasad and Talhinhas, 2005). The scientific community has long studied the biomolecular processes regulating this lifestyle, especially those related to the switch from biotrophy to necrotrophy. The species complex has a very wide host range. Meta-analyses have revealed that C. acutatum s.l. strains are associated with infections in hundreds of species from over 90 genera of plants (Magnoliophyta: monocotyledons and dicotyledons, Pinophyta, and Pteridophyta), along with at least two insect species (Dufresne et al., 2000; Thon et al., 2002; Wharton and Diéguez-Uribeondo, 2004; O’Connell et al., 2012; Marcelino et al., 2008; Mascarin et al., 2016). In a few cases, associations have been noted with marine ecosystems (Manire et al., 2002; Namikoshi et al., 2002). There appears to be little to no evidence of co-evolution between host and pathogen, particularly in cultivated fruit systems like strawberry and olive, which are susceptible to many members of this species complex (Jayawardena et al., 2016).', 0.85847008228302]]
Context 1: [['This Perspective article presents a review of the current knowledge on C. acutatum phylogeny, biology, and pathology. It also demonstrates the suitability of C. acutatum for the study of gene family evolution on a fine scale to uncover evolutionary events in the genome associated with the evolution of phenotypic characters important for host interactions.', 0.6187214255332947]]
Context 2: [['Recently, more focus has been placed on conidium morphology, particularly shape and dimensions. The acute conidial ends that contribute to the typical fusiform shape are considered critical morphological features of C. acutatum (Simmonds 1965). However, the name C. acutatum has been applied to various species exhibiting fusiform conidia, many of which are closely related to C. acutatum s. str. Moreover, conidial shape can show significant variation both within the species and among strains (Damm et al. 2012). Studies have shown that the fusiform conidial shape is not a consistent feature in the C. acutatum species complex. For instance, Talhinhas et al. (2002) noted that Colletotrichum isolates from Lupinus spp. (equivalent to C. lupini) displayed varying proportions of conidia with round ends or one round and one acute end, resulting in cylindrical or clavate shapes. In a recent investigation, many strains previously classified as C. gloeosporioides, based on typical cylindrical conidia (Cannon et al. 2008), were found to belong to different species within the C. acutatum complex (Damm et al. 2012). Additionally, there are species with acute-ended conidia that are phylogenetically distinct from the C. acutatum complex, such as C. pseudoacutatum and C. proteae (Cannon et al. 2012; Damm et al. 2012; Liu et al. 2013). The revision of the C. acutatum complex has recognized 31 species through a multilocus molecular approach, significantly advancing our understanding of these plant pathogens (Damm et al. 2012).', 0.5459936261177063]]
Context 3: [['Our research aims to present a comprehensive revision of the C. acutatum species complex. We thoroughly survey the constituent taxa and delineate additional species where needed. We have examined a large number of C. acutatum s. lat. strains, isolated from various hosts and geographic areas. Multi-locus molecular analysis serves as the basis for species recognition, although morphological and cultural characters allowing alternative means of species recognition are provided where possible.', 0.3330196738243103]]
Context 4: [['At this point, it was widely presumed that C. acutatum was a species complex containing several constituent taxa. However, there was substantial reluctance to recognize the clades involved as independent species due to the lack of distinctive morphological and cultural characters. For example, C. lupini was not formally recognized as separate from C. acutatum by Talhinhas et al. (2002) or by Sreenivasaprasad & Talhinhas (2005). Some attempts were made to address these concerns through the adoption of formae speciales, such as C. acutatum f. sp. pineum (Dingley & Gilmour 1972), C. acutatum f. sp. hakeae (Lubbe et al. 2004), and C. acutatum f. sp. fioriniae (Marcelino et al. 2008). However, this mechanism for recognizing pathology-related taxa is now rarely used.', 0.3277970552444458]]
Context 5: [['Considering the frequency with which strains from the C. acutatum species complex are encountered and their pathogenicity to a wide range of crop plants, it would be surprising if earlier names for C. acutatum did not exist. Walker et al. (1991) found that C. xanthii (Halsted 1893) was synonymous with C. acutatum based on morphological criteria, but no authentic sequences are available, and it is currently unclear which clade this species fits into. At that time, there was no interest among Colletotrichum researchers to replace the name C. acutatum, and now the name is so widely used that a change would likely not gain recognition. Other older taxa have been recognized as belonging to the C. acutatum complex, but as close relatives rather than formal synonyms. Colletotrichum lupini was found to be an independent taxon within the C. acutatum complex by Nirenberg et al. (2002), rather than belonging to the C. gloeosporioides aggregate, as assumed by Yang & Sweetingham (1998) and Elmer et al. (2001). Farr et al. (2006) found C. phormii (based on Fusarium phormii, Hennings 1898) to be closely related to C. acutatum and noted that older reports of C. gloeosporioides as pathogens of Phormium could actually refer to C. phormii as well.', 0.23714189231395721]]
Context 6: [['The holotype of Glomerella acutata is therefore an interspecific hybrid between C. acutatum and C. fioriniae. This may be construed as strong evidence that these two taxa constitute a single biological species, suggesting that the species concepts used in this paper are too narrow. However, the parent strains of the holotype originate from geographically distant populations, and there are instances in other fungal groups (e.g., Neurospora) where non-sympatric populations lose post-mating reproductive isolation barriers (Turner et al. 2010, 2011). Further research on population structures and mating-type barriers would be instructive.', 0.2118760496377945]]
Context 7: [['Sato, T., & Moriwaki, J. (2013). Molecular re-identification of strains in NIAS Genbank belonging to phylogenetic groups A2 and A4 of the Colletotrichum acutatum species complex. Microbiology and Cultures Collections, 29, 13–23.', 0.19202636182308197]]
Context 8: [['The C. acutatum species complex has undergone speciation more prolifically than previously suspected, indicating that it is likely still evolving rapidly. The emergence of new species is likely encouraged by modern global agricultural practices, which facilitate the mixing of gene pools, combined with imperfect phytosanitary regulations.', 0.1894424706697464]]
Context 9: [['Shivas, R.G., and Tan, Y.P. (2009). A taxonomic reassessment of Colletotrichum acutatum, introducing C. fioriniae comb. et stat. nov. and C. simmondsii sp. nov. Fungal Diversity, 39: 111-122.', 0.18839384615421295]]

query: What should I do to prevent the disease from spreading in my strawberry field?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Strawberries (Fragaria×ananassa Duch.) are a widely cultivated hybrid species within the Rosaceae family, renowned for their fruit. They are increasingly significant for the agricultural economic development of countries like Iran, particularly in the Kurdistan province, which leads in strawberry production, predominantly under open-field conditions (Tehranifar and Sarsaefi, 2002). Various biotic and abiotic factors contribute to the decline in strawberry production globally. Notably, over 100 fungal species can invade strawberry plants, with approximately one-third causing serious diseases on different plant parts (Martin and others).', 0.3071492612361908]]

Context 7: [['Although strawberries are considered a minor crop, they provide a significant source of income for many fruit and nursery growers. In the United States, strawberries were cultivated on nearly 20,000 hectares in 1989, yielding a total production of 555,000 tons valued at $520 million. Florida ranks second only to California in the production of fresh-market strawberries. For U.S. winter production (December through March), strawberries are grown on approximately 2,400 hectares. The major cultural problems faced by the Florida strawberry industry include: 1) anthracnose diseases, 2) yearly infestations of the two-spotted spider mite (Tetranychus urticae Koch), and 3) variability in the quality of nursery transplants. Commercial fields are established annually, similar to California practices. Freshly dug transplants are sourced from nurseries in Florida or from northern states and Canada. The use of transplants from northern nurseries is crucial to avoid anthracnose disease issues and to ensure that plants have undergone sufficient natural chilling to induce floral bud initiation.', 0.24389374256134033]]
Context 8: [['Strand, L. L. 2008. Integrated Pest Management for Strawberries, 2nd Ed. University of California, Oakland.', 0.2381291538476944]]
Context 9: [['Strawberry (Fragaria × ananassa) is a major crop cultivated in China (Xie et al. 2010). The production of strawberries has rapidly expanded in recent years, positioning China as one of the world’s largest producers and exporters. As of 2013, strawberry cultivation covered 100.5 × 10^3 hectares, yielding 2.8 million tonnes (The Ministry of Agriculture of the People’s Republic of China 2014). However, with increased production, many fungal diseases have emerged as significant challenges, negatively impacting fruit yield and quality (Mass 1998, Smith 2008). Among these, anthracnose, caused by species of Colletotrichum, is one of the most critical diseases affecting strawberries.', 0.23027776181697845]]

query: What is the role of Mississippi's climate and soil conditions in testing and developing anthracnose-resistant strawberry cultivars?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['A total of 1,515 anthracnose-resistant selections were identified from the seedlings tested in Mississippi. Four of these resistant strawberry clones were released as breeding lines (Galletta et al., 1993) and have since been utilized as sources of anthracnose resistance in several breeding programs. Additionally, Smith et al. (1998) released the cultivar Pelican, which demonstrates high resistance to both anthracnose crown rot caused by C. fragariae and anthracnose fruit rot caused by C. acutatum. Pelican is also resistant to varieties of red stele caused by Phytophthora fragariae.', 0.9564937353134155]]
Context 1: [['A total of 1,515 anthracnose-resistant selections were identified from the seedlings tested in Mississippi. Four of these resistant strawberry clones were subsequently released as breeding lines (Galletta et al., 1993) and have served as sources of anthracnose resistance in various breeding programs. Additionally, Smith et al. (1998) released the cultivar "Pelican," which is highly resistant to both anthracnose crown rot caused by C. fragariae and anthracnose fruit rot caused by C. acutatum. "Pelican" also shows resistance to varieties of red stele caused by Phytophthora fragariae.', 0.9564390182495117]]
Context 2: [['The USDA Small Fruit Research Laboratory in Poplarville, Mississippi, along with cooperators in North Carolina, Florida, and Louisiana, is screening strawberry seedlings for resistance to anthracnose (Colletotrichum sp.). Anthracnose is a destructive disease affecting plants and fruits in the southern and south-central United States, involving several species of fungi (Maas, 1984). A screening method developed at the USDA laboratory in Mississippi identified two clones, MSUS 73 and 74, as strongly resistant to anthracnose crown rot, yielding results comparable to standard cultivars while also exhibiting superior internal fruit color. Additionally, several selections from North Carolina, such as ‘NC 3874’ and ‘NC 3892’, show resistance to both anthracnose and red stele.', 0.9278849363327026]]
Context 3: [['In the early 1980s, when anthracnose became a major disease affecting strawberries in the southeastern United States, the USDA-ARS initiated a breeding program aimed at developing anthracnose-resistant cultivars suitable for the region. This program was established at the Small Fruit Research Station in Poplarville, MS, and the Fruit Laboratory in Beltsville, MD, in collaboration with state experiment stations in Florida, Louisiana, and North Carolina (Galletta et al., 1997; Smith and Spiers, 1982). From 1976 to 1995, over 160,000 progeny from 448 crosses made primarily by G.J. Galletta at Beltsville were screened for anthracnose resistance in the greenhouse at Poplarville, MS.', 0.9213963747024536]]
Context 4: [['In the early 1980s, anthracnose became a significant disease affecting strawberries in the southeastern United States. In response, the USDA-ARS established a breeding program to develop anthracnose-resistant cultivars suited to the strawberry-growing regions of this area. This initiative was conducted at the Small Fruit Research Station in Poplarville, MS, and the Fruit Laboratory in Beltsville, MD, in collaboration with state experiment stations in Florida, Louisiana, and North Carolina (Galletta et al., 1997; Smith and Spiers, 1982).', 0.8535460829734802]]
Context 5: [['Anthracnose is an important disease of strawberry caused by Colletotrichum spp., which affects foliage, runners, crowns, and fruits (Howard et al., 1992). Three primary fungal pathogens—C. acutatum sensu lato, C. gloeosporioides sensu lato, and C. fragariae—are known to cause anthracnose disease in strawberries (Freeman and Katan, 1997). The crown rot syndrome is characteristic of infections from C. gloeosporioides sensu lato and C. fragariae, while fruit rot is mainly attributed to C. acutatum sensu lato, leading to significant yield losses (Howard et al., 1992). Currently, numerous species are classified under what is now known as the C. acutatum complex, with six species—C. acutatum sensu stricto, C. fioriniae, C. godetiae, C. nymphaeae, C. salicis, and C. simmondsii—identified as associated with strawberry anthracnose worldwide (Damm et al., 2012). Among these, C. nymphaeae is the most prevalent pathogen causing strawberry anthracnose globally, including in Iran (Baroncelli et al., 2015; Karimi et al., 2017; Wang et al., 2019). Currently, no effective chemical control methods exist for managing strawberry anthracnose; available options are limited to preventive treatments applied before fruit production (Denoyes-Rothan et al., 1999). Additionally, concerns about the toxic effects of chemical fungicides on the environment and the development of resistance in fungal strains highlight the need for alternative control strategies. Consequently, utilizing resistant cultivars appears to be the most efficient and practical approach for suppressing anthracnose development. In light of recent anthracnose outbreaks in strawberry fields in the Kurdistan province of Iran (Karimi et al., 2017), and the necessity for appropriate strategies to address this issue, the aim of this study was to evaluate the resistance of several commercial strawberry cultivars to the anthracnose fruit rot caused by C. nymphaeae under in vivo and greenhouse conditions.', 0.43337327241897583]]
Context 6: [['Ballington, J.R., J.L. Shuman, B.J. Smith, and S.C. Hokanson. 2002. Breeding strawberries (Fragaria × ananassa) for resistance to anthracnose caused by Colletotrichum acutatum. Acta Horticulturae 567:89–92.', 0.291695237159729]]
Context 7: [['Ballington, J.R., J.L. Shuman, B.J. Smith, and S.C. Hokanson. 2002. Breeding strawberries (Fragaria × ananassa) for resistance to anthracnose caused by Colletotrichum acutatum. Acta Hort. 567: 89—92.', 0.27790307998657227]]
Context 8: [['Smith, B. J. (2006). USDA-ARS strawberry anthracnose resistance breeding program. Acta Hort., 708:463-470.', 0.2499687522649765]]
Context 9: [['This study highlights the variability in resistance among strawberry cultivars to AFR and provides insights into cultivar selection for disease management.', 0.20374388992786407]]
