query: What genetic markers were used in the multilocus phylogenetic analysis?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Phylogenetic trees constructed from ApMat and gs gene sequences exhibited similar topologies to the multigene phylogenetic tree, confirming that the ApMat and gs loci are highly informative and distinguish most species in the Gloeosporioides species complex (Silva et al. 2012; Sharma et al. 2013; Liu et al. 2015). However, some recently described species (Diao et al. 2017; Marin-Felix et al. 2017) could not be placed within the ApMat and gs phylogenetic trees due to the absence of ApMat gene sequence data. Although previous reports indicated that the gs gene alone is not a reliable marker for differentiating C. siamense isolates (Weir et al. 2012), our data showed multiple base pair differences in the gene sequences of the gs loci of C. siamense, similar to those observed in the ApMat locus. Additionally, the lack of noticeable subclading in C. siamense in the 5-gene tree, compared to the ApMat and gs tree, confirmed that the ApMat and gs loci are more informative than the other five gene loci. The ApMat gene has been shown to enhance the systematics of the Gloeosporioides species complex, providing complementary phylogenetic information compared to other loci (Silva et al. 2012). Liu et al. (2015) also employed the ApMAT gene in recent molecular phylogenetic analyses of species in this complex and discussed the advantages of using ApMat in conjunction with gs to resolve phylogeny.', 0.9323039650917053]]
Context 1: [['The relationships among our species were not clearly evident based solely on the topologies of gene trees. Phylogenetic reconstructions were performed on three combined datasets to evaluate how these discordances influenced species relationships and their node support in multilocus datasets, as well as to compare the degrees of resolution. Overall, both the traditional and Apn-MAT datasets produced almost completely resolved and highly supported trees but displayed two different topologies. In one topology, C. siamense was reciprocally monophyletic with C. asianum (FIG. 5a; bootstrap: 95; PP: 1.00), while in another, it was monophyletic with C. fructicola (FIG. 5b; bootstrap: 78; PP: 1.00). When all markers were combined, the prevailing phylogenetic relationships aligned with the Apn-MAT dataset, supporting the reciprocal monophyly between C. siamense and C. fructicola (FIG. 5c; bootstrap: 97; PP: 1.00). Notably, both the topology and node support for the single ApMAT marker were comparable to those of the seven-gene concatenated dataset.', 0.7537146806716919]]
Context 2: [['The multilocus phylogenetic analysis of 20 isolates from Japan indicated that these isolates tend to group together within each species, suggesting a single introduction of the different species into the field. This finding is perhaps not surprising given that the isolates originated from a restricted geographical area, but further phylogenetic analyses are needed to confirm this, as the current analysis was limited to only 20 isolates.', 0.6138879060745239]]
Context 3: [['Furthermore, unlike many undescribed or poorly understood lineages in this complex, the species we studied are well characterized and recognized through multilocus phylogenetic and morphological studies. This is crucial when evaluating the utility of newly developed molecular tools for systematic purposes. All these species have been simultaneously used in previous phylogenetic studies, establishing an objective starting point for understanding their taxonomic relationships and enabling a more meaningful comparison between traditional gene-tree concatenation methods and recent species-tree reconstruction techniques.', 0.5028092861175537]]
Context 4: [['To compare sequences with 46 isolates downloaded from GenBank, ITS, GAPDH, ACT, and CHS-1 sequences of all isolates were concatenated using the Fasta alignment joiner software. The aligned sequences were 98.0% to 99.5% homologous to the ex-type C. gloeosporioides s.s. ICMP 17821. Multilocus phylogenetic trees were constructed using neighbor-joining and maximum parsimony methods. The final dataset consisted of 1,061 sites, including 715 conserved sites, 312 variable sites, 163 parsimony informative sites, and 140 singleton sites. In the maximum parsimony phylogenetic tree, the tree length was 465, with a consistency index of 0.56 and a retention index of 0.84. Composite indices were 0.57 for all sites and 0.47 for parsimony-informative sites. The tested isolates clustered with C. gloeosporioides s.s. with 98% bootstrap support (Fig. 4). In the neighbor-joining phylogenetic tree, the total branch length was 0.57, and all 13 studied isolates clustered with C. gloeosporioides s.s., including its ex-type, with 100% bootstrap support (see Supplementary Fig. S1).', 0.4436190724372864]]
Context 5: [['In the single-gene trees for TUB2, CAL, and ApMAT, as well as in the multilocus phylogenetic tree, 39 isolates clustered with strong statistical support in the clade containing the type strain CBS 130417 and other related isolates of C. siamense (Fig. 3; single-gene trees not shown). These 39 isolates formed a subclade with a high support value (1/100/98 for BI/ML/MP) (Fig. 3). Additionally, in single-gene trees for GAPDH, ACT, TUB2, CAL, and ApMAT, as well as in the multilocus phylogenetic tree, six isolates clustered with strong statistical support in the clade containing the type strain CBS 130416 and other related isolates of C. fructicola (Fig. 3; single-gene trees not shown).', 0.3115532398223877]]
Context 6: [['Phylogenetic Analysis: A phylogenetic tree was generated using Bayesian inference based on concatenated sequences of genes: ACT, CHS-1, GAPDH, ITS, and TUB. Monilochaetes infuscans (CBS 869.96) served as an outgroup. Bayesian posterior probabilities (PP ≥ 0.90), maximum parsimony bootstrap support values (ML ≥ 50%), and RAxML bootstrap support values (ML ≥ 50%) are indicated at the nodes of the tree. Ex-type isolates are highlighted in bold. Colored blocks represent clades containing isolates from Pyrus spp.; circles denote isolates sourced from leaves. The scale bar illustrates 0.09 expected changes per site.', 0.3007969856262207]]
Context 7: [['For phylogenetic classification, genomic DNA was extracted from fungal isolates grown on PDA using a modified CTAB extraction protocol. The ITS, ACT, CHS-1, and GAPDH gene regions were amplified using established methods. DNA sequencing was performed on an ABI PRISM 3730XL analyzer at Macrogen (Seoul, Korea). Each sequence was assembled and proofread using MEGA v.7. The sequences generated in this study were deposited in GenBank (PP839268-PP839270 for ITS, PP908669-PP908671 for ACT, PP908672-PP908674 for CHS-1, PP908675-PP908677 for GAPDH). Multiple alignments were conducted using MAFFT ver. 7. Maximum likelihood phylogenetic analyses were carried out using RAxML on the CIPRES web portal with the GTR+G model and 1,000 bootstrap replicates. The phylogenetic analysis revealed that three isolates formed a monophyletic group with C. nymphaeae CBS 515.78 (ex-type), CBS 526.77, CBS 129936, and CBS 126366, with bootstrap support of 89%.', 0.2419682741165161]]
Context 8: [['The incongruence length difference (ILD) test indicated that the ACT, CHS-1, ITS, and TUB2 markers were homogeneous. Consequently, concatenated sequences of these four markers were utilized to generate a phylogenetic tree comprising a total of 81 isolates, including 44 ex-type and epitype strains. The topology of the maximum likelihood (ML) tree was consistent with that of the Bayesian tree; therefore, only the ML tree is presented (Figure 4). Among the 37 isolates, ten clustered with C. asianum strains (ICMP 18580, ICMP 18696, NN8, WM52, and NN19) showing a posterior probability of 0.97 and bootstrap values of 99%. Three isolates formed a clade with C. siamense strains (ICMP 18578, ICMP 17795, ICMP 18121, ICMP 12567, and ICMP 18574) with a posterior probability of 0.97 and bootstrap values of 77%. Nineteen isolates clustered with the C. gloeosporioides strain (ICMP 17821) with a posterior probability of 1.00 and bootstrap values of 99%. Five isolates were clustered with C. acutatum (CBS 112996, IMI 223120, IMI 216370, CBS 144.29, and CBS 979.69) showing a posterior probability of 0.85 and bootstrap values of 99%.', 0.1667453497648239]]
Context 9: [['The species we accept are based on a phylogenetic species concept, with all species forming strongly supported, monophyletic clades within our multigene phylogenies. However, not all terminal clades are recognized as named species. In most cases, any well-supported within-species phylogenetic structure evident in the multigene phylogeny is not resolved consistently across all gene trees. This lack of congruence between gene trees indicates that the diversity being sampled is below the species level, according to the logic of the genealogical concordance phylogenetic species recognition (GCPSR) concept (Taylor et al. 2000). Although concatenating gene sequences is a convenient way to present multigene data, it can mask discordance between individual gene phylogenies. An alternative method, using a species-tree approach (Figs. 3, 4B, 5B), combines multi-gene data from multiple isolates hypothesized to represent a single species, allowing for the estimation of the evolutionary history of the species rather than that of individual isolates. Fig. 3 shows the results of such an analysis for the C. gloeosporioides complex, while Figs. 4B and 5B illustrate relationships within the Musae and Kahawae clades, respectively, at an expanded scale. Posterior probabilities for some of the speciation events are low, particularly within the Musae and Kahawae clades. This may be because, while species-tree algorithms account for incomplete lineage sorting (Heled & Drummond 2010, Chung & Ané 2011), most do not compensate for horizontal gene transfer, reassortment, or introgression. Hybridization could also result in discordant gene phylogenies. Hybrids are known in the C. acutatum complex, such as Glomerella acutata, a hybrid formed by crossing C. acutatum and C. fioriniae strains in the laboratory, as well as a putative hybrid strain collected from terminal crook disease on Pinus in New Zealand, where both species coexist in nature (Damm et al. 2012a, this issue). Hybrids also form in the C. gloeosporioides complex, such as the Carya and Aeschynomene populations discussed by Cisar et al. (1994), which are more or less genetically equivalent to our species within the C. gloeosporioides complex.', 0.16589896380901337]]

query: What factors contribute to the high incidence of anthracnose in Taiwan's strawberry fields?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Anthracnose is a key limiting factor for strawberry production in Taiwan and many other regions. Outbreaks of anthracnose in strawberry nurseries and fields have caused yield losses of up to 50-80%. This study demonstrated the diversity of pathogenic Colletotrichum species associated with strawberry in Taiwan. The findings provide precise information about pathogen identity, which is valuable for screening resistant varieties and developing effective disease management strategies. Regardless of whether inoculated on wounded or non-wounded leaves, the predominant pathogen C. siamense caused larger lesions at 30°C than at 25°C, which is significant in subtropical Taiwan and similar areas. No significant difference was observed between the mycelial growth rates of C. siamense at 25°C, 28°C, and 30°C; hence, the higher disease severity at 30°C may be due to reduced resistance of strawberry plants to anthracnose at elevated temperatures. In Taiwan, the susceptible cultivar Taoyuan No. 1 has been widely cultivated for over 30 years. Developing temperature-independent resistant cultivars will be crucial for strawberry breeding programs in Taiwan and other tropical and subtropical regions. Future work will focus on monitoring pathogen population changes, investigating fungicide sensitivity levels of different Colletotrichum species, and developing molecular detection methods to assist in producing strawberry seedlings free of latent infection by major Colletotrichum species.', 0.9839682579040527]]
Context 1: [['Anthracnose is an important disease of strawberry caused by Colletotrichum spp., which affects foliage, runners, crowns, and fruits (Howard et al., 1992). Three primary fungal pathogens—C. acutatum sensu lato, C. gloeosporioides sensu lato, and C. fragariae—are known to cause anthracnose disease in strawberries (Freeman and Katan, 1997). The crown rot syndrome is characteristic of infections from C. gloeosporioides sensu lato and C. fragariae, while fruit rot is mainly attributed to C. acutatum sensu lato, leading to significant yield losses (Howard et al., 1992). Currently, numerous species are classified under what is now known as the C. acutatum complex, with six species—C. acutatum sensu stricto, C. fioriniae, C. godetiae, C. nymphaeae, C. salicis, and C. simmondsii—identified as associated with strawberry anthracnose worldwide (Damm et al., 2012). Among these, C. nymphaeae is the most prevalent pathogen causing strawberry anthracnose globally, including in Iran (Baroncelli et al., 2015; Karimi et al., 2017; Wang et al., 2019). Currently, no effective chemical control methods exist for managing strawberry anthracnose; available options are limited to preventive treatments applied before fruit production (Denoyes-Rothan et al., 1999). Additionally, concerns about the toxic effects of chemical fungicides on the environment and the development of resistance in fungal strains highlight the need for alternative control strategies. Consequently, utilizing resistant cultivars appears to be the most efficient and practical approach for suppressing anthracnose development. In light of recent anthracnose outbreaks in strawberry fields in the Kurdistan province of Iran (Karimi et al., 2017), and the necessity for appropriate strategies to address this issue, the aim of this study was to evaluate the resistance of several commercial strawberry cultivars to the anthracnose fruit rot caused by C. nymphaeae under in vivo and greenhouse conditions.', 0.7073221206665039]]
Context 2: [['Strawberry anthracnose was first reported in China in 1990 (Hu, 1990). Shao (1992) documented the first instance of strawberry anthracnose in Shanghai, identifying the pathogen as Colletotrichum acutatum (Dai et al., 2006). Zhang et al. (2007) expanded on these findings by identifying C. gloeosporioides and C. fragariae (syn. C. theobromicola) as causal agents based on morphological characteristics. Ren et al. (2008, 2011) concluded that these three species are the main pathogens causing anthracnose in strawberries in China. Crown rot represents the most severe disease issue in many strawberry-producing regions of China (Ren et al., 2008). In the Zhejiang region, nearly 50% of seedling deaths in nurseries and over 40% yield losses in strawberry fields have been recorded (Xie et al., 2010). In 2009, the yield of greenhouse-cultivated strawberries in Donggang City, Liaoning Province, was reduced by over 10% due to crown rot (Wang, 2013). The average incidence of crown rot in greenhouses in Hubei Province was 41.7% in 2011 (Xiang et al., 2012). However, most studies conducted in China regarding this disease have primarily relied on morphological and single-gene (mainly ITS) analysis (Dai et al., 2006; Ren et al., 2008, 2011). Due to overlapping characteristics, species delimitation based solely on morphology is challenging in this genus. Employing multi-gene analysis alongside morphology can provide better resolution (Cai et al., 2009; Hyde et al., 2014). Therefore, the objective of this study was to identify the pathogens responsible for strawberry anthracnose in China using a morphological and multi-gene approach.', 0.6388095617294312]]
Context 3: [['From 2010 to 2016, we conducted surveys of anthracnose in strawberries in Miaoli County. More than 50% of diseased plants exhibited symptoms characteristic of anthracnose crown rot (ACR), as described by McInnes et al. (1992). ACR resulted in plant losses of up to 30-40% during the seedling stage and around 20% after transplanting. Initial symptoms in crown tissue included a marbled red and white appearance, which progressed to brown rot and eventual rapid wilting of the plant. Anthracnose symptoms also appeared on other parts of the plant, including leaves, petioles, runners, fruits, and roots. These symptoms manifested as circular black spots on leaves, withering and girdling on runners.', 0.2967980206012726]]
Context 4: [['Madden, L.V., Wilson, L.L., Ellis, M.A. 1993. Field spread of anthracnose in strawberry. Plant Disease. 77:861–866.', 0.25904595851898193]]
Context 5: [['Nam MH, Yoo JH, Yun TS, Kim HH, Kim HG. Anthracnose of strawberry: Etiological and ecological characteristics and management. Res Plant Dis 2023;29:205-19.', 0.23672617971897125]]
Context 6: [['Howard CM, Albregts EE. Anthracnose. In: Compendium of Strawberry Diseases. American Phytopathological Society: Paul St, ed. Maas JL, USA; 1984. pp. 85-87.', 0.1898690164089203]]
Context 7: [["The strawberry (Fragaria × ananassa), a small fruit crop, was introduced to Bangladesh in 1996 from Japan and the USA, gaining notable acceptance among both growers and consumers. However, as acreage expanded, anthracnose crown rot (ACR) has emerged as a significant challenge for strawberry producers. In March 2016, typical symptoms of ACR were observed in the 'Strawberry Festival' cultivar at a farmer's field in the Rajshahi district of Bangladesh. Symptoms were apparent in approximately 10% of the plants, manifesting as wilting of entire plants during the heat of the day and flagging of young leaves, resembling water deficiency.", 0.18406672775745392]]
Context 8: [['Wang, C. H. (2013). Occurrence and control of strawberry anthracnose in Donggang area.', 0.1580367088317871]]
Context 9: [['Shao, X. H. (1992). New disease of strawberry: Strawberry anthracnose. Acta Agriculturae Shanghai.', 0.15385957062244415]]

Context 6: [['On certain fruits, such as apple and blueberry (Vaccinium spp.), members of the C. acutatum species complex cause both pre-harvest and post-harvest diseases (Milholland, 1995; Jones et al., 1996; Shi et al., 1996). There are many other examples of post-harvest decay in fruits like peaches (Prunus persica), almonds (Prunus dulcis), avocado (Persea americana), mango (Mangifera indica), papaya (Carica papaya), and guava (Psidium guajava) that stem from quiescent infections that began in the field (Agostini et al., 1992; Freeman and Shabi, 1996; Smith, 1998; Afanador-Kafuri et al., 2003).', 0.11818753182888031]]

query: Can I use fungicides on strawberry plants that already have flowers or fruits?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['The application of fungicides to control strawberry anthracnose is limited due to restrictions on pesticide usage and the susceptibility of strawberry plants to Colletotrichum during all stages of development, including flowers, green, and ripe fruit. To reduce anthracnose infection in plant nurseries, it is essential to produce disease-free propagation material, which is a prerequisite for establishing disease-free nursery transplants. Control measures practiced in the United States involve frequent applications of fungicides.', 0.9882886409759521]]
Context 1: [['Additionally, multisite fungicides such as captan, thiram, and chlorothalonil, which have been available for many decades, remain effective in reducing strawberry anthracnose incidence (Mertely et al. 2018). Chlorothalonil is only registered for nonbearing nurseries when flowers and fruit are absent, yet our surveys indicated that its usage is significantly lower compared to newer single-site fungicides. Due to their efficacy and low resistance risk, multisite fungicides should be the mainstay for disease control in strawberry nurseries. Other non-chemical alternatives, such as heat (Wang et al. 2017) and ultraviolet treatments (Onofre et al. 2017), are currently under investigation and could serve as valuable tools for disease management, reducing the reliance on single-site fungicides.', 0.9547736644744873]]
Context 2: [['In the southeastern United States, anthracnose crown rot and fruit rot can be particularly severe in strawberry production fields, especially during wet harvest seasons, which can lead to total crop loss. Fungicides are used to control anthracnose diseases; however, several have become ineffective due to the development of fungicide-resistant strains of the pathogens. Field observations in Florida indicated that growing strawberry plants in soils with low N levels reduced the severity of anthracnose, although this also severely limited fruit production. Both the form of nitrogen and calcium levels influence disease severity. For instance, calcium has been employed to manage soil-borne diseases caused by Pythium spp. on various crops, while nitrate forms of N have been shown to suppress Fusarium wilt in tomatoes, whereas ammonium forms increase disease severity.', 0.7119261026382446]]
Context 3: [['ABSTRACT: Strawberry anthracnose, caused by Colletotrichum fragariae, is a serious problem in the southeastern United States, resulting in significant losses in strawberry nurseries. Control measures using fungicides are crucial, particularly with recommended applications of captafol, benomyl, captan, and maneb.', 0.44734349846839905]]

query: Why is it challenging to distinguish between various Colletotrichum species in field conditions?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['In a drastic move, von Arx (1957) reduced the number of recognized Colletotrichum species from several hundred to 11 based on morphological characteristics, with many taxa treated as synonyms of C. gloeosporioides and C. dematium. Several additional species have since been accepted based on morphological criteria (Sutton, 1980; 1992). The difficulties in recognizing Colletotrichum species can be attributed to: 1) the limited and variable morphological characters; 2) an extensive host range and variability in pathogenicity (Bailey and Jeger, 1992; Freeman et al., 2000; Latunde-Dada, 2001; Du et al., 2005; Thaung, 2008); 3) type specimens that are often missing or in poor condition, making them unsuitable for molecular studies; and 4) numerous rDNA ITS sequences of Colletotrichum strains in NCBI that are often misidentified (Crouch et al., 2009d; Damm et al., 2009).', 0.9600749611854553]]
Context 1: [['Despite significant developments over the last ten years, the taxonomy of Colletotrichum is in a state of flux. Many uncertainties exist in the systematics of fungal pathogens from this genus; depending on the taxonomic "guides," the number of species can range from 29 to over 700 (von Arx, 1957; Sutton, 1992). One of the most confusing species is C. gloeosporioides. For example, 594 species of Colletotrichum were reclassified by von Arx as synonyms of C. gloeosporioides. Identification has primarily relied on morphological characteristics of conidia, vegetative and sexual structures, as well as host specificity and cultural characteristics (von Arx, 1957). Unfortunately, conidial morphology and colony characteristics vary even within isolates. Consequently, classical methods have been supplemented with biochemical and molecular technologies to differentiate Colletotrichum species (J. W. Kronstad, ed., Fungal Pathology, 127-148. © 2000 Kluwer Academic Publishers). For a more complete discussion of this topic, see Sherriff et al. (1994).', 0.8197532296180725]]
Context 2: [['Before the molecular era, the taxonomy of Colletotrichum species was primarily based on morphological and cultural characteristics, including conidia size and shape, presence or absence of setae, colony color, and growth rate (von Arx 1957; Sutton 1980, 1992). However, these characteristics can be unreliable for species differentiation due to variability under changing environmental conditions (Cai et al. 2009).', 0.48749640583992004]]
Context 3: [['Much has been written about various individual species of Colletotrichum, yet in many cases, the name used represents a species complex, and it is unclear which actual species is involved. In the following section, we review three species of Colletotrichum to highlight the problems associated with inadequate knowledge of the species and potential incorrect or inaccurate naming.', 0.46698296070098877]]
Context 4: [['Citation: Cai, L., Hyde, K.D., Taylor, P.W.J., Weir, B.S., Waller, J., Abang, M.M., Zhang, J.Z., Yang, Y.L., Phoulivong, S., Liu, Z.Y., Prihastuti, H., Shivas, R.G., McKenzie, E.H.C., Johnston, P.R. (2009). A polyphasic approach for studying Colletotrichum. Fungal Diversity, 39: 183-204.', 0.37929269671440125]]
Context 5: [['The genus Colletotrichum is considered one of the top ten important genera of fungal pathogens globally (Dean et al., 2012). Colletotrichum is an ancient fungus that has co-evolved with flowering plants. Plant microfossils of Protocolletotrichum preserved on angiosperm leaf cuticles suggest that the diverse pathogenic strategies of Colletotrichum spp. have been established since the Late Cretaceous period (Kar et al., 2004). Different complexes within the genus may have diverged between 4.8 and 32.2 million years ago (MYA) (Bhunjun et al., 2021). The emergence of agricultural cultivation and the intensive disturbance of natural environments have further driven the diversification of Colletotrichum species. These fungi have adapted to thousands of hosts and can be found as endophytes, pathogens, and saprobes (Freeman et al., 1998; Dean et al., 2012; Hirayama et al., 2018; da Silva et al., 2020; Jayawardena et al., 2020). Currently, a total of 257 Colletotrichum species grouped into 15 complexes and 13 additional singletons have been accepted in this genus.', 0.3598746359348297]]
Context 6: [['Cai, L., Hyde, K.D., Taylor, P.W.J., Weir, B., Waller, J., Abang, M.M., Zhang, J.Z., Yang, Y.L., Phoulivong, S., Liu, Z.Y., Prihastuti, H., Shivas, R.G., McKenzie, E.H.C., and Johnston, P.R. (2009). A polyphasic approach for studying Colletotrichum. Fungal Diversity 39: 183-204.', 0.2678954601287842]]
Context 7: [['Jayawardena, R. S., Hyde, K. D., Damm, U., Cai, L., Liu, M., Li, X. H., Zhang, W., Zhao, W. S., and Yan, J. Y. (2016). Notes on currently accepted species of Colletotrichum. Mycosphere, 7, 1192-1260.', 0.2546353042125702]]
Context 8: [['Hyde, K. D., Cai, L., McKenzie, E. H. C., Yang, Y. L., Zhang, J. Z., and Prihastuti, H. (2009b). Colletotrichum: A catalogue of confusion. Fungal Divers., 39, 1-17.', 0.25424131751060486]]
Context 9: [['Due to the complex situations described, diagnostics and etiology of Colletotrichum are critical.', 0.25144150853157043]]

query: Can overwatering contribute to the spread of anthracnose?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Anthracnose spreads within a field by splashing water, and living mulches (such as wheat, rye, or ryegrass) in row middles have been shown to reduce disease spread within a field. Sublethal doses of grass-specific herbicides, such as sethoxydim, may be used to prevent excessive growth of ryegrass (Gupton, 2000). Organic mulches, such as wheat straw or pine needles, also reduce splash and result in a lower incidence of anthracnose compared to rows mulched with plastic (Madden, 1992; Smith and Spiers, 1986). Additionally, anthracnose is less severe when water is supplied to plants using drip irrigation rather than overhead irrigation (Madden, 1992; Smith and Spiers, 1986). Anthracnose crown rot was observed to be less severe in commercial fields when strawberries were grown in soils with low nitrogen fertility (Howard et al., 1992). In greenhouse studies, Smith (1987, 1989) determined that strawberries grown in soils with high levels of nitrogen, especially from ammonium sources, are more susceptible to anthracnose than plants grown in soils with lower nitrogen levels or those with high levels of calcium nitrate.', 0.7039137482643127]]
Context 1: [['Anthracnose spreads within a field by splashing water, and living mulches (such as wheat, rye, or ryegrass) in row middles have been shown to reduce disease spread within a field. Sublethal doses of grass-specific herbicides, such as sethoxydim, may be used to prevent excessive growth of ryegrass (Gupton, 2000). Organic mulches, such as wheat straw or pine needles, also reduce splash and result in a lower incidence of anthracnose compared to rows mulched with plastic (Madden, 1992; Smith and Spiers, 1986). Anthracnose is less severe when water is supplied to plants using drip irrigation rather than overhead irrigation (Madden, 1992; Smith and Spiers, 1986).', 0.6870133876800537]]

query: Can anthracnose be detected in the early stages of plant growth?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['From 2010 to 2016, we conducted surveys of anthracnose in strawberries in Miaoli County. More than 50% of diseased plants exhibited symptoms characteristic of anthracnose crown rot (ACR), as described by McInnes et al. (1992). ACR resulted in plant losses of up to 30-40% during the seedling stage and around 20% after transplanting. Initial symptoms in crown tissue included a marbled red and white appearance, which progressed to brown rot and eventual rapid wilting of the plant. Anthracnose symptoms also appeared on other parts of the plant, including leaves, petioles, runners, fruits, and roots. These symptoms manifested as circular black spots on leaves, withering and girdling on runners.', 0.36480996012687683]]
Context 1: [['Based on field trials in Florida (Mertely et al., 2009), the recommendation for anthracnose control involves weekly applications of a broad-spectrum protectant fungicide (captan) at the lowest label rate early in the season when conditions are less favorable for anthracnose development. Later, when anthracnose-infected flowers and fruit may be present, it is recommended to increase the rate of the protectant fungicide to the highest label rate. Warm, rainy weather in early spring often leads to epidemics, during which additional fungicides may be necessary. Growers are encouraged to scout their fields regularly for anthracnose symptoms, such as blighted flowers or black spots on green fruit. If symptoms are detected, the application of a strobilurin fungicide (such as Abound or Cabrio) in conjunction with the protectant fungicide is recommended. During the main bloom period, in late January and early February, fungicides containing two active ingredients (one for anthracnose control and one for Botrytis fruit rot control), such as CaptEvate, Pristine, or Switch, are advised. Tank mixes or higher rates of protectant fungicides should be maintained until the end of the harvest season or until dry weather effectively suppresses the disease.', 0.2593463361263275]]
Context 2: [['Hemmi, T. (1920). Kurze Mitteilung über drei Fälle von Anthracnose auf Pflanzen. Annals of the Phytopathological Society of Japan, 1(3), 13–21.', 0.25344470143318176]]
Context 3: [['Additional Keywords: anthracnose, disease spread, Fragaria × ananassa, models, quantitative epidemiology.', 0.2312929630279541]]
Context 4: [['Crouch J, Beirn LA. 2009. Anthracnose of cereals and grasses. Fungal Diversity 39:19–44.', 0.22563311457633972]]

query: What is the best time to apply fungicides for anthracnose?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Based on field trials in Florida (Mertely et al., 2009), the recommendation for anthracnose control involves weekly applications of a broad-spectrum protectant fungicide (captan) at the lowest label rate early in the season when conditions are less favorable for anthracnose development. Later, when anthracnose-infected flowers and fruit may be present, it is recommended to increase the rate of the protectant fungicide to the highest label rate. Warm, rainy weather in early spring often leads to epidemics, during which additional fungicides may be necessary. Growers are encouraged to scout their fields regularly for anthracnose symptoms, such as blighted flowers or black spots on green fruit. If symptoms are detected, the application of a strobilurin fungicide (such as Abound or Cabrio) in conjunction with the protectant fungicide is recommended. During the main bloom period, in late January and early February, fungicides containing two active ingredients (one for anthracnose control and one for Botrytis fruit rot control), such as CaptEvate, Pristine, or Switch, are advised. Tank mixes or higher rates of protectant fungicides should be maintained until the end of the harvest season or until dry weather effectively suppresses the disease.', 0.9673244953155518]]
Context 1: [['Present and Future Management of Anthracnose: Fungicides, including chemicals such as benzimidazoles (e.g., thiabendazole, benomyl, and carbendazim) and sterol inhibitors (e.g., imazalil, prochloraz, and propiconazole), have been used effectively to control anthracnose disease in banana, mango, papaya, and avocado plants [140]. Benzimidazoles are commonly applied as dips or sprays to inhibit the anthracnose-causing fungus, Colletotrichum spp. [141], but the large-scale and continuous use of fungicides has led to the development of fungal resistance. For instance, benzimidazole-resistant Colletotrichum has been detected in mangoes and bananas [140]. Additionally, the excessive use of fungicides negatively impacts human health and the environment, as chemical residues often contaminate soil and water [142]. Biocontrol offers an alternative, non-toxic method for managing fruit crop anthracnose. Biocontrol agents, such as antagonistic microbes including yeast, bacteria, and filamentous fungi (particularly Trichoderma spp.), have shown promising results and are gaining popularity for their direct application to fruit surfaces post-harvest [143].', 0.9430851936340332]]
Context 2: [['Past failures of fungicides to control anthracnose epidemics may have stemmed from the development of resistance in the Colletotrichum population. In the early 1970s, benomyl effectively reduced anthracnose crown rot incidence (Horn et al., 1972; Howard, 1971) and was widely used by strawberry growers for years. However, anthracnose pathogens developed resistance to it and other benzimidazole fungicides, rendering benomyl ineffective. In vitro and greenhouse trials have been conducted to identify fungicides to which Colletotrichum pathogens have developed resistance (LaMondia, 1993, 1995; McInnes et al., 1992a, 1992b; Smith and Black, 1991, 1992, 1993). Current fungicide labels address pathogen resistance by restricting the number of consecutive and total applications of a product per season. For instance, the fungicides Abound (azoxystrobin, Syngenta, Greensboro, NC), Cabrio (pyraclostrobin, BASF, Research Triangle Park, NC), and Pristine (pyraclostrobin and boscalid, BASF) are limited to four or five applications per season, with no more than two consecutive applications before alternating with a fungicide that has a different mode of action. Natural products have also been evaluated as alternative fungicides, offering different modes of action, lower toxicity, and increased efficacy (Abril et al., 2008).', 0.8926013708114624]]
Context 3: [['The efficacy of fungicides for anthracnose control is routinely assessed in field studies. For example, 16 different fungicide treatments were evaluated in five studies conducted in Hammond, LA, and Poplarville, MS, during the 2002, 2003, and 2005 fruiting seasons (Wedge et al., 2007).', 0.8300839066505432]]
Context 4: [['There is an urgent need for multi- and single-site fungicide alternatives effective against anthracnose in strawberry nurseries and production fields. The antifungal antibiotic natamycin, widely used as a natural mold inhibitor in food products, has shown promise in controlling anthracnose root and crown infections caused by C. acutatum on strawberry transplants (Cordova et al. 2017; Haack et al. 2018). Similarly, fluazinam, a single-site respiration inhibitor fungicide from FRAC group 29, has demonstrated significant control of anthracnose fruit rot (Mertely et al. 2018). A request has been submitted through the Interregional Research Project Number 4 for its registration for nursery use only. Reducing the overlap of the same modes of action used during nursery and fruit production phases could help extend the lifespan of single-site fungicides at high risk of resistance.', 0.8130152225494385]]
Context 5: [['Until highly resistant cultivars are available, growers must rely on chemical applications and cultural practices to reduce losses due to anthracnose. The failure of fungicides to control anthracnose epidemics may be due to the development of fungicide resistance in the Colletotrichum spp. population. For example, benomyl effectively reduced the incidence of anthracnose crown rot (Horn et al., 1972; Howard, 1971) and was used intensively by strawberry growers for years to control anthracnose and other diseases. However, the anthracnose pathogens, C. acutatum and C. fragariae, developed resistance to it and other benzimidazole fungicides (LaMondia, 1995; McInnes et al., 1992a; Smith and Black, 1992, 1993), rendering benomyl ineffective for anthracnose control in strawberry fields.', 0.7677279114723206]]
Context 6: [['Until highly resistant cultivars are available, growers must rely on chemical applications and cultural practices to reduce losses due to anthracnose. The failure of fungicides to control anthracnose epidemics may be attributed to the development of fungicide resistance in the Colletotrichum species population. For example, benomyl was shown to effectively reduce the incidence of anthracnose crown rot (Horn et al., 1972; Howard, 1971) and was used intensively by strawberry growers for years to control anthracnose and other diseases. However, the anthracnose pathogens, C. acutatum and C. fragariae, developed resistance to it and other benzimidazole fungicides (LaMondia, 1995; McInnes et al., 1992a; Smith and Black, 1992, 1993), leading to the ineffectiveness of benomyl for anthracnose control in strawberry fields.', 0.7676710486412048]]
Context 7: [['Anthracnose fruit rot was observed on berries treated with pyraclostrobin + boscalid, cyprodinil + fludioxonil, azoxystrobin, pyraclostrobin, and captan + fenhexamid, as well as captan alone. Studies conducted in North Carolina indicated that a fungicide spray program consisting of only four applications—one application of a mixture of captan and Topsin M (thiophanate-methyl, Cerexagri-Nisso, King of Prussia, PA), two applications of Pristine, and one application of CaptEvate (fenhexamid and captan, Arysta, Cary, NC)—provided a similar level of disease control as a season-long spray program with eight applications (Rahman et al., 2009). Each application in the shorter program included two fungicides, as both Pristine and CaptEvate contain two active ingredients.', 0.7496468424797058]]
Context 8: [['In addition to chemical treatments, heat treatment of transplants may reduce mortality from anthracnose, but this practice is not widely used due to its potential to reduce plant vigor (Freeman et al., 1997). In-season fungicide spray applications are common to prevent foliar and fruit infections (Koike et al., 2008; MacKenzie and Peres, 2012), but these are ineffective against crown rot and root necrosis (Daugovish et al., 2009).', 0.7009783387184143]]
Context 9: [['Nursery surveys confirmed the intensive use of QoI fungicides. Single-site fungicides, such as QoIs, have frequently been used in nurseries to control anthracnose and other diseases, ensuring the delivery of symptom-free stock material. Along with commercial products containing only azoxystrobin or pyraclostrobin, premixes with QoI fungicides were also utilized. This has led to an increased selection rate for QoI-resistant populations as early as the nursery phase. Since transplants produced in large nurseries are sold to smaller ones, plants may be exposed to multiple QoI applications throughout each propagation phase. Consequently, during the fruit production phase, growers face challenges in controlling anthracnose outbreaks with limited effective chemical options.', 0.7002593278884888]]

Context 2: [['Based on field trials in Florida (Mertely et al., 2009), the recommendation for anthracnose control involves weekly applications of a broad-spectrum protectant fungicide (captan) at the lowest label rate early in the season when conditions are less favorable for anthracnose development. Later, when anthracnose-infected flowers and fruit may be present, it is recommended to increase the rate of the protectant fungicide to the highest label rate. Warm, rainy weather in early spring often leads to epidemics, during which additional fungicides may be necessary. Growers are encouraged to scout their fields regularly for anthracnose symptoms, such as blighted flowers or black spots on green fruit. If symptoms are detected, the application of a strobilurin fungicide (such as Abound or Cabrio) in conjunction with the protectant fungicide is recommended. During the main bloom period, in late January and early February, fungicides containing two active ingredients (one for anthracnose control and one for Botrytis fruit rot control), such as CaptEvate, Pristine, or Switch, are advised. Tank mixes or higher rates of protectant fungicides should be maintained until the end of the harvest season or until dry weather effectively suppresses the disease.', 0.20503205060958862]]
Context 3: [['Additional keywords: phosphonate fungicides, phosphorous acid.', 0.1944372057914734]]
Context 4: [['Anthracnose fruit rot was observed on berries treated with pyraclostrobin + boscalid, cyprodinil + fludioxonil, azoxystrobin, pyraclostrobin, and captan + fenhexamid, as well as captan alone. Studies conducted in North Carolina indicated that a fungicide spray program consisting of only four applications—one application of a mixture of captan and Topsin M (thiophanate-methyl, Cerexagri-Nisso, King of Prussia, PA), two applications of Pristine, and one application of CaptEvate (fenhexamid and captan, Arysta, Cary, NC)—provided a similar level of disease control as a season-long spray program with eight applications (Rahman et al., 2009). Each application in the shorter program included two fungicides, as both Pristine and CaptEvate contain two active ingredients.', 0.15053193271160126]]
Context 5: [['Bartlett, D. W., Clough, J. M., Godwin, J. R., Hall, A. A., Hamer, M., and Parr-Dobrzanski, B. 2002. The strobilurin fungicides. Pest Management Science 58: 649-662.', 0.14987251162528992]]

Las plantas de frutilla tratadas con el producto Tebuconazole + Trifloxystrobin presentan un mayor contenido de clorofila en las hojas. Context 9: [['Nursery surveys confirmed the intensive use of QoI fungicides. Single-site fungicides, such as QoIs, have frequently been used in nurseries to control anthracnose and other diseases, ensuring the delivery of symptom-free stock material. Along with commercial products containing only azoxystrobin or pyraclostrobin, premixes with QoI fungicides were also utilized. This has led to an increased selection rate for QoI-resistant populations as early as the nursery phase. Since transplants produced in large nurseries are sold to smaller ones, plants may be exposed to multiple QoI applications throughout each propagation phase. Consequently, during the fruit production phase, growers face challenges in controlling anthracnose outbreaks with limited effective chemical options.', 0.10566099733114243]]

query: What are the long-term effects of anthracnose on strawberry plants?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Anthracnose is an important disease of strawberry caused by Colletotrichum spp., which affects foliage, runners, crowns, and fruits (Howard et al., 1992). Three primary fungal pathogens—C. acutatum sensu lato, C. gloeosporioides sensu lato, and C. fragariae—are known to cause anthracnose disease in strawberries (Freeman and Katan, 1997). The crown rot syndrome is characteristic of infections from C. gloeosporioides sensu lato and C. fragariae, while fruit rot is mainly attributed to C. acutatum sensu lato, leading to significant yield losses (Howard et al., 1992). Currently, numerous species are classified under what is now known as the C. acutatum complex, with six species—C. acutatum sensu stricto, C. fioriniae, C. godetiae, C. nymphaeae, C. salicis, and C. simmondsii—identified as associated with strawberry anthracnose worldwide (Damm et al., 2012). Among these, C. nymphaeae is the most prevalent pathogen causing strawberry anthracnose globally, including in Iran (Baroncelli et al., 2015; Karimi et al., 2017; Wang et al., 2019). Currently, no effective chemical control methods exist for managing strawberry anthracnose; available options are limited to preventive treatments applied before fruit production (Denoyes-Rothan et al., 1999). Additionally, concerns about the toxic effects of chemical fungicides on the environment and the development of resistance in fungal strains highlight the need for alternative control strategies. Consequently, utilizing resistant cultivars appears to be the most efficient and practical approach for suppressing anthracnose development. In light of recent anthracnose outbreaks in strawberry fields in the Kurdistan province of Iran (Karimi et al., 2017), and the necessity for appropriate strategies to address this issue, the aim of this study was to evaluate the resistance of several commercial strawberry cultivars to the anthracnose fruit rot caused by C. nymphaeae under in vivo and greenhouse conditions.', 0.9613747596740723]]
Context 1: [["Anthracnose fungi can attack various parts of the strawberry plant, including crowns, petioles, leaves, fruit trusses, flowers, buds, and fruit. The fungi's ability to attack multiple plant parts, coupled with the involvement of several pathogen species, contributes to the complex nature of strawberry anthracnose. Brooks reported in 1931 that C. fragariae caused spotting and girdling of runners, and later indicated that it also caused spotting of petioles and crown rot in a summer nursery, leading to wilting and death of the plants. Researchers in Louisiana observed all these symptoms and noted that crown rot also occurred in the fruit production field.", 0.9549893140792847]]
Context 2: [['From May to September 1995, a severe outbreak of strawberry anthracnose was observed in several strawberry-growing nurseries in Israel. Following transplantation to production fields during September and October, entire beds of strawberry plants collapsed. Typical anthracnose symptoms observed from November 1995 to June 1996 included crown rot, flower blight, and green and ripe fruit rot. This marked the first record of strawberry anthracnose in Israel. Furthermore, in at least four production fields in the same region, hundreds of plants developed symptoms of stunting and chlorosis, which are atypical of strawberry anthracnose. When these plants were uprooted, most of their roots were dark brown and decayed. Colletotrichum was readily isolated from these samples.', 0.8388140201568604]]
Context 3: [['So far, anthracnose epidemics have affected strawberry nurseries and production fields worldwide. Reports on Colletotrichum spp. associated with strawberries, curated from literature in PubMed and Clarivate combined with fungal database searches (Farr and Rossman, 2022), were compiled to understand the global diversity and occurrence of the causal agents of strawberry anthracnose. From our findings, since 1931 until July 9, 2022, there have been over 220 citations and 310 records related to the identification of causal agents of strawberry anthracnose at the genus level of Colletotrichum in 36 countries across six continents, with 282 records providing pathogen identification at the species or species complex level.', 0.8216012716293335]]
Context 4: [['Nam MH, Yoo JH, Yun TS, Kim HH, Kim HG. Anthracnose of strawberry: Etiological and ecological characteristics and management. Res Plant Dis 2023;29:205-19.', 0.7711870074272156]]
Context 5: [['In November 2021, anthracnose symptoms were observed on strawberries (cv. Kingsberry) in Nonsan, Chungnam Province. Early symptoms of anthracnose fruit rot (AFR) include blackening of specific tissues of the strawberry. These symptoms progress with the enlargement of lesions, which hinder proper fruit development and lead to the formation of orange-colored spores within the lesions. Similar symptoms were noted on the petioles, with sunken and blackened tissues similar to those on the fruit, accompanied by the formation of an orange conidial mass.', 0.7671339511871338]]
Context 6: [['Horn, N. L., and R. G. Carver. 1962. Anthracnose and powdery mildew on strawberry plants in Louisiana. Plant Disease Reporter 45:591-592.', 0.7410135865211487]]
Context 7: [['The term "anthracnose" was first used to describe a new disease of strawberries caused by Colletotrichum fragariae Brooks. "Strawberry anthracnose" continues to be used as a general term to identify all diseases of strawberries caused by species of Colletotrichum. Strawberry anthracnose diseases have been reported to be caused by C. acutatum J.H. Simmonds, C. gloeosporioides (Penz.) Penz. & Sacc. in Penz. (the teleomorph of Cromereilla cingulata (Stoneman) Spauld. & H. Schrenk), and C. dematium (Pers.) Grove. The latter species only occasionally causes strawberry fruit rots and will not be discussed here.', 0.7393340468406677]]
Context 8: [['De los Santos, B., de Paredes, G., and Munoz, F. R. (2002). Influence of anthracnose epiphytotic development on strawberry fruit production in Huelva (Southwestern Spain). Acta Hortic., 567:623-626.', 0.7305086255073547]]

query: What are the benefits of greenhouse cultivation for small-scale strawberry farmers?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['In Korea, strawberries (Fragaria × ananassa) are favored for winter cultivation when the production of other vegetables and fruits is relatively low. In 2003, strawberries were planted on a total area of 7,503 hectares in Korea, with plastic greenhouse cultivation comprising 7,172 hectares and a total production of 205,427 tonnes for the fresh market (Anonymous, 2004). Forcing, where strawberries are transplanted into greenhouses in mid-September and induced to fruit in December (Oda, 1991), is becoming more common in Korea. June-bearing cultivars such as Maehyang, Akihime, and Nyoho, used for forcing, have proven difficult to grow due to their susceptibility to anthracnose (Nam et al., 1998; Kim & Nam, 1999). Anthracnose is one of the most damaging diseases of strawberries, causing wilting and death of transplants in the nursery field. query: Are there natural methods to disinfect plant materials before planting?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['In this method, 1 to 1.5-meter-long white (with a black interior), UV-resistant polyethylene bags filled with old, disinfected coir dust are utilized. These bags are approximately 6 cm in height and 18 cm in width. They are arranged end to end horizontally in rows on the floor, leaving walking space in between. The bags may be positioned in paired rows depending on the crop being grown. Small openings are made on the upper surface of the bags, into which seedlings or other planting materials are pressed, placed in net pots within the coir dust. Two to three plants can be established per bag. Two small cuts low on each side of the bags allow for drainage. Fertigation is practiced using black slender tubes leading from the main supply line to each plant. The entire floor is covered with white UV-resistant polyethylene before placing the bags. This white polyethylene reflects sunlight onto the plants and reduces the relative humidity between plants, thereby decreasing the incidence of fungal diseases.', 0.34447863698005676]]

query: What methods can farmers use to control anthracnose disease in crops?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Until highly resistant cultivars are available, growers must rely on chemical applications and cultural practices to reduce losses due to anthracnose. The failure of fungicides to control anthracnose epidemics may be due to the development of fungicide resistance in the Colletotrichum spp. population. For example, benomyl effectively reduced the incidence of anthracnose crown rot (Horn et al., 1972; Howard, 1971) and was used intensively by strawberry growers for years to control anthracnose and other diseases. However, the anthracnose pathogens, C. acutatum and C. fragariae, developed resistance to it and other benzimidazole fungicides (LaMondia, 1995; McInnes et al., 1992a; Smith and Black, 1992, 1993), rendering benomyl ineffective for anthracnose control in strawberry fields.', 0.8946601152420044]]
Context 1: [['Until highly resistant cultivars are available, growers must rely on chemical applications and cultural practices to reduce losses due to anthracnose. The failure of fungicides to control anthracnose epidemics may be attributed to the development of fungicide resistance in the Colletotrichum species population. For example, benomyl was shown to effectively reduce the incidence of anthracnose crown rot (Horn et al., 1972; Howard, 1971) and was used intensively by strawberry growers for years to control anthracnose and other diseases. However, the anthracnose pathogens, C. acutatum and C. fragariae, developed resistance to it and other benzimidazole fungicides (LaMondia, 1995; McInnes et al., 1992a; Smith and Black, 1992, 1993), leading to the ineffectiveness of benomyl for anthracnose control in strawberry fields.', 0.8890165090560913]]
Context 2: [['As our knowledge of the anthracnose pathogens and the epidemiology of anthracnose diseases has increased, so has our ability to control these diseases. Changes in cultural practices have resulted in reduced levels of disease. Additionally, the development and registration of more effective fungicides for use on strawberries have significantly reduced losses from both anthracnose crown rot and fruit rot. Anthracnose-resistant cultivars have also diminished economic losses due to these diseases. Nevertheless, growers may still experience severe losses when environmental factors are highly favorable for anthracnose development.', 0.855811357498169]]
Context 3: [['As our understanding of the anthracnose pathogens and the epidemiology of anthracnose diseases has improved, so has our capacity to control these diseases. Changes in cultural practices have led to reduced levels of disease. Additionally, the development and registration of more effective fungicides for use on strawberries have significantly decreased losses due to anthracnose crown rot and fruit rot. The introduction of partially resistant cultivars has also helped mitigate economic losses due to these diseases. Nonetheless, growers may still experience severe losses when environmental conditions are highly conducive to anthracnose development.', 0.8302000761032104]]
Context 4: [['Increased losses due to anthracnose fruit and crown rots may be related to the shift from matted-row culture to the annual plasticulture production system in the United States. Breeding for genetic resistance to anthracnose and the development of resistant cultivars are primary means for reducing economic losses due to this disease. This approach is environmentally sound because it results in reduced fungicide use. As our knowledge of the anthracnose pathogens and the epidemiology of anthracnose diseases has increased, so has our ability to control these diseases. Changes in cultural practices have resulted in reduced levels of disease. Simultaneously, the development of more effective fungicides and their registration for use on strawberries have significantly reduced losses due to both anthracnose crown rot and fruit rot. Anthracnose-resistant cultivars have also decreased economic losses caused by these diseases. Nevertheless, growers may still face severe losses when environmental conditions are highly favorable for anthracnose development.', 0.7824742794036865]]
Context 5: [['Figure 1 illustrates the anthracnose disease cycle in tropical fruit crops, drawn by Latiffah Zakaria. Anthracnose pathogens infect not only fruits but also other plant organs, including leaves, flowers, twigs, and branches. The conidia and spores formed in these infected tissues are released and dispersed during rainy days or periods of high humidity, becoming the primary inoculum for fruit infection at the preharvest stage. The most visible anthracnose symptoms are black or dark brown sunken lesions that contain conidial masses on the surface of infected fruits. Small individual lesions can merge to form larger lesions. These dark lesions on the fruit surface are unattractive to consumers and significantly reduce the market value of the affected fruits. Figures 2A–E display anthracnose lesions on several tropical fruit crops.', 0.33260104060173035]]
Context 6: [['Anthracnose spreads within a field through splashing water. Living mulches, such as wheat, rye, or rye grass, in row middles have been shown to reduce disease spread. Organic mulches like wheat straw or pine needles also reduce splash and result in a lower incidence of anthracnose compared to rows mulched with plastic (Coelho et al., 2008; Madden, 1992; Smith and Spiers, 1986). Additionally, anthracnose is less severe when water is supplied to plants using drip irrigation rather than overhead irrigation (Coelho et al., 2008; Madden, 1992; Smith and Spiers, 1986).', 0.3207513988018036]]
Context 7: [['Strandberg, J. O., Stamps, R. H., and Norman, D. J. 1996. Fern Anthracnose: A Guide for Effective Disease Management. University of Florida, Agricultural Experiment Station Technical Bulletin 900.', 0.21850323677062988]]

query: How does crop rotation benefit fields affected by anthracnose?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Anthracnose spreads within a field by splashing water, and living mulches (such as wheat, rye, or ryegrass) in row middles have been shown to reduce disease spread within a field. Sublethal doses of grass-specific herbicides, such as sethoxydim, may be used to prevent excessive growth of ryegrass (Gupton, 2000). Organic mulches, such as wheat straw or pine needles, also reduce splash and result in a lower incidence of anthracnose compared to rows mulched with plastic (Madden, 1992; Smith and Spiers, 1986). Additionally, anthracnose is less severe when water is supplied to plants using drip irrigation rather than overhead irrigation (Madden, 1992; Smith and Spiers, 1986). Anthracnose crown rot was observed to be less severe in commercial fields when strawberries were grown in soils with low nitrogen fertility (Howard et al., 1992). In greenhouse studies, Smith (1987, 1989) determined that strawberries grown in soils with high levels of nitrogen, especially from ammonium sources, are more susceptible to anthracnose than plants grown in soils with lower nitrogen levels or those with high levels of calcium nitrate.', 0.20029321312904358]]
Context 1: [['Additional Keywords: anthracnose, disease spread, Fragaria × ananassa, models, quantitative epidemiology.', 0.19340622425079346]]
Context 2: [['Crouch, J.A., and Beirn, L.A. (2009). Anthracnose of cereals and grasses. Fungal Diversity 39: 19-44.', 0.17130924761295319]]

Context 8: [['Erregers der Anthraknose an Bergenien. Nachrichtenblatt des Deutschen Pflanzenschutzdienstes 52: 1–4.', 0.13790518045425415]]
Context 9: [['Until highly resistant cultivars are available, growers must rely on chemical applications and cultural practices to reduce losses due to anthracnose. The failure of fungicides to control anthracnose epidemics may be due to the development of fungicide resistance in the Colletotrichum spp. population. For example, benomyl effectively reduced the incidence of anthracnose crown rot (Horn et al., 1972; Howard, 1971) and was used intensively by strawberry growers for years to control anthracnose and other diseases. However, the anthracnose pathogens, C. acutatum and C. fragariae, developed resistance to it and other benzimidazole fungicides (LaMondia, 1995; McInnes et al., 1992a; Smith and Black, 1992, 1993), rendering benomyl ineffective for anthracnose control in strawberry fields.', 0.13434076309204102]]

Context 0: [['Most external reference samples are costly, and their frequent use increases the operating costs of the laboratory. Internal reference samples are usually much less expensive. Therefore, if a relationship between external and internal reference samples can be firmly established, frequent use of internal reference samples, with occasional use of external reference samples, can reduce costs while still providing acceptable quality assurance.', 0.9055218696594238]]
Context 1: [['Internal reference samples are necessary for each type of test material and analysis conducted within the laboratory. The internal sample should not be the same as the homogeneous material routinely used in testing new methods and analytical techniques. A sample obtained from a large, well-mixed, and homogeneous composite bulk sample should be included in each batch analyzed. Variation from the mean, as calculated over previous batches, may indicate an error.', 0.5778152346611023]]

query: What are the consequences of late detection of anthracnose in strawberry fields?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Anthracnose is an important disease of strawberry caused by Colletotrichum spp., which affects foliage, runners, crowns, and fruits (Howard et al., 1992). Three primary fungal pathogens—C. acutatum sensu lato, C. gloeosporioides sensu lato, and C. fragariae—are known to cause anthracnose disease in strawberries (Freeman and Katan, 1997). The crown rot syndrome is characteristic of infections from C. gloeosporioides sensu lato and C. fragariae, while fruit rot is mainly attributed to C. acutatum sensu lato, leading to significant yield losses (Howard et al., 1992). Currently, numerous species are classified under what is now known as the C. acutatum complex, with six species—C. acutatum sensu stricto, C. fioriniae, C. godetiae, C. nymphaeae, C. salicis, and C. simmondsii—identified as associated with strawberry anthracnose worldwide (Damm et al., 2012). Among these, C. nymphaeae is the most prevalent pathogen causing strawberry anthracnose globally, including in Iran (Baroncelli et al., 2015; Karimi et al., 2017; Wang et al., 2019). Currently, no effective chemical control methods exist for managing strawberry anthracnose; available options are limited to preventive treatments applied before fruit production (Denoyes-Rothan et al., 1999). Additionally, concerns about the toxic effects of chemical fungicides on the environment and the development of resistance in fungal strains highlight the need for alternative control strategies. Consequently, utilizing resistant cultivars appears to be the most efficient and practical approach for suppressing anthracnose development. In light of recent anthracnose outbreaks in strawberry fields in the Kurdistan province of Iran (Karimi et al., 2017), and the necessity for appropriate strategies to address this issue, the aim of this study was to evaluate the resistance of several commercial strawberry cultivars to the anthracnose fruit rot caused by C. nymphaeae under in vivo and greenhouse conditions.', 0.929736316204071]]
Context 1: [['From May to September 1995, a severe outbreak of strawberry anthracnose was observed in several strawberry-growing nurseries in Israel. Following transplantation to production fields during September and October, entire beds of strawberry plants collapsed. Typical anthracnose symptoms observed from November 1995 to June 1996 included crown rot, flower blight, and green and ripe fruit rot. This marked the first record of strawberry anthracnose in Israel. Furthermore, in at least four production fields in the same region, hundreds of plants developed symptoms of stunting and chlorosis, which are atypical of strawberry anthracnose. When these plants were uprooted, most of their roots were dark brown and decayed. Colletotrichum was readily isolated from these samples.', 0.8423389792442322]]
Context 2: [["Anthracnose fungi can attack various parts of the strawberry plant, including crowns, petioles, leaves, fruit trusses, flowers, buds, and fruit. The fungi's ability to attack multiple plant parts, coupled with the involvement of several pathogen species, contributes to the complex nature of strawberry anthracnose. Brooks reported in 1931 that C. fragariae caused spotting and girdling of runners, and later indicated that it also caused spotting of petioles and crown rot in a summer nursery, leading to wilting and death of the plants. Researchers in Louisiana observed all these symptoms and noted that crown rot also occurred in the fruit production field.", 0.758719265460968]]
Context 3: [['In November 2021, anthracnose symptoms were observed on strawberries (cv. Kingsberry) in Nonsan, Chungnam Province. Early symptoms of anthracnose fruit rot (AFR) include blackening of specific tissues of the strawberry. These symptoms progress with the enlargement of lesions, which hinder proper fruit development and lead to the formation of orange-colored spores within the lesions. Similar symptoms were noted on the petioles, with sunken and blackened tissues similar to those on the fruit, accompanied by the formation of an orange conidial mass.', 0.7263109683990479]]
Context 4: [['So far, anthracnose epidemics have affected strawberry nurseries and production fields worldwide. Reports on Colletotrichum spp. associated with strawberries, curated from literature in PubMed and Clarivate combined with fungal database searches (Farr and Rossman, 2022), were compiled to understand the global diversity and occurrence of the causal agents of strawberry anthracnose. From our findings, since 1931 until July 9, 2022, there have been over 220 citations and 310 records related to the identification of causal agents of strawberry anthracnose at the genus level of Colletotrichum in 36 countries across six continents, with 282 records providing pathogen identification at the species or species complex level.', 0.6929798722267151]]
Context 5: [['Madden, L.V., Wilson, L.L., Ellis, M.A. 1993. Field spread of anthracnose in strawberry. Plant Disease. 77:861–866.', 0.5150737166404724]]
Context 6: [['Howard CM, Albregts EE. Anthracnose. In: Compendium of Strawberry Diseases. American Phytopathological Society: Paul St, ed. Maas JL, USA; 1984. pp. 85-87.', 0.44439905881881714]]
Context 7: [['Smith, B. J. 1998. Anthracnose leaf spot, irregular spot, anthracnose fruit rot (black spot), and anthracnose crown rot. In: Compendium of Strawberry Diseases. J. L. Mass, ed. American Phytopathological Society, St. Paul, MN. Pages 24-25, 31-33, and 46-48.', 0.38371121883392334]]

Context 1: [['Strawberries (Fragaria×ananassa Duch.) are a widely cultivated hybrid species within the Rosaceae family, renowned for their fruit. query: What symptoms should I look for to diagnose anthracnose?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Inflorescences, leaves, and fruits showing typical anthracnose symptoms were collected from orchards located in Chachoengsao, Phichit, and Ratchaburi. Visual anthracnose symptoms included inflorescence blight, small brown to black spots, and irregularly shaped lesions with necrotic brown to black areas on leaves. Symptoms on ripe fruit were characterized by small black circular spots and irregular, necrotic, sunken brown to black lesions. In severely infected fruit, extensive rot was observed, and under high humidity, bright orange to pale-colored spore masses could be seen. Infected premature fruits often dropped from the trees. A total of 37 fungal isolates resembling Colletotrichum spp. were obtained.', 0.477812796831131]]
Context 1: [['From 2010 to 2016, we conducted surveys of anthracnose in strawberries in Miaoli County. More than 50% of diseased plants exhibited symptoms characteristic of anthracnose crown rot (ACR), as described by McInnes et al. (1992). ACR resulted in plant losses of up to 30-40% during the seedling stage and around 20% after transplanting. Initial symptoms in crown tissue included a marbled red and white appearance, which progressed to brown rot and eventual rapid wilting of the plant. Anthracnose symptoms also appeared on other parts of the plant, including leaves, petioles, runners, fruits, and roots. These symptoms manifested as circular black spots on leaves, withering and girdling on runners.', 0.3776603043079376]]
Context 2: [['Figure 1 illustrates the anthracnose disease cycle in tropical fruit crops, drawn by Latiffah Zakaria. Anthracnose pathogens infect not only fruits but also other plant organs, including leaves, flowers, twigs, and branches. The conidia and spores formed in these infected tissues are released and dispersed during rainy days or periods of high humidity, becoming the primary inoculum for fruit infection at the preharvest stage. The most visible anthracnose symptoms are black or dark brown sunken lesions that contain conidial masses on the surface of infected fruits. Small individual lesions can merge to form larger lesions. These dark lesions on the fruit surface are unattractive to consumers and significantly reduce the market value of the affected fruits. Figures 2A–E display anthracnose lesions on several tropical fruit crops.', 0.33790507912635803]]
Context 3: [['Smith, B.J. (1998c). Anthracnose leaf spot and irregular leaf spot, pp. 24–25. In J.L. Maas (Ed.), Compendium of strawberry diseases (2nd ed.). American Phytopathological Society, St. Paul, MN.', 0.2141256332397461]]

query: How can anthracnose be managed?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Accurate identification and scientific naming of anthracnose pathogens are crucial because precise taxonomic information allows us to classify a given species as a pathogen, saprophyte, or endophyte. The species involved in anthracnose affecting tropical fruits may exhibit different characteristics, emphasizing the importance of proper identification of the causative pathogen for effective disease management.', 0.35457175970077515]]
Context 1: [['Strandberg, J. O., Stamps, R. H., and Norman, D. J. 1996. Fern Anthracnose: A Guide for Effective Disease Management. University of Florida, Agricultural Experiment Station Technical Bulletin 900.', 0.30005088448524475]]
Context 2: [['As our knowledge of the anthracnose pathogens and the epidemiology of anthracnose diseases has increased, so has our ability to control these diseases. Changes in cultural practices have resulted in reduced levels of disease. Additionally, the development and registration of more effective fungicides for use on strawberries have significantly reduced losses from both anthracnose crown rot and fruit rot. Anthracnose-resistant cultivars have also diminished economic losses due to these diseases. Nevertheless, growers may still experience severe losses when environmental factors are highly favorable for anthracnose development.', 0.29532915353775024]]
Context 3: [['As our understanding of the anthracnose pathogens and the epidemiology of anthracnose diseases has improved, so has our capacity to control these diseases. Changes in cultural practices have led to reduced levels of disease. Additionally, the development and registration of more effective fungicides for use on strawberries have significantly decreased losses due to anthracnose crown rot and fruit rot. The introduction of partially resistant cultivars has also helped mitigate economic losses due to these diseases. Nonetheless, growers may still experience severe losses when environmental conditions are highly conducive to anthracnose development.', 0.2945743799209595]]
Context 4: [['Increased losses due to anthracnose fruit and crown rots may be related to the shift from matted-row culture to the annual plasticulture production system in the United States. Breeding for genetic resistance to anthracnose and the development of resistant cultivars are primary means for reducing economic losses due to this disease. This approach is environmentally sound because it results in reduced fungicide use. As our knowledge of the anthracnose pathogens and the epidemiology of anthracnose diseases has increased, so has our ability to control these diseases. Changes in cultural practices have resulted in reduced levels of disease. Simultaneously, the development of more effective fungicides and their registration for use on strawberries have significantly reduced losses due to both anthracnose crown rot and fruit rot. Anthracnose-resistant cultivars have also decreased economic losses caused by these diseases. Nevertheless, growers may still face severe losses when environmental conditions are highly favorable for anthracnose development.', 0.24058598279953003]]
Context 5: [['Until highly resistant cultivars are available, growers must rely on chemical applications and cultural practices to reduce losses due to anthracnose. The failure of fungicides to control anthracnose epidemics may be due to the development of fungicide resistance in the Colletotrichum spp. population. For example, benomyl effectively reduced the incidence of anthracnose crown rot (Horn et al., 1972; Howard, 1971) and was used intensively by strawberry growers for years to control anthracnose and other diseases. However, the anthracnose pathogens, C. acutatum and C. fragariae, developed resistance to it and other benzimidazole fungicides (LaMondia, 1995; McInnes et al., 1992a; Smith and Black, 1992, 1993), rendering benomyl ineffective for anthracnose control in strawberry fields.', 0.23240557312965393]]
Context 6: [['Until highly resistant cultivars are available, growers must rely on chemical applications and cultural practices to reduce losses due to anthracnose. The failure of fungicides to control anthracnose epidemics may be attributed to the development of fungicide resistance in the Colletotrichum species population. For example, benomyl was shown to effectively reduce the incidence of anthracnose crown rot (Horn et al., 1972; Howard, 1971) and was used intensively by strawberry growers for years to control anthracnose and other diseases. However, the anthracnose pathogens, C. acutatum and C. fragariae, developed resistance to it and other benzimidazole fungicides (LaMondia, 1995; McInnes et al., 1992a; Smith and Black, 1992, 1993), leading to the ineffectiveness of benomyl for anthracnose control in strawberry fields.', 0.22690294682979584]]
Context 7: [['Smith, B.J. (1998c). Anthracnose leaf spot and irregular leaf spot, pp. 24–25. In J.L. Maas (Ed.), Compendium of strawberry diseases (2nd ed.). American Phytopathological Society, St. Paul, MN.', 0.18264880776405334]]
Context 8: [['Anthracnose spreads within a field through splashing water. Living mulches, such as wheat, rye, or rye grass, in row middles have been shown to reduce disease spread. Organic mulches like wheat straw or pine needles also reduce splash and result in a lower incidence of anthracnose compared to rows mulched with plastic (Coelho et al., 2008; Madden, 1992; Smith and Spiers, 1986). Additionally, anthracnose is less severe when water is supplied to plants using drip irrigation rather than overhead irrigation (Coelho et al., 2008; Madden, 1992; Smith and Spiers, 1986).', 0.17982345819473267]]
Context 9: [['Urdaneta, L., Sanabria, M., Rodríguez, D., & Pérez de Camacaro, M. (2013). Antracnosis causada por Colletotrichum spp. Investigación Agraria, 20(1), 38-50.', 0.16672711074352264]]
