query: What methods are used to establish host ranges for Colletotrichum species?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['In a drastic move, von Arx (1957) reduced the number of recognized Colletotrichum species from several hundred to 11 based on morphological characteristics, with many taxa treated as synonyms of C. gloeosporioides and C. dematium. Several additional species have since been accepted based on morphological criteria (Sutton, 1980; 1992). The difficulties in recognizing Colletotrichum species can be attributed to: 1) the limited and variable morphological characters; 2) an extensive host range and variability in pathogenicity (Bailey and Jeger, 1992; Freeman et al., 2000; Latunde-Dada, 2001; Du et al., 2005; Thaung, 2008); 3) type specimens that are often missing or in poor condition, making them unsuitable for molecular studies; and 4) numerous rDNA ITS sequences of Colletotrichum strains in NCBI that are often misidentified (Crouch et al., 2009d; Damm et al., 2009).', 0.9693973064422607]]
Context 1: [['Despite significant developments over the last ten years, the taxonomy of Colletotrichum is in a state of flux. Many uncertainties exist in the systematics of fungal pathogens from this genus; depending on the taxonomic "guides," the number of species can range from 29 to over 700 (von Arx, 1957; Sutton, 1992). One of the most confusing species is C. gloeosporioides. For example, 594 species of Colletotrichum were reclassified by von Arx as synonyms of C. gloeosporioides. Identification has primarily relied on morphological characteristics of conidia, vegetative and sexual structures, as well as host specificity and cultural characteristics (von Arx, 1957). Unfortunately, conidial morphology and colony characteristics vary even within isolates. Consequently, classical methods have been supplemented with biochemical and molecular technologies to differentiate Colletotrichum species (J. W. Kronstad, ed., Fungal Pathology, 127-148. © 2000 Kluwer Academic Publishers). For a more complete discussion of this topic, see Sherriff et al. (1994).', 0.9692697525024414]]
Context 2: [['The genus Colletotrichum is considered one of the top ten important genera of fungal pathogens globally (Dean et al., 2012). Colletotrichum is an ancient fungus that has co-evolved with flowering plants. Plant microfossils of Protocolletotrichum preserved on angiosperm leaf cuticles suggest that the diverse pathogenic strategies of Colletotrichum spp. have been established since the Late Cretaceous period (Kar et al., 2004). Different complexes within the genus may have diverged between 4.8 and 32.2 million years ago (MYA) (Bhunjun et al., 2021). The emergence of agricultural cultivation and the intensive disturbance of natural environments have further driven the diversification of Colletotrichum species. These fungi have adapted to thousands of hosts and can be found as endophytes, pathogens, and saprobes (Freeman et al., 1998; Dean et al., 2012; Hirayama et al., 2018; da Silva et al., 2020; Jayawardena et al., 2020). Currently, a total of 257 Colletotrichum species grouped into 15 complexes and 13 additional singletons have been accepted in this genus.', 0.9176934957504272]]
Context 3: [['Citation: Cai, L., Hyde, K.D., Taylor, P.W.J., Weir, B.S., Waller, J., Abang, M.M., Zhang, J.Z., Yang, Y.L., Phoulivong, S., Liu, Z.Y., Prihastuti, H., Shivas, R.G., McKenzie, E.H.C., Johnston, P.R. (2009). A polyphasic approach for studying Colletotrichum. Fungal Diversity, 39: 183-204.', 0.6580396890640259]]
Context 4: [['The name Colletotrichum was first introduced by Tode (1790) under the genus Vermicularia. The genus Colletotrichum itself was established by Corda (1831) and is now recognized as comprising “coelomycetes” with a Glomerella teleomorph stage (Sutton, 1992; Shenoy et al., 2007a; Hyde et al., 2009). This genus includes species with endophytic, epiphytic, saprobic, and phytopathogenic lifestyles (Kumar and Hyde, 2004; Photita et al., 2001a,b).', 0.3769620954990387]]

query: How can studying pathogen populations help in forecasting and managing crop disease epidemics?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['The role of host density in disease dynamics is poorly understood, yet it may be crucial in regulating spatial and temporal aspects of epidemics in both natural and agricultural ecosystems. In unmanaged or minimally managed communities, density-dependent plant mortality mediated by pathogen activity has been suggested in some studies. However, confounding variables in these systems have hindered a clear demonstration of a causal relationship between density and disease.', 0.2752273380756378]]
Context 1: [['Global food security relies on numerous physical, agronomic, and socioeconomic factors. However, it is clear that climate change and its effects on plant health will increasingly threaten human populations, especially those in poorer regions. We have demonstrated that reported observations of hundreds of pests and pathogens are consistent with the hypothesis of climate change drivers, as opposed to the hypothesis of enhanced detection capabilities in developed countries. While countries at higher latitudes are better equipped to monitor and manage emerging pests and diseases, they also tend to have the highest productivity per unit of land area, raising concerns about food security. If climate change facilitates the spread of crop-destroying organisms, there will be a renewed need to monitor pest and disease occurrences and control them effectively.', 0.2734527289867401]]

query: In what ways can MEGA X aid researchers in constructing timetrees for comparative genomics?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [["Over the past decade, genome sequencing has become an efficient and potent means to investigate a broad array of biological systems, from large-scale studies of biological diversity to tracking the evolution and origin of pathogenic microbes. The numerous steps required to glean interpretable and actionable results from raw sequence data invariably require comparative analysis of molecular sequences to discover functional and adaptive genome differences. The Molecular Evolutionary Genetics Analysis (MEGA) software provides tools to conduct such analyses. MEGA includes a large repertoire of programs for assembling sequence alignments, inferring evolutionary trees, estimating genetic distances and diversities, inferring ancestral sequences, computing timetrees, and testing selection. Over the last 25 years, MEGA's use in evolutionary analysis has been cited in over one hundred thousand studies in diverse biological fields.", 0.8782244920730591]]
Context 1: [['Key Words: multiple sequence alignment, metagenome, protein structure, progressive alignment, parallel processing.', 0.2830631732940674]]
Context 2: [['The Molecular Evolutionary Genetics Analysis (MEGA) software implements various analytical methods and tools for phylogenomics and phylomedicine. We report a transformation of MEGA to enable cross-platform use on Microsoft Windows and Linux operating systems. MEGA X does not require virtualization or emulation software and provides a uniform user experience across platforms. Additionally, MEGA X has been upgraded to utilize multiple computing cores for many molecular evolutionary analyses. MEGA X is available in two interfaces (graphical and command line) and can be downloaded free of charge from www.megasoftware.net.', 0.22337229549884796]]
Context 3: [['We have also enhanced MEGA’s computational core by increasing the number of methods that can utilize multiple processors and cores on the same machine. This improvement will significantly reduce the runtime for computationally demanding inferences. Users can specify the maximum number of cores to deploy in the Analysis Preferences dialog box (FIG. 2G). By default, MEGA X uses all available cores, minus one, ensuring that no more than 80% of RAM is consumed. Computational methods benefiting from calculation parallelization include those for selecting the best model for nucleotide or amino acid substitutions and bootstrap tests of molecular phylogenies employed with distance-based and parsimony-based methods. Users can already utilize multiple cores during the heuristic search for the Maximum Likelihood (ML) tree in MEGA.', 0.20480987429618835]]
Context 4: [['The redesigned GUI elements in MEGAX include several explorer windows: (A) the Sequence Data Explorer, (B) the Timetree Wizard, and (C) the Tree Explorer, all of which use the native widget set of the target operating system. Options dialogs (D) and the Caption Expert (E) were developed using HTML and JavaScript, displayed through MEGA\'s integrated web browser built on the Chromium Embedded Framework. The redesigned Analysis Preferences dialog box (F) allows users to select options for data analysis, including (G) the number of threads to employ and (H) a "Save Settings" button for generating a .mao file for use with MEGA-CC for high-throughput analysis.', 0.193115696310997]]
Context 5: [['Altschul, S. F., Gish, W., Miller, W., Myers, E. W., and Lipman, D. J. (1990). Basic local alignment search tool. J. Mol. Biol., 215, 403-410.', 0.15379691123962402]]
Context 6: [['In conclusion, the cross-platform MEGAX will benefit many existing users and encourage others to consider using MEGAX in their research and teaching endeavors. The consistency of user experience across platforms should be particularly useful in facilitating collaborative analyses within and among research groups, as well as in teaching diverse groups of students. In the near future, we aim to complete the development of a macOS version to make MEGAX available on all major operating systems.', 0.136552095413208]]
Context 7: [['Altschul, S. F., Gish, W., Miller, W., Myers, E. W., & Lipman, D. J. Basic local alignment search tool. Journal of Molecular Biology, 215, 403-410 (1990).', 0.13255272805690765]]

After producing several conidia, the conidiogenous cells of many species extend without forming a septum and create a new conidiogenous locus at the tip. query: What future research is suggested for better management of strawberry anthracnose?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Anthracnose is an important disease of strawberry caused by Colletotrichum spp., which affects foliage, runners, crowns, and fruits (Howard et al., 1992). Three primary fungal pathogens—C. acutatum sensu lato, C. gloeosporioides sensu lato, and C. fragariae—are known to cause anthracnose disease in strawberries (Freeman and Katan, 1997). The crown rot syndrome is characteristic of infections from C. gloeosporioides sensu lato and C. fragariae, while fruit rot is mainly attributed to C. acutatum sensu lato, leading to significant yield losses (Howard et al., 1992). Currently, numerous species are classified under what is now known as the C. acutatum complex, with six species—C. acutatum sensu stricto, C. fioriniae, C. godetiae, C. nymphaeae, C. salicis, and C. simmondsii—identified as associated with strawberry anthracnose worldwide (Damm et al., 2012). Among these, C. nymphaeae is the most prevalent pathogen causing strawberry anthracnose globally, including in Iran (Baroncelli et al., 2015; Karimi et al., 2017; Wang et al., 2019). Currently, no effective chemical control methods exist for managing strawberry anthracnose; available options are limited to preventive treatments applied before fruit production (Denoyes-Rothan et al., 1999). Additionally, concerns about the toxic effects of chemical fungicides on the environment and the development of resistance in fungal strains highlight the need for alternative control strategies. Consequently, utilizing resistant cultivars appears to be the most efficient and practical approach for suppressing anthracnose development. In light of recent anthracnose outbreaks in strawberry fields in the Kurdistan province of Iran (Karimi et al., 2017), and the necessity for appropriate strategies to address this issue, the aim of this study was to evaluate the resistance of several commercial strawberry cultivars to the anthracnose fruit rot caused by C. nymphaeae under in vivo and greenhouse conditions.', 0.903980016708374]]
Context 1: [['Hu, D. Y., Qian, C., and Liu, X. F. (2014). Research progress of strawberry anthracnose. Chin. Vegetables, 1:9-14.', 0.4320814907550812]]
Context 2: [['Shao, X. H. (1992). New disease of strawberry: Strawberry anthracnose. Acta Agriculturae Shanghai.', 0.34988585114479065]]
Context 3: [['Overall, the study highlights the importance of cultural practices and genetic resistance in managing strawberry anthracnose effectively.', 0.32379961013793945]]

Context 5: [['The term "anthracnose" was first used to describe a new disease of strawberries caused by Colletotrichum fragariae Brooks. "Strawberry anthracnose" continues to be used as a general term to identify all diseases of strawberries caused by species of Colletotrichum. query: What specific processes do Colletotrichum spp. use to penetrate host tissues through appressoria?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['The histology of infection by Colletotrichum spp. has been studied thoroughly on several hosts. Conidia germinate either by producing germ tubes and terminal appressoria or by forming sessile appressoria. Appressoria become melanized and develop pores from which host penetration occurs. Two types of infections can develop: (i) intracellular hemibiotrophic, in which infection vesicles or swollen hyphae form within epidermal cells (e.g., on Pinus needles), and (ii) subcuticular, intramural necrotrophic, where cuticular penetration is followed by hyphal proliferation within the cuticle and epidermal cell walls.', 0.9923229217529297]]
Context 1: [['The genus Colletotrichum represents a large number of economically important Ascomycete fungi that collectively cause anthracnose disease or leaf blights on significant agricultural crops and ornamental plants worldwide. Colletotrichum spp. often serve as models in studies ranging from pathogenic development and differentiation to plant-microbe interactions. During establishment and colonization of host plants, members of this genus uniquely acquire nutrients via both biotrophy and necrotrophy. Thus, in a single interaction, these fungal pathogens exhibit two modes of nutrient acquisition: initially, nutrients are acquired from living cells, after which a necrotrophic phase is initiated, allowing the same fungus to obtain nutrients from dead cells killed by the fungus. A given species of this genus can exhibit both strategies separately or concurrently. Additionally, these fungi develop a series of specialized infection-related structures, including germ tubes, appressoria, primary intracellular hyphae, and secondary necrotrophic hyphae. Therefore, Colletotrichum species are experimentally attractive organisms for studying the molecular, biochemical, and cellular basis of fungal pathogenicity, development, and signal transduction (see Bailey and Jeger, 1992; Prusky et al., 1999).', 0.9814003705978394]]
Context 2: [['This review focuses on current research into the infection process of Colletotrichum species, with an overall emphasis on how signal transduction influences pre-penetration morphogenesis, including conidiation, conidial attachment, conidial germination, germ tube formation, and appressorial differentiation. Post-penetration biotrophic and necrotrophic growth patterns will also be described. Additionally, intriguing studies involving host specificity and chromosome transfer will be summarized.', 0.963386058807373]]
Context 3: [['Appressoria serve as infection and survival structures in Colletotrichum spp. The development of appressoria in this group of fungi is influenced by several factors, including nutrient stress, host surface characteristics, phylloplane microorganisms, temperature, and light intensity. In our study, appressorial production was favored by cooler temperatures and was severely impaired at 35°C. Similar results have been obtained on agar.', 0.9299908876419067]]
Context 4: [['O’Connell, R. J., Perfect, S., Hughes, B., Carzaniga, R., Bailey, J., and Green, J. (2000). Dissecting the cell biology of Colletotrichum infection processes. In D. Prusky, S. Freeman, & M. Dickman (Eds.), Colletotrichum: Host Specificity, Pathology, and Host-Pathogen Interaction (pp. 57-77). The American Phytopathological Society, St. Paul, MN.', 0.6977754831314087]]
Context 5: [['O’Connell, R., Perfect, S., Hughes, B., Carzaniga, R., Bailey, J., and Green, J. 2000. Dissecting the cell biology of Colletotrichum infection processes. In: Host Specificity, Pathology, and Host-Parasite Interactions of Colletotrichum. D. Prusky, S. Freeman, and M. D. Dickman, eds. American Phytopathological Society, St. Paul, MN. Pages 57-77.', 0.6929647326469421]]
Context 6: [['Observations and measurements of conidial size and shape have usually been made using conidial masses mounted in water, cotton blue, or lactic acid (Cannon et al., 2008). It should be noted that many species of Colletotrichum produce secondary conidia in culture directly from germinated primary conidia; these may vary morphologically when compared to those produced in conidiomata (Cannon et al., 2000). Conidial and mycelial appressoria (also referred to as hyphopodia) are often described in Colletotrichum species. Sutton (1980) characterized the mycelial appressoria formed in potato-carrot agar (PCA) using a slide culture technique, while others have used potato dextrose agar (PDA) with incubation in the dark (Johnston and Jones, 1997; Malloch, 1981) or have observed mycelial appressoria formed on the undersurface of SNA cultures (Damm et al., 2009). Conidial appressoria have been recorded when conidia are germinated in drops of deionized water on plastic cover slips in a moist chamber (Johnson et al., 1997; Chaky et al., 2001). Conidial appressoria are taxonomically uninformative and of little use for species diagnosis (Sutton, 1980, 1992). However, Du et al. (2005) noted that the shape of appressoria can differentiate C. acutatum (with rather smooth appressoria) from C. gloeosporioides (with more lobed appressoria). Crouch et al. (2009b) found that appressoria shape and size are useful for delimiting grass-associated Colletotrichum species but should be used in combination with host range. Yang et al. (2009) found that conidial appressoria can distinguish two species of Colletotrichum from Amaryllidaceae. The conidial appressoria of C. hippeastri are larger than those of C. hymenocallidis and are irregular, crenate, or lobed, occasionally becoming complex. In contrast, C. hymenocallidis appressoria are ovate or sometimes clavate.', 0.6532925367355347]]
Context 7: [['O’Connell, R. J., Perfect, S., Hughes, B., Carzaniga, R., Bailey, J., and Green, J. 2000. Dissecting the cell biology of Colletotrichum infection processes. Pages 57-77 in: Colletotrichum: Host Specificity, Pathology, and Host–Pathogen Interaction. D. Prusky, S. Freeman, and M. Dickman, eds. The American Phytopathological Society, St. Paul, MN.', 0.6313514113426208]]
Context 8: [['Available morphological characters of Colletotrichum species include: 1) characters on natural substrates, such as size and shape of conidiomata (acervuli), conidia, conidiophores, and setae; 2) size and shape of conidia, conidiophores, and setae in culture; and 3) size and shape of appressoria. Acervuli, setae, and conidial characters (shape and dimensions) on natural substrates can vary due to environmental factors, and conidia may be absent from infected host tissues. Some Colletotrichum species, such as C. musae and C. gossypii, consistently fail to produce setae in conidiomata (Sutton and Waterston, 1970), and their presence on natural hosts is often inconsistent for species diagnosis (von Arx, 1957; Sutton, 1966). Morphological characters may vary with environmental factors, and incubation conditions, such as media and temperature, should be standardized (Cannon et al., 2000) for species comparison and identification. Unfortunately, there is no recommended standard for...', 0.5340976119041443]]
Context 9: [['Stress conditions or postharvest storage can lead to the development of appressoria from germinating spores. Colletotrichum is one of the most important genera of plant pathogenic fungi, responsible for numerous diseases across a variety of crops worldwide (Sutton 1992, Cannon et al. 2000, 2012, Cai et al. 2009, Udayanga et al. 2013). Recently, Colletotrichum species have been included in the list of the ten most significant plant pathogenic fungi globally, based on their scientific and economic importance (Dean et al. 2012).', 0.4893050193786621]]

query: What challenges are associated with the management of anthracnose in strawberry fields?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Anthracnose is an important disease of strawberry caused by Colletotrichum spp., which affects foliage, runners, crowns, and fruits (Howard et al., 1992). Three primary fungal pathogens—C. acutatum sensu lato, C. gloeosporioides sensu lato, and C. fragariae—are known to cause anthracnose disease in strawberries (Freeman and Katan, 1997). The crown rot syndrome is characteristic of infections from C. gloeosporioides sensu lato and C. fragariae, while fruit rot is mainly attributed to C. acutatum sensu lato, leading to significant yield losses (Howard et al., 1992). Currently, numerous species are classified under what is now known as the C. acutatum complex, with six species—C. acutatum sensu stricto, C. fioriniae, C. godetiae, C. nymphaeae, C. salicis, and C. simmondsii—identified as associated with strawberry anthracnose worldwide (Damm et al., 2012). Among these, C. nymphaeae is the most prevalent pathogen causing strawberry anthracnose globally, including in Iran (Baroncelli et al., 2015; Karimi et al., 2017; Wang et al., 2019). Currently, no effective chemical control methods exist for managing strawberry anthracnose; available options are limited to preventive treatments applied before fruit production (Denoyes-Rothan et al., 1999). Additionally, concerns about the toxic effects of chemical fungicides on the environment and the development of resistance in fungal strains highlight the need for alternative control strategies. Consequently, utilizing resistant cultivars appears to be the most efficient and practical approach for suppressing anthracnose development. In light of recent anthracnose outbreaks in strawberry fields in the Kurdistan province of Iran (Karimi et al., 2017), and the necessity for appropriate strategies to address this issue, the aim of this study was to evaluate the resistance of several commercial strawberry cultivars to the anthracnose fruit rot caused by C. nymphaeae under in vivo and greenhouse conditions.', 0.989942193031311]]
Context 1: [['So far, anthracnose epidemics have affected strawberry nurseries and production fields worldwide. Reports on Colletotrichum spp. associated with strawberries, curated from literature in PubMed and Clarivate combined with fungal database searches (Farr and Rossman, 2022), were compiled to understand the global diversity and occurrence of the causal agents of strawberry anthracnose. From our findings, since 1931 until July 9, 2022, there have been over 220 citations and 310 records related to the identification of causal agents of strawberry anthracnose at the genus level of Colletotrichum in 36 countries across six continents, with 282 records providing pathogen identification at the species or species complex level.', 0.8040435910224915]]
Context 2: [["Anthracnose fungi can attack various parts of the strawberry plant, including crowns, petioles, leaves, fruit trusses, flowers, buds, and fruit. The fungi's ability to attack multiple plant parts, coupled with the involvement of several pathogen species, contributes to the complex nature of strawberry anthracnose. Brooks reported in 1931 that C. fragariae caused spotting and girdling of runners, and later indicated that it also caused spotting of petioles and crown rot in a summer nursery, leading to wilting and death of the plants. Researchers in Louisiana observed all these symptoms and noted that crown rot also occurred in the fruit production field.", 0.6364132165908813]]
Context 3: [['From May to September 1995, a severe outbreak of strawberry anthracnose was observed in several strawberry-growing nurseries in Israel. Following transplantation to production fields during September and October, entire beds of strawberry plants collapsed. Typical anthracnose symptoms observed from November 1995 to June 1996 included crown rot, flower blight, and green and ripe fruit rot. This marked the first record of strawberry anthracnose in Israel. Furthermore, in at least four production fields in the same region, hundreds of plants developed symptoms of stunting and chlorosis, which are atypical of strawberry anthracnose. When these plants were uprooted, most of their roots were dark brown and decayed. Colletotrichum was readily isolated from these samples.', 0.5519933104515076]]
Context 4: [['Madden, L.V., Wilson, L.L., Ellis, M.A. 1993. Field spread of anthracnose in strawberry. Plant Disease. 77:861–866.', 0.463997483253479]]
Context 5: [['Howard CM, Albregts EE. Anthracnose. In: Compendium of Strawberry Diseases. American Phytopathological Society: Paul St, ed. Maas JL, USA; 1984. pp. 85-87.', 0.4045933485031128]]
Context 6: [['In the early 1980s, anthracnose became a significant disease affecting strawberries in the southeastern United States. In response, the USDA-ARS established a breeding program to develop anthracnose-resistant cultivars suited to the strawberry-growing regions of this area. This initiative was conducted at the Small Fruit Research Station in Poplarville, MS, and the Fruit Laboratory in Beltsville, MD, in collaboration with state experiment stations in Florida, Louisiana, and North Carolina (Galletta et al., 1997; Smith and Spiers, 1982).', 0.38669830560684204]]
Context 7: [['Smith, B. J. 1998. Anthracnose leaf spot, irregular spot, anthracnose fruit rot (black spot), and anthracnose crown rot. In: Compendium of Strawberry Diseases. J. L. Mass, ed. American Phytopathological Society, St. Paul, MN. Pages 24-25, 31-33, and 46-48.', 0.36640676856040955]]
Context 8: [['In November 2021, anthracnose symptoms were observed on strawberries (cv. Kingsberry) in Nonsan, Chungnam Province. Early symptoms of anthracnose fruit rot (AFR) include blackening of specific tissues of the strawberry. These symptoms progress with the enlargement of lesions, which hinder proper fruit development and lead to the formation of orange-colored spores within the lesions. Similar symptoms were noted on the petioles, with sunken and blackened tissues similar to those on the fruit, accompanied by the formation of an orange conidial mass.', 0.3609205484390259]]
Context 9: [['Shao, X. H. (1992). New disease of strawberry: Strawberry anthracnose. Acta Agriculturae Shanghai.', 0.3416178226470947]]

Context 9: [['Figure 1 illustrates the anthracnose disease cycle in tropical fruit crops, drawn by Latiffah Zakaria. Anthracnose pathogens infect not only fruits but also other plant organs, including leaves, flowers, twigs, and branches. The conidia and spores formed in these infected tissues are released and dispersed during rainy days or periods of high humidity, becoming the primary inoculum for fruit infection at the preharvest stage. The most visible anthracnose symptoms are black or dark brown sunken lesions that contain conidial masses on the surface of infected fruits. Small individual lesions can merge to form larger lesions. These dark lesions on the fruit surface are unattractive to consumers and significantly reduce the market value of the affected fruits. Figures 2A–E display anthracnose lesions on several tropical fruit crops.', 0.14494669437408447]]

Context 1: [['Many species belonging to the genus Colletotrichum are associated with plant diseases, commonly referred to as anthracnose. Colletotrichum spp. can affect a wide range of hosts, and these pathogens are characterized by global distribution. Virtually every cultivated botanical family is susceptible to one or more species of Colletotrichum, making it one of the most studied plant pathogenic fungi (Prusky et al., 2000; Latunde-Dada, 2001; Dean et al., 2012). Common hosts include many dicotyledonous plants such as strawberry, apple, citrus, and stone fruits, as well as major cereals such as maize and sorghum. Members of this genus can cause crop losses of up to 100% in many staple foods (Bailey and Jeger, 1992; Prusky et al., 2000; Talhinhas et al., 2005; Cannon et al., 2012).', 0.5131760835647583]]

query: Are there established guidelines for conducting experiments to assess the cross-infection rates of Colletotrichum isolates?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Pathogenicity testing is highlighted as a crucial step to determine whether a specific Colletotrichum species is host-specific or has a broader host range. Host-specific taxa may have limited distributions, which carry significant biosecurity implications. Conversely, species with a wide host range may be more cosmopolitan and potentially opportunistic pathogens. Koch’s postulates have been applied to confirm the pathogenicity of various Colletotrichum isolates. For instance, studies have shown that C. acutatum causes Rhododendron anthracnose, while C. boninense was implicated in leaf infections of Euonymus. New species descriptions occasionally include data on pathogenicity testing, although this is not always the case. Further pathogenicity research is encouraged to validate findings across verified Colletotrichum species.', 0.3929688632488251]]

query: Can a single host be infected by multiple Colletotrichum species?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Many species belonging to the genus Colletotrichum are associated with plant diseases, commonly referred to as anthracnose. Colletotrichum spp. can affect a wide range of hosts, and these pathogens are characterized by global distribution. Virtually every cultivated botanical family is susceptible to one or more species of Colletotrichum, making it one of the most studied plant pathogenic fungi (Prusky et al., 2000; Latunde-Dada, 2001; Dean et al., 2012). Common hosts include many dicotyledonous plants such as strawberry, apple, citrus, and stone fruits, as well as major cereals such as maize and sorghum. Members of this genus can cause crop losses of up to 100% in many staple foods (Bailey and Jeger, 1992; Prusky et al., 2000; Talhinhas et al., 2005; Cannon et al., 2012).', 0.9871513843536377]]
Context 1: [['The genus Colletotrichum is considered one of the top ten important genera of fungal pathogens globally (Dean et al., 2012). Colletotrichum is an ancient fungus that has co-evolved with flowering plants. Plant microfossils of Protocolletotrichum preserved on angiosperm leaf cuticles suggest that the diverse pathogenic strategies of Colletotrichum spp. have been established since the Late Cretaceous period (Kar et al., 2004). Different complexes within the genus may have diverged between 4.8 and 32.2 million years ago (MYA) (Bhunjun et al., 2021). The emergence of agricultural cultivation and the intensive disturbance of natural environments have further driven the diversification of Colletotrichum species. These fungi have adapted to thousands of hosts and can be found as endophytes, pathogens, and saprobes (Freeman et al., 1998; Dean et al., 2012; Hirayama et al., 2018; da Silva et al., 2020; Jayawardena et al., 2020). Currently, a total of 257 Colletotrichum species grouped into 15 complexes and 13 additional singletons have been accepted in this genus.', 0.9241561889648438]]

query: How has strawberry anthracnose impacted the economic sustainability of strawberry production?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['So far, anthracnose epidemics have affected strawberry nurseries and production fields worldwide. Reports on Colletotrichum spp. associated with strawberries, curated from literature in PubMed and Clarivate combined with fungal database searches (Farr and Rossman, 2022), were compiled to understand the global diversity and occurrence of the causal agents of strawberry anthracnose. From our findings, since 1931 until July 9, 2022, there have been over 220 citations and 310 records related to the identification of causal agents of strawberry anthracnose at the genus level of Colletotrichum in 36 countries across six continents, with 282 records providing pathogen identification at the species or species complex level.', 0.6428065896034241]]
Context 1: [['Anthracnose is an important disease of strawberry caused by Colletotrichum spp., which affects foliage, runners, crowns, and fruits (Howard et al., 1992). Three primary fungal pathogens—C. acutatum sensu lato, C. gloeosporioides sensu lato, and C. fragariae—are known to cause anthracnose disease in strawberries (Freeman and Katan, 1997). The crown rot syndrome is characteristic of infections from C. gloeosporioides sensu lato and C. fragariae, while fruit rot is mainly attributed to C. acutatum sensu lato, leading to significant yield losses (Howard et al., 1992). Currently, numerous species are classified under what is now known as the C. acutatum complex, with six species—C. acutatum sensu stricto, C. fioriniae, C. godetiae, C. nymphaeae, C. salicis, and C. simmondsii—identified as associated with strawberry anthracnose worldwide (Damm et al., 2012). Among these, C. nymphaeae is the most prevalent pathogen causing strawberry anthracnose globally, including in Iran (Baroncelli et al., 2015; Karimi et al., 2017; Wang et al., 2019). Currently, no effective chemical control methods exist for managing strawberry anthracnose; available options are limited to preventive treatments applied before fruit production (Denoyes-Rothan et al., 1999). Additionally, concerns about the toxic effects of chemical fungicides on the environment and the development of resistance in fungal strains highlight the need for alternative control strategies. Consequently, utilizing resistant cultivars appears to be the most efficient and practical approach for suppressing anthracnose development. In light of recent anthracnose outbreaks in strawberry fields in the Kurdistan province of Iran (Karimi et al., 2017), and the necessity for appropriate strategies to address this issue, the aim of this study was to evaluate the resistance of several commercial strawberry cultivars to the anthracnose fruit rot caused by C. nymphaeae under in vivo and greenhouse conditions.', 0.6316460967063904]]
Context 2: [['Strawberries (Fragaria×ananassa Duch.) are a widely cultivated hybrid species within the Rosaceae family, renowned for their fruit. They are increasingly significant for the agricultural economic development of countries like Iran, particularly in the Kurdistan province, which leads in strawberry production, predominantly under open-field conditions (Tehranifar and Sarsaefi, 2002). Various biotic and abiotic factors contribute to the decline in strawberry production globally. Notably, over 100 fungal species can invade strawberry plants, with approximately one-third causing serious diseases on different plant parts (Martin and others).', 0.40211260318756104]]
Context 3: [['Species of the fungal plant pathogen Colletotrichum are responsible for strawberry (Fragaria × ananassa Duch.) anthracnose, one of the major diseases affecting this crop. Major species that cause strawberry anthracnose include C. acutatum J.H. Simmons, C. fragariae Brooks, and C. gloeosporioides (Penz.) Penz. & Sacc. Symptoms of the disease manifest in various phases. Infection of mother plants with anthracnose may result in the collapse of the entire plant due to crown rot. In the nursery, lesions form on stolons that eventually girdle the runners, leading to wilting and death of unrooted daughter plants distal to the lesion. Death of daughter plants in the nursery and in field transplants can also be caused by crown rot. Infected transplants are capable of spreading the disease from the nursery to the field, and entire crops can be destroyed by anthracnose in strawberry fruit production fields under conducive environmental conditions.', 0.40136852860450745]]
Context 4: [['De los Santos, B., de Paredes, G., and Munoz, F. R. (2002). Influence of anthracnose epiphytotic development on strawberry fruit production in Huelva (Southwestern Spain). Acta Hortic., 567:623-626.', 0.36199817061424255]]
Context 5: [['Although strawberries are considered a minor crop, they provide a significant source of income for many fruit and nursery growers. In the United States, strawberries were cultivated on nearly 20,000 hectares in 1989, yielding a total production of 555,000 tons valued at $520 million. Florida ranks second only to California in the production of fresh-market strawberries. For U.S. winter production (December through March), strawberries are grown on approximately 2,400 hectares. The major cultural problems faced by the Florida strawberry industry include: 1) anthracnose diseases, 2) yearly infestations of the two-spotted spider mite (Tetranychus urticae Koch), and 3) variability in the quality of nursery transplants. Commercial fields are established annually, similar to California practices. Freshly dug transplants are sourced from nurseries in Florida or from northern states and Canada. The use of transplants from northern nurseries is crucial to avoid anthracnose disease issues and to ensure that plants have undergone sufficient natural chilling to induce floral bud initiation.', 0.3596402704715729]]
Context 6: [['Strawberry anthracnose was first reported in China in 1990 (Hu, 1990). Shao (1992) documented the first instance of strawberry anthracnose in Shanghai, identifying the pathogen as Colletotrichum acutatum (Dai et al., 2006). Zhang et al. (2007) expanded on these findings by identifying C. gloeosporioides and C. fragariae (syn. C. theobromicola) as causal agents based on morphological characteristics. Ren et al. (2008, 2011) concluded that these three species are the main pathogens causing anthracnose in strawberries in China. Crown rot represents the most severe disease issue in many strawberry-producing regions of China (Ren et al., 2008). In the Zhejiang region, nearly 50% of seedling deaths in nurseries and over 40% yield losses in strawberry fields have been recorded (Xie et al., 2010). In 2009, the yield of greenhouse-cultivated strawberries in Donggang City, Liaoning Province, was reduced by over 10% due to crown rot (Wang, 2013). The average incidence of crown rot in greenhouses in Hubei Province was 41.7% in 2011 (Xiang et al., 2012). However, most studies conducted in China regarding this disease have primarily relied on morphological and single-gene (mainly ITS) analysis (Dai et al., 2006; Ren et al., 2008, 2011). Due to overlapping characteristics, species delimitation based solely on morphology is challenging in this genus. Employing multi-gene analysis alongside morphology can provide better resolution (Cai et al., 2009; Hyde et al., 2014). Therefore, the objective of this study was to identify the pathogens responsible for strawberry anthracnose in China using a morphological and multi-gene approach.', 0.3565032184123993]]
Context 7: [['De los Santos, B., de Paredes, G., and Munoz, F. R. 2002. Influence of anthracnose epiphytotic development on strawberry fruit production in Huelva (Southwestern Spain). Acta Hortic. 567:623-626.', 0.3367961049079895]]
Context 8: [['From May to September 1995, a severe outbreak of strawberry anthracnose was observed in several strawberry-growing nurseries in Israel. Following transplantation to production fields during September and October, entire beds of strawberry plants collapsed. Typical anthracnose symptoms observed from November 1995 to June 1996 included crown rot, flower blight, and green and ripe fruit rot. This marked the first record of strawberry anthracnose in Israel. Furthermore, in at least four production fields in the same region, hundreds of plants developed symptoms of stunting and chlorosis, which are atypical of strawberry anthracnose. When these plants were uprooted, most of their roots were dark brown and decayed. Colletotrichum was readily isolated from these samples.', 0.3237404525279999]]
Context 9: [['Shao, X. H. (1992). New disease of strawberry: Strawberry anthracnose. Acta Agriculturae Shanghai.', 0.3132001757621765]]

Context 8: [['Anthracnose spreads within a field through splashing water. Living mulches, such as wheat, rye, or rye grass, in row middles have been shown to reduce disease spread. Organic mulches like wheat straw or pine needles also reduce splash and result in a lower incidence of anthracnose compared to rows mulched with plastic (Coelho et al., 2008; Madden, 1992; Smith and Spiers, 1986). query: What symptoms should farmers look for to identify a Colletotrichum infection?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Many species belonging to the genus Colletotrichum are associated with plant diseases, commonly referred to as anthracnose. Colletotrichum spp. can affect a wide range of hosts, and these pathogens are characterized by global distribution. Virtually every cultivated botanical family is susceptible to one or more species of Colletotrichum, making it one of the most studied plant pathogenic fungi (Prusky et al., 2000; Latunde-Dada, 2001; Dean et al., 2012). Common hosts include many dicotyledonous plants such as strawberry, apple, citrus, and stone fruits, as well as major cereals such as maize and sorghum. Members of this genus can cause crop losses of up to 100% in many staple foods (Bailey and Jeger, 1992; Prusky et al., 2000; Talhinhas et al., 2005; Cannon et al., 2012).', 0.30741193890571594]]

query: What is the significance of Benomyl sensitivity testing in identifying Colletotrichum species and understanding fungicide resistance?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Past failures of fungicides to control anthracnose epidemics may have stemmed from the development of resistance in the Colletotrichum population. In the early 1970s, benomyl effectively reduced anthracnose crown rot incidence (Horn et al., 1972; Howard, 1971) and was widely used by strawberry growers for years. However, anthracnose pathogens developed resistance to it and other benzimidazole fungicides, rendering benomyl ineffective. In vitro and greenhouse trials have been conducted to identify fungicides to which Colletotrichum pathogens have developed resistance (LaMondia, 1993, 1995; McInnes et al., 1992a, 1992b; Smith and Black, 1991, 1992, 1993). Current fungicide labels address pathogen resistance by restricting the number of consecutive and total applications of a product per season. For instance, the fungicides Abound (azoxystrobin, Syngenta, Greensboro, NC), Cabrio (pyraclostrobin, BASF, Research Triangle Park, NC), and Pristine (pyraclostrobin and boscalid, BASF) are limited to four or five applications per season, with no more than two consecutive applications before alternating with a fungicide that has a different mode of action. Natural products have also been evaluated as alternative fungicides, offering different modes of action, lower toxicity, and increased efficacy (Abril et al., 2008).', 0.9874927997589111]]
Context 1: [['The fact that Colletotrichum species differ in their sensitivity to certain fungicides, such as benomyl, is critical for chemical pathogen control. This variability should be taken into account when implementing a spray program, especially in mixed populations like C. acutatum and C. gloeosporioides, which affect several hosts, including apple, citrus, mango, peach, pecan, and strawberries. Differential sensitivity among these species may result in shifts in population ratios.', 0.9832116961479187]]
Context 2: [['Semiselective Medium: Naturally occurring populations of fungi and bacteria in soil complicate studies of specific organisms found in low numbers. To develop a semiselective medium suitable for both controlled environments and field samples, a selective marker was necessary. The fungicide benomyl, previously used extensively in leatherleaf fern production, did not control fern anthracnose; thus, C. acutatum was expected to be tolerant to it. Induced resistance to benomyl is believed to arise from a single gene mutation and is easily induced and stable. However, some consider the resistance of C. acutatum to benomyl to be natural rather than the result of selection pressure. Benomyl has been included in semiselective media developed in other studies for the isolation of Colletotrichum spp. from soil.', 0.9615846872329712]]
Context 3: [['Benomyl Sensitivity Assessment Benomyl sensitivity based on fungicide disk assays indicates various resistance levels. Additional testing revealed that isolates from California were not vegetatively compatible with those from Israel, and that California isolates were distinct based on arbitrarily primed polymerase chain reaction (ap-PCR). For further context, benomyl sensitivity was also assessed at a concentration of 5 µg/ml.', 0.9288083910942078]]
Context 4: [['Smith, B.J. and L.L. Black. 1993. In vitro fungicide studies show the occurrence of benomyl-resistant Colletotrichum spp. from strawberry. Adv. Strawberry Res. 12:42-48.', 0.9275935888290405]]

retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['In a drastic move, von Arx (1957) reduced the number of recognized Colletotrichum species from several hundred to 11 based on morphological characteristics, with many taxa treated as synonyms of C. gloeosporioides and C. dematium. Several additional species have since been accepted based on morphological criteria (Sutton, 1980; 1992). The difficulties in recognizing Colletotrichum species can be attributed to: 1) the limited and variable morphological characters; 2) an extensive host range and variability in pathogenicity (Bailey and Jeger, 1992; Freeman et al., 2000; Latunde-Dada, 2001; Du et al., 2005; Thaung, 2008); 3) type specimens that are often missing or in poor condition, making them unsuitable for molecular studies; and 4) numerous rDNA ITS sequences of Colletotrichum strains in NCBI that are often misidentified (Crouch et al., 2009d; Damm et al., 2009).', 0.9732557535171509]]
Context 1: [['The genus Colletotrichum is considered one of the top ten important genera of fungal pathogens globally (Dean et al., 2012). Colletotrichum is an ancient fungus that has co-evolved with flowering plants. Plant microfossils of Protocolletotrichum preserved on angiosperm leaf cuticles suggest that the diverse pathogenic strategies of Colletotrichum spp. have been established since the Late Cretaceous period (Kar et al., 2004). Different complexes within the genus may have diverged between 4.8 and 32.2 million years ago (MYA) (Bhunjun et al., 2021). The emergence of agricultural cultivation and the intensive disturbance of natural environments have further driven the diversification of Colletotrichum species. These fungi have adapted to thousands of hosts and can be found as endophytes, pathogens, and saprobes (Freeman et al., 1998; Dean et al., 2012; Hirayama et al., 2018; da Silva et al., 2020; Jayawardena et al., 2020). Currently, a total of 257 Colletotrichum species grouped into 15 complexes and 13 additional singletons have been accepted in this genus.', 0.726059079170227]]

retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['The first record of C. acutatum s.l. in the UK was in 1978, found on Anemone sp. grown in Jersey. In 1982, the first incidence of anthracnose disease in strawberries caused by C. acutatum s.l. was recorded in the UK, attributed to the importation of infected strawberry runners from the USA. DNA sequences in public databases suggest that two UK isolates (CBS198.35 and CBS199.35), collected in 1935 from Phormium spp. (New Zealand flax), belong to C. acutatum s.l. CABI database records from 1978 to 1983 show the incidence of the pathogen on various hosts and in different UK locations. However, it seems improbable that the initial outbreak on strawberries led to widespread dispersal of the pathogen. In 1993, Lovelidge proposed that continued introduction of infected strawberry material from abroad made the disease likely to become endemic in the UK. Subsequent years saw further outbreaks on strawberries linked to the importation of infected propagation material, mainly from mainland Europe, as well as on other important crop hosts.', 0.9934213757514954]]
Context 1: [['Colletotrichum acutatum s.l. was first described as a strawberry pathogen in California in 1983 and has since spread worldwide, including the UK, through runners and propagating material. An extensive genetic characterization of C. acutatum s.l., representing the global diversity of the pathogen, led to its subdivision into genetic groups named A1 to A9. More recently, C. acutatum s.l. has been subdivided into over 30 species based on multilocus phylogeny.', 0.9914603233337402]]
Context 2: [['Colletotrichum acutatum sensu lato, along with C. salicis and C. miyabeana, is commonly found on strawberries in Oceania but has only been sporadically detected in Europe. Isolates of these species have not been identified on strawberries in the UK. The variability observed within the UK populations of C. acutatum sensu lato aligns, in part, with previous reports of C. acutatum on strawberries in specific geographic regions. For instance, in countries such as France, Israel, Bulgaria, and Spain, most strawberry anthracnose pathogen isolates clustered into the same species, C. nymphaeae, with minimal intra-specific diversity observed within each country. In contrast, Belgian isolates exhibited a different composition: 33% belonged to C. nymphaeae, 5% to C. fioriniae, 50% to C. godetiae, 3% to C. acutatum sensu stricto, and 6% to C. salicis. The C. acutatum sensu lato status in the UK may stem from a recent introduction in the late 1970s from a limited number of sources. The reasons behind the varying occurrences of different Colletotrichum species associated with strawberry production across geographic locations remain unclear; however, the sources of imported planting materials and local trade practices are heavily implicated.', 0.9782319664955139]]
Context 3: [['Thirty-four Colletotrichum acutatum sensu lato (s.l.) isolates were selected for pathogenicity tests on fruits and plants. This included six representative isolates from each of the three species associated with strawberry production in the UK (highlighted in Table 1 and in bold in Fig. 1) and one or more isolates representative of all the major species in the C. acutatum complex. Four C. gloeosporioides s.l. isolates, obtained from strawberry-infected tissues in the UK (CSL 780 and CSL 869, C. aenigma) and the USA (CSL 311 and CSL 386, C. fruticola), were included as an out-group.', 0.9725375175476074]]
Context 4: [['Some host plants appear to be particularly susceptible to infection by multiple Colletotrichum taxa. The occurrence of species on strawberry has been well researched due to the former status of C. acutatum as a regulated quarantine pathogen. We found that strains from this host belong to six different clades within the C. acutatum species complex: C. simmondsii (three strains from Australia), C. nymphaeae (38 strains, mostly from Europe and the USA), C. fioriniae (seven strains from New Zealand, the UK, and the USA), C. godetiae (10 strains, all from Europe), C. acutatum s. str. (one strain from Australia), and C. salicis (four strains from New Zealand). A study by MacKenzie et al. (2009) demonstrated that strains from strawberry were more aggressive to strawberry than strains from Vaccinium. Based on TUB2 sequences generated by those authors, the strains from strawberry were assigned to C. nymphaeae, while the strains from Vaccinium were assigned to C. fioriniae. The apparent differences in pathogenicity may not stem from the different hosts but rather from the fact that the strains studied belong to different species. To our knowledge, C. acutatum s. str. has rarely been found in Europe, and then mostly on ornamental plants. So far, it has only been isolated from strawberry in Australia. In pathogenicity tests by Talhinhas et al. (2005), an isolate of C. acutatum s. str. from olive caused anthracnose symptoms on strawberry fruits; its virulence was comparable to that of group A2 (C. nymphaeae and related species), A3 (C. fioriniae), or A4 (C. godetiae). If further quarantine regulation is to be implemented, beyond the generalized prohibition of contamination by any members of the C. acutatum species complex, more rigorous diagnostic methods will be needed.', 0.9232731461524963]]
Context 5: [['The results from this study, along with previous research, may explain the increasing significance of C. acutatum in northern regions (15, 20). Once introduced in an area, C. acutatum could possess distinct advantages over other strawberry-infecting species of Colletotrichum at cooler temperatures, which are typical for northern climates. Two of these advantages include a shorter latent period for C. acutatum and a greater production of spores at lower temperatures.', 0.8184517025947571]]
Context 6: [['Based on four sequence loci (ITS, TUB, GAPDH, and MAT1-2), the Colletotrichum acutatum sensu lato isolates were assigned to three newly designated species: C. nymphaeae, C. godetiae, and C. fioriniae, following a recent taxonomic re-assessment [18]. According to available literature, C. nymphaeae is the most common species, while C. godetiae is also frequently reported in European and American strawberry fields [6]. These two species were the most representative in our dataset of isolates related to strawberries in the UK. C. fioriniae has a worldwide distribution and is common on strawberries, but only a few isolates were identified in our collection, and this group was not commonly present in the fields in the UK.', 0.8049118518829346]]
Context 7: [['On strawberry plants, C. acutatum primarily causes black spot disease on the fruit but can also affect crowns, roots, and leaves (Freeman & Katan 1997), making it one of the most serious diseases in commercial fruit production. The conidia are formed in acervuli on the host, while in culture, they can also be produced in the aerial mycelium (Johnston & Jones 1997). C. acutatum has been observed to form secondary conidia on living strawberry leaves, stimulated by extracts from the strawberry plant, especially flower extracts (Leandro et al. 2001; Leandro et al. 2003). According to Buddie et al. (1999), secondary conidia may be produced directly from germinating primary conidia, and these are generally smaller and more variable in shape, which can obscure the differences between taxa. Additionally, C. acutatum forms simple pigmented appressoria but has few or no setae (Simmonds 1965).', 0.7295527458190918]]
Context 8: [['This study provides strong evidence that C. acutatum can become established, persist, and produce inoculum on symptomless strawberry leaves under a range of temperatures and intermittent wetness periods. In addition to our previous work at 26°C under continuous wetness (19), we have now shown that secondary conidia and appressoria may be produced under environmental conditions typical of many temperate strawberry-producing areas in the world. The survival of C. acutatum on strawberry leaves has implications for long-distance dissemination on transplants, as well as the proliferation and dissemination of the fungus within production fields. Furthermore, asymptomatic foliage of other plant species, including weeds, has been recently suggested as an additional inoculum source for C. acutatum (12). The environmental biology of C. acutatum on symptomless foliage should therefore be considered when developing management practices for strawberry anthracnose.', 0.5733811259269714]]
Context 9: [['C. acutatum was first described as a separate species by Simmonds. Many isolates now identified as C. acutatum were either classified under C. gloeosporioides or considered species of Gloeo sporium. C. acutatum affects hosts that are also targeted by other Colletotrichum species, possibly leading to its earlier misidentification. For instance, strawberries can be affected by C. acutatum, C. gloeosporioides, and C. fragariae. The latter two typically cause petiole and stolon lesions, as well as crown rot on strawberries.', 0.5561544299125671]]

query: What impact does the pathogenicity of Colletotrichum species have on the post-harvest quality of strawberries?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Despite intensive research that has contributed to the understanding of the Colletotrichum genus pathogenic to strawberries, there is still a lack of an accurate inventory of these causal agents. The population and prevalence of strawberry-virulent Colletotrichum species have not been systematically investigated in major producers such as China. To address these gaps, this review aims to summarize the biodiversity of Colletotrichum species pathogenic to strawberries by examining the global discovery history. Subsequently, the prevalence of Colletotrichum species pathogenic to strawberries in China was analyzed using available data. Finally, we categorized the host range of the two predominant species responsible for strawberry crown rot. This knowledge has important applications for biosecurity risk management (e.g., proper risk estimation in strawberry seedling trade), accurate diagnosis, and anthracnose control. It further lays the groundwork for systematically managing Colletotrichum genera in agricultural ecosystems, not only for the strawberry industry.', 0.9644361734390259]]

(teleomorph: Glomerella cingulata (Stoneman) Spauld. & H. Schrenk).', 0.9438523650169373]]

query: What are the differences between traditional and hydroponic strawberry farming?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Korean strawberry production amounted to 1.23 billion won and 163 thousand tons in 2020. It ranked first among horticultural crops and is a primary income crop for farms. In 2021, the greenhouse strawberry cultivation area was 6057 ha, while open field cultivation accounted for only 46 ha, less than 1% of the total strawberry cultivation area. The hydroponic cultivation area for strawberries expanded to 1596 ha in 2020. Hydroponics using an artificial substrate can provide physical and chemical conditions suitable for nutrient absorption by plants. Intensive and effective crop management can be achieved through hydroponic techniques that supply nutrients using a nutrient solution in the substrates. In hydroponics, water supply control is performed to maintain...', 0.4147966206073761]]
Context 1: [['RDA. Manual for Strawberry Cultivation; RDA: Jeonju, Korea, 2019; p. 144.', 0.19534020125865936]]
Context 2: [['In the traditional system of strawberry production, plants are grown in the ground, and crop rotation is essential. However, in recent cultivation systems, plants are continuously cultivated on elevated benches to improve production efficiency. This continuous cropping system usually increases weed populations and necessitates intensive herbicide applications, which can also enhance the risk of disease dissemination from weeds to strawberries. The present study demonstrated that an increase of C. fructicola in weeds heightened the incidence of anthracnose in strawberries during the following cultivation season. While there are numerous sources of C. fructicola that lead to disease during subsequent strawberry cultivations, the increase of pathogens on herbicide-treated weeds can be a significant source.', 0.1746322214603424]]

query: What are the key differences between Colletotrichum boninense and Colletotrichum siamense?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Colletotrichum boninense Moriwaki, Toy. Sato & Tsukib. This species occurs on the leaves of Crinum asiaticum, presenting as reddish-brown, ellipsoid to irregular spots and forming pink conidial masses with rare setae (Fig. 6A). In this study, although the conidia of C. boninense (CSSN1 and CSSX8) are wider than those of the holotype and paratype, their shape and cultural characteristics are similar, and they cluster in one clade with high bootstrap support (there is one base difference in the ITS sequence among them and the holotype). Additionally, the holotype and paratype of C. boninense were collected from Crinum asiaticum var. sinicum in Japan.', 0.9494516849517822]]
Context 1: [['Colletotrichum oncidii differs from the closely related C. boninense by forming appressoria that are larger and lobate, while those of C. boninense are entire or crenate. Additionally, C. oncidii has longer setae (SNA: 65–120 µm, Anthriscus stem: 75–210 µm) that are 2–5-septate on both media, whereas those of C. boninense are only 20–60 or 30–70 µm long and 1–2-septate. No teleomorph is known.', 0.778031051158905]]
Context 2: [['Although recently described, Colletotrichum boninense is well established in the literature as an anthracnose pathogen or endophyte of various host plants worldwide. It is especially prominent on members of Amaryllidaceae, Orchidaceae, Proteaceae, and Solanaceae. Reports from literature and preliminary studies using ITS sequence data indicated that C. boninense represents a species complex. A multilocus molecular phylogenetic analysis (ITS, ACT, TUB2, CHS-1, GAPDH, HIS3, CAL) of 86 strains previously identified as C. boninense and other related strains revealed 18 clades. These clades are recognized here as separate species, including C. boninense s. str., C. hippeastri, C. karstii, and 12 previously undescribed species: C. annellatum, C. beeveri, C. brassicicola, C. brasiliense, C. colombiense, C. constrictum, C. cymbidiicola, C. dacrycarpi, C. novae-zelandiae, C. oncidii, C. parsonsiae, and C. torulosum. Seven of the new species are known only from New Zealand, possibly reflecting a sampling bias. The new combination C. phyllanthi was established, and C. dracaenae Petch was epitypified and renamed as C. petchii. Typical for species of the C. boninense species complex are conidiogenous cells with prominent periclinal thickening, which may extend to form a new conidiogenous locus or annellations, and conidia featuring a prominent basal scar. Many species in the C. boninense complex form teleomorphs in culture.', 0.6878577470779419]]
Context 3: [['Notes: There are four species in the C. boninense species complex known to occur on Passiflora: C. brasiliense from Brazil (on fruits), C. colombiense from Colombia (on leaves), C. torulosum from New Zealand (on leaves), and C. karstii from Japan and Colombia (on leaves) and Brazil (on fruits). According to Johnston & Jones (1997), C. gloeosporioides Group E (= C. novae-zelandiae) and C. gloeosporioides Group I (= C. constrictum) have also been isolated from Passiflora, although this has not been confirmed by molecular methods. Colletotrichum brasiliense and C. colombiense are currently known only from Passiflora. C. brasiliense is documented only in Brazil, where it causes anthracnose of yellow passion fruit (Passiflora edulis f. flavicarpa; Tozze et al. 2010). It is closely related to C. parsonsiae and C. hippeastri, distinguished by most genes, including ITS, although the CHS-1 sequence of one isolate was identical to that of C. parsonsii. Appressoria exhibit a lower L/W ratio (1.2) compared to other species in this group.', 0.6462939381599426]]
Context 4: [['Damm, U., Cannon, P. F., Woudenberg, J. H. C., Johnston, P. R., Weir, B. S., Tan, Y. P., Shivas, R. G., and Crous, P. W. (2012b). The Colletotrichum boninense species complex. Stud. Mycol., 73, 1-36.', 0.6308164000511169]]
Context 5: [['Moriwaki J, Sato T, Tsukiboshi T. Morphological and molecular characterization of Colletotrichum boninense sp. nov. from Japan. Mycoscience. 2003; 44: 47–53. https://doi.org/10.1007/S10267-002-0079-7.', 0.6251072287559509]]
Context 6: [['Damm U, Cannon PF, Woudenberg JH, Johnston PR, and Weir BS et al. (2012) examined the Colletotrichum boninense species complex in Studies in Mycology (73: 1-36). Prihastuti H, Cai L, Chen H, McKenzie EHC, and Hyde KD (2009) characterized Colletotrichum species associated with coffee berries in northern Thailand, as discussed in Fungal Diversity (39: 89-109).', 0.6131529211997986]]
Context 7: [['Colletotrichum boninense Moriwaki, Toy. Sato & Tsukib., Mycoscience 44(1): 48. 2003. Fig. 4.', 0.5958784818649292]]
Context 8: [['Damm, U., Cannon, P.F., Woudenberg, J.H.C., Johnston, P.R., Weir, B.S., Tan, Y.P., Shivas, R.G., & Crous, P.W. (2012). The Colletotrichum boninense species complex. Studies in Mycology, 73, 1–36.', 0.5854830741882324]]
Context 9: [['Damm, U., Cannon, P.F., Woudenberg, J.H.C., Johnston, P.R., Weir, B.S., et al. (2012b). The Colletotrichum boninense species complex. Studies in Mycology 73: 1–36.', 0.5470094680786133]]

query: How can breeding programs benefit from identifying relatively resistant cultivars?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['The USDA-ARS program resulted in over 1,500 anthracnose-resistant selections from seedlings field-tested in Mississippi. Four of these selections were released as breeding lines (Galletta et al., 1993), and one was released as the cultivar Pelican, which is highly resistant to anthracnose crown rot caused by Colletotrichum fragariae and to anthracnose fruit rot caused by C. acutatum (Smith et al., 1998). Pelican is also resistant to five races of red stele caused by Phytophthora fragariae. Other selections have been utilized as parent lines in various breeding programs. To enhance genetic diversity in strawberry germplasm used in breeding, anthracnose-resistant clones have been identified in native plant collections and are being incorporated as parent lines (Lewers et al., 2007).', 0.7427221536636353]]
Context 1: [['The development of cultivars resistant to red stele has been a primary objective of the USDA program. Various resistant cultivars have been introduced, including ‘Surecrop’, ‘Midway’, ‘Sunrise’, ‘Guardian’, ‘Earliglow’, and more recently, ‘Scott’, ‘Allstar’, ‘Lester’, and ‘Lateglow’. In the Pacific Northwest, Waldo introduced ‘Siletz’ in 1955, marking the first red stele-resistant strawberry for this region. Since then, two other significant red stele-resistant cultivars, ‘Hood’ and ‘Benton’, have emerged from the cooperative USDA-Oregon State strawberry breeding program. Furthermore, the first day-neutral cultivars with multiple resistances to red stele, ‘Tristar’ and ‘Tribute’, were released from Beltsville in 1981 (Galletta et al., 1981).', 0.6733133792877197]]
Context 2: [['Initially, the parent lines consisted of eastern cultivars and advanced selections from the breeding program at Beltsville. As the program progressed, resistant selections from the anthracnose program were crossed with commercial cultivars to enhance the horticultural characteristics of the progeny. Seeds from the crosses made at Beltsville were germinated at Poplarville, where the resulting seedlings were inoculated with a conidial suspension of Colletotrichum fragariae, incubated in a dew chamber for 48 hours, then moved to a warm greenhouse and evaluated for anthracnose severity 30 days after inoculation.', 0.5362627506256104]]
Context 3: [['Variance (Watkins and Spangelo, 1968) can be improved by evaluating a large number of parental combinations (progeny testing) to identify and select the best combinations for resistance to anthracnose. In a second phase, these best crosses should be grown on a larger scale to select the best genotypes among them. Additionally, recombination of the best selections can be performed to obtain improved populations. Selection in a breeding program typically involves multiple characteristics; therefore, the best crosses should combine anthracnose resistance with other desirable horticultural traits.', 0.4743347465991974]]
Context 4: [['From 1976 to 1995, over 160,000 progeny from 448 crosses made at Beltsville, primarily by G.J. Galletta, were screened for anthracnose resistance in a greenhouse at Poplarville, MS. Initially, the parent lines consisted of eastern cultivars and advanced selections from the breeding program at Beltsville. As the program progressed, resistant selections from the anthracnose program were crossed with commercial cultivars to enhance the horticultural characteristics of the progeny.', 0.4470445215702057]]
Context 5: [['Selfings of resistant cultivars such as Arking-S1, Chandler-S1, and Rosanne-S1, exhibit various resistance ratios and probabilities, highlighting their effectiveness against the pathogen.', 0.2750290632247925]]
Context 6: [['Regarding the absence of resistance, the S1 progenies from susceptible parental cultivars, including Darestival, Elsanta, Fern, Hokowase, HummiGento, Pajaro, Valeta, and Yolo, showed very low percentages of resistant genotypes (ranging from 0.0 to 8.8%, with an average of 3%) (refer to Table 3). This result aligns well with the hypothesis of a segregation ratio of 0:1 (resistant/susceptible) with P > 0.05. The populations derived from intercrosses among these cultivars maintained the same ratio, thereby supporting the hypothesis of the absence of a dominant gene.', 0.2544032037258148]]
Context 7: [['During the 1920s, more than 130 strawberry cultivars and 20 selections of Fragaria species were utilized in the breeding program, with 44 of these parents originating from Europe (Darrow et al., 1934). Thousands of seedlings were evaluated, resulting in the naming of several cultivars (Darrow, 1937). The two most significant cultivars from this early work were ‘Blakemore’ and ‘Fairfax’. ‘Blakemore’ quickly became a leading cultivar, setting a standard for firmness that allowed successful long-distance shipping of fruit. This cultivar demonstrated wide adaptability in the southern and south-central regions of the U.S. and continues to be commercially grown in some areas. Both ‘Blakemore’ and ‘Fairfax’, along with other USDA selections such as 253, 543, and 634, became widely used as parent plants in subsequent breeding programs (Darrow, 1966). ‘Fairfax’ was particularly valued for its excellent fruit quality and resistance to leaf spot (Darrow, 1962).', 0.24590705335140228]]
Context 8: [['Additionally, all cultivars except ‘Gaviota’, FL 99-164, ‘Carmine’, and ‘Camino Real’ were tested in at least two seasons. ‘Treasure’ was identified as more resistant, while ‘Gaviota’ was found to be more susceptible than any of the other cultivars examined. ‘Strawberry Festival’ had an intermediate level of resistance, approximately the same as that of ‘Aromas’.', 0.2232673615217209]]
Context 9: [['Plant Breeding Institute, The University of Sydney, Cobbitty, NSW, 2570, Australia.', 0.21086813509464264]]

query: What are the typical symptoms of anthracnose disease in strawberries?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Numerous reports indicate that strawberry anthracnose pathogens may originate from weed species. For instance, C. fragariae was found attacking the weed Cassia obtusifolia L. (sicklepod, coffeweed) in Florida, causing typical disease symptoms. Inoculation of strawberry with the Cassia isolates resulted in typical anthracnose symptoms, while isolates from strawberry were equally virulent on Cassia. Similarly, inoculation of Duchesnea indica (Andr.) Focke (wild strawberry), F. virginiana Duch. (Virginia wild strawberry), and Potentilla canadensis L. with C. fragariae induced anthracnose disease on these hosts, suggesting that strawberry anthracnose pathogens have a broad host range.', 0.9958187937736511]]
Context 1: [['From May to September 1995, a severe outbreak of strawberry anthracnose was observed in several strawberry-growing nurseries in Israel. Following transplantation to production fields during September and October, entire beds of strawberry plants collapsed. Typical anthracnose symptoms observed from November 1995 to June 1996 included crown rot, flower blight, and green and ripe fruit rot. This marked the first record of strawberry anthracnose in Israel. Furthermore, in at least four production fields in the same region, hundreds of plants developed symptoms of stunting and chlorosis, which are atypical of strawberry anthracnose. When these plants were uprooted, most of their roots were dark brown and decayed. Colletotrichum was readily isolated from these samples.', 0.9907379746437073]]
Context 2: [['In November 2021, anthracnose symptoms were observed on strawberries (cv. Kingsberry) in Nonsan, Chungnam Province. Early symptoms of anthracnose fruit rot (AFR) include blackening of specific tissues of the strawberry. These symptoms progress with the enlargement of lesions, which hinder proper fruit development and lead to the formation of orange-colored spores within the lesions. Similar symptoms were noted on the petioles, with sunken and blackened tissues similar to those on the fruit, accompanied by the formation of an orange conidial mass.', 0.9853731989860535]]
Context 3: [['Anthracnose is an important disease of strawberry caused by Colletotrichum spp., which affects foliage, runners, crowns, and fruits (Howard et al., 1992). Three primary fungal pathogens—C. acutatum sensu lato, C. gloeosporioides sensu lato, and C. fragariae—are known to cause anthracnose disease in strawberries (Freeman and Katan, 1997). The crown rot syndrome is characteristic of infections from C. gloeosporioides sensu lato and C. fragariae, while fruit rot is mainly attributed to C. acutatum sensu lato, leading to significant yield losses (Howard et al., 1992). Currently, numerous species are classified under what is now known as the C. acutatum complex, with six species—C. acutatum sensu stricto, C. fioriniae, C. godetiae, C. nymphaeae, C. salicis, and C. simmondsii—identified as associated with strawberry anthracnose worldwide (Damm et al., 2012). Among these, C. nymphaeae is the most prevalent pathogen causing strawberry anthracnose globally, including in Iran (Baroncelli et al., 2015; Karimi et al., 2017; Wang et al., 2019). Currently, no effective chemical control methods exist for managing strawberry anthracnose; available options are limited to preventive treatments applied before fruit production (Denoyes-Rothan et al., 1999). Additionally, concerns about the toxic effects of chemical fungicides on the environment and the development of resistance in fungal strains highlight the need for alternative control strategies. Consequently, utilizing resistant cultivars appears to be the most efficient and practical approach for suppressing anthracnose development. In light of recent anthracnose outbreaks in strawberry fields in the Kurdistan province of Iran (Karimi et al., 2017), and the necessity for appropriate strategies to address this issue, the aim of this study was to evaluate the resistance of several commercial strawberry cultivars to the anthracnose fruit rot caused by C. nymphaeae under in vivo and greenhouse conditions.', 0.9836556911468506]]
Context 4: [["Anthracnose fungi can attack various parts of the strawberry plant, including crowns, petioles, leaves, fruit trusses, flowers, buds, and fruit. The fungi's ability to attack multiple plant parts, coupled with the involvement of several pathogen species, contributes to the complex nature of strawberry anthracnose. query: How should I monitor my strawberry plants for signs of anthracnose?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Anthracnose is an important disease of strawberry caused by Colletotrichum spp., which affects foliage, runners, crowns, and fruits (Howard et al., 1992). Three primary fungal pathogens—C. acutatum sensu lato, C. gloeosporioides sensu lato, and C. fragariae—are known to cause anthracnose disease in strawberries (Freeman and Katan, 1997). The crown rot syndrome is characteristic of infections from C. gloeosporioides sensu lato and C. fragariae, while fruit rot is mainly attributed to C. acutatum sensu lato, leading to significant yield losses (Howard et al., 1992). Currently, numerous species are classified under what is now known as the C. acutatum complex, with six species—C. acutatum sensu stricto, C. fioriniae, C. godetiae, C. nymphaeae, C. salicis, and C. simmondsii—identified as associated with strawberry anthracnose worldwide (Damm et al., 2012). Among these, C. nymphaeae is the most prevalent pathogen causing strawberry anthracnose globally, including in Iran (Baroncelli et al., 2015; Karimi et al., 2017; Wang et al., 2019). Currently, no effective chemical control methods exist for managing strawberry anthracnose; available options are limited to preventive treatments applied before fruit production (Denoyes-Rothan et al., 1999). Additionally, concerns about the toxic effects of chemical fungicides on the environment and the development of resistance in fungal strains highlight the need for alternative control strategies. Consequently, utilizing resistant cultivars appears to be the most efficient and practical approach for suppressing anthracnose development. In light of recent anthracnose outbreaks in strawberry fields in the Kurdistan province of Iran (Karimi et al., 2017), and the necessity for appropriate strategies to address this issue, the aim of this study was to evaluate the resistance of several commercial strawberry cultivars to the anthracnose fruit rot caused by C. nymphaeae under in vivo and greenhouse conditions.', 0.790886640548706]]
Context 1: [['Species of the fungal plant pathogen Colletotrichum are responsible for strawberry (Fragaria × ananassa Duch.) anthracnose, one of the major diseases affecting this crop. Major species that cause strawberry anthracnose include C. acutatum J.H. Simmons, C. fragariae Brooks, and C. gloeosporioides (Penz.) Penz. & Sacc. Symptoms of the disease manifest in various phases. Infection of mother plants with anthracnose may result in the collapse of the entire plant due to crown rot. In the nursery, lesions form on stolons that eventually girdle the runners, leading to wilting and death of unrooted daughter plants distal to the lesion. Death of daughter plants in the nursery and in field transplants can also be caused by crown rot. Infected transplants are capable of spreading the disease from the nursery to the field, and entire crops can be destroyed by anthracnose in strawberry fruit production fields under conducive environmental conditions.', 0.6986253261566162]]
