query: What are the advantages of using Bayesian methods in phylogenetic studies?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Bayesian inference (BI) was employed to reconstruct most of the phylogenies using MrBayes v. 3.2.1 (Ronquist et al. 2012). Bayesian inference has significant advantages over other analysis methods, such as maximum likelihood and maximum parsimony (Archibald et al. 2003), as it provides measures of clade support in the form of posterior probabilities instead of random resampling bootstraps. jModelTest v. 0.1.1 (Posada 2008) was utilized to conduct statistical selection of the best-fit models of nucleotide substitution using the corrected Akaike information criteria (AICc) (see Table 3). Initial analyses indicated that individual genes were broadly congruent, thus nucleotide alignments of all genes were concatenated using Geneious, and separate partitions were created for each gene with its own model of nucleotide substitution. Analyses of the full dataset were run twice for 5 x 10^7 generations and twice for 2 x 10^7 generations for the clade trees. Samples were taken from the posterior every 1000 generations. Convergence of all parameters was checked using internal diagnostics of the standard deviation of split frequencies and performance scale reduction factors (PSRF), as well as externally with Tracer v. 1.5 (Rambaut & Drummond 2007). Based on these diagnostics, the first 25% of generations were discarded as burn-in.', 0.9830970764160156]]
Context 1: [['Huelsenbeck, J.P., Ronquist, F., 2001. MRBAYES: Bayesian inference of phylogeny. Bioinformatics 17: 754–755.', 0.5900323390960693]]

query: What is the significance of the detached fruit assay in this study?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['In this study, distinct levels of resistance to anthracnose fruit rot (AFR) were revealed in trials involving detached leaves, fruit, and crown-based assays. In all assays, fruit, leaf, and crown infections were confirmed by re-isolation of the pathogen. In the detached leaf assay, the cultivars ‘Missionary’, ‘New Kurdistan’, ‘Ventana1’, ‘Ventana’, and ‘Blakemore’ exhibited significantly greater resistance to the disease compared to other cultivars (df = 24, F = 14.66, P ≤ 0.01). The exception included ‘Ten Beauty’, ‘N. Selva’, ‘Chandler’, ‘Aliso’, ‘Fresno’, ‘Mac Donance’, ‘Gaviota’, ‘Dachnitsa’, ‘Aromas’, and ‘Mrak’. The most susceptible cultivar was ‘Camarosa’, followed by ‘Selva’, ‘Paros’, ‘Diamant’, ‘Karcynberg’, ‘Kurdistan’, ‘Pajaro’, ‘Queen Eliza’, ‘Sequia’, and ‘Yallova’.', 0.9244614839553833]]
Context 1: [['In the detached fruit assay, AFR was observed on all fruits from different cultivars. However, the severity of the disease varied significantly (df = 24, F = 16.85, P ≤ 0.01) among cultivars. ‘Blakemore’ and ‘Kurdistan’ were the most resistant cultivars to AFR, significantly outperforming others, including ‘Aliso’, ‘Mrak’, ‘Diamant’, ‘Yallova’, ‘New Kurdistan’, ‘Mac Donance’, and ‘Ten Beauty’. Conversely, ‘Gaviota’ was highly susceptible, significantly more so than all other cultivars except ‘Camarosa’.', 0.863734245300293]]
Context 2: [['These findings align with previous studies indicating that susceptibility to anthracnose fruit rot (AFR) varies among different organs of a cultivar, including fruit, leaf, and root. Notably, no relationship was established between the susceptibility of various cultivars and the different organs of a single cultivar (Delp and Milholland, 1980; Smith and Spires, 1982; Smith and Black, 1990; Chandler et al., 1997). Furthermore, the presence of the pathogen might not cause symptoms on foliage, leading to latent infections. Consistent with Shuman (2001), our results suggest that the detached fruit assay is a better indicator of AFR disease susceptibility, though other methods could also enhance the understanding of disease epidemiology.', 0.8014431595802307]]
Context 3: [['Infection Post-deposition: A study was conducted to determine if the micro-environment within the canopies varied in terms of favorableness for fruit infection. The effect of plant density treatment on fruit infection post-deposition was assessed by determining the disease incidence of inoculated, detached fruit placed within each treatment row canopy and in unsheltered areas adjacent to the plot site. Greenhouse-grown fruit (‘Midway’) at the white stage were collected with the pedicels and inoculated in the laboratory as previously described (43), using a concentration of 1 × 10³ conidia/ml. This inoculum density produces a fruit disease incidence of approximately 0.5 with 12 hours of wetness at 25°C in controlled-environment chambers (41).', 0.6446011662483215]]
Context 4: [['The table outlines three assays: Detached Fruit Assay (DFA), Detached Leaf Assay (DLA), and Crown Infection Assay (CIA). For each cultivar, disease severity (DS) and disease incidence (DI) percentages are provided.', 0.5792855620384216]]
Context 5: [['General methods were similar to those described by Madden et al. (21) and Yang et al. (37, 38). Detached fruit, with pedicels intact, were collected from strawberry plants at the white stage, which is when chlorophyll breakdown occurs. The fruit was placed in 50 ml of deionized water and agitated for 1.5 minutes. After removal, the spore suspension was vortexed for another 1.5 minutes. Four 10-µl samples were placed on a hemacytometer to calculate the density of conidia per milliliter, with the mean of the samples used to represent each fruit. Each test was conducted at least three times, with each species, isolate, and temperature combination tested in random order.', 0.5729034543037415]]
Context 6: [['In order to test the pathogenicity of the new species, detached fruits and leaf inoculations were conducted. To determine whether this new species can infect the rhizome (crown), seedling inoculations were also carried out.', 0.43077754974365234]]
Context 7: [['The data indicate that disease severity was consistently high for some cultivars in both detached leaf and detached fruit assays, with several showing 100% disease incidence.', 0.35485896468162537]]
Context 8: [['Sporulation on infected fruit attached to plants was assessed for C. acutatum OH and MS, C. fragariae MS, and C. gloeosporioides FL to validate results from detached fruit.', 0.3340395390987396]]
Context 9: [['Detached untreated fruits of each cultivar were inoculated with the conidial suspension of C. nymphaeae PET1 at a concentration of 1 × 10^6 conidia mL^-1, containing Tween 80 (0.1%; v/v), as described in the pathogenicity test. Six fruits were inoculated for each cultivar. After 7 days, disease incidence and severity were calculated based on the previously mentioned index.', 0.32875826954841614]]

query: What are the common symptoms of anthracnose in plants?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['From 2010 to 2016, we conducted surveys of anthracnose in strawberries in Miaoli County. More than 50% of diseased plants exhibited symptoms characteristic of anthracnose crown rot (ACR), as described by McInnes et al. (1992). ACR resulted in plant losses of up to 30-40% during the seedling stage and around 20% after transplanting. Initial symptoms in crown tissue included a marbled red and white appearance, which progressed to brown rot and eventual rapid wilting of the plant. Anthracnose symptoms also appeared on other parts of the plant, including leaves, petioles, runners, fruits, and roots. These symptoms manifested as circular black spots on leaves, withering and girdling on runners.', 0.9590631723403931]]
Context 1: [['Figure 1 illustrates the anthracnose disease cycle in tropical fruit crops, drawn by Latiffah Zakaria. Anthracnose pathogens infect not only fruits but also other plant organs, including leaves, flowers, twigs, and branches. The conidia and spores formed in these infected tissues are released and dispersed during rainy days or periods of high humidity, becoming the primary inoculum for fruit infection at the preharvest stage. The most visible anthracnose symptoms are black or dark brown sunken lesions that contain conidial masses on the surface of infected fruits. Small individual lesions can merge to form larger lesions. These dark lesions on the fruit surface are unattractive to consumers and significantly reduce the market value of the affected fruits. Figures 2A–E display anthracnose lesions on several tropical fruit crops.', 0.7873862385749817]]
Context 2: [['Inflorescences, leaves, and fruits showing typical anthracnose symptoms were collected from orchards located in Chachoengsao, Phichit, and Ratchaburi. Visual anthracnose symptoms included inflorescence blight, small brown to black spots, and irregularly shaped lesions with necrotic brown to black areas on leaves. Symptoms on ripe fruit were characterized by small black circular spots and irregular, necrotic, sunken brown to black lesions. In severely infected fruit, extensive rot was observed, and under high humidity, bright orange to pale-colored spore masses could be seen. Infected premature fruits often dropped from the trees. A total of 37 fungal isolates resembling Colletotrichum spp. were obtained.', 0.6941798329353333]]
Context 3: [['Hemmi, T. (1920). Kurze Mitteilung über drei Fälle von Anthracnose auf Pflanzen. Annals of the Phytopathological Society of Japan, 1(3), 13–21.', 0.44570615887641907]]
Context 4: [['Smith, B.J. (1998c). Anthracnose leaf spot and irregular leaf spot, pp. 24–25. In J.L. Maas (Ed.), Compendium of strawberry diseases (2nd ed.). American Phytopathological Society, St. Paul, MN.', 0.20724156498908997]]
Context 5: [['Additional Keywords: anthracnose, disease spread, Fragaria × ananassa, models, quantitative epidemiology.', 0.20549623668193817]]

query: Which treatment is the most effective on anthracnose?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['The efficacy of fungicides for anthracnose control is routinely assessed in field studies. For example, 16 different fungicide treatments were evaluated in five studies conducted in Hammond, LA, and Poplarville, MS, during the 2002, 2003, and 2005 fruiting seasons (Wedge et al., 2007).', 0.8595342040061951]]
Context 1: [['Until highly resistant cultivars are available, growers must rely on chemical applications and cultural practices to reduce losses due to anthracnose. The failure of fungicides to control anthracnose epidemics may be attributed to the development of fungicide resistance in the Colletotrichum species population. For example, benomyl was shown to effectively reduce the incidence of anthracnose crown rot (Horn et al., 1972; Howard, 1971) and was used intensively by strawberry growers for years to control anthracnose and other diseases. However, the anthracnose pathogens, C. acutatum and C. fragariae, developed resistance to it and other benzimidazole fungicides (LaMondia, 1995; McInnes et al., 1992a; Smith and Black, 1992, 1993), leading to the ineffectiveness of benomyl for anthracnose control in strawberry fields.', 0.6251190900802612]]
Context 2: [['Until highly resistant cultivars are available, growers must rely on chemical applications and cultural practices to reduce losses due to anthracnose. The failure of fungicides to control anthracnose epidemics may be due to the development of fungicide resistance in the Colletotrichum spp. population. For example, benomyl effectively reduced the incidence of anthracnose crown rot (Horn et al., 1972; Howard, 1971) and was used intensively by strawberry growers for years to control anthracnose and other diseases. However, the anthracnose pathogens, C. acutatum and C. fragariae, developed resistance to it and other benzimidazole fungicides (LaMondia, 1995; McInnes et al., 1992a; Smith and Black, 1992, 1993), rendering benomyl ineffective for anthracnose control in strawberry fields.', 0.5609443187713623]]
Context 3: [['As our knowledge of the anthracnose pathogens and the epidemiology of anthracnose diseases has increased, so has our ability to control these diseases. Changes in cultural practices have resulted in reduced levels of disease. Additionally, the development and registration of more effective fungicides for use on strawberries have significantly reduced losses from both anthracnose crown rot and fruit rot. Anthracnose-resistant cultivars have also diminished economic losses due to these diseases. Nevertheless, growers may still experience severe losses when environmental factors are highly favorable for anthracnose development.', 0.5435210466384888]]
Context 4: [['As our understanding of the anthracnose pathogens and the epidemiology of anthracnose diseases has improved, so has our capacity to control these diseases. Changes in cultural practices have led to reduced levels of disease. Additionally, the development and registration of more effective fungicides for use on strawberries have significantly decreased losses due to anthracnose crown rot and fruit rot. The introduction of partially resistant cultivars has also helped mitigate economic losses due to these diseases. Nonetheless, growers may still experience severe losses when environmental conditions are highly conducive to anthracnose development.', 0.5314050316810608]]
Context 5: [['Increased losses due to anthracnose fruit and crown rots may be related to the shift from matted-row culture to the annual plasticulture production system in the United States. Breeding for genetic resistance to anthracnose and the development of resistant cultivars are primary means for reducing economic losses due to this disease. This approach is environmentally sound because it results in reduced fungicide use. As our knowledge of the anthracnose pathogens and the epidemiology of anthracnose diseases has increased, so has our ability to control these diseases. Changes in cultural practices have resulted in reduced levels of disease. Simultaneously, the development of more effective fungicides and their registration for use on strawberries have significantly reduced losses due to both anthracnose crown rot and fruit rot. Anthracnose-resistant cultivars have also decreased economic losses caused by these diseases. Nevertheless, growers may still face severe losses when environmental conditions are highly favorable for anthracnose development.', 0.4576162099838257]]
Context 6: [['In vivo results showed varying incidences of anthracnose at different days after inoculation (DDI), with lower incidences (6.6-13.3%) noted for several treatments at 14 DDI. In contrast, higher incidences (19.9-33.3%) were recorded for others, indicating moderate efficacy. By 21 DDI, no increases in incidence were observed for some treatments, while others showed moderate levels of fungal presence (20-40%).', 0.40180787444114685]]
Context 7: [['Strandberg, J. O., Stamps, R. H., and Norman, D. J. 1996. Fern Anthracnose: A Guide for Effective Disease Management. University of Florida, Agricultural Experiment Station Technical Bulletin 900.', 0.2482648491859436]]
Context 8: [['Anthracnose spreads within a field through splashing water. Living mulches, such as wheat, rye, or rye grass, in row middles have been shown to reduce disease spread. Organic mulches like wheat straw or pine needles also reduce splash and result in a lower incidence of anthracnose compared to rows mulched with plastic (Coelho et al., 2008; Madden, 1992; Smith and Spiers, 1986). Additionally, anthracnose is less severe when water is supplied to plants using drip irrigation rather than overhead irrigation (Coelho et al., 2008; Madden, 1992; Smith and Spiers, 1986).', 0.24208781123161316]]
Context 9: [['Anthracnose spreads within a field by splashing water, and living mulches (such as wheat, rye, or ryegrass) in row middles have been shown to reduce disease spread within a field. Sublethal doses of grass-specific herbicides, such as sethoxydim, may be used to prevent excessive growth of ryegrass (Gupton, 2000). Organic mulches, such as wheat straw or pine needles, also reduce splash and result in a lower incidence of anthracnose compared to rows mulched with plastic (Madden, 1992; Smith and Spiers, 1986). Anthracnose is less severe when water is supplied to plants using drip irrigation rather than overhead irrigation (Madden, 1992; Smith and Spiers, 1986).', 0.23779430985450745]]

The genome analysis of Colletotrichum orbiculare is nearing completion, allowing for comparisons of genomic data across three Colletotrichum species: C. higginsianum, C. graminicola, and C. orbiculare, which belong to different phylogenetic clades within the genus. Context 1: [['Colletotrichum cuscutae is differentiated from other species by all studied genes except for ITS, most effectively by TUB2 and ACT. The closest matches for the TUB2 sequence (98% identity, 8 bp differences) were FN611029 and FN611028 from Citrus aurantifolia and Citrus sinensis in Florida, USA (Ramos et al. 2006), while the closest matches for the GAPDH sequence (98% identity, 4 bp differences) were EU168905, EU647318, and EU647319 from sweet orange (Peres et al. 2008, MacKenzie et al. 2009). query: What is the significance of the length-to-width ratio of appressoria in distinguishing between different strains of Colletotrichum?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Table Description: The table presents measurements of appressoria from various strains of Colletotrichum. It includes columns for species, accession numbers, appressoria dimensions on SNA (length × width in µm), and the corresponding length-to-width ratios. Each row provides specific data for different strains, such as CBS 128530, which has appressoria measuring between 9–14(–16.5) × 5–7.5(–9.5) µm, with a noted L/W ratio. The dimensions vary significantly across different strains, reflecting a range of morphological characteristics important for identification and classification within this genus. The measurements are noted with ranges and variances, illustrating the diversity present among the strains studied.', 0.9954197406768799]]
Context 1: [['(d) Yellow. A yellow isolate, similar to the one produced by G. cingulata, is occasionally obtained, although this is not found in field isolates. Some authors (Sutton, 1962) have suggested using the characteristics of the appressorium as one criterion for separating species of Colletotrichum. The size and shape of the appressoria formed by the species discussed here were briefly investigated, but the differences did not appear to be sufficient to warrant a more detailed examination. The mean length of the appressoria mostly ranged between 8 and 9 µm, with a mean breadth between 6.0 and 6.5 µm. The appressoria of C. atramentarium were somewhat larger, with a mean length of 11.3 µm, while those of C. musae were shorter, averaging 7.7 µm. The majority examined were more or less obovate, but in all species, a varying number of individuals were definitely lobed or angular. The appressoria of C. acutatum were generally more regular, whereas those of C. musae were less so.', 0.9684555530548096]]
Context 2: [['Observations and measurements of conidial size and shape have usually been made using conidial masses mounted in water, cotton blue, or lactic acid (Cannon et al., 2008). It should be noted that many species of Colletotrichum produce secondary conidia in culture directly from germinated primary conidia; these may vary morphologically when compared to those produced in conidiomata (Cannon et al., 2000). Conidial and mycelial appressoria (also referred to as hyphopodia) are often described in Colletotrichum species. Sutton (1980) characterized the mycelial appressoria formed in potato-carrot agar (PCA) using a slide culture technique, while others have used potato dextrose agar (PDA) with incubation in the dark (Johnston and Jones, 1997; Malloch, 1981) or have observed mycelial appressoria formed on the undersurface of SNA cultures (Damm et al., 2009). Conidial appressoria have been recorded when conidia are germinated in drops of deionized water on plastic cover slips in a moist chamber (Johnson et al., 1997; Chaky et al., 2001). Conidial appressoria are taxonomically uninformative and of little use for species diagnosis (Sutton, 1980, 1992). However, Du et al. (2005) noted that the shape of appressoria can differentiate C. acutatum (with rather smooth appressoria) from C. gloeosporioides (with more lobed appressoria). Crouch et al. (2009b) found that appressoria shape and size are useful for delimiting grass-associated Colletotrichum species but should be used in combination with host range. Yang et al. (2009) found that conidial appressoria can distinguish two species of Colletotrichum from Amaryllidaceae. The conidial appressoria of C. hippeastri are larger than those of C. hymenocallidis and are irregular, crenate, or lobed, occasionally becoming complex. In contrast, C. hymenocallidis appressoria are ovate or sometimes clavate.', 0.9066189527511597]]
Context 3: [['n=13.0±2.6×3.7±0.3μm, and the length/width (L/W) ratio is 3.5. Appressoria are found singly or in loose groups, are medium brown, smooth-walled, and can be subglobose, elliptical, or clavate, with edges that are either undulate or entire. Their dimensions range from (5–)6–11.5(–16.5) µm × (3.5–)5.5–7.5(–8.5) µm, with a mean ± SD of 8.8 ± 2.7 µm × 6.5 ± 1.1 µm, yielding an L/W ratio of 1.4. The strain CBS 502.97 forms smaller appressoria, measuring (3.5–)4.5–7.5(–10.5) × (3–)3.5–5(–5.5) µm, with a mean ± SD of 6.0 ± 1.7 µm × 4.2 ± 0.7 µm and an L/W ratio of 1.4.', 0.8385152220726013]]
Context 4: [['This table summarizes the measurements of appressoria on SNA for various species of the Colletotrichum acutatum complex. query: What environmental conditions favor the development of anthracnose?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['As our understanding of the anthracnose pathogens and the epidemiology of anthracnose diseases has improved, so has our capacity to control these diseases. Changes in cultural practices have led to reduced levels of disease. Additionally, the development and registration of more effective fungicides for use on strawberries have significantly decreased losses due to anthracnose crown rot and fruit rot. The introduction of partially resistant cultivars has also helped mitigate economic losses due to these diseases. Nonetheless, growers may still experience severe losses when environmental conditions are highly conducive to anthracnose development.', 0.9786887168884277]]
Context 1: [['Increased losses due to anthracnose fruit and crown rots may be related to the shift from matted-row culture to the annual plasticulture production system in the United States. This approach is environmentally sound because it results in reduced fungicide use. As our knowledge of the anthracnose pathogens and the epidemiology of anthracnose diseases has increased, so has our ability to control these diseases. Changes in cultural practices have resulted in reduced levels of disease. Simultaneously, the development of more effective fungicides and their registration for use on strawberries have significantly reduced losses due to both anthracnose crown rot and fruit rot. Context 3: [['Fungicides: Formulated products of natamycin (DelvoCid Instant; DSM, Heerlen, The Netherlands), azoxystrobin (Abound Flowable; Syngenta Crop Protection Inc., Greensboro, NC), chlorothalonil (Bravo Weather Stick; Syngenta Crop Protection Inc.), cyprodinil (Vangard 75WG; Syngenta Crop Protection Inc.), fludioxonil (Scholar 50WP; Syngenta Crop Protection Inc.), and pydiflumetofen (experimental product A19649B; Syngenta Crop Protection Inc.) were used on plants, either individually or in mixtures of fludioxonil and cyprodinil (Switch WG; Syngenta Crop Protection Inc.) or of pydiflumetofen and fludioxonil (experimental product A20560C; Syngenta Crop Protection Inc.). Additionally, the biological control agent S. lydicus WYEC 108 (minimum of 10^3 CFU/g of formulated product; Actinovate AG; Valent U.S.A. LLC, Walnut Creek, CA) was included in field trials. Aqueous solutions were used in all studies.', 0.1723375916481018]]
Context 4: [['Based on field trials in Florida (Mertely et al., 2009), the recommendation for anthracnose control involves weekly applications of a broad-spectrum protectant fungicide (captan) at the lowest label rate early in the season when conditions are less favorable for anthracnose development. Later, when anthracnose-infected flowers and fruit may be present, it is recommended to increase the rate of the protectant fungicide to the highest label rate. Warm, rainy weather in early spring often leads to epidemics, during which additional fungicides may be necessary. Growers are encouraged to scout their fields regularly for anthracnose symptoms, such as blighted flowers or black spots on green fruit. If symptoms are detected, the application of a strobilurin fungicide (such as Abound or Cabrio) in conjunction with the protectant fungicide is recommended. During the main bloom period, in late January and early February, fungicides containing two active ingredients (one for anthracnose control and one for Botrytis fruit rot control), such as CaptEvate, Pristine, or Switch, are advised. Tank mixes or higher rates of protectant fungicides should be maintained until the end of the harvest season or until dry weather effectively suppresses the disease.', 0.17165200412273407]]

Context 2: [['Anthracnose is a significant disease affecting grape crops (Dowling et al., 2020). Beyond causing severe yield losses, anthracnose epidemics can diminish the quality of the produce (Waller et al., 2002; Dowling et al., 2020). The most economically damaging symptoms often include blossom blight and fruit rots; however, necrotic lesions may also develop on leaves, stems, and twigs, leading to plant deterioration and reduced fruit quality (Dowling et al., 2020).', 0.18614786863327026]]
Context 3: [['Crouch, J.A., and Beirn, L.A. (2009). Anthracnose of cereals and grasses. Fungal Diversity 39: 19-44.', 0.18522004783153534]]
Context 4: [['Silva Pesqueira, A. D.; Arruda Bacchi, L. M.; Gavassoni, W. L. (2016). Associação de fungicidas no controle da antracnose da soja no Mato Grosso do Sul. Revista Ciencia Agronomica, 47(1), 203-212.', 0.17361168563365936]]
Context 5: [['Crouch J, Beirn LA. 2009. Anthracnose of cereals and grasses. Fungal Diversity 39:19–44.', 0.16224977374076843]]
Context 6: [['For the management of anthracnose crown rot, water washing or fungicide treatments of bare-root transplants have been utilized in the nursery or immediately before planting in production fields (Daugovish et al., 2009; Freeman et al., 1997). Running water effectively removes soil from root and crown tissues, potentially eliminating inoculum, but it does not control any infections already present (Koike et al., 2008). Pre-plant fungicide dips have been shown to decrease anthracnose crown rot; however, only two products are currently registered for this use in the United States. The single-site mode of action quinone outside inhibitor (QoI), azoxystrobin, has been widely used as a preplant dip and as a foliar treatment for managing anthracnose and other fungal diseases (Bartlett et al., 2002; Koike et al., 2008; Turechek et al., 2006). Resistance has been reported against this fungicide group in Colletotrichum acutatum populations from strawberries in Florida (Forcelini et al., 2016). During the 2015-16 California nursery crown rot outbreak, growers reported reduced efficacy of azoxystrobin dips, suggesting that resistance may also be present in California (K. Ivors, unpublished). A premixed product of the anilinopyrimidine cyprodinil and the phenylpyrrole fludioxonil is also registered, but phytotoxicity and stunting of plants have been reported under certain environmental conditions or following off-label exposure (G. Holmes, unpublished).', 0.15060576796531677]]
Context 7: [['Anthracnose spreads within a field by splashing water, and living mulches (such as wheat, rye, or ryegrass) in row middles have been shown to reduce disease spread within a field. Sublethal doses of grass-specific herbicides, such as sethoxydim, may be used to prevent excessive growth of ryegrass (Gupton, 2000). Organic mulches, such as wheat straw or pine needles, also reduce splash and result in a lower incidence of anthracnose compared to rows mulched with plastic (Madden, 1992; Smith and Spiers, 1986). Additionally, anthracnose is less severe when water is supplied to plants using drip irrigation rather than overhead irrigation (Madden, 1992; Smith and Spiers, 1986). Anthracnose crown rot was observed to be less severe in commercial fields when strawberries were grown in soils with low nitrogen fertility (Howard et al., 1992). In greenhouse studies, Smith (1987, 1989) determined that strawberries grown in soils with high levels of nitrogen, especially from ammonium sources, are more susceptible to anthracnose than plants grown in soils with lower nitrogen levels or those with high levels of calcium nitrate.', 0.1442394107580185]]
Context 8: [['Anthracnose spreads within a field through splashing water. Living mulches, such as wheat, rye, or rye grass, in row middles have been shown to reduce disease spread. Organic mulches like wheat straw or pine needles also reduce splash and result in a lower incidence of anthracnose compared to rows mulched with plastic (Coelho et al., 2008; Madden, 1992; Smith and Spiers, 1986). query: What do the infected parts of plants look like when Colletotrichum attacks?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Filamentous fungi of the genus Colletotrichum and its teleomorph Glomerella are considered major plant pathogens worldwide. They cause significant economic damage to crops in tropical, subtropical, and temperate regions. Cereals, legumes, ornamentals, vegetables, and fruit trees may be seriously affected by these pathogens. Although many cultivated fruit crops are infected by Colletotrichum species, the most significant economic losses occur when the fruiting stage is attacked. Colletotrichum species cause typical disease symptoms known as anthracnose, characterized by sunken necrotic tissue where orange conidial masses are produced. Anthracnose diseases can appear in both developing and mature plant tissues.', 0.9544260501861572]]
Context 1: [['Colletotrichum species are economically important plant pathogens, particularly in tropical, subtropical, and temperate regions, where they affect a wide range of plant hosts (Sutton 1992). The typical symptoms of Colletotrichum infections include sunken necrotic lesions, often bearing orange conidial masses, referred to as anthracnose (Freeman et al. 1998). The impact of these pathogens on fruit crops is significant, causing severe yield losses; for example, bitter rot is one of the most critical diseases affecting apple fruit, potentially leading to yield losses of up to 50% (Sutton 1990).', 0.8021645545959473]]
Context 2: [['Numerous cases have been reported in which several Colletotrichum species or biotypes are associated with a single host. For example, C. gloeosporioides (Penz.) Penz. & Sacc. in Penz. (teleomorph: Glomerella cingulata (Stoneman) Spauld. & H. Schrenk), which is considered a cumulative species and forms the sexual stage in some instances, is predominantly found as a postharvest disease affecting fruits such as avocado and mango. Strawberry may be infected by three Colletotrichum species: C. fragariae, C. acutatum, and C. gloeosporioides, causing anthracnose of fruit and other plant parts. Similarly, C. acutatum J.H. Simmonds has been reported to infect a large number of fruit crops, including avocado, strawberry, almond, apple, and peach. Citrus can be affected by four different Colletotrichum diseases: postbloom fruit drop and key lime anthracnose, both caused by C. acutatum, as well as shoot dieback and leaf spot, and postharvest fruit decay, both caused by C. gloeosporioides. Other species with multiple host ranges include C. coccodes, C. capsici, and C. dematium.', 0.7648187875747681]]
Context 3: [['The genus Colletotrichum represents a large number of economically important Ascomycete fungi that collectively cause anthracnose disease or leaf blights on significant agricultural crops and ornamental plants worldwide. Colletotrichum spp. often serve as models in studies ranging from pathogenic development and differentiation to plant-microbe interactions. During establishment and colonization of host plants, members of this genus uniquely acquire nutrients via both biotrophy and necrotrophy. Thus, in a single interaction, these fungal pathogens exhibit two modes of nutrient acquisition: initially, nutrients are acquired from living cells, after which a necrotrophic phase is initiated, allowing the same fungus to obtain nutrients from dead cells killed by the fungus. A given species of this genus can exhibit both strategies separately or concurrently. Additionally, these fungi develop a series of specialized infection-related structures, including germ tubes, appressoria, primary intracellular hyphae, and secondary necrotrophic hyphae. Therefore, Colletotrichum species are experimentally attractive organisms for studying the molecular, biochemical, and cellular basis of fungal pathogenicity, development, and signal transduction (see Bailey and Jeger, 1992; Prusky et al., 1999).', 0.5494120121002197]]
Context 4: [['Many species belonging to the genus Colletotrichum are associated with plant diseases, commonly referred to as anthracnose. Colletotrichum spp. can affect a wide range of hosts, and these pathogens are characterized by global distribution. Virtually every cultivated botanical family is susceptible to one or more species of Colletotrichum, making it one of the most studied plant pathogenic fungi (Prusky et al., 2000; Latunde-Dada, 2001; Dean et al., 2012). Common hosts include many dicotyledonous plants such as strawberry, apple, citrus, and stone fruits, as well as major cereals such as maize and sorghum. Members of this genus can cause crop losses of up to 100% in many staple foods (Bailey and Jeger, 1992; Prusky et al., 2000; Talhinhas et al., 2005; Cannon et al., 2012).', 0.5284136533737183]]
Context 5: [['Colletotrichum is one of the most important genera of plant pathogenic fungi, with many of the 200 plus species known to cause disease in crop plants worldwide (Alahakoon et al. 1994; Rojas et al. 2010; Cannon et al. 2012; Damm et al. 2012a, 2012b; Udayanga et al. 2013; Shivas et al. 2016; De Silva et al. 2017a).', 0.4718485176563263]]
Context 6: [['Latunde-Dada, A.O. (2001). Colletotrichum: Tales of forcible entry, stealth, transient confinement, and breakout. Molecular Plant Pathology 2: 187-198.', 0.32770806550979614]]

Context 1: [['Various studies highlight the significance of Colletotrichum species in agriculture. Crouch et al. (2009) discussed anthracnose disease caused by the novel species Colletotrichum navitas, while Damm et al. (2013) addressed the Colletotrichum orbiculare species complex, which affects field crops and weeds. Other works by Damm et al. (2012) explored the Colletotrichum acutatum and Colletotrichum boninense species complexes.', 0.5315945148468018]]
Context 2: [['The genus Colletotrichum is considered one of the top ten important genera of fungal pathogens globally (Dean et al., 2012). Colletotrichum is an ancient fungus that has co-evolved with flowering plants. Plant microfossils of Protocolletotrichum preserved on angiosperm leaf cuticles suggest that the diverse pathogenic strategies of Colletotrichum spp. have been established since the Late Cretaceous period (Kar et al., 2004). Different complexes within the genus may have diverged between 4.8 and 32.2 million years ago (MYA) (Bhunjun et al., 2021). The emergence of agricultural cultivation and the intensive disturbance of natural environments have further driven the diversification of Colletotrichum species. These fungi have adapted to thousands of hosts and can be found as endophytes, pathogens, and saprobes (Freeman et al., 1998; Dean et al., 2012; Hirayama et al., 2018; da Silva et al., 2020; Jayawardena et al., 2020). Currently, a total of 257 Colletotrichum species grouped into 15 complexes and 13 additional singletons have been accepted in this genus.', 0.441904217004776]]

query: What are the genetic differences between C. nymphaeae and C. godetiae?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['The strains detailed include multiple entries for Colletotrichum nymphaeae and Colletotrichum godetiae. For example, strain codes KM246541 to KM252146 are identified with the genetic identifiers such as ITS, TUB, MAT1-2, and GAPDH. These codes represent different genetic markers used for identification purposes.', 0.761168360710144]]
Context 1: [['Another possible synonym of C. nymphaeae is C. nymphaeicola (Kelkar 1972, as C. "nymphicola"). Judging from the description and illustration, this is certainly a species of Colletotrichum, but the conidia were described as oblong, measuring 5–15 × 1.5–3 µm. This wide variation in size makes it impossible to place it in any currently defined species. The type was reportedly deposited in HCIO, but apparently no cultures were obtained. Gloeosporium nymphaeae (Hemmi & Kawase 1954) causes symptoms similar to those of C. nymphaeae, but setae were observed, which were not noted in C. nymphaeae by either ourselves or van der Aa (1978). The conidia of Gm. nymphaeae were described as rounded at both ends, measuring 9–17 × 3–6 µm. We have not been able to locate type material or living cultures of this fungus. Another species of Colletotrichum associated with water lilies, C. nupharicola, was described by Johnson et al. (1997). This species appears to have significantly longer and wider conidia than C. nymphaeae, with mean widths of individual strains ranging between 6.5 and 7.5 µm. The figures are difficult to interpret, and the overall range of conidial size in the description is surprising. It has been found to belong within the C. gloeosporioides complex (Weir et al. 2012).', 0.6601583361625671]]
Context 2: [['Notes: Sequence data from the ex-holotype culture of C. nupharicola places it within the C. gloeosporioides complex, genetically close to C. fructicola and C. alienum in the Musae clade. This species appears to be host-specific and is characterized by slow growth in culture and large conidia (Johnson et al. 1997). Johnson et al. (1997) also compare C. nupharicola with another water plant pathogen, C. nymphaeae, which is epitypified and shown to belong to the C. acutatum species complex by Damm et al. (2012a, this issue).', 0.38218414783477783]]
Context 3: [['Morphological and Cultural Characterization: Few differences in colony morphology were observed among the five species identified when grown on potato dextrose agar (PDA). All selected isolates developed white colonies that turned gray after 10 days. Isolates of C. nymphaeae and C. gloeosporioides produced numerous conidia on PDA, while the other three species produced fewer conidia (Fig. 5). The conidia produced by C. nymphaeae were sharp at both ends (Fig. 6), which distinguished them from the other four species studied (Table 3).', 0.38195309042930603]]
Context 4: [['Johnson, D.A., Carris, L.M., & Rogers, J.D. (1997). Morphological and molecular characterization of Colletotrichum nymphaeae and C. nupharicola sp. nov. on water-lilies (Nymphaea and Nuphar). Mycological Research, 101, 641–649.', 0.2846856713294983]]
Context 5: [['Johnson, D. A., Carris, L. M., & Rogers, J. D. (1997). Morphological and molecular characterization of Colletotrichum nymphaeae and C. nupharicola sp. nov. on water-lilies (Nymphaea and Nuphar). Mycological Research, 101, 641–649.', 0.2793963551521301]]
Context 6: [['Johnson, D.A., Carris, L.M., and Rogers, J.D. (1997). Morphological and molecular characterization of Colletotrichum nymphaeae and C. nupharicola sp. nov. on water-lilies (Nymphaea and Nuphar). Mycological Research 101: 641-849.', 0.253683477640152]]
Context 7: [['These subclades show few base pair differences. We refrain from describing further species within C. nymphaeae. While the majority of the strains were identified as C. nymphaeae, other strains, including the newly described species C. paranaense and C. melonis, are part of a main clade within the C. acutatum species complex (indicated as main clade 1 in Damm et al. 2012). This clade comprises closely related species predominantly found on various hosts in Central and South America, distinguished primarily by GAPDH and TUB2 sequences. For instance, C. lupini was originally described as G. sorghicola. Some strains from apple in this study were identified as C. melonis and the new species, C. paranaense. ITS sequences place the remaining strains from apple in Brazil, as noted in Giaretta et al. (2012), in the same main clade, though species-level identification is not possible based solely on this data. No species in this clade was previously associated with diseases of apple, peach, or guava fruits, and none of the other four species of the C. acutatum complex reported by Damm et al. (2012) from other regions were found associated with apples in Brazil. The species composition of the C. acutatum complex linked to apple bitter rot in Brazil appears distinct from other global regions, which may be significant for plant quarantine.', 0.24143807590007782]]

query: How does the infection strategy of hemibiotrophic fungi like Colletotrichum species transition between biotrophic and necrotrophic phases?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['The genus Colletotrichum represents a large number of economically important Ascomycete fungi that collectively cause anthracnose disease or leaf blights on significant agricultural crops and ornamental plants worldwide. Colletotrichum spp. often serve as models in studies ranging from pathogenic development and differentiation to plant-microbe interactions. During establishment and colonization of host plants, members of this genus uniquely acquire nutrients via both biotrophy and necrotrophy. Thus, in a single interaction, these fungal pathogens exhibit two modes of nutrient acquisition: initially, nutrients are acquired from living cells, after which a necrotrophic phase is initiated, allowing the same fungus to obtain nutrients from dead cells killed by the fungus. A given species of this genus can exhibit both strategies separately or concurrently. Additionally, these fungi develop a series of specialized infection-related structures, including germ tubes, appressoria, primary intracellular hyphae, and secondary necrotrophic hyphae. Therefore, Colletotrichum species are experimentally attractive organisms for studying the molecular, biochemical, and cellular basis of fungal pathogenicity, development, and signal transduction (see Bailey and Jeger, 1992; Prusky et al., 1999).', 0.9925334453582764]]
Context 1: [['Bailey, J.A., et al. (1992). Infection strategies of Colletotrichum species. In: Colletotrichum: Biology, Pathology and Control (Eds. J.A. Bailey and M.J. Jeger). CAB International: Wallingford: 88-120.', 0.8336107134819031]]
Context 2: [['Bailey, J. A., O’Connell, R. J., Pring, R. J., and Nash, C. (1992). Infection strategies of Colletotrichum species. Pages 88-120 in: Colletotrichum: Biology, Pathology and Control. J. A. Bailey and M. J. Jeger, eds. CAB International, Wallingford, U.K.', 0.685460090637207]]
Context 3: [['Bailey, J. A., O’Connell, R. J., Pring, R. J., and Nash, C. 1992. Infection strategies of Colletotrichum species. Pages 88-120 in: Colletotrichum: Biology, Pathology and Control. J. A. Bailey and M. J. Jeger, eds. CAB International, Wallingford, U.K.', 0.6786282658576965]]
Context 4: [['The genus Colletotrichum is considered one of the top ten important genera of fungal pathogens globally (Dean et al., 2012). Colletotrichum is an ancient fungus that has co-evolved with flowering plants. Plant microfossils of Protocolletotrichum preserved on angiosperm leaf cuticles suggest that the diverse pathogenic strategies of Colletotrichum spp. have been established since the Late Cretaceous period (Kar et al., 2004). Different complexes within the genus may have diverged between 4.8 and 32.2 million years ago (MYA) (Bhunjun et al., 2021). The emergence of agricultural cultivation and the intensive disturbance of natural environments have further driven the diversification of Colletotrichum species. These fungi have adapted to thousands of hosts and can be found as endophytes, pathogens, and saprobes (Freeman et al., 1998; Dean et al., 2012; Hirayama et al., 2018; da Silva et al., 2020; Jayawardena et al., 2020). Currently, a total of 257 Colletotrichum species grouped into 15 complexes and 13 additional singletons have been accepted in this genus.', 0.5599660873413086]]
Context 5: [['Citation: Cai, L., Hyde, K.D., Taylor, P.W.J., Weir, B.S., Waller, J., Abang, M.M., Zhang, J.Z., Yang, Y.L., Phoulivong, S., Liu, Z.Y., Prihastuti, H., Shivas, R.G., McKenzie, E.H.C., Johnston, P.R. (2009). A polyphasic approach for studying Colletotrichum. Fungal Diversity, 39: 183-204.', 0.4934443235397339]]
Context 6: [['Damm, U., Baroncelli, R., Cai, L., Kubo, Y., O’Connell, R., Weir, B., Yoshino, K., and Cannon, P. F. 2010. Colletotrichum: Species, ecology, and interactions. IMA Fungus 1:161-165.', 0.4288537800312042]]
Context 7: [['Filamentous fungi of the genus Colletotrichum and its teleomorph Glomerella are considered major plant pathogens worldwide. They cause significant economic damage to crops in tropical, subtropical, and temperate regions. Cereals, legumes, ornamentals, vegetables, and fruit trees may be seriously affected by these pathogens. Although many cultivated fruit crops are infected by Colletotrichum species, the most significant economic losses occur when the fruiting stage is attacked. Colletotrichum species cause typical disease symptoms known as anthracnose, characterized by sunken necrotic tissue where orange conidial masses are produced. Anthracnose diseases can appear in both developing and mature plant tissues.', 0.400629460811615]]
Context 8: [['Cai, L., Hyde, K.D., Taylor, P.W.J., Weir, B., Waller, J., Abang, M.M., Zhang, J.Z., Yang, Y.L., Phoulivong, S., Liu, Z.Y., Prihastuti, H., Shivas, R.G., McKenzie, E.H.C., and Johnston, P.R. query: Is it possible to prevent anthracnose from occurring in the first place?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Anthracnose spreads within a field by splashing water, and living mulches (such as wheat, rye, or ryegrass) in row middles have been shown to reduce disease spread within a field. Sublethal doses of grass-specific herbicides, such as sethoxydim, may be used to prevent excessive growth of ryegrass (Gupton, 2000). Organic mulches, such as wheat straw or pine needles, also reduce splash and result in a lower incidence of anthracnose compared to rows mulched with plastic (Madden, 1992; Smith and Spiers, 1986). Additionally, anthracnose is less severe when water is supplied to plants using drip irrigation rather than overhead irrigation (Madden, 1992; Smith and Spiers, 1986). Anthracnose crown rot was observed to be less severe in commercial fields when strawberries were grown in soils with low nitrogen fertility (Howard et al., 1992). In greenhouse studies, Smith (1987, 1989) determined that strawberries grown in soils with high levels of nitrogen, especially from ammonium sources, are more susceptible to anthracnose than plants grown in soils with lower nitrogen levels or those with high levels of calcium nitrate.', 0.2444653958082199]]
Context 1: [['Strandberg, J. O., Stamps, R. H., and Norman, D. J. 1996. Fern Anthracnose: A Guide for Effective Disease Management. University of Florida, Agricultural Experiment Station Technical Bulletin 900.', 0.2193915843963623]]
Context 2: [['Urdaneta, L., Sanabria, M., Rodríguez, D., & Pérez de Camacaro, M. (2013). Antracnosis causada por Colletotrichum spp. Investigación Agraria, 20(1), 38-50.', 0.21757158637046814]]
Context 3: [['Anthracnose is a significant disease affecting grape crops (Dowling et al., 2020). Beyond causing severe yield losses, anthracnose epidemics can diminish the quality of the produce (Waller et al., 2002; Dowling et al., 2020). The most economically damaging symptoms often include blossom blight and fruit rots; however, necrotic lesions may also develop on leaves, stems, and twigs, leading to plant deterioration and reduced fruit quality (Dowling et al., 2020).', 0.21511560678482056]]
Context 4: [['Until highly resistant cultivars are available, growers must rely on chemical applications and cultural practices to reduce losses due to anthracnose. The failure of fungicides to control anthracnose epidemics may be due to the development of fungicide resistance in the Colletotrichum spp. population. For example, benomyl effectively reduced the incidence of anthracnose crown rot (Horn et al., 1972; Howard, 1971) and was used intensively by strawberry growers for years to control anthracnose and other diseases. However, the anthracnose pathogens, C. acutatum and C. fragariae, developed resistance to it and other benzimidazole fungicides (LaMondia, 1995; McInnes et al., 1992a; Smith and Black, 1992, 1993), rendering benomyl ineffective for anthracnose control in strawberry fields.', 0.2051457315683365]]
Context 5: [['Additional Keywords: anthracnose, disease spread, Fragaria × ananassa, models, quantitative epidemiology.', 0.20422859489917755]]
Context 6: [['Bergstrom, G. C., and Nicholson, R. L. 1999. The biology of corn anthracnose: Knowledge to exploit for improved management. Plant Dis. 83:596-608.', 0.203761026263237]]
Context 7: [['Hemmi, T. (1920). Kurze Mitteilung über drei Fälle von Anthracnose auf Pflanzen. Annals of the Phytopathological Society of Japan, 1(3), 13–21.', 0.20106764137744904]]
Context 8: [['As our understanding of the anthracnose pathogens and the epidemiology of anthracnose diseases has improved, so has our capacity to control these diseases. Changes in cultural practices have led to reduced levels of disease. Additionally, the development and registration of more effective fungicides for use on strawberries have significantly decreased losses due to anthracnose crown rot and fruit rot. The introduction of partially resistant cultivars has also helped mitigate economic losses due to these diseases. Nonetheless, growers may still experience severe losses when environmental conditions are highly conducive to anthracnose development.', 0.19936200976371765]]
Context 9: [['As our knowledge of the anthracnose pathogens and the epidemiology of anthracnose diseases has increased, so has our ability to control these diseases. Changes in cultural practices have resulted in reduced levels of disease. Additionally, the development and registration of more effective fungicides for use on strawberries have significantly reduced losses from both anthracnose crown rot and fruit rot. Anthracnose-resistant cultivars have also diminished economic losses due to these diseases. Nevertheless, growers may still experience severe losses when environmental factors are highly favorable for anthracnose development.', 0.19232921302318573]]

query: What is the primary pathogen causing anthracnose fruit rot in strawberries in Iran?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Anthracnose is an important disease of strawberry caused by Colletotrichum spp., which affects foliage, runners, crowns, and fruits (Howard et al., 1992). Three primary fungal pathogens—C. acutatum sensu lato, C. gloeosporioides sensu lato, and C. fragariae—are known to cause anthracnose disease in strawberries (Freeman and Katan, 1997). The crown rot syndrome is characteristic of infections from C. gloeosporioides sensu lato and C. fragariae, while fruit rot is mainly attributed to C. acutatum sensu lato, leading to significant yield losses (Howard et al., 1992). Currently, numerous species are classified under what is now known as the C. acutatum complex, with six species—C. acutatum sensu stricto, C. fioriniae, C. godetiae, C. nymphaeae, C. salicis, and C. simmondsii—identified as associated with strawberry anthracnose worldwide (Damm et al., 2012). Among these, C. nymphaeae is the most prevalent pathogen causing strawberry anthracnose globally, including in Iran (Baroncelli et al., 2015; Karimi et al., 2017; Wang et al., 2019). Currently, no effective chemical control methods exist for managing strawberry anthracnose; available options are limited to preventive treatments applied before fruit production (Denoyes-Rothan et al., 1999). Additionally, concerns about the toxic effects of chemical fungicides on the environment and the development of resistance in fungal strains highlight the need for alternative control strategies. Consequently, utilizing resistant cultivars appears to be the most efficient and practical approach for suppressing anthracnose development. In light of recent anthracnose outbreaks in strawberry fields in the Kurdistan province of Iran (Karimi et al., 2017), and the necessity for appropriate strategies to address this issue, the aim of this study was to evaluate the resistance of several commercial strawberry cultivars to the anthracnose fruit rot caused by C. nymphaeae under in vivo and greenhouse conditions.', 0.9977514147758484]]
Context 1: [['The term "anthracnose" was first used to describe a new disease of strawberries caused by Colletotrichum fragariae Brooks. "Strawberry anthracnose" continues to be used as a general term to identify all diseases of strawberries caused by species of Colletotrichum. Strawberry anthracnose diseases have been reported to be caused by C. acutatum J.H. Simmonds, C. gloeosporioides (Penz.) Penz. & Sacc. in Penz. (the teleomorph of Cromereilla cingulata (Stoneman) Spauld. & H. Schrenk), and C. dematium (Pers.) Grove. The latter species only occasionally causes strawberry fruit rots and will not be discussed here.', 0.8142701387405396]]

query: Are there specific Colletotrichum species that have been identified as the primary threats to citrus production in Europe, and how are they managed?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [["The citrus industry is one of the most significant fruit sectors globally. The Mediterranean countries rank second only to China in fruit production and are the largest fruit exporters after South Africa (FAO 2016). Therefore, understanding all pathogens affecting this crop is imperative. The current study aimed to investigate the major citrus production areas in Europe through large-scale sampling and to identify isolates using a polyphasic approach. This method revealed many cryptic and new Colletotrichum species associated with citrus, classified into four modern taxonomic species complexes. Surveys conducted in 2015 and 2016 across commercial nurseries, orchards, gardens, and plant collections aimed to determine the occurrence of Colletotrichum spp. related to citrus and allied genera (Atlantia, Fortunella, Microcitrus, Murraya, Poncirus). The study's specific objectives included conducting extensive sampling of fresh plant materials, cultivating Colletotrichum isolates, subjecting these isolates to DNA sequence analyses alongside morphological characterization, comparing results with other phylogenetic studies, and evaluating the pathogenicity of Colletotrichum species on citrus fruit. Major diseases of citrus caused by Colletotrichum species include postbloom fruit drop (PFD), petal necrosis, and key lime anthracnose (KLA), with C. abscissum and C. gloeosporioides being significant agents. Extensive investigations across several citrus-producing regions revealed varying associations of these pathogens with different citrus species.", 0.9893691539764404]]
Context 1: [['Species of Colletotrichum are recognized as significant plant pathogens, saprobes, and endophytes across a variety of plant hosts. Several species are notably problematic for citrus, causing pre- and post-harvest infections such as anthracnose, postbloom fruit drop, tear stain, and stem-end rot, as well as wither-tip on twigs. This study utilized multi-locus sequence typing to investigate the occurrence, diversity, and pathogenicity of Colletotrichum spp. associated with citrus and allied genera in European orchards, nurseries, and gardens. Surveys were conducted in Greece, Italy, Malta, Portugal, and Spain during 2015 and 2016, resulting in the isolation of 174 Colletotrichum strains from symptomatic leaves, fruits, petals, and twigs. A multi-locus phylogeny was constructed based on seven genomic loci (ITS, GAPDH, ACT, CAL, CHS-1, HIS3, and TUB2), and the morphological characteristics of the isolates were assessed. Preliminary pathogenicity tests were performed on orange fruits using representative isolates. The Colletotrichum strains were classified into three major species complexes. Within the C. gloeosporioides species complex, C. gloeosporioides s.str., and two novel species (C. helleniense and C. hystricis) were identified. In the C. boninense species complex, C. karstii, C. novae-zelandiae, and two novel species (C. catinaense and C. limonicola) were noted, while C. acutatum s.str. was identified as a member of the C. acutatum species complex. C. gloeosporioides and C. karstii were the predominant species isolated. This study represents the first report of C. acutatum on citrus.', 0.9799598455429077]]
Context 2: [['Guarnaccia, V., Groenewald, J. Z., Polizzi, G., & Crous, P. W. (2017). High species diversity in Colletotrichum associated with citrus diseases in Europe. Persoonia, 39, 32-50.', 0.7604678273200989]]
Context 3: [['Guarnaccia V, Groenewald JZ, Polizzi G, et al. 2017. High species diversity in Colletotrichum associated with citrus diseases in Europe. Persoonia 39: 32–50.', 0.7040240168571472]]
Context 4: [['Recently, infections caused by Colletotrichum spp. have severely compromised citrus production in different Mediterranean countries. Heavy pre-harvest anthracnose symptoms were observed on orange fruits and lesions on mandarin leaves in Italy (Aiello et al. 2015, Perrone et al. 2016). Twig wither-tip symptoms were noted on cultivated orange trees in Tunisia (Rhaiem & Taylor 2016), and severe anthracnose symptoms were recorded on unripe and ripe lemon fruits in Portugal (Ramos et al. 2016).', 0.42509132623672485]]
Context 5: [['Kaur R, Rewal HS, Sethi A. (2007). Pre-harvest stem-end rot in citrus cultivars due to Colletotrichum gloeosporioides. European Journal of Horticultural Science, 72, 20–25.', 0.22239188849925995]]
Context 6: [['Colletotrichum spp. are frequently linked with various citrus diseases worldwide, including PFD (Post Fruit Drop) on sweet orange, KLA (Kumquat Leaf Anthracnose), and post-harvest anthracnose across different hosts.', 0.21465647220611572]]

Context 8: [['Timmer, L. W., and Brown, G. E. 2000. Biology and control of anthracnose diseases of citrus. Pages 300-316 in: Host Specificity, Pathology, and Host-Pathogen Interactions of Colletotrichum. D. Prusky, S. Freeman, and M. P. Dickman, eds. query: How does the association of Colletotrichum godetiae with Clarkia hybrida cv. Kelvedon Glory inform its original classification?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Notes: Colletotrichum godetiae was described from seeds of Clarkia (syn. Godetia) hybrida cv. Kelvedon Glory by Neergard (1943) and validated with a Latin description seven years later (Neergard 1950). Colletotrichum godetiae corresponds to the C. acutatum group A4 as recognized by Sreenivasaprasad & Talhinhas (2005) and to part of clade F as defined by Guerber et al. (2003). According to Sreenivasaprasad & Talhinhas (2005), group A4 corresponds to group B from New Zealand (Lardner et al. 1999). However, the only C. acutatum group B strain from New Zealand that we have studied belongs to C. acerbum (A6-2). Faedda et al. (2011) described strains from group A4 that cause olive anthracnose in Italy as C. clavatum, not knowing that an older name for this species exists, of which the ex-holotype culture is available in the CBS culture collection. The ex-holo- and ex-paratype strains are included in this study (Fig. 1). Von Arx (1957) regarded C. godetiae as a synonym of Colletotrichum guajavae Damm, P.F. Cannon & Crous, sp. nov. MycoBank MB800501. Fig. 12.', 0.9957053065299988]]

query: What are the challenges of distinguishing between closely related Colletotrichum species in agricultural research?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['In a drastic move, von Arx (1957) reduced the number of recognized Colletotrichum species from several hundred to 11 based on morphological characteristics, with many taxa treated as synonyms of C. gloeosporioides and C. dematium. Several additional species have since been accepted based on morphological criteria (Sutton, 1980; 1992). The difficulties in recognizing Colletotrichum species can be attributed to: 1) the limited and variable morphological characters; 2) an extensive host range and variability in pathogenicity (Bailey and Jeger, 1992; Freeman et al., 2000; Latunde-Dada, 2001; Du et al., 2005; Thaung, 2008); 3) type specimens that are often missing or in poor condition, making them unsuitable for molecular studies; and 4) numerous rDNA ITS sequences of Colletotrichum strains in NCBI that are often misidentified (Crouch et al., 2009d; Damm et al., 2009).', 0.9172061681747437]]
Context 1: [['Despite significant developments over the last ten years, the taxonomy of Colletotrichum is in a state of flux. Many uncertainties exist in the systematics of fungal pathogens from this genus; depending on the taxonomic "guides," the number of species can range from 29 to over 700 (von Arx, 1957; Sutton, 1992). One of the most confusing species is C. gloeosporioides. For example, 594 species of Colletotrichum were reclassified by von Arx as synonyms of C. gloeosporioides. Identification has primarily relied on morphological characteristics of conidia, vegetative and sexual structures, as well as host specificity and cultural characteristics (von Arx, 1957). Unfortunately, conidial morphology and colony characteristics vary even within isolates. Consequently, classical methods have been supplemented with biochemical and molecular technologies to differentiate Colletotrichum species (J. W. Kronstad, ed., Fungal Pathology, 127-148. © 2000 Kluwer Academic Publishers). For a more complete discussion of this topic, see Sherriff et al. (1994).', 0.5830112099647522]]
Context 2: [['The genus Colletotrichum is considered one of the top ten important genera of fungal pathogens globally (Dean et al., 2012). Colletotrichum is an ancient fungus that has co-evolved with flowering plants. Plant microfossils of Protocolletotrichum preserved on angiosperm leaf cuticles suggest that the diverse pathogenic strategies of Colletotrichum spp. have been established since the Late Cretaceous period (Kar et al., 2004). Different complexes within the genus may have diverged between 4.8 and 32.2 million years ago (MYA) (Bhunjun et al., 2021). The emergence of agricultural cultivation and the intensive disturbance of natural environments have further driven the diversification of Colletotrichum species. These fungi have adapted to thousands of hosts and can be found as endophytes, pathogens, and saprobes (Freeman et al., 1998; Dean et al., 2012; Hirayama et al., 2018; da Silva et al., 2020; Jayawardena et al., 2020). Currently, a total of 257 Colletotrichum species grouped into 15 complexes and 13 additional singletons have been accepted in this genus.', 0.5789498090744019]]

query: Why is it important to correctly identify Colletotrichum species?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['In a drastic move, von Arx (1957) reduced the number of recognized Colletotrichum species from several hundred to 11 based on morphological characteristics, with many taxa treated as synonyms of C. gloeosporioides and C. dematium. Several additional species have since been accepted based on morphological criteria (Sutton, 1980; 1992). The difficulties in recognizing Colletotrichum species can be attributed to: 1) the limited and variable morphological characters; 2) an extensive host range and variability in pathogenicity (Bailey and Jeger, 1992; Freeman et al., 2000; Latunde-Dada, 2001; Du et al., 2005; Thaung, 2008); 3) type specimens that are often missing or in poor condition, making them unsuitable for molecular studies; and 4) numerous rDNA ITS sequences of Colletotrichum strains in NCBI that are often misidentified (Crouch et al., 2009d; Damm et al., 2009).', 0.9707913398742676]]
Context 1: [['Colletotrichum is one of the most important genera of plant pathogenic fungi worldwide, causing disease symptoms commonly known as anthracnose on a wide range of important crops, fruits, and ornamental plants (Bailey et al., 1992). Notable species include Colletotrichum lindemuthianum, C. gloeosporioides, C. acutatum, C. falcatum, C. nupharicola, and C. nymphaeae. Some plant pathogenic species are significant for quarantine because they could be introduced into regions where the disease is not present (Farr et al., 2006). The taxonomy and phylogeny of the genus Colletotrichum remain confusing (Hyde et al., 2009; Cai et al., 2009). Historically, if anthracnose was found on a host for which there were no prior records of that fungus-host relationship, the species was interpreted as new and formally described (Cannon et al., 2000). This practice was later rejected (von Arx, 1957; Sutton, 1980; Baxter et al., 1983), yet new species are still occasionally described in Colletotrichum (Sivanesan et al., 1993; Nakanura et al., 2006; Liu et al., 2007). Currently, more than 688 epithets are listed in Index Fungorum (www.indexfungorum.org/names/names.asp). Based on a morphological study, von Arx (1957) included more than 600 synonyms under C. gloeosporioides and 84 synonyms under C. dematium. Sutton (1992) listed 39 accepted species in Colletotrichum, each with a brief description. In recent years, molecular tools have been used to infer the evolutionary relationships of Colletotrichum species. Some species have been segregated from the C. gloeosporioides complex based on nu-rDNA ITS sequence data and morphological characteristics, such as C. boninense.', 0.9578871726989746]]
Context 2: [['Despite significant developments over the last ten years, the taxonomy of Colletotrichum is in a state of flux. Many uncertainties exist in the systematics of fungal pathogens from this genus; depending on the taxonomic "guides," the number of species can range from 29 to over 700 (von Arx, 1957; Sutton, 1992). One of the most confusing species is C. gloeosporioides. For example, 594 species of Colletotrichum were reclassified by von Arx as synonyms of C. gloeosporioides. Identification has primarily relied on morphological characteristics of conidia, vegetative and sexual structures, as well as host specificity and cultural characteristics (von Arx, 1957). Unfortunately, conidial morphology and colony characteristics vary even within isolates. Consequently, classical methods have been supplemented with biochemical and molecular technologies to differentiate Colletotrichum species (J. W. Kronstad, ed., Fungal Pathology, 127-148. © 2000 Kluwer Academic Publishers). For a more complete discussion of this topic, see Sherriff et al. (1994).', 0.9202420115470886]]
Context 3: [['The genus Colletotrichum is considered one of the top ten important genera of fungal pathogens globally (Dean et al., 2012). Colletotrichum is an ancient fungus that has co-evolved with flowering plants. Plant microfossils of Protocolletotrichum preserved on angiosperm leaf cuticles suggest that the diverse pathogenic strategies of Colletotrichum spp. have been established since the Late Cretaceous period (Kar et al., 2004). Different complexes within the genus may have diverged between 4.8 and 32.2 million years ago (MYA) (Bhunjun et al., 2021). The emergence of agricultural cultivation and the intensive disturbance of natural environments have further driven the diversification of Colletotrichum species. These fungi have adapted to thousands of hosts and can be found as endophytes, pathogens, and saprobes (Freeman et al., 1998; Dean et al., 2012; Hirayama et al., 2018; da Silva et al., 2020; Jayawardena et al., 2020). Currently, a total of 257 Colletotrichum species grouped into 15 complexes and 13 additional singletons have been accepted in this genus.', 0.9183683395385742]]
Context 4: [['Much has been written about various individual species of Colletotrichum, yet in many cases, the name used represents a species complex, and it is unclear which actual species is involved. In the following section, we review three species of Colletotrichum to highlight the problems associated with inadequate knowledge of the species and potential incorrect or inaccurate naming.', 0.7068358063697815]]
Context 5: [['Cano, J., Guarro, J., and Gene, J. (2004). Molecular and morphological identification of Colletotrichum species of clinical interest. Journal of Clinical Microbiology 42: 2450-2454.', 0.6103619933128357]]
Context 6: [['The name Colletotrichum was first introduced by Tode (1790) under the genus Vermicularia. The genus Colletotrichum itself was established by Corda (1831) and is now recognized as comprising “coelomycetes” with a Glomerella teleomorph stage (Sutton, 1992; Shenoy et al., 2007a; Hyde et al., 2009). This genus includes species with endophytic, epiphytic, saprobic, and phytopathogenic lifestyles (Kumar and Hyde, 2004; Photita et al., 2001a,b).', 0.5923771858215332]]
Context 7: [['Citation: Cai, L., Hyde, K.D., Taylor, P.W.J., Weir, B.S., Waller, J., Abang, M.M., Zhang, J.Z., Yang, Y.L., Phoulivong, S., Liu, Z.Y., Prihastuti, H., Shivas, R.G., McKenzie, E.H.C., Johnston, P.R. (2009). A polyphasic approach for studying Colletotrichum. Fungal Diversity, 39: 183-204.', 0.5816161036491394]]
