query: What are the typical symptoms of anthracnose caused by Colletotrichum?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Colletotrichum is one of the most important genera of plant pathogenic fungi worldwide, causing disease symptoms commonly known as anthracnose on a wide range of important crops, fruits, and ornamental plants (Bailey et al., 1992). Notable species include Colletotrichum lindemuthianum, C. gloeosporioides, C. acutatum, C. falcatum, C. nupharicola, and C. nymphaeae. Some plant pathogenic species are significant for quarantine because they could be introduced into regions where the disease is not present (Farr et al., 2006). The taxonomy and phylogeny of the genus Colletotrichum remain confusing (Hyde et al., 2009; Cai et al., 2009). Historically, if anthracnose was found on a host for which there were no prior records of that fungus-host relationship, the species was interpreted as new and formally described (Cannon et al., 2000). This practice was later rejected (von Arx, 1957; Sutton, 1980; Baxter et al., 1983), yet new species are still occasionally described in Colletotrichum (Sivanesan et al., 1993; Nakanura et al., 2006; Liu et al., 2007). Currently, more than 688 epithets are listed in Index Fungorum (www.indexfungorum.org/names/names.asp). Based on a morphological study, von Arx (1957) included more than 600 synonyms under C. gloeosporioides and 84 synonyms under C. dematium. Sutton (1992) listed 39 accepted species in Colletotrichum, each with a brief description. In recent years, molecular tools have been used to infer the evolutionary relationships of Colletotrichum species. Some species have been segregated from the C. gloeosporioides complex based on nu-rDNA ITS sequence data and morphological characteristics, such as C. boninense.', 0.9959724545478821]]
Context 1: [['Colletotrichum species are primarily recognized as the causal agents of anthracnose, which occurs on various plant parts, including leaves, stems, flowers, and fruits. The disease cycles of anthracnose on different hosts exhibit similar components (Peres et al., 2005; De Silva et al., 2017); they are typically polycyclic, with splash-borne asexual spores (conidia) initiating and spreading epidemics. Other Colletotrichum-related diseases include crown rot in strawberries and black dot disease on the roots of tomatoes and potatoes (Dillard and Cobb, 1997; Dillard and Cobb, 1998; Waller et al., 2002). Additionally, Colletotrichum species can cause post-harvest diseases, particularly in avocado, almond, and citrus fruits (Prusky, 1996; Ismail and Zhang, 2004; Prusky et al., 2013). In these cases, the pathogens form infection structures (appressoria) on the host but remain dormant within the fruit until after harvest, during which symptoms may emerge (Ismail and Zhang, 2004; Prusky et al., 2013). Several studies have indicated that species within a clade exhibit similar colonization and infection behaviors, with the establishment of quiescence being host- and tissue-specific (Sanders and Korsten, 2003; Damm et al., 2012; Weir et al., 2012; Prusky et al., 2013; Jayawardena et al., 2016; Zakaria, 2021). Furthermore, species within clades have comparable temperature requirements for mycelial growth, conidial germination, infection, and spore production (Salotti et al., 2022). For example, species such as C. gloeosporioides, C. fragariae, C. gossypii, and C. musaebelonging to the gloeosporioides clade show optimum temperatures for mycelial growth, sporulation, conidial germination, and infection between 25 and 32°C (Salotti et al., 2022).', 0.9926034808158875]]
Context 2: [['Abstract: In tropical fruit crops, anthracnose is primarily caused by species of the fungal genus Colletotrichum. These phytopathogens can infect various parts of the fruit crops; however, infections occurring during postharvest or ripening stages lead to significant economic losses. The disease manifests as black to dark brown sunken lesions on the fruit surface, which diminishes fruit quality and marketability. Common tropical fruit crops susceptible to anthracnose include mango, papaya, banana, avocado, guava, and dragon fruit, all of which are economically important in many developing countries. It is essential to note that newly identified Colletotrichum species associated with fruit anthracnose can infect multiple hosts, though some species may exhibit host specificity. Utilizing multiple markers, many phylogenetic species of Colletotrichum have been recognized as anthracnose-causing pathogens. Given that effective disease management strategies depend on a comprehensive understanding of the causative agents, up-to-date information regarding Colletotrichum species and the risks posed by newly identified species in tropical fruit plantations and harvested fruits is crucial. Furthermore, these newly recorded species may be significant for biosecurity and should be classified as quarantine pathogens, particularly as tropical fruits are traded globally.', 0.9856663346290588]]
Context 3: [["Three species have been documented as causal agents of strawberry anthracnose: Colletotrichum gloeosporioides, C. fragariae, and C. acutatum (Denoyes-Rothan et al. 2003). The anthracnose disease caused by Colletotrichum spp. impacts a wide variety of woody and herbaceous plants, particularly tropical and subtropical crops and fruit trees (Cannon et al. 2012; Freeman et al. 1998; Hyde et al. 2009; Sutton 1992; Wikee et al. 2011). The genus has recently been recognized as the world's eighth most important group of plant-pathogenic fungi due to its scientific and economic significance (Dean et al. 2012). However, the identification of Colletotrichum spp. has historically been challenging. Single-gene phylogenetic analyses have often failed to accurately delineate species (Hyde et al. 2009). Ko Ko et al. (2011) emphasized the need to resurvey plant pathogens like Colletotrichum spp. using molecular methods, as previous morphological and internal transcribed spacer data are likely to be incorrect. Understanding of Colletotrichum spp. has significantly advanced through these molecular approaches.", 0.9745328426361084]]
Context 4: [['Colletotrichum spp. often cause anthracnose disease in herbaceous or woody plants in tropical and subtropical regions (Cannon et al. 2012). The genus Colletotrichum is one of the eight major plant pathogens worldwide (Dean et al. 2012). Three species or species complexes of Colletotrichum have been reported to cause anthracnose in strawberries: the Colletotrichum gloeosporioides complex, Colletotrichum fragariae, and the Colletotrichum acutatum complex (Denoyes-Rothan et al. 2003). The C. gloeosporioides complex is found worldwide and has a wide range of hosts, whereas C. acutatum and C. fragariae have narrower host ranges (MacKenzie et al. 2008). Although a few C. acutatum infections in Chinese strawberries have been reported, the primary species affecting strawberries in China are believed to be C. gloeosporioides and C. fragariae (Buddie et al. 1999; Han et al. 2016).', 0.9647898077964783]]
Context 5: [['Many species belonging to the genus Colletotrichum are associated with plant diseases, commonly referred to as anthracnose. Colletotrichum spp. can affect a wide range of hosts, and these pathogens are characterized by global distribution. Virtually every cultivated botanical family is susceptible to one or more species of Colletotrichum, making it one of the most studied plant pathogenic fungi (Prusky et al., 2000; Latunde-Dada, 2001; Dean et al., 2012). Common hosts include many dicotyledonous plants such as strawberry, apple, citrus, and stone fruits, as well as major cereals such as maize and sorghum. Members of this genus can cause crop losses of up to 100% in many staple foods (Bailey and Jeger, 1992; Prusky et al., 2000; Talhinhas et al., 2005; Cannon et al., 2012).', 0.9637293815612793]]
Context 6: [['Colletotrichum is a genus of fungi that often causes anthracnose disease. In Japan and elsewhere, strawberry anthracnose has been attributed to infections by Colletotrichum gloeosporioides, which caused at least one major epidemic of anthracnose crown rot in the United States during the 1970s (Smith 2008; Suzuki et al. 2010). Anthracnose disease is a major problem in the Japanese strawberry cultivation industry, where infections are thought to be spread primarily through latently infected plants and infected plant material (Suzuki et al. 2010). The presence of even one infected plant can result in the infection of an entire field, highlighting the importance of early detection and classification.', 0.9577197432518005]]
Context 7: [['Y.-Z. Diao et al.: Colletotrichum causing anthracnose disease.', 0.9416853189468384]]
Context 8: [['Diao, Y.-Z., et al. (2014). Colletotrichum causing anthracnose disease.', 0.9377748370170593]]
Context 9: [['Urdaneta, L., Sanabria, M., Rodríguez, D., & Pérez de Camacaro, M. (2013). Antracnosis causada por Colletotrichum spp. Investigación Agraria, 20(1), 38-50.', 0.9219856262207031]]

query: What are the primary methods used to identify pathogens causing anthracnose?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Accurate identification and scientific naming of anthracnose pathogens are crucial because precise taxonomic information allows us to classify a given species as a pathogen, saprophyte, or endophyte. The species involved in anthracnose affecting tropical fruits may exhibit different characteristics, emphasizing the importance of proper identification of the causative pathogen for effective disease management.', 0.790531575679779]]
Context 1: [['Increased losses due to anthracnose fruit and crown rots may be related to the shift from matted-row culture to the annual plasticulture production system in the United States. Breeding for genetic resistance to anthracnose and the development of resistant cultivars are primary means for reducing economic losses due to this disease. This approach is environmentally sound because it results in reduced fungicide use. As our knowledge of the anthracnose pathogens and the epidemiology of anthracnose diseases has increased, so has our ability to control these diseases. Changes in cultural practices have resulted in reduced levels of disease. Simultaneously, the development of more effective fungicides and their registration for use on strawberries have significantly reduced losses due to both anthracnose crown rot and fruit rot. Anthracnose-resistant cultivars have also decreased economic losses caused by these diseases. Nevertheless, growers may still face severe losses when environmental conditions are highly favorable for anthracnose development.', 0.5187379121780396]]
Context 2: [['After infection, many anthracnose pathogens enter a state of quiescence or latency, a characteristic commonly seen in pathogens causing postharvest diseases, including Colletotrichum. During this latent period, anthracnose pathogens remain dormant within host tissues until conditions become favorable for disease development.', 0.3002997040748596]]
Context 3: [['Leaves, flowers, and both green and ripe fruit can be highly susceptible to anthracnose, which can lead to the complete loss of fruit in some cases. In central Brazil, a recent epidemic of anthracnose caused significant yield losses, ranging from 30% to 68%. During May to September in 1995 and 1996, severe outbreaks of strawberry anthracnose were reported in many strawberry nurseries in Israel. Following transplantation, entire beds of strawberry plants collapsed due to crown rot. The causal agent was identified as Colletotrichum acutatum. Recently, various molecular techniques have been utilized to accurately and reliably identify the species of Colletotrichum responsible for strawberry anthracnose. The polymerase chain reaction (PCR) method confirmed that over 100 Israeli isolates belong to the species C. acutatum.', 0.28746649622917175]]
Context 4: [['Urdaneta, L., Sanabria, M., Rodríguez, D., & Pérez de Camacaro, M. (2013). Antracnosis causada por Colletotrichum spp. Investigación Agraria, 20(1), 38-50.', 0.20742294192314148]]

query: What is the significance of C. orchidophilum being restricted to the Orchidaceae family in terms of its ecology and distribution?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Notes: Diagnostic features for C. orchidophilum include its very narrow (usually 3–3.5 µm wide) cylindrical conidia, abundantly formed setae, and dark brown, uniformly shaped, pyriform to spathulate appressoria. Colletotrichum orchidophilum is basal to the C. acutatum species complex (fig. 1 in Cannon et al. 2012, this issue) and is therefore used as an outgroup in the phylogeny of the C. acutatum complex (Fig. 1). This species is associated with a range of genera in the Orchidaceae. According to BLASTn searches with ITS sequences, C. orchidophilum has possibly also been found on other orchids in different countries: on Cycnoches aureum in Panama (DQ286148, Farr et al. 2006), on Pleione sp. (AJ301980, Nirenberg et al. 2002), and as an endophyte of Dendrobium nobile in China (FJ042519, Yuan et al. 2009). As far as we can tell, C. orchidophilum is restricted to the Orchidaceae.', 0.996610701084137]]
Context 1: [['Colletotrichum orchidophilum Damm, P.F. Cannon & Crous, sp. nov. MycoBank MB800507. Fig. 21.', 0.29020681977272034]]
Context 2: [['Colletotrichum orchidophilum differs from C. orchidearum in its formation of much narrower conidia. The conidia of C. orchidearum forma eriae measure (13.5–) 15.5–19.5 × 5–6 µm, with a mean ± SD of 17.2 ± 1.6 × 5.6 ± 0.3 µm, and an L/W ratio of 3.1 (n = 20). In contrast, the conidia of forma physosiphonis measure (14–) 16–18.5 × 5–6 µm, with a mean ± SD of 17.2 ± 1.1 × 5.5 ± 0.3 µm, also having an L/W ratio of 3.1 (n = 20). C. orchidearum was described by Allescher (1902) based on three diseased orchid plants collected from the glasshouses of the Munich botanic garden. Each collection was assigned a separate name at the forma rank, as listed above. Although no forma orchidearum was officially named, that designation comes into effect upon the description of the other forms (Art. 26). The species account included a description of the overall taxon and compared it with C. macrosporum, another orchid species described by Saccardo (1896) from a Brazilian collection. Saccardo noted that C. macrosporum has substantially larger conidia than those of C. orchidearum (measurements of 28–32 × 8–10 µm were reported), and its relationships remain unknown. One of the forms introduced by Allescher, forma cymbidii, is invalidly published as it lacks a description.', 0.2717035710811615]]

While the dicot clade did not exhibit any clear substructure linked to host specificity, the monocot clade comprised three subclades: one was restricted to Orchidaceae, while the other two contained strains from Crinum (Amaryllidaceae). The dicot clade corresponds to C. karstii, as recognized in this paper, whereas the monocot clade includes C. boninense s. str. Our research does not support this division. query: Are there any specific cultural practices that can reduce the spread of anthracnose?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Until highly resistant cultivars are available, growers must rely on chemical applications and cultural practices to reduce losses due to anthracnose. The failure of fungicides to control anthracnose epidemics may be due to the development of fungicide resistance in the Colletotrichum spp. population. For example, benomyl effectively reduced the incidence of anthracnose crown rot (Horn et al., 1972; Howard, 1971) and was used intensively by strawberry growers for years to control anthracnose and other diseases. However, the anthracnose pathogens, C. acutatum and C. fragariae, developed resistance to it and other benzimidazole fungicides (LaMondia, 1995; McInnes et al., 1992a; Smith and Black, 1992, 1993), rendering benomyl ineffective for anthracnose control in strawberry fields.', 0.9920543432235718]]
Context 1: [['As our knowledge of the anthracnose pathogens and the epidemiology of anthracnose diseases has increased, so has our ability to control these diseases. Changes in cultural practices have resulted in reduced levels of disease. Additionally, the development and registration of more effective fungicides for use on strawberries have significantly reduced losses from both anthracnose crown rot and fruit rot. Anthracnose-resistant cultivars have also diminished economic losses due to these diseases. Nevertheless, growers may still experience severe losses when environmental factors are highly favorable for anthracnose development.', 0.9879192113876343]]

Context 0: [['Plants can be infected at all stages of growth when environmental conditions are favorable. A black mycelial mat of the fungus may form on the basal stem or "foot" area of the plant, and most roots may appear heavily melanized. On young plants, above-ground symptoms resemble general nutrient stress (Fig. 2) and are frequently misdiagnosed as nitrogen deficiency. query: Under what conditions can C. acutatum survive for months in soil, and how does soil type and moisture affect this survival?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['In inoculations conducted under controlled greenhouse conditions, C. acutatum from strawberry was isolated from inoculated plants that did not exhibit disease symptoms but maintained virulence on strawberry. The fungus was detected by a plating method both on and inside inoculated leaves at various time points after plant inoculation. The authenticity of the isolates as C. acutatum was validated by PCR using C. acutatum-specific primers. The PCR technique proved accurate and sensitive enough to detect the pathogen in inoculated tissues within 24 hours post-inoculation. This method is valuable for detecting C. acutatum in the tissues of various plant species, indicating that the fungus can exhibit both epiphytic and endophytic lifestyles without causing visible disease symptoms. PCR and fungal isolation data indicate that the pathogen can remain viable for extended periods within the tissues of various plant species without inducing disease symptoms. Although the experiments were concluded after three months for technical reasons, the final levels of inoculum in the examined tissues and the decay curves suggest that the pathogen had the potential to inhabit the infected plants for much longer periods. Furthermore, it has been shown that C. acutatum from strawberry can survive for nine months within plant debris in soil.', 0.9894261360168457]]
Context 1: [['Survival of C. acutatum in Soil and Leaf Debris: Populations of C. acutatum conidia recovered from laboratory soil tests decreased steadily, especially under moist or saturated conditions. Within 1 week, detectable populations decreased by more than 30% across all treatments. By 4 weeks, the number of viable conidia fell below 100 conidia per gram of soil when soil moisture was above 6%. In contrast, under dry conditions (1% moisture), it took 105 days for populations to fall below 100 conidia per gram of soil.', 0.9849287867546082]]
Context 2: [['Thus, conidia of C. acutatum can survive for extended periods in debris or soil under dry conditions. However, the fungus is unable to compete or multiply on leaf debris or in soil under moist conditions where other organisms are active.', 0.9845615029335022]]
Context 3: [['Conidia of C. acutatum from leatherleaf fern survived for up to one year in dry soil in Florida. Survival was shorter in moist soil, with conidia maintaining their viability for about 35 days in soils with 12% to 24% moisture. In leaf debris, the fungus remained viable after 56 days when soil moisture was at 6% or less, but not at higher moisture levels. C. acutatum remained viable for at least 105 days when infected plants were buried in field plots, and conidia remained viable on fabric for 35 to 45 days.', 0.982315182685852]]
Context 4: [['Although C. acutatum survives in soil, on plant debris, and in fumigated field soil, it is assumed that the main source of inoculum usually originates from infected strawberry plant material from the nursery. However, in nurseries or production fields, the pathogen may be introduced through contaminated soil, on field equipment, or may be splash-dispersed or blown in from surrounding vegetation that may carry the fungus without visible symptoms. This work has shown that C. acutatum from strawberries can survive and colonize many other plant species under controlled greenhouse conditions without causing disease, exhibiting epiphytic, endophytic, and non-pathogenic lifestyles. These findings emphasize that various crop plants, including weeds, may serve as potential inoculum sources of C. acutatum. Further investigation is needed to understand the contribution of inoculum from such plants to the development of anthracnose disease in strawberries under field conditions and in the dispersal of the pathogen from season to season.', 0.9576528668403625]]
Context 5: [['Fig. 4: Survival of C. acutatum in leaf debris when added to soil and incubated under controlled conditions, showing an initial increase in detectable conidia followed by a steady decline over five months.', 0.9503887295722961]]
Context 6: [['This study provides strong evidence that C. acutatum can become established, persist, and produce inoculum on symptomless strawberry leaves under a range of temperatures and intermittent wetness periods. In addition to our previous work at 26°C under continuous wetness (19), we have now shown that secondary conidia and appressoria may be produced under environmental conditions typical of many temperate strawberry-producing areas in the world. The survival of C. acutatum on strawberry leaves has implications for long-distance dissemination on transplants, as well as the proliferation and dissemination of the fungus within production fields. Furthermore, asymptomatic foliage of other plant species, including weeds, has been recently suggested as an additional inoculum source for C. acutatum (12). The environmental biology of C. acutatum on symptomless foliage should therefore be considered when developing management practices for strawberry anthracnose.', 0.9430227279663086]]
Context 7: [['The role of alternative hosts in the disease cycles caused by C. acutatum is also not well understood. The fungus can infect both anemones and strawberries, suggesting potential spread between these crops. Research has shown that C. acutatum is capable of colonizing surrounding weeds, such as Vicia spp. and Conyza spp., and can survive for three months on the leaves of tomatoes, peppers, and eggplants. This indicates that the pathogen could spread from strawberries to adjacent weeds and then reinfest new strawberry fields in subsequent years. Molecular and vegetative compatibility studies have indicated that isolates from weeds, anemones, and strawberries form a single population in Israel. Further studies demonstrated that while C. acutatum initially fails to penetrate the tissues of peppers, eggplants, and tomatoes, intercellular penetration occurs later, suggesting the fungus may live as an endophyte on these hosts.', 0.7940136194229126]]
Context 8: [['The ability of flower extracts to stimulate C. acutatum conidiation decreased with increasing durations of dry periods, possibly due to rising fungal mortality over time. In contrast, appressoria tended to persist on leaves and coverslips both before and after treatment applications, consistent with their role as survival structures. The fact that C. acutatum could be stimulated to multiply on coverslips and leaves even after two weeks of exposure to dry conditions clearly indicates the durability of C. acutatum propagules and demonstrates that survival does not depend on the presence of a host. C. acutatum survival on inert material has also been shown on the clothing of fern field workers, where conidia survived for over four weeks.', 0.7290981411933899]]
Context 9: [['Fig. 6: Number of C. acutatum sclerotia recovered from soil maintained in the laboratory at 25°C over a 56-day period, with soil moisture levels of 1% (n), 3% (l), 6% (t), 12% (s), and 24% (u).', 0.599723756313324]]

query: What strategies are recommended for the prevention of anthracnose in strawberry nurseries?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Anthracnose is an important disease of strawberry caused by Colletotrichum spp., which affects foliage, runners, crowns, and fruits (Howard et al., 1992). Three primary fungal pathogens—C. acutatum sensu lato, C. gloeosporioides sensu lato, and C. fragariae—are known to cause anthracnose disease in strawberries (Freeman and Katan, 1997). The crown rot syndrome is characteristic of infections from C. gloeosporioides sensu lato and C. fragariae, while fruit rot is mainly attributed to C. acutatum sensu lato, leading to significant yield losses (Howard et al., 1992). Currently, numerous species are classified under what is now known as the C. acutatum complex, with six species—C. acutatum sensu stricto, C. fioriniae, C. godetiae, C. nymphaeae, C. salicis, and C. simmondsii—identified as associated with strawberry anthracnose worldwide (Damm et al., 2012). Among these, C. nymphaeae is the most prevalent pathogen causing strawberry anthracnose globally, including in Iran (Baroncelli et al., 2015; Karimi et al., 2017; Wang et al., 2019). Currently, no effective chemical control methods exist for managing strawberry anthracnose; available options are limited to preventive treatments applied before fruit production (Denoyes-Rothan et al., 1999). Additionally, concerns about the toxic effects of chemical fungicides on the environment and the development of resistance in fungal strains highlight the need for alternative control strategies. Consequently, utilizing resistant cultivars appears to be the most efficient and practical approach for suppressing anthracnose development. In light of recent anthracnose outbreaks in strawberry fields in the Kurdistan province of Iran (Karimi et al., 2017), and the necessity for appropriate strategies to address this issue, the aim of this study was to evaluate the resistance of several commercial strawberry cultivars to the anthracnose fruit rot caused by C. nymphaeae under in vivo and greenhouse conditions.', 0.9914091229438782]]
Context 1: [['Introduction: The spread of strawberry anthracnose can be exacerbated by the use of infected runner plantlets (Hirayama et al. 2010). Effective management strategies must consider these factors to mitigate disease outbreaks.', 0.9166600108146667]]
Context 2: [['Species of the fungal plant pathogen Colletotrichum are responsible for strawberry (Fragaria × ananassa Duch.) anthracnose, one of the major diseases affecting this crop. Major species that cause strawberry anthracnose include C. acutatum J.H. Simmons, C. fragariae Brooks, and C. gloeosporioides (Penz.) Penz. & Sacc. Symptoms of the disease manifest in various phases. Infection of mother plants with anthracnose may result in the collapse of the entire plant due to crown rot. In the nursery, lesions form on stolons that eventually girdle the runners, leading to wilting and death of unrooted daughter plants distal to the lesion. Death of daughter plants in the nursery and in field transplants can also be caused by crown rot. Infected transplants are capable of spreading the disease from the nursery to the field, and entire crops can be destroyed by anthracnose in strawberry fruit production fields under conducive environmental conditions.', 0.7361765503883362]]
Context 3: [['Strawberry anthracnose can affect plants at any lifecycle stage, but plants are particularly susceptible at the seedling stage and immediately after planting (Wang et al. 2008). The disease primarily affects strawberry roots, petioles, and stolons, but can also infect flowers and fruit, leading to severe outbreaks (Mertely and Legard 2004). Symptoms include irregular ulcer-like lesions, reddish-brown stolons during initial stolon development, black spindle-shaped lesions on leaves and petioles, wilting, and dead roots (Debode et al. 2009; Freeman and Katan 1997). In Zhejiang, nearly 50% of seedling deaths and over 40% of production losses in nurseries are attributed to this disease (Xie et al. 2010). If environmental conditions are favorable, anthracnose can reduce strawberry yield by up to 80%. Transplants are considered the main source of primary inoculum, but the complete epidemiology of Colletotrichum spp. on strawberries in China remains unclear.', 0.7337930798530579]]
Context 4: [['So far, anthracnose epidemics have affected strawberry nurseries and production fields worldwide. Reports on Colletotrichum spp. associated with strawberries, curated from literature in PubMed and Clarivate combined with fungal database searches (Farr and Rossman, 2022), were compiled to understand the global diversity and occurrence of the causal agents of strawberry anthracnose. From our findings, since 1931 until July 9, 2022, there have been over 220 citations and 310 records related to the identification of causal agents of strawberry anthracnose at the genus level of Colletotrichum in 36 countries across six continents, with 282 records providing pathogen identification at the species or species complex level.', 0.6874622702598572]]
Context 5: [['From May to September 1995, a severe outbreak of strawberry anthracnose was observed in several strawberry-growing nurseries in Israel. Following transplantation to production fields during September and October, entire beds of strawberry plants collapsed. Typical anthracnose symptoms observed from November 1995 to June 1996 included crown rot, flower blight, and green and ripe fruit rot. This marked the first record of strawberry anthracnose in Israel. Furthermore, in at least four production fields in the same region, hundreds of plants developed symptoms of stunting and chlorosis, which are atypical of strawberry anthracnose. When these plants were uprooted, most of their roots were dark brown and decayed. Colletotrichum was readily isolated from these samples.', 0.6872109174728394]]
Context 6: [["Anthracnose fungi can attack various parts of the strawberry plant, including crowns, petioles, leaves, fruit trusses, flowers, buds, and fruit. The fungi's ability to attack multiple plant parts, coupled with the involvement of several pathogen species, contributes to the complex nature of strawberry anthracnose. Brooks reported in 1931 that C. fragariae caused spotting and girdling of runners, and later indicated that it also caused spotting of petioles and crown rot in a summer nursery, leading to wilting and death of the plants. Researchers in Louisiana observed all these symptoms and noted that crown rot also occurred in the fruit production field.", 0.5722390413284302]]
Context 7: [['Nam MH, Yoo JH, Yun TS, Kim HH, Kim HG. Anthracnose of strawberry: Etiological and ecological characteristics and management. Res Plant Dis 2023;29:205-19.', 0.5253480076789856]]
Context 8: [['In the early 1980s, anthracnose became a significant disease affecting strawberries in the southeastern United States. In response, the USDA-ARS established a breeding program to develop anthracnose-resistant cultivars suited to the strawberry-growing regions of this area. This initiative was conducted at the Small Fruit Research Station in Poplarville, MS, and the Fruit Laboratory in Beltsville, MD, in collaboration with state experiment stations in Florida, Louisiana, and North Carolina (Galletta et al., 1997; Smith and Spiers, 1982).', 0.4790155589580536]]
Context 9: [['Howard CM, Albregts EE. Anthracnose. In: Compendium of Strawberry Diseases. American Phytopathological Society: Paul St, ed. Maas JL, USA; 1984. pp. 85-87.', 0.41769251227378845]]

query: According to von Arx's 1957 paper, how does Colletotrichum differ from other genera of plant-pathogenic fungi in terms of lifecycle and pathogenicity?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['In a drastic move, von Arx (1957) reduced the number of recognized Colletotrichum species from several hundred to 11 based on morphological characteristics, with many taxa treated as synonyms of C. gloeosporioides and C. dematium. Several additional species have since been accepted based on morphological criteria (Sutton, 1980; 1992). The difficulties in recognizing Colletotrichum species can be attributed to: 1) the limited and variable morphological characters; 2) an extensive host range and variability in pathogenicity (Bailey and Jeger, 1992; Freeman et al., 2000; Latunde-Dada, 2001; Du et al., 2005; Thaung, 2008); 3) type specimens that are often missing or in poor condition, making them unsuitable for molecular studies; and 4) numerous rDNA ITS sequences of Colletotrichum strains in NCBI that are often misidentified (Crouch et al., 2009d; Damm et al., 2009).', 0.9950514435768127]]

query: How does Colletotrichum miaoliense differ genetically from other species?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Three isolates of C. miaoliense were collected from Miaoli County and Nantou County, Taiwan. Multi-locus analysis revealed that C. miaoliense forms a robust clade distinct from other known species in the C. acutatum species complex. Among the six Colletotrichum species in this complex (C. acutatum, C. fioriniae, C. godetiae, C. nymphaeae, C. salicis, and C. simmondsii) identified as anthracnose pathogens of strawberry, C. miaoliense is most closely related phylogenetically to C. nymphaeae and C. simmondsii. Morphologically, C. miaoliense differs from C. nymphaeae (CBS 515.78) in conidial size (16.1 × 2.3 – 4.9 × 0.7 μm versus 14.2 × 1.1 – 4.1 × 0.34 μm), conidial shape (one end round and the other rounded to acute, contrasting with the new species where both ends are acute), and appressoria size (8.7 × 2.5 – 5.5 × 1.0 μm versus 7.5 × 1.0 μm).', 0.9936878085136414]]
Context 1: [['Colletotrichum miaoliense sp. nov. P. C. Chung & H. Y. Wu. MycoBank number MB835424. Etymology: The epithet "miaoliense" specifically refers to Miaoli County, Taiwan, where the new taxon was discovered.', 0.6827717423439026]]
Context 2: [['After examining type and other materials, Arx (1957a, 1957b) concluded that Gloeosporium musarum Cke. & Mass. is a synonym of Colletotrichum musae (Berk. & Curt.) Arx (Myxosporium musae Berk. & Curt.). In this paper, Colletotrichum musae is used as the name for the banana anthracnose organism. C. musae is the most host-specific of the organisms discussed and is also very consistent in morphological and cultural characteristics. The conidial measurements are similar to those of C. gloeosporioides, while the cultural traits resemble those of a cultural type of C. gloeosporioides var. minor, which appears occasionally. Arx (1957) regarded the fungus as a host-specific form of C. gloeosporioides. It is a rapid grower with a high optimum and maximum temperature, similar to this species. The host-parasite relationships of this organism in Queensland have been investigated in detail (Simmonds and Mitchell 1940; Simmonds 1941, 1963).', 0.45022696256637573]]
Context 3: [['Notes: The most prominent species of Colletotrichum associated with Musa species is C. musae, a central species in one of the major clades of the C. gloeosporioides species complex (Weir et al. 2012). It was recently epitypified with a strain from Florida (Su et al. 2011). One strain we examined (CBS 502.97 = LARS 58) was first studied by Sherriff et al. (1994) under the misapplied name C. musae. However, Johnston & Jones (1997) confirmed it as a member of the C. acutatum complex. Notably, Colletotrichum paxtonii does not appear to produce setae at all, while C. musae rarely does, which may have contributed to past confusion between the two species.', 0.2852064073085785]]
Context 4: [['Figure 4. Colletotrichum miaoliense sp. nov. ML1040. Images include (a) upper side of the colony, (b) reverse side of the colony, (c, d) conidiomata, (e-p) appressoria (induced in dH2O on a microscope slide), (q) conidia from conidiomata, (r) conidia from aerial mycelium, (s-w) conidiophores. (a, b) were cultured on PDA; (c, d), and (q-w) were observed on 1/4-strength PDA. Scale bars: (c, d) = 0.2 mm, (e) = 10 μm, which also applies to (f-p, q), and (r-w).', 0.27346888184547424]]
Context 5: [['Notes: Colletotrichum musae was originally described from North Carolina (Berkeley 1874), and the name was recently epitypified by Su et al. (2011) based on a specimen collected in Florida (ex-epitype culture CBS 116870). Su et al. (2011) cite several strains from Thailand that align with their concept of C. musae. Isolates from anthracnose symptoms on banana fruit from various parts of the world are consistent with our study. These isolates form a well-supported clade within the C. gloeosporioides species complex, show low levels of genetic differentiation, and, based on ITS sequences, align with C. musae sensu Sreenivasaprasad et al. (1996), Nirenberg et al. (2002), and Shenoy et al. (2007). The morphology in culture agrees with the description by Sutton & Waterston (1970).', 0.26786351203918457]]
Context 6: [['Photita, W., Taylor, P. W., Ford, R., Hyde, K. D., and Lumyong, S. (2005). Morphological and molecular characterization of Colletotrichum species from...', 0.2337050586938858]]
Context 7: [['MycoBank MB563594. Figs 35, 36.', 0.2077217400074005]]
Context 8: [['MycoBank MB563591. Figs 13, 14.', 0.1946643590927124]]
Context 9: [["Colletotrichum musae (formerly Gloeosporium musarum) was extensively discussed by Simmonds and Mitchell (1940). Although three cultural types are recognized, the normal form is the one typically obtained from field isolations, characterized by a uniform appearance for the species. The aerial mycelium is white to light grey, loose, and not significantly elevated. Spores are produced early and abundantly directly on the mycelium or on acervuli that develop over the medium's surface, giving the colony a distinctive pink appearance.", 0.18540939688682556]]

query: Is it possible to fully eliminate anthracnose from a strawberry field in Florida through fungicide treatment alone, or is integrated pest management (IPM) more effective?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['In the southeastern United States, anthracnose crown rot and fruit rot can be particularly severe in strawberry production fields, especially during wet harvest seasons, which can lead to total crop loss. Fungicides are used to control anthracnose diseases; however, several have become ineffective due to the development of fungicide-resistant strains of the pathogens. Field observations in Florida indicated that growing strawberry plants in soils with low N levels reduced the severity of anthracnose, although this also severely limited fruit production. Both the form of nitrogen and calcium levels influence disease severity. For instance, calcium has been employed to manage soil-borne diseases caused by Pythium spp. on various crops, while nitrate forms of N have been shown to suppress Fusarium wilt in tomatoes, whereas ammonium forms increase disease severity.', 0.9477487802505493]]
Context 1: [['Strawberry anthracnose, caused mainly by the Colletotrichum acutatum species complex, is a significant disease affecting strawberry production. Surveys were conducted, and isolates were collected from affected areas, specifically strawberry nurseries and production fields in six states across the United States. The use of fungicides, particularly quinone outside inhibitors (QoIs), has been widely employed for controlling C. acutatum for the past 20 years. Resistance to QoIs was first reported in Florida in 2013, and subsequent anthracnose outbreaks occurred in strawberry nurseries and production fields throughout the U.S. in 2015. Fungicide use surveys indicated that, in certain locations, the number of QoI applications exceeded the recommended levels for this fungicide group. This situation necessitates immediate changes in anthracnose management strategies to incorporate other chemical and non-chemical approaches, aiming to limit the selection of resistant populations and prevent future outbreaks.', 0.9152965545654297]]
Context 2: [['There is an urgent need for multi- and single-site fungicide alternatives effective against anthracnose in strawberry nurseries and production fields. The antifungal antibiotic natamycin, widely used as a natural mold inhibitor in food products, has shown promise in controlling anthracnose root and crown infections caused by C. acutatum on strawberry transplants (Cordova et al. 2017; Haack et al. 2018). Similarly, fluazinam, a single-site respiration inhibitor fungicide from FRAC group 29, has demonstrated significant control of anthracnose fruit rot (Mertely et al. 2018). A request has been submitted through the Interregional Research Project Number 4 for its registration for nursery use only. Reducing the overlap of the same modes of action used during nursery and fruit production phases could help extend the lifespan of single-site fungicides at high risk of resistance.', 0.7549022436141968]]
Context 3: [['MacKenzie, S., and Peres, N. 2012. Use of leaf wetness and temperature to time fungicide applications to control anthracnose fruit rot of strawberry in Florida. Plant Disease 96: 522-528.', 0.7479823231697083]]
Context 4: [['Howard, C. M., Chandler, C. K., and Albregts, E. E. (1991). Strawberry anthracnose in Florida. In The Strawberry into the 21st Century: Proc. North Am. Strawberry Conf., 3rd ed. A. Dale and J. Luby (Eds.), Timber Press, Portland, OR, 219-220.', 0.6742259860038757]]
Context 5: [['Anthracnose of strawberry (Fragaria × ananassa Duchesne) has become a major constraint on strawberry production in the United States. While C. gloeosporioides and C. fragariae are often associated with infection of plant parts other than the fruit, both species are capable of infecting and rotting the fruit, leading to significant yield losses. The extensive use of fungicides is often necessary to manage this disease, and methods to reduce the number of spray applications or optimize the timing of fungicide applications are needed. Disease forecasting, based on environmental conditions, may provide additional management strategies.', 0.6736060380935669]]
Context 6: [['Howard, C. M., Chandler, C. K., and Albregts, E. E. 1991. Strawberry anthracnose in Florida. Pages 219-220 in: The Strawberry into the 21st Century: Proc. North Am. Strawberry Conf. 3rd. A. Dale and J. J. Luby, eds. Timber Press, Portland, OR.', 0.6733559966087341]]
Context 7: [['Howard, C. M., Chandler, C. K., and Albregts, E. E. 1991. Strawberry anthracnose in Florida. Pages 219-220 in: The Strawberry into the 21st Century: Proc. North Am. Strawberry Conf., 3rd. A. Dale and J. Luby, eds. Timber Press, Portland, OR.', 0.6733500361442566]]
Context 8: [['ABSTRACT: Strawberry anthracnose, caused by Colletotrichum fragariae, is a serious problem in the southeastern United States, resulting in significant losses in strawberry nurseries. Control measures using fungicides are crucial, particularly with recommended applications of captafol, benomyl, captan, and maneb.', 0.5772726535797119]]
Context 9: [['Until highly resistant cultivars are available, growers must rely on chemical applications and cultural practices to reduce losses due to anthracnose. The failure of fungicides to control anthracnose epidemics may be due to the development of fungicide resistance in the Colletotrichum spp. population. For example, benomyl effectively reduced the incidence of anthracnose crown rot (Horn et al., 1972; Howard, 1971) and was used intensively by strawberry growers for years to control anthracnose and other diseases. However, the anthracnose pathogens, C. acutatum and C. fragariae, developed resistance to it and other benzimidazole fungicides (LaMondia, 1995; McInnes et al., 1992a; Smith and Black, 1992, 1993), rendering benomyl ineffective for anthracnose control in strawberry fields.', 0.5603120923042297]]

query: Which cultivar was found to be the most susceptible to anthracnose fruit rot?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['In this study, distinct levels of resistance to anthracnose fruit rot (AFR) were revealed in trials involving detached leaves, fruit, and crown-based assays. In all assays, fruit, leaf, and crown infections were confirmed by re-isolation of the pathogen. In the detached leaf assay, the cultivars ‘Missionary’, ‘New Kurdistan’, ‘Ventana1’, ‘Ventana’, and ‘Blakemore’ exhibited significantly greater resistance to the disease compared to other cultivars (df = 24, F = 14.66, P ≤ 0.01). The exception included ‘Ten Beauty’, ‘N. Selva’, ‘Chandler’, ‘Aliso’, ‘Fresno’, ‘Mac Donance’, ‘Gaviota’, ‘Dachnitsa’, ‘Aromas’, and ‘Mrak’. The most susceptible cultivar was ‘Camarosa’, followed by ‘Selva’, ‘Paros’, ‘Diamant’, ‘Karcynberg’, ‘Kurdistan’, ‘Pajaro’, ‘Queen Eliza’, ‘Sequia’, and ‘Yallova’.', 0.9975905418395996]]
Context 1: [['These findings align with previous studies indicating that susceptibility to anthracnose fruit rot (AFR) varies among different organs of a cultivar, including fruit, leaf, and root. Notably, no relationship was established between the susceptibility of various cultivars and the different organs of a single cultivar (Delp and Milholland, 1980; Smith and Spires, 1982; Smith and Black, 1990; Chandler et al., 1997). Furthermore, the presence of the pathogen might not cause symptoms on foliage, leading to latent infections. Consistent with Shuman (2001), our results suggest that the detached fruit assay is a better indicator of AFR disease susceptibility, though other methods could also enhance the understanding of disease epidemiology.', 0.9961463212966919]]
Context 2: [['Planting resistant cultivars such as Sweet Charlie, Florida Radiance, and Florida Elyana has reduced losses from anthracnose fruit rot in Florida, likely because C. acutatum lacks the genetic diversity to overcome this resistance (Mertely et al., 2009). However, when moderately susceptible (e.g., Strawberry Festival) or highly susceptible cultivars (e.g., Camarosa and Treasure) are grown, regular fungicide applications are often necessary to manage the disease (Chang and Smith, 2007). Unless highly resistant cultivars are planted, growers must rely on a combination of chemical applications and cultural practices to mitigate anthracnose losses.', 0.9883129000663757]]
Context 3: [['The USDA Small Fruit Research Laboratory in Poplarville, Mississippi, along with cooperators in North Carolina, Florida, and Louisiana, is screening strawberry seedlings for resistance to anthracnose (Colletotrichum sp.). Anthracnose is a destructive disease affecting plants and fruits in the southern and south-central United States, involving several species of fungi (Maas, 1984). A screening method developed at the USDA laboratory in Mississippi identified two clones, MSUS 73 and 74, as strongly resistant to anthracnose crown rot, yielding results comparable to standard cultivars while also exhibiting superior internal fruit color. Additionally, several selections from North Carolina, such as ‘NC 3874’ and ‘NC 3892’, show resistance to both anthracnose and red stele.', 0.9602932333946228]]
Context 4: [['The USDA-ARS program resulted in over 1,500 anthracnose-resistant selections from seedlings field-tested in Mississippi. Four of these selections were released as breeding lines (Galletta et al., 1993), and one was released as the cultivar Pelican, which is highly resistant to anthracnose crown rot caused by Colletotrichum fragariae and to anthracnose fruit rot caused by C. acutatum (Smith et al., 1998). Pelican is also resistant to five races of red stele caused by Phytophthora fragariae. Other selections have been utilized as parent lines in various breeding programs. To enhance genetic diversity in strawberry germplasm used in breeding, anthracnose-resistant clones have been identified in native plant collections and are being incorporated as parent lines (Lewers et al., 2007).', 0.9592816233634949]]
Context 5: [['Two cultivars with different resistance levels to anthracnose were compared: (a) cv. Campinas IAC 2712 (susceptible) and (b) cv. Dover (partially resistant). Although ‘Dover’ is reported to be resistant to Colletotrichum acutatum (Howard et al. 1992; Denoyes-Rothan et al. 1999), the resistance is not complete, and significant losses due to anthracnose have been noted in Brasília for this genotype (Furlanetto et al. 1996). The incidence of flower blight and diseased fruits (%) was recorded weekly at 23, 29, 37, and 44 days after infection (DAI). AUDPCs were calculated as previously described.', 0.9554612636566162]]
Context 6: [['Increased losses due to anthracnose fruit and crown rots may be related to the shift from matted-row culture to the annual plasticulture production system in the United States. Breeding for genetic resistance to anthracnose and the development of resistant cultivars are primary means for reducing economic losses due to this disease. This approach is environmentally sound because it results in reduced fungicide use. As our knowledge of the anthracnose pathogens and the epidemiology of anthracnose diseases has increased, so has our ability to control these diseases. Changes in cultural practices have resulted in reduced levels of disease. Simultaneously, the development of more effective fungicides and their registration for use on strawberries have significantly reduced losses due to both anthracnose crown rot and fruit rot. Anthracnose-resistant cultivars have also decreased economic losses caused by these diseases. Nevertheless, growers may still face severe losses when environmental conditions are highly favorable for anthracnose development.', 0.7787607312202454]]
Context 7: [['Smith, B.J. (1998b). Anthracnose fruit rot (black spot). In J.L. Maas (Ed.), Compendium of Strawberry Diseases (2nd ed., pp. 31–33). American Phytopathological Society, St. Paul, MN.', 0.5850040912628174]]
Context 8: [['Smith, B. J. (1998). Anthracnose fruit rot (black spot). In J. L. Maas (Ed.), Compendium of Strawberry Diseases (2nd ed., pp. 31-33). The American Phytopathological Society, St. Paul, MN.', 0.5755611062049866]]

query: How does cultivar selection impact the overall profitability of strawberry farming?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [["In Taiwan, strawberry (Fragaria × ananassa Duch.) is a high-value crop, cultivated over an average area of approximately 500 hectares annually in the past five years. The majority of strawberry cultivation (over 90%) is concentrated in Miaoli County, with the cultivar 'Taoyuan No. 1' as the predominant variety, having been widely used for more than 30 years. In recent years, anthracnose has emerged as a particularly destructive disease affecting strawberry crops.", 0.22516939043998718]]
Context 1: [['A labor crisis in the 1960s in the Pacific Northwest spurred interest in breeding strawberry cultivars for machine harvesting. A portion of the cooperative USDA-Oregon State Experiment Station project was directed toward this goal, which included the Oregon State University Agriculture Engineering Department, responsible for building harvesting and capping equipment. Selecting strawberries with an erect fruiting habit that ripen most of their fruit at once and are easy to cap—important traits for machine harvesting—is feasible due to the variability in available strawberry germplasm. Inheritance patterns for simultaneous ripening of fruit indicated that early-season parents, such as ‘Sunrise’, could produce progeny with a high percentage of ripe fruit at one time (Lawrence et al., 1975). Semi-erect and easy-capping types could also be derived from parents such as ‘Hood’, ‘Benton’, and other selections from the Pacific Northwest and California. Additionally, selections that have over 80% of the fruit ripe at one time and possess the easy-cap character could also exhibit good processing qualities (Lawrence et al., 1975). The cultivar ‘Linn’ was introduced in 1975 as a machine-harvest processing berry; however, commercial machine harvesting did not materialize, and ‘Linn’ lost favor because it does not maintain berry size as plants age and is too tart for the fresh market. Currently, machine harvesting of strawberries for the commercial processing industry remains at an experimental stage in the Pacific Northwest.', 0.22448799014091492]]

query: Why is Colletotrichum bad for farmers?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Many species belonging to the genus Colletotrichum are associated with plant diseases, commonly referred to as anthracnose. Colletotrichum spp. can affect a wide range of hosts, and these pathogens are characterized by global distribution. Virtually every cultivated botanical family is susceptible to one or more species of Colletotrichum, making it one of the most studied plant pathogenic fungi (Prusky et al., 2000; Latunde-Dada, 2001; Dean et al., 2012). Common hosts include many dicotyledonous plants such as strawberry, apple, citrus, and stone fruits, as well as major cereals such as maize and sorghum. Members of this genus can cause crop losses of up to 100% in many staple foods (Bailey and Jeger, 1992; Prusky et al., 2000; Talhinhas et al., 2005; Cannon et al., 2012).', 0.8573710918426514]]
Context 1: [['The genus Colletotrichum represents a large number of economically important Ascomycete fungi that collectively cause anthracnose disease or leaf blights on significant agricultural crops and ornamental plants worldwide. Colletotrichum spp. often serve as models in studies ranging from pathogenic development and differentiation to plant-microbe interactions. During establishment and colonization of host plants, members of this genus uniquely acquire nutrients via both biotrophy and necrotrophy. Thus, in a single interaction, these fungal pathogens exhibit two modes of nutrient acquisition: initially, nutrients are acquired from living cells, after which a necrotrophic phase is initiated, allowing the same fungus to obtain nutrients from dead cells killed by the fungus. A given species of this genus can exhibit both strategies separately or concurrently. Additionally, these fungi develop a series of specialized infection-related structures, including germ tubes, appressoria, primary intracellular hyphae, and secondary necrotrophic hyphae. Therefore, Colletotrichum species are experimentally attractive organisms for studying the molecular, biochemical, and cellular basis of fungal pathogenicity, development, and signal transduction (see Bailey and Jeger, 1992; Prusky et al., 1999).', 0.8426498770713806]]
Context 2: [['The genus Colletotrichum is considered one of the top ten important genera of fungal pathogens globally (Dean et al., 2012). Colletotrichum is an ancient fungus that has co-evolved with flowering plants. Plant microfossils of Protocolletotrichum preserved on angiosperm leaf cuticles suggest that the diverse pathogenic strategies of Colletotrichum spp. have been established since the Late Cretaceous period (Kar et al., 2004). Different complexes within the genus may have diverged between 4.8 and 32.2 million years ago (MYA) (Bhunjun et al., 2021). The emergence of agricultural cultivation and the intensive disturbance of natural environments have further driven the diversification of Colletotrichum species. These fungi have adapted to thousands of hosts and can be found as endophytes, pathogens, and saprobes (Freeman et al., 1998; Dean et al., 2012; Hirayama et al., 2018; da Silva et al., 2020; Jayawardena et al., 2020). Currently, a total of 257 Colletotrichum species grouped into 15 complexes and 13 additional singletons have been accepted in this genus.', 0.7638399600982666]]
Context 3: [['Bernstein B, Zehr EI, Dean RA, et al. 1995. Characteristics of Colletotrichum due to its economically useful traits, including cold temperature and poor soil tolerance.', 0.5836784243583679]]
Context 4: [['Damm, U., Baroncelli, R., Cai, L., Kubo, Y., O’Connell, R., Weir, B., Yoshino, K., and Cannon, P. F. 2010. Colletotrichum: Species, ecology, and interactions. IMA Fungus 1:161-165.', 0.37023112177848816]]

query: What impact does the anthracnose fungus, collected by R. Villanueva-Arce in 2003, have on fruit-bearing plants beyond Annona cherimola?

Context 1: [['Additional Keywords: anthracnose fruit rot, phyllosphere.', 0.2511650323867798]]
Context 2: [['Accurate identification and scientific naming of anthracnose pathogens are crucial because precise taxonomic information allows us to classify a given species as a pathogen, saprophyte, or endophyte. The species involved in anthracnose affecting tropical fruits may exhibit different characteristics, emphasizing the importance of proper identification of the causative pathogen for effective disease management.', 0.15083692967891693]]
Context 3: [['Arauz, L. F. Mango anthracnose: Economic impact and current options for integrated management. Plant Disease, 84(6), 600-611 (2000).', 0.1475498378276825]]
Context 4: [['Erregers der Anthraknose an Bergenien. Nachrichtenblatt des Deutschen Pflanzenschutzdienstes 52: 1–4.', 0.14317697286605835]]
Context 5: [['A detailed examination of diverse Colletotrichum species associated with anthracnose in banana, papaya, mango, dragon fruit, guava, and avocado reveals that some of these species infect not only the fruits but also the stems and leaves. This indicates that other parts of the plants may harbor sources of inoculum for anthracnose infections in fruit crops. Several species, including C. siamense, C. asianum, C. scovillei, C. gloeosporioides, C. karstii, C. fructicola, and C. tropicale, can infect multiple hosts, demonstrating the potential for cross-infection among various types of fruit crops and other plants.', 0.1239788606762886]]
Context 6: [['Due to the economic importance of anthracnose in tropical fruit production and commercialization, this review focuses on the current knowledge regarding Colletotrichum species associated with tropical fruit crops reported in several fruit-producing countries. Emphasis is placed on species related to mango, papaya, banana, avocado, guava, and dragon fruit, as these crops significantly contribute to the economic well-being of their inhabitants.', 0.11521483212709427]]
Context 7: [['Abstract: In tropical fruit crops, anthracnose is primarily caused by species of the fungal genus Colletotrichum. These phytopathogens can infect various parts of the fruit crops; however, infections occurring during postharvest or ripening stages lead to significant economic losses. The disease manifests as black to dark brown sunken lesions on the fruit surface, which diminishes fruit quality and marketability. Common tropical fruit crops susceptible to anthracnose include mango, papaya, banana, avocado, guava, and dragon fruit, all of which are economically important in many developing countries. It is essential to note that newly identified Colletotrichum species associated with fruit anthracnose can infect multiple hosts, though some species may exhibit host specificity. Utilizing multiple markers, many phylogenetic species of Colletotrichum have been recognized as anthracnose-causing pathogens. Given that effective disease management strategies depend on a comprehensive understanding of the causative agents, up-to-date information regarding Colletotrichum species and the risks posed by newly identified species in tropical fruit plantations and harvested fruits is crucial. Furthermore, these newly recorded species may be significant for biosecurity and should be classified as quarantine pathogens, particularly as tropical fruits are traded globally.', 0.11473361402750015]]
Context 8: [['Bieysse, D., Bella Manga, D., Mouen Bedimo, J. A., Ndeumeni, J. P., Roussel, V., Fabre, J. V., and Berry, D. 2002. L’anthracnose des baies une menace potentielle pour la culture mondiale de l’Arabica. Plantations, Recherche, Développement. May 2002:145-152.', 0.10259128361940384]]

Context 1: [['Many species belonging to the genus Colletotrichum are associated with plant diseases, commonly referred to as anthracnose. Colletotrichum spp. can affect a wide range of hosts, and these pathogens are characterized by global distribution. Virtually every cultivated botanical family is susceptible to one or more species of Colletotrichum, making it one of the most studied plant pathogenic fungi (Prusky et al., 2000; Latunde-Dada, 2001; Dean et al., 2012). Common hosts include many dicotyledonous plants such as strawberry, apple, citrus, and stone fruits, as well as major cereals such as maize and sorghum. Members of this genus can cause crop losses of up to 100% in many staple foods (Bailey and Jeger, 1992; Prusky et al., 2000; Talhinhas et al., 2005; Cannon et al., 2012).', 0.29986295104026794]]

query: What specific factors might explain why C. acutatum did not produce disease symptoms on most of the tested plants, even though conidia were recovered from them?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Strawberry, eggplant, tomato, and pepper plants were inoculated with a conidial suspension of C. acutatum derived from strawberry. Conidia were recovered from all plants over a 2- to 3-month period, regardless of whether overhead or drip irrigation was used (see Fig. 2). The number of conidia recovered from strawberry was comparable to that from the other plants at all time points and, in most cases, the differences were not significant (P < 0.05) across the different plant species, although disease symptoms were observed only on the strawberry plants. Significant numbers of conidia were still recovered from the plants at the end of the experiment, indicating that the survival potential of the fungus on all plant species exceeded 3 months.', 0.9918012022972107]]
Context 1: [['In Israel, inoculation of isolates of C. acutatum from anemone and strawberry into each host resulted in typical anthracnose symptoms on both plant species. Molecular studies indicated that the isolates from the two hosts were similar and formed a single genetic subgroup. Isolates of C. acutatum were recovered from pepper, eggplant, tomato, bean, as well as from weeds of the genera Vicia and Conyza; however, disease symptoms occurred only on strawberry. C. acutatum isolates from tulip tree in Argentina were also pathogenic to strawberry fruit. Thus, strawberry isolates of C. acutatum can parasitize and cause disease on other hosts or, alternatively, survive on other crops and weeds without producing symptoms.', 0.9847676157951355]]
Context 2: [['In strawberries, C. acutatum is typically introduced into production fields from nurseries. While some plants may exhibit symptoms, often the pathogen is introduced through asymptomatic leaves or petioles, likely as appressoria or quiescent infections. It remains unclear whether quiescent infections develop into lesions or if appressoria germinate to produce conidia. However, conidia of C. acutatum can generate several secondary conidia from each deposited conidium on the leaf surface. This suggests that the fungus is reproducing by utilizing nutrients on the leaf surface rather than relying on reserves from the original conidium. In these instances, it appears that the fungus is growing as an epiphyte rather than producing quiescent infections.', 0.9522066116333008]]
Context 3: [['In inoculations conducted under controlled greenhouse conditions, C. acutatum from strawberry was isolated from inoculated plants that did not exhibit disease symptoms but maintained virulence on strawberry. The fungus was detected by a plating method both on and inside inoculated leaves at various time points after plant inoculation. The authenticity of the isolates as C. acutatum was validated by PCR using C. acutatum-specific primers. The PCR technique proved accurate and sensitive enough to detect the pathogen in inoculated tissues within 24 hours post-inoculation. This method is valuable for detecting C. acutatum in the tissues of various plant species, indicating that the fungus can exhibit both epiphytic and endophytic lifestyles without causing visible disease symptoms. PCR and fungal isolation data indicate that the pathogen can remain viable for extended periods within the tissues of various plant species without inducing disease symptoms. Although the experiments were concluded after three months for technical reasons, the final levels of inoculum in the examined tissues and the decay curves suggest that the pathogen had the potential to inhabit the infected plants for much longer periods. Furthermore, it has been shown that C. acutatum from strawberry can survive for nine months within plant debris in soil.', 0.9341785907745361]]
Context 4: [['Four C. acutatum isolates from fruits and roots were used to inoculate the foliage and roots of strawberry plants to determine whether symptom development could be affected by the source of the isolate. The tested isolates, regardless of their origin, caused typical anthracnose symptoms on petioles, leaves, and stolons of both Chandler and Sharon cultivars 7 to 10 days after inoculation. After 30 days, 100% mortality was observed in all foliar-inoculated plants, compared to 0% mortality in the water control plants, which remained healthy thereafter.', 0.782552182674408]]
Context 5: [['A difference between the mean disease severity ratings of C. acutatum and C. fragariae in both experiments confirmed previous results (Smith and Black, 1990), indicating that C. acutatum produces a less severe plant disease reaction compared to C. fragariae. Although Colletotrichum acutatum is occasionally isolated from the crowns of dying plants in the field, it primarily acts as a fruit rot organism with the capability to cause crown rot.', 0.7197880148887634]]
Context 6: [['This is the first report of secondary conidia production by C. acutatum on symptomless strawberry leaves. Secondary conidiation, also known as microcyclic or precocious conidiation, is defined as conidiation that occurs directly after conidial germination with little or no mycelial growth. This phenomenon has been reported for several fungi, including other Colletotrichum species, but its occurrence in C. acutatum was previously described only in vitro and on other hosts.', 0.6130485534667969]]
Context 7: [['Survival of C. acutatum in Soil and Leaf Debris: Populations of C. acutatum conidia recovered from laboratory soil tests decreased steadily, especially under moist or saturated conditions. Within 1 week, detectable populations decreased by more than 30% across all treatments. By 4 weeks, the number of viable conidia fell below 100 conidia per gram of soil when soil moisture was above 6%. In contrast, under dry conditions (1% moisture), it took 105 days for populations to fall below 100 conidia per gram of soil.', 0.5808014869689941]]
Context 8: [['C. acutatum, as noted by various studies (Peres et al. 2008; Lee et al. 2007; Talhinhas et al. 2011; Polashock et al. 2009; Wharton & Schilder 2008), has a well-known morphological feature: the shape of its conidia, which are characterized by acute ends (Simmonds 1965). However, other conidial shapes are frequently encountered, particularly cylindrical forms with only one acute end. These variations are often observed in strains that have been repeatedly subcultured, as well as in the “terminal crook” disease of pine (Dingley & Gilmour 1972) and in the anthracnose affecting leather leaf fern (Schiller et al. 2006). There are also reports of disseminated infections in sea turtles (Manire et al. 2002) and infections in scale insects (Marcelino et al. 2008). Differentiating between C. acutatum (s. lat.) and C. gloeosporioides (s. lat.) is challenging due to the existence of many intermediate strains that exhibit a limited number of typical fusiform conidia alongside numerous cylindrical ones (Van der Aa et al. 1990).', 0.5229164958000183]]
Context 9: [['Biotroph–Necrotroph Combination Lifestyle (Almond, Key Lime): There are several diseases where C. acutatum primarily functions as a necrotroph but can also act as a biotroph, exhibiting a combination of biotrophic and necrotrophic interactions. This lifestyle includes anthracnose of almond, key lime, and leatherleaf fern. In these instances, acervuli and conidia are abundantly produced on affected tissues. The conidia are splash-dispersed to healthy tissues, which become infected quickly. The fungus can survive as dried conidia in acervuli or as mycelia in dead tissues, including spurs and mummified almond fruit.', 0.5205345749855042]]

query: What tools are used to check the DNA of Colletotrichum?

Context 0: [['To address the inadequacies of traditional identification methods, molecular techniques have been employed to characterize and identify taxa within Colletotrichum (Sreenivasaprasad et al., 1996; Abang et al., 2002; Moriwaki et al., 2002; Peres et al., 2002; Guerber et al., 2003; Photita et al., 2005; Du et al., 2005; Shenoy et al., 2007b; Whitelaw-Weckert et al., 2007; Peres et al., 2008; Than et al., 2008a-c). query: What are the primary methods for maintaining fungal cultures in laboratories?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Fungal Isolates: Fungal isolates were obtained from K. S. Yoder at Virginia Tech’s Winchester Agricultural Research and Extension Center. They were maintained on potato dextrose agar (PDA) in Petri dishes, subcultured weekly, and kept at 22°C during experiments. Conidia for inoculum were harvested from seven-day-old cultures. For long-term storage, cultures were preserved on PDA in culture tubes at 4°C. Conidia were harvested by flooding the dishes with sterile distilled water, scraping the plates with a rubber spatula, and filtering the suspension through four layers of sterile cheesecloth. Desired concentrations of conidia were prepared by diluting original suspensions after counting them with a hemacytometer.', 0.5439606308937073]]

Long-term storage at 4 °C involved cutting mycelial plugs from the edge of actively growing cultures on PDA and suspending them in sterile water.', 0.17524400353431702]]
Context 3: [['Mycelial plugs (5 mm) were transferred from the edge of actively growing cultures to fresh potato dextrose agar (PDA, 1.5%, Difco) plates. Cultures were maintained at 28 °C with a 12/12 hour fluorescent light/dark cycle. The morphological characteristics of all isolates, including colony and conidial traits, were observed. Microscopic examination was conducted with a Carl Zeiss Imager A2 microscope after one month of cultivation. Among the 1,285 obtained isolates (as shown in Table 1), 121 representative isolates were selected for further multilocus phylogenetic analyses based on geographical location, morphology (including colony shape, color, and characteristics of aerial mycelia and conidia).', 0.11885567754507065]]
Context 4: [['Mycelium: slowly growing, partly thin, hyaline; partly thick, brown with more pronounced septa.', 0.0940079540014267]]
Context 5: [['Isolation of genomic DNA: Fungal mycelium was produced in 200 ml of liquid medium (24 g/liter of potato dextrose broth [PDB], 1 g/liter of yeast extract, and 1 g/liter of casein hydrolysate). Cultures were shaken at 100 rpm for 5 days at 27°C. Mycelium was harvested by filtration through mesh sieves (40 µm), washed with sterile water, and deposited onto Whatman paper to remove excess water. Mycelium was ground to a fine powder in liquid nitrogen using a mortar and pestle and stored at –80°C. Three grams of mycelium powder was transferred to a 50-ml tube, and DNA was extracted using a method adapted from Saghai-Maroof by the addition of two chloroform/octanol phases and the addition of 10 mg/ml RNase A. DNA concentration was assessed using spectrometric measurement (GeneQuant II, Pharmacia Biotech).', 0.08404450118541718]]
Context 6: [['Mycelia, grown for five days on PDA, were dried with sterile filter paper and collected in a sterile centrifuge tube. Mycelial powder was obtained using the trituration method in liquid nitrogen.', 0.07926895469427109]]
Context 7: [['Culture characteristics: Colonies on SNA are flat with an entire margin, hyaline to pale cinnamon, on filter paper partly pale saffron, and the agar medium is partly covered with very short white aerial mycelium.', 0.07217563688755035]]
Context 8: [['Culture Characteristics: Colonies on SNA are flat with an entire margin, hyaline to buff. On filter paper and Anthriscus stems, they are partly covered with woolly to felty white to pale grey aerial mycelium and orange acervuli. The reverse is hyaline to buff, and under filter paper, it appears pale olivaceous grey, with growth measuring 20 mm in 7 days (30 mm in 10 days). Colonies on OA are flat to raised with an entire margin, partly covered with woolly white to pale olivaceous grey aerial mycelium and olivaceous grey to orange acervuli appearing in rings. The reverse is buff, pale olivaceous grey to olivaceous grey with orange sectors, showing growth of 19–21 mm in 7 days (27.5–31 mm in 10 days). Conidia in mass are orange.', 0.06431259959936142]]
Context 9: [['Culture Characteristics: On SNA (Synthetic Nutrient Agar), the colonies are flat with an entire margin, hyaline in color, measuring 60–61 mm in diameter after 7 days (72–75 mm after 10 days). On PDA (Potato Dextrose Agar), colonies also appear flat, with an entire margin and color varying from buff honey to pinkish, exhibiting a green to grey margin and entirely covered with white aerial mycelium and black conidiomata. The reverse side shows buff to pale luteous to dark green coloration, measuring 69–71 mm in diameter after 7 days (80–82 mm after 10 days).', 0.0620063953101635]]

query: Why is ammonium nitrogen better than nitrate nitrogen for reducing Colletotrichum?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['The form of nitrogen significantly influenced both the severity of Fusarium crown and root rot and the growth of tomato seedlings in a soilless rockwool system (Fig. 1). Increasing concentrations of nitrate-N reduced disease severity and improved plant growth compared to ammonium forms. Both ammonium sulfate and ammonium chloride produced similar responses, indicating that NH4+ was the harmful component (Fig. 1). Ammonium nitrate has been reported to either have no effect on Fusarium diseases or to increase disease severity, similar to ammonium-N (Jones et al., 1989; Schneider, 1985). While this was generally true for Fusarium crown and root rot, testing a range of concentrations revealed that at low concentrations (10 to 100 mg·L–1 N), ammonium nitrate reduced disease similarly to nitrate-N (Figs. 1D, 2D). However, the negative influence of the NH4+ ion became apparent at concentrations above 125 mg·L–1 N (Figs. 1D, 2D). At higher concentrations, seedlings might have lacked sufficient available carbohydrates to convert the excess ammonium, which is toxic for tomato seedlings (Woltz et al., 1992), into nontoxic amino acids (Pate, 1973). Nitrates have long been recognized for their role in reducing seedling diseases caused by Rhizoctonia solani (Huber and Watson, 1974); however, contradictory results have been reported for Fusarium crown and root rot. Mihuta-Grimm et al. (1990) noted that nitrogen supplied as a 20N–20P–20K fertilizer had no effect on the growth of F. oxysporum f.sp. radicis-lycopersici in rockwool compared to non-fertilized treatments. Jarvis and Thorpe (1980) found no effect of nitrogen form (with total N applied unspecified) on disease or yield when adequate lime was provided to counteract potential pH effects. In fact, the differential effect of nitrogen form on pH is a significant mechanism for suppressing many soilborne pathogens (Huber and Watson, 1974). In contrast, Woltz et al. (1992) reported differences between nitrate and ammonium-N (each at 225 mg·L–1).', 0.6566478610038757]]
Context 1: [["Brooker et al.'s study on nitrate non-utilizing mutants of Colletotrichum (Phytopathology 81:672-677).", 0.4796248972415924]]
Context 2: [['Nitrogen is absorbed by plant roots in two forms: ammonium (NH4-N) and nitrate (NO3-N). Ammonium ions are produced in soils through the breakdown of organic matter (OM), manures, urea, or ammonium-containing fertilizers. Nitrate ions are the final form of nitrogen breakdown and reactions (excluding gaseous forms of nitrogen). They can also be supplied to the soil through fertilizers.', 0.3339911997318268]]
Context 3: [['Nitrogen can be lost from the soil in several ways, including volatilization, anaerobic denitrification, and leaching. Normally, ammonium does not leach from the soil because its positive charge is attracted to and “held” by the negative charges present on the surfaces of clay and humus particles. However, when ammonium is transformed into nitrate, it loses its positive charge, and the soil no longer retains the available nitrogen unless positive charges are present (anion exchange capacity). Water percolating through the soil profile may leach and deplete mobile nitrate from the upper layers to the lower layers and even into the groundwater if leaching is excessive. Such excessive nitrate leaching is often a consequence of inadequate nitrogen fertilizer management.', 0.25321170687675476]]
Context 4: [['Bremner, J. M., & Keeney, D. R. (1965). Steam Distillation Methods for Determination of Ammonium, Nitrate, and Nitrite. Anal. Chem. Acta, 32, 215–163.', 0.1408151537179947]]
Context 5: [[') ratio. Ammonium and nitrate, plus nitrite (NO2), are quantified through steam distillation of ammonia (NH3), utilizing heavy magnesium oxide (MgO) for ammonium and Devarda’s alloy for nitrate. The distillate is collected in saturated boric acid (H3BO3) and titrated to pH 5.0 with dilute sulfuric acid (H2SO4). This method determines dissolved and adsorbed forms of ammonium, nitrate, and nitrite in soils. The sum determined by this method is referred to as mineral nitrogen.', 0.13129118084907532]]
Context 6: [['Jones, Jr., J.B. 1991. Kjeldahl Method for Nitrogen Determination. Micro-Macro Publishing Inc., Athens, GA, USA.', 0.12971772253513336]]
Context 7: [['Nitrate is highly soluble in water, and various solutions, including water, have been used as extractants. Exchangeable ammonium can be extracted at room temperature with a neutral potassium salt solution. Various extractants at different molarities have been employed, such as 0.05 M K2SO4, 0.1 M KCl, 1 M KCl, and 2 M KCl.', 0.12325915694236755]]
Context 8: [['Bremner, J. M., & Mulvaney, C. S. (1982). Nitrogen Total. In A. L. Page (Ed.), Methods of Soil Analysis, Agron. No. 9, Part 2: Chemical and Microbiological Properties (2nd ed., pp. 595–624). American Society of Agronomy.', 0.11409196257591248]]
Context 9: [['This procedure encompasses both digestion and distillation. The soil sample is digested in concentrated H₂SO₄ with a catalyst mixture to increase the boiling temperature and facilitate the conversion of organic nitrogen to ammonium nitrogen (NH₄-N). The NH₄-N from the digest is extracted through steam distillation, utilizing excess sodium hydroxide (NaOH) to raise the pH. The distillate is then collected in a saturated boric acid (H₃BO₃) solution and titrated with dilute sulfuric acid (H₂SO₄) to a pH of 5.0. This method measures ammonium nitrogen, most forms of organic nitrogen, and a variable fraction of nitrate nitrogen in the soil. For most soils, the Kjeldahl procedure provides a reliable estimate of total soil nitrogen content. If necessary, nitrate nitrogen can be included via reduced iron or salicylic acid modifications of the Kjeldahl method (see the following section).', 0.11221415549516678]]
