Context 3: [['This table serves as a comprehensive reference for researchers studying these fungal species and their genetic diversity.', 0.21772898733615875]]
Context 4: [['Protein-coding genes and their introns often exhibit more variation than the internal transcribed spacer (ITS), and the need for secondary barcodes based on these genes has been discussed in relation to certain groups of fungi (Fitzpatrick et al. 2006; Aguileta et al. 2008; Weir & Johnston 2011). Ideally, one of the seven protein-coding genes used in this study could be proposed as a secondary barcode for accurately identifying species within the Colletotrichum gloeosporioides complex. A preliminary analysis of the performance of these genes as barcodes was conducted as part of Cai et al. (2009), where GAPDH, CAL, and ACT performed well, while CHS-1, ITS, and TEF (EF1α) performed poorly. However, the analysis by Cai et al. (2009) included only five species within the C. gloeosporioides complex, treating the Musae and Kahawae clades at the species level. With the final classification presented here, none of the genes analyzed provides an effective barcode on its own across the entire complex. Among the individual genes, TUB2, GS, and GAPDH are among the most effective at distinguishing species. However, C. clidemiae is polyphyletic in the TUB2 gene tree, and GS sequences are necessary to distinguish C. fructicola from C. alienum. With GS, C. aotearoa, C. kahawae subsp. ciggaro, and C. siamense are paraphyletic. GAPDH is the easiest of all the tested genes to amplify and sequence; however, when using this gene, GS sequences are needed to distinguish C. fructicola from C. alienum and C. aeschynomenes from C. siamense, while C. tropicale is paraphyletic. In the species descriptions, we provide notes on which genes are best for genetic identification. These summaries are presented in Table 4, which outlines the effectiveness of all species and genes. For species represented by a single or only a few isolates, the species boundaries may not be accurate; we recommend utilizing two protein-coding genes in addition to ITS for sequence-based identifications. A meta-analysis of DNA barcodes across the entire genus will be required to identify the combination of genes effective for distinguishing all Colletotrichum species.', 0.2138620913028717]]
Context 5: [['The closest match in BLASTn searches with the TUB2 sequence of strain CBS 198.35 (98% identity, 7 bp differences) was Glomerella acutata isolate PCF 459 (EU635504) from strawberry in Belgium (Debode et al. 2009), and with 98% identity (8 bp differences) to isolate PT250 (= CBS 129953) AJ748624 from olive in Portugal (see A6-1) (Talhinhas et al. 2005). This last strain is classified as C. rhombiforme in this study. The GAPDH sequence of strain CBS 198.35 showed no closer match from GenBank than 86% identity.', 0.21132414042949677]]
Context 6: [['Sequences derived in this study were lodged in GenBank (Table 1), the concatenated alignment and trees in TreeBASE (www.treebase.org) study number S12535, and taxonomic novelties in MycoBank (Crous et al. 2004).', 0.19656740128993988]]

Context 8: [['Regarding their informative potential, all newly developed primer pairs produced sequences that surpassed the commonly used ITS and two other gene fragments, β-tub2 and GS, which are regarded as fairly informative (Talhinhas et al. 2005, Prihastuti et al. 2009, Rojas et al. 2010). query: What happens to strawberries if the fungus isn't stopped?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [["Anthracnose fungi can attack various parts of the strawberry plant, including crowns, petioles, leaves, fruit trusses, flowers, buds, and fruit. The fungi's ability to attack multiple plant parts, coupled with the involvement of several pathogen species, contributes to the complex nature of strawberry anthracnose. Brooks reported in 1931 that C. fragariae caused spotting and girdling of runners, and later indicated that it also caused spotting of petioles and crown rot in a summer nursery, leading to wilting and death of the plants. Researchers in Louisiana observed all these symptoms and noted that crown rot also occurred in the fruit production field.", 0.3247561752796173]]
Context 1: [['The difficulty in controlling anthracnose crown rot arises from the fact that Colletotrichum spp. can kill strawberry plants after aggressively invading crown tissue, with a long latent period during which no symptoms are visible. Additionally, there are no long-term effective fungicides available, and the diverse origins of the causal agents are unpredictable (Peres et al., 2017; Forcelini and Peres, 2018; Hirayama et al., 2018). Furthermore, Colletotrichum spp. can be dispersed from asymptomatic plants over long distances, while relevant quarantine measures for strawberry trade are lacking in China. Recognizing the causal agents is a prerequisite for disease control. Initially, identification largely depended on morphological observation and virulence tests. Repeated in vitro subculturing of microbes can alter both their morphology and virulence. The fact that morphological characteristics can vary based on host choice or environmental conditions poses a significant concern for fungal identification. Strawberry anthracnose was first reported nearly a century ago (Brooks, 1931). Through PCR and DNA sequencing techniques, researchers have clarified the genetic distinctions among Colletotrichum spp. associated with strawberries, categorizing pathogens of worldwide origin into C. acutatum, C. fragariae, and C. gloeosporioides (Martínez-Culebras et al., 2000, 2003). However, ambiguously annotated data for Colletotrichum species frequently appear in GenBank, leading to confusion (Nilsson et al., 2006; Hyde et al., 2009). The emergence of multi-locus phylogeny has significantly aided in the identification of fungal species. Many pathologists and biologists have greatly expanded knowledge of Colletotrichum systematics (Cannon et al., 2012; Damm et al., 2012a, b; Weir et al., 2012), providing a solid foundation for future research. A landmark study corrected many synonymous names and offered a valuable reference for understanding Colletotrichum pathogens (Hyde et al., 2014). The delineation of Colletotrichum species and the description of new species continue to progress with the advent of novel technologies such as whole genome sequencing (Jayawardena et al., 2020, 2021; Bhunjun et al., 2021; Talhinhas and Baroncelli, 2021).', 0.3010255992412567]]
Context 2: [['Anthracnose is an important disease of strawberry caused by Colletotrichum spp., which affects foliage, runners, crowns, and fruits (Howard et al., 1992). Three primary fungal pathogens—C. acutatum sensu lato, C. gloeosporioides sensu lato, and C. fragariae—are known to cause anthracnose disease in strawberries (Freeman and Katan, 1997). The crown rot syndrome is characteristic of infections from C. gloeosporioides sensu lato and C. fragariae, while fruit rot is mainly attributed to C. acutatum sensu lato, leading to significant yield losses (Howard et al., 1992). Currently, numerous species are classified under what is now known as the C. acutatum complex, with six species—C. acutatum sensu stricto, C. fioriniae, C. godetiae, C. nymphaeae, C. salicis, and C. simmondsii—identified as associated with strawberry anthracnose worldwide (Damm et al., 2012). Among these, C. nymphaeae is the most prevalent pathogen causing strawberry anthracnose globally, including in Iran (Baroncelli et al., 2015; Karimi et al., 2017; Wang et al., 2019). Currently, no effective chemical control methods exist for managing strawberry anthracnose; available options are limited to preventive treatments applied before fruit production (Denoyes-Rothan et al., 1999). Additionally, concerns about the toxic effects of chemical fungicides on the environment and the development of resistance in fungal strains highlight the need for alternative control strategies. Consequently, utilizing resistant cultivars appears to be the most efficient and practical approach for suppressing anthracnose development. In light of recent anthracnose outbreaks in strawberry fields in the Kurdistan province of Iran (Karimi et al., 2017), and the necessity for appropriate strategies to address this issue, the aim of this study was to evaluate the resistance of several commercial strawberry cultivars to the anthracnose fruit rot caused by C. nymphaeae under in vivo and greenhouse conditions.', 0.2379348874092102]]
Context 3: [['Strawberries (Fragaria×ananassa Duch.) are a widely cultivated hybrid species within the Rosaceae family, renowned for their fruit. They are increasingly significant for the agricultural economic development of countries like Iran, particularly in the Kurdistan province, which leads in strawberry production, predominantly under open-field conditions (Tehranifar and Sarsaefi, 2002). Various biotic and abiotic factors contribute to the decline in strawberry production globally. Notably, over 100 fungal species can invade strawberry plants, with approximately one-third causing serious diseases on different plant parts (Martin and others).', 0.2316468209028244]]
Context 4: [['Anthracnose caused by Colletotrichum species is one of the most destructive diseases affecting strawberry production worldwide. Fungi of the genus Colletotrichum, which are ancient and co-evolved with flowering plants, rank eighth among the ten most economically important fungal pathogens and have diversified to adapt to various hosts. Since its first report in the United States in 1931, strawberry anthracnose has spread globally, resulting in devastating economic, social, and ecological consequences. In many ways, producing organic strawberries is largely impractical because of this disease. Colletotrichum species pathogenic to strawberries have been extensively characterized. This review aims to provide an accurate inventory of these species by revisiting their discovery history over the past 90 years. A total of 23 Colletotrichum species, clustered into five species complexes and two singleton taxa, have been accepted as strawberry pathogens with a global occurrence illustrated. The relative prevalence of distinct Colletotrichum species associated with strawberries has been systematically analyzed in China. Finally, the host range of the two prevailing species, C. fructicola and C. siamense, which cause significant damage globally, is summarized, with the goal of improving diagnostic accuracy and anthracnose management in agricultural ecosystems.', 0.21568408608436584]]
Context 5: [['Sommer, N.F., R.J. Fortlage, F.G. Mitchell, and E.C. Maxie. 1973. Reduction of postharvest loss of strawberry fruits from gray mold. J. Amer. Soc. Hort. Sci. 98:285–288.', 0.19879551231861115]]
Context 6: [['Jones, R. K., C. N. Clayton, and R. D. Milholland. 1977. Strawberry diseases and control. N.C.S.U. Plant Pathology Information Note 199.', 0.19309638440608978]]
Context 7: [['Mass JL. (1998). Compendium of Strawberry Diseases, 2nd Edition. U.S. Department of Agriculture, Beltsville, Maryland. APS Press.', 0.18190427124500275]]
Context 8: [['Maas, J. L. 1987. Compendium of Strawberry Diseases. The American Phytopathological Society, St. Paul, MN.', 0.1818600594997406]]
Context 9: [['Martin, R. R., and Spiegel, S. 1998. Compendium of Strawberry Diseases. 2nd Edition. American Phytopathological Society, St. Paul, MN, pp. 62-75.', 0.17847378551959991]]

Various biotic and abiotic factors contribute to the decline in strawberry production globally. Notably, over 100 fungal species can invade strawberry plants, with approximately one-third causing serious diseases on different plant parts (Martin and others).', 0.9242295622825623]]
Context 1: [['Strawberry (Fragaria × ananassa) is a major crop cultivated in China (Xie et al. 2010). The production of strawberries has rapidly expanded in recent years, positioning China as one of the world’s largest producers and exporters. As of 2013, strawberry cultivation covered 100.5 × 10^3 hectares, yielding 2.8 million tonnes (The Ministry of Agriculture of the People’s Republic of China 2014). However, with increased production, many fungal diseases have emerged as significant challenges, negatively impacting fruit yield and quality (Mass 1998, Smith 2008). Among these, anthracnose, caused by species of Colletotrichum, is one of the most critical diseases affecting strawberries.', 0.8711689114570618]]
Context 2: [['Although strawberries are considered a minor crop, they provide a significant source of income for many fruit and nursery growers. In the United States, strawberries were cultivated on nearly 20,000 hectares in 1989, yielding a total production of 555,000 tons valued at $520 million. Florida ranks second only to California in the production of fresh-market strawberries. For U.S. winter production (December through March), strawberries are grown on approximately 2,400 hectares. The major cultural problems faced by the Florida strawberry industry include: 1) anthracnose diseases, 2) yearly infestations of the two-spotted spider mite (Tetranychus urticae Koch), and 3) variability in the quality of nursery transplants. Commercial fields are established annually, similar to California practices. Freshly dug transplants are sourced from nurseries in Florida or from northern states and Canada. The use of transplants from northern nurseries is crucial to avoid anthracnose disease issues and to ensure that plants have undergone sufficient natural chilling to induce floral bud initiation.', 0.5108407735824585]]
Context 3: [['Korean strawberry production amounted to 1.23 billion won and 163 thousand tons in 2020. It ranked first among horticultural crops and is a primary income crop for farms. The hydroponic cultivation area for strawberries expanded to 1596 ha in 2020. Hydroponics using an artificial substrate can provide physical and chemical conditions suitable for nutrient absorption by plants. Intensive and effective crop management can be achieved through hydroponic techniques that supply nutrients using a nutrient solution in the substrates. In hydroponics, water supply control is performed to maintain...', 0.49261221289634705]]

query: What is the typical incubation period for anthracnose symptoms to appear on strawberries?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['From 2010 to 2016, we conducted surveys of anthracnose in strawberries in Miaoli County. More than 50% of diseased plants exhibited symptoms characteristic of anthracnose crown rot (ACR), as described by McInnes et al. (1992). ACR resulted in plant losses of up to 30-40% during the seedling stage and around 20% after transplanting. Initial symptoms in crown tissue included a marbled red and white appearance, which progressed to brown rot and eventual rapid wilting of the plant. Anthracnose symptoms also appeared on other parts of the plant, including leaves, petioles, runners, fruits, and roots. These symptoms manifested as circular black spots on leaves, withering and girdling on runners.', 0.9794124364852905]]
Context 1: [['From May to September 1995, a severe outbreak of strawberry anthracnose was observed in several strawberry-growing nurseries in Israel. Following transplantation to production fields during September and October, entire beds of strawberry plants collapsed. Typical anthracnose symptoms observed from November 1995 to June 1996 included crown rot, flower blight, and green and ripe fruit rot. This marked the first record of strawberry anthracnose in Israel. Furthermore, in at least four production fields in the same region, hundreds of plants developed symptoms of stunting and chlorosis, which are atypical of strawberry anthracnose. When these plants were uprooted, most of their roots were dark brown and decayed. Colletotrichum was readily isolated from these samples.', 0.9708296656608582]]
Context 2: [['In November 2021, anthracnose symptoms were observed on strawberries (cv. Kingsberry) in Nonsan, Chungnam Province. Early symptoms of anthracnose fruit rot (AFR) include blackening of specific tissues of the strawberry. These symptoms progress with the enlargement of lesions, which hinder proper fruit development and lead to the formation of orange-colored spores within the lesions. Similar symptoms were noted on the petioles, with sunken and blackened tissues similar to those on the fruit, accompanied by the formation of an orange conidial mass.', 0.9541082978248596]]
Context 3: [['Numerous reports indicate that strawberry anthracnose pathogens may originate from weed species. For instance, C. fragariae was found attacking the weed Cassia obtusifolia L. (sicklepod, coffeweed) in Florida, causing typical disease symptoms. Inoculation of strawberry with the Cassia isolates resulted in typical anthracnose symptoms, while isolates from strawberry were equally virulent on Cassia. Similarly, inoculation of Duchesnea indica (Andr.) Focke (wild strawberry), F. virginiana Duch. (Virginia wild strawberry), and Potentilla canadensis L. with C. fragariae induced anthracnose disease on these hosts, suggesting that strawberry anthracnose pathogens have a broad host range.', 0.9209602475166321]]
Context 4: [['Strawberry anthracnose can affect plants at any lifecycle stage, but plants are particularly susceptible at the seedling stage and immediately after planting (Wang et al. 2008). The disease primarily affects strawberry roots, petioles, and stolons, but can also infect flowers and fruit, leading to severe outbreaks (Mertely and Legard 2004). Symptoms include irregular ulcer-like lesions, reddish-brown stolons during initial stolon development, black spindle-shaped lesions on leaves and petioles, wilting, and dead roots (Debode et al. 2009; Freeman and Katan 1997). In Zhejiang, nearly 50% of seedling deaths and over 40% of production losses in nurseries are attributed to this disease (Xie et al. 2010). If environmental conditions are favorable, anthracnose can reduce strawberry yield by up to 80%. Transplants are considered the main source of primary inoculum, but the complete epidemiology of Colletotrichum spp. on strawberries in China remains unclear.', 0.8794221878051758]]
Context 5: [["Supplementary Figure S1 provides a visual representation of anthracnose symptoms on strawberry plants, depicting various stages and characteristics of infection. Panel (a) shows a strawberry plant affected by anthracnose crown rot, exhibiting chlorotic to blighted leaves and wilting. Panel (b) presents a longitudinal section of an infected crown, revealing marbled reddish-brown necrosis. Panel (c) illustrates black necrotic leaf spots, while panel (d) highlights withering and girdling on a runner. Panel (e) displays the fungal colony's initial white coloration, which later becomes light gray on the upper side. Finally, panel (f) shows conidia that are hyaline, oblong to cylindrical, with rounded obtuse ends, with a scale bar indicating a size of 10 μm.", 0.8025867938995361]]
Context 6: [['Anthracnose caused by Colletotrichum spp. is a significant threat to strawberry production, particularly in warm and humid climates. Rain-splashed conidia of Colletotrichum spp. serve as the primary inoculum that initiates epidemics of strawberry anthracnose disease. After landing on the plant surface, the conidia germinate, form appressoria, and then penetrate the epidermal cells. Colletotrichum spp. can infect various strawberry tissues, resulting in black or irregular spots on leaves, sunken black spots or necrotic lesions on petioles, stolons, and fruits, as well as wilting of the entire plant due to crown rot. Under high humidity, concentric rings of acervuli with orange conidial masses can be observed on necrotic tissues. In Florida, USA, anthracnose can lead to the death of up to 80% of seedlings in nurseries and yield losses exceeding 50% in fields. In Taiwan, strawberry seedlings are propagated from March to September, during which high temperatures, humidity, and heavy rainfall are prevalent.', 0.7562880516052246]]
Context 7: [['Species of the fungal plant pathogen Colletotrichum are responsible for strawberry (Fragaria × ananassa Duch.) anthracnose, one of the major diseases affecting this crop. Major species that cause strawberry anthracnose include C. acutatum J.H. Simmons, C. fragariae Brooks, and C. gloeosporioides (Penz.) Penz. & Sacc. Symptoms of the disease manifest in various phases. Infection of mother plants with anthracnose may result in the collapse of the entire plant due to crown rot. In the nursery, lesions form on stolons that eventually girdle the runners, leading to wilting and death of unrooted daughter plants distal to the lesion. Death of daughter plants in the nursery and in field transplants can also be caused by crown rot. Infected transplants are capable of spreading the disease from the nursery to the field, and entire crops can be destroyed by anthracnose in strawberry fruit production fields under conducive environmental conditions.', 0.6578093767166138]]
Context 8: [['Anthracnose is an important disease of strawberry caused by Colletotrichum spp., which affects foliage, runners, crowns, and fruits (Howard et al., 1992). Three primary fungal pathogens—C. acutatum sensu lato, C. gloeosporioides sensu lato, and C. fragariae—are known to cause anthracnose disease in strawberries (Freeman and Katan, 1997). The crown rot syndrome is characteristic of infections from C. gloeosporioides sensu lato and C. fragariae, while fruit rot is mainly attributed to C. acutatum sensu lato, leading to significant yield losses (Howard et al., 1992). Currently, numerous species are classified under what is now known as the C. acutatum complex, with six species—C. acutatum sensu stricto, C. fioriniae, C. godetiae, C. nymphaeae, C. salicis, and C. simmondsii—identified as associated with strawberry anthracnose worldwide (Damm et al., 2012). Among these, C. nymphaeae is the most prevalent pathogen causing strawberry anthracnose globally, including in Iran (Baroncelli et al., 2015; Karimi et al., 2017; Wang et al., 2019). Currently, no effective chemical control methods exist for managing strawberry anthracnose; available options are limited to preventive treatments applied before fruit production (Denoyes-Rothan et al., 1999). Additionally, concerns about the toxic effects of chemical fungicides on the environment and the development of resistance in fungal strains highlight the need for alternative control strategies. Consequently, utilizing resistant cultivars appears to be the most efficient and practical approach for suppressing anthracnose development. In light of recent anthracnose outbreaks in strawberry fields in the Kurdistan province of Iran (Karimi et al., 2017), and the necessity for appropriate strategies to address this issue, the aim of this study was to evaluate the resistance of several commercial strawberry cultivars to the anthracnose fruit rot caused by C. nymphaeae under in vivo and greenhouse conditions.', 0.56328284740448]]
Context 9: [['Figure 1 depicts the symptoms of strawberry anthracnose, showing various stages of infection: (a) wilted seedling plants at the early disease stage in a greenhouse, (b) wilted and dead plants in the field, (c) dead plants with crown rot symptoms, and (d) reddish-brown tissue of a strawberry crown infected by Colletotrichum sp.', 0.4996112287044525]]

Context 4: [['Consensus sequences from the sequences generated using forward and reverse primers were obtained using DNAStar v.5.1 and SeqMan v.5.00 (Burland, 2000). A combined dataset of the five gene regions was prepared using Clustal X v.1.81 (Thompson et al., 1997). Further alignment of sequences was achieved using default settings in MAFFT v.7 (Katoh & Toh, 2008, http://mafft.cbrc.jp/alignment/server/), and manual adjustments were made using BioEdit v.7.0.9.0 (Hall, 1999) where necessary. Two separate phylogenetic trees were constructed: one for the acutatum species complex and another for the gloeosporioides species complex. Maximum Parsimony analysis (MP) was performed using PAUP v. 4.0b10 (Swofford, 2002) to obtain the most parsimonious trees. Gaps were treated as missing data, and ambiguously aligned regions were excluded. Trees were inferred using the heuristic search option with Tree Bisection Reconnection (TBR) branch swapping and 1,000 random sequence additions. A maximum of 5,000 trees were set up, branches of zero length were collapsed, and all multiple parsimonious trees were saved. Descriptive tree statistics for parsimony—Tree Length (TL), Consistency Index (CI), Retention Index (RI), Rescaled Consistency Index (RC), and Homoplasy Index (HI)—were calculated for trees generated under different optimality criteria. The robustness of the most parsimonious trees was evaluated by 1,000 bootstrap replications resulting from the maximum parsimony analysis (Hillis & Bull, 1993). Kishino-Hasegawa tests (KHT) (Kishino & Hasegawa, 1989) were performed to determine whether the trees were significantly different. Bayesian inference (BI) was also employed to construct the phylogenies using MrBayes v.3.1.2 (Ronquist et al., 2003). MrModeltest v.2.3 (Nylander, 2004) was used to select the best-fit model of nucleotide substitution. The HYK+I model was selected for ITS, a HKY+G model for GAPDH and β-tubulin, a K80+I+G model for CHS-1, and a GTR+G model for ACT were incorporated into the analysis. Six simultaneous Markov chains were run for 1,000,000 generations, and trees were sampled every 100th generation. The 2,000 trees representing the burn-in phase of the analyses were discarded, and the remaining 8,000 trees were used to calculate posterior probabilities (PP) in the majority rule consensus tree. The alignments and trees are deposited in TreeBASE (Sanderson et al., 1994) under accession number S20238.', 0.28096216917037964]]

Context 8: [['To determine whether the seven sequence datasets were congruent and combinable, we visually compared tree topologies based on 70% reciprocal Neighbour-Joining bootstrap with Maximum Likelihood distances (10,000 replicates). Substitution models for each partition were determined separately using MrModeltest v. 2.3 (Nylander 2004), following the methodology outlined by Mason-Gamer & Kellogg (1996). A maximum parsimony analysis was conducted on the multilocus alignment (ITS, ACT, TUB2, CHS-1, GAPDH, HIS3, CAL) using PAUP (Phylogenetic Analysis Using Parsimony) v. 4.0b10 (Swofford, 2000). The analysis employed a heuristic search option with 100 random sequence additions and tree bisection and reconstruction (TBR) as the branch-swapping algorithm. Alignment gaps were treated as missing data, and all characters were unordered and of equal weight. The robustness of the resulting trees was evaluated using 500 bootstrap replications with two random sequence additions (Hillis & Bull 1993). Tree length, consistency index (CI), retention index (RI), rescaled consistency index (RC), and homoplasy index (HI) were calculated for the resulting trees. A Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) algorithm was used to generate phylogenetic trees with Bayesian probabilities using MrBayes v. 3.1.1 (Ronquist & Huelsenbeck 2003) for the combined sequence datasets. Models of nucleotide substitution for each gene, as determined by MrModeltest v. 2.3, were applied to each gene partition. Two MCMC chains were run from random trees for one million generations, with sampling every 100 generations. The likelihood scores for the two runs were 2,730 and 2,170. Consequently, the first 2,450 trees (the average of both) were discarded as part of the burn-in phase, and posterior probabilities were determined from the remaining trees. Context 6: [['Strawberry anthracnose can affect plants at any lifecycle stage, but plants are particularly susceptible at the seedling stage and immediately after planting (Wang et al. 2008). query: What challenges are associated with the morphological identification of Colletotrichum species?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['In a drastic move, von Arx (1957) reduced the number of recognized Colletotrichum species from several hundred to 11 based on morphological characteristics, with many taxa treated as synonyms of C. gloeosporioides and C. dematium. Several additional species have since been accepted based on morphological criteria (Sutton, 1980; 1992). The difficulties in recognizing Colletotrichum species can be attributed to: 1) the limited and variable morphological characters; 2) an extensive host range and variability in pathogenicity (Bailey and Jeger, 1992; Freeman et al., 2000; Latunde-Dada, 2001; Du et al., 2005; Thaung, 2008); 3) type specimens that are often missing or in poor condition, making them unsuitable for molecular studies; and 4) numerous rDNA ITS sequences of Colletotrichum strains in NCBI that are often misidentified (Crouch et al., 2009d; Damm et al., 2009).', 0.9947307109832764]]
Context 1: [['Traditionally, Colletotrichum species are identified based on morphological characteristics, including conidial and appressorial size and shape, the presence of acervuli, setae, or sclerotia, sexual structures, and cultural traits such as growth rate and colony color. Distinguishing Colletotrichum species morphologically has been challenging due to their phenotypic similarities and the influence of variable environmental factors on the expression of morphological traits. Consequently, all available morphological characteristics are often combined and used for systematic species discrimination.', 0.9938637018203735]]
Context 2: [['Despite significant developments over the last ten years, the taxonomy of Colletotrichum is in a state of flux. Many uncertainties exist in the systematics of fungal pathogens from this genus; depending on the taxonomic "guides," the number of species can range from 29 to over 700 (von Arx, 1957; Sutton, 1992). One of the most confusing species is C. gloeosporioides. For example, 594 species of Colletotrichum were reclassified by von Arx as synonyms of C. gloeosporioides. Identification has primarily relied on morphological characteristics of conidia, vegetative and sexual structures, as well as host specificity and cultural characteristics (von Arx, 1957). Unfortunately, conidial morphology and colony characteristics vary even within isolates. Consequently, classical methods have been supplemented with biochemical and molecular technologies to differentiate Colletotrichum species (J. W. Kronstad, ed., Fungal Pathology, 127-148. © 2000 Kluwer Academic Publishers). For a more complete discussion of this topic, see Sherriff et al. (1994).', 0.9747009873390198]]
Context 3: [['Cano, J., Guarro, J., and Gene, J. (2004). Molecular and morphological identification of Colletotrichum species of clinical interest. Journal of Clinical Microbiology 42: 2450-2454.', 0.9490379095077515]]
Context 4: [['Before the molecular era, the taxonomy of Colletotrichum species was primarily based on morphological and cultural characteristics, including conidia size and shape, presence or absence of setae, colony color, and growth rate (von Arx 1957; Sutton 1980, 1992). However, these characteristics can be unreliable for species differentiation due to variability under changing environmental conditions (Cai et al. 2009).', 0.859616756439209]]
Context 5: [['Photita, W., Taylor, P. W., Ford, R., Hyde, K. D., and Lumyong, S. (2005). Morphological and molecular characterization of Colletotrichum species from...', 0.6883304715156555]]
Context 6: [['Much has been written about various individual species of Colletotrichum, yet in many cases, the name used represents a species complex, and it is unclear which actual species is involved. In the following section, we review three species of Colletotrichum to highlight the problems associated with inadequate knowledge of the species and potential incorrect or inaccurate naming.', 0.5818074345588684]]
Context 7: [['Noireung P, Phoulivong S, Liu F, et al. (2012). Novel species of Colletotrichum revealed by morphology and molecular analysis. Cryptogamie Mycologie, 33: 347–362.', 0.4725438952445984]]

query: How does the use of plasticulture affect the economic and environmental aspects of strawberry farming?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['In Korea, strawberries (Fragaria × ananassa) are favored for winter cultivation when the production of other vegetables and fruits is relatively low. In 2003, strawberries were planted on a total area of 7,503 hectares in Korea, with plastic greenhouse cultivation comprising 7,172 hectares and a total production of 205,427 tonnes for the fresh market (Anonymous, 2004). Forcing, where strawberries are transplanted into greenhouses in mid-September and induced to fruit in December (Oda, 1991), is becoming more common in Korea. June-bearing cultivars such as Maehyang, Akihime, and Nyoho, used for forcing, have proven difficult to grow due to their susceptibility to anthracnose (Nam et al., 1998; Kim & Nam, 1999). Anthracnose is one of the most damaging diseases of strawberries, causing wilting and death of transplants in the nursery field. The pathogen responsible for the disease in Korea is Colletotrichum gloeosporioides, first reported in 1992 (Kim et al., 1992).', 0.29822906851768494]]
Context 1: [['Chandler, C.K., Albregts, E.E., Brecht, J.K., and Howard, C.M. 1997. ‘Sweet Charlie’ Strawberry. HortScience, 32: 1132-1133.', 0.17335014045238495]]
Context 2: [['Strawberries (Fragaria×ananassa Duch.) are a widely cultivated hybrid species within the Rosaceae family, renowned for their fruit. query: To what extent does the presence of the sexual stage (Glomerella) in C. gloeosporioides contribute to genetic diversity and pathogenicity?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['The existence of the teleomorph Glomerella may sometimes help in differentiating between species; however, the sexual stage has only been observed in some isolates of C. gloeosporioides from avocado (T. Katan and S. Freeman, unpublished), but not from almond. In contrast to the morphological heterogeneity observed among C. gloeosporioides isolates from avocado, the population originating from almond in Israel had uniformly growing white-to-gray colonies. It can be concluded that colony color and shape of conidia are unsatisfactory methods for species identification, primarily due to the diversity of these characteristics in C. gloeosporioides, which is indicative of its heterogeneity.', 0.9809884428977966]]
Context 1: [['This paper aims to clarify the genetic and taxonomic relationships within the C. gloeosporioides species complex using a diverse set of isolates that samples its genetic, biological, and geographic diversity. Type specimens or cultures derived from type specimens have been examined whenever possible. Although we do not treat all names placed in synonymy with C. gloeosporioides or Glomerella cingulata by von Arx & Müller (1954) and von Arx (1957, 1970), we do include all names that have been suggested to have a close relationship with C. gloeosporioides in recent literature, along with all subspecific taxa and formae speciales within C. gloeosporioides and G. cingulata.', 0.7128479480743408]]
Context 2: [['In the case of the Colletotrichum gloeosporioides complex, sexual compatibility has been reported to be limited to individuals sharing the same host range (Brasier, 1987). Cisar et al. (1994) discovered that some isolates of C. gloeosporioides, pathogenic to distantly related hosts, are also sexually compatible. This finding aligns with studies on C. acutatum, indicating that genetically isolated strains may retain the ability to mate. Similar findings have been reported for Fusarium and other fungi (Donoghue, 1985; Taylor et al., 2000; Leslie et al., 2001; Amata et al., in press).', 0.6433113813400269]]
Context 3: [['C. gloeosporioides occurs in many crops and is a species aggregate that includes several polymorphic subgroups exhibiting varying degrees of pathogenicity, host specificity, and genetic homogeneity (Hyde et al., 2009a). The recent epitypification of C. gloeosporioides has facilitated accurate classification through comparative analysis.', 0.6405349373817444]]
Context 4: [['C. gloeosporioides is a highly variable species, as evidenced by its morphological traits and molecular markers. Furthermore, some strains of C. gloeosporioides/G. cingulata from avocado produce the sexual stage in culture, suggesting that they may also reproduce sexually.', 0.4374561011791229]]
Context 5: [['For the first time, four European isolates of Colletotrichum gloeosporioides from strawberry, which have been rarely observed, were included in a study of genetic polymorphism and pathogenic variability. The RAPD patterns of all 14 isolates of C. gloeosporioides showed a high level of polymorphism, as previously described. Because isolates of C. gloeosporioides from strawberry collected in Europe and the United States were closely related genetically, it is possible that the C. gloeosporioides isolates pathogenic on strawberry were also introduced into Europe from North America through plant trade, similar to what has been suggested for C. acutatum. The dissemination of C. gloeosporioides and C. acutatum through plant exchanges between Europe and the United States, along with genetic and pathogenic variation within both species, could be further investigated using Californian and European isolates of C. acutatum and C. gloeosporioides.', 0.427628755569458]]
Context 6: [['Although C. gloeosporioides infects hundreds of different plant species, individual strains may have restricted host ranges, as demonstrated by a clonal subpopulation of C. gloeosporioides from almond grown in Israel. It is often presumed that host-specific populations reproduce only asexually; however, certain isolates of C. gloeosporioides with different host specificities have been observed to mate under laboratory conditions. Highly variable populations are generally more adaptable to changing conditions than those with limited variation, and sexual reproduction and recombination play a significant role in the genetic variability observed in fungal populations.', 0.36706623435020447]]
Context 7: [['An attempt was made to sample the genetic diversity of Colletotrichum gloeosporioides as broadly as possible. Isolates from diverse hosts around the world were selected for more intensive study. A BLAST search of GenBank using the ITS sequence of the epitype culture of C. gloeosporioides (Cannon et al. 2008) provided a coarse estimate for the genetic limits of the C. gloeosporioides complex. The ITS diversity across the complex was utilized to select a genetically diverse set of isolates. Voucher cultures were obtained from the research groups that deposited the GenBank records. In addition to these, isolates representing the known genetic and morphological diversity of C. gloeosporioides from New Zealand were included. These isolates were collected from rots of both native and introduced fruits, from diseased exotic weeds, and as endophytes from the leaves of native podocarps. Additional isolates, representing ex-type and authentic cultures of as many named taxa and formae speciales within the C. gloeosporioides complex as possible, were sourced from international culture collections. Approximately 400 isolates belonging to the C. gloeosporioides complex were obtained. GAPDH gene sequences were generated for all isolates as an initial measure of genetic diversity. A subset of 156 isolates, selected to represent a range of genetic, geographic, and host plant diversity, was used in this research (see Table 1).', 0.30624860525131226]]
Context 8: [['Notes: Sawada (1922) provided an English translation of his original description. This species was described as a stem pathogen of Boehmeria nivea and remains recognized in this context (e.g., Li & Ma 1993). Wang et al. (2010) cite several GenBank accessions from isolates they identify as C. gloeosporioides, which cause severe disease in Boehmeria. Based on a comparison of the GenBank data with our ITS gene tree, these and other isolates from the same host deposited by the same authors (GQ120479–GQ120499) appear to represent three different taxa within the C. gloeosporioides complex — C. gloeosporioides s. str., C. aotearoa, and C. fructicola. Isolates representative of all three taxa are reportedly pathogenic on Boehmeria (Wang et al. 2010). The genetic relationships of these fungi need to be confirmed using additional genes.', 0.2930138409137726]]
Context 9: [["Colletotrichum gloeosporioides f. gloeosporioides and f. stylosanthis were distinguished by Munaut et al. (2002) based on specific isolates. The species complex is characterized by genetic variability, with some isolates exhibiting a specific string of C's in the ITS1 region.", 0.28239113092422485]]

query: What are the key morphological features used to differentiate Colletotrichum species?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Despite significant developments over the last ten years, the taxonomy of Colletotrichum is in a state of flux. Many uncertainties exist in the systematics of fungal pathogens from this genus; depending on the taxonomic "guides," the number of species can range from 29 to over 700 (von Arx, 1957; Sutton, 1992). One of the most confusing species is C. gloeosporioides. For example, 594 species of Colletotrichum were reclassified by von Arx as synonyms of C. gloeosporioides. Identification has primarily relied on morphological characteristics of conidia, vegetative and sexual structures, as well as host specificity and cultural characteristics (von Arx, 1957). Unfortunately, conidial morphology and colony characteristics vary even within isolates. Consequently, classical methods have been supplemented with biochemical and molecular technologies to differentiate Colletotrichum species (J. W. Kronstad, ed., Fungal Pathology, 127-148. © 2000 Kluwer Academic Publishers). For a more complete discussion of this topic, see Sherriff et al. (1994).', 0.989401638507843]]
Context 1: [['Traditionally, Colletotrichum species are identified based on morphological characteristics, including conidial and appressorial size and shape, the presence of acervuli, setae, or sclerotia, sexual structures, and cultural traits such as growth rate and colony color. Distinguishing Colletotrichum species morphologically has been challenging due to their phenotypic similarities and the influence of variable environmental factors on the expression of morphological traits. Consequently, all available morphological characteristics are often combined and used for systematic species discrimination.', 0.9873172640800476]]
Context 2: [['Before the molecular era, the taxonomy of Colletotrichum species was primarily based on morphological and cultural characteristics, including conidia size and shape, presence or absence of setae, colony color, and growth rate (von Arx 1957; Sutton 1980, 1992). However, these characteristics can be unreliable for species differentiation due to variability under changing environmental conditions (Cai et al. 2009).', 0.9785465598106384]]
Context 3: [['Traditional identification systems in Colletotrichum have heavily relied on morphological and cultural characteristics (von Arx, 1957; Sutton, 1980, 1992; Bailey and Jeger, 1992; Freeman et al., 1998). Sutton (1992) noted that morphology alone does not provide sufficient information for precise identification, especially for species within the C. gloeosporioides and C. dematium complexes. Crouch et al. (2009b) argued that conidial size and shape, along with conidial appressoria, were taxonomically uninformative and of limited use for species diagnosis in graminicolous Colletotrichum species. Species with similar morphological characteristics may exhibit considerable variation at the physiological and pathogenic levels, making this recognition crucial for biosecurity, plant breeding, and integrated disease management. Taxonomy based solely on morphology is likely to result in ambiguity. Recent studies have shown that morphological characters should be used in conjunction with other characters to establish species relationships within Colletotrichum (Crouch et al., 2009b; Prihastuti et al., 2009).', 0.9721338152885437]]
Context 4: [['In a drastic move, von Arx (1957) reduced the number of recognized Colletotrichum species from several hundred to 11 based on morphological characteristics, with many taxa treated as synonyms of C. gloeosporioides and C. dematium. Several additional species have since been accepted based on morphological criteria (Sutton, 1980; 1992). The difficulties in recognizing Colletotrichum species can be attributed to: 1) the limited and variable morphological characters; 2) an extensive host range and variability in pathogenicity (Bailey and Jeger, 1992; Freeman et al., 2000; Latunde-Dada, 2001; Du et al., 2005; Thaung, 2008); 3) type specimens that are often missing or in poor condition, making them unsuitable for molecular studies; and 4) numerous rDNA ITS sequences of Colletotrichum strains in NCBI that are often misidentified (Crouch et al., 2009d; Damm et al., 2009).', 0.9710595011711121]]
Context 5: [['Species concepts in Colletotrichum have evolved from the use of basic morphological data to a polyphasic approach that incorporates a significant molecular component. This evolution has made traditional classifications less practical, as holotypes and other types are not very useful since DNA cannot usually be extracted. It is recommended that future studies adopt a polyphasic approach before introducing new species of Colletotrichum or designating epitypes. This approach should integrate molecular, morphological, physiological, and pathogenic data.', 0.811650276184082]]
Context 6: [['Cano, J., Guarro, J., and Gene, J. (2004). Molecular and morphological identification of Colletotrichum species of clinical interest. Journal of Clinical Microbiology 42: 2450-2454.', 0.8065505623817444]]
Context 7: [['Photita, W., Taylor, P. W., Ford, R., Hyde, K. D., and Lumyong, S. (2005). Morphological and molecular characterization of Colletotrichum species from...', 0.74711674451828]]
Context 8: [['Noireung P, Phoulivong S, Liu F, et al. (2012). Novel species of Colletotrichum revealed by morphology and molecular analysis. Cryptogamie Mycologie, 33: 347–362.', 0.5898954272270203]]
Context 9: [['The genus Colletotrichum is considered one of the top ten important genera of fungal pathogens globally (Dean et al., 2012). Colletotrichum is an ancient fungus that has co-evolved with flowering plants. Plant microfossils of Protocolletotrichum preserved on angiosperm leaf cuticles suggest that the diverse pathogenic strategies of Colletotrichum spp. have been established since the Late Cretaceous period (Kar et al., 2004). Different complexes within the genus may have diverged between 4.8 and 32.2 million years ago (MYA) (Bhunjun et al., 2021). The emergence of agricultural cultivation and the intensive disturbance of natural environments have further driven the diversification of Colletotrichum species. These fungi have adapted to thousands of hosts and can be found as endophytes, pathogens, and saprobes (Freeman et al., 1998; Dean et al., 2012; Hirayama et al., 2018; da Silva et al., 2020; Jayawardena et al., 2020). Currently, a total of 257 Colletotrichum species grouped into 15 complexes and 13 additional singletons have been accepted in this genus.', 0.5410509705543518]]

query: Can irrigation methods influence the spread of anthracnose?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Anthracnose spreads within a field by splashing water, and living mulches (such as wheat, rye, or ryegrass) in row middles have been shown to reduce disease spread within a field. Sublethal doses of grass-specific herbicides, such as sethoxydim, may be used to prevent excessive growth of ryegrass (Gupton, 2000). Organic mulches, such as wheat straw or pine needles, also reduce splash and result in a lower incidence of anthracnose compared to rows mulched with plastic (Madden, 1992; Smith and Spiers, 1986). Anthracnose is less severe when water is supplied to plants using drip irrigation rather than overhead irrigation (Madden, 1992; Smith and Spiers, 1986).', 0.9191384315490723]]
Context 1: [['Anthracnose spreads within a field by splashing water, and living mulches (such as wheat, rye, or ryegrass) in row middles have been shown to reduce disease spread within a field. Sublethal doses of grass-specific herbicides, such as sethoxydim, may be used to prevent excessive growth of ryegrass (Gupton, 2000). Organic mulches, such as wheat straw or pine needles, also reduce splash and result in a lower incidence of anthracnose compared to rows mulched with plastic (Madden, 1992; Smith and Spiers, 1986). Additionally, anthracnose is less severe when water is supplied to plants using drip irrigation rather than overhead irrigation (Madden, 1992; Smith and Spiers, 1986). Anthracnose crown rot was observed to be less severe in commercial fields when strawberries were grown in soils with low nitrogen fertility (Howard et al., 1992). In greenhouse studies, Smith (1987, 1989) determined that strawberries grown in soils with high levels of nitrogen, especially from ammonium sources, are more susceptible to anthracnose than plants grown in soils with lower nitrogen levels or those with high levels of calcium nitrate.', 0.9151212573051453]]
Context 2: [['Anthracnose spreads within a field through splashing water. Living mulches, such as wheat, rye, or rye grass, in row middles have been shown to reduce disease spread. query: How does continuous monocropping affect the severity of Colletotrichum diseases?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Many species belonging to the genus Colletotrichum are associated with plant diseases, commonly referred to as anthracnose. Colletotrichum spp. can affect a wide range of hosts, and these pathogens are characterized by global distribution. Virtually every cultivated botanical family is susceptible to one or more species of Colletotrichum, making it one of the most studied plant pathogenic fungi (Prusky et al., 2000; Latunde-Dada, 2001; Dean et al., 2012). Common hosts include many dicotyledonous plants such as strawberry, apple, citrus, and stone fruits, as well as major cereals such as maize and sorghum. Members of this genus can cause crop losses of up to 100% in many staple foods (Bailey and Jeger, 1992; Prusky et al., 2000; Talhinhas et al., 2005; Cannon et al., 2012).', 0.3231523334980011]]
Context 1: [['Colletotrichum species are economically important plant pathogens, particularly in tropical, subtropical, and temperate regions, where they affect a wide range of plant hosts (Sutton 1992). The typical symptoms of Colletotrichum infections include sunken necrotic lesions, often bearing orange conidial masses, referred to as anthracnose (Freeman et al. 1998). The impact of these pathogens on fruit crops is significant, causing severe yield losses; for example, bitter rot is one of the most critical diseases affecting apple fruit, potentially leading to yield losses of up to 50% (Sutton 1990).', 0.2527483105659485]]
Context 2: [['Waller, J.M.; Bridge, P.D. "Recent advances in understanding Colletotrichum diseases of some tropical perennial crops." query: What are the main challenges in controlling fungal pathogens in strawberry crops?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Strawberry (Fragaria × ananassa) is a major crop cultivated in China (Xie et al. 2010). The production of strawberries has rapidly expanded in recent years, positioning China as one of the world’s largest producers and exporters. As of 2013, strawberry cultivation covered 100.5 × 10^3 hectares, yielding 2.8 million tonnes (The Ministry of Agriculture of the People’s Republic of China 2014). However, with increased production, many fungal diseases have emerged as significant challenges, negatively impacting fruit yield and quality (Mass 1998, Smith 2008). Among these, anthracnose, caused by species of Colletotrichum, is one of the most critical diseases affecting strawberries.', 0.9213045835494995]]
Context 1: [['Strawberry anthracnose was first reported in China in 1990 (Hu, 1990). Shao (1992) documented the first instance of strawberry anthracnose in Shanghai, identifying the pathogen as Colletotrichum acutatum (Dai et al., 2006). Zhang et al. (2007) expanded on these findings by identifying C. gloeosporioides and C. fragariae (syn. C. theobromicola) as causal agents based on morphological characteristics. Ren et al. (2008, 2011) concluded that these three species are the main pathogens causing anthracnose in strawberries in China. Crown rot represents the most severe disease issue in many strawberry-producing regions of China (Ren et al., 2008). In the Zhejiang region, nearly 50% of seedling deaths in nurseries and over 40% yield losses in strawberry fields have been recorded (Xie et al., 2010). In 2009, the yield of greenhouse-cultivated strawberries in Donggang City, Liaoning Province, was reduced by over 10% due to crown rot (Wang, 2013). The average incidence of crown rot in greenhouses in Hubei Province was 41.7% in 2011 (Xiang et al., 2012). However, most studies conducted in China regarding this disease have primarily relied on morphological and single-gene (mainly ITS) analysis (Dai et al., 2006; Ren et al., 2008, 2011). Due to overlapping characteristics, species delimitation based solely on morphology is challenging in this genus. Employing multi-gene analysis alongside morphology can provide better resolution (Cai et al., 2009; Hyde et al., 2014). Therefore, the objective of this study was to identify the pathogens responsible for strawberry anthracnose in China using a morphological and multi-gene approach.', 0.5342645049095154]]
Context 2: [['Strawberries (Fragaria×ananassa Duch.) are a widely cultivated hybrid species within the Rosaceae family, renowned for their fruit. They are increasingly significant for the agricultural economic development of countries like Iran, particularly in the Kurdistan province, which leads in strawberry production, predominantly under open-field conditions (Tehranifar and Sarsaefi, 2002). Various biotic and abiotic factors contribute to the decline in strawberry production globally. Notably, over 100 fungal species can invade strawberry plants, with approximately one-third causing serious diseases on different plant parts (Martin and others).', 0.4290795624256134]]
Context 3: [['Jones, R. K., C. N. Clayton, and R. D. Milholland. 1977. Strawberry diseases and control. N.C.S.U. Plant Pathology Information Note 199.', 0.2907384932041168]]
Context 4: [['Strawberry anthracnose is a significant disease in China, leading to considerable economic losses. Several species of Colletotrichum are recognized as pathogens of strawberry. A survey of strawberry fields across eight provinces in China was conducted to identify the causal agents of this disease. The disease primarily manifests as crown rot, causing plant wilting and death during the nursery stage and after transplanting in greenhouses, making anthracnose a major threat to strawberry production and quality.', 0.2465091496706009]]
Context 5: [['Martin, R. R., and Spiegel, S. 1998. Compendium of Strawberry Diseases. 2nd Edition. American Phytopathological Society, St. Paul, MN, pp. 62-75.', 0.23739922046661377]]
Context 6: [['Although strawberries are considered a minor crop, they provide a significant source of income for many fruit and nursery growers. In the United States, strawberries were cultivated on nearly 20,000 hectares in 1989, yielding a total production of 555,000 tons valued at $520 million. Florida ranks second only to California in the production of fresh-market strawberries. For U.S. winter production (December through March), strawberries are grown on approximately 2,400 hectares. The major cultural problems faced by the Florida strawberry industry include: 1) anthracnose diseases, 2) yearly infestations of the two-spotted spider mite (Tetranychus urticae Koch), and 3) variability in the quality of nursery transplants. Commercial fields are established annually, similar to California practices. Freshly dug transplants are sourced from nurseries in Florida or from northern states and Canada. The use of transplants from northern nurseries is crucial to avoid anthracnose disease issues and to ensure that plants have undergone sufficient natural chilling to induce floral bud initiation.', 0.23389267921447754]]
Context 7: [['Strand, L. L. 2008. Integrated Pest Management for Strawberries, 2nd Ed. University of California, Oakland.', 0.23348431289196014]]
Context 8: [['Maas, J.L. 1998. Compendium of Strawberry Diseases. 2nd ed. Saint Paul: The American Phytopathological Society.', 0.22943423688411713]]
Context 9: [['Maas, J. L. (Ed.). (1984). Compendium of Strawberry Diseases. American Phytopathological Society, St. Paul, MN.', 0.22845779359340668]]

query: How does heat treatment work for controlling plant diseases?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['In the United States, a standard heat treatment (5 minutes at 49°C) is practiced for bare-rooted transplants to control foliar nematodes and anthracnose. In this study, the heat treatment did not visibly harm transplants and significantly reduced mortality caused by C. acutatum. However, it may adversely affect plant vigor, especially for transplants meant for production fields. While this treatment could serve as an alternative to chemical fungicides, its long-term impacts on plant development and yield require further investigation. Nonchemical control methods might help minimize the emergence of fungicide-tolerant or resistant fungal strains.', 0.8978846669197083]]
Context 1: [['Plant Disease, July 2018, 1289.', 0.24288222193717957]]
Context 2: [['The experimental period involved light intensities ranging from 40% to 80%, with daylight intensity fluctuating between 550 and 1200 µmol m−2 s−1. The inoculated plants were treated with a solution containing 2 mL−1 of the inoculum and subsequently placed in a dew chamber set at 30 °C and 100% relative humidity (RH) for 2 days. Following this incubation, they were moved to a glasshouse maintained at temperatures between 24 and 28 °C (Gupton & Smith, 1991). After 17 days, the disease severity on each plant was assessed and rated on a disease index (DI) scale of 0 to 4, defined as follows: 0 for healthy plants; 1 for less than 50% of petioles affected; 2 for 50% or more petioles affected; 3 for wilted plants; and 4 for complete necrosis.', 0.12537573277950287]]
Context 3: [['Do not include diseased or dead plant material in a sample.', 0.11826121062040329]]
Context 4: [['Infection Post-deposition: A study was conducted to determine if the micro-environment within the canopies varied in terms of favorableness for fruit infection. The effect of plant density treatment on fruit infection post-deposition was assessed by determining the disease incidence of inoculated, detached fruit placed within each treatment row canopy and in unsheltered areas adjacent to the plot site. Greenhouse-grown fruit (‘Midway’) at the white stage were collected with the pedicels and inoculated in the laboratory as previously described (43), using a concentration of 1 × 10³ conidia/ml. This inoculum density produces a fruit disease incidence of approximately 0.5 with 12 hours of wetness at 25°C in controlled-environment chambers (41).', 0.07773170620203018]]
Context 5: [['Air temperature, relative humidity, leaf wetness, water temperature, and water electrical conductivity for each treatment were monitored every minute using electronic sensors and dataloggers (Campbell Scientific, Logan, UT). Data were summarized daily to provide average, maximum, and minimum values for each sensor.', 0.07658406347036362]]
Context 6: [['Hourly progress of IP depending on temperature: The hourly change in infection progress based on temperature.', 0.05790916457772255]]
Context 7: [['The moisture required for sporulation is provided by the host plant. The infection rate also depends on a correction factor (CF) for diseased sites (i.e., stages L, V, I, and R) and a multiplication factor (Rc), representing the proportion of daughter lesions generated per mother lesion, which is influenced by temperature (RcT) and wetness duration (RcWD). Infection occurs during the period of host susceptibility (HS), which is regulated by the plant growth stage and varies among hosts. Latent sites become visible at the end of an incubation period (IP), and visible sites become infectious at the end of a latency period (LP). Both periods depend on temperature; the progression of IP and LP is determined by an incubation rate (INCR) and a latency rate (LATR), respectively. Infectious sites produce secondary conidia (CON) during the infectious period (iP) and are eventually removed at a removal rate (REMR).', 0.04986247047781944]]
Context 8: [['Prusky, D. 1996. Pathogen quiescence in postharvest diseases. Annual Review of Phytopathology 34:413-434.', 0.04575376212596893]]
Context 9: [['In a separate analysis regarding the effects of pre-plant dip treatments on fruit yield, the data were processed separately for each trial, considering harvest timing and frequency. Generally, the yield data corresponded with the treatments’ performance in mitigating disease severity and plant mortality. Water dip treatments did not enhance yield compared to the untreated control, except in the first trial with QoI-sensitive inoculum. Natamycin treatments achieved yields comparable to the industry-standard fludioxonil-cyprodinil mixture. However, azoxystrobin-treated transplants exhibited higher yields than the untreated control but were similar in effectiveness to natamycin and fludioxonil treatments when inoculated with QoI-sensitive isolates. When faced with QoI-resistant isolates, azoxystrobin yielded results comparable to the untreated control.', 0.04132336005568504]]

query: How does the TUB2 sequence of Colletotrichum guajavae compare to that of C. scovillei in terms of nucleotide differences?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Colletotrichum guajavae can be distinguished from other species in clade 2 of the C. acutatum complex using TUB2, GAPDH, and ACT sequences, with GAPDH proving most effective. Data from GAPDH alone place the species within the highly variable C. nymphaeae cluster. With TUB2 and ACT, there is only a 1 base pair difference between C. guajavae and C. scovillei, while CHS-1 and HIS3 sequences are identical to those of C. scovillei. Morphologically, C. guajavae is not reliably distinguishable from these species. BLASTn searches with the GAPDH sequence of strain CBS 853.73 show 100% identity with HM038337 from a Colletotrichum sp. isolate MFU 09 0624 from Ziziphus mauritiana (jujube) in Laos (Phoulivong et al. 2010), suggesting that this strain may also belong to C. guajavae. The closest match for the TUB2 sequence of strain CBS 853.73, showing 100% identity, was GU246633 from isolate R14 from Capsicum annuum in South Korea (Sang et al. 2011). This isolate is identified as C. scovillei; however, the available sequence does not encompass the region containing the single nucleotide polymorphism that differentiates the TUB2 sequences of C. guajavae and C. scovillei.', 0.9974187612533569]]
Context 1: [['Notes: Colletotrichum scovillei belongs to clade 2 of the C. acutatum species complex and can be differentiated from other species using TUB2, GAPDH, and ACT sequences, with GAPDH being the most clearly differential. The CHS-1 and HIS3 sequences are identical to those of C. guajavae. The conidia are slightly longer than typical for C. simmondsii and C. nymphaeae, exhibiting a larger length/width ratio. However, these characteristics can vary within the clade, necessitating sequence data for reliable distinction between the taxa.', 0.9948821067810059]]
Context 2: [['The closest match in a BLASTn search with the GAPDH sequence of strain CBS 126529 (with 100% identity) was HM038335 from Colletotrichum sp. isolate MFU 090619, obtained from Capsicum annuum (chili) in Laos (Phoulivong et al. 2010). Among the closest matches with the TUB2 sequence, there were 100% identity matches with DQ454059 and DQ454060 from Capsicum annuum isolates obtained in Thailand (Than et al. 2008a). One of these isolates is included in this study. Another 100% match was with GU246633 from isolate R14 of Capsicum annuum in South Korea (Sang et al. 2011). All of these strains likely belong to C. scovillei. Based on the GAPDH sequence of strain LLB17, C. scovillei also occurs on Capsicum annuum in Taiwan (as part of group D3 in Guerber et al. 2003).', 0.871755063533783]]
Context 3: [['Peres et al. (2002) isolated C. acutatum (sensu lato) from a guava fruit in Brazil, which caused lesions slightly larger than those caused by a C. acutatum (sensu lato) isolate from strawberry. The ITS sequences generated indicated that the isolates from guava and strawberry in Brazil belong to the same major clade as C. guajavae. The ITS sequence is identical to that of C. guajavae, yet it matches several other species within this complex, making precise identification impossible without further information. A phylogenetic analysis from combined GAPDH and GS sequences in the study by Guerber et al. (2003) places both strains within clade D (equivalent to clade 2 in this study), but not within the same subclade. The GAPDH sequence from Guerber et al. (2003) differs by 5 base pairs from that of C. guajavae ex-holotype strain IMI 350839. Additionally, a strain from guava in New Zealand, included in the same study, belongs to clade J3 sensu Guerber et al. (2003) (identified as C. acutatum sensu stricto). Beyond C. acutatum sensu lato and C. psidii, Farr & Rossman (2012) list occurrences of C. coccodes in Myanmar, C. gloeosporioides in Brazil, China, Cuba, India, Mexico, Puerto Rico, South Africa, the USA, the Virgin Islands, and Mexico, as well as Colletotrichum sp. in Brazil, Jamaica, and Mexico; it is possible that some of these reports may actually refer to C. guajavae.', 0.48226723074913025]]
Context 4: [['Brazil shares the same ITS sequence as C. guajavae (Damm et al., 2012). Another Colletotrichum species affecting guava, C. psidii, was described in Italy and belongs to the C. gloeosporioides species complex (Weir et al., 2012).', 0.33642080426216125]]
Context 5: [['Most Colletotrichum isolates derived from Hevea plants have been found to belong to the C. gloeosporioides and C. acutatum species complexes (Jayasinghe et al. 1997, Saha et al. 2002, Gazis & Chaverri 2010, Gazis et al. 2011, Damm et al. 2012). However, one isolate from Hevea guianensis in Peru possesses an ITS sequence that places it within the C. boninense species complex, closely related to C. karstii or C. phyllanthi (Gazis et al. 2011; GenBank HQ022474). The ITS sequence of C. annellatum differs by two base pairs from C. karstii and C. phyllanthi. Additional research is necessary to clarify the taxonomic placement of the strain from Peru.', 0.31867220997810364]]
Context 6: [["Fungal Material and DNA Extraction: The Colletotrichum spp. isolates used in this study are detailed in Table I. Nineteen isolates were sourced from the collection maintained at CIFC/IICT (Portugal), and three from the Mae Fah Luang University collection (Thailand), representing six previously characterized species within the C. gloeosporioides complex: C. fragariae, C. gloeosporioides, C. kahawae, C. asianum, C. siamense, and C. fructicola, including ex-type specimens for the latter three species. The C. kahawae isolates were identified through BLAST queries of the ITS and β-tubulin 2 (β-tub2) sequences against the holotype (GenBank accession numbers FJ972608 [E value = 0, Max identity = 100%] and FJ907432 [E value = 0, Max identity = 100%]) and their ability to induce CBD symptoms on detached green coffee berries. This method was found to be the most reliable for identifying true C. kahawae isolates, as recent findings indicated non-C. kahawae isolates with identical genetic sequences for several nuclear markers, including ITS and β-tub2 (data not shown). The C. gloeosporioides sampling included isolates similar to the ex-epitype strain at the ITS and β-tub2 loci (GenBank accession numbers EU371022 [E value = 0, Max identity = 98%] and FJ907445 [E value = 0, Max identity = 99%], respectively). Context 9: [['Strain CBS 134727 of C. abscissum grouped with strains causing citrus postbloom fruit drop. This strain was collected from guava fruit with anthracnose in a commercial orchard in Cafelândia. Previous studies revealed its pathogenicity to citrus, causing postbloom fruit drop in 70% of inoculated flowers (Ramiro et al., unpublished data). Guava volatiles repel Diaphorina citri, the vector of citrus Huanglongbing (HLB), making guava intercropping a strategy to control HLB (Beattie et al., 2006). However, the ability of guava to host C. abscissum has significant epidemiological implications for citrus postbloom fruit drop outbreaks. All strains tested for pathogenicity on fruits were able to infect various hosts, though they varied in aggressiveness. Studies have shown a lack of host specificity among Colletotrichum species infecting fruits (Peres et al. 2002; MacKenzie et al. 2009; Lakshmi et al. 2011; Phoulivong et al. 2012; de Souza et al. 2013; Peng et al. 2013; Baroncelli et al. 2015). (2009), genetically distinct strains of C. acutatum (s. lat.) from strawberry, blueberry, citrus, and fern exhibited pathogenicity and varied in aggressiveness, with the highest incidence and largest lesions on their original host. Based on TUB2 sequences, Damm et al. (2012) linked the strains from strawberry to others.', 0.15884274244308472]]

query: What are the primary methods of anthracnose spread in strawberry fields?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Anthracnose is an important disease of strawberry caused by Colletotrichum spp., which affects foliage, runners, crowns, and fruits (Howard et al., 1992). Three primary fungal pathogens—C. acutatum sensu lato, C. gloeosporioides sensu lato, and C. fragariae—are known to cause anthracnose disease in strawberries (Freeman and Katan, 1997). The crown rot syndrome is characteristic of infections from C. gloeosporioides sensu lato and C. fragariae, while fruit rot is mainly attributed to C. acutatum sensu lato, leading to significant yield losses (Howard et al., 1992). Currently, numerous species are classified under what is now known as the C. acutatum complex, with six species—C. acutatum sensu stricto, C. fioriniae, C. godetiae, C. nymphaeae, C. salicis, and C. simmondsii—identified as associated with strawberry anthracnose worldwide (Damm et al., 2012). Among these, C. nymphaeae is the most prevalent pathogen causing strawberry anthracnose globally, including in Iran (Baroncelli et al., 2015; Karimi et al., 2017; Wang et al., 2019). Currently, no effective chemical control methods exist for managing strawberry anthracnose; available options are limited to preventive treatments applied before fruit production (Denoyes-Rothan et al., 1999). Additionally, concerns about the toxic effects of chemical fungicides on the environment and the development of resistance in fungal strains highlight the need for alternative control strategies. Consequently, utilizing resistant cultivars appears to be the most efficient and practical approach for suppressing anthracnose development. In light of recent anthracnose outbreaks in strawberry fields in the Kurdistan province of Iran (Karimi et al., 2017), and the necessity for appropriate strategies to address this issue, the aim of this study was to evaluate the resistance of several commercial strawberry cultivars to the anthracnose fruit rot caused by C. nymphaeae under in vivo and greenhouse conditions.', 0.9956489205360413]]
Context 1: [["Anthracnose fungi can attack various parts of the strawberry plant, including crowns, petioles, leaves, fruit trusses, flowers, buds, and fruit. The fungi's ability to attack multiple plant parts, coupled with the involvement of several pathogen species, contributes to the complex nature of strawberry anthracnose. Brooks reported in 1931 that C. fragariae caused spotting and girdling of runners, and later indicated that it also caused spotting of petioles and crown rot in a summer nursery, leading to wilting and death of the plants. Researchers in Louisiana observed all these symptoms and noted that crown rot also occurred in the fruit production field.", 0.7800379991531372]]
Context 2: [['Introduction: The spread of strawberry anthracnose can be exacerbated by the use of infected runner plantlets (Hirayama et al. 2010). Effective management strategies must consider these factors to mitigate disease outbreaks.', 0.7559618949890137]]
Context 3: [['So far, anthracnose epidemics have affected strawberry nurseries and production fields worldwide. Reports on Colletotrichum spp. associated with strawberries, curated from literature in PubMed and Clarivate combined with fungal database searches (Farr and Rossman, 2022), were compiled to understand the global diversity and occurrence of the causal agents of strawberry anthracnose. From our findings, since 1931 until July 9, 2022, there have been over 220 citations and 310 records related to the identification of causal agents of strawberry anthracnose at the genus level of Colletotrichum in 36 countries across six continents, with 282 records providing pathogen identification at the species or species complex level.', 0.7381430864334106]]
Context 4: [['From May to September 1995, a severe outbreak of strawberry anthracnose was observed in several strawberry-growing nurseries in Israel. Following transplantation to production fields during September and October, entire beds of strawberry plants collapsed. Typical anthracnose symptoms observed from November 1995 to June 1996 included crown rot, flower blight, and green and ripe fruit rot. This marked the first record of strawberry anthracnose in Israel. Furthermore, in at least four production fields in the same region, hundreds of plants developed symptoms of stunting and chlorosis, which are atypical of strawberry anthracnose. When these plants were uprooted, most of their roots were dark brown and decayed. Colletotrichum was readily isolated from these samples.', 0.6855024695396423]]
Context 5: [['Howard CM, Albregts EE. Anthracnose. In: Compendium of Strawberry Diseases. American Phytopathological Society: Paul St, ed. Maas JL, USA; 1984. pp. 85-87.', 0.405191034078598]]
Context 6: [['Smith, B. J. 1998. Anthracnose leaf spot, irregular spot, anthracnose fruit rot (black spot), and anthracnose crown rot. In: Compendium of Strawberry Diseases. J. L. Mass, ed. American Phytopathological Society, St. Paul, MN. Pages 24-25, 31-33, and 46-48.', 0.379506379365921]]
Context 7: [['The term "anthracnose" was first used to describe a new disease of strawberries caused by Colletotrichum fragariae Brooks. "Strawberry anthracnose" continues to be used as a general term to identify all diseases of strawberries caused by species of Colletotrichum. Strawberry anthracnose diseases have been reported to be caused by C. acutatum J.H. Simmonds, C. gloeosporioides (Penz.) Penz. & Sacc. in Penz. (the teleomorph of Cromereilla cingulata (Stoneman) Spauld. & H. Schrenk), and C. dematium (Pers.) Grove. The latter species only occasionally causes strawberry fruit rots and will not be discussed here.', 0.3170589506626129]]
Context 8: [['In November 2021, anthracnose symptoms were observed on strawberries (cv. Kingsberry) in Nonsan, Chungnam Province. Early symptoms of anthracnose fruit rot (AFR) include blackening of specific tissues of the strawberry. These symptoms progress with the enlargement of lesions, which hinder proper fruit development and lead to the formation of orange-colored spores within the lesions. Similar symptoms were noted on the petioles, with sunken and blackened tissues similar to those on the fruit, accompanied by the formation of an orange conidial mass.', 0.3107806146144867]]
Context 9: [['Brooks, A.N. 1931. Anthracnose of strawberry caused by Colletotrichum fragariae, n. sp. Phytopathology 21: 739—744.', 0.30943116545677185]]

query: What happens to a plant when it gets infected by fungi?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Plants can be infected at all stages of growth when environmental conditions are favorable. Characteristic root symptoms include light to dark brown or black lesions and necrotic tips (Fig. 1). Severe infection can blacken and extensively destroy the root system. A black mycelial mat of the fungus may form on the basal stem or "foot" area of the plant, and most roots may appear heavily melanized. On young plants, above-ground symptoms resemble general nutrient stress (Fig. 2) and are frequently misdiagnosed as nitrogen deficiency. A misdiagnosis of magnesium deficiency, especially in highly weathered soils, along with the application of dolomitic lime (calcium and magnesium carbonates) as a magnesium source, can increase the severity of take-all and exacerbate nutrient deficiencies.', 0.6016799211502075]]

query: Which herbicide should be used to manage fungal diseases?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['The sensitivity ranges of the isolates to various fungicides were 0.2 to 1.6 mg/ml and 0.002 to 0.2 mg/ml, respectively, with average values of 6.5 to 6.9 mg/ml, 1.5 to 0.6 mg/ml, 0.9 to 0.4 mg/ml, and 0.1 to 0.05 mg/ml, respectively. All isolates were more sensitive to difenoconazole, flusilazole, and carbendazim than to tebuconazole (P < 0.01). However, sensitivities to the same fungicide varied among isolates. Specifically, isolates SL-31 and TS-09 were the least sensitive to carbendazim and tebuconazole, with resistance ratios of 87.3 and 51.6, respectively. Sensitivities to difenoconazole and flusilazole were largely consistent across all isolates, with resistance ratios ranging from 1 to 4.6 and from 1 to 7, respectively. Therefore, difenoconazole and flusilazole could be recommended for disease control. Notably, differences in pathogenicity and fungicide sensitivity were not correlated with geographic regions. These findings indicate a high level of intraspecific diversity within the populations of Colletotrichum gloeosporioides s.s. responsible for walnut anthracnose. For effective management, a targeted control strategy should be developed based on different geographic regions.', 0.2336387038230896]]
Context 1: [['Fungicides: Formulated products of natamycin (DelvoCid Instant; DSM, Heerlen, The Netherlands), azoxystrobin (Abound Flowable; Syngenta Crop Protection Inc., Greensboro, NC), chlorothalonil (Bravo Weather Stick; Syngenta Crop Protection Inc.), cyprodinil (Vangard 75WG; Syngenta Crop Protection Inc.), fludioxonil (Scholar 50WP; Syngenta Crop Protection Inc.), and pydiflumetofen (experimental product A19649B; Syngenta Crop Protection Inc.) were used on plants, either individually or in mixtures of fludioxonil and cyprodinil (Switch WG; Syngenta Crop Protection Inc.) or of pydiflumetofen and fludioxonil (experimental product A20560C; Syngenta Crop Protection Inc.). Additionally, the biological control agent S. lydicus WYEC 108 (minimum of 10^3 CFU/g of formulated product; Actinovate AG; Valent U.S.A. LLC, Walnut Creek, CA) was included in field trials.
