query: What are the comparative effectiveness and limitations of various fungicides, including prochloraz formulations, for controlling strawberry anthracnose?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Various fungicides and a heat treatment were assessed for their ability to control strawberry anthracnose caused by the fungus Colletotrichum acutatum under laboratory, greenhouse, and field conditions. The effective dose causing 50% inhibition of mycelial growth (ED50) was measured at 30.5, 12.2, 0.2, 0.15, 0.05, 0.07, and 0.05 µg/ml for the fungicides folpet, captan, propiconazole, difenoconazole, combined prochloraz-Zn/folpet, prochloraz-Zn, and prochloraz-Mn, respectively.', 0.9956578016281128]]
Context 1: [['Prochloraz was effective in controlling strawberry anthracnose under all tested conditions; however, the current formulation of this fungicide resulted in a residual taste.', 0.9820643663406372]]
Context 2: [['Additionally, multisite fungicides such as captan, thiram, and chlorothalonil, which have been available for many decades, remain effective in reducing strawberry anthracnose incidence (Mertely et al. 2018). Chlorothalonil is only registered for nonbearing nurseries when flowers and fruit are absent, yet our surveys indicated that its usage is significantly lower compared to newer single-site fungicides. Due to their efficacy and low resistance risk, multisite fungicides should be the mainstay for disease control in strawberry nurseries. Other non-chemical alternatives, such as heat (Wang et al. 2017) and ultraviolet treatments (Onofre et al. 2017), are currently under investigation and could serve as valuable tools for disease management, reducing the reliance on single-site fungicides.', 0.9797296524047852]]
Context 3: [['Certain fungicides, including propiconazole, have been reported to successfully limit in vitro growth of C. fragariae, while fluazinam, a protectant fungicide, provides good control of strawberry anthracnose in post-harvest berries.', 0.9706016182899475]]
Context 4: [['This study evaluated the fungicides prochloraz-Zn, prochloraz-Mn (both protectant sterol-biosynthesis inhibitors), captan, folpet, a combined formulation of prochloraz-Zn and folpet, propiconazole, difenoconazole, and a heat treatment for the control of C. acutatum in naturally infected strawberry plants under laboratory, greenhouse, and field conditions. Fungicides were applied at the transplant stage to determine whether a single-dip treatment is sufficient for disease control.', 0.9601806998252869]]
Context 5: [['Past failures of fungicides to control anthracnose epidemics may have stemmed from the development of resistance in the Colletotrichum population. In the early 1970s, benomyl effectively reduced anthracnose crown rot incidence (Horn et al., 1972; Howard, 1971) and was widely used by strawberry growers for years. However, anthracnose pathogens developed resistance to it and other benzimidazole fungicides, rendering benomyl ineffective. In vitro and greenhouse trials have been conducted to identify fungicides to which Colletotrichum pathogens have developed resistance (LaMondia, 1993, 1995; McInnes et al., 1992a, 1992b; Smith and Black, 1991, 1992, 1993). Current fungicide labels address pathogen resistance by restricting the number of consecutive and total applications of a product per season. For instance, the fungicides Abound (azoxystrobin, Syngenta, Greensboro, NC), Cabrio (pyraclostrobin, BASF, Research Triangle Park, NC), and Pristine (pyraclostrobin and boscalid, BASF) are limited to four or five applications per season, with no more than two consecutive applications before alternating with a fungicide that has a different mode of action. Natural products have also been evaluated as alternative fungicides, offering different modes of action, lower toxicity, and increased efficacy (Abril et al., 2008).', 0.9563871026039124]]
Context 6: [['Strawberry anthracnose, caused mainly by the Colletotrichum acutatum species complex, is a significant disease affecting strawberry production. Surveys were conducted, and isolates were collected from affected areas, specifically strawberry nurseries and production fields in six states across the United States. The use of fungicides, particularly quinone outside inhibitors (QoIs), has been widely employed for controlling C. acutatum for the past 20 years. Resistance to QoIs was first reported in Florida in 2013, and subsequent anthracnose outbreaks occurred in strawberry nurseries and production fields throughout the U.S. in 2015. Fungicide use surveys indicated that, in certain locations, the number of QoI applications exceeded the recommended levels for this fungicide group. This situation necessitates immediate changes in anthracnose management strategies to incorporate other chemical and non-chemical approaches, aiming to limit the selection of resistant populations and prevent future outbreaks.', 0.9455052018165588]]
Context 7: [['Smith, B.J., & Black, L.L. (1991). Greenhouse efficacy of fungicides for control of anthracnose crown rot of strawberry. In A. Dale & J. Lubby (Eds.), The Strawberry into the 21st Century (pp. 221–223). Timber Press, Portland, OR.', 0.9401036500930786]]
Context 8: [['Smith, B.J. and L.L. Black. 1991. Greenhouse efficacy of fungicides for control of anthracnose crown rot of strawberry, p. 221-223. In: A. Dale and J. Luby (eds.). The Strawberry into the 21st Century. Timber Press, Portland, OR.', 0.9397217035293579]]
Context 9: [['There is an urgent need for multi- and single-site fungicide alternatives effective against anthracnose in strawberry nurseries and production fields. The antifungal antibiotic natamycin, widely used as a natural mold inhibitor in food products, has shown promise in controlling anthracnose root and crown infections caused by C. acutatum on strawberry transplants (Cordova et al. 2017; Haack et al. 2018). Similarly, fluazinam, a single-site respiration inhibitor fungicide from FRAC group 29, has demonstrated significant control of anthracnose fruit rot (Mertely et al. 2018). A request has been submitted through the Interregional Research Project Number 4 for its registration for nursery use only. Reducing the overlap of the same modes of action used during nursery and fruit production phases could help extend the lifespan of single-site fungicides at high risk of resistance.', 0.9370049238204956]]

query: What are the key indicators of an effective fungicide application against anthracnose?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['There is an urgent need for multi- and single-site fungicide alternatives effective against anthracnose in strawberry nurseries and production fields. The antifungal antibiotic natamycin, widely used as a natural mold inhibitor in food products, has shown promise in controlling anthracnose root and crown infections caused by C. acutatum on strawberry transplants (Cordova et al. 2017; Haack et al. 2018). Similarly, fluazinam, a single-site respiration inhibitor fungicide from FRAC group 29, has demonstrated significant control of anthracnose fruit rot (Mertely et al. 2018). A request has been submitted through the Interregional Research Project Number 4 for its registration for nursery use only. Reducing the overlap of the same modes of action used during nursery and fruit production phases could help extend the lifespan of single-site fungicides at high risk of resistance.', 0.9771775603294373]]
Context 1: [['Present and Future Management of Anthracnose: Fungicides, including chemicals such as benzimidazoles (e.g., thiabendazole, benomyl, and carbendazim) and sterol inhibitors (e.g., imazalil, prochloraz, and propiconazole), have been used effectively to control anthracnose disease in banana, mango, papaya, and avocado plants [140]. Benzimidazoles are commonly applied as dips or sprays to inhibit the anthracnose-causing fungus, Colletotrichum spp. [141], but the large-scale and continuous use of fungicides has led to the development of fungal resistance. For instance, benzimidazole-resistant Colletotrichum has been detected in mangoes and bananas [140]. Additionally, the excessive use of fungicides negatively impacts human health and the environment, as chemical residues often contaminate soil and water [142]. Biocontrol offers an alternative, non-toxic method for managing fruit crop anthracnose. Biocontrol agents, such as antagonistic microbes including yeast, bacteria, and filamentous fungi (particularly Trichoderma spp.), have shown promising results and are gaining popularity for their direct application to fruit surfaces post-harvest [143].', 0.9750562906265259]]
Context 2: [['Until highly resistant cultivars are available, growers must rely on chemical applications and cultural practices to reduce losses due to anthracnose. The failure of fungicides to control anthracnose epidemics may be attributed to the development of fungicide resistance in the Colletotrichum species population. For example, benomyl was shown to effectively reduce the incidence of anthracnose crown rot (Horn et al., 1972; Howard, 1971) and was used intensively by strawberry growers for years to control anthracnose and other diseases. However, the anthracnose pathogens, C. acutatum and C. fragariae, developed resistance to it and other benzimidazole fungicides (LaMondia, 1995; McInnes et al., 1992a; Smith and Black, 1992, 1993), leading to the ineffectiveness of benomyl for anthracnose control in strawberry fields.', 0.9287548661231995]]
Context 3: [['Past failures of fungicides to control anthracnose epidemics may have stemmed from the development of resistance in the Colletotrichum population. In the early 1970s, benomyl effectively reduced anthracnose crown rot incidence (Horn et al., 1972; Howard, 1971) and was widely used by strawberry growers for years. However, anthracnose pathogens developed resistance to it and other benzimidazole fungicides, rendering benomyl ineffective. In vitro and greenhouse trials have been conducted to identify fungicides to which Colletotrichum pathogens have developed resistance (LaMondia, 1993, 1995; McInnes et al., 1992a, 1992b; Smith and Black, 1991, 1992, 1993). Current fungicide labels address pathogen resistance by restricting the number of consecutive and total applications of a product per season. For instance, the fungicides Abound (azoxystrobin, Syngenta, Greensboro, NC), Cabrio (pyraclostrobin, BASF, Research Triangle Park, NC), and Pristine (pyraclostrobin and boscalid, BASF) are limited to four or five applications per season, with no more than two consecutive applications before alternating with a fungicide that has a different mode of action. Natural products have also been evaluated as alternative fungicides, offering different modes of action, lower toxicity, and increased efficacy (Abril et al., 2008).', 0.8984396457672119]]
Context 4: [['Until highly resistant cultivars are available, growers must rely on chemical applications and cultural practices to reduce losses due to anthracnose. The failure of fungicides to control anthracnose epidemics may be due to the development of fungicide resistance in the Colletotrichum spp. population. For example, benomyl effectively reduced the incidence of anthracnose crown rot (Horn et al., 1972; Howard, 1971) and was used intensively by strawberry growers for years to control anthracnose and other diseases. However, the anthracnose pathogens, C. acutatum and C. fragariae, developed resistance to it and other benzimidazole fungicides (LaMondia, 1995; McInnes et al., 1992a; Smith and Black, 1992, 1993), rendering benomyl ineffective for anthracnose control in strawberry fields.', 0.886712908744812]]
Context 5: [['Based on field trials in Florida (Mertely et al., 2009), the recommendation for anthracnose control involves weekly applications of a broad-spectrum protectant fungicide (captan) at the lowest label rate early in the season when conditions are less favorable for anthracnose development. Later, when anthracnose-infected flowers and fruit may be present, it is recommended to increase the rate of the protectant fungicide to the highest label rate. Warm, rainy weather in early spring often leads to epidemics, during which additional fungicides may be necessary. Growers are encouraged to scout their fields regularly for anthracnose symptoms, such as blighted flowers or black spots on green fruit. If symptoms are detected, the application of a strobilurin fungicide (such as Abound or Cabrio) in conjunction with the protectant fungicide is recommended. During the main bloom period, in late January and early February, fungicides containing two active ingredients (one for anthracnose control and one for Botrytis fruit rot control), such as CaptEvate, Pristine, or Switch, are advised. Tank mixes or higher rates of protectant fungicides should be maintained until the end of the harvest season or until dry weather effectively suppresses the disease.', 0.7827960848808289]]
Context 6: [['Various fungicides and a heat treatment were assessed for their ability to control strawberry anthracnose caused by the fungus Colletotrichum acutatum under laboratory, greenhouse, and field conditions. The effective dose causing 50% inhibition of mycelial growth (ED50) was measured at 30.5, 12.2, 0.2, 0.15, 0.05, 0.07, and 0.05 µg/ml for the fungicides folpet, captan, propiconazole, difenoconazole, combined prochloraz-Zn/folpet, prochloraz-Zn, and prochloraz-Mn, respectively.', 0.7823501825332642]]
Context 7: [['In addition to chemical treatments, heat treatment of transplants may reduce mortality from anthracnose, but this practice is not widely used due to its potential to reduce plant vigor (Freeman et al., 1997). In-season fungicide spray applications are common to prevent foliar and fruit infections (Koike et al., 2008; MacKenzie and Peres, 2012), but these are ineffective against crown rot and root necrosis (Daugovish et al., 2009).', 0.7527226805686951]]
Context 8: [['Anthracnose fruit rot was observed on berries treated with pyraclostrobin + boscalid, cyprodinil + fludioxonil, azoxystrobin, pyraclostrobin, and captan + fenhexamid, as well as captan alone. Studies conducted in North Carolina indicated that a fungicide spray program consisting of only four applications—one application of a mixture of captan and Topsin M (thiophanate-methyl, Cerexagri-Nisso, King of Prussia, PA), two applications of Pristine, and one application of CaptEvate (fenhexamid and captan, Arysta, Cary, NC)—provided a similar level of disease control as a season-long spray program with eight applications (Rahman et al., 2009). Each application in the shorter program included two fungicides, as both Pristine and CaptEvate contain two active ingredients.', 0.746653139591217]]
Context 9: [['Nursery surveys confirmed the intensive use of QoI fungicides. Single-site fungicides, such as QoIs, have frequently been used in nurseries to control anthracnose and other diseases, ensuring the delivery of symptom-free stock material. Along with commercial products containing only azoxystrobin or pyraclostrobin, premixes with QoI fungicides were also utilized. This has led to an increased selection rate for QoI-resistant populations as early as the nursery phase. Since transplants produced in large nurseries are sold to smaller ones, plants may be exposed to multiple QoI applications throughout each propagation phase. Consequently, during the fruit production phase, growers face challenges in controlling anthracnose outbreaks with limited effective chemical options.', 0.7431466579437256]]

query: In what ways can nursery practices for strawberries, such as those for the cultivar Ofra, influence the success of transplanting in the field?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['In Korea, strawberries (Fragaria × ananassa) are favored for winter cultivation when the production of other vegetables and fruits is relatively low. In 2003, strawberries were planted on a total area of 7,503 hectares in Korea, with plastic greenhouse cultivation comprising 7,172 hectares and a total production of 205,427 tonnes for the fresh market (Anonymous, 2004). Forcing, where strawberries are transplanted into greenhouses in mid-September and induced to fruit in December (Oda, 1991), is becoming more common in Korea. June-bearing cultivars such as Maehyang, Akihime, and Nyoho, used for forcing, have proven difficult to grow due to their susceptibility to anthracnose (Nam et al., 1998; Kim & Nam, 1999). Anthracnose is one of the most damaging diseases of strawberries, causing wilting and death of transplants in the nursery field. The pathogen responsible for the disease in Korea is Colletotrichum gloeosporioides, first reported in 1992 (Kim et al., 1992).', 0.6077802777290344]]
Context 1: [['Although strawberries are considered a minor crop, they provide a significant source of income for many fruit and nursery growers. In the United States, strawberries were cultivated on nearly 20,000 hectares in 1989, yielding a total production of 555,000 tons valued at $520 million. Florida ranks second only to California in the production of fresh-market strawberries. For U.S. winter production (December through March), strawberries are grown on approximately 2,400 hectares. The major cultural problems faced by the Florida strawberry industry include: 1) anthracnose diseases, 2) yearly infestations of the two-spotted spider mite (Tetranychus urticae Koch), and 3) variability in the quality of nursery transplants. Commercial fields are established annually, similar to California practices. Freshly dug transplants are sourced from nurseries in Florida or from northern states and Canada. The use of transplants from northern nurseries is crucial to avoid anthracnose disease issues and to ensure that plants have undergone sufficient natural chilling to induce floral bud initiation.', 0.4639480412006378]]
Context 2: [['The establishment of transplants in the field is a critical phase in strawberry production in Israel. Plants affected by strawberry anthracnose during this stage face significant mortality rates.', 0.18469534814357758]]

query: What role does the genetic basis of fungal mating systems play in the ecological adaptation of Colletotrichum species?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['The genus Colletotrichum is considered one of the top ten important genera of fungal pathogens globally (Dean et al., 2012). Colletotrichum is an ancient fungus that has co-evolved with flowering plants. Plant microfossils of Protocolletotrichum preserved on angiosperm leaf cuticles suggest that the diverse pathogenic strategies of Colletotrichum spp. have been established since the Late Cretaceous period (Kar et al., 2004). Different complexes within the genus may have diverged between 4.8 and 32.2 million years ago (MYA) (Bhunjun et al., 2021). The emergence of agricultural cultivation and the intensive disturbance of natural environments have further driven the diversification of Colletotrichum species. These fungi have adapted to thousands of hosts and can be found as endophytes, pathogens, and saprobes (Freeman et al., 1998; Dean et al., 2012; Hirayama et al., 2018; da Silva et al., 2020; Jayawardena et al., 2020). Currently, a total of 257 Colletotrichum species grouped into 15 complexes and 13 additional singletons have been accepted in this genus.', 0.6226422190666199]]
Context 1: [['Citation: Cai, L., Hyde, K.D., Taylor, P.W.J., Weir, B.S., Waller, J., Abang, M.M., Zhang, J.Z., Yang, Y.L., Phoulivong, S., Liu, Z.Y., Prihastuti, H., Shivas, R.G., McKenzie, E.H.C., Johnston, P.R. (2009). A polyphasic approach for studying Colletotrichum. Fungal Diversity, 39: 183-204.', 0.496940553188324]]
Context 2: [['Cai, L., Hyde, K. D., Taylor, P. W. J., Weir, B., Waller, J. M., Abang, M. M., Zhang, J. Z., Yang, Y. L., Phoulivong, S., Liu, Z. Y., Prihastuti, H., Shivas, R. G., McKenzie, E. H. C., and Johnston, P. R. (2009). A polyphasic approach for studying Colletotrichum. Fungal Divers., 39, 183-204.', 0.33155789971351624]]
Context 3: [['Despite significant developments over the last ten years, the taxonomy of Colletotrichum is in a state of flux. Many uncertainties exist in the systematics of fungal pathogens from this genus; depending on the taxonomic "guides," the number of species can range from 29 to over 700 (von Arx, 1957; Sutton, 1992). One of the most confusing species is C. gloeosporioides. For example, 594 species of Colletotrichum were reclassified by von Arx as synonyms of C. gloeosporioides. Identification has primarily relied on morphological characteristics of conidia, vegetative and sexual structures, as well as host specificity and cultural characteristics (von Arx, 1957). Unfortunately, conidial morphology and colony characteristics vary even within isolates. Consequently, classical methods have been supplemented with biochemical and molecular technologies to differentiate Colletotrichum species (J. W. Kronstad, ed., Fungal Pathology, 127-148. © 2000 Kluwer Academic Publishers). For a more complete discussion of this topic, see Sherriff et al. (1994).', 0.3294663727283478]]

query: How effective are fungicides such as captan and folpet when used on high-value crops like tomatoes and strawberries?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Various fungicides and a heat treatment were assessed for their ability to control strawberry anthracnose caused by the fungus Colletotrichum acutatum under laboratory, greenhouse, and field conditions. The effective dose causing 50% inhibition of mycelial growth (ED50) was measured at 30.5, 12.2, 0.2, 0.15, 0.05, 0.07, and 0.05 µg/ml for the fungicides folpet, captan, propiconazole, difenoconazole, combined prochloraz-Zn/folpet, prochloraz-Zn, and prochloraz-Mn, respectively.', 0.9764725565910339]]
Context 1: [['Additionally, multisite fungicides such as captan, thiram, and chlorothalonil, which have been available for many decades, remain effective in reducing strawberry anthracnose incidence (Mertely et al. 2018). Chlorothalonil is only registered for nonbearing nurseries when flowers and fruit are absent, yet our surveys indicated that its usage is significantly lower compared to newer single-site fungicides. Due to their efficacy and low resistance risk, multisite fungicides should be the mainstay for disease control in strawberry nurseries. Other non-chemical alternatives, such as heat (Wang et al. 2017) and ultraviolet treatments (Onofre et al. 2017), are currently under investigation and could serve as valuable tools for disease management, reducing the reliance on single-site fungicides.', 0.9712511897087097]]
Context 2: [['The study concluded that captafol was the most effective fungicide against C. fragariae, providing adequate control at concentrations of 1.2-2.4 g a.i./L when applied every 7 days. The mixture of captan and benomyl offered some control but was less effective than captafol. The findings suggest that maintaining the application of fungicides at appropriate intervals is crucial for managing strawberry anthracnose effectively.', 0.9444026350975037]]
Context 3: [['In summary, while captafol demonstrated fungicidal activity against strawberry anthracnose, other fungicides like benomyl and maneb have shown reduced effectiveness in recent years, necessitating the ongoing evaluation of control strategies for this pervasive disease.', 0.5959206223487854]]
Context 4: [['In laboratory experiments, infection in segments of strawberry runners treated with prochloraz-Zn reached 60%, which was significantly reduced compared to the combined prochloraz-Zn/folpet (90%), captan, folpet, and water controls (100%). In the greenhouse, the number of naturally infected transplants killed was significantly reduced by all fungicides and the heat treatment (5 minutes at 49°C) compared to the non-treated control. Prochloraz-Zn was the most effective chemical control treatment but did not differ significantly from the heat treatment.', 0.4635322391986847]]
Context 5: [['Anthracnose fruit rot was observed on berries treated with pyraclostrobin + boscalid, cyprodinil + fludioxonil, azoxystrobin, pyraclostrobin, and captan + fenhexamid, as well as captan alone. Studies conducted in North Carolina indicated that a fungicide spray program consisting of only four applications—one application of a mixture of captan and Topsin M (thiophanate-methyl, Cerexagri-Nisso, King of Prussia, PA), two applications of Pristine, and one application of CaptEvate (fenhexamid and captan, Arysta, Cary, NC)—provided a similar level of disease control as a season-long spray program with eight applications (Rahman et al., 2009). Each application in the shorter program included two fungicides, as both Pristine and CaptEvate contain two active ingredients.', 0.31559088826179504]]
Context 6: [['Control of C. acutatum in Field Transplants: In field trials conducted in 1995 and 1996, mortality caused by C. acutatum in naturally infected strawberry transplants was significantly reduced by all fungicide treatments compared to the non-treated control. Prochloraz-Mn and prochloraz-Zn were the most effective in reducing transplant mortality. In 1995, prochloraz-Mn reduced mortality by 93.3%, while in 1996, reductions were 86.8% for prochloraz-Mn and 93.1% for prochloraz-Zn, with no significant differences between them. Prochloraz-Zn/folpet, propiconazole, and difenoconazole were less effective than prochloraz alone. In 1995, transplant mortality was reduced by 66.7% and 37.7% with prochloraz-Zn/folpet and propiconazole, respectively. In 1996, reductions were 52.9% and 29.1% with prochloraz-Zn/folpet and difenoconazole, respectively. Similar to the greenhouse experiments, prochloraz fungicides, difenoconazole, and propiconazole exhibited slight phytotoxicity.', 0.28801098465919495]]
Context 7: [['Fungicide efficacy has been evaluated through in vitro, greenhouse, and field studies, with some pathogens showing resistance to specific fungicides. Developing anthracnose-resistant cultivars remains a primary objective for most strawberry breeding programs in the southern United States.', 0.2536429762840271]]
Context 8: [['Fungicide efficacy has been assessed through in vitro, greenhouse, and field studies, revealing some pathogen resistance to certain fungicides. Developing anthracnose-resistant cultivars remains a major objective of most strawberry breeding programs in the southern United States.', 0.24750441312789917]]
Context 9: [['Table 1 presents the effective doses of various fungicides that resulted in 50% inhibition (ED50) of Colletotrichum acutatum in vitro. The table includes entries for captan, propiconazole, difenoconazole, prochloraz-Zn combined with folpet, prochloraz-Zn alone, and prochloraz-Mn, listing the specific concentrations needed for each to achieve the inhibition. This data highlights the comparative efficacy of these fungicides in controlling the pathogen in laboratory settings.', 0.23432999849319458]]

query: Did the study suggest any best practices for implementing crop rotation and nitrogen fertilization in strawberry fields?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['The combined effects of rotation crops and nitrogen fertilizers were examined on the strawberry black root rot disease complex. In July 1995, microplots were filled with soil that had a history of strawberry black root rot and seeded with two types of oats (Avena strigosa ‘Saia oats’ or A. sativa ‘Garry oats’) or with sorgho-sudangrass (Sorghum bicolor × S. sudanense ‘Triple S’). Microplots planted with 1-year-old ‘Honeoye’ strawberry crowns served as controls. In May 1996, the crops were chopped and incorporated into the soil. The soil was then replanted with 1-year-old ‘Honeoye’ strawberry crowns and fertilized with (NH4)2SO4 or Ca(NO3)2 at equivalent nitrogen rates. Two months later, (NH4)2SO4-treated plants exhibited 36% more leaf area and 41% more runners than strawberries treated with Ca(NO3)2. Strawberries that had been precropped with ‘Saia’ oats produced 135% more runners and 38% more early fruit yield compared to those grown in control microplots. Total fruit yield was not affected by the treatments.', 0.905580461025238]]
Context 1: [['These results indicate that strawberry growers can adjust their fertilizer practices by opting for Ca(NO3)2 as their N source. This adjustment can help reduce the severity of anthracnose crown rot while ensuring adequate foliar N levels necessary for optimal growth and production. As anticipated, foliar N levels increased with higher treatment N levels, while P and K levels did not influence foliar N.', 0.660485029220581]]
Context 2: [['The goal of these recommendations is to avoid abiotic stresses, such as drought, winter injury, and heavy wet soils, while employing a two-year rotation with grains. In New England, straw is commonly used as a winter mulch for strawberries, leading many growers to adopt grain rotations to produce straw. However, the effectiveness of rotation crops can vary regarding their susceptibility as hosts to R. fragariae and P. penetrans. Past research has shown that ‘Saia’ oats (Avena strigosa Schreb.) and ‘Triple S’ sorgho-sudangrass (Sorghum bicolor × S. sudanense) are poor hosts for these pathogens, whereas ‘Garry’ oats (Avena sativa L), rye (Secale cereale L), buckwheat (Fagopyrum esculentum Moench), canola (Brassica napus L), and strawberries may either increase or have no effect on the population densities of the pathogens. Additionally, studies by Hildebrand and West indicated that strawberry black root rot increased following specific rotation crops, which were associated with elevated levels of both fluorescing and non-fluorescing gram-negative rod bacteria in the strawberry rhizosphere.', 0.6440715193748474]]
Context 3: [['Compared to Ca(NO3)2, the (NH4)2SO4 treatment reduced the percentage of blackened roots. The influence of the cover crops on growth and disease was more pronounced with (NH4)2SO4 fertilization than with Ca(NO3)2. Combining ‘Saia’ oats or sorgho-sudangrass rotation with (NH4)2SO4 fertilization led to a reduction in lesion nematode (Pratylenchus penetrans) numbers in subsequent strawberry roots compared to controls. Furthermore, the combination of ‘Saia’ or ‘Garry’ oats as a precrop with applications of (NH4)2SO4 reduced black root rot severity relative to controls. Only the ‘Garry’ oat rotation reduced strawberry root colonization by Rhizoctonia fragariae when compared to controls. Additional effects associated with (NH4)2SO4 treatment included a decrease in rhizosphere soil pH by 0.2 units, a reduction in fluorescent pseudomonads in the rhizosphere by 10- to 15-fold, and leaves with higher concentrations of nitrogen, potassium, sulfur, manganese, and zinc compared to plants treated with Ca(NO3)2. Therefore, rotation with ‘Saia’ oats combined with (NH4)2SO4 fertilization may suppress strawberry black root rot and enhance yields through multiple effects on the host, pathogens, and associated microflora.', 0.6379991173744202]]
Context 4: [['Combining Saia oats as a single-season rotation with (NH4)2SO4 fertilization produced larger strawberry plants, more early yield, and less damage from black root rot than if Saia oats were combined with Ca(NO3)2 or if another rotation crop was paired with the (NH4)2SO4 treatment. Rotating strawberries with sorgho-sudangrass and fertilizing with (NH4)2SO4 reduced lesion nematodes but did not affect disease severity or yield. Similarly, Garry oats reduced disease severity and root colonization by R. fragariae but did not increase plant growth or yield.', 0.5004295706748962]]
Context 5: [['Increasing nitrogen and potassium in nutrient solutions resulted in higher percentages of both elements in strawberry but also increased the severity of anthracnose. To decrease anthracnose in strawberries, it is suggested that a minimum of nitrogen and potassium should be present in any fertilizer used, not exceeding 15 and 10 units of nitrogen and potassium, respectively.', 0.47463998198509216]]
Context 6: [['Elmer, W. H., and Lamondia, J. A. (1999). Influence of ammonium sulfate and rotation crops on strawberry root rot. Plant Dis., 83:119-123.', 0.4165493845939636]]
Context 7: [['In a related study, the severity of anthracnose fruit rot, caused by Colletotrichum acutatum, was also reduced with the application of Ca(NO3)2 on greenhouse-grown strawberries. Similar findings were reported regarding the control of Fusarium diseases in tomatoes and chrysanthemums. Notably, there was a significant variation in foliar N levels among different strawberry clones, suggesting that N applications should be customized for each cultivar. Nonetheless, the trend of decreased anthracnose severity with nitrate fertilizers was consistent across five strawberry clones tested, indicating that other cultivars may respond similarly.', 0.4143666625022888]]
Context 8: [['Elmer, W. H., and LaMondia, J. A. 1999. Influence of ammonium sulfate and rotation crops on strawberry black root rot. Plant Dis. 83:119-123.', 0.3888031244277954]]
Context 9: [['The application of nitrogen (N) in the form of calcium nitrate (Ca(NO3)2) significantly reduced the severity of anthracnose crown rot in strawberries. In contrast, the levels of phosphorus (P) and potassium (K) in fertilizers did not have a similar effect. Plants receiving N as Ca(NO3)2 exhibited fewer symptoms of anthracnose crown rot compared to those receiving N in ammonium form. Although these trials were conducted with potted plants in a greenhouse, the findings are applicable to strawberries grown in sandy soils, typical of Florida.', 0.3631685674190521]]

query: What are the primary environmental factors required for successful strawberry cultivation?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Strawberries (Fragaria×ananassa Duch.) are a widely cultivated hybrid species within the Rosaceae family, renowned for their fruit. They are increasingly significant for the agricultural economic development of countries like Iran, particularly in the Kurdistan province, which leads in strawberry production, predominantly under open-field conditions (Tehranifar and Sarsaefi, 2002). Various biotic and abiotic factors contribute to the decline in strawberry production globally. Notably, over 100 fungal species can invade strawberry plants, with approximately one-third causing serious diseases on different plant parts (Martin and others).', 0.5426968336105347]]
Context 1: [['Strawberry (Fragaria ananassa Duch.) is a popular small fruit crop known for its high economic and nutritive value, and it is in high demand globally. From 2008 to 2018, the annual worldwide cultivation of strawberries increased from approximately 400 to 483 thousand hectares. Although strawberries are native to temperate regions, they can also be grown in tropical and subtropical regions, sometimes under high-altitude conditions. The land areas devoted to strawberry cultivation in Colombia, Peru, Guatemala, Bolivia, and Taiwan in 2018 were 1,482 ha, 1,453 ha, 690 ha, 522 ha, and 506 ha, respectively.', 0.23208484053611755]]
Context 2: [['Peng, D. L., and Peng, S. L. (2011). Strawberry biological characteristics and key cultivation techniques. Jilin Vegetables, 5: 22-24.', 0.22620642185211182]]
Context 3: [['Korean strawberry production amounted to 1.23 billion won and 163 thousand tons in 2020. It ranked first among horticultural crops and is a primary income crop for farms. In 2021, the greenhouse strawberry cultivation area was 6057 ha, while open field cultivation accounted for only 46 ha, less than 1% of the total strawberry cultivation area. The hydroponic cultivation area for strawberries expanded to 1596 ha in 2020. Hydroponics using an artificial substrate can provide physical and chemical conditions suitable for nutrient absorption by plants. Intensive and effective crop management can be achieved through hydroponic techniques that supply nutrients using a nutrient solution in the substrates. In hydroponics, water supply control is performed to maintain...', 0.22360998392105103]]
Context 4: [['The modern strawberry, Fragaria × ananassa Duchesne, is of relatively recent origin. It was not until the North American F. virginiana and the South American F. chiloensis were brought together and hybridized in Europe around 1750 that the progenitor of the strawberry we know today was developed. The high degree of genetic heterozygosity in Fragaria spp. has facilitated the creation of strawberry cultivars adapted to a wide range of environmental conditions and resistant to several diseases and pests. Today, cultivars are available that can survive the bitterly cold winters of Alaska, as well as those that thrive in the long, hot seasons of Pretoria, South Africa.', 0.21254391968250275]]
Context 5: [['Scott, D.H. and F.J. Lawrence. 1975. Strawberries, p. 71-97. In: J. Janick and J.N. Moore (eds.). Advances in fruit breeding. Purdue University Press, West Lafayette, Indiana.', 0.2109259068965912]]
Context 6: [['Strawberries, perhaps the most delectable of fruits, are grown for their attractiveness and exquisite flavor in most temperate and many tropical areas of the world. Some believe the world would indeed be a dull place without strawberries to excite the taste buds and enliven desserts and pastries. Strawberry cultivation can be traced back thousands of years, with origins in Europe well documented in literature and art. Fragaria vesca L. (diploid, 2n=14 chromosomes) and F. moschata (hexaploid, 2n=42 chromosomes) were cultivated in palace and church gardens. Strawberry culture in the New World, particularly in North and South America, is less well documented. North American natives appreciated the springtime appearance of F. virginiana Duchesne (octaploid, 2n=56 chromosomes) fruit, although this species was likely not cultivated until Europeans began exploring and settling in North America. However, native inhabitants of Chile and Peru had selected and cultivated superior variants of F. chiloensis (L.) Quebe- sene (octaploid, 2n=56 chromosomes) well before the arrival of conquistadors in the 16th century.', 0.20866626501083374]]
Context 7: [['Smith, B.J., C.L. Gupton, G.J. Galletta, J.L. Maas, J.M. Enns, J.R. Ballington, Jr., R.J. Constantin, T.J. DiVittorio, and D. Himelrick. 1998. Pelican strawberry. HortScience 33:1082-1084.', 0.20521456003189087]]
Context 8: [['Strand, L. L. 2008. Integrated Pest Management for Strawberries, 2nd Ed. University of California, Oakland.', 0.20333915948867798]]
Context 9: [['Although strawberries are considered a minor crop, they provide a significant source of income for many fruit and nursery growers. In the United States, strawberries were cultivated on nearly 20,000 hectares in 1989, yielding a total production of 555,000 tons valued at $520 million. Florida ranks second only to California in the production of fresh-market strawberries. For U.S. winter production (December through March), strawberries are grown on approximately 2,400 hectares. The major cultural problems faced by the Florida strawberry industry include: 1) anthracnose diseases, 2) yearly infestations of the two-spotted spider mite (Tetranychus urticae Koch), and 3) variability in the quality of nursery transplants. Commercial fields are established annually, similar to California practices. Freshly dug transplants are sourced from nurseries in Florida or from northern states and Canada. The use of transplants from northern nurseries is crucial to avoid anthracnose disease issues and to ensure that plants have undergone sufficient natural chilling to induce floral bud initiation.', 0.2007843255996704]]

Additionally, cultivars with relative resistance may be crossed with commercial cultivars in breeding programs to improve and develop resistant varieties. To the best of our knowledge, this study represents the first attempt to evaluate the reaction of certain commercial strawberry cultivars against Colletotrichum nymphaeae, which causes strawberry AFR.', 0.8618730902671814]]
Context 1: [['During the 1920s, more than 130 strawberry cultivars and 20 selections of Fragaria species were utilized in the breeding program, with 44 of these parents originating from Europe (Darrow et al., 1934). Thousands of seedlings were evaluated, resulting in the naming of several cultivars (Darrow, 1937). The two most significant cultivars from this early work were ‘Blakemore’ and ‘Fairfax’. ‘Blakemore’ quickly became a leading cultivar, setting a standard for firmness that allowed successful long-distance shipping of fruit. This cultivar demonstrated wide adaptability in the southern and south-central regions of the U.S. and continues to be commercially grown in some areas. Both ‘Blakemore’ and ‘Fairfax’, along with other USDA selections such as 253, 543, and 634, became widely used as parent plants in subsequent breeding programs (Darrow, 1966). ‘Fairfax’ was particularly valued for its excellent fruit quality and resistance to leaf spot (Darrow, 1962).', 0.42704281210899353]]
Context 2: [['The development of cultivars resistant to red stele has been a primary objective of the USDA program. In the Pacific Northwest, Waldo introduced ‘Siletz’ in 1955, marking the first red stele-resistant strawberry for this region. Since then, two other significant red stele-resistant cultivars, ‘Hood’ and ‘Benton’, have emerged from the cooperative USDA-Oregon State strawberry breeding program. Furthermore, the first day-neutral cultivars with multiple resistances to red stele, ‘Tristar’ and ‘Tribute’, were released from Beltsville in 1981 (Galletta et al., 1981).', 0.423162579536438]]

query: How do variations within the C. acutatum species complex influence host specialization and infection patterns?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Members of the C. acutatum species complex have been well-documented from agricultural and natural hosts worldwide (Perfect et al., 1999; Peres et al., 2005; Sreenivasaprasad and Talhinhas, 2005). The scientific community has long studied the biomolecular processes regulating this lifestyle, especially those related to the switch from biotrophy to necrotrophy. The species complex has a very wide host range. Meta-analyses have revealed that C. acutatum s.l. strains are associated with infections in hundreds of species from over 90 genera of plants (Magnoliophyta: monocotyledons and dicotyledons, Pinophyta, and Pteridophyta), along with at least two insect species (Dufresne et al., 2000; Thon et al., 2002; Wharton and Diéguez-Uribeondo, 2004; O’Connell et al., 2012; Marcelino et al., 2008; Mascarin et al., 2016). In a few cases, associations have been noted with marine ecosystems (Manire et al., 2002; Namikoshi et al., 2002). There appears to be little to no evidence of co-evolution between host and pathogen, particularly in cultivated fruit systems like strawberry and olive, which are susceptible to many members of this species complex (Jayawardena et al., 2016).', 0.9614489078521729]]
Context 1: [['Differences in pathogenicity among strains from different hosts have been observed in several studies. Some fruit diseases caused by the C. acutatum complex have been shown to arise from distinct phylogenetic lineages (Peres et al. 2008), with strawberry fruit rot, in particular, rarely attributed to isolates from heterogeneous hosts (Mackenzie et al. 2009). Cross-infection potential was tested in various studies, including those by Bernstein et al. (1995), Freeman and Shabi (1996), Freeman et al. (2001b), and Mackenzie et al. (2007). Cross-infection may occur both in the field and in laboratory settings (Afanador-Kafuri et al. 2003). Freeman et al. (2001a) found that C. acutatum from strawberry could cause lesions on various fruits, whether they were wounded or intact. In vitro infection studies by Whitelaw-Weckert et al. (2007) revealed low host specificity among isolates that can be assigned to C. acutatum, C. simmondsii, and C. fioriniae.', 0.7288216948509216]]
Context 2: [['Recently, more focus has been placed on conidium morphology, particularly shape and dimensions. The acute conidial ends that contribute to the typical fusiform shape are considered critical morphological features of C. acutatum (Simmonds 1965). However, the name C. acutatum has been applied to various species exhibiting fusiform conidia, many of which are closely related to C. acutatum s. str. Moreover, conidial shape can show significant variation both within the species and among strains (Damm et al. 2012). Studies have shown that the fusiform conidial shape is not a consistent feature in the C. acutatum species complex. For instance, Talhinhas et al. (2002) noted that Colletotrichum isolates from Lupinus spp. (equivalent to C. lupini) displayed varying proportions of conidia with round ends or one round and one acute end, resulting in cylindrical or clavate shapes. In a recent investigation, many strains previously classified as C. gloeosporioides, based on typical cylindrical conidia (Cannon et al. 2008), were found to belong to different species within the C. acutatum complex (Damm et al. 2012). Additionally, there are species with acute-ended conidia that are phylogenetically distinct from the C. acutatum complex, such as C. pseudoacutatum and C. proteae (Cannon et al. 2012; Damm et al. 2012; Liu et al. 2013). The revision of the C. acutatum complex has recognized 31 species through a multilocus molecular approach, significantly advancing our understanding of these plant pathogens (Damm et al. 2012).', 0.7248852252960205]]
Context 3: [['C. acutatum, as noted by various studies (Peres et al. 2008; Lee et al. 2007; Talhinhas et al. 2011; Polashock et al. 2009; Wharton & Schilder 2008), has a well-known morphological feature: the shape of its conidia, which are characterized by acute ends (Simmonds 1965). However, other conidial shapes are frequently encountered, particularly cylindrical forms with only one acute end. These variations are often observed in strains that have been repeatedly subcultured, as well as in the “terminal crook” disease of pine (Dingley & Gilmour 1972) and in the anthracnose affecting leather leaf fern (Schiller et al. 2006). There are also reports of disseminated infections in sea turtles (Manire et al. 2002) and infections in scale insects (Marcelino et al. 2008). Differentiating between C. acutatum (s. lat.) and C. gloeosporioides (s. lat.) is challenging due to the existence of many intermediate strains that exhibit a limited number of typical fusiform conidia alongside numerous cylindrical ones (Van der Aa et al. 1990).', 0.5862597823143005]]
Context 4: [['The perceived lack of host specificity in the C. acutatum complex likely has multiple causes, but a significant issue stems from inadequate identification practices in pathology studies. Many investigations still avoid including sequence-based evidence or rely solely on ITS sequences, with only a few depositing adequate voucher material. This leads to less rigorous name usage than is necessary, resulting in misleading outcomes and poor comparability between studies. It must be acknowledged that many, if not most, of the species recognized through multigene analyses do not seem to be restricted to particular plants.', 0.5829077363014221]]
Context 5: [['In the subsequent text, it discusses research on C. acutatum and its genetic diversity. Primed PCR and AT-rich DNA analyses identified four subgroups of the pathogen. Subgroup I contains isolates from various hosts, including almond, apple, peach, and pecan in the U.S., while Israeli isolates from almond belong to subgroup IV. Other studies revealed that isolates from numerous hosts across different countries clustered into the same genetic subgroups, suggesting a lack of host specificity but some evidence of specialization for certain hosts, like key lime.', 0.49720045924186707]]
Context 6: [['Our research aims to present a comprehensive revision of the C. acutatum species complex. We thoroughly survey the constituent taxa and delineate additional species where needed. We have examined a large number of C. acutatum s. lat. strains, isolated from various hosts and geographic areas. Multi-locus molecular analysis serves as the basis for species recognition, although morphological and cultural characters allowing alternative means of species recognition are provided where possible.', 0.3696117401123047]]
Context 7: [['The sexual stage of certain genetic subgroups of C. acutatum has been characterized under laboratory conditions and designated as Glomerella acutata. Research indicates that many isolates from diverse hosts can mate and form mature perithecia in culture. Crosses within isolates in group C, as well as some intergroup crosses, exhibit high fertility, while others show weak fertility or infertility. However, mating compatibility in C. acutatum and other Colletotrichum species is complex.', 0.3386366665363312]]
Context 8: [['Other hosts attacked by more than one species of the C. acutatum species complex include apple, citrus, olive, cranberry, and blueberry. For example, the causal organisms of bitter rot of apple in Korea belong to C. acutatum clades 2 (C. nymphaeae and related species) and 3 (C. fioriniae) (Lee et al. 2007). In our study, strains from Malus belong to five species: C. acerbum (one strain), C. fioriniae (13 strains), C. godetiae (two strains), C. nymphaeae (one strain), and C. salicis (two strains). Talhinhas et al. (2005) identified five groups, now recognized as species, within C. acutatum s. lat. occurring on olives in Portugal: A2 (now C. nymphaeae), A3 (C. fioriniae), A4 (C. godetiae), A5 (C. acutatum), and A6 (C. rhombiforme).', 0.33592697978019714]]
Context 9: [['Varying band patterns indicate that C. acutatum isolates from diverse hosts—including anemone, almond, apple, peach, pecan, and strawberry—represent three genotypes, showcasing considerable overall heterogeneity within this species.', 0.33094754815101624]]

query: How does pathogen diversity within a population affect the success of fungicide treatments?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['The sensitivity ranges of the isolates to various fungicides were 0.2 to 1.6 mg/ml and 0.002 to 0.2 mg/ml, respectively, with average values of 6.5 to 6.9 mg/ml, 1.5 to 0.6 mg/ml, 0.9 to 0.4 mg/ml, and 0.1 to 0.05 mg/ml, respectively. All isolates were more sensitive to difenoconazole, flusilazole, and carbendazim than to tebuconazole (P < 0.01). However, sensitivities to the same fungicide varied among isolates. Specifically, isolates SL-31 and TS-09 were the least sensitive to carbendazim and tebuconazole, with resistance ratios of 87.3 and 51.6, respectively. Sensitivities to difenoconazole and flusilazole were largely consistent across all isolates, with resistance ratios ranging from 1 to 4.6 and from 1 to 7, respectively. Therefore, difenoconazole and flusilazole could be recommended for disease control. Notably, differences in pathogenicity and fungicide sensitivity were not correlated with geographic regions. These findings indicate a high level of intraspecific diversity within the populations of Colletotrichum gloeosporioides s.s. responsible for walnut anthracnose. For effective management, a targeted control strategy should be developed based on different geographic regions.', 0.4497946500778198]]
Context 1: [['Past failures of fungicides to control anthracnose epidemics may have stemmed from the development of resistance in the Colletotrichum population. In the early 1970s, benomyl effectively reduced anthracnose crown rot incidence (Horn et al., 1972; Howard, 1971) and was widely used by strawberry growers for years. However, anthracnose pathogens developed resistance to it and other benzimidazole fungicides, rendering benomyl ineffective. In vitro and greenhouse trials have been conducted to identify fungicides to which Colletotrichum pathogens have developed resistance (LaMondia, 1993, 1995; McInnes et al., 1992a, 1992b; Smith and Black, 1991, 1992, 1993). Current fungicide labels address pathogen resistance by restricting the number of consecutive and total applications of a product per season. For instance, the fungicides Abound (azoxystrobin, Syngenta, Greensboro, NC), Cabrio (pyraclostrobin, BASF, Research Triangle Park, NC), and Pristine (pyraclostrobin and boscalid, BASF) are limited to four or five applications per season, with no more than two consecutive applications before alternating with a fungicide that has a different mode of action. Natural products have also been evaluated as alternative fungicides, offering different modes of action, lower toxicity, and increased efficacy (Abril et al., 2008).', 0.22013649344444275]]

query: What are the challenges of scaling hydroponic strawberry production for commercial use?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Abstract: Although hydroponic techniques enable intensive and effective crop management, controlling watering for each crop type and growth stage is challenging with commonly used timed watering systems. This often results in excessive or insufficient watering. Hydroponic technology that considers drainage rates can minimize drainage amounts, thereby reducing environmental pollution and fertilizer consumption. This study compared drainage rates and timed watering methods in a strawberry hydroponic system to determine the optimal drainage rate. As the drainage rate increased, the amount of water supplied also increased. A significantly negative correlation was found between the amount of water supplied and the total nitrogen content. The drainage electrical conductivity (EC) level was highest in the 10% drainage rate group. In the 20% drainage rate treatment, leaf length and width increased compared to the four applications of the timer-supplying method. The yield of fruits weighing more than 27 g was highest in the 20% drainage rate treatment, indicating it was the most appropriate. We propose that it is possible to reduce unnecessary fertilizer consumption and increase productivity by managing water supply through drainage rates for precise water supply management in strawberries.', 0.5451347827911377]]
Context 1: [['Korean strawberry production amounted to 1.23 billion won and 163 thousand tons in 2020. It ranked first among horticultural crops and is a primary income crop for farms. In 2021, the greenhouse strawberry cultivation area was 6057 ha, while open field cultivation accounted for only 46 ha, less than 1% of the total strawberry cultivation area. The hydroponic cultivation area for strawberries expanded to 1596 ha in 2020. Hydroponics using an artificial substrate can provide physical and chemical conditions suitable for nutrient absorption by plants. Intensive and effective crop management can be achieved through hydroponic techniques that supply nutrients using a nutrient solution in the substrates. In hydroponics, water supply control is performed to maintain...', 0.3387441635131836]]
Context 2: [['Although strawberries are considered a minor crop, they provide a significant source of income for many fruit and nursery growers. Florida ranks second only to California in the production of fresh-market strawberries. For U.S. winter production (December through March), strawberries are grown on approximately 2,400 hectares. The major cultural problems faced by the Florida strawberry industry include: 1) anthracnose diseases, 2) yearly infestations of the two-spotted spider mite (Tetranychus urticae Koch), and 3) variability in the quality of nursery transplants. Commercial fields are established annually, similar to California practices. Freshly dug transplants are sourced from nurseries in Florida or from northern states and Canada. Context 0: [['Abstract: Colletotrichum fructicola is a major causal agent of anthracnose in strawberries in Nara, Japan. We hypothesized that various weeds growing in and around strawberry fields serve as inoculum sources for this disease. Additionally, we investigated the effect of herbicide treatment on C. fructicola sporulation on these weeds.', 0.9701234698295593]]
Context 1: [['The experiment assessed the pathogenicity of Colletotrichum fructicola on various weed species and its influence on strawberry plants. It was found that C. fructicola is not pathogenic on strawberries. Among the weed species tested, Amaranthus blitum exhibited the highest infection rate, with 17.9% affected by C. fructicola (see Table 2). Other weeds, such as Digitaria ciliaris, Galinsoga ciliata, Solidago altissima, Erigeron annuus, and Sonchus oleraceus, showed relatively low detection rates (4.3% to 8.1%) without displaying symptoms. Notably, C. fructicola was not isolated from the remaining seven weed species, which included Senecio vulgaris, Cyperus microiria, Lamium amplexicaule, Portulaca oleracea, Alopecurus aequalis, Capsella bursa-pastoris, and Cerastium glomeratum. The fungus was isolated more frequently from warm-season weeds compared to cool-season ones (refer to Table 2).', 0.7968448996543884]]

query: What cultivation practices can limit the spread of Colletotrichum?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['The genus Colletotrichum is considered one of the top ten important genera of fungal pathogens globally (Dean et al., 2012). Colletotrichum is an ancient fungus that has co-evolved with flowering plants. Plant microfossils of Protocolletotrichum preserved on angiosperm leaf cuticles suggest that the diverse pathogenic strategies of Colletotrichum spp. have been established since the Late Cretaceous period (Kar et al., 2004). Different complexes within the genus may have diverged between 4.8 and 32.2 million years ago (MYA) (Bhunjun et al., 2021). The emergence of agricultural cultivation and the intensive disturbance of natural environments have further driven the diversification of Colletotrichum species. These fungi have adapted to thousands of hosts and can be found as endophytes, pathogens, and saprobes (Freeman et al., 1998; Dean et al., 2012; Hirayama et al., 2018; da Silva et al., 2020; Jayawardena et al., 2020). Currently, a total of 257 Colletotrichum species grouped into 15 complexes and 13 additional singletons have been accepted in this genus.', 0.6201382875442505]]
Context 1: [['Many species belonging to the genus Colletotrichum are associated with plant diseases, commonly referred to as anthracnose. Colletotrichum spp. can affect a wide range of hosts, and these pathogens are characterized by global distribution. Virtually every cultivated botanical family is susceptible to one or more species of Colletotrichum, making it one of the most studied plant pathogenic fungi (Prusky et al., 2000; Latunde-Dada, 2001; Dean et al., 2012). Common hosts include many dicotyledonous plants such as strawberry, apple, citrus, and stone fruits, as well as major cereals such as maize and sorghum. Members of this genus can cause crop losses of up to 100% in many staple foods (Bailey and Jeger, 1992; Prusky et al., 2000; Talhinhas et al., 2005; Cannon et al., 2012).', 0.4814787209033966]]

query: What are the environmental risks associated with using chemical fungicides for anthracnose control?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Present and Future Management of Anthracnose: Fungicides, including chemicals such as benzimidazoles (e.g., thiabendazole, benomyl, and carbendazim) and sterol inhibitors (e.g., imazalil, prochloraz, and propiconazole), have been used effectively to control anthracnose disease in banana, mango, papaya, and avocado plants [140]. Benzimidazoles are commonly applied as dips or sprays to inhibit the anthracnose-causing fungus, Colletotrichum spp. [141], but the large-scale and continuous use of fungicides has led to the development of fungal resistance. For instance, benzimidazole-resistant Colletotrichum has been detected in mangoes and bananas [140]. Additionally, the excessive use of fungicides negatively impacts human health and the environment, as chemical residues often contaminate soil and water [142]. Biocontrol offers an alternative, non-toxic method for managing fruit crop anthracnose. Biocontrol agents, such as antagonistic microbes including yeast, bacteria, and filamentous fungi (particularly Trichoderma spp.), have shown promising results and are gaining popularity for their direct application to fruit surfaces post-harvest [143].', 0.9851470589637756]]
Context 1: [['Until highly resistant cultivars are available, growers must rely on chemical applications and cultural practices to reduce losses due to anthracnose. The failure of fungicides to control anthracnose epidemics may be due to the development of fungicide resistance in the Colletotrichum spp. population. For example, benomyl effectively reduced the incidence of anthracnose crown rot (Horn et al., 1972; Howard, 1971) and was used intensively by strawberry growers for years to control anthracnose and other diseases. However, the anthracnose pathogens, C. acutatum and C. fragariae, developed resistance to it and other benzimidazole fungicides (LaMondia, 1995; McInnes et al., 1992a; Smith and Black, 1992, 1993), rendering benomyl ineffective for anthracnose control in strawberry fields.', 0.9152722358703613]]
Context 2: [['Until highly resistant cultivars are available, growers must rely on chemical applications and cultural practices to reduce losses due to anthracnose. The failure of fungicides to control anthracnose epidemics may be attributed to the development of fungicide resistance in the Colletotrichum species population. For example, benomyl was shown to effectively reduce the incidence of anthracnose crown rot (Horn et al., 1972; Howard, 1971) and was used intensively by strawberry growers for years to control anthracnose and other diseases. However, the anthracnose pathogens, C. acutatum and C. fragariae, developed resistance to it and other benzimidazole fungicides (LaMondia, 1995; McInnes et al., 1992a; Smith and Black, 1992, 1993), leading to the ineffectiveness of benomyl for anthracnose control in strawberry fields.', 0.9074278473854065]]
Context 3: [['There is an urgent need for multi- and single-site fungicide alternatives effective against anthracnose in strawberry nurseries and production fields. The antifungal antibiotic natamycin, widely used as a natural mold inhibitor in food products, has shown promise in controlling anthracnose root and crown infections caused by C. acutatum on strawberry transplants (Cordova et al. 2017; Haack et al. 2018). Similarly, fluazinam, a single-site respiration inhibitor fungicide from FRAC group 29, has demonstrated significant control of anthracnose fruit rot (Mertely et al. 2018). A request has been submitted through the Interregional Research Project Number 4 for its registration for nursery use only. Reducing the overlap of the same modes of action used during nursery and fruit production phases could help extend the lifespan of single-site fungicides at high risk of resistance.', 0.806527853012085]]
Context 4: [['For the management of anthracnose crown rot, water washing or fungicide treatments of bare-root transplants have been utilized in the nursery or immediately before planting in production fields (Daugovish et al., 2009; Freeman et al., 1997). Running water effectively removes soil from root and crown tissues, potentially eliminating inoculum, but it does not control any infections already present (Koike et al., 2008). Pre-plant fungicide dips have been shown to decrease anthracnose crown rot; however, only two products are currently registered for this use in the United States. The single-site mode of action quinone outside inhibitor (QoI), azoxystrobin, has been widely used as a preplant dip and as a foliar treatment for managing anthracnose and other fungal diseases (Bartlett et al., 2002; Koike et al., 2008; Turechek et al., 2006). Resistance has been reported against this fungicide group in Colletotrichum acutatum populations from strawberries in Florida (Forcelini et al., 2016). During the 2015-16 California nursery crown rot outbreak, growers reported reduced efficacy of azoxystrobin dips, suggesting that resistance may also be present in California (K. Ivors, unpublished). A premixed product of the anilinopyrimidine cyprodinil and the phenylpyrrole fludioxonil is also registered, but phytotoxicity and stunting of plants have been reported under certain environmental conditions or following off-label exposure (G. Holmes, unpublished).', 0.7900792360305786]]
Context 5: [['As our knowledge of the anthracnose pathogens and the epidemiology of anthracnose diseases has increased, so has our ability to control these diseases. Changes in cultural practices have resulted in reduced levels of disease. Additionally, the development and registration of more effective fungicides for use on strawberries have significantly reduced losses from both anthracnose crown rot and fruit rot. Anthracnose-resistant cultivars have also diminished economic losses due to these diseases. Nevertheless, growers may still experience severe losses when environmental factors are highly favorable for anthracnose development.', 0.7605698108673096]]
Context 6: [['Past failures of fungicides to control anthracnose epidemics may have stemmed from the development of resistance in the Colletotrichum population. In the early 1970s, benomyl effectively reduced anthracnose crown rot incidence (Horn et al., 1972; Howard, 1971) and was widely used by strawberry growers for years. However, anthracnose pathogens developed resistance to it and other benzimidazole fungicides, rendering benomyl ineffective. In vitro and greenhouse trials have been conducted to identify fungicides to which Colletotrichum pathogens have developed resistance (LaMondia, 1993, 1995; McInnes et al., 1992a, 1992b; Smith and Black, 1991, 1992, 1993). Current fungicide labels address pathogen resistance by restricting the number of consecutive and total applications of a product per season. For instance, the fungicides Abound (azoxystrobin, Syngenta, Greensboro, NC), Cabrio (pyraclostrobin, BASF, Research Triangle Park, NC), and Pristine (pyraclostrobin and boscalid, BASF) are limited to four or five applications per season, with no more than two consecutive applications before alternating with a fungicide that has a different mode of action. Natural products have also been evaluated as alternative fungicides, offering different modes of action, lower toxicity, and increased efficacy (Abril et al., 2008).', 0.7569725513458252]]
Context 7: [['As our understanding of the anthracnose pathogens and the epidemiology of anthracnose diseases has improved, so has our capacity to control these diseases. Changes in cultural practices have led to reduced levels of disease. Additionally, the development and registration of more effective fungicides for use on strawberries have significantly decreased losses due to anthracnose crown rot and fruit rot. The introduction of partially resistant cultivars has also helped mitigate economic losses due to these diseases. Nonetheless, growers may still experience severe losses when environmental conditions are highly conducive to anthracnose development.', 0.7470991015434265]]
Context 8: [['Increased losses due to anthracnose fruit and crown rots may be related to the shift from matted-row culture to the annual plasticulture production system in the United States. Breeding for genetic resistance to anthracnose and the development of resistant cultivars are primary means for reducing economic losses due to this disease. This approach is environmentally sound because it results in reduced fungicide use. As our knowledge of the anthracnose pathogens and the epidemiology of anthracnose diseases has increased, so has our ability to control these diseases. Changes in cultural practices have resulted in reduced levels of disease. Simultaneously, the development of more effective fungicides and their registration for use on strawberries have significantly reduced losses due to both anthracnose crown rot and fruit rot. Anthracnose-resistant cultivars have also decreased economic losses caused by these diseases. Nevertheless, growers may still face severe losses when environmental conditions are highly favorable for anthracnose development.', 0.739225447177887]]
Context 9: [['In-vitro trials have been used to screen fungicides for their ability to control anthracnose (LaMondia, 1993; McInnes et al., 1992b; Smith and Black, 1992). Smith and Black (1993) reported that all 16 C. acutatum, 14 out of 18 C. fragariae, and both C. gloeosporioides isolates tested in vitro were resistant to benomyl, and all benomyl-resistant isolates were also resistant to carbendazim, which belongs to the same class of fungicides as benomyl. In a greenhouse study, plants treated with propiconazole exhibited lower disease severity ratings than those treated with captafol or benomyl (Smith and Black, 1991). However, the propiconazole-treated plants were shorter, with dark green leaves that appeared thicker than the leaves of untreated plants.', 0.6468501091003418]]

query: What is the significance of the CAL gene in the study of Colletotrichum species?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['A polyphasic approach combining multilocus phylogenetic analysis with recognizable phenotypic characteristics is recommended for accurate species identification within the Colletotrichum genus. According to Weir et al., internal transcribed spacer (ITS) sequences alone are not reliable for distinguishing different species within the C. gloeosporioides species complex. Additional loci recommended for identifying Colletotrichum species include actin (ACT), calmodulin (CAL), chitin synthase-1 (CHS-1), glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate dehydrogenase (GAPDH), and β-tubulin (TUB2).', 0.9333893656730652]]
Context 1: [['In recent years, genome sequences for 28 species of Colletotrichum have been published, and comparative genomic studies have concentrated on genes associated with pathogenicity (Gan et al., 2013), host specialization (Baroncelli et al., 2016; Gan et al., 2016), and transitions between biotrophic and necrotrophic lifestyles (O’Connell et al., 2012), as well as between endophytic and parasitic lifestyles (Hacquard et al., 2016; Hiruma et al., 2016). Comparative analyses of secretomes have revealed that most predicted secreted proteins possess enzymatic activity, with many identified as candidate effectors (O’Connell et al., 2012; Gan et al., 2013; Baroncelli et al., 2016; Sanz-Martín et al., 2016). The host range of Colletotrichum species seems to be linked to gene loss or gain in families encoding carbohydrate-active enzymes (CAZymes) and proteases (Baroncelli et al., 2016). Notably, gene families encoding proteases and carbohydrate-degrading enzymes are significantly expanded in Colletotrichum compared to other Sordariomycetes (Gan et al., 2013; Baroncelli et al., 2016), indicating the increased importance of these families in the infection processes of Colletotrichum species. Transcriptional profiling experiments have also shown that CAZymes, along with other classes of secreted proteins, are highly modulated during the infection process, further implicating them as critical players in pathogenicity (Kleemann et al., 2012; O’Connell et al., 2012).', 0.9235045313835144]]
Context 2: [['A similar set of six genes (ITS, ACT, CHS, GPDH, histone 3, and beta-tubulin) was used by Damm et al. (2009) to study Colletotrichum species with curved conidia from herbaceous hosts, which included six different clades. The best separability of the species was observed using both GPDH and histone 3 genes, which were superior to ITS, ACT, CHS, and beta-tubulin. The most appropriate gene for barcoding Colletotrichum must be selected during the species delimitation process since we can only choose one or more barcoding genes when we know which taxa need to be distinguished. A good approach would be to test and establish a selection of loci used by different groups involved in Colletotrichum systematics to work towards identifying the best barcoding gene.', 0.9022123217582703]]
Context 3: [['Purpose: To amplify and sequence CAL in Colletotrichum spp.', 0.8068086504936218]]
Context 4: [['Gan, P., Narusaka, M., Kumakura, N., Tsushima, A., Takano, Y., Narusaka, Y., Shirasu, K. (2016). Genus-wide comparative genome analyses of Colletotrichum species reveal specific gene family losses and gains during adaptation to specific infection lifestyles. Genome Biology and Evolution, 8(5):1467–1481.', 0.6190486550331116]]
Context 5: [['Crouch, J.A., Clarke, B., and Hillman, B. (2009a). What is the value of ITS sequence data in Colletotrichum systematics and species diagnosis? A case study using the falcate-spored graminicolous Colletotrichum group. Mycologia 101: 648-656.', 0.5104796886444092]]

query: Has Dr. Timmer published extensively on citrus disease control strategies, and if so, in which journals?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [["Dr. Timmer is a professor of plant pathology at the University of Florida. He received his B.S. in botany and plant pathology from Michigan State University and his Ph.D. from the University of California, Riverside. He spent two years conducting research on citrus diseases in Argentina during his doctoral program. From 1970 to 1978, he worked on research and extension related to citrus diseases at the Texas A&I University Citrus Center (now the Texas A&M Kingsville Citrus Center) in Weslaco, TX. Subsequently, he accepted a position with the University of Florida's Citrus Research and Education Center in Lake Alfred, where he is currently employed. His current research program focuses on basic research regarding the population genetics of fungi such as Pyricularia, Colletotrichum, and Fusarium. He also manages a large program addressing fungal diseases of citrus trees, including etiology, epidemiology, and disease control. For many years, his assignment was 100% research; however, it changed to 70% extension three years ago. Dr. Timmer has been active in the American Phytopathological Society (APS) and has served terms as both associate and senior editor of Phytopathology and currently as senior editor of Plant Disease. He has been an invited speaker at many APS symposia and has also been active in the Mycological Society of America.", 0.976579487323761]]
