query: What are the primary economic impacts of anthracnose disease on strawberry production?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Anthracnose is an important disease of strawberry caused by Colletotrichum spp., which affects foliage, runners, crowns, and fruits (Howard et al., 1992). Three primary fungal pathogens—C. acutatum sensu lato, C. gloeosporioides sensu lato, and C. fragariae—are known to cause anthracnose disease in strawberries (Freeman and Katan, 1997). The crown rot syndrome is characteristic of infections from C. gloeosporioides sensu lato and C. fragariae, while fruit rot is mainly attributed to C. acutatum sensu lato, leading to significant yield losses (Howard et al., 1992). Currently, numerous species are classified under what is now known as the C. acutatum complex, with six species—C. acutatum sensu stricto, C. fioriniae, C. godetiae, C. nymphaeae, C. salicis, and C. simmondsii—identified as associated with strawberry anthracnose worldwide (Damm et al., 2012). Among these, C. nymphaeae is the most prevalent pathogen causing strawberry anthracnose globally, including in Iran (Baroncelli et al., 2015; Karimi et al., 2017; Wang et al., 2019). Currently, no effective chemical control methods exist for managing strawberry anthracnose; available options are limited to preventive treatments applied before fruit production (Denoyes-Rothan et al., 1999). Additionally, concerns about the toxic effects of chemical fungicides on the environment and the development of resistance in fungal strains highlight the need for alternative control strategies. Consequently, utilizing resistant cultivars appears to be the most efficient and practical approach for suppressing anthracnose development. In light of recent anthracnose outbreaks in strawberry fields in the Kurdistan province of Iran (Karimi et al., 2017), and the necessity for appropriate strategies to address this issue, the aim of this study was to evaluate the resistance of several commercial strawberry cultivars to the anthracnose fruit rot caused by C. nymphaeae under in vivo and greenhouse conditions.', 0.9841166138648987]]
Context 1: [['In the early 1980s, anthracnose became a significant disease affecting strawberries in the southeastern United States. In response, the USDA-ARS established a breeding program to develop anthracnose-resistant cultivars suited to the strawberry-growing regions of this area. This initiative was conducted at the Small Fruit Research Station in Poplarville, MS, and the Fruit Laboratory in Beltsville, MD, in collaboration with state experiment stations in Florida, Louisiana, and North Carolina (Galletta et al., 1997; Smith and Spiers, 1982).', 0.6751275062561035]]
Context 2: [['So far, anthracnose epidemics have affected strawberry nurseries and production fields worldwide. Reports on Colletotrichum spp. associated with strawberries, curated from literature in PubMed and Clarivate combined with fungal database searches (Farr and Rossman, 2022), were compiled to understand the global diversity and occurrence of the causal agents of strawberry anthracnose. From our findings, since 1931 until July 9, 2022, there have been over 220 citations and 310 records related to the identification of causal agents of strawberry anthracnose at the genus level of Colletotrichum in 36 countries across six continents, with 282 records providing pathogen identification at the species or species complex level.', 0.6689565181732178]]
Context 3: [['De los Santos, B., de Paredes, G., and Munoz, F. R. (2002). Influence of anthracnose epiphytotic development on strawberry fruit production in Huelva (Southwestern Spain). Acta Hortic., 567:623-626.', 0.6153213977813721]]
Context 4: [['De los Santos, B., de Paredes, G., and Munoz, F. R. 2002. Influence of anthracnose epiphytotic development on strawberry fruit production in Huelva (Southwestern Spain). Acta Hortic. 567:623-626.', 0.5888115763664246]]
Context 5: [['Howard CM, Albregts EE. Anthracnose. In: Compendium of Strawberry Diseases. American Phytopathological Society: Paul St, ed. Maas JL, USA; 1984. pp. 85-87.', 0.574996829032898]]
Context 6: [["Anthracnose fungi can attack various parts of the strawberry plant, including crowns, petioles, leaves, fruit trusses, flowers, buds, and fruit. The fungi's ability to attack multiple plant parts, coupled with the involvement of several pathogen species, contributes to the complex nature of strawberry anthracnose. Brooks reported in 1931 that C. fragariae caused spotting and girdling of runners, and later indicated that it also caused spotting of petioles and crown rot in a summer nursery, leading to wilting and death of the plants. Researchers in Louisiana observed all these symptoms and noted that crown rot also occurred in the fruit production field.", 0.5516391396522522]]
Context 7: [['The term "anthracnose" was first used to describe a new disease of strawberries caused by Colletotrichum fragariae Brooks. "Strawberry anthracnose" continues to be used as a general term to identify all diseases of strawberries caused by species of Colletotrichum. Strawberry anthracnose diseases have been reported to be caused by C. acutatum J.H. Simmonds, C. gloeosporioides (Penz.) Penz. & Sacc. in Penz. (the teleomorph of Cromereilla cingulata (Stoneman) Spauld. & H. Schrenk), and C. dematium (Pers.) Grove. The latter species only occasionally causes strawberry fruit rots and will not be discussed here.', 0.5258569121360779]]
Context 8: [['Shao, X. H. (1992). New disease of strawberry: Strawberry anthracnose. Acta Agriculturae Shanghai.', 0.4771725535392761]]

query: How do multi-gene phylogenies improve the classification of Colletotrichum species?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['The shift towards multi-gene phylogenetic analysis has significantly changed the classification and species concepts within the Colletotrichum genus (Cannon et al. 2012, Damm et al. 2012a, b, 2013, 2014, Weir et al. 2012). Many Colletotrichum species are classified as latent plant pathogens, endophytes, epiphytes, or saprobes, and may adopt a pathogenic lifestyle when host plants are stressed (Damm et al. 2009, Cannon et al. 2012). Systematic studies of nearly all recognized species have identified several complexes, revealing that some Colletotrichum species historically considered as causal agents of significant plant diseases are actually different species. For example, C. alienum is now recognized as a key species in Proteaceae cultivation (Liu et al. 2013), while C. acutatum s.lat. was found in Mediterranean countries causing diseases in various hosts, such as Fragaria × ananassa (Garrido et al. 2008), Arbutus unedo (Polizzi et al. 2011), and Olea europaea (Talhinhas et al. 2011). Given the economic losses in citrus orchards, understanding these species interactions is crucial.', 0.9975691437721252]]
Context 1: [['The identification of Colletotrichum species has long been challenging due to limited morphological characteristics. Single-gene phylogenetic analyses have also proven unsuccessful in clearly delineating species, partly due to the high number of erroneous names in GenBank. This paper reviews the taxonomic problems associated with Colletotrichum and the difficulties in identifying taxa at the species level. We advocate for epitypification and the use of multi-locus phylogenetic methods to better delimit species and understand the genus.', 0.9931873083114624]]

Context 8: [['Disentangling species complexes within the Colletotrichum genus presents a significant challenge for taxonomists. Given the global importance of this genus, primarily consisting of plant pathogens, it is critical to accurately identify species and/or pathotypes to enhance biosecurity and disease control efforts. Traditional methods of species identification have relied on morphological, cultural, and host-preference criteria. However, these methods often prove unreliable, leading to unresolved taxonomic issues. As stated by Sutton (1992), relying solely on morphology is insufficient for improving the systematics of species complexes like C. gloeosporioides.', 0.8807383179664612]]

query: How do genetic variations in Colletotrichum species affect their pathogenicity on different hosts?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['The genus Colletotrichum is considered one of the top ten important genera of fungal pathogens globally (Dean et al., 2012). Colletotrichum is an ancient fungus that has co-evolved with flowering plants. Plant microfossils of Protocolletotrichum preserved on angiosperm leaf cuticles suggest that the diverse pathogenic strategies of Colletotrichum spp. have been established since the Late Cretaceous period (Kar et al., 2004). Different complexes within the genus may have diverged between 4.8 and 32.2 million years ago (MYA) (Bhunjun et al., 2021). The emergence of agricultural cultivation and the intensive disturbance of natural environments have further driven the diversification of Colletotrichum species. These fungi have adapted to thousands of hosts and can be found as endophytes, pathogens, and saprobes (Freeman et al., 1998; Dean et al., 2012; Hirayama et al., 2018; da Silva et al., 2020; Jayawardena et al., 2020). Currently, a total of 257 Colletotrichum species grouped into 15 complexes and 13 additional singletons have been accepted in this genus.', 0.9730901122093201]]
Context 1: [['In a drastic move, von Arx (1957) reduced the number of recognized Colletotrichum species from several hundred to 11 based on morphological characteristics, with many taxa treated as synonyms of C. gloeosporioides and C. dematium. Several additional species have since been accepted based on morphological criteria (Sutton, 1980; 1992). The difficulties in recognizing Colletotrichum species can be attributed to: 1) the limited and variable morphological characters; 2) an extensive host range and variability in pathogenicity (Bailey and Jeger, 1992; Freeman et al., 2000; Latunde-Dada, 2001; Du et al., 2005; Thaung, 2008); 3) type specimens that are often missing or in poor condition, making them unsuitable for molecular studies; and 4) numerous rDNA ITS sequences of Colletotrichum strains in NCBI that are often misidentified (Crouch et al., 2009d; Damm et al., 2009).', 0.9429488778114319]]

Context 1: [['Many species belonging to the genus Colletotrichum are associated with plant diseases, commonly referred to as anthracnose. Colletotrichum spp. can affect a wide range of hosts, and these pathogens are characterized by global distribution. Virtually every cultivated botanical family is susceptible to one or more species of Colletotrichum, making it one of the most studied plant pathogenic fungi (Prusky et al., 2000; Latunde-Dada, 2001; Dean et al., 2012). Common hosts include many dicotyledonous plants such as strawberry, apple, citrus, and stone fruits, as well as major cereals such as maize and sorghum. query: What environmental conditions promote the growth of anthracnose pathogens in strawberries?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Anthracnose is an important disease of strawberry caused by Colletotrichum spp., which affects foliage, runners, crowns, and fruits (Howard et al., 1992). Three primary fungal pathogens—C. acutatum sensu lato, C. gloeosporioides sensu lato, and C. fragariae—are known to cause anthracnose disease in strawberries (Freeman and Katan, 1997). The crown rot syndrome is characteristic of infections from C. gloeosporioides sensu lato and C. fragariae, while fruit rot is mainly attributed to C. acutatum sensu lato, leading to significant yield losses (Howard et al., 1992). Currently, numerous species are classified under what is now known as the C. acutatum complex, with six species—C. acutatum sensu stricto, C. fioriniae, C. godetiae, C. nymphaeae, C. salicis, and C. simmondsii—identified as associated with strawberry anthracnose worldwide (Damm et al., 2012). Among these, C. nymphaeae is the most prevalent pathogen causing strawberry anthracnose globally, including in Iran (Baroncelli et al., 2015; Karimi et al., 2017; Wang et al., 2019). Currently, no effective chemical control methods exist for managing strawberry anthracnose; available options are limited to preventive treatments applied before fruit production (Denoyes-Rothan et al., 1999). Additionally, concerns about the toxic effects of chemical fungicides on the environment and the development of resistance in fungal strains highlight the need for alternative control strategies. Consequently, utilizing resistant cultivars appears to be the most efficient and practical approach for suppressing anthracnose development. In light of recent anthracnose outbreaks in strawberry fields in the Kurdistan province of Iran (Karimi et al., 2017), and the necessity for appropriate strategies to address this issue, the aim of this study was to evaluate the resistance of several commercial strawberry cultivars to the anthracnose fruit rot caused by C. nymphaeae under in vivo and greenhouse conditions.', 0.9704422950744629]]
Context 1: [["Anthracnose fungi can attack various parts of the strawberry plant, including crowns, petioles, leaves, fruit trusses, flowers, buds, and fruit. The fungi's ability to attack multiple plant parts, coupled with the involvement of several pathogen species, contributes to the complex nature of strawberry anthracnose. Brooks reported in 1931 that C. fragariae caused spotting and girdling of runners, and later indicated that it also caused spotting of petioles and crown rot in a summer nursery, leading to wilting and death of the plants. Researchers in Louisiana observed all these symptoms and noted that crown rot also occurred in the fruit production field.", 0.6715630292892456]]
Context 2: [['Numerous reports indicate that strawberry anthracnose pathogens may originate from weed species. For instance, C. fragariae was found attacking the weed Cassia obtusifolia L. (sicklepod, coffeweed) in Florida, causing typical disease symptoms. Inoculation of strawberry with the Cassia isolates resulted in typical anthracnose symptoms, while isolates from strawberry were equally virulent on Cassia. Similarly, inoculation of Duchesnea indica (Andr.) Focke (wild strawberry), F. virginiana Duch. (Virginia wild strawberry), and Potentilla canadensis L. with C. fragariae induced anthracnose disease on these hosts, suggesting that strawberry anthracnose pathogens have a broad host range.', 0.6072443127632141]]
Context 3: [['So far, anthracnose epidemics have affected strawberry nurseries and production fields worldwide. Reports on Colletotrichum spp. associated with strawberries, curated from literature in PubMed and Clarivate combined with fungal database searches (Farr and Rossman, 2022), were compiled to understand the global diversity and occurrence of the causal agents of strawberry anthracnose. From our findings, since 1931 until July 9, 2022, there have been over 220 citations and 310 records related to the identification of causal agents of strawberry anthracnose at the genus level of Colletotrichum in 36 countries across six continents, with 282 records providing pathogen identification at the species or species complex level.', 0.4793025851249695]]
Context 4: [['Howard CM, Albregts EE. Anthracnose. In: Compendium of Strawberry Diseases. American Phytopathological Society: Paul St, ed. Maas JL, USA; 1984. pp. 85-87.', 0.4598623514175415]]

query: In the absence of a functional cuticle, does the cutinase enzyme still play an important role in fungal infection of chili fruits?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [["In contrast, there was no difference in infection and colonization by F8-3B-pAA1 transformants and the wild type on wounded fruit, suggesting that cutinase no longer played an important role in cell infection after the cuticle was penetrated. Hence, there was no disadvantage to the F8-3B-pAA1 transformants having reduced expression of cutinase once they had infected the pericarp tissue. These results were consistent with previously reported work demonstrating that the C. capsici pathotype F8-3B was able to infect chili fruits when wound inoculation was applied. If the hypothesis is that cutinase assists with the penetration of the fungal pathogen, then the wound inoculation method is unlikely to demonstrate the function of the gene since the host's first layer of defense (cuticle and epidermis) has been disrupted.", 0.9979606866836548]]
Context 1: [['The phytopathogenic fungus Colletotrichum truncatum infects and colonizes chili fruit through direct penetration of the cuticle. The cutinase gene of C. truncatum (CtCut1), a cutin-degrading enzyme, was identified, cloned, and shown to be essential for breaching the cuticle of chili fruit. The expression of the CtCut1 gene was studied through RNA-mediated gene silencing, and its impact on fungal pathogenicity was demonstrated. A vector, pAA1, encoding a hairpin RNA of GFP and CtCut1 was constructed and transformed into the virulent strain of C. truncatum, pathotype F8-3B. The F8-3B-pAA1 transformants exhibited reduced patterns of infection, with one isolate showing a 45.8% reduction in cutinase activity (reduction in CtCut1 transcript) compared to the wild type. Importantly, CtCut1-deficient strains were unable to infect detached chili and soybean hosts as efficiently as the wild type, showing a delay in the infection period. However, artificial wounding of the cuticle allowed these F8-3B-pAA1 transformants to infect and colonize host tissues, resulting in typical anthracnose disease lesions. Coupled with microscopy, these data suggested that the defect in pathogenicity was likely due to a failure in penetrating the host cutin. This research contributes to the understanding of plant-fungal interactions through the development of a fungal transformation system for C. truncatum and the implementation of RNAi technology, which provides an alternative genetic tool for studies of gene function, particularly for essential pathogenicity genes.', 0.9968384504318237]]
Context 2: [['The infection and colonization by F8-3B-pAA1 transformants on detached chili and soybean hosts were less efficient compared to the wild-type F8-3B, further suggesting the involvement of the gene during pathogenesis. Transformed strains were unable to infect normally, and there was a delay in infection, as indicated by the extremely slow development of anthracnose symptoms on chili fruits. It is suggested that direct penetration through the host cuticle during the infection process of C. truncatum was largely governed by the presence of cutinase in the fungus.', 0.9638166427612305]]
Context 3: [['Cutinase has been proposed as the hydrolyzing agent of the plant cuticle and/or an elicitor of cutin monomers, which trigger signaling pathways within fungal pathogens. Despite the identification of cutinase in various Colletotrichum species such as C. gloeosporioides, C. kahawae, C. trifolii, C. lagenarium, and C. capsici, the characterization of the gene and its function in the C. truncatum-chili interaction remains unexplored.', 0.9616663455963135]]
Context 4: [['Auyong et al. (2015) investigated the role of cutinase and its impact on the pathogenicity of Colletotrichum truncatum (Journal of Plant Pathology and Microbiology 6:259-269). Mongkolporn et al. (2010) documented differential reactions on mature green and ripe chili fruit infected by three Colletotrichum species (Plant Disease 94:306-310). Mongkolporn and Taylor (2018) provided an overview of chili anthracnose, discussing Colletotrichum taxonomy and pathogenicity (Plant Pathology 67:1255-1263).', 0.9199155569076538]]
Context 5: [['To achieve successful pathogenicity, fungi employ various infection strategies to breach the host cuticle. Some pathogens utilize mechanical means through specialized infection structures, while others penetrate the cuticle directly with the assistance of extracellular cutinase activity. Colletotrichum truncatum, a pathogen of legumes, cereals, grasses, and vegetable crops such as Capsicum species, is an ascomycete that infects its host through direct penetration of the host cuticle. The infection and penetration process is believed to be triggered by cutin-degrading enzymes such as cutinase. Numerous cutinases have been isolated and characterized from different fungi. These enzymes are suggested to play roles in carbon acquisition for saprophytic growth, as well as in fungal penetration and surface adhesion.', 0.7431445121765137]]
Context 6: [['Pathogenicity tests of Colletotrichum spp. from chili revealed that, while all species were pathogenic on chili fruits after wounding the surface, most produced a low level of infection on non-wounded fruit. This illustrates the importance of the cuticle acting as a barrier to infection by Colletotrichum spp. (Auyong et al. 2015) and emphasizes the need for informed and standardized inoculation techniques in pathogenicity assays. Some species, such as C. tropicale, C. makassarense, and C. plurivorum, which exhibited low infection levels in the assays on non-wounded fruit, may have a predominantly endophytic lifestyle and then switch to a necrotrophic lifestyle to complete their life cycle (De Silva et al. 2017b). However, further pathogenicity tests on different chili cultivars and at varying fruit maturity stages are necessary to comprehensively evaluate their pathogenicity. Pathogenicity testing of C. plurivorum on chili leaves and fruits showed that isolates collected from Chiang Rai and Malaysia could infect leaves but not fruits (results not shown), suggesting they might be specialized leaf pathogens. In contrast, two isolates of C. plurivorum from Bangkok did not infect leaves but did infect wounded fruits, demonstrating the pathogenic variation that can exist within a single species.', 0.45346957445144653]]
Context 7: [['Mongkolporn, O., Montri, P., Supakaew, T., and Taylor, P.W.J. (2010). Differential reactions on mature green and ripe chili fruit infected by three Colletotrichum species. Plant Disease In press.', 0.2460433691740036]]
Context 8: [['Keywords: anthracnose, β-tubulin, chilli, Colletotrichum, ITS, morphology, pathogenicity, phylogeny.', 0.22828742861747742]]
Context 9: [['Mongkolporn, O., Montri, P., Supakaew, T., & Taylor, P.W.J. (2010). Differential reactions on mature green and ripe chili fruit infected by three Colletotrichum species. Plant Disease, 94, 306-310.', 0.22215905785560608]]

Characteristic root symptoms include light to dark brown or black lesions and necrotic tips (Fig. 1). Severe infection can blacken and extensively destroy the root system. A black mycelial mat of the fungus may form on the basal stem or "foot" area of the plant, and most roots may appear heavily melanized. On young plants, above-ground symptoms resemble general nutrient stress (Fig. 2) and are frequently misdiagnosed as nitrogen deficiency. query: Why is fungicide sensitivity testing relevant for Colletotrichum?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['He, L. F., Li, X. X., Gao, Y. Y., Li, B. X., Mu, W., and Liu, F. (2019). Characterization and fungicide sensitivity of Colletotrichum spp. from different hosts in Shandong, China. Plant Disease, 103, 34-43.', 0.9845556616783142]]
Context 1: [['The fact that Colletotrichum species differ in their sensitivity to certain fungicides, such as benomyl, is critical for chemical pathogen control. This variability should be taken into account when implementing a spray program, especially in mixed populations like C. acutatum and C. gloeosporioides, which affect several hosts, including apple, citrus, mango, peach, pecan, and strawberries. Differential sensitivity among these species may result in shifts in population ratios.', 0.9762029647827148]]
Context 2: [['He L et al. characterized and assessed fungicide sensitivity of Colletotrichum species from various hosts in Shandong, China.', 0.946422278881073]]
Context 3: [['The sensitivity ranges of the isolates to various fungicides were 0.2 to 1.6 mg/ml and 0.002 to 0.2 mg/ml, respectively, with average values of 6.5 to 6.9 mg/ml, 1.5 to 0.6 mg/ml, 0.9 to 0.4 mg/ml, and 0.1 to 0.05 mg/ml, respectively. All isolates were more sensitive to difenoconazole, flusilazole, and carbendazim than to tebuconazole (P < 0.01). However, sensitivities to the same fungicide varied among isolates. Specifically, isolates SL-31 and TS-09 were the least sensitive to carbendazim and tebuconazole, with resistance ratios of 87.3 and 51.6, respectively. Sensitivities to difenoconazole and flusilazole were largely consistent across all isolates, with resistance ratios ranging from 1 to 4.6 and from 1 to 7, respectively. Therefore, difenoconazole and flusilazole could be recommended for disease control. Notably, differences in pathogenicity and fungicide sensitivity were not correlated with geographic regions. These findings indicate a high level of intraspecific diversity within the populations of Colletotrichum gloeosporioides s.s. responsible for walnut anthracnose. For effective management, a targeted control strategy should be developed based on different geographic regions.', 0.8799189329147339]]
Context 4: [['Past failures of fungicides to control anthracnose epidemics may have stemmed from the development of resistance in the Colletotrichum population. In the early 1970s, benomyl effectively reduced anthracnose crown rot incidence (Horn et al., 1972; Howard, 1971) and was widely used by strawberry growers for years. However, anthracnose pathogens developed resistance to it and other benzimidazole fungicides, rendering benomyl ineffective. In vitro and greenhouse trials have been conducted to identify fungicides to which Colletotrichum pathogens have developed resistance (LaMondia, 1993, 1995; McInnes et al., 1992a, 1992b; Smith and Black, 1991, 1992, 1993). Current fungicide labels address pathogen resistance by restricting the number of consecutive and total applications of a product per season. For instance, the fungicides Abound (azoxystrobin, Syngenta, Greensboro, NC), Cabrio (pyraclostrobin, BASF, Research Triangle Park, NC), and Pristine (pyraclostrobin and boscalid, BASF) are limited to four or five applications per season, with no more than two consecutive applications before alternating with a fungicide that has a different mode of action. Natural products have also been evaluated as alternative fungicides, offering different modes of action, lower toxicity, and increased efficacy (Abril et al., 2008).', 0.874144434928894]]
Context 5: [['Table 2 Description: Table 2 presents the effective concentrations of fungicides required to inhibit 50% of mycelial growth or conidial germination for both QoI-sensitive and -resistant isolates of Colletotrichum acutatum. It likely includes specific concentrations (EC50 values) for each fungicide tested, categorized by the type of isolate, highlighting the differential effectiveness of various fungicides against the pathogen based on its resistance profile.', 0.749875545501709]]
Context 6: [["This table presents the toxicity data of four fungicides against Colletotrichum gloeosporioides sensu stricto. It includes the median effective concentration (EC50) values measured in mg/ml and the corresponding 95% confidence intervals (CI). The fungicides tested are Tebuconazole, Difenoconazole, Flusilazole, and Carbendazim. Tebuconazole showed an EC50 value ranging between 6.5 and 6.9 mg/ml, while Difenoconazole had a lower value between 1.5 and 0.6 mg/ml. Flusilazole had an EC50 value ranging from 0.9 to 0.4 mg/ml, and Carbendazim demonstrated the lowest toxicity with an EC50 value between 0.1 and 0.05 mg/ml. The table also notes that means sharing a common letter in the same column are not significantly different according to Tukey's Honestly Significant Difference (HSD) test (P < 0.01).", 0.628230631351471]]

query: Can you identify the main symptoms of anthracnose on chili plants caused by Colletotrichum species, and how do they differ across various strains?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Anthracnose, caused by Colletotrichum species, is a serious disease affecting over 30 plant genera. Several DNA phylogenetic studies have identified Colletotrichum species that infect chili in various countries. Despite China being the largest producer of chili, with significant multi-gene analysis, little is known about the species affecting local crops. In this study, samples of diseased chili were collected from 29 provinces in China, resulting in the isolation of 1,285 strains. We observed and compared the morphological characteristics of all strains, and performed multi-locus phylogenetic analyses (ITS, ACT, CAL, CHS-1, GAPDH, TUB2, and HIS3) on selected representative strains. Fifteen Colletotrichum species were identified, with C. fioriniae, C. fructicola, C. gloeosporioides, C. scovillei, and C. truncatum being the most prevalent. Additionally, three new species, C. conoides, C. grossum, and C. liaoningense, are described in this paper. Colletotrichum aenigma, C. cliviae, C. endophytica, C. hymenocallidis, C. incanum, C. karstii, and C. viniferum were reported for the first time in chili. Pathogenicity was confirmed for all species isolated from chili, except for C. endophytica. This study enhances our understanding of the species responsible for anthracnose in chili and provides valuable information for effective disease management in China.', 0.9949225783348083]]
Context 1: [['The distribution of Colletotrichum species that cause anthracnose in chili varies across different countries that cultivate this crop. For instance, only six out of the 24 Colletotrichum pathogens of chili have been identified in Australia (De Silva et al. 2017a), while only three species have been reported in Thailand (Mongkolporn and Taylor 2018) and five in Malaysia (Noor and Zakaria 2018). In most previous studies, species identification relied solely on morphological data, leading to uncertainties in the taxonomy of Colletotrichum spp. responsible for anthracnose in chili-producing Asian countries. Accurate identification of these pathogens is crucial for mitigating the risk of new pathogen incursions, which could have devastating impacts on local industries. Additionally, precise species identification is vital for resistance breeding programs and understanding the host range of various species. Some Colletotrichum species, such as C. karstii, C. siamense, and C. truncatum, have broad host ranges (Cannon et al. 2012; Damm et al. 2012b). The main Colletotrichum species known to cause anthracnose in chili are primarily from the acutatum and gloeosporioides complexes. Recently, additional species from the boninense and orchidarium complexes have also been implicated (Diao et al. 2017; Damm et al. 2019). Therefore, understanding the taxonomy, diversity, pathogenicity, and distribution of Colletotrichum species affecting chili is essential.', 0.9926632642745972]]
Context 2: [['Symptoms of anthracnose on chili fruits manifest as circular or angular sunken lesions, alongside irregular brown spots with dark edges on leaves. A total of 1,285 isolates of Colletotrichum species were collected from 29 provinces in China. Despite extensive efforts to sample symptomatic plants in Tibet and Xinjiang over several years, no suitable specimens were found. All strains were isolated from fruits, except in Jiangxi province, where severe damage was noted on chili leaves.', 0.9918293356895447]]
Context 3: [['Chilli pepper fruits with blemishes have reduced marketability (Manandhar et al., 1995). Colletotrichum spp. are among the most significant plant pathogens globally, causing the economically important disease anthracnose in a wide range of hosts, including cereals, legumes, vegetables, and tree fruits (Bailey & Jeger, 1992). Among these hosts, Capsicum annuum is considered the most important vegetable in Thailand (Poulos, 2002) and is severely infected by anthracnose, with yield losses of up to 50% (Pakdeevaraporn et al., 2005). Typical anthracnose symptoms on chilli fruits include sunken necrotic tissues with concentric rings of acervuli. Accurate taxonomic identification is crucial for plant breeding and disease management (Freeman et al., 1998). Traditionally, identification and characterization of Colletotrichum species were based on morphological characteristics such as the size and shape of conidia and appressoria, the presence of setae or a teleomorph, and cultural characteristics like colony morphology.', 0.9902296662330627]]
Context 4: [['The current study aims to investigate the Colletotrichum species causing anthracnose in chili (Capsicum spp.) in China through large-scale sampling and isolation, alongside morphological characterization and multi-locus phylogeny of the isolated strains. Chili is an important vegetable crop globally, with China having the largest cultivated area, producing over 28 million tons annually for domestic consumption and export (Li et al. 2009). Anthracnose, caused by Colletotrichum spp., is one of the most destructive diseases limiting chili production, resulting in yield losses of up to 40% in China (Lin et al. 2004).', 0.9822005033493042]]
Context 5: [['Diao, Y. Z., et al. Colletotrichum species causing anthracnose disease of chili in China. Persoonia: Molecular Phylogeny and Evolution of Fungi, 38, 20 (2017).', 0.9585341811180115]]
Context 6: [['Colletotrichum species causing anthracnose in chili have previously been identified as C. acutatum (characterized by straight conidia with acute ends), C. gloeosporioides (straight conidia with obtuse ends), and C. truncatum (falcate conidia) (Than et al. 2008; Mongkolporn et al. 2010). However, recent multigene phylogenetic analyses have revealed that C. acutatum is a species complex (the acutatum complex) consisting of 34 closely related species (Marin-Felix et al. 2017), with seven species identified as responsible for anthracnose in chili (Mongkolporn and Taylor 2018). Similarly, C. gloeosporioides has been found to be a complex of 38 closely related species (Marin-Felix et al. 2017), with nine species identified as pathogens of chili (Mongkolporn and Taylor 2018). Morphological traits are insufficient to differentiate many species with straight conidia, particularly those in the acutatum and gloeosporioides complexes affecting chili. Thus, multigene phylogenetic analyses are essential for accurate species identification (De Silva et al. 2017a).', 0.9501669406890869]]
Context 7: [['Pathogenicity tests conducted with three species of Colletotrichum isolated from infected chilli fruits demonstrated that all isolates were pathogenic to the susceptible Thai elite cultivar Bangchang. This result confirmed that these three Colletotrichum species are causal agents of anthracnose infection in chilli. Additionally, the non-infection of the resistant genotype C. chinense PBC 932 by C. capsici and C. gloeosporioides reaffirmed the importance of this resistance in the interspecific breeding program (Pakdeevaraporn et al., 2005). The anthracnose symptoms produced by all three isolates of C. acutatum in wound-inoculated fruits of PBC 932 indicated that C. acutatum was pathogenic and could overcome the resistance.', 0.934779167175293]]
Context 8: [['Cueva, F. D., Mendoza, J. S., & Balendres, M. A. A new Colletotrichum species causing anthracnose of chili in the Philippines and its pathogenicity to chili cultivar Django. Crop Protection, 112, 264-268 (2018).', 0.9301910400390625]]
Context 9: [['A collection of Colletotrichum species isolates was analyzed for their anthracnose severity scores on a 0–9 scale across seven chili cultivars at the ripe red fruit stage. The isolates included various species such as C. aenigma, C. cliviae, C. conoides, C. endophytica, C. fioriniae, C. fructicola, C. gloeosporioides, C. grossum, C. hymenocallidis, C. incanum, C. karstii, C. liaoningense, C. scovillei, C. truncatum, and C. viniferum.', 0.9274147152900696]]

query: What are some examples of Colletotrichum species causing anthracnose in plants?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Colletotrichum spp. often cause anthracnose disease in herbaceous or woody plants in tropical and subtropical regions (Cannon et al. 2012). The genus Colletotrichum is one of the eight major plant pathogens worldwide (Dean et al. 2012). Three species or species complexes of Colletotrichum have been reported to cause anthracnose in strawberries: the Colletotrichum gloeosporioides complex, Colletotrichum fragariae, and the Colletotrichum acutatum complex (Denoyes-Rothan et al. 2003). The C. gloeosporioides complex is found worldwide and has a wide range of hosts, whereas C. acutatum and C. fragariae have narrower host ranges (MacKenzie et al. 2008). Although a few C. acutatum infections in Chinese strawberries have been reported, the primary species affecting strawberries in China are believed to be C. gloeosporioides and C. fragariae (Buddie et al. 1999; Han et al. 2016).', 0.9977307915687561]]
Context 1: [['Colletotrichum is one of the most important genera of plant pathogenic fungi worldwide, causing disease symptoms commonly known as anthracnose on a wide range of important crops, fruits, and ornamental plants (Bailey et al., 1992). Notable species include Colletotrichum lindemuthianum, C. gloeosporioides, C. acutatum, C. falcatum, C. nupharicola, and C. nymphaeae. Some plant pathogenic species are significant for quarantine because they could be introduced into regions where the disease is not present (Farr et al., 2006). The taxonomy and phylogeny of the genus Colletotrichum remain confusing (Hyde et al., 2009; Cai et al., 2009). Historically, if anthracnose was found on a host for which there were no prior records of that fungus-host relationship, the species was interpreted as new and formally described (Cannon et al., 2000). This practice was later rejected (von Arx, 1957; Sutton, 1980; Baxter et al., 1983), yet new species are still occasionally described in Colletotrichum (Sivanesan et al., 1993; Nakanura et al., 2006; Liu et al., 2007). Currently, more than 688 epithets are listed in Index Fungorum (www.indexfungorum.org/names/names.asp). Based on a morphological study, von Arx (1957) included more than 600 synonyms under C. gloeosporioides and 84 synonyms under C. dematium. Sutton (1992) listed 39 accepted species in Colletotrichum, each with a brief description. In recent years, molecular tools have been used to infer the evolutionary relationships of Colletotrichum species. Some species have been segregated from the C. gloeosporioides complex based on nu-rDNA ITS sequence data and morphological characteristics, such as C. boninense.', 0.9973680377006531]]
Context 2: [["Three species have been documented as causal agents of strawberry anthracnose: Colletotrichum gloeosporioides, C. fragariae, and C. acutatum (Denoyes-Rothan et al. 2003). The anthracnose disease caused by Colletotrichum spp. impacts a wide variety of woody and herbaceous plants, particularly tropical and subtropical crops and fruit trees (Cannon et al. 2012; Freeman et al. 1998; Hyde et al. 2009; Sutton 1992; Wikee et al. 2011). The genus has recently been recognized as the world's eighth most important group of plant-pathogenic fungi due to its scientific and economic significance (Dean et al. 2012). However, the identification of Colletotrichum spp. has historically been challenging. Single-gene phylogenetic analyses have often failed to accurately delineate species (Hyde et al. 2009). Ko Ko et al. (2011) emphasized the need to resurvey plant pathogens like Colletotrichum spp. using molecular methods, as previous morphological and internal transcribed spacer data are likely to be incorrect. Understanding of Colletotrichum spp. has significantly advanced through these molecular approaches.", 0.997062623500824]]
Context 3: [['Many species belonging to the genus Colletotrichum are associated with plant diseases, commonly referred to as anthracnose. Colletotrichum spp. can affect a wide range of hosts, and these pathogens are characterized by global distribution. Virtually every cultivated botanical family is susceptible to one or more species of Colletotrichum, making it one of the most studied plant pathogenic fungi (Prusky et al., 2000; Latunde-Dada, 2001; Dean et al., 2012). Common hosts include many dicotyledonous plants such as strawberry, apple, citrus, and stone fruits, as well as major cereals such as maize and sorghum. Members of this genus can cause crop losses of up to 100% in many staple foods (Bailey and Jeger, 1992; Prusky et al., 2000; Talhinhas et al., 2005; Cannon et al., 2012).', 0.9969539642333984]]
Context 4: [['Various studies highlight the significance of Colletotrichum species in agriculture. Crouch et al. (2009) discussed anthracnose disease caused by the novel species Colletotrichum navitas, while Damm et al. (2013) addressed the Colletotrichum orbiculare species complex, which affects field crops and weeds. Other works by Damm et al. (2012) explored the Colletotrichum acutatum and Colletotrichum boninense species complexes.', 0.9950937032699585]]
Context 5: [['Bailey JA, Nash C, Morgan LW, O’Connell RJ, TeBeest DO (1996). Molecular taxonomy of Colletotrichum species causing anthracnose on the Malvaceae. Phytopathology 86: 1076–1083.', 0.9868398904800415]]
Context 6: [['A significant effort has been dedicated to identifying which species of Colletotrichum are involved in various anthracnose-type diseases of plants and developing tools for their identification and differentiation. Multiple hosts can be affected by a single species, while multiple species can impact a single host. Simmonds was the first to describe C. acutatum as a new species, distinct from others.', 0.9849499464035034]]
Context 7: [['Y.-Z. Diao et al.: Colletotrichum causing anthracnose disease.', 0.9719293117523193]]
Context 8: [['Diao, Y.-Z., et al. (2014). Colletotrichum causing anthracnose disease.', 0.965817928314209]]
Context 9: [['Urdaneta, L., Sanabria, M., Rodríguez, D., & Pérez de Camacaro, M. (2013). Antracnosis causada por Colletotrichum spp. Investigación Agraria, 20(1), 38-50.', 0.9534922242164612]]

query: How does the phenotypic plasticity of C. gloeosporioides contribute to its adaptability across different host species and environmental conditions?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Although C. gloeosporioides infects hundreds of different plant species, individual strains may have restricted host ranges, as demonstrated by a clonal subpopulation of C. gloeosporioides from almond grown in Israel. It is often presumed that host-specific populations reproduce only asexually; however, certain isolates of C. gloeosporioides with different host specificities have been observed to mate under laboratory conditions. Highly variable populations are generally more adaptable to changing conditions than those with limited variation, and sexual reproduction and recombination play a significant role in the genetic variability observed in fungal populations.', 0.9463028907775879]]

query: How does fungicide sensitivity testing help in managing crop diseases?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['The sensitivity ranges of the isolates to various fungicides were 0.2 to 1.6 mg/ml and 0.002 to 0.2 mg/ml, respectively, with average values of 6.5 to 6.9 mg/ml, 1.5 to 0.6 mg/ml, 0.9 to 0.4 mg/ml, and 0.1 to 0.05 mg/ml, respectively. All isolates were more sensitive to difenoconazole, flusilazole, and carbendazim than to tebuconazole (P < 0.01). However, sensitivities to the same fungicide varied among isolates. Specifically, isolates SL-31 and TS-09 were the least sensitive to carbendazim and tebuconazole, with resistance ratios of 87.3 and 51.6, respectively. Sensitivities to difenoconazole and flusilazole were largely consistent across all isolates, with resistance ratios ranging from 1 to 4.6 and from 1 to 7, respectively. Therefore, difenoconazole and flusilazole could be recommended for disease control. Notably, differences in pathogenicity and fungicide sensitivity were not correlated with geographic regions. These findings indicate a high level of intraspecific diversity within the populations of Colletotrichum gloeosporioides s.s. responsible for walnut anthracnose. For effective management, a targeted control strategy should be developed based on different geographic regions.', 0.3707903027534485]]
Context 1: [['Sensitivity to azoxystrobin was evaluated based on mycelial growth using two discriminatory doses of azoxystrobin (3 and 100 µg/ml). The commercial formulation of azoxystrobin (Abound 2.08F, 22.9% active ingredient; Syngenta Crop Protection, Greensboro, NC) was employed for the fungicide sensitivity assays. Salicylhydroxamic acid was not included in the medium, as Forcelini et al. (2016) reported that C. acutatum isolates from strawberries do not utilize an alternative respiration pathway.', 0.2280198186635971]]
Context 2: [['Additional keywords: phosphonate fungicides, phosphorous acid.', 0.19110915064811707]]
Context 3: [['Abril, M., K.J. Curry, B.J. Smith, and D.E. Wedge. 2008. Improved microassays used to test natural product-based and conventional fungicides on plant pathogenic fungi. Plant Dis. 92:106-112.', 0.1728583425283432]]
Context 4: [['For the management of anthracnose crown rot, water washing or fungicide treatments of bare-root transplants have been utilized in the nursery or immediately before planting in production fields (Daugovish et al., 2009; Freeman et al., 1997). Running water effectively removes soil from root and crown tissues, potentially eliminating inoculum, but it does not control any infections already present (Koike et al., 2008). Pre-plant fungicide dips have been shown to decrease anthracnose crown rot; however, only two products are currently registered for this use in the United States. The single-site mode of action quinone outside inhibitor (QoI), azoxystrobin, has been widely used as a preplant dip and as a foliar treatment for managing anthracnose and other fungal diseases (Bartlett et al., 2002; Koike et al., 2008; Turechek et al., 2006). Resistance has been reported against this fungicide group in Colletotrichum acutatum populations from strawberries in Florida (Forcelini et al., 2016). During the 2015-16 California nursery crown rot outbreak, growers reported reduced efficacy of azoxystrobin dips, suggesting that resistance may also be present in California (K. Ivors, unpublished). A premixed product of the anilinopyrimidine cyprodinil and the phenylpyrrole fludioxonil is also registered, but phytotoxicity and stunting of plants have been reported under certain environmental conditions or following off-label exposure (G. Holmes, unpublished).', 0.16479752957820892]]
Context 5: [['Howard, C. M., Albregts, E. E., and Chandler, C. K. 1991. Evaluation of fungicides for control of gray mold and fruit anthracnose, 1990. Fungic. Nematicide Tests 46:105.', 0.147315114736557]]
Context 6: [['FRAC. 2017. FRAC Code List 2017: Fungicides sorted by mode of action (including FRAC code numbering). www.frac.info, Fungicide Resistance Action Committee.', 0.13913816213607788]]
Context 7: [['The in vitro sensitivity of isolates to four fungicides—tebuconazole, difenoconazole, flusilazole, and carbendazim—was assessed using a mycelium growth rate method. Tebuconazole (97% active ingredient; provided by Jiangsu Changlong Agrochemical Co., Ltd.) and difenoconazole (95.8% active ingredient; provided by Qingdao Hansen Biologic Science Co., Ltd.) were dissolved in acetone. Flusilazole (92% active ingredient) and carbendazim (97.5% active ingredient; provided by Qingdao Hansen Biologic Science Co., Ltd.) were dissolved in cyclohexanone and 1% (wt/wt) hydrochloric acid, respectively. The concentration of all solutions was set at 10,000 mg/ml and stored at 4°C.', 0.13616085052490234]]
Context 8: [['Fungicides: Formulated products of natamycin (DelvoCid Instant; DSM, Heerlen, The Netherlands), azoxystrobin (Abound Flowable; Syngenta Crop Protection Inc., Greensboro, NC), chlorothalonil (Bravo Weather Stick; Syngenta Crop Protection Inc.), cyprodinil (Vangard 75WG; Syngenta Crop Protection Inc.), fludioxonil (Scholar 50WP; Syngenta Crop Protection Inc.), and pydiflumetofen (experimental product A19649B; Syngenta Crop Protection Inc.) were used on plants, either individually or in mixtures of fludioxonil and cyprodinil (Switch WG; Syngenta Crop Protection Inc.) or of pydiflumetofen and fludioxonil (experimental product A20560C; Syngenta Crop Protection Inc.). Additionally, the biological control agent S. lydicus WYEC 108 (minimum of 10^3 CFU/g of formulated product; Actinovate AG; Valent U.S.A. LLC, Walnut Creek, CA) was included in field trials. Aqueous solutions were used in all studies.', 0.11695156246423721]]
Context 9: [['In-vitro trials have been used to screen fungicides for their ability to control anthracnose (LaMondia, 1993; McInnes et al., 1992b; Smith and Black, 1992). Smith and Black (1993) reported that all 16 C. acutatum, 14 out of 18 C. fragariae, and both C. gloeosporioides isolates tested in vitro were resistant to benomyl, and all benomyl-resistant isolates were also resistant to carbendazim, which is in the same class of fungicides as benomyl. In a greenhouse study, plants treated with propiconazole had lower disease severity ratings than did plants treated with captafol or benomyl (Smith and Black, 1991). However, the propiconazole-treated plants were shorter with dark green leaves that appeared thicker than the leaves of untreated plants.', 0.11055109649896622]]

query: What method was used to identify the Colletotrichum species?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Despite significant developments over the last ten years, the taxonomy of Colletotrichum is in a state of flux. Many uncertainties exist in the systematics of fungal pathogens from this genus; depending on the taxonomic "guides," the number of species can range from 29 to over 700 (von Arx, 1957; Sutton, 1992). One of the most confusing species is C. gloeosporioides. For example, 594 species of Colletotrichum were reclassified by von Arx as synonyms of C. gloeosporioides. Identification has primarily relied on morphological characteristics of conidia, vegetative and sexual structures, as well as host specificity and cultural characteristics (von Arx, 1957). Unfortunately, conidial morphology and colony characteristics vary even within isolates. Consequently, classical methods have been supplemented with biochemical and molecular technologies to differentiate Colletotrichum species (J. W. Kronstad, ed., Fungal Pathology, 127-148. © 2000 Kluwer Academic Publishers). For a more complete discussion of this topic, see Sherriff et al. (1994).', 0.9911978840827942]]
Context 1: [['In a drastic move, von Arx (1957) reduced the number of recognized Colletotrichum species from several hundred to 11 based on morphological characteristics, with many taxa treated as synonyms of C. gloeosporioides and C. dematium. Several additional species have since been accepted based on morphological criteria (Sutton, 1980; 1992). The difficulties in recognizing Colletotrichum species can be attributed to: 1) the limited and variable morphological characters; 2) an extensive host range and variability in pathogenicity (Bailey and Jeger, 1992; Freeman et al., 2000; Latunde-Dada, 2001; Du et al., 2005; Thaung, 2008); 3) type specimens that are often missing or in poor condition, making them unsuitable for molecular studies; and 4) numerous rDNA ITS sequences of Colletotrichum strains in NCBI that are often misidentified (Crouch et al., 2009d; Damm et al., 2009).', 0.9845630526542664]]
Context 2: [['Citation: Cai, L., Hyde, K.D., Taylor, P.W.J., Weir, B.S., Waller, J., Abang, M.M., Zhang, J.Z., Yang, Y.L., Phoulivong, S., Liu, Z.Y., Prihastuti, H., Shivas, R.G., McKenzie, E.H.C., Johnston, P.R. (2009). A polyphasic approach for studying Colletotrichum. Fungal Diversity, 39: 183-204.', 0.9463037252426147]]
Context 3: [['Cano, J., Guarro, J., and Gene, J. (2004). Molecular and morphological identification of Colletotrichum species of clinical interest. Journal of Clinical Microbiology 42: 2450-2454.', 0.9169195294380188]]
Context 4: [['The genus Colletotrichum is considered one of the top ten important genera of fungal pathogens globally (Dean et al., 2012). Colletotrichum is an ancient fungus that has co-evolved with flowering plants. Plant microfossils of Protocolletotrichum preserved on angiosperm leaf cuticles suggest that the diverse pathogenic strategies of Colletotrichum spp. have been established since the Late Cretaceous period (Kar et al., 2004). Different complexes within the genus may have diverged between 4.8 and 32.2 million years ago (MYA) (Bhunjun et al., 2021). The emergence of agricultural cultivation and the intensive disturbance of natural environments have further driven the diversification of Colletotrichum species. These fungi have adapted to thousands of hosts and can be found as endophytes, pathogens, and saprobes (Freeman et al., 1998; Dean et al., 2012; Hirayama et al., 2018; da Silva et al., 2020; Jayawardena et al., 2020). Currently, a total of 257 Colletotrichum species grouped into 15 complexes and 13 additional singletons have been accepted in this genus.', 0.8981563448905945]]
Context 5: [['Cai, L., Hyde, K.D., Taylor, P.W.J., Weir, B., Waller, J., Abang, M.M., Zhang, J.Z., Yang, Y.L., Phoulivong, S., Liu, Z.Y., Prihastuti, H., Shivas, R.G., McKenzie, E.H.C., and Johnston, P.R. (2009). A polyphasic approach for studying Colletotrichum. Fungal Diversity 39: 183-204.', 0.8873679637908936]]
Context 6: [['The name Colletotrichum was first introduced by Tode (1790) under the genus Vermicularia. The genus Colletotrichum itself was established by Corda (1831) and is now recognized as comprising “coelomycetes” with a Glomerella teleomorph stage (Sutton, 1992; Shenoy et al., 2007a; Hyde et al., 2009). This genus includes species with endophytic, epiphytic, saprobic, and phytopathogenic lifestyles (Kumar and Hyde, 2004; Photita et al., 2001a,b).', 0.8486246466636658]]
Context 7: [['Photita, W., Taylor, P. W., Ford, R., Hyde, K. D., and Lumyong, S. (2005). Morphological and molecular characterization of Colletotrichum species from...', 0.80613774061203]]
Context 8: [['Jayawardena, R. S., Hyde, K. D., Damm, U., Cai, L., Liu, M., Li, X. H., Zhang, W., Zhao, W. S., and Yan, J. Y. (2016). Notes on currently accepted species of Colletotrichum. Mycosphere, 7, 1192-1260.', 0.6949412822723389]]
Context 9: [['To validate the taxonomy of Colletotrichum species through morphological characteristics and DNA phylogenetic analysis.', 0.6899930238723755]]

query: What insights can be drawn from the use of molecular tools, such as PCR, in identifying pathogens like Phytophthora infestans and Colletotrichum acutatum?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Considerable progress has been made in recent years in delineating anthracnose diseases and their causal agents. Molecular tools have effectively distinguished Colletotrichum species, clearly separating C. acutatum from C. gloeosporioides and identifying genetically distinct subgroups within C. acutatum. Nonetheless, the disease cycles of C. acutatum in many host-pathogen systems remain poorly understood, even in economically important crops. This pathogen can reproduce on various tissue types across different hosts and can exist as a necrotroph, biotroph, endophyte, or epiphyte, depending on the plant species and tissue involved. The tissues affected are very specific for each host combination, and the pathogen develops a highly specialized relationship at the cellular level that is evident in the disease cycle for each host. Further investigation is needed into the biotrophic and epiphytic phases of the pathogen and the means by which C. acutatum reproduces in the absence of pathogenesis. The tissue specificity and life cycles of C. acutatum are likely under genetic control, and it may be possible to induce mutants that are no longer pathogenic to certain hosts or tissues, thereby elucidating the genetic basis for tissue or host specificity, as seen in other Colletotrichum species.', 0.8751581311225891]]
Context 1: [['Sreenivasaprasad S, Sharada K, Brown AE, Mills PR. (1996). PCR-based detection of Colletotrichum acutatum on strawberry and other plants. Phytopathology 91:986–992.', 0.4346312880516052]]
Context 2: [['Molecular approaches have been successfully utilized for the taxonomic identification and determination of genetic diversity in Colletotrichum populations. Recent studies have employed species-specific primers to differentiate between C. acutatum and C. gloeosporioides from various hosts. To enhance the effectiveness of this approach for in vivo pathogen diagnosis, it is essential to develop simple and rapid DNA extraction techniques, enabling multiple sampling and testing.', 0.3969517648220062]]
Context 3: [['Traditional methods may not accurately differentiate between species and subspecies of Colletotrichum. Consequently, various molecular methods have been used to characterize populations. Arbitrarily primed polymerase chain reaction (ap-PCR) and limited restriction digest analyses of PCR-amplified ribosomal DNA (rDNA) have been employed to differentiate representative isolates of C. gloeosporioides and C. acutatum from diverse hosts, including strawberry.', 0.3969458043575287]]
Context 4: [['rDNA genes exist as multiple copies in the genome. Due to the lesser conservation of sequence, the non-transcribed and internal transcribed spacer (ITS) regions between the small and large nuclear rDNA subunits are suitable for detecting recent evolutionary divergence within Colletotrichum. In our study, limited restriction digest analyses of PCR-amplified rDNA were utilized to differentiate representative isolates of C. gloeosporioides from a diverse range of hosts, as well as from rDNA of C. acutatum sourced from strawberry. Species-specific primers have been designed based on the dissimilarities in the sequences of the ITS regions from various Colletotrichum species. We employed such primers to differentiate between C. acutatum and C. gloeosporioides. As shown in Figure 5A, a single PCR-amplified fragment of 490 bp was evident in isolates of C. acutatum from a broad host range but was absent in C. gloeosporioides isolates. Similarly, primers specific for C. gloeosporioides and C. fragariae amplified a specific 450-bp fragment, allowing these two species to be distinguished from C. acutatum. This method also facilitated the differentiation between C. acutatum from almond, apple, peach, and strawberry, and C. gloeosporioides from papaya and citrus. These findings indicate that rDNA analysis serves as an effective taxonomic tool for species identification and diagnostic pathogen detection in plants, although it may not reveal subpopulations within a species.', 0.38813576102256775]]
Context 5: [['Sreenivasaprasad, S., Mills, P. R., and Brown, P. E. 1994. Nucleotide sequence of the rDNA spacer 1 enables identification of isolates of Colletotrichum as C. acutatum. Mycol. Res. 98:186-188.', 0.28238335251808167]]
Context 6: [['Sreenivasaprasad, S., Mills, P.R., and Brown, A.E. (1994). Nucleotide sequence of the rDNA spacer 1 enables identification of isolates of Colletotrichum as C. acutatum. Mycological Research 98: 186-188.', 0.2659543454647064]]
Context 7: [['Sreenivasaprasad, S., Mills, P. R., Brown, A. E. (1994). Nucleotide sequence of the rDNA spacer 1 enables identification of isolates of Colletotrichum as C. acutatum. Mycological Research 98: 186–188.', 0.25901150703430176]]
Context 8: [['Horowitz, S., Freeman, S., and Sharon, A. 2002. Use of green fluorescent protein-transgenic strains to study pathogenic and non-pathogenic lifestyles in Colletotrichum acutatum. Phytopathology 92:743-749.', 0.25631698966026306]]
Context 9: [['Random Amplified Polymorphic DNA (RAPD), or ap-PCR, has been extensively utilized for the identification and characterization of isolates in Colletotrichum. We employed ap-PCR using primers derived from minisatellite or repeat sequences (CAGCAGCAGCAGCAG, TGTCTGTCTGTCTGTC, GACACGACACGACAC, GACAGACAGACAGACA) to compare Colletotrichum species from almond, avocado, strawberry, and other fruits. Unique band patterns were observed among the clonal populations of C. acutatum from strawberry and C. gloeosporioides from almond, while avocado isolates exhibited polymorphisms.', 0.2507239282131195]]

Context 4: [['Guava (Psidium guajava L.) is cultivated for its edible fruits, which are rich in vitamin C and dietary fiber. Guava fruits can be consumed fresh or processed into products such as purées, jams, marmalades, jellies, fruit pastes, juice, syrup, candy, and chutneys. Additionally, guava leaves are utilized in folk medicine due to their beneficial properties in treating various ailments, including diarrhea, dysentery, gastroenteritis, hypertension, and diabetes, as well as improving locomotor coordination. This tropical fruit crop is native to Mexico, Central America, and South America and has different local names depending on the region. For example, it is known as jambu batu in Malay, amrood in Hindi, perakka in Malayalam, and farang in Thai. In French-speaking regions, guava is referred to as goyave or goyavier; Hawaiians call it kuawa, while in Portuguese-speaking areas, it is known as goiaba or goiabeira. India is the leading producer of guava, with an estimated annual production of 17,650,000 metric tons, followed by Thailand and China. Other guava-producing countries include Pakistan, Mexico, Indonesia, Brazil, the Philippines, and Nigeria.', 0.15805858373641968]]

query: What percentage of the isolates were identified as Colletotrichum siamense?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Colletotrichum siamense, part of the gloeosporioides complex, was also notable, representing 11% of total isolates causing anthracnose in chili fruit in Indonesia, Sri Lanka, and Thailand, but it was not detected in Malaysia and Taiwan. Nonetheless, Noor and Zakaria (2018) reported the identification of C. siamense in Malaysia, likely due to a larger sampling size of infected chili across various states. Within the C. siamense clade, small subclades were observed that corresponded with different geographical regions from which the isolates were collected. C. siamense has been reported to infect chili in Asia, Australia, and Brazil, and is a common pathogen of many other plant species (Weir et al. 2012; James et al. 2014; Sharma and Shenoy 2014; Liu et al. 2016a, 2016b; de Oliveira et al. 2017; De Silva et al. 2017a; Diao et al. 2017; Suwannarat et al. 2017).', 0.9964534044265747]]
Context 1: [['Phylogenetic analyses of the gloeosporioides species complex identified 69% (29) of the chili fruit isolates as C. siamense. In the two-gene tree, a distinct subclade within the C. siamense clade formed with 100% bootstrap support, comprising isolates from Chiang Mai in Thailand, as well as Gowa and Jeneponto in South Sulawesi, Indonesia (Fig. 3). These isolates exhibited notable sequence differences compared to the ex-type reference C. siamense strain (CBS 130417), showing a 28 base pair difference in the gs gene and a 25 base pair difference in the ApMat gene. A significant subclade within C. siamense exhibited full (100% BS/1 PP) support values in the two-gene tree. While the same isolates in the five-gene tree did not demonstrate the same level of difference, they showed strong similarities among the C. siamense isolates. Additionally, in the two-gene tree, significant subclades of isolates were associated with different geographical regions.', 0.9822151064872742]]
Context 2: [['Notes: This species is placed in synonymy with Colletotrichum siamense. See additional notes and specimens examined under C. siamense. Yang et al. (2009) reported this species as a leaf pathogen of Hymenocallis americana. They distinguished C. hymenocallidis from C. siamense, which is also described from Hymenocallis, primarily based on multi-gene phylogeny and differences in colony color. Although the gene selection was suitable for resolving genetic relationships within the C. gloeosporioides group, Yang et al. (2009) included only five isolates of the C. gloeosporioides complex in their phylogeny. Based on this isolate selection, the C. hymenocallidis isolates appeared genetically distinct from C. siamense. However, in our analysis, where the C. siamense/C. hymenocallidis group is represented by 30 isolates from a wide range of hosts worldwide, the authentic isolates of the two species fall within a monophyletic clade that cannot be further subdivided phylogenetically.', 0.9699264764785767]]
Context 3: [['Notes: Isolates of Colletotrichum siamense from different countries showed variations in morphological characteristics, including growth rates and culture morphology on PDA. Representative conidial measurements from isolates representing various subclades in the phylogenetic trees are as follows: CPC 30233 (Gowa, Indonesia), 12.5 × 17 × 2.5 × 5.5 µm; UOM 1132 (Ratchaburi, Thailand), 9.5 × 14.5 × 3.5 × 5 µm; UOM 1126/F4-1C (Kanchanaburi, Thailand), 12 × 15 × 5 × 7 µm; UOM 1116 (Kandy, Sri Lanka), 10.5 × 16.5 × 3.5 × 5.5 µm. These morphological characteristics were highly consistent within each country. The species was described by Prihastuti et al. (2009); conidia from the ex-holotype specimen (ICMP 18578/BDP-I2) were reported as 7 × 18.3 × 3 × 4.3 µm (mean = 10.18 ± 1.74 × 3.46 ± 0.36), encompassing the range observed in our isolates. Context 4: [['C. siamense has been associated with mango anthracnose in Colombia (Pardo-De la Hoz et al. 2016) and found on mango fruit in Sanya, Hainan Province, China (Qin et al. 2017). Context 5: [['Notes: This species is placed in synonymy with Colletotrichum siamense based on ITS, GAPDH, CAL, TUB2, and ACT gene sequences from the ex-holotype culture deposited in GenBank by Wikee et al. Context 6: [['Colletotrichum siamense, as described by Prihastuti et al. (2009) in "Fungal Diversity 39," has been examined in various regions. Gyuiot on 27 Aug. 2016 (cultures PAFQ67, PAFQ68, PAFQ71, PAFQ73, PAFQ74) and from Zhejiang Province, Hangzhou City, on leaves of P. pyrifolia cv. Guanyangxueli on 18 Aug. 2016 (PAFQ78), and on leaves of P. pyrifolia cv. Cuiguan on the same date (PAFQ85). Notably, C. siamense was first reported on Coffea arabica in Thailand (Prihastuti et al., 2009) and has since been documented on a wide range of hosts (e.g., Yang et al., 2009; Wikee et al., 2011; Wei et al., 2012; Wang et al., 2016; Liu et al., 2016b). Context 7: [['Colletotrichum siamense was described by Prihastuti, L. Cai & K.D. Hyde in Fungal Diversity 39: 98 (2009). It is also related to Colletotrichum jasmini-sambac (Wikee, K.D. Hyde, L. Cai & McKenzie, Fungal Diversity 46: 174, 2011) and Colletotrichum hymenocallidis (Yan L. Yang, Zuo Y. Liu, K.D. Hyde & L. Cai, Fungal Diversity 39: 138, 2009).', 0.7999805212020874]]
Context 8: [['Colletotrichum siamense has also been noted as a significant species causing mango anthracnose in China and eastern Australia. This species has a broad host range in tropical and subtropical regions, capable of infecting banana (Musa spp.), papaya (Carica papaya L.), dragon fruit (Hylocereus spp.), guava (Psidium guajava), and avocado. It was suggested by James et al. that C. siamense is likely a common and widespread saprophyte or endophyte, as the authors were able to isolate it from asymptomatic fruit of other plants, with the exception of mango and avocado. Similar to C. asianum, C. siamense has been reported to cause disease in coffee in Thailand, but not in mango until this study.', 0.7842769026756287]]
Context 9: [['Colletotrichum siamense is reported for the first time causing anthracnose of Capsicum annuum in Indonesia and Sri Lanka. Colletotrichum siamense (gloeosporioides complex) was also common in Indonesia, Sri Lanka, and Thailand.', 0.7278646230697632]]

query: Can molecular techniques, such as PCR or gene sequencing, be used to accurately identify Colletotrichum lupini var. setosum in lupin crops, and how reliable are these techniques?

Context 0: [['Colletotrichum lupini is an economically significant pathogen of lupin crops worldwide, leading to substantial interest in breeding resistant host cultivars (e.g., Adhikari et al. 2011). While C. lupini shows a clear host preference based on the strains examined, some cultures were derived from hosts other than lupins, specifically from Manihot, Camellia, and Cinnamomum. Sreenivasaprasad & Talhinhas (2005) also identified Urtica dioica as a host. A study by Nirenberg & Gerlach (2000) demonstrated that a strain of C. lupini var. setosum could infect Bergenia in greenhouse tests. Pathogenicity tests by Sreenivasaprasad & Talhinhas (2005) failed to show host specificity of C. acutatum strains from lupins (now considered C. lupini), although Lardner et al. (1999) found that the strains they categorized in C. acutatum Group D (now known to belong to C. lupini) did not infect pine seedlings like C. acutatum f. sp. pineum (now regarded as C. acutatum s. str.). The strain from Camellia in the UK (IMI 351261), deposited in 1992 by R. Cook, is likely one of the avirulent C. acutatum strains reported from ornamental Camellia species by Dickens and Cook (1989).', 0.6875084042549133]]

query: Are there significant differences in the effectiveness of calcium sulfate versus calcium chloride in managing anthracnose fruit rot?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Anthracnose fruit rot caused by C. acutatum was less severe on fruit from greenhouse-grown plants receiving drench or foliar applications of calcium sulfate than on fruit from plants receiving water, calcium chloride, or calcium nitrate treatments. Fruit from plants receiving foliar applications of CaCl₂ developed less fruit rot than that from plants receiving soil applications of CaCl₂ (Smith and Gupton, 1993). The primary means to reduce the buildup of anthracnose fruit rot in the field is to harvest fruit frequently and remove all rotten fruit. Following severe infections early in the fruiting season, all infected fruit should be stripped from the plants and removed from the field. Infected areas of a field should be harvested last in the day, or workers should wash up and change to clean clothes when entering uninfected areas of the field after harvesting areas with fruit rot present.', 0.9911558628082275]]
Context 1: [['During the middle to late part of the growing season, when calcium chloride is usually applied for its effects on fruit quality, no reduction in the incidence of sooty blotch or flyspeck has been observed, although the severity of these issues is often reduced (A. R. Biggs, unpublished). Currently, there are no data on the effects of calcium salts on the incidence of white rot or black rot. Although further research is necessary, calcium salts may play a future role in disease management for fruit destined for processing, particularly in years when inoculum levels are low and environmental conditions are not highly favorable.', 0.7728450894355774]]
Context 2: [['Smith, B.J., & Gupton, C.L. (1993). Calcium applications before harvest affect the severity of anthracnose fruit rot in greenhouse-grown strawberries. Acta Hort., 348, 477–482.', 0.6499914526939392]]
Context 3: [['Smith, B. J., and Gupton, C. L. (1993). Calcium applications before harvest affect the severity of anthracnose fruit rot of greenhouse-grown strawberries. Acta Hort., 348:477-482.', 0.5798720717430115]]
Context 4: [['Effects of field applications of calcium salts on apple fruit regarding the incidence and severity of bitter rot were studied in 1997 (Golden Delicious) and 1998 (Nittany). Fruit on trees that had not been sprayed with fungicides were treated with calcium chloride, calcium propionate, or calcium silicate (1997 only) or calcium hydroxide (1998 only) at a concentration of 1,200 mg of calcium per liter. Each set of 10 fruits per treatment was sprayed to runoff with 1,200 mg of calcium per liter plus 0.1% Nufilm 17 (Miller Chemical Co., Biglerville, PA) weekly for three consecutive weeks. Preliminary tests with Nufilm 17 confirmed that the adjuvant had no effect on fruit infection by Colletotrichum spp. The day following the third calcium application, attached fruit were inoculated with either C. gloeosporioides or C. acutatum. Inoculations were made by preparing suspensions of conidia as described above, immersing 2.5-cm-wide cheesecloth strips (four layers thick) into the suspensions, and wrapping the strips around the widest part of the fruit. The strips were secured with one layer each of plastic wrap and aluminum foil. The inoculum was removed after 5 to 7 days. Control treatments included fruits sprayed with distilled water and inoculated, as well as non-sprayed fruits that were inoculated without conidia. The experiment was conducted three times in each of the two years. All fruit from the three trials in each year were harvested at the normal harvest date for the specific cultivar. The harvested fruits were arranged in labeled trays and were observed weekly for disease incidence, defined as the presence of bitter rot, determined from visible sporulation or reisolation when necessary. Data on disease incidence were subjected to analysis of variance, and means were separated using the Waller-Duncan k-ratio t test (SAS).', 0.4829016625881195]]
Context 5: [['This table details the incidence of bitter rot on Golden Delicious apples following three weekly applications of different calcium solutions during June, July, or August. After treatment, the fruits were inoculated with conidia from either Colletotrichum gloeosporioides or C. acutatum. The incidence percentages were recorded over four weeks. The calcium propionate treatment showed 0% incidence at one week but rose to 77% by the fourth week. Calcium chloride had similar patterns, with lower initial incidences but higher rates by week four. Calcium silicate showed a significant increase in incidence, reaching 100% by week four. The control group had the highest incidences across all weeks, indicating that untreated fruit were most susceptible to the pathogens.', 0.39828619360923767]]
Context 6: [['Bitter rot, caused by Colletotrichum gloeosporioides (teleomorph = Glomerella cingulata) and C. acutatum, is a destructive fruit rot affecting apples and pears in the southern, central, and mid-Atlantic regions of the United States and in many other countries where these fruits are cultivated. The application of supplemental calcium to apples is a routine practice in orchards prone to calcium-related nutritional disorders such as cork spot and bitter pit. The most common form of calcium supplement used is calcium chloride (in 75% food-grade flakes); however, many proprietary products containing calcium in other forms or combined with additional nutrients are also available.', 0.36503252387046814]]
Context 7: [['In six field trials, where fruits received three weekly dilute applications of calcium solutions, those treated with calcium salts and then inoculated with conidia of either C. gloeosporioides or C. acutatum exhibited lower incidences of infection compared to the control fruits. These experiments demonstrate that calcium salts have suppressive activity against the bitter rot pathogens and could be integrated into a disease management program.', 0.3582925796508789]]
Context 8: [['Calcium supplements are typically applied starting 2 to 4 weeks after petal fall and may continue through the preharvest period for as many as eight applications. Recommended rates of calcium chloride range from 17 to 56 kg/ha per year, based on the potential severity of nutritional disorders. The development of effective fungicides has reduced the prevalence of the disease compared to the past, although significant fruit losses from bitter rot can still occur during years with conducive weather conditions.', 0.3556334972381592]]
Context 9: [['The effects of three calcium salts on conidial germination, germ tube elongation, growth in vitro, and infectivity in the laboratory and field were studied for the apple bitter rot pathogens, Colletotrichum gloeosporioides and C. acutatum. Calcium chloride, calcium propionate, and calcium silicate, at 1,000 µg of calcium per ml, had no effect on conidial germination; however, calcium chloride and calcium propionate inhibited germ tube growth by 41% and 50% relative to the control, respectively. All three calcium salts reduced fungal dry weight in liquid culture media.', 0.34810349345207214]]

query: Is crop rotation effective against anthracnose?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Until highly resistant cultivars are available, growers must rely on chemical applications and cultural practices to reduce losses due to anthracnose. The failure of fungicides to control anthracnose epidemics may be due to the development of fungicide resistance in the Colletotrichum spp. population. For example, benomyl effectively reduced the incidence of anthracnose crown rot (Horn et al., 1972; Howard, 1971) and was used intensively by strawberry growers for years to control anthracnose and other diseases. However, the anthracnose pathogens, C. acutatum and C. fragariae, developed resistance to it and other benzimidazole fungicides (LaMondia, 1995; McInnes et al., 1992a; Smith and Black, 1992, 1993), rendering benomyl ineffective for anthracnose control in strawberry fields.', 0.3178270161151886]]
Context 1: [['Until highly resistant cultivars are available, growers must rely on chemical applications and cultural practices to reduce losses due to anthracnose. The failure of fungicides to control anthracnose epidemics may be attributed to the development of fungicide resistance in the Colletotrichum species population. For example, benomyl was shown to effectively reduce the incidence of anthracnose crown rot (Horn et al., 1972; Howard, 1971) and was used intensively by strawberry growers for years to control anthracnose and other diseases. However, the anthracnose pathogens, C. acutatum and C. fragariae, developed resistance to it and other benzimidazole fungicides (LaMondia, 1995; McInnes et al., 1992a; Smith and Black, 1992, 1993), leading to the ineffectiveness of benomyl for anthracnose control in strawberry fields.', 0.2902906537055969]]
Context 2: [['Increased losses due to anthracnose fruit and crown rots may be related to the shift from matted-row culture to the annual plasticulture production system in the United States. Breeding for genetic resistance to anthracnose and the development of resistant cultivars are primary means for reducing economic losses due to this disease. This approach is environmentally sound because it results in reduced fungicide use. As our knowledge of the anthracnose pathogens and the epidemiology of anthracnose diseases has increased, so has our ability to control these diseases. Changes in cultural practices have resulted in reduced levels of disease. Simultaneously, the development of more effective fungicides and their registration for use on strawberries have significantly reduced losses due to both anthracnose crown rot and fruit rot. Anthracnose-resistant cultivars have also decreased economic losses caused by these diseases. Nevertheless, growers may still face severe losses when environmental conditions are highly favorable for anthracnose development.', 0.24121040105819702]]
