query: Can I mix different fungicides to control anthracnose more effectively?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Past failures of fungicides to control anthracnose epidemics may have stemmed from the development of resistance in the Colletotrichum population. In the early 1970s, benomyl effectively reduced anthracnose crown rot incidence (Horn et al., 1972; Howard, 1971) and was widely used by strawberry growers for years. However, anthracnose pathogens developed resistance to it and other benzimidazole fungicides, rendering benomyl ineffective. In vitro and greenhouse trials have been conducted to identify fungicides to which Colletotrichum pathogens have developed resistance (LaMondia, 1993, 1995; McInnes et al., 1992a, 1992b; Smith and Black, 1991, 1992, 1993). Current fungicide labels address pathogen resistance by restricting the number of consecutive and total applications of a product per season. For instance, the fungicides Abound (azoxystrobin, Syngenta, Greensboro, NC), Cabrio (pyraclostrobin, BASF, Research Triangle Park, NC), and Pristine (pyraclostrobin and boscalid, BASF) are limited to four or five applications per season, with no more than two consecutive applications before alternating with a fungicide that has a different mode of action. Natural products have also been evaluated as alternative fungicides, offering different modes of action, lower toxicity, and increased efficacy (Abril et al., 2008).', 0.9853987693786621]]
Context 1: [['There is an urgent need for multi- and single-site fungicide alternatives effective against anthracnose in strawberry nurseries and production fields. The antifungal antibiotic natamycin, widely used as a natural mold inhibitor in food products, has shown promise in controlling anthracnose root and crown infections caused by C. acutatum on strawberry transplants (Cordova et al. 2017; Haack et al. 2018). Similarly, fluazinam, a single-site respiration inhibitor fungicide from FRAC group 29, has demonstrated significant control of anthracnose fruit rot (Mertely et al. 2018). A request has been submitted through the Interregional Research Project Number 4 for its registration for nursery use only. Reducing the overlap of the same modes of action used during nursery and fruit production phases could help extend the lifespan of single-site fungicides at high risk of resistance.', 0.9778712391853333]]
Context 2: [['Present and Future Management of Anthracnose: Fungicides, including chemicals such as benzimidazoles (e.g., thiabendazole, benomyl, and carbendazim) and sterol inhibitors (e.g., imazalil, prochloraz, and propiconazole), have been used effectively to control anthracnose disease in banana, mango, papaya, and avocado plants [140]. Benzimidazoles are commonly applied as dips or sprays to inhibit the anthracnose-causing fungus, Colletotrichum spp. [141], but the large-scale and continuous use of fungicides has led to the development of fungal resistance. For instance, benzimidazole-resistant Colletotrichum has been detected in mangoes and bananas [140]. Additionally, the excessive use of fungicides negatively impacts human health and the environment, as chemical residues often contaminate soil and water [142]. Biocontrol offers an alternative, non-toxic method for managing fruit crop anthracnose. Biocontrol agents, such as antagonistic microbes including yeast, bacteria, and filamentous fungi (particularly Trichoderma spp.), have shown promising results and are gaining popularity for their direct application to fruit surfaces post-harvest [143].', 0.9732662439346313]]
Context 3: [['Until highly resistant cultivars are available, growers must rely on chemical applications and cultural practices to reduce losses due to anthracnose. The failure of fungicides to control anthracnose epidemics may be due to the development of fungicide resistance in the Colletotrichum spp. population. For example, benomyl effectively reduced the incidence of anthracnose crown rot (Horn et al., 1972; Howard, 1971) and was used intensively by strawberry growers for years to control anthracnose and other diseases. However, the anthracnose pathogens, C. acutatum and C. fragariae, developed resistance to it and other benzimidazole fungicides (LaMondia, 1995; McInnes et al., 1992a; Smith and Black, 1992, 1993), rendering benomyl ineffective for anthracnose control in strawberry fields.', 0.9447216987609863]]
Context 4: [['Until highly resistant cultivars are available, growers must rely on chemical applications and cultural practices to reduce losses due to anthracnose. The failure of fungicides to control anthracnose epidemics may be attributed to the development of fungicide resistance in the Colletotrichum species population. For example, benomyl was shown to effectively reduce the incidence of anthracnose crown rot (Horn et al., 1972; Howard, 1971) and was used intensively by strawberry growers for years to control anthracnose and other diseases. However, the anthracnose pathogens, C. acutatum and C. fragariae, developed resistance to it and other benzimidazole fungicides (LaMondia, 1995; McInnes et al., 1992a; Smith and Black, 1992, 1993), leading to the ineffectiveness of benomyl for anthracnose control in strawberry fields.', 0.9372945427894592]]
Context 5: [['Based on field trials in Florida (Mertely et al., 2009), the recommendation for anthracnose control involves weekly applications of a broad-spectrum protectant fungicide (captan) at the lowest label rate early in the season when conditions are less favorable for anthracnose development. Later, when anthracnose-infected flowers and fruit may be present, it is recommended to increase the rate of the protectant fungicide to the highest label rate. Warm, rainy weather in early spring often leads to epidemics, during which additional fungicides may be necessary. Growers are encouraged to scout their fields regularly for anthracnose symptoms, such as blighted flowers or black spots on green fruit. If symptoms are detected, the application of a strobilurin fungicide (such as Abound or Cabrio) in conjunction with the protectant fungicide is recommended. During the main bloom period, in late January and early February, fungicides containing two active ingredients (one for anthracnose control and one for Botrytis fruit rot control), such as CaptEvate, Pristine, or Switch, are advised. Tank mixes or higher rates of protectant fungicides should be maintained until the end of the harvest season or until dry weather effectively suppresses the disease.', 0.9233601689338684]]
Context 6: [['The efficacy of fungicides for anthracnose control is routinely assessed in field studies. For example, 16 different fungicide treatments were evaluated in five studies conducted in Hammond, LA, and Poplarville, MS, during the 2002, 2003, and 2005 fruiting seasons (Wedge et al., 2007).', 0.922581136226654]]
Context 7: [['Nursery surveys confirmed the intensive use of QoI fungicides. Single-site fungicides, such as QoIs, have frequently been used in nurseries to control anthracnose and other diseases, ensuring the delivery of symptom-free stock material. Along with commercial products containing only azoxystrobin or pyraclostrobin, premixes with QoI fungicides were also utilized. This has led to an increased selection rate for QoI-resistant populations as early as the nursery phase. Since transplants produced in large nurseries are sold to smaller ones, plants may be exposed to multiple QoI applications throughout each propagation phase. Consequently, during the fruit production phase, growers face challenges in controlling anthracnose outbreaks with limited effective chemical options.', 0.9196091890335083]]
Context 8: [['For the management of anthracnose crown rot, water washing or fungicide treatments of bare-root transplants have been utilized in the nursery or immediately before planting in production fields (Daugovish et al., 2009; Freeman et al., 1997). Running water effectively removes soil from root and crown tissues, potentially eliminating inoculum, but it does not control any infections already present (Koike et al., 2008). Pre-plant fungicide dips have been shown to decrease anthracnose crown rot; however, only two products are currently registered for this use in the United States. The single-site mode of action quinone outside inhibitor (QoI), azoxystrobin, has been widely used as a preplant dip and as a foliar treatment for managing anthracnose and other fungal diseases (Bartlett et al., 2002; Koike et al., 2008; Turechek et al., 2006). Resistance has been reported against this fungicide group in Colletotrichum acutatum populations from strawberries in Florida (Forcelini et al., 2016). During the 2015-16 California nursery crown rot outbreak, growers reported reduced efficacy of azoxystrobin dips, suggesting that resistance may also be present in California (K. Ivors, unpublished). A premixed product of the anilinopyrimidine cyprodinil and the phenylpyrrole fludioxonil is also registered, but phytotoxicity and stunting of plants have been reported under certain environmental conditions or following off-label exposure (G. Holmes, unpublished).', 0.8577055931091309]]
Context 9: [['In-vitro trials have been used to screen fungicides for their ability to control anthracnose (LaMondia, 1993; McInnes et al., 1992b; Smith and Black, 1992). Smith and Black (1993) reported that all 16 C. acutatum, 14 out of 18 C. fragariae, and both C. gloeosporioides isolates tested in vitro were resistant to benomyl, and all benomyl-resistant isolates were also resistant to carbendazim, which belongs to the same class of fungicides as benomyl. In a greenhouse study, plants treated with propiconazole exhibited lower disease severity ratings than those treated with captafol or benomyl (Smith and Black, 1991). However, the propiconazole-treated plants were shorter, with dark green leaves that appeared thicker than the leaves of untreated plants.', 0.7222857475280762]]

query: Could the observed growth rate of C. siamense (12.9 ± 1.9 mm per day) and C. fructicola (13.1 ± 1.7 mm per day) be affected by seasonal changes in their natural habitats?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Growth rates were similar for both species, with C. siamense averaging 12.9 ± 1.9 mm per day, and C. fructicola averaging 13.1 ± 1.7 mm per day, indicating comparable mycelial growth under the same conditions.', 0.9385411739349365]]
Context 1: [["Among the five Colletotrichum species identified in this study, C. siamense exhibited greater mycelial growth rates on PDA, particularly at higher temperatures. The fitness advantage of C. siamense in warm weather may explain its current geographical distribution. In the literature, C. siamense has been most frequently reported in tropical and subtropical regions, while C. boninense, C. fructicola, and C. karstii have been documented across a wide range of latitudes. Temperature is a key environmental factor affecting a pathogen's survival. A recent study based on published observations of 612 crop pests and pathogens from 1960 onward revealed significant positive latitudinal shifts of many important pests and pathogens under climate change. More research on the genetic and biological characteristics of different Colletotrichum species from diverse geographical areas is necessary to understand the emergence and spread of anthracnose diseases. With rising global temperatures, it will be particularly important to monitor the expansion of the heat-adapted C. siamense toward higher latitudes.", 0.8691616058349609]]
Context 2: [['The table provides a detailed morphological characterization of the two Colletotrichum species. It lists colony characteristics, mycelial growth rates in mm per day, conidial shape, and appressorial shape and sizes in mm for multiple isolates. For C. siamense, colonies are described as white, becoming pale brown or greenish gray, with an average mycelial growth rate of approximately 12.9 mm per day. The conidia are cylindrical with obtuse ends, and the appressoria are ovate, measuring between 4.8 and 6.0 mm. In contrast, C. fructicola colonies are gray to dark gray with age, exhibiting an average growth rate of around 13.1 mm per day. Its conidia are also cylindrical, while the appressoria are clavate to ovate, measuring 4.8 to 6.0 mm.', 0.6883691549301147]]
Context 3: [['Morphological and Cultural Characterization: All tested isolates developed white colonies that turned gray to black after 14 days on PDA (Potato Dextrose Agar). Colony sectoring was observed in 8 of the 29 isolates. There was considerable variation in the mycelial growth rate among the 29 isolates of Colletotrichum. The average mycelial growth rate for C. asianum was 6.7 to 10.7 mm/day, for C. fructicola, 7.3 to 12.4 mm/day, and for C. siamense, 9.4 to 11.1 mm/day. The conidia were all hyaline, guttulate, one-celled, and cylindrical.', 0.45339053869247437]]
Context 4: [['In addition to phylogenetic analysis, we investigated morphological features, including cultural characteristics, colony growth rate, and the shape and size of conidia and appressoria, as well as detached fruit assays (see Table 3). The cultural characteristics of C. siamense and C. fructicola isolates were consistent with findings from previous studies (Prihastuti et al. 2009; Yang et al. 2009). Colonies of C. siamense appeared either white with gray or white with some orange, while C. fructicola colonies featured dark gray centers and white peripheral mycelium. Additionally, the size variation of conidia between our C. siamense and C. fructicola isolates aligned with the known variability within the C. gloeosporioides species complex (Weir et al. 2012). Specifically, the mean length of C. siamense conidia was slightly shorter than that of C. fructicola, although the mean width of conidia from both species was nearly identical (Weir et al. 2012). Furthermore, the colony growth rate and appressorial size of C. fructicola were higher and larger, respectively, compared to those of C. siamense when cultured on PDA at 28°C in the dark, consistent with previous data (Prihastuti et al. 2009). However, differences in conidial and appressorial sizes were noted across studies. For instance, the mean length of conidia from our C. siamense isolates was 16.0 µm, while Prihastuti et al. (2009) reported a mean length of 10.17 µm, which may be due to variations in cultural conditions or differences in host sources. Yang et al. (2009) used the same C. siamense isolates as those in the Prihastuti et al. study and recorded a conidial length of 15.3 µm.', 0.4373001456260681]]
Context 5: [['A representative isolate from each of five Colletotrichum species was grown on Potato Dextrose Agar (PDA) at temperatures ranging from 18°C to 32°C. The maximum growth rate of C. siamense ML133 was estimated at 27.9°C, while the maximum growth rates for C. fructicola ML348, C. karstii ML351, C. boninense ML521, and C. miaoliense ML1040 were observed at 26.0°C, 26.9°C, 24.0°C, and 26.5°C, respectively (see Figure 5 and Supplementary Table S3). The growth rate of C. boninense ML521 drastically decreased at 32°C. C. miaoliense ML1040 exhibited the slowest growth rate across all tested temperatures, except at 32°C. The ranking of species by growth rates at higher temperatures (28°C, 30°C, and 32°C) is as follows: C. siamense ML133 > C. fructicola ML348 > C. karstii ML351 and C. boninense ML521 (at 28°C and 30°C) > C. miaoliense ML1040 > C. boninense ML521 (at 32°C) (refer to Figure 5 and Supplementary Table S3). Additionally, the growth rates of C. siamense ML133 were compared with those of two other representative isolates from C. siamense, C. fructicola, C. karstii, and C. miaoliense (see Supplementary Table S4). The ranking of isolates by mycelial growth rates at both 25°C and 30°C on PDA was as follows: C. siamense ML133 and ML540 > C. siamense ML612 and C. fructicola ML368 > C. fructicola ML356 and C. karstii ML1792 > C. karstii ML442 > C. miaoliense ML1042 and ML1794.', 0.3090704083442688]]
Context 6: [['Initially, colonies of the isolates on PDA appeared white and then developed a grey to dark grey color at the center over time, showing a growth rate of 9.98 ± 1.8 mm per day. The shape and size of the conidia were cylindrical, measuring 14.6 ± 0.47 × 3.99 ± 0.11 µm. The appressoria were ovoid, sometimes clavate, with measurements of 9.93 ± 0.32 × 4.90 ± 0.10 µm. Prihastuti et al. (2009) noted that the colony characteristics and conidial shape and size of C. fructicola were similar to those of C. gloeosporioides, although the appressoria of C. fructicola were ovoid and sometimes clavate.', 0.3071635663509369]]
Context 7: [['D, G: Setae and conidiophores.', 0.22403594851493835]]
Context 8: [['The average conidial sizes for the isolates were: for C. asianum, 12.1 to 18.6 µm by 4.2 to 5.6 µm; for C. fructicola, 14.1 to 20.2 µm by 3.7 to 4.3 µm; and for C. siamense, 15.0 to 18.5 µm by 5.0 to 5.5 µm. The various Colletotrichum species reported here displayed differences in conidial size and growth rates.', 0.20920409262180328]]
Context 9: [['Inoculations of wounded leaves were conducted at 30 °C for C. siamense ML133, C. boninense ML521, and two additional representative isolates of C. siamense, C. fructicola, C. karstii, and C. miaoliense (Fig. S7). The results showed that C. siamense (ML133, ML540, ML612) and C. fructicola ML356 caused significantly larger lesions (1.21–1.74 cm in diameter at 7 days post-inoculation (dpi); 3.06–3.47 cm in diameter at 14 dpi) than C. fructicola ML368, C. karstii (ML442, ML1792), and C. miaoliense (ML1042, ML1794) (0.42–0.76 cm in diameter at 7 dpi; 1.06–2.15 cm in diameter at 14 dpi).', 0.14801084995269775]]

query: How does temperature affect the growth of Colletotrichum species?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Bernstein B, Zehr EI, Dean RA, et al. 1995. Characteristics of Colletotrichum due to its economically useful traits, including cold temperature and poor soil tolerance.', 0.5453717112541199]]
Context 1: [['Citation: Cai, L., Hyde, K.D., Taylor, P.W.J., Weir, B.S., Waller, J., Abang, M.M., Zhang, J.Z., Yang, Y.L., Phoulivong, S., Liu, Z.Y., Prihastuti, H., Shivas, R.G., McKenzie, E.H.C., Johnston, P.R. (2009). A polyphasic approach for studying Colletotrichum. Fungal Diversity, 39: 183-204.', 0.3827815353870392]]
Context 2: [['The genus Colletotrichum represents a large number of economically important Ascomycete fungi that collectively cause anthracnose disease or leaf blights on significant agricultural crops and ornamental plants worldwide. Colletotrichum spp. often serve as models in studies ranging from pathogenic development and differentiation to plant-microbe interactions. During establishment and colonization of host plants, members of this genus uniquely acquire nutrients via both biotrophy and necrotrophy. Thus, in a single interaction, these fungal pathogens exhibit two modes of nutrient acquisition: initially, nutrients are acquired from living cells, after which a necrotrophic phase is initiated, allowing the same fungus to obtain nutrients from dead cells killed by the fungus. A given species of this genus can exhibit both strategies separately or concurrently. Additionally, these fungi develop a series of specialized infection-related structures, including germ tubes, appressoria, primary intracellular hyphae, and secondary necrotrophic hyphae. Therefore, Colletotrichum species are experimentally attractive organisms for studying the molecular, biochemical, and cellular basis of fungal pathogenicity, development, and signal transduction (see Bailey and Jeger, 1992; Prusky et al., 1999).', 0.3442451059818268]]
Context 3: [['Before the molecular era, the taxonomy of Colletotrichum species was primarily based on morphological and cultural characteristics, including conidia size and shape, presence or absence of setae, colony color, and growth rate (von Arx 1957; Sutton 1980, 1992). However, these characteristics can be unreliable for species differentiation due to variability under changing environmental conditions (Cai et al. 2009).', 0.34060537815093994]]
Context 4: [['The genus Colletotrichum is considered one of the top ten important genera of fungal pathogens globally (Dean et al., 2012). Colletotrichum is an ancient fungus that has co-evolved with flowering plants. Plant microfossils of Protocolletotrichum preserved on angiosperm leaf cuticles suggest that the diverse pathogenic strategies of Colletotrichum spp. have been established since the Late Cretaceous period (Kar et al., 2004). Different complexes within the genus may have diverged between 4.8 and 32.2 million years ago (MYA) (Bhunjun et al., 2021). The emergence of agricultural cultivation and the intensive disturbance of natural environments have further driven the diversification of Colletotrichum species. These fungi have adapted to thousands of hosts and can be found as endophytes, pathogens, and saprobes (Freeman et al., 1998; Dean et al., 2012; Hirayama et al., 2018; da Silva et al., 2020; Jayawardena et al., 2020). Currently, a total of 257 Colletotrichum species grouped into 15 complexes and 13 additional singletons have been accepted in this genus.', 0.2936251163482666]]
Context 5: [['Traditionally, Colletotrichum species are identified based on morphological characteristics, including conidial and appressorial size and shape, the presence of acervuli, setae, or sclerotia, sexual structures, and cultural traits such as growth rate and colony color. Distinguishing Colletotrichum species morphologically has been challenging due to their phenotypic similarities and the influence of variable environmental factors on the expression of morphological traits. Consequently, all available morphological characteristics are often combined and used for systematic species discrimination.', 0.2888329327106476]]
Context 6: [['In Colletotrichum: Biology, Pathology and Control (eds. J.A. Bailey and M.J. Jeger). CAB International: Wallingford.', 0.285516619682312]]
Context 7: [['Yang, Y.L., Liu, Z.Y., Cai, L., Hyde, K.D., Yu, Z.N., & McKenzie, E.H.C. (2009). Colletotrichum.', 0.28002527356147766]]

query: How is MEGA X utilized in teaching evolutionary genetics to students?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['The Molecular Evolutionary Genetics Analysis (MEGA) software implements various analytical methods and tools for phylogenomics and phylomedicine. We report a transformation of MEGA to enable cross-platform use on Microsoft Windows and Linux operating systems. MEGA X does not require virtualization or emulation software and provides a uniform user experience across platforms. Additionally, MEGA X has been upgraded to utilize multiple computing cores for many molecular evolutionary analyses. MEGA X is available in two interfaces (graphical and command line) and can be downloaded free of charge from www.megasoftware.net.', 0.9632614850997925]]
Context 1: [["Over the past decade, genome sequencing has become an efficient and potent means to investigate a broad array of biological systems, from large-scale studies of biological diversity to tracking the evolution and origin of pathogenic microbes. The numerous steps required to glean interpretable and actionable results from raw sequence data invariably require comparative analysis of molecular sequences to discover functional and adaptive genome differences. The Molecular Evolutionary Genetics Analysis (MEGA) software provides tools to conduct such analyses. MEGA includes a large repertoire of programs for assembling sequence alignments, inferring evolutionary trees, estimating genetic distances and diversities, inferring ancestral sequences, computing timetrees, and testing selection. Over the last 25 years, MEGA's use in evolutionary analysis has been cited in over one hundred thousand studies in diverse biological fields.", 0.7895893454551697]]
Context 2: [['In conclusion, the cross-platform MEGAX will benefit many existing users and encourage others to consider using MEGAX in their research and teaching endeavors. The consistency of user experience across platforms should be particularly useful in facilitating collaborative analyses within and among research groups, as well as in teaching diverse groups of students. In the near future, we aim to complete the development of a macOS version to make MEGAX available on all major operating systems.', 0.454871267080307]]
Context 3: [['We have also enhanced MEGA’s computational core by increasing the number of methods that can utilize multiple processors and cores on the same machine. This improvement will significantly reduce the runtime for computationally demanding inferences. Users can specify the maximum number of cores to deploy in the Analysis Preferences dialog box (FIG. 2G). By default, MEGA X uses all available cores, minus one, ensuring that no more than 80% of RAM is consumed. Computational methods benefiting from calculation parallelization include those for selecting the best model for nucleotide or amino acid substitutions and bootstrap tests of molecular phylogenies employed with distance-based and parsimony-based methods. Users can already utilize multiple cores during the heuristic search for the Maximum Likelihood (ML) tree in MEGA.', 0.29163968563079834]]
Context 4: [['Tamura, K., Stecher, G., Peterson, D., Filipski, A., & Kumar, S. (2013). MEGA6: Molecular evolutionary genetics analysis version 6.0. Molecular Biology and Evolution, 30, 2725–2729.', 0.27968212962150574]]
Context 5: [['Tamura, K., Stecher, G., Peterson, D., et al. (2013). MEGA6: Molecular Evolutionary Genetics Analysis version 6.0. Molecular Biology and Evolution.', 0.26444995403289795]]
Context 6: [['Key Words: multiple sequence alignment, metagenome, protein structure, progressive alignment, parallel processing.', 0.21119879186153412]]
Context 7: [['Waterhouse AM, Procter JB, Martin DM, Clamp M, Barton GJ. 2009. Bioinformatics.', 0.17041745781898499]]
Context 8: [['FIG. 1. The MEGA X main form has a modernized look and feel while maintaining the familiar structure of previous versions of MEGA. (A) The top toolbar organizes the numerous analyses available in MEGA X into logical groups accessed via drop-down menus. (C) Icons on the main form offer convenient access to input data and results explorer windows. query: Can anthracnose be transmitted through water runoff?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Anthracnose spreads within a field through splashing water. Living mulches, such as wheat, rye, or rye grass, in row middles have been shown to reduce disease spread. Organic mulches like wheat straw or pine needles also reduce splash and result in a lower incidence of anthracnose compared to rows mulched with plastic (Coelho et al., 2008; Madden, 1992; Smith and Spiers, 1986). Context 6: [['Anthracnose spreads within a field by splashing water, and living mulches (such as wheat, rye, or ryegrass) in row middles have been shown to reduce disease spread within a field. Sublethal doses of grass-specific herbicides, such as sethoxydim, may be used to prevent excessive growth of ryegrass (Gupton, 2000). Organic mulches, such as wheat straw or pine needles, also reduce splash and result in a lower incidence of anthracnose compared to rows mulched with plastic (Madden, 1992; Smith and Spiers, 1986). Additionally, anthracnose is less severe when water is supplied to plants using drip irrigation rather than overhead irrigation (Madden, 1992; Smith and Spiers, 1986). Anthracnose crown rot was observed to be less severe in commercial fields when strawberries were grown in soils with low nitrogen fertility (Howard et al., 1992). In greenhouse studies, Smith (1987, 1989) determined that strawberries grown in soils with high levels of nitrogen, especially from ammonium sources, are more susceptible to anthracnose than plants grown in soils with lower nitrogen levels or those with high levels of calcium nitrate.', 0.13483990728855133]]

query: What are the potential environmental benefits of using single-dip treatments with fungicides in strawberry transplants?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['The purpose of this research was to evaluate new fungicides with registration potential for use as preplant dip treatments of bare-root strawberry transplants for the management of anthracnose crown rot. The specific objectives were to (i) determine whether QoI...', 0.986869752407074]]
Context 1: [['There is an urgent need for multi- and single-site fungicide alternatives effective against anthracnose in strawberry nurseries and production fields. The antifungal antibiotic natamycin, widely used as a natural mold inhibitor in food products, has shown promise in controlling anthracnose root and crown infections caused by C. acutatum on strawberry transplants (Cordova et al. 2017; Haack et al. 2018). Similarly, fluazinam, a single-site respiration inhibitor fungicide from FRAC group 29, has demonstrated significant control of anthracnose fruit rot (Mertely et al. 2018). A request has been submitted through the Interregional Research Project Number 4 for its registration for nursery use only. Reducing the overlap of the same modes of action used during nursery and fruit production phases could help extend the lifespan of single-site fungicides at high risk of resistance.', 0.9770691990852356]]
Context 2: [['This study evaluated the fungicides prochloraz-Zn, prochloraz-Mn (both protectant sterol-biosynthesis inhibitors), captan, folpet, a combined formulation of prochloraz-Zn and folpet, propiconazole, difenoconazole, and a heat treatment for the control of C. acutatum in naturally infected strawberry plants under laboratory, greenhouse, and field conditions. Fungicides were applied at the transplant stage to determine whether a single-dip treatment is sufficient for disease control.', 0.9748256802558899]]
Context 3: [['Fig. 2. Effect of fungicide dip treatments of A and B (Portola); C and D (Monterey); or E and F (Fronteras) strawberry transplants inoculated with a mixture of four isolates—each of A, C, and E (quinone outside inhibitor [QoI]-sensitive) or B, D, and F (QoI-resistant) isolates of Colletotrichum acutatum on disease severity. Plants were evaluated after 5 or 14 weeks for aboveground vegetative growth based on a rating scale of 0 = healthy, vigorous plant; 1 = growth reduced; 2 = growth and vigor reduced; 3 = growth and vigor extremely reduced; and 4 = dead. Average disease severity was determined based on 10 plants for each of four replications in each experiment. Bars followed by the same letter within a graph are not significantly different based on least significant difference mean separation (P > 0.05) procedures. Rates are based on active ingredient, except for Streptomyces lydicus, where the rate is based on the formulated product.', 0.9429479241371155]]
Context 4: [['Additionally, multisite fungicides such as captan, thiram, and chlorothalonil, which have been available for many decades, remain effective in reducing strawberry anthracnose incidence (Mertely et al. 2018). Chlorothalonil is only registered for nonbearing nurseries when flowers and fruit are absent, yet our surveys indicated that its usage is significantly lower compared to newer single-site fungicides. Due to their efficacy and low resistance risk, multisite fungicides should be the mainstay for disease control in strawberry nurseries. Other non-chemical alternatives, such as heat (Wang et al. 2017) and ultraviolet treatments (Onofre et al. 2017), are currently under investigation and could serve as valuable tools for disease management, reducing the reliance on single-site fungicides.', 0.9221064448356628]]
Context 5: [['The experimental fungicide pydiflumetofen was not effective against C. acutatum in our in vitro and field studies. However, this fungicide is very active against B. cinerea and has shown high efficacy in reducing powdery mildew in strawberries (J. E. Adaskaveg, unpublished). The pydiflumetofen-fludioxonil premixture was among the most effective of our preplant dip treatments for crown rot in strawberries, likely due to the fludioxonil component. Therefore, this premixture has potential as a broad-spectrum post-plant field fungicide for strawberries.', 0.915467381477356]]
Context 6: [['Transplants of all three strawberry cultivars inoculated with either QoI-sensitive or -resistant isolates and dip-treated with natamycin at both rates, or with the pydiflumetofen-fludioxonil or fludioxonil-cyprodinil premixes, showed significantly (P < 0.05) lower disease severity and plant mortality compared to controls. There were generally no significant (P > 0.05) differences among these four treatments, with the new fungicides providing similar control to the registered premix of fludioxonil and cyprodinil. Among the six cultivar-inoculum combinations, the 0.5 g/liter rate of natamycin was significantly (P > 0.05) less effective than the 1 g/liter rate only for Portola inoculated with QoI-resistant isolates. No stunting of plants or other signs of phytotoxicity were observed in any treatment during these trials.', 0.8300282955169678]]
Context 7: [['The application of fungicides to control strawberry anthracnose is limited due to restrictions on pesticide usage and the susceptibility of strawberry plants to Colletotrichum during all stages of development, including flowers, green, and ripe fruit. To reduce anthracnose infection in plant nurseries, it is essential to produce disease-free propagation material, which is a prerequisite for establishing disease-free nursery transplants. Control measures practiced in the United States involve frequent applications of fungicides.', 0.6681552529335022]]
Context 8: [['In laboratory experiments, infection in segments of strawberry runners treated with prochloraz-Zn reached 60%, which was significantly reduced compared to the combined prochloraz-Zn/folpet (90%), captan, folpet, and water controls (100%). In the greenhouse, the number of naturally infected transplants killed was significantly reduced by all fungicides and the heat treatment (5 minutes at 49°C) compared to the non-treated control. Prochloraz-Zn was the most effective chemical control treatment but did not differ significantly from the heat treatment.', 0.6215067505836487]]
Context 9: [['In field experiments conducted during 1995 and 1996, the number of naturally infected strawberry transplants killed was significantly reduced by all fungicide treatments relative to the non-treated control. The percent reduction of transplant mortality in the field was 93.3%, 93.1%, 66.7%, 37.7%, and 29.1% for prochloraz-Mn, prochloraz-Zn, combined prochloraz-Zn/folpet, propiconazole, and difenoconazole, respectively.', 0.5936746001243591]]

Context 5: [['Many species belonging to the genus Colletotrichum are associated with plant diseases, commonly referred to as anthracnose. Colletotrichum spp. can affect a wide range of hosts, and these pathogens are characterized by global distribution. Virtually every cultivated botanical family is susceptible to one or more species of Colletotrichum, making it one of the most studied plant pathogenic fungi (Prusky et al., 2000; Latunde-Dada, 2001; Dean et al., 2012). Context 0: [['Huber, D. M., and Wilhelm, N. S. 1988. The role of manganese in resistance to plant disease. Pages 155-173 in: Manganese in Soils and Plants. R. D. Graham, R. J. Hannam, and J. C. Uren, eds., Kluwer Academic Publishers, Dordrecht, The Netherlands.', 0.2167186737060547]]
Context 1: [['Five years into an intensive study on the natural biological control of take-all through continuous wheat monocropping (48), a fortuitous event redirected our attention to manganese. One of our farmer-cooperators directly drilled soybeans across our study area shortly after we harvested the wheat. Soybeans in the most severely affected take-all areas exhibited slow growth and intense chlorosis, characteristic of severe manganese deficiency, whereas plants in adjacent areas appeared normal (16). Tissue analysis of the soybeans confirmed the manganese deficiency only in plants grown in regions of the field where wheat was severely infected by take-all. A manganese sulfate foliar spray alleviated this deficiency.', 0.18193435668945312]]

query: In what ways does the research challenge or reinforce existing knowledge about the role of phosphite in plant pathology?
retrieved_context:

The question has been raised as to whether phosphonates can replace phosphates as a phosphorus source, potentially offering additional disease control benefits. Context 7: [['Evaluating the effect of combined phosphate and phosphite nutrition, Carswell et al. (3) found that adding phosphite (1.5 to 10 mM) to phosphate-limited Brassica nigra seedlings reduced plant growth. In phosphate-sufficient plants, only the 10 mM phosphite levels caused a reduction. Additionally, while the root-to-shoot ratios of phosphate-stressed plants were typically high (3, 11, 13), phosphite supplementation decreased the root-to-shoot ratio to about 40% of control values. Carswell et al. (3) explained these effects as a disruption of the phosphate-starvation response by phosphonates, causing phosphate-limited plants to behave as though they are phosphorus-sufficient. In our study, root-to-shoot ratios of tomato plants were also significantly lower for phosphorous acid-fertilized plants compared to no-phosphorus plants, indicating similar effects on phosphate metabolism. However, a combined treatment of 1 mM phosphate and 0.3 mM phosphorous acid increased leaf area significantly in two experiments, with a trend for greater leaf dry weight compared to phosphate treatment alone in three experiments. This finding might explain the labeling of commercial phosphite formulations as supplemental fertilizers for improved plant growth and increased crop yield. Additional studies are needed to evaluate possible interactions between phosphite and phosphate fertilizers. Phosphorous acid is readily absorbed by plants and is both xylem- and phloem-mobile (10). Using ion chromatography for quantifying phosphorous acid, Ouimette and Coffey (10) demonstrated that phosphonates are quite stable in avocado plants, persisting in this form for at least several months. Similarly, Robertson and Boyer (12) reported a biological inertness of organic and inorganic phosphites. In our experiments, phosphate concentrations in tomato plants treated with technical phosphite did not differ statistically from those of the no-phosphorus control plants. Phosphate levels in the solutions were not significantly different (P > 0.05) when freshly made or after one week in the recirculating hydroponic system, supporting previous work that molecular oxygen does not readily oxidize phosphonates in aqueous solutions (12). A general trend for higher phosphate levels was observed in the 1.0 mM phosphite solutions compared to the no-phosphorus treatment. In both fresh and aged solutions, measurable phosphate levels in the no-phosphorus and 1 mM phosphite treatments ranged from 0.2 to 0.6 µg/ml, respectively. Contamination may have occurred from the salts used in the basic nutrient solution. In plants treated with a commercial formulation of phosphite, phosphate concentrations were significantly above those of the no-phosphorus treated plants. This increase could be explained by the slightly elevated phosphate levels in the nutrient solution. Decreased phosphate concentrations in the plant tissue of the 1 mM phosphate/0.3 mM phosphite treated plants compared to the 1 mM phosphate treated plants aligns with previous studies that showed growth of phosphate-sufficient plants in the presence of phosphite resulted in reduced root and leaf phosphate levels (3). The effect of phosphorus compounds on disease control was studied using P. capsici–inoculated pepper plants. Plants grown with both formulations of phosphorous...', 0.08712934702634811]]

query: What are the long-term ecological impacts of widespread fungicide use in intensive farming systems?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Nursery surveys confirmed the intensive use of QoI fungicides. Single-site fungicides, such as QoIs, have frequently been used in nurseries to control anthracnose and other diseases, ensuring the delivery of symptom-free stock material. Along with commercial products containing only azoxystrobin or pyraclostrobin, premixes with QoI fungicides were also utilized. This has led to an increased selection rate for QoI-resistant populations as early as the nursery phase. Since transplants produced in large nurseries are sold to smaller ones, plants may be exposed to multiple QoI applications throughout each propagation phase. Consequently, during the fruit production phase, growers face challenges in controlling anthracnose outbreaks with limited effective chemical options.', 0.5256093144416809]]

query: How often do I need to spray fungicides, and which ones work best for strawberries?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['ABSTRACT: Strawberry anthracnose, caused by Colletotrichum fragariae, is a serious problem in the southeastern United States, resulting in significant losses in strawberry nurseries. Control measures using fungicides are crucial, particularly with recommended applications of captafol, benomyl, captan, and maneb.', 0.7853121161460876]]
Context 1: [['Additionally, multisite fungicides such as captan, thiram, and chlorothalonil, which have been available for many decades, remain effective in reducing strawberry anthracnose incidence (Mertely et al. 2018). Chlorothalonil is only registered for nonbearing nurseries when flowers and fruit are absent, yet our surveys indicated that its usage is significantly lower compared to newer single-site fungicides. Due to their efficacy and low resistance risk, multisite fungicides should be the mainstay for disease control in strawberry nurseries. Other non-chemical alternatives, such as heat (Wang et al. 2017) and ultraviolet treatments (Onofre et al. 2017), are currently under investigation and could serve as valuable tools for disease management, reducing the reliance on single-site fungicides.', 0.6778137683868408]]
Context 2: [['Pavan, W., C.W. Fraisse, and N.A. Peres. 2009. A web-based decision support tool for timing fungicide applications in strawberry. University of Florida Publication AE450, Agricultural and Biological Engineering Department, Florida Cooperative Extension Service, IFAS, University of Florida, Gainesville, FL.', 0.5831298232078552]]
Context 3: [['Nam, M. H.; Kim, H. S.; Nam, Y. G.; Peres, N. A.; Kim, H. G. (2011). Fungicide spray program to reduce application in anthracnose of strawberry. Research Plant Disease, 17(3), 295-301.', 0.5745353698730469]]
Context 4: [['The experimental fungicide pydiflumetofen was not effective against C. acutatum in our in vitro and field studies. However, this fungicide is very active against B. cinerea and has shown high efficacy in reducing powdery mildew in strawberries (J. E. Adaskaveg, unpublished). The pydiflumetofen-fludioxonil premixture was among the most effective of our preplant dip treatments for crown rot in strawberries, likely due to the fludioxonil component. Therefore, this premixture has potential as a broad-spectrum post-plant field fungicide for strawberries.', 0.48585668206214905]]
Context 5: [['Smith, B.J. and L.L. Black. 1991. Greenhouse efficacy of fungicides for control of anthracnose crown rot of strawberry, p. 221-223. In: A. Dale and J. Luby (eds.). The Strawberry into the 21st Century. Timber Press, Portland, OR.', 0.48123058676719666]]
Context 6: [['Smith, B.J., & Black, L.L. (1991). Greenhouse efficacy of fungicides for control of anthracnose crown rot of strawberry. In A. Dale & J. Lubby (Eds.), The Strawberry into the 21st Century (pp. 221–223). Timber Press, Portland, OR.', 0.47806572914123535]]
Context 7: [['Strawberry anthracnose, caused mainly by the Colletotrichum acutatum species complex, is a significant disease affecting strawberry production. Surveys were conducted, and isolates were collected from affected areas, specifically strawberry nurseries and production fields in six states across the United States. The use of fungicides, particularly quinone outside inhibitors (QoIs), has been widely employed for controlling C. acutatum for the past 20 years. Resistance to QoIs was first reported in Florida in 2013, and subsequent anthracnose outbreaks occurred in strawberry nurseries and production fields throughout the U.S. in 2015. Fungicide use surveys indicated that, in certain locations, the number of QoI applications exceeded the recommended levels for this fungicide group. This situation necessitates immediate changes in anthracnose management strategies to incorporate other chemical and non-chemical approaches, aiming to limit the selection of resistant populations and prevent future outbreaks.', 0.4750610589981079]]
Context 8: [['Past failures of fungicides to control anthracnose epidemics may have stemmed from the development of resistance in the Colletotrichum population. In the early 1970s, benomyl effectively reduced anthracnose crown rot incidence (Horn et al., 1972; Howard, 1971) and was widely used by strawberry growers for years. However, anthracnose pathogens developed resistance to it and other benzimidazole fungicides, rendering benomyl ineffective. In vitro and greenhouse trials have been conducted to identify fungicides to which Colletotrichum pathogens have developed resistance (LaMondia, 1993, 1995; McInnes et al., 1992a, 1992b; Smith and Black, 1991, 1992, 1993). Current fungicide labels address pathogen resistance by restricting the number of consecutive and total applications of a product per season. For instance, the fungicides Abound (azoxystrobin, Syngenta, Greensboro, NC), Cabrio (pyraclostrobin, BASF, Research Triangle Park, NC), and Pristine (pyraclostrobin and boscalid, BASF) are limited to four or five applications per season, with no more than two consecutive applications before alternating with a fungicide that has a different mode of action. Natural products have also been evaluated as alternative fungicides, offering different modes of action, lower toxicity, and increased efficacy (Abril et al., 2008).', 0.46558138728141785]]
Context 9: [['Smith, B.J., & Black, L.L. (1991). Greenhouse efficacy of fungicides for control of anthracnose crown rot of strawberry, pp. 221–223. In A. Dale & J. Lubby (Eds.), The strawberry into the 21st century. Timber Press, Portland, OR.', 0.45534276962280273]]

Context 1: [['Although strawberries are considered a minor crop, they provide a significant source of income for many fruit and nursery growers. In the United States, strawberries were cultivated on nearly 20,000 hectares in 1989, yielding a total production of 555,000 tons valued at $520 million. Florida ranks second only to California in the production of fresh-market strawberries. For U.S. winter production (December through March), strawberries are grown on approximately 2,400 hectares. The major cultural problems faced by the Florida strawberry industry include: 1) anthracnose diseases, 2) yearly infestations of the two-spotted spider mite (Tetranychus urticae Koch), and 3) variability in the quality of nursery transplants. Commercial fields are established annually, similar to California practices. Freshly dug transplants are sourced from nurseries in Florida or from northern states and Canada. The use of transplants from northern nurseries is crucial to avoid anthracnose disease issues and to ensure that plants have undergone sufficient natural chilling to induce floral bud initiation.', 0.2744521498680115]]

query: What impact does anthracnose have on strawberry seedlings in Taiwan?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Strawberry anthracnose can affect plants at any lifecycle stage, but plants are particularly susceptible at the seedling stage and immediately after planting (Wang et al. 2008). The disease primarily affects strawberry roots, petioles, and stolons, but can also infect flowers and fruit, leading to severe outbreaks (Mertely and Legard 2004). Symptoms include irregular ulcer-like lesions, reddish-brown stolons during initial stolon development, black spindle-shaped lesions on leaves and petioles, wilting, and dead roots (Debode et al. 2009; Freeman and Katan 1997). In Zhejiang, nearly 50% of seedling deaths and over 40% of production losses in nurseries are attributed to this disease (Xie et al. 2010). If environmental conditions are favorable, anthracnose can reduce strawberry yield by up to 80%. Transplants are considered the main source of primary inoculum, but the complete epidemiology of Colletotrichum spp. on strawberries in China remains unclear.', 0.9695910811424255]]
Context 1: [['From 2010 to 2016, we conducted surveys of anthracnose in strawberries in Miaoli County. More than 50% of diseased plants exhibited symptoms characteristic of anthracnose crown rot (ACR), as described by McInnes et al. (1992). ACR resulted in plant losses of up to 30-40% during the seedling stage and around 20% after transplanting. Initial symptoms in crown tissue included a marbled red and white appearance, which progressed to brown rot and eventual rapid wilting of the plant. Anthracnose symptoms also appeared on other parts of the plant, including leaves, petioles, runners, fruits, and roots. These symptoms manifested as circular black spots on leaves, withering and girdling on runners.', 0.9233709573745728]]
Context 2: [['Strawberry anthracnose was first reported in China in 1990 (Hu, 1990). Shao (1992) documented the first instance of strawberry anthracnose in Shanghai, identifying the pathogen as Colletotrichum acutatum (Dai et al., 2006). Zhang et al. (2007) expanded on these findings by identifying C. gloeosporioides and C. fragariae (syn. C. theobromicola) as causal agents based on morphological characteristics. Ren et al. (2008, 2011) concluded that these three species are the main pathogens causing anthracnose in strawberries in China. Crown rot represents the most severe disease issue in many strawberry-producing regions of China (Ren et al., 2008). In the Zhejiang region, nearly 50% of seedling deaths in nurseries and over 40% yield losses in strawberry fields have been recorded (Xie et al., 2010). In 2009, the yield of greenhouse-cultivated strawberries in Donggang City, Liaoning Province, was reduced by over 10% due to crown rot (Wang, 2013). The average incidence of crown rot in greenhouses in Hubei Province was 41.7% in 2011 (Xiang et al., 2012). However, most studies conducted in China regarding this disease have primarily relied on morphological and single-gene (mainly ITS) analysis (Dai et al., 2006; Ren et al., 2008, 2011). Due to overlapping characteristics, species delimitation based solely on morphology is challenging in this genus. Employing multi-gene analysis alongside morphology can provide better resolution (Cai et al., 2009; Hyde et al., 2014). Therefore, the objective of this study was to identify the pathogens responsible for strawberry anthracnose in China using a morphological and multi-gene approach.', 0.721050500869751]]
Context 3: [['Anthracnose is an important disease of strawberry caused by Colletotrichum spp., which affects foliage, runners, crowns, and fruits (Howard et al., 1992). Three primary fungal pathogens—C. acutatum sensu lato, C. gloeosporioides sensu lato, and C. fragariae—are known to cause anthracnose disease in strawberries (Freeman and Katan, 1997). The crown rot syndrome is characteristic of infections from C. gloeosporioides sensu lato and C. fragariae, while fruit rot is mainly attributed to C. acutatum sensu lato, leading to significant yield losses (Howard et al., 1992). Currently, numerous species are classified under what is now known as the C. acutatum complex, with six species—C. acutatum sensu stricto, C. fioriniae, C. godetiae, C. nymphaeae, C. salicis, and C. simmondsii—identified as associated with strawberry anthracnose worldwide (Damm et al., 2012). Among these, C. nymphaeae is the most prevalent pathogen causing strawberry anthracnose globally, including in Iran (Baroncelli et al., 2015; Karimi et al., 2017; Wang et al., 2019). Currently, no effective chemical control methods exist for managing strawberry anthracnose; available options are limited to preventive treatments applied before fruit production (Denoyes-Rothan et al., 1999). Additionally, concerns about the toxic effects of chemical fungicides on the environment and the development of resistance in fungal strains highlight the need for alternative control strategies. Consequently, utilizing resistant cultivars appears to be the most efficient and practical approach for suppressing anthracnose development. In light of recent anthracnose outbreaks in strawberry fields in the Kurdistan province of Iran (Karimi et al., 2017), and the necessity for appropriate strategies to address this issue, the aim of this study was to evaluate the resistance of several commercial strawberry cultivars to the anthracnose fruit rot caused by C. nymphaeae under in vivo and greenhouse conditions.', 0.5953360795974731]]
Context 4: [["Anthracnose fungi can attack various parts of the strawberry plant, including crowns, petioles, leaves, fruit trusses, flowers, buds, and fruit. The fungi's ability to attack multiple plant parts, coupled with the involvement of several pathogen species, contributes to the complex nature of strawberry anthracnose. Brooks reported in 1931 that C. fragariae caused spotting and girdling of runners, and later indicated that it also caused spotting of petioles and crown rot in a summer nursery, leading to wilting and death of the plants. Researchers in Louisiana observed all these symptoms and noted that crown rot also occurred in the fruit production field.", 0.46947795152664185]]
Context 5: [['As our knowledge of the anthracnose pathogens and the epidemiology of anthracnose diseases has increased, so has our ability to control these diseases. Anthracnose-resistant cultivars have also diminished economic losses due to these diseases. Nevertheless, growers may still experience severe losses when environmental factors are highly favorable for anthracnose development.', 0.3817662000656128]]

query: Is it easy or hard to tell different types of Colletotrichum apart?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['In a drastic move, von Arx (1957) reduced the number of recognized Colletotrichum species from several hundred to 11 based on morphological characteristics, with many taxa treated as synonyms of C. gloeosporioides and C. dematium. Several additional species have since been accepted based on morphological criteria (Sutton, 1980; 1992). The difficulties in recognizing Colletotrichum species can be attributed to: 1) the limited and variable morphological characters; 2) an extensive host range and variability in pathogenicity (Bailey and Jeger, 1992; Freeman et al., 2000; Latunde-Dada, 2001; Du et al., 2005; Thaung, 2008); 3) type specimens that are often missing or in poor condition, making them unsuitable for molecular studies; and 4) numerous rDNA ITS sequences of Colletotrichum strains in NCBI that are often misidentified (Crouch et al., 2009d; Damm et al., 2009).', 0.7838631868362427]]
Context 1: [['Despite significant developments over the last ten years, the taxonomy of Colletotrichum is in a state of flux. Many uncertainties exist in the systematics of fungal pathogens from this genus; depending on the taxonomic "guides," the number of species can range from 29 to over 700 (von Arx, 1957; Sutton, 1992). One of the most confusing species is C. gloeosporioides. For example, 594 species of Colletotrichum were reclassified by von Arx as synonyms of C. gloeosporioides. Identification has primarily relied on morphological characteristics of conidia, vegetative and sexual structures, as well as host specificity and cultural characteristics (von Arx, 1957). Unfortunately, conidial morphology and colony characteristics vary even within isolates. Consequently, classical methods have been supplemented with biochemical and molecular technologies to differentiate Colletotrichum species (J. W. Kronstad, ed., Fungal Pathology, 127-148. © 2000 Kluwer Academic Publishers). For a more complete discussion of this topic, see Sherriff et al. (1994).', 0.6765019297599792]]

Context 4: [['Yang, Y.L., Liu, Z.Y., Cai, L., Hyde, K.D., Yu, Z.N., & McKenzie, E.H.C. (2009). Colletotrichum.', 0.4184378981590271]]
Context 5: [['The genus Colletotrichum is considered one of the top ten important genera of fungal pathogens globally (Dean et al., 2012). Colletotrichum is an ancient fungus that has co-evolved with flowering plants. Plant microfossils of Protocolletotrichum preserved on angiosperm leaf cuticles suggest that the diverse pathogenic strategies of Colletotrichum spp. have been established since the Late Cretaceous period (Kar et al., 2004). Different complexes within the genus may have diverged between 4.8 and 32.2 million years ago (MYA) (Bhunjun et al., 2021). The emergence of agricultural cultivation and the intensive disturbance of natural environments have further driven the diversification of Colletotrichum species. These fungi have adapted to thousands of hosts and can be found as endophytes, pathogens, and saprobes (Freeman et al., 1998; Dean et al., 2012; Hirayama et al., 2018; da Silva et al., 2020; Jayawardena et al., 2020). Currently, a total of 257 Colletotrichum species grouped into 15 complexes and 13 additional singletons have been accepted in this genus.', 0.4124157130718231]]

query: What are the first signs of anthracnose on strawberries?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['In November 2021, anthracnose symptoms were observed on strawberries (cv. Kingsberry) in Nonsan, Chungnam Province. Early symptoms of anthracnose fruit rot (AFR) include blackening of specific tissues of the strawberry. These symptoms progress with the enlargement of lesions, which hinder proper fruit development and lead to the formation of orange-colored spores within the lesions. Similar symptoms were noted on the petioles, with sunken and blackened tissues similar to those on the fruit, accompanied by the formation of an orange conidial mass.', 0.9908002018928528]]
Context 1: [['The term "anthracnose" was first used to describe a new disease of strawberries caused by Colletotrichum fragariae Brooks. "Strawberry anthracnose" continues to be used as a general term to identify all diseases of strawberries caused by species of Colletotrichum. Strawberry anthracnose diseases have been reported to be caused by C. acutatum J.H. Simmonds, C. gloeosporioides (Penz.) Penz. & Sacc. in Penz. (the teleomorph of Cromereilla cingulata (Stoneman) Spauld. & H. Schrenk), and C. dematium (Pers.) Grove. The latter species only occasionally causes strawberry fruit rots and will not be discussed here.', 0.986014723777771]]
Context 2: [['From 2010 to 2016, we conducted surveys of anthracnose in strawberries in Miaoli County. More than 50% of diseased plants exhibited symptoms characteristic of anthracnose crown rot (ACR), as described by McInnes et al. (1992). ACR resulted in plant losses of up to 30-40% during the seedling stage and around 20% after transplanting. Initial symptoms in crown tissue included a marbled red and white appearance, which progressed to brown rot and eventual rapid wilting of the plant. Anthracnose symptoms also appeared on other parts of the plant, including leaves, petioles, runners, fruits, and roots. These symptoms manifested as circular black spots on leaves, withering and girdling on runners.', 0.9859849214553833]]
Context 3: [['From May to September 1995, a severe outbreak of strawberry anthracnose was observed in several strawberry-growing nurseries in Israel. Following transplantation to production fields during September and October, entire beds of strawberry plants collapsed. Typical anthracnose symptoms observed from November 1995 to June 1996 included crown rot, flower blight, and green and ripe fruit rot. This marked the first record of strawberry anthracnose in Israel. Furthermore, in at least four production fields in the same region, hundreds of plants developed symptoms of stunting and chlorosis, which are atypical of strawberry anthracnose. When these plants were uprooted, most of their roots were dark brown and decayed. Colletotrichum was readily isolated from these samples.', 0.9820050001144409]]
Context 4: [['Anthracnose is an important disease of strawberry caused by Colletotrichum spp., which affects foliage, runners, crowns, and fruits (Howard et al., 1992). Three primary fungal pathogens—C. acutatum sensu lato, C. gloeosporioides sensu lato, and C. fragariae—are known to cause anthracnose disease in strawberries (Freeman and Katan, 1997). The crown rot syndrome is characteristic of infections from C. gloeosporioides sensu lato and C. fragariae, while fruit rot is mainly attributed to C. acutatum sensu lato, leading to significant yield losses (Howard et al., 1992). Currently, numerous species are classified under what is now known as the C. acutatum complex, with six species—C. acutatum sensu stricto, C. fioriniae, C. godetiae, C. nymphaeae, C. salicis, and C. simmondsii—identified as associated with strawberry anthracnose worldwide (Damm et al., 2012). Among these, C. nymphaeae is the most prevalent pathogen causing strawberry anthracnose globally, including in Iran (Baroncelli et al., 2015; Karimi et al., 2017; Wang et al., 2019). Currently, no effective chemical control methods exist for managing strawberry anthracnose; available options are limited to preventive treatments applied before fruit production (Denoyes-Rothan et al., 1999). Additionally, concerns about the toxic effects of chemical fungicides on the environment and the development of resistance in fungal strains highlight the need for alternative control strategies. Consequently, utilizing resistant cultivars appears to be the most efficient and practical approach for suppressing anthracnose development. In light of recent anthracnose outbreaks in strawberry fields in the Kurdistan province of Iran (Karimi et al., 2017), and the necessity for appropriate strategies to address this issue, the aim of this study was to evaluate the resistance of several commercial strawberry cultivars to the anthracnose fruit rot caused by C. nymphaeae under in vivo and greenhouse conditions.', 0.9516069293022156]]
Context 5: [['Smith, B. J. 1998. Anthracnose leaf spot, irregular spot, anthracnose fruit rot (black spot), and anthracnose crown rot. In: Compendium of Strawberry Diseases. J. L. Mass, ed. American Phytopathological Society, St. Paul, MN. Pages 24-25, 31-33, and 46-48.', 0.8417154550552368]]
Context 6: [["Anthracnose fungi can attack various parts of the strawberry plant, including crowns, petioles, leaves, fruit trusses, flowers, buds, and fruit. The fungi's ability to attack multiple plant parts, coupled with the involvement of several pathogen species, contributes to the complex nature of strawberry anthracnose. Brooks reported in 1931 that C. fragariae caused spotting and girdling of runners, and later indicated that it also caused spotting of petioles and crown rot in a summer nursery, leading to wilting and death of the plants. Researchers in Louisiana observed all these symptoms and noted that crown rot also occurred in the fruit production field.", 0.8069785237312317]]
Context 7: [['Numerous reports indicate that strawberry anthracnose pathogens may originate from weed species. For instance, C. fragariae was found attacking the weed Cassia obtusifolia L. (sicklepod, coffeweed) in Florida, causing typical disease symptoms. Inoculation of strawberry with the Cassia isolates resulted in typical anthracnose symptoms, while isolates from strawberry were equally virulent on Cassia. Similarly, inoculation of Duchesnea indica (Andr.) Focke (wild strawberry), F. virginiana Duch. (Virginia wild strawberry), and Potentilla canadensis L. with C. fragariae induced anthracnose disease on these hosts, suggesting that strawberry anthracnose pathogens have a broad host range.', 0.8006533980369568]]
Context 8: [['Ye, Z. W., Zheng, H. Q., & Tong, Y. M. (1997). First report on species of strawberry anthracnose pathogen in Shanghai suburbs and resistance of some strawberry cultivars to anthracnose. Acta Agriculturae Shanghai, 13, 75–80.', 0.7841391563415527]]

Context 0: [['Colletotrichum acutatum J.H. Simmonds is a common pathogen affecting a wide range of crops and non-cultivated plant species. Common hosts encompass many dicotyledonous plants, including strawberries, apples, citrus, and stone fruits; serious diseases have also been reported on leatherleaf ferns and pines. Notably, there are no known reports of C. acutatum affecting grasses. query: What patterns of geographic distribution are observed in the C. acutatum species complex, and what historical factors might explain these patterns?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Members of the C. acutatum species complex have been well-documented from agricultural and natural hosts worldwide (Perfect et al., 1999; Peres et al., 2005; Sreenivasaprasad and Talhinhas, 2005). The scientific community has long studied the biomolecular processes regulating this lifestyle, especially those related to the switch from biotrophy to necrotrophy. The species complex has a very wide host range. Meta-analyses have revealed that C. acutatum s.l. strains are associated with infections in hundreds of species from over 90 genera of plants (Magnoliophyta: monocotyledons and dicotyledons, Pinophyta, and Pteridophyta), along with at least two insect species (Dufresne et al., 2000; Thon et al., 2002; Wharton and Diéguez-Uribeondo, 2004; O’Connell et al., 2012; Marcelino et al., 2008; Mascarin et al., 2016). In a few cases, associations have been noted with marine ecosystems (Manire et al., 2002; Namikoshi et al., 2002). There appears to be little to no evidence of co-evolution between host and pathogen, particularly in cultivated fruit systems like strawberry and olive, which are susceptible to many members of this species complex (Jayawardena et al., 2016).', 0.6609185338020325]]
Context 1: [['Recently, more focus has been placed on conidium morphology, particularly shape and dimensions. The acute conidial ends that contribute to the typical fusiform shape are considered critical morphological features of C. acutatum (Simmonds 1965). However, the name C. acutatum has been applied to various species exhibiting fusiform conidia, many of which are closely related to C. acutatum s. str. Moreover, conidial shape can show significant variation both within the species and among strains (Damm et al. 2012). Studies have shown that the fusiform conidial shape is not a consistent feature in the C. acutatum species complex. For instance, Talhinhas et al. (2002) noted that Colletotrichum isolates from Lupinus spp. (equivalent to C. lupini) displayed varying proportions of conidia with round ends or one round and one acute end, resulting in cylindrical or clavate shapes. In a recent investigation, many strains previously classified as C. gloeosporioides, based on typical cylindrical conidia (Cannon et al. 2008), were found to belong to different species within the C. acutatum complex (Damm et al. 2012). Additionally, there are species with acute-ended conidia that are phylogenetically distinct from the C. acutatum complex, such as C. pseudoacutatum and C. proteae (Cannon et al. 2012; Damm et al. 2012; Liu et al. 2013). The revision of the C. acutatum complex has recognized 31 species through a multilocus molecular approach, significantly advancing our understanding of these plant pathogens (Damm et al. 2012).', 0.40913307666778564]]
Context 2: [['The holotype of Glomerella acutata is therefore an interspecific hybrid between C. acutatum and C. fioriniae. This may be construed as strong evidence that these two taxa constitute a single biological species, suggesting that the species concepts used in this paper are too narrow. However, the parent strains of the holotype originate from geographically distant populations, and there are instances in other fungal groups (e.g., Neurospora) where non-sympatric populations lose post-mating reproductive isolation barriers (Turner et al. 2010, 2011). Further research on population structures and mating-type barriers would be instructive.', 0.40293848514556885]]
Context 3: [['C. acutatum, as noted by various studies (Peres et al. 2008; Lee et al. 2007; Talhinhas et al. 2011; Polashock et al. 2009; Wharton & Schilder 2008), has a well-known morphological feature: the shape of its conidia, which are characterized by acute ends (Simmonds 1965). However, other conidial shapes are frequently encountered, particularly cylindrical forms with only one acute end. These variations are often observed in strains that have been repeatedly subcultured, as well as in the “terminal crook” disease of pine (Dingley & Gilmour 1972) and in the anthracnose affecting leather leaf fern (Schiller et al. 2006). There are also reports of disseminated infections in sea turtles (Manire et al. 2002) and infections in scale insects (Marcelino et al. 2008). Differentiating between C. acutatum (s. lat.) and C. gloeosporioides (s. lat.) is challenging due to the existence of many intermediate strains that exhibit a limited number of typical fusiform conidia alongside numerous cylindrical ones (Van der Aa et al. 1990).', 0.3869347870349884]]
Context 4: [['Our research aims to present a comprehensive revision of the C. acutatum species complex. We thoroughly survey the constituent taxa and delineate additional species where needed. We have examined a large number of C. acutatum s. lat. strains, isolated from various hosts and geographic areas. Multi-locus molecular analysis serves as the basis for species recognition, although morphological and cultural characters allowing alternative means of species recognition are provided where possible.', 0.37538355588912964]]
Context 5: [['Notably, the occurrence of C. acutatum s.l., C. boninense s.l., and C. truncatum s.l. species was essentially random in China. Furthermore, C. nymphaeae and C. miaoliense were only identified in temperate zones, including Hebei and Beijing, or from subtropical regions with elevations around 1,000 meters (1,100 meters in Enshi, Hubei; 1,300 meters in Renai; or 960 meters in Shitan, Nantou, Taiwan) (Han et al. 2016; Chung et al. 2020).', 0.3750773072242737]]
Context 6: [['Research has characterized C. acutatum s.l. populations related to strawberries in specific geographic areas, including Israel, France, Bulgaria, Spain, Belgium, and other European countries, as well as in specific regions of the USA. Other studies have attempted to characterize C. acutatum s.l. related to strawberries using isolates collected worldwide, employing genomic fingerprinting techniques (such as RFLP and apPCR) and sequence analysis based on the ITS region. Results indicate at least one representative clonal population, suggesting a single source of origin, and indicate that the disease spreads through infected propagation material. However, ITS sequences alone or genomic fingerprinting are not adequate to discriminate among the newly assigned species designations.', 0.3737553358078003]]
Context 7: [['In this study, the C. acutatum species complex was identified exclusively on the Aeolian Islands (Italy), a volcanic archipelago located north of Sicily.', 0.30984219908714294]]
Context 8: [['The C. acutatum species complex has undergone speciation more prolifically than previously suspected, indicating that it is likely still evolving rapidly. The emergence of new species is likely encouraged by modern global agricultural practices, which facilitate the mixing of gene pools, combined with imperfect phytosanitary regulations.', 0.2961491346359253]]
Context 9: [['At this point, it was widely presumed that C. acutatum was a species complex containing several constituent taxa. However, there was substantial reluctance to recognize the clades involved as independent species due to the lack of distinctive morphological and cultural characters. For example, C. lupini was not formally recognized as separate from C. acutatum by Talhinhas et al. (2002) or by Sreenivasaprasad & Talhinhas (2005). Some attempts were made to address these concerns through the adoption of formae speciales, such as C. acutatum f. sp. pineum (Dingley & Gilmour 1972), C. acutatum f. sp. hakeae (Lubbe et al. 2004), and C. acutatum f. sp. fioriniae (Marcelino et al. 2008). However, this mechanism for recognizing pathology-related taxa is now rarely used.', 0.26853588223457336]]

query: How does soil pH influence nutrient availability for strawberry plants?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Compared to Ca(NO3)2, the (NH4)2SO4 treatment reduced the percentage of blackened roots. The influence of the cover crops on growth and disease was more pronounced with (NH4)2SO4 fertilization than with Ca(NO3)2. Combining ‘Saia’ oats or sorgho-sudangrass rotation with (NH4)2SO4 fertilization led to a reduction in lesion nematode (Pratylenchus penetrans) numbers in subsequent strawberry roots compared to controls. Furthermore, the combination of ‘Saia’ or ‘Garry’ oats as a precrop with applications of (NH4)2SO4 reduced black root rot severity relative to controls. Only the ‘Garry’ oat rotation reduced strawberry root colonization by Rhizoctonia fragariae when compared to controls. Additional effects associated with (NH4)2SO4 treatment included a decrease in rhizosphere soil pH by 0.2 units, a reduction in fluorescent pseudomonads in the rhizosphere by 10- to 15-fold, and leaves with higher concentrations of nitrogen, potassium, sulfur, manganese, and zinc compared to plants treated with Ca(NO3)2. Therefore, rotation with ‘Saia’ oats combined with (NH4)2SO4 fertilization may suppress strawberry black root rot and enhance yields through multiple effects on the host, pathogens, and associated microflora.', 0.39551955461502075]]

Additionally, the crop growth and tissue contents of nitrogen, phosphorus, potassium, and calcium in the entire above-ground parts of the plant were investigated.
