query: Which strawberry cultivars were identified as most resistant to anthracnose fruit rot?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['A total of 1,515 anthracnose-resistant selections were identified from the seedlings tested in Mississippi. Four of these resistant strawberry clones were subsequently released as breeding lines (Galletta et al., 1993) and have served as sources of anthracnose resistance in various breeding programs. Additionally, Smith et al. (1998) released the cultivar "Pelican," which is highly resistant to both anthracnose crown rot caused by C. fragariae and anthracnose fruit rot caused by C. acutatum. "Pelican" also shows resistance to varieties of red stele caused by Phytophthora fragariae.', 0.9980100989341736]]
Context 1: [['A total of 1,515 anthracnose-resistant selections were identified from the seedlings tested in Mississippi. Four of these resistant strawberry clones were released as breeding lines (Galletta et al., 1993) and have since been utilized as sources of anthracnose resistance in several breeding programs. Additionally, Smith et al. (1998) released the cultivar Pelican, which demonstrates high resistance to both anthracnose crown rot caused by C. fragariae and anthracnose fruit rot caused by C. acutatum. Pelican is also resistant to varieties of red stele caused by Phytophthora fragariae.', 0.9979705214500427]]
Context 2: [['Anthracnose is an important disease of strawberry caused by Colletotrichum spp., which affects foliage, runners, crowns, and fruits (Howard et al., 1992). Three primary fungal pathogens—C. acutatum sensu lato, C. gloeosporioides sensu lato, and C. fragariae—are known to cause anthracnose disease in strawberries (Freeman and Katan, 1997). The crown rot syndrome is characteristic of infections from C. gloeosporioides sensu lato and C. fragariae, while fruit rot is mainly attributed to C. acutatum sensu lato, leading to significant yield losses (Howard et al., 1992). Currently, numerous species are classified under what is now known as the C. acutatum complex, with six species—C. acutatum sensu stricto, C. fioriniae, C. godetiae, C. nymphaeae, C. salicis, and C. simmondsii—identified as associated with strawberry anthracnose worldwide (Damm et al., 2012). Among these, C. nymphaeae is the most prevalent pathogen causing strawberry anthracnose globally, including in Iran (Baroncelli et al., 2015; Karimi et al., 2017; Wang et al., 2019). Currently, no effective chemical control methods exist for managing strawberry anthracnose; available options are limited to preventive treatments applied before fruit production (Denoyes-Rothan et al., 1999). Additionally, concerns about the toxic effects of chemical fungicides on the environment and the development of resistance in fungal strains highlight the need for alternative control strategies. Consequently, utilizing resistant cultivars appears to be the most efficient and practical approach for suppressing anthracnose development. In light of recent anthracnose outbreaks in strawberry fields in the Kurdistan province of Iran (Karimi et al., 2017), and the necessity for appropriate strategies to address this issue, the aim of this study was to evaluate the resistance of several commercial strawberry cultivars to the anthracnose fruit rot caused by C. nymphaeae under in vivo and greenhouse conditions.', 0.9967944025993347]]
Context 3: [['Colletotrichum species cause severe diseases in many fruit and vegetable crops globally, with C. fragariae, C. acutatum, and C. gloeosporioides responsible for anthracnose diseases in strawberries (Smith and Black, 1990). Since the 1930s, anthracnose crown rot caused by C. fragariae and C. gloeosporioides has been a significant threat in strawberry nurseries and production fields in the southeastern United States (Brooks, 1931). The first report of the anthracnose fruit rot pathogen, C. acutatum, in the United States was documented in 1986 (Smith and Black, 1986). Increased losses attributed to anthracnose fruit and crown rots in the U.S. since the 1980s may be associated with a transition from matted-row culture to annual plasticulture production, as well as changes in cultivars. Anthracnose diseases are becoming increasingly important, leading to significant economic losses for strawberry growers worldwide. This report aims to summarize anthracnose-related research from the United States (excluding studies from California and Florida) to enhance understanding of these diseases and their control.', 0.9672141671180725]]
Context 4: [['Colletotrichum species cause serious diseases in many fruit and vegetable crops worldwide, with C. fragariae, C. acutatum, and C. gloeosporioides being responsible for anthracnose diseases in strawberries (Smith and Black, 1990). Since the 1930s, anthracnose crown rot caused by C. fragariae and C. gloeosporioides has been a significant issue in strawberry nurseries and fruit production fields in the southeastern United States (Brooks, 1931). In 1986, the anthracnose fruit rot pathogen C. acutatum was first reported in U.S. strawberries (Smith and Black, 1986). The increase in anthracnose-related losses since the 1980s is likely due to the shift from matted-row culture to annual plasticulture systems and changes in cultivars. Anthracnose diseases are gaining importance, leading to major economic losses for strawberry growers globally. This report aims to summarize anthracnose-related research from the United States (excluding California and Florida) to enhance understanding of these diseases and their control.', 0.9622801542282104]]
Context 5: [['In the early 1980s, anthracnose became a significant disease affecting strawberries in the southeastern United States. In response, the USDA-ARS established a breeding program to develop anthracnose-resistant cultivars suited to the strawberry-growing regions of this area. This initiative was conducted at the Small Fruit Research Station in Poplarville, MS, and the Fruit Laboratory in Beltsville, MD, in collaboration with state experiment stations in Florida, Louisiana, and North Carolina (Galletta et al., 1997; Smith and Spiers, 1982).', 0.9520761966705322]]
Context 6: [['In the early 1980s, when anthracnose became a major disease affecting strawberries in the southeastern United States, the USDA-ARS initiated a breeding program aimed at developing anthracnose-resistant cultivars suitable for the region. This program was established at the Small Fruit Research Station in Poplarville, MS, and the Fruit Laboratory in Beltsville, MD, in collaboration with state experiment stations in Florida, Louisiana, and North Carolina (Galletta et al., 1997; Smith and Spiers, 1982). From 1976 to 1995, over 160,000 progeny from 448 crosses made primarily by G.J. Galletta at Beltsville were screened for anthracnose resistance in the greenhouse at Poplarville, MS.', 0.9516986608505249]]
Context 7: [["The strawberry (Fragaria × ananassa), a small fruit crop, was introduced to Bangladesh in 1996 from Japan and the USA, gaining notable acceptance among both growers and consumers. However, as acreage expanded, anthracnose crown rot (ACR) has emerged as a significant challenge for strawberry producers. In March 2016, typical symptoms of ACR were observed in the 'Strawberry Festival' cultivar at a farmer's field in the Rajshahi district of Bangladesh. Symptoms were apparent in approximately 10% of the plants, manifesting as wilting of entire plants during the heat of the day and flagging of young leaves, resembling water deficiency.", 0.9306731224060059]]
Context 8: [['Ye, Z. W., Zheng, H. Q., & Tong, Y. M. (1997). First report on species of strawberry anthracnose pathogen in Shanghai suburbs and resistance of some strawberry cultivars to anthracnose. Acta Agriculturae Shanghai, 13, 75–80.', 0.9269298911094666]]

query: Can the findings in Yaguchi et al. (1996) about Colletotrichum acutatum help in developing strategies to prevent anthracnose in other plants beyond Cosmos bipinnatus?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Colletotrichum acutatum J.H. Simmonds is a common pathogen affecting a wide range of crops and non-cultivated plant species. The fungus is cosmopolitan and causes significant crop losses annually. Symptoms of the disease can include fruit rots, as well as shoot, leaf, and flower blights. Common hosts encompass many dicotyledonous plants, including strawberries, apples, citrus, and stone fruits; serious diseases have also been reported on leatherleaf ferns and pines. Notably, there are no known reports of C. acutatum affecting grasses. While well-documented from agricultural hosts, recent findings of C. acutatum in a moribund sea turtle and a native forest suggest it may inhabit other less-studied niches.', 0.4870872497558594]]

Characteristic root symptoms include light to dark brown or black lesions and necrotic tips (Fig. 1). Severe infection can blacken and extensively destroy the root system. A black mycelial mat of the fungus may form on the basal stem or "foot" area of the plant, and most roots may appear heavily melanized. On young plants, above-ground symptoms resemble general nutrient stress (Fig. 2) and are frequently misdiagnosed as nitrogen deficiency. query: Why is species identification important in managing Colletotrichum diseases?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Cano, J., Guarro, J., and Gene, J. (2004). Molecular and morphological identification of Colletotrichum species of clinical interest. Journal of Clinical Microbiology 42: 2450-2454.', 0.4707048535346985]]
Context 1: [['In a drastic move, von Arx (1957) reduced the number of recognized Colletotrichum species from several hundred to 11 based on morphological characteristics, with many taxa treated as synonyms of C. gloeosporioides and C. dematium. Several additional species have since been accepted based on morphological criteria (Sutton, 1980; 1992). The difficulties in recognizing Colletotrichum species can be attributed to: 1) the limited and variable morphological characters; 2) an extensive host range and variability in pathogenicity (Bailey and Jeger, 1992; Freeman et al., 2000; Latunde-Dada, 2001; Du et al., 2005; Thaung, 2008); 3) type specimens that are often missing or in poor condition, making them unsuitable for molecular studies; and 4) numerous rDNA ITS sequences of Colletotrichum strains in NCBI that are often misidentified (Crouch et al., 2009d; Damm et al., 2009).', 0.44327470660209656]]
Context 2: [['Citation: Cai, L., Hyde, K.D., Taylor, P.W.J., Weir, B.S., Waller, J., Abang, M.M., Zhang, J.Z., Yang, Y.L., Phoulivong, S., Liu, Z.Y., Prihastuti, H., Shivas, R.G., McKenzie, E.H.C., Johnston, P.R. (2009). A polyphasic approach for studying Colletotrichum. Fungal Diversity, 39: 183-204.', 0.3933572471141815]]
Context 3: [['The genus Colletotrichum is considered one of the top ten important genera of fungal pathogens globally (Dean et al., 2012). Colletotrichum is an ancient fungus that has co-evolved with flowering plants. Plant microfossils of Protocolletotrichum preserved on angiosperm leaf cuticles suggest that the diverse pathogenic strategies of Colletotrichum spp. have been established since the Late Cretaceous period (Kar et al., 2004). Different complexes within the genus may have diverged between 4.8 and 32.2 million years ago (MYA) (Bhunjun et al., 2021). The emergence of agricultural cultivation and the intensive disturbance of natural environments have further driven the diversification of Colletotrichum species. These fungi have adapted to thousands of hosts and can be found as endophytes, pathogens, and saprobes (Freeman et al., 1998; Dean et al., 2012; Hirayama et al., 2018; da Silva et al., 2020; Jayawardena et al., 2020). Currently, a total of 257 Colletotrichum species grouped into 15 complexes and 13 additional singletons have been accepted in this genus.', 0.37477874755859375]]

query: What is the Colletotrichum acutatum species complex, and why is it significant in plant pathology?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Colletotrichum acutatum s. str. causes diseases in a wide range of unrelated plants, some of which are economically significant, including Carica papaya, strawberry (Fragaria × ananassa), pine (Pinus spp.), Hakea spp., and rooibos (Aspalathus linearis). Two of these are associated with formae speciales, which are not recognized as a taxonomic rank in the International Code of Nomenclature for Algae, Fungi, and Plants (ICN), as they are based on fungus/plant interactions rather than single species. Consequently, formal ICN-compliant taxa cannot use formae speciales as basionyms for new combinations.', 0.9910011887550354]]
Context 1: [['Additionally, Wharton and Diéguez-Uribeondo (2004) discussed the biology of Colletotrichum acutatum, contributing to the understanding of its role in plant pathology. Lastly, Monod et al. (2016) highlighted the highly conserved nature of certain genes across various species, indicating their potential importance in pathogenicity.', 0.9844644665718079]]
Context 2: [['Colletotrichum acutatum J.H. Simmonds is a common pathogen affecting a wide range of crops and non-cultivated plant species. The fungus is cosmopolitan and causes significant crop losses annually. Symptoms of the disease can include fruit rots, as well as shoot, leaf, and flower blights. Common hosts encompass many dicotyledonous plants, including strawberries, apples, citrus, and stone fruits; serious diseases have also been reported on leatherleaf ferns and pines. Notably, there are no known reports of C. acutatum affecting grasses. While well-documented from agricultural hosts, recent findings of C. acutatum in a moribund sea turtle and a native forest suggest it may inhabit other less-studied niches.', 0.9779415130615234]]

query: How do environmental conditions influence the efficacy of fungicides across different plant species?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['For the management of anthracnose crown rot, water washing or fungicide treatments of bare-root transplants have been utilized in the nursery or immediately before planting in production fields (Daugovish et al., 2009; Freeman et al., 1997). Running water effectively removes soil from root and crown tissues, potentially eliminating inoculum, but it does not control any infections already present (Koike et al., 2008). Pre-plant fungicide dips have been shown to decrease anthracnose crown rot; however, only two products are currently registered for this use in the United States. The single-site mode of action quinone outside inhibitor (QoI), azoxystrobin, has been widely used as a preplant dip and as a foliar treatment for managing anthracnose and other fungal diseases (Bartlett et al., 2002; Koike et al., 2008; Turechek et al., 2006). Resistance has been reported against this fungicide group in Colletotrichum acutatum populations from strawberries in Florida (Forcelini et al., 2016). During the 2015-16 California nursery crown rot outbreak, growers reported reduced efficacy of azoxystrobin dips, suggesting that resistance may also be present in California (K. Ivors, unpublished). A premixed product of the anilinopyrimidine cyprodinil and the phenylpyrrole fludioxonil is also registered, but phytotoxicity and stunting of plants have been reported under certain environmental conditions or following off-label exposure (G. Holmes, unpublished).', 0.264777272939682]]
Context 1: [['Additional keywords: phosphonate fungicides, phosphorous acid.', 0.21990647912025452]]
Context 2: [['Fungicide efficacy has been evaluated through in vitro, greenhouse, and field studies, with some pathogens showing resistance to specific fungicides. query: What challenges are associated with resistance development in Colletotrichum species to fungicides like prochloraz?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Past failures of fungicides to control anthracnose epidemics may have stemmed from the development of resistance in the Colletotrichum population. In the early 1970s, benomyl effectively reduced anthracnose crown rot incidence (Horn et al., 1972; Howard, 1971) and was widely used by strawberry growers for years. However, anthracnose pathogens developed resistance to it and other benzimidazole fungicides, rendering benomyl ineffective. In vitro and greenhouse trials have been conducted to identify fungicides to which Colletotrichum pathogens have developed resistance (LaMondia, 1993, 1995; McInnes et al., 1992a, 1992b; Smith and Black, 1991, 1992, 1993). Current fungicide labels address pathogen resistance by restricting the number of consecutive and total applications of a product per season. For instance, the fungicides Abound (azoxystrobin, Syngenta, Greensboro, NC), Cabrio (pyraclostrobin, BASF, Research Triangle Park, NC), and Pristine (pyraclostrobin and boscalid, BASF) are limited to four or five applications per season, with no more than two consecutive applications before alternating with a fungicide that has a different mode of action. Natural products have also been evaluated as alternative fungicides, offering different modes of action, lower toxicity, and increased efficacy (Abril et al., 2008).', 0.9671922326087952]]
Context 1: [['Despite the effectiveness of Prochloraz, it should be thoroughly tested before widespread application in strawberry fruiting fields due to potential resistance or tolerance of C. acutatum and other Colletotrichum species. Isolates of C. kahawae, typically highly sensitive to Prochloraz, have demonstrated acquired tolerance in culture. Similarly, isolates of C. acutatum from various hosts, including strawberries, have shown resistance to benzimidazole fungicides compared to C. gloeosporioides isolates.', 0.9621482491493225]]
Context 2: [['The fact that Colletotrichum species differ in their sensitivity to certain fungicides, such as benomyl, is critical for chemical pathogen control. This variability should be taken into account when implementing a spray program, especially in mixed populations like C. acutatum and C. gloeosporioides, which affect several hosts, including apple, citrus, mango, peach, pecan, and strawberries. Differential sensitivity among these species may result in shifts in population ratios.', 0.7091583013534546]]
Context 3: [['The sensitivity ranges of the isolates to various fungicides were 0.2 to 1.6 mg/ml and 0.002 to 0.2 mg/ml, respectively, with average values of 6.5 to 6.9 mg/ml, 1.5 to 0.6 mg/ml, 0.9 to 0.4 mg/ml, and 0.1 to 0.05 mg/ml, respectively. All isolates were more sensitive to difenoconazole, flusilazole, and carbendazim than to tebuconazole (P < 0.01). However, sensitivities to the same fungicide varied among isolates. Specifically, isolates SL-31 and TS-09 were the least sensitive to carbendazim and tebuconazole, with resistance ratios of 87.3 and 51.6, respectively. Sensitivities to difenoconazole and flusilazole were largely consistent across all isolates, with resistance ratios ranging from 1 to 4.6 and from 1 to 7, respectively. Therefore, difenoconazole and flusilazole could be recommended for disease control. Notably, differences in pathogenicity and fungicide sensitivity were not correlated with geographic regions. These findings indicate a high level of intraspecific diversity within the populations of Colletotrichum gloeosporioides s.s. responsible for walnut anthracnose. For effective management, a targeted control strategy should be developed based on different geographic regions.', 0.2504364252090454]]
Context 4: [['He, L. F., Li, X. X., Gao, Y. Y., Li, B. X., Mu, W., and Liu, F. (2019). Characterization and fungicide sensitivity of Colletotrichum spp. from different hosts in Shandong, China. Plant Disease, 103, 34-43.', 0.24227356910705566]]
Context 5: [['Smith, B.J., & Black, L.L. (1993). In vitro fungicide studies show the occurrence of benomyl-resistant Colletotrichum spp. from strawberry. Advances in Strawberry Research, 12, 42–48.', 0.23681998252868652]]
Context 6: [['Host Range and Specificity Some Colletotrichum species exhibit extensive host ranges, while others are more specific. Certain strains, such as C. gloeosporioides and C. acutatum, infect a broad range of hosts, whereas others, like C. dematium, may have more restricted host interactions. These characteristics are vital for the development of commercial mycoherbicides aimed at controlling specific weeds like northern jointvetch.', 0.2353535294532776]]

query: How do gene families encoding carbohydrate-active enzymes and proteases contribute to the pathogenicity of Colletotrichum species?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['In recent years, genome sequences for 28 species of Colletotrichum have been published, and comparative genomic studies have concentrated on genes associated with pathogenicity (Gan et al., 2013), host specialization (Baroncelli et al., 2016; Gan et al., 2016), and transitions between biotrophic and necrotrophic lifestyles (O’Connell et al., 2012), as well as between endophytic and parasitic lifestyles (Hacquard et al., 2016; Hiruma et al., 2016). Comparative analyses of secretomes have revealed that most predicted secreted proteins possess enzymatic activity, with many identified as candidate effectors (O’Connell et al., 2012; Gan et al., 2013; Baroncelli et al., 2016; Sanz-Martín et al., 2016). The host range of Colletotrichum species seems to be linked to gene loss or gain in families encoding carbohydrate-active enzymes (CAZymes) and proteases (Baroncelli et al., 2016). Notably, gene families encoding proteases and carbohydrate-degrading enzymes are significantly expanded in Colletotrichum compared to other Sordariomycetes (Gan et al., 2013; Baroncelli et al., 2016), indicating the increased importance of these families in the infection processes of Colletotrichum species. Transcriptional profiling experiments have also shown that CAZymes, along with other classes of secreted proteins, are highly modulated during the infection process, further implicating them as critical players in pathogenicity (Kleemann et al., 2012; O’Connell et al., 2012).', 0.9982432126998901]]
Context 1: [['The genus Colletotrichum is considered one of the top ten important genera of fungal pathogens globally (Dean et al., 2012). Colletotrichum is an ancient fungus that has co-evolved with flowering plants. Plant microfossils of Protocolletotrichum preserved on angiosperm leaf cuticles suggest that the diverse pathogenic strategies of Colletotrichum spp. have been established since the Late Cretaceous period (Kar et al., 2004). Different complexes within the genus may have diverged between 4.8 and 32.2 million years ago (MYA) (Bhunjun et al., 2021). The emergence of agricultural cultivation and the intensive disturbance of natural environments have further driven the diversification of Colletotrichum species. These fungi have adapted to thousands of hosts and can be found as endophytes, pathogens, and saprobes (Freeman et al., 1998; Dean et al., 2012; Hirayama et al., 2018; da Silva et al., 2020; Jayawardena et al., 2020). Currently, a total of 257 Colletotrichum species grouped into 15 complexes and 13 additional singletons have been accepted in this genus.', 0.37594884634017944]]

retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Many species belonging to the genus Colletotrichum are associated with plant diseases, commonly referred to as anthracnose. Colletotrichum spp. can affect a wide range of hosts, and these pathogens are characterized by global distribution. Virtually every cultivated botanical family is susceptible to one or more species of Colletotrichum, making it one of the most studied plant pathogenic fungi (Prusky et al., 2000; Latunde-Dada, 2001; Dean et al., 2012). Common hosts include many dicotyledonous plants such as strawberry, apple, citrus, and stone fruits, as well as major cereals such as maize and sorghum. Members of this genus can cause crop losses of up to 100% in many staple foods (Bailey and Jeger, 1992; Prusky et al., 2000; Talhinhas et al., 2005; Cannon et al., 2012).', 0.85495924949646]]
Context 1: [['The genus Colletotrichum represents a large number of economically important Ascomycete fungi that collectively cause anthracnose disease or leaf blights on significant agricultural crops and ornamental plants worldwide. Colletotrichum spp. often serve as models in studies ranging from pathogenic development and differentiation to plant-microbe interactions. During establishment and colonization of host plants, members of this genus uniquely acquire nutrients via both biotrophy and necrotrophy. Thus, in a single interaction, these fungal pathogens exhibit two modes of nutrient acquisition: initially, nutrients are acquired from living cells, after which a necrotrophic phase is initiated, allowing the same fungus to obtain nutrients from dead cells killed by the fungus. A given species of this genus can exhibit both strategies separately or concurrently. Additionally, these fungi develop a series of specialized infection-related structures, including germ tubes, appressoria, primary intracellular hyphae, and secondary necrotrophic hyphae. Therefore, Colletotrichum species are experimentally attractive organisms for studying the molecular, biochemical, and cellular basis of fungal pathogenicity, development, and signal transduction (see Bailey and Jeger, 1992; Prusky et al., 1999).', 0.7952730059623718]]
Context 2: [['Colletotrichum is one of the most important genera of plant pathogenic fungi, with many of the 200 plus species known to cause disease in crop plants worldwide (Alahakoon et al. 1994; Rojas et al. 2010; Cannon et al. 2012; Damm et al. 2012a, 2012b; Udayanga et al. 2013; Shivas et al. 2016; De Silva et al. 2017a).', 0.6075342297554016]]

query: How does host range diversity in the C. acutatum species complex correlate with genetic variability and genome plasticity?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['The general evolutionary trend emerging in the Colletotrichum acutatum species complex indicates that distinct populations are undergoing significant changes in their host association patterns. This may suggest a role of behavioral switching in mating and changes in host associations. The occurrence of heterothallism appears to influence host range diversity, while isolates capable of homothallism, such as C. salicis and C. phormii, exhibit a narrower host range. This evolutionary trend suggests that the capacity of populations to exchange genetic information leads to genomic rearrangements, thereby increasing genome plasticity and expanding the host spectrum of this pathogen.', 0.9963011741638184]]
Context 1: [['Abstract: Colletotrichum acutatum is recognized as a significant anthracnose pathogen affecting a broad range of host plants globally. Numerous studies have reported subgroups within the C. acutatum species complex. A multilocus molecular phylogenetic analysis (ITS, ACT, TUB2, CHS-1, GAPDH, HIS3) involving 331 strains previously identified as C. acutatum and related taxa—spanning various hosts across diverse geographic regions—confirmed the previously recognized molecular groups and identified several novel taxa. Thirty-one species are accepted, of which 21 have not been previously recognized. Colletotrichum orchidophilum clusters basal to the C. acutatum species complex. This complex exhibits high phenotypic diversity, with some species showing preferences for specific hosts or geographic regions, while others are plurivorous and found in multiple areas. In this study, only C. salicis and C. rhombiforme formed sexual morphs in culture; however, sexual morphs have been documented from other taxa, particularly in laboratory crosses, with evidence of hybridization between different species. A new species, C. pseudoacutatum, was also described, resembling C. acutatum but not belonging to its species complex.', 0.9374808073043823]]
Context 2: [['The sexual stage of certain genetic subgroups of C. acutatum has been characterized under laboratory conditions and designated as Glomerella acutata. Research indicates that many isolates from diverse hosts can mate and form mature perithecia in culture. Crosses within isolates in group C, as well as some intergroup crosses, exhibit high fertility, while others show weak fertility or infertility. However, mating compatibility in C. acutatum and other Colletotrichum species is complex.', 0.30175960063934326]]
Context 3: [['In the subsequent text, it discusses research on C. acutatum and its genetic diversity. Primed PCR and AT-rich DNA analyses identified four subgroups of the pathogen. Subgroup I contains isolates from various hosts, including almond, apple, peach, and pecan in the U.S., while Israeli isolates from almond belong to subgroup IV. Other studies revealed that isolates from numerous hosts across different countries clustered into the same genetic subgroups, suggesting a lack of host specificity but some evidence of specialization for certain hosts, like key lime.', 0.29518020153045654]]
Context 4: [['Guerber, J.C., Liu, B., Correll, J.C., & Johnston, P.R. (2003). Characterization of diversity in Colletotrichum acutatum sensu lato by sequence analysis of two gene introns, mtDNA, intron RFLPs, and mating compatibility. Mycologia, 95, 872–895.', 0.2843238413333893]]
Context 5: [['Guerber, J. C., Liu, B., Correll, J. C., & Johnston, P. R. (2003). Characterization of diversity in Colletotrichum acutatum sensu lato by sequence analysis of two gene introns, mtDNA, and intron RFLPs, and mating compatibility. Mycologia, 95, 872–895.', 0.28351929783821106]]

Context 7: [['This Perspective article presents a review of the current knowledge on C. acutatum phylogeny, biology, and pathology. It also demonstrates the suitability of C. acutatum for the study of gene family evolution on a fine scale to uncover evolutionary events in the genome associated with the evolution of phenotypic characters important for host interactions.', 0.27084019780158997]]
Context 8: [['Guerber, J. C., Liu, B., Correll, J. C., and Johnston, P. R. (2003). Characterization of diversity in Colletotrichum acutatum sensu lato by sequence analysis of two gene introns, mtDNA, and intron RFLPs, and mating compatibility. Mycologia, 95, 872-895.', 0.25994303822517395]]
Context 9: [['The perceived lack of host specificity in the C. acutatum complex likely has multiple causes, but a significant issue stems from inadequate identification practices in pathology studies. Many investigations still avoid including sequence-based evidence or rely solely on ITS sequences, with only a few depositing adequate voucher material. This leads to less rigorous name usage than is necessary, resulting in misleading outcomes and poor comparability between studies. query: What are the implications of identifying the NIS1 effector gene in C. orbiculare for understanding plant-pathogen interactions in N. benthamiana?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Through functional screening of C. orbiculare cDNAs using the N. benthamiana-Agrobacterium tumefaciens in planta expression system, researchers identified a novel effector gene, NIS1, whose product induces cell death in N. benthamiana. Deletion of the signal peptide of Nis1 abolished its cell death activity, indicating that Nis1 is recognized in the apoplasts of N. benthamiana. GFP-based localization studies, combined with biochemical analysis, revealed that Nis1 is secreted from C. orbiculare cells during the fungal invasion phase inside plant tissue.', 0.9931812882423401]]
Context 1: [['Nis1-mediated cell death was suppressed by virus-induced gene silencing (VIGS) of SGT1 or HSP90 in N. benthamiana, while VIGS of RAR1 had no effect. These results suggest that SGT1 and HSP90, components of R-gene mediated defenses, are involved in the Nis1-inducing cell death pathway. Surprisingly, deletion of NIS1 had no significant effect on the infection behavior of C. orbiculare on N. benthamiana. Overexpression of Nis1 in Arabidopsis thaliana led to growth reduction, implying that the NIS1-encoded effector interferes with plant development. This indicates that C. orbiculare secretes effectors that can modulate host plant responses.', 0.9543142318725586]]
Context 2: [['Gene manipulation techniques, such as Agrobacterium tumefaciens-mediated transformation or protoplast transformation, have been established (Tsuji et al. 2003) for studies on host-parasite interactions. The model plant Nicotiana benthamiana is being used as a susceptible host. So far, several factors related to infection and morphogenesis have been identified in C. orbiculare 104-T. Essential signal transduction pathways, including the cAMP-dependent pathway and MAP kinase pathway, play a crucial role in germination, appressorium development, infection hyphae formation, and invasive growth, while the melanin biosynthesis pathway is vital for appressorium function. Various structural and regulatory genes involved in these pathways have been identified (Takano et al. 1997, Tanaka et al. 2009). Additionally, peroxisome function is essential for pathogenesis; two peroxisome biogenesis genes, PEX6 and PEX13, are critical for these processes.', 0.696137547492981]]

query: How is Fragaria × ananassa (strawberry) significant to global agriculture?

Context 0: [['The modern strawberry, Fragaria × ananassa Duchesne, is of relatively recent origin. It was not until the North American F. virginiana and the South American F. chiloensis were brought together and hybridized in Europe around 1750 that the progenitor of the strawberry we know today was developed. The high degree of genetic heterozygosity in Fragaria spp. has facilitated the creation of strawberry cultivars adapted to a wide range of environmental conditions and resistant to several diseases and pests. query: Is the —addfragments option useful for enhancing the resolution of ITS sequence alignments in fungal biodiversity studies?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['The result of the latter option (—6merpair —addfragments) is shown in Figures 2D and E. In this alignment, ITS1 and ITS2 are clearly separated and aligned to appropriate positions in the full-length alignment. Moreover, this strategy is computationally much less expensive (CPU time = 15 min [first step] + 1.5 min [second step]) than the full application of L-INS-i (CPU time = 98h). The former option (—multipair —addfragments) also returns a similar result to the latter (—6merpair) but is slower (CPU time = 48.6 min [second step]).', 0.875328540802002]]

Context 2: [['Figure 2 illustrates ITS alignments using different options of MAFFT, displayed on Jalview (Waterhouse et al. 2009). Panels (A) and (B) show incorrect alignments produced by the FFT-NS-2 and L-INS-i algorithms, respectively. Panel (C) depicts an incorrect alignment made with mafft-profile. Here, the full-length sequences were aligned using the L-INS-i algorithm, and each new sequence was subsequently added to this alignment using mafft-profile. Panel (D) presents a more reasonable alignment achieved through a two-step strategy, utilizing the —6merpair and —addfragments option in the second step. Panel (E) is a reordered version of (D), with sequences arranged such that similar sequences are grouped closely. All calculations were performed using 16 cores on a Linux PC with a 2.67GHz Intel Xeon E7-8837 and 256 GB RAM.', 0.8074840903282166]]
Context 3: [['With the rise of second-generation sequencers, aligning short reads to an existing alignment has become necessary. query: What are the most effective cultural practices for managing anthracnose in strawberry fields?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Anthracnose is an important disease of strawberry caused by Colletotrichum spp., which affects foliage, runners, crowns, and fruits (Howard et al., 1992). Three primary fungal pathogens—C. acutatum sensu lato, C. gloeosporioides sensu lato, and C. fragariae—are known to cause anthracnose disease in strawberries (Freeman and Katan, 1997). The crown rot syndrome is characteristic of infections from C. gloeosporioides sensu lato and C. fragariae, while fruit rot is mainly attributed to C. acutatum sensu lato, leading to significant yield losses (Howard et al., 1992). Currently, numerous species are classified under what is now known as the C. acutatum complex, with six species—C. acutatum sensu stricto, C. fioriniae, C. godetiae, C. nymphaeae, C. salicis, and C. simmondsii—identified as associated with strawberry anthracnose worldwide (Damm et al., 2012). Among these, C. nymphaeae is the most prevalent pathogen causing strawberry anthracnose globally, including in Iran (Baroncelli et al., 2015; Karimi et al., 2017; Wang et al., 2019). Currently, no effective chemical control methods exist for managing strawberry anthracnose; available options are limited to preventive treatments applied before fruit production (Denoyes-Rothan et al., 1999). Additionally, concerns about the toxic effects of chemical fungicides on the environment and the development of resistance in fungal strains highlight the need for alternative control strategies. Consequently, utilizing resistant cultivars appears to be the most efficient and practical approach for suppressing anthracnose development. In light of recent anthracnose outbreaks in strawberry fields in the Kurdistan province of Iran (Karimi et al., 2017), and the necessity for appropriate strategies to address this issue, the aim of this study was to evaluate the resistance of several commercial strawberry cultivars to the anthracnose fruit rot caused by C. nymphaeae under in vivo and greenhouse conditions.', 0.9958764314651489]]
Context 1: [['Overall, the study highlights the importance of cultural practices and genetic resistance in managing strawberry anthracnose effectively.', 0.9837227463722229]]
Context 2: [['Howard CM, Albregts EE. Anthracnose. In: Compendium of Strawberry Diseases. American Phytopathological Society: Paul St, ed. Maas JL, USA; 1984. pp. 85-87.', 0.35475942492485046]]
Context 3: [['So far, anthracnose epidemics have affected strawberry nurseries and production fields worldwide. Reports on Colletotrichum spp. associated with strawberries, curated from literature in PubMed and Clarivate combined with fungal database searches (Farr and Rossman, 2022), were compiled to understand the global diversity and occurrence of the causal agents of strawberry anthracnose. From our findings, since 1931 until July 9, 2022, there have been over 220 citations and 310 records related to the identification of causal agents of strawberry anthracnose at the genus level of Colletotrichum in 36 countries across six continents, with 282 records providing pathogen identification at the species or species complex level.', 0.3220363259315491]]

query: What is anthracnose and why is it significant to strawberry production?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Anthracnose is an important disease of strawberry caused by Colletotrichum spp., which affects foliage, runners, crowns, and fruits (Howard et al., 1992). Three primary fungal pathogens—C. acutatum sensu lato, C. gloeosporioides sensu lato, and C. fragariae—are known to cause anthracnose disease in strawberries (Freeman and Katan, 1997). The crown rot syndrome is characteristic of infections from C. gloeosporioides sensu lato and C. fragariae, while fruit rot is mainly attributed to C. acutatum sensu lato, leading to significant yield losses (Howard et al., 1992). Currently, numerous species are classified under what is now known as the C. acutatum complex, with six species—C. acutatum sensu stricto, C. fioriniae, C. godetiae, C. nymphaeae, C. salicis, and C. simmondsii—identified as associated with strawberry anthracnose worldwide (Damm et al., 2012). Among these, C. nymphaeae is the most prevalent pathogen causing strawberry anthracnose globally, including in Iran (Baroncelli et al., 2015; Karimi et al., 2017; Wang et al., 2019). Currently, no effective chemical control methods exist for managing strawberry anthracnose; available options are limited to preventive treatments applied before fruit production (Denoyes-Rothan et al., 1999). Additionally, concerns about the toxic effects of chemical fungicides on the environment and the development of resistance in fungal strains highlight the need for alternative control strategies. Consequently, utilizing resistant cultivars appears to be the most efficient and practical approach for suppressing anthracnose development. In light of recent anthracnose outbreaks in strawberry fields in the Kurdistan province of Iran (Karimi et al., 2017), and the necessity for appropriate strategies to address this issue, the aim of this study was to evaluate the resistance of several commercial strawberry cultivars to the anthracnose fruit rot caused by C. nymphaeae under in vivo and greenhouse conditions.', 0.990800678730011]]
Context 1: [["Anthracnose fungi can attack various parts of the strawberry plant, including crowns, petioles, leaves, fruit trusses, flowers, buds, and fruit. The fungi's ability to attack multiple plant parts, coupled with the involvement of several pathogen species, contributes to the complex nature of strawberry anthracnose. Brooks reported in 1931 that C. fragariae caused spotting and girdling of runners, and later indicated that it also caused spotting of petioles and crown rot in a summer nursery, leading to wilting and death of the plants. Researchers in Louisiana observed all these symptoms and noted that crown rot also occurred in the fruit production field.", 0.8771334886550903]]
Context 2: [['De los Santos, B., de Paredes, G., and Munoz, F. R. (2002). Influence of anthracnose epiphytotic development on strawberry fruit production in Huelva (Southwestern Spain). Acta Hortic., 567:623-626.', 0.8648302555084229]]
Context 3: [['So far, anthracnose epidemics have affected strawberry nurseries and production fields worldwide. Reports on Colletotrichum spp. associated with strawberries, curated from literature in PubMed and Clarivate combined with fungal database searches (Farr and Rossman, 2022), were compiled to understand the global diversity and occurrence of the causal agents of strawberry anthracnose. From our findings, since 1931 until July 9, 2022, there have been over 220 citations and 310 records related to the identification of causal agents of strawberry anthracnose at the genus level of Colletotrichum in 36 countries across six continents, with 282 records providing pathogen identification at the species or species complex level.', 0.8475210070610046]]
Context 4: [['The term "anthracnose" was first used to describe a new disease of strawberries caused by Colletotrichum fragariae Brooks. "Strawberry anthracnose" continues to be used as a general term to identify all diseases of strawberries caused by species of Colletotrichum. Strawberry anthracnose diseases have been reported to be caused by C. acutatum J.H. Simmonds, C. gloeosporioides (Penz.) Penz. & Sacc. in Penz. (the teleomorph of Cromereilla cingulata (Stoneman) Spauld. & H. Schrenk), and C. dematium (Pers.) Grove. The latter species only occasionally causes strawberry fruit rots and will not be discussed here.', 0.8120920658111572]]
Context 5: [['De los Santos, B., de Paredes, G., and Munoz, F. R. 2002. Influence of anthracnose epiphytotic development on strawberry fruit production in Huelva (Southwestern Spain). Acta Hortic. 567:623-626.', 0.7833577394485474]]

query: Why is it hard to control Colletotrichum?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Many species belonging to the genus Colletotrichum are associated with plant diseases, commonly referred to as anthracnose. Colletotrichum spp. can affect a wide range of hosts, and these pathogens are characterized by global distribution. Virtually every cultivated botanical family is susceptible to one or more species of Colletotrichum, making it one of the most studied plant pathogenic fungi (Prusky et al., 2000; Latunde-Dada, 2001; Dean et al., 2012). Common hosts include many dicotyledonous plants such as strawberry, apple, citrus, and stone fruits, as well as major cereals such as maize and sorghum. Members of this genus can cause crop losses of up to 100% in many staple foods (Bailey and Jeger, 1992; Prusky et al., 2000; Talhinhas et al., 2005; Cannon et al., 2012).', 0.46712368726730347]]

(2009). A polyphasic approach for studying Colletotrichum. Fungal Diversity, 39: 183-204.', 0.34073272347450256]]
Context 9: [['The genus Colletotrichum is considered one of the top ten important genera of fungal pathogens globally (Dean et al., 2012). Colletotrichum is an ancient fungus that has co-evolved with flowering plants. Plant microfossils of Protocolletotrichum preserved on angiosperm leaf cuticles suggest that the diverse pathogenic strategies of Colletotrichum spp. have been established since the Late Cretaceous period (Kar et al., 2004). Different complexes within the genus may have diverged between 4.8 and 32.2 million years ago (MYA) (Bhunjun et al., 2021). The emergence of agricultural cultivation and the intensive disturbance of natural environments have further driven the diversification of Colletotrichum species. These fungi have adapted to thousands of hosts and can be found as endophytes, pathogens, and saprobes (Freeman et al., 1998; Dean et al., 2012; Hirayama et al., 2018; da Silva et al., 2020; Jayawardena et al., 2020). Currently, a total of 257 Colletotrichum species grouped into 15 complexes and 13 additional singletons have been accepted in this genus.', 0.3221520483493805]]

query: What are the limitations of using morphological characters for Colletotrichum taxonomy?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Traditional identification systems in Colletotrichum have heavily relied on morphological and cultural characteristics (von Arx, 1957; Sutton, 1980, 1992; Bailey and Jeger, 1992; Freeman et al., 1998). Sutton (1992) noted that morphology alone does not provide sufficient information for precise identification, especially for species within the C. gloeosporioides and C. dematium complexes. Crouch et al. (2009b) argued that conidial size and shape, along with conidial appressoria, were taxonomically uninformative and of limited use for species diagnosis in graminicolous Colletotrichum species. Species with similar morphological characteristics may exhibit considerable variation at the physiological and pathogenic levels, making this recognition crucial for biosecurity, plant breeding, and integrated disease management. Taxonomy based solely on morphology is likely to result in ambiguity. Recent studies have shown that morphological characters should be used in conjunction with other characters to establish species relationships within Colletotrichum (Crouch et al., 2009b; Prihastuti et al., 2009).', 0.995448887348175]]
Context 1: [['In a drastic move, von Arx (1957) reduced the number of recognized Colletotrichum species from several hundred to 11 based on morphological characteristics, with many taxa treated as synonyms of C. gloeosporioides and C. dematium. Several additional species have since been accepted based on morphological criteria (Sutton, 1980; 1992). The difficulties in recognizing Colletotrichum species can be attributed to: 1) the limited and variable morphological characters; 2) an extensive host range and variability in pathogenicity (Bailey and Jeger, 1992; Freeman et al., 2000; Latunde-Dada, 2001; Du et al., 2005; Thaung, 2008); 3) type specimens that are often missing or in poor condition, making them unsuitable for molecular studies; and 4) numerous rDNA ITS sequences of Colletotrichum strains in NCBI that are often misidentified (Crouch et al., 2009d; Damm et al., 2009).', 0.9947932362556458]]
Context 2: [['Despite significant developments over the last ten years, the taxonomy of Colletotrichum is in a state of flux. Many uncertainties exist in the systematics of fungal pathogens from this genus; depending on the taxonomic "guides," the number of species can range from 29 to over 700 (von Arx, 1957; Sutton, 1992). One of the most confusing species is C. gloeosporioides. For example, 594 species of Colletotrichum were reclassified by von Arx as synonyms of C. gloeosporioides. Identification has primarily relied on morphological characteristics of conidia, vegetative and sexual structures, as well as host specificity and cultural characteristics (von Arx, 1957). Unfortunately, conidial morphology and colony characteristics vary even within isolates. Consequently, classical methods have been supplemented with biochemical and molecular technologies to differentiate Colletotrichum species (J. W. Kronstad, ed., Fungal Pathology, 127-148. © 2000 Kluwer Academic Publishers). For a more complete discussion of this topic, see Sherriff et al. (1994).', 0.9774222373962402]]
Context 3: [['Before the molecular era, the taxonomy of Colletotrichum species was primarily based on morphological and cultural characteristics, including conidia size and shape, presence or absence of setae, colony color, and growth rate (von Arx 1957; Sutton 1980, 1992). However, these characteristics can be unreliable for species differentiation due to variability under changing environmental conditions (Cai et al. 2009).', 0.9771892428398132]]
Context 4: [['In the past, common identification systems for Colletotrichum included traditional morphological taxonomy, molecular classification based on ITS sequences, and the presence of secondary metabolites, among other traits. However, these methods alone or in combination were insufficient to fully resolve the species identity of individual Colletotrichum isolates. Additional characteristics, including other aspects of morphology and multi-gene phylogenetic analyses, are necessary for accurate identification of Colletotrichum species.', 0.9686146974563599]]
Context 5: [['Traditionally, Colletotrichum species are identified based on morphological characteristics, including conidial and appressorial size and shape, the presence of acervuli, setae, or sclerotia, sexual structures, and cultural traits such as growth rate and colony color. Distinguishing Colletotrichum species morphologically has been challenging due to their phenotypic similarities and the influence of variable environmental factors on the expression of morphological traits. Consequently, all available morphological characteristics are often combined and used for systematic species discrimination.', 0.9490790367126465]]
Context 6: [['Species concepts in Colletotrichum have evolved from the use of basic morphological data to a polyphasic approach that incorporates a significant molecular component. This evolution has made traditional classifications less practical, as holotypes and other types are not very useful since DNA cannot usually be extracted. It is recommended that future studies adopt a polyphasic approach before introducing new species of Colletotrichum or designating epitypes. This approach should integrate molecular, morphological, physiological, and pathogenic data.', 0.7265763878822327]]
Context 7: [['To validate the taxonomy of Colletotrichum species through morphological characteristics and DNA phylogenetic analysis.', 0.6672414541244507]]
Context 8: [['Gunnell, P. S., and Gubler, W. D. 1992. Taxonomy and morphology of Colletotrichum.', 0.5428743958473206]]
Context 9: [['Photita, W., Taylor, P. W., Ford, R., Hyde, K. D., and Lumyong, S. (2005). Morphological and molecular characterization of Colletotrichum species from...', 0.47663208842277527]]

These complexes can now be further studied to deepen our understanding of the genus beyond just species complexes. The question of whether these complexes can be divided into multiple species, a few species with many subspecies, varieties, or forms, or merely into subspecies, varieties, or forms remains a topic of debate, often influenced by personal preference rather than scientific evidence. query: How can farmers minimize the risk of anthracnose during the strawberry growing season?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Anthracnose is an important disease of strawberry caused by Colletotrichum spp., which affects foliage, runners, crowns, and fruits (Howard et al., 1992). Three primary fungal pathogens—C. acutatum sensu lato, C. gloeosporioides sensu lato, and C. fragariae—are known to cause anthracnose disease in strawberries (Freeman and Katan, 1997). The crown rot syndrome is characteristic of infections from C. gloeosporioides sensu lato and C. fragariae, while fruit rot is mainly attributed to C. acutatum sensu lato, leading to significant yield losses (Howard et al., 1992). Currently, numerous species are classified under what is now known as the C. acutatum complex, with six species—C. acutatum sensu stricto, C. fioriniae, C. godetiae, C. nymphaeae, C. salicis, and C. simmondsii—identified as associated with strawberry anthracnose worldwide (Damm et al., 2012). Among these, C. nymphaeae is the most prevalent pathogen causing strawberry anthracnose globally, including in Iran (Baroncelli et al., 2015; Karimi et al., 2017; Wang et al., 2019). Currently, no effective chemical control methods exist for managing strawberry anthracnose; available options are limited to preventive treatments applied before fruit production (Denoyes-Rothan et al., 1999). Additionally, concerns about the toxic effects of chemical fungicides on the environment and the development of resistance in fungal strains highlight the need for alternative control strategies. Consequently, utilizing resistant cultivars appears to be the most efficient and practical approach for suppressing anthracnose development. In light of recent anthracnose outbreaks in strawberry fields in the Kurdistan province of Iran (Karimi et al., 2017), and the necessity for appropriate strategies to address this issue, the aim of this study was to evaluate the resistance of several commercial strawberry cultivars to the anthracnose fruit rot caused by C. nymphaeae under in vivo and greenhouse conditions.', 0.756933331489563]]
Context 1: [['In the early 1980s, anthracnose became a significant disease affecting strawberries in the southeastern United States. In response, the USDA-ARS established a breeding program to develop anthracnose-resistant cultivars suited to the strawberry-growing regions of this area. This initiative was conducted at the Small Fruit Research Station in Poplarville, MS, and the Fruit Laboratory in Beltsville, MD, in collaboration with state experiment stations in Florida, Louisiana, and North Carolina (Galletta et al., 1997; Smith and Spiers, 1982).', 0.4524792432785034]]
Context 2: [["Anthracnose fungi can attack various parts of the strawberry plant, including crowns, petioles, leaves, fruit trusses, flowers, buds, and fruit. The fungi's ability to attack multiple plant parts, coupled with the involvement of several pathogen species, contributes to the complex nature of strawberry anthracnose. Brooks reported in 1931 that C. fragariae caused spotting and girdling of runners, and later indicated that it also caused spotting of petioles and crown rot in a summer nursery, leading to wilting and death of the plants. Researchers in Louisiana observed all these symptoms and noted that crown rot also occurred in the fruit production field.", 0.33194583654403687]]
Context 3: [['Howard CM, Albregts EE. Anthracnose. In: Compendium of Strawberry Diseases. American Phytopathological Society: Paul St, ed. Maas JL, USA; 1984. pp. 85-87.', 0.3200854957103729]]

query: What impact does soil moisture have on the spread of anthracnose?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Anthracnose spreads within a field by splashing water, and living mulches (such as wheat, rye, or ryegrass) in row middles have been shown to reduce disease spread within a field. Sublethal doses of grass-specific herbicides, such as sethoxydim, may be used to prevent excessive growth of ryegrass (Gupton, 2000). Organic mulches, such as wheat straw or pine needles, also reduce splash and result in a lower incidence of anthracnose compared to rows mulched with plastic (Madden, 1992; Smith and Spiers, 1986). Additionally, anthracnose is less severe when water is supplied to plants using drip irrigation rather than overhead irrigation (Madden, 1992; Smith and Spiers, 1986). Anthracnose crown rot was observed to be less severe in commercial fields when strawberries were grown in soils with low nitrogen fertility (Howard et al., 1992). In greenhouse studies, Smith (1987, 1989) determined that strawberries grown in soils with high levels of nitrogen, especially from ammonium sources, are more susceptible to anthracnose than plants grown in soils with lower nitrogen levels or those with high levels of calcium nitrate.', 0.6987711787223816]]

query: How does sexual reproduction vary among Colletotrichum species, and what role does it play in their evolution?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Despite significant developments over the last ten years, the taxonomy of Colletotrichum is in a state of flux. Many uncertainties exist in the systematics of fungal pathogens from this genus; depending on the taxonomic "guides," the number of species can range from 29 to over 700 (von Arx, 1957; Sutton, 1992). One of the most confusing species is C. gloeosporioides. For example, 594 species of Colletotrichum were reclassified by von Arx as synonyms of C. gloeosporioides. Identification has primarily relied on morphological characteristics of conidia, vegetative and sexual structures, as well as host specificity and cultural characteristics (von Arx, 1957). Unfortunately, conidial morphology and colony characteristics vary even within isolates. Consequently, classical methods have been supplemented with biochemical and molecular technologies to differentiate Colletotrichum species (J. W. Kronstad, ed., Fungal Pathology, 127-148. © 2000 Kluwer Academic Publishers). For a more complete discussion of this topic, see Sherriff et al. (1994).', 0.4624306261539459]]
Context 1: [['Citation: Cai, L., Hyde, K.D., Taylor, P.W.J., Weir, B.S., Waller, J., Abang, M.M., Zhang, J.Z., Yang, Y.L., Phoulivong, S., Liu, Z.Y., Prihastuti, H., Shivas, R.G., McKenzie, E.H.C., Johnston, P.R. (2009). A polyphasic approach for studying Colletotrichum. Fungal Diversity, 39: 183-204.', 0.3422275483608246]]
Context 2: [['The genus Colletotrichum is considered one of the top ten important genera of fungal pathogens globally (Dean et al., 2012). Colletotrichum is an ancient fungus that has co-evolved with flowering plants. Plant microfossils of Protocolletotrichum preserved on angiosperm leaf cuticles suggest that the diverse pathogenic strategies of Colletotrichum spp. have been established since the Late Cretaceous period (Kar et al., 2004). Different complexes within the genus may have diverged between 4.8 and 32.2 million years ago (MYA) (Bhunjun et al., 2021). The emergence of agricultural cultivation and the intensive disturbance of natural environments have further driven the diversification of Colletotrichum species. These fungi have adapted to thousands of hosts and can be found as endophytes, pathogens, and saprobes (Freeman et al., 1998; Dean et al., 2012; Hirayama et al., 2018; da Silva et al., 2020; Jayawardena et al., 2020). Currently, a total of 257 Colletotrichum species grouped into 15 complexes and 13 additional singletons have been accepted in this genus.', 0.3164958953857422]]

Context 5: [['Despite intensive research that has contributed to the understanding of the Colletotrichum genus pathogenic to strawberries, there is still a lack of an accurate inventory of these causal agents. The population and prevalence of strawberry-virulent Colletotrichum species have not been systematically investigated in major producers such as China. To address these gaps, this review aims to summarize the biodiversity of Colletotrichum species pathogenic to strawberries by examining the global discovery history. Subsequently, the prevalence of Colletotrichum species pathogenic to strawberries in China was analyzed using available data. Finally, we categorized the host range of the two predominant species responsible for strawberry crown rot. This knowledge has important applications for biosecurity risk management (e.g., proper risk estimation in strawberry seedling trade), accurate diagnosis, and anthracnose control. It further lays the groundwork for systematically managing Colletotrichum genera in agricultural ecosystems, not only for the strawberry industry.', 0.7317946553230286]]

query: Did the study demonstrate that Colletotrichum musae is the sole agent responsible for banana anthracnose, or were other fungal species involved?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['The use of a single fungal species for study can lead to cost savings compared to sequencing multiple genes. A study by Li et al. (2019) identified Colletotrichum musae as one of the species associated with mango anthracnose, suggesting that Colletotrichum species may not be host-specific to bananas as previously thought. Among the main banana-producing countries, detailed studies on anthracnose pathogens have primarily been conducted in Brazil, where five species were identified as associated with the disease. Colletotrichum musae remains the most prevalent species reported in Brazil. Information on Colletotrichum species causing banana anthracnose in India, China, the Philippines, and Ecuador is limited. The available data mostly consist of disease reports or newly recorded species, with only one or two species commonly noted.', 0.9966830611228943]]
Context 1: [['Colletotrichum musae is a major causal agent of banana anthracnose and is associated with fruit disease spots in Musa species across various countries. C. cliviicola has been linked to anthracnose in Clivia miniata and Cymbidium hookerianum in China, as well as to Phaseolus and Saccharum species in India. It has also been found as an endophyte in M. indica in Brazil.', 0.9939684867858887]]
Context 2: [['After examining type and other materials, Arx (1957a, 1957b) concluded that Gloeosporium musarum Cke. & Mass. is a synonym of Colletotrichum musae (Berk. & Curt.) Arx (Myxosporium musae Berk. & Curt.). In this paper, Colletotrichum musae is used as the name for the banana anthracnose organism. C. musae is the most host-specific of the organisms discussed and is also very consistent in morphological and cultural characteristics. The conidial measurements are similar to those of C. gloeosporioides, while the cultural traits resemble those of a cultural type of C. gloeosporioides var. minor, which appears occasionally. Arx (1957) regarded the fungus as a host-specific form of C. gloeosporioides. It is a rapid grower with a high optimum and maximum temperature, similar to this species. The host-parasite relationships of this organism in Queensland have been investigated in detail (Simmonds and Mitchell 1940; Simmonds 1941, 1963).', 0.9938200116157532]]
Context 3: [['Colletotrichum musae has long been linked to banana anthracnose worldwide [23,102–107]. Besides anthracnose, it can also cause stem-end, crown, and blossom-end rots in bananas [108]. Given its prevalence, Vieira et al. (2017) [23] proposed that this species may be host-specific to bananas; however, a comprehensive global study is necessary to confirm this hypothesis.', 0.9934186935424805]]
Context 4: [['Su, Y. Y., Noireung, P., Liu, F., Hyde, K. D., Moslem, M. A., Bahkali, A. H., Abd-Elsalam, K. A., and Cai, L. 2011. Epitypification of Colletotrichum musae, the causative agent of banana anthracnose. Mycoscience 52:376-382.', 0.9919798374176025]]
Context 5: [['Su, Y.Y., Noireung, P., Liu, F., Hyde, K.D., Moslem, M.A., Bahkali, A.H., Abd-Elsalam, K.A., & Cai, L. (2011). Epitypification of Colletotrichum musae, the causative agent of banana anthracnose. Mycoscience, 52, 376–382.', 0.991868257522583]]
Context 6: [['Su, Y.Y., Noireung, P., Liu, F., Hyde, K.D., Moslem, M.A., et al. (2011). Epitypification of Colletotrichum musae, the causative agent of banana anthracnose. Mycoscience 52: 376–382.', 0.9859603643417358]]
Context 7: [['Notes: Colletotrichum musae was originally described from North Carolina (Berkeley 1874), and the name was recently epitypified by Su et al. (2011) based on a specimen collected in Florida (ex-epitype culture CBS 116870). Su et al. (2011) cite several strains from Thailand that align with their concept of C. musae. Isolates from anthracnose symptoms on banana fruit from various parts of the world are consistent with our study. These isolates form a well-supported clade within the C. gloeosporioides species complex, show low levels of genetic differentiation, and, based on ITS sequences, align with C. musae sensu Sreenivasaprasad et al. (1996), Nirenberg et al. (2002), and Shenoy et al. (2007). The morphology in culture agrees with the description by Sutton & Waterston (1970).', 0.9651798605918884]]
Context 8: [['Jagana, D.; Hegde, Y.R.; Lella, R. Green nanoparticles: A novel approach for the management of banana anthracnose caused by Colletotrichum musae. International Journal of Current Microbiology and Applied Sciences 2017, 6, 1749–1756.', 0.9304160475730896]]
Context 9: [['A detailed examination of diverse Colletotrichum species associated with anthracnose in banana, papaya, mango, dragon fruit, guava, and avocado reveals that some of these species infect not only the fruits but also the stems and leaves. This indicates that other parts of the plants may harbor sources of inoculum for anthracnose infections in fruit crops. Several species, including C. siamense, C. asianum, C. scovillei, C. gloeosporioides, C. karstii, C. fructicola, and C. tropicale, can infect multiple hosts, demonstrating the potential for cross-infection among various types of fruit crops and other plants.', 0.8578625321388245]]

query: How are strawberry plants propagated in nurseries for large-scale farming?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Although strawberries are considered a minor crop, they provide a significant source of income for many fruit and nursery growers. In the United States, strawberries were cultivated on nearly 20,000 hectares in 1989, yielding a total production of 555,000 tons valued at $520 million. Florida ranks second only to California in the production of fresh-market strawberries. For U.S. winter production (December through March), strawberries are grown on approximately 2,400 hectares. The major cultural problems faced by the Florida strawberry industry include: 1) anthracnose diseases, 2) yearly infestations of the two-spotted spider mite (Tetranychus urticae Koch), and 3) variability in the quality of nursery transplants. Commercial fields are established annually, similar to California practices. Freshly dug transplants are sourced from nurseries in Florida or from northern states and Canada. The use of transplants from northern nurseries is crucial to avoid anthracnose disease issues and to ensure that plants have undergone sufficient natural chilling to induce floral bud initiation.', 0.37089043855667114]]
Context 1: [['Strawberry transplants are primarily produced in nurseries located in northern latitudes, such as Canada, or at higher altitudes in North Carolina and California (Brown 2003). While low temperatures may limit disease development, they do not completely eliminate the pathogen from strawberry transplants.', 0.20535895228385925]]
Context 2: [['In Korea, strawberries (Fragaria × ananassa) are favored for winter cultivation when the production of other vegetables and fruits is relatively low. In 2003, strawberries were planted on a total area of 7,503 hectares in Korea, with plastic greenhouse cultivation comprising 7,172 hectares and a total production of 205,427 tonnes for the fresh market (Anonymous, 2004). Forcing, where strawberries are transplanted into greenhouses in mid-September and induced to fruit in December (Oda, 1991), is becoming more common in Korea. June-bearing cultivars such as Maehyang, Akihime, and Nyoho, used for forcing, have proven difficult to grow due to their susceptibility to anthracnose (Nam et al., 1998; Kim & Nam, 1999). Anthracnose is one of the most damaging diseases of strawberries, causing wilting and death of transplants in the nursery field. The pathogen responsible for the disease in Korea is Colletotrichum gloeosporioides, first reported in 1992 (Kim et al., 1992).', 0.19488225877285004]]

query: How does the geographic distribution of strawberry anthracnose correlate with the distribution of strawberry farms in Zhejiang Province?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Ren HY, Jiang GH, Fang L, Zhang YC, Yang XF, Miao LX, et al. Identification and characterization of the pathogen of strawberry anthracnose in Zhejiang Province. Acta Agric Zhejiangensis. 2011; 23: 937–941. http://www.zjnyxb.cn/CN/abstract/abstract117.shtml. (in Chinese).', 0.918328046798706]]
Context 1: [['Strawberry anthracnose was first reported in China in 1990 (Hu, 1990). Shao (1992) documented the first instance of strawberry anthracnose in Shanghai, identifying the pathogen as Colletotrichum acutatum (Dai et al., 2006). Zhang et al. (2007) expanded on these findings by identifying C. gloeosporioides and C. fragariae (syn. C. theobromicola) as causal agents based on morphological characteristics. Ren et al. (2008, 2011) concluded that these three species are the main pathogens causing anthracnose in strawberries in China. Crown rot represents the most severe disease issue in many strawberry-producing regions of China (Ren et al., 2008). In the Zhejiang region, nearly 50% of seedling deaths in nurseries and over 40% yield losses in strawberry fields have been recorded (Xie et al., 2010). In 2009, the yield of greenhouse-cultivated strawberries in Donggang City, Liaoning Province, was reduced by over 10% due to crown rot (Wang, 2013). The average incidence of crown rot in greenhouses in Hubei Province was 41.7% in 2011 (Xiang et al., 2012). However, most studies conducted in China regarding this disease have primarily relied on morphological and single-gene (mainly ITS) analysis (Dai et al., 2006; Ren et al., 2008, 2011). Due to overlapping characteristics, species delimitation based solely on morphology is challenging in this genus. Employing multi-gene analysis alongside morphology can provide better resolution (Cai et al., 2009; Hyde et al., 2014). Therefore, the objective of this study was to identify the pathogens responsible for strawberry anthracnose in China using a morphological and multi-gene approach.', 0.8697200417518616]]
Context 2: [['Ren HY, Jiang GH, Fang L, Zhang YC, Yang XF, Miao LX, Wang HR. (2011). Identification and Biological Characteristics of Pathogens of Strawberry Anthracnose in Jiangsu Province. Acta Agriculturae Zhejiangensis 23, 937–941.', 0.788149356842041]]
Context 3: [['Strawberries (Fragaria ananassa), native to South America, are widely cultivated in China, with cultivation areas increasing from 90,100 ha in 1985 to 330,000 ha in 2012. China produces 35.7% of all strawberries globally, making it the largest producer (Peng and Peng 2011). Zhejiang Province ranks among the top eight strawberry-producing regions in China (Shen 2014).', 0.4396592080593109]]
Context 4: [['Shao, X. H. (1992). New disease of strawberry: Strawberry anthracnose. Acta Agriculturae Shanghai.', 0.21530058979988098]]
Context 5: [['Hu, D. Y., Qian, C., and Liu, X. F. (2014). Research progress of strawberry anthracnose. Chin. Vegetables, 1:9-14.', 0.14972184598445892]]
Context 6: [['Chandler, C. K., Legard, D. E., Dunigan, D. D., Crocker, T. E., & Sims, C. A. (2000). ‘Strawberry Festival’ strawberry. HortScience, 35, 1366-1367.', 0.14083456993103027]]
Context 7: [['Brooks, A.N. 1931. Anthracnose of strawberry caused by Colletotrichum fragariae, n. sp. Phytopathology 21: 739—744.', 0.13991345465183258]]
Context 8: [['Anthracnose is an important disease of strawberry caused by Colletotrichum spp., which affects foliage, runners, crowns, and fruits (Howard et al., 1992). Three primary fungal pathogens—C. acutatum sensu lato, C. gloeosporioides sensu lato, and C. fragariae—are known to cause anthracnose disease in strawberries (Freeman and Katan, 1997). The crown rot syndrome is characteristic of infections from C. gloeosporioides sensu lato and C. fragariae, while fruit rot is mainly attributed to C. acutatum sensu lato, leading to significant yield losses (Howard et al., 1992). Currently, numerous species are classified under what is now known as the C. acutatum complex, with six species—C. acutatum sensu stricto, C. fioriniae, C. godetiae, C. nymphaeae, C. salicis, and C. simmondsii—identified as associated with strawberry anthracnose worldwide (Damm et al., 2012). Among these, C. nymphaeae is the most prevalent pathogen causing strawberry anthracnose globally, including in Iran (Baroncelli et al., 2015; Karimi et al., 2017; Wang et al., 2019). Currently, no effective chemical control methods exist for managing strawberry anthracnose; available options are limited to preventive treatments applied before fruit production (Denoyes-Rothan et al., 1999). Additionally, concerns about the toxic effects of chemical fungicides on the environment and the development of resistance in fungal strains highlight the need for alternative control strategies. Consequently, utilizing resistant cultivars appears to be the most efficient and practical approach for suppressing anthracnose development. In light of recent anthracnose outbreaks in strawberry fields in the Kurdistan province of Iran (Karimi et al., 2017), and the necessity for appropriate strategies to address this issue, the aim of this study was to evaluate the resistance of several commercial strawberry cultivars to the anthracnose fruit rot caused by C. nymphaeae under in vivo and greenhouse conditions.', 0.139682799577713]]
Context 9: [['Howard CM, Albregts EE. Anthracnose. In: Compendium of Strawberry Diseases. American Phytopathological Society: Paul St, ed. Maas JL, USA; 1984. pp. 85-87.', 0.1356687992811203]]

query: What are the implications of climate change on the future of strawberry cultivation?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Strawberries (Fragaria×ananassa Duch.) are a widely cultivated hybrid species within the Rosaceae family, renowned for their fruit. They are increasingly significant for the agricultural economic development of countries like Iran, particularly in the Kurdistan province, which leads in strawberry production, predominantly under open-field conditions (Tehranifar and Sarsaefi, 2002). Various biotic and abiotic factors contribute to the decline in strawberry production globally. Notably, over 100 fungal species can invade strawberry plants, with approximately one-third causing serious diseases on different plant parts (Martin and others).', 0.20495301485061646]]
Context 1: [['Strawberry (Fragaria ananassa Duch.) is a popular small fruit crop known for its high economic and nutritive value, and it is in high demand globally. From 2008 to 2018, the annual worldwide cultivation of strawberries increased from approximately 400 to 483 thousand hectares. Although strawberries are native to temperate regions, they can also be grown in tropical and subtropical regions, sometimes under high-altitude conditions. The land areas devoted to strawberry cultivation in Colombia, Peru, Guatemala, Bolivia, and Taiwan in 2018 were 1,482 ha, 1,453 ha, 690 ha, 522 ha, and 506 ha, respectively.', 0.19065727293491364]]
Context 2: [['Strawberry (Fragaria × ananassa) is a major crop cultivated in China (Xie et al. 2010). The production of strawberries has rapidly expanded in recent years, positioning China as one of the world’s largest producers and exporters. As of 2013, strawberry cultivation covered 100.5 × 10^3 hectares, yielding 2.8 million tonnes (The Ministry of Agriculture of the People’s Republic of China 2014). However, with increased production, many fungal diseases have emerged as significant challenges, negatively impacting fruit yield and quality (Mass 1998, Smith 2008). Among these, anthracnose, caused by species of Colletotrichum, is one of the most critical diseases affecting strawberries.', 0.1691794991493225]]
Context 3: [['Chandler, C.K., Albregts, E.E., Brecht, J.K., and Howard, C.M. 1997. ‘Sweet Charlie’ Strawberry. HortScience, 32: 1132-1133.', 0.16678090393543243]]

Context 6: [['Strawberries, perhaps the most delectable of fruits, are grown for their attractiveness and exquisite flavor in most temperate and many tropical areas of the world. Some believe the world would indeed be a dull place without strawberries to excite the taste buds and enliven desserts and pastries. Strawberry cultivation can be traced back thousands of years, with origins in Europe well documented in literature and art. Fragaria vesca L. (diploid, 2n=14 chromosomes) and F. moschata (hexaploid, 2n=42 chromosomes) were cultivated in palace and church gardens. Strawberry culture in the New World, particularly in North and South America, is less well documented. North American natives appreciated the springtime appearance of F. virginiana Duchesne (octaploid, 2n=56 chromosomes) fruit, although this species was likely not cultivated until Europeans began exploring and settling in North America. However, native inhabitants of Chile and Peru had selected and cultivated superior variants of F. chiloensis (L.) Quebe- sene (octaploid, 2n=56 chromosomes) well before the arrival of conquistadors in the 16th century.', 0.1533598154783249]]
