query: Can resistant varieties completely prevent anthracnose?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Until highly resistant cultivars are available, growers must rely on chemical applications and cultural practices to reduce losses due to anthracnose. The failure of fungicides to control anthracnose epidemics may be due to the development of fungicide resistance in the Colletotrichum spp. population. For example, benomyl effectively reduced the incidence of anthracnose crown rot (Horn et al., 1972; Howard, 1971) and was used intensively by strawberry growers for years to control anthracnose and other diseases. However, the anthracnose pathogens, C. acutatum and C. fragariae, developed resistance to it and other benzimidazole fungicides (LaMondia, 1995; McInnes et al., 1992a; Smith and Black, 1992, 1993), rendering benomyl ineffective for anthracnose control in strawberry fields.', 0.7079340815544128]]
Context 1: [['Two cultivars with different resistance levels to anthracnose were compared: (a) cv. Campinas IAC 2712 (susceptible) and (b) cv. Dover (partially resistant). Although ‘Dover’ is reported to be resistant to Colletotrichum acutatum (Howard et al. 1992; Denoyes-Rothan et al. 1999), the resistance is not complete, and significant losses due to anthracnose have been noted in Brasília for this genotype (Furlanetto et al. 1996). The incidence of flower blight and diseased fruits (%) was recorded weekly at 23, 29, 37, and 44 days after infection (DAI). AUDPCs were calculated as previously described.', 0.697716236114502]]
Context 2: [['Until highly resistant cultivars are available, growers must rely on chemical applications and cultural practices to reduce losses due to anthracnose. The failure of fungicides to control anthracnose epidemics may be attributed to the development of fungicide resistance in the Colletotrichum species population. For example, benomyl was shown to effectively reduce the incidence of anthracnose crown rot (Horn et al., 1972; Howard, 1971) and was used intensively by strawberry growers for years to control anthracnose and other diseases. However, the anthracnose pathogens, C. acutatum and C. fragariae, developed resistance to it and other benzimidazole fungicides (LaMondia, 1995; McInnes et al., 1992a; Smith and Black, 1992, 1993), leading to the ineffectiveness of benomyl for anthracnose control in strawberry fields.', 0.6601905226707458]]
Context 3: [['As our understanding of the anthracnose pathogens and the epidemiology of anthracnose diseases has improved, so has our capacity to control these diseases. Changes in cultural practices have led to reduced levels of disease. Additionally, the development and registration of more effective fungicides for use on strawberries have significantly decreased losses due to anthracnose crown rot and fruit rot. The introduction of partially resistant cultivars has also helped mitigate economic losses due to these diseases. Nonetheless, growers may still experience severe losses when environmental conditions are highly conducive to anthracnose development.', 0.6028944253921509]]
Context 4: [['As our knowledge of the anthracnose pathogens and the epidemiology of anthracnose diseases has increased, so has our ability to control these diseases. Changes in cultural practices have resulted in reduced levels of disease. Additionally, the development and registration of more effective fungicides for use on strawberries have significantly reduced losses from both anthracnose crown rot and fruit rot. Anthracnose-resistant cultivars have also diminished economic losses due to these diseases. Nevertheless, growers may still experience severe losses when environmental factors are highly favorable for anthracnose development.', 0.5187634825706482]]
Context 5: [['Increased losses due to anthracnose fruit and crown rots may be related to the shift from matted-row culture to the annual plasticulture production system in the United States. Breeding for genetic resistance to anthracnose and the development of resistant cultivars are primary means for reducing economic losses due to this disease. This approach is environmentally sound because it results in reduced fungicide use. As our knowledge of the anthracnose pathogens and the epidemiology of anthracnose diseases has increased, so has our ability to control these diseases. Changes in cultural practices have resulted in reduced levels of disease. Simultaneously, the development of more effective fungicides and their registration for use on strawberries have significantly reduced losses due to both anthracnose crown rot and fruit rot. Anthracnose-resistant cultivars have also decreased economic losses caused by these diseases. Nevertheless, growers may still face severe losses when environmental conditions are highly favorable for anthracnose development.', 0.46474990248680115]]
Context 6: [['Ye Z, Zheng H, Tong Y, Noguchi Y, Sugiyama K, Sakata Y, et al. Anthracnose pathogen in Shanghai suburbs and resistance of some strawberry varieties.', 0.4310068190097809]]
Context 7: [['Leaves, flowers, and both green and ripe fruit can be highly susceptible to anthracnose, which can lead to the complete loss of fruit in some cases. In central Brazil, a recent epidemic of anthracnose caused significant yield losses, ranging from 30% to 68%. During May to September in 1995 and 1996, severe outbreaks of strawberry anthracnose were reported in many strawberry nurseries in Israel. Following transplantation, entire beds of strawberry plants collapsed due to crown rot. The causal agent was identified as Colletotrichum acutatum. Recently, various molecular techniques have been utilized to accurately and reliably identify the species of Colletotrichum responsible for strawberry anthracnose. The polymerase chain reaction (PCR) method confirmed that over 100 Israeli isolates belong to the species C. acutatum.', 0.23109367489814758]]

query: How does conidial morphology vary among Colletotrichum species, and why is this significant?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Despite significant developments over the last ten years, the taxonomy of Colletotrichum is in a state of flux. Many uncertainties exist in the systematics of fungal pathogens from this genus; depending on the taxonomic "guides," the number of species can range from 29 to over 700 (von Arx, 1957; Sutton, 1992). One of the most confusing species is C. gloeosporioides. For example, 594 species of Colletotrichum were reclassified by von Arx as synonyms of C. gloeosporioides. Identification has primarily relied on morphological characteristics of conidia, vegetative and sexual structures, as well as host specificity and cultural characteristics (von Arx, 1957). Unfortunately, conidial morphology and colony characteristics vary even within isolates. Consequently, classical methods have been supplemented with biochemical and molecular technologies to differentiate Colletotrichum species (J. W. Kronstad, ed., Fungal Pathology, 127-148. © 2000 Kluwer Academic Publishers). For a more complete discussion of this topic, see Sherriff et al. (1994).', 0.9931051135063171]]
Context 1: [['Identification and characterization of Colletotrichum species typically rely on morphological characteristics (Hyde et al. 2009; Photita et al. 2005), including conidial morphology, production of perithecia (Freeman et al. 2000), and sensitivity to benomyl (Valero et al. 2010). However, morphological differences alone are insufficient to distinguish between Colletotrichum species due to inherent variations.', 0.9926345944404602]]
Context 2: [['Available morphological characters of Colletotrichum species include: 1) characters on natural substrates, such as size and shape of conidiomata (acervuli), conidia, conidiophores, and setae; 2) size and shape of conidia, conidiophores, and setae in culture; and 3) size and shape of appressoria. Acervuli, setae, and conidial characters (shape and dimensions) on natural substrates can vary due to environmental factors, and conidia may be absent from infected host tissues. Some Colletotrichum species, such as C. musae and C. gossypii, consistently fail to produce setae in conidiomata (Sutton and Waterston, 1970), and their presence on natural hosts is often inconsistent for species diagnosis (von Arx, 1957; Sutton, 1966). Morphological characters may vary with environmental factors, and incubation conditions, such as media and temperature, should be standardized (Cannon et al., 2000) for species comparison and identification. Unfortunately, there is no recommended standard for...', 0.9881889820098877]]
Context 3: [['Cultural characteristics on agar media have been applied for the diagnosis of some Colletotrichum species (von Arx, 1957). The conidial morphology of C. gloeosporioides and C. lindemuthianum is similar, but their cultural characters are distinctly different. Colletotrichum lindemuthianum produces dark pigmentation in media and grows consistently slower than C. gloeosporioides (Baxter et al., 1983; Sutton, 1992). Likewise, C. musae grows relatively fast, forming effuse colonies and glabrous conidiomata with many conidia, while C. destructivum forms large conidiogenous zones with scattered, relatively short setae and has limited conidial production (Baxter et al., 1983). The shape and size of conidia and appressoria, as well as cultural characteristics, should be evaluated and used with caution, as these traits are highly dependent on growth conditions. Erroneous diagnosis can largely be avoided if morphology is used in conjunction with other characters such as molecular sequence data, biochemical and physiological characteristics, and host range. Crouch et al. (2009b) demonstrated that falcate-spored, grass-associated Colletotrichum species could be distinguished by a combination of molecular data, appressorial morphology, and host range. However, for most Colletotrichum species, host range has not been determined, and available information should be considered with caution, as it is often based on wrongly identified species (Damm et al., 2009).', 0.9867551922798157]]
Context 4: [['Observations and measurements of conidial size and shape have usually been made using conidial masses mounted in water, cotton blue, or lactic acid (Cannon et al., 2008). It should be noted that many species of Colletotrichum produce secondary conidia in culture directly from germinated primary conidia; these may vary morphologically when compared to those produced in conidiomata (Cannon et al., 2000). Conidial and mycelial appressoria (also referred to as hyphopodia) are often described in Colletotrichum species. Sutton (1980) characterized the mycelial appressoria formed in potato-carrot agar (PCA) using a slide culture technique, while others have used potato dextrose agar (PDA) with incubation in the dark (Johnston and Jones, 1997; Malloch, 1981) or have observed mycelial appressoria formed on the undersurface of SNA cultures (Damm et al., 2009). Conidial appressoria have been recorded when conidia are germinated in drops of deionized water on plastic cover slips in a moist chamber (Johnson et al., 1997; Chaky et al., 2001). Conidial appressoria are taxonomically uninformative and of little use for species diagnosis (Sutton, 1980, 1992). However, Du et al. (2005) noted that the shape of appressoria can differentiate C. acutatum (with rather smooth appressoria) from C. gloeosporioides (with more lobed appressoria). Crouch et al. (2009b) found that appressoria shape and size are useful for delimiting grass-associated Colletotrichum species but should be used in combination with host range. Yang et al. (2009) found that conidial appressoria can distinguish two species of Colletotrichum from Amaryllidaceae. The conidial appressoria of C. hippeastri are larger than those of C. hymenocallidis and are irregular, crenate, or lobed, occasionally becoming complex. In contrast, C. hymenocallidis appressoria are ovate or sometimes clavate.', 0.9866356253623962]]
Context 5: [['Traditionally, Colletotrichum species have been identified based on morphological characteristics. Taxonomists have utilized several features, including the size and shape of conidia and appressoria, the presence or absence of setae, sclerotia, acervuli, and teleomorph states, as well as cultural characters such as colony color, growth rate, and texture (Simmonds, 1965; Smith and Black, 1990; Sutton, 1992; TeBeest et al., 1997; Photita et al., 2005; Than et al., 2008a-c; Thaung, 2008). However, these criteria alone are not always sufficient for reliable differentiation among Colletotrichum species due to variations in morphology and phenotype influenced by environmental factors.', 0.9863225221633911]]
Context 6: [['Corresponding to the taxonomic classification determined by multi-locus phylogenetic analyses, most Colletotrichum species exhibited characteristic morphological features, including colony colors, the density of aerial mycelium, and the shapes and sizes of conidia, ascospores, appressoria, and setae (Fig. 7–18). These morphological characteristics have been used in previous studies to delimit species (Damm et al. 2012a, b, 2014; Liu et al. 2013a, 2015; Hou et al. 2016; Guarnaccia et al. 2017). Notably, the Colletotrichum species associated with pear anthracnose produced pigments that varied in color among species and isolates. Additionally, these species differed in their ability to form a sexual morph in culture.', 0.9809482097625732]]
Context 7: [['Traditional identification systems in Colletotrichum have heavily relied on morphological and cultural characteristics (von Arx, 1957; Sutton, 1980, 1992; Bailey and Jeger, 1992; Freeman et al., 1998). Sutton (1992) noted that morphology alone does not provide sufficient information for precise identification, especially for species within the C. gloeosporioides and C. dematium complexes. Crouch et al. (2009b) argued that conidial size and shape, along with conidial appressoria, were taxonomically uninformative and of limited use for species diagnosis in graminicolous Colletotrichum species. Species with similar morphological characteristics may exhibit considerable variation at the physiological and pathogenic levels, making this recognition crucial for biosecurity, plant breeding, and integrated disease management. Taxonomy based solely on morphology is likely to result in ambiguity. Recent studies have shown that morphological characters should be used in conjunction with other characters to establish species relationships within Colletotrichum (Crouch et al., 2009b; Prihastuti et al., 2009).', 0.9792885184288025]]
Context 8: [['Morphological observations: The colonies of the Colletotrichum isolates were initially white, later turning pale gray, with sparse aerial mycelium that was hairy and sometimes produced abundant orange (hex code #FF8040) piochnotes (Fig. 2). There was high variation in mycelial growth rates among the 128 Colletotrichum isolates (Supplementary Table S3), with averages of 0.38 to 1.59 cm/day for C. asianum, 0.52 to 1.51 cm/day for C. siamense, and 0.60 to 1.19 cm/day for C. fructicola. Conidia were all hyaline, aseptate, and ranged from long elliptic to cylindrical. The average conidial sizes (as detailed in Supplementary Table S3) varied among species. For isolates grown on PDA, the length of conidia for each isolate varied, with notable variations across species.', 0.9712166786193848]]
Context 9: [['This table details various Colletotrichum species and their characteristics associated with the Amaryllidaceae family. It includes information on species names, isolate numbers, mycelial appressoria shape and size, conidial appressoria shape and size, colony characteristics, and mycelial growth rates (in mm per day). For instance, C. boninense shows cylindrical shapes with a mean size of 16.3 ± 1.2 × 6.6 ± 0.7 µm, while C. hippeastri exhibits irregular, sepia to dark brown appressoria measuring 10.5-14.5 × 6-11 µm. The colony characteristics vary significantly among the species, ranging from white aerial mycelia to dark brown or grey shades. The growth rates also differ, with some species exhibiting rapid growth compared to others.', 0.9517667889595032]]

query: How might clade-based approaches be applied to other fungal genera besides Colletotrichum?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Discussion: Recent phylogenetic studies of the genus Colletotrichum have revealed clustering in 11 major clades, including significant species complexes such as C. acutatum, C. boninense, C. gloeosporioides, and C. truncatum. These studies facilitate the differentiation and description of numerous taxa.', 0.5434976816177368]]
Context 1: [['Colletotrichum species are categorized into phylogenetic clades (also referred to as species complexes) based on multilocus molecular analysis. Species within a clade are closely related and share similar temperature requirements (Cannon et al., 2012; Vieira et al., 2020; Talhinhas and Baroncelli, 2021; Salotti et al., 2022). A recent systematic review identified 15 major clades of the genus, along with several smaller clusters and isolated species (Talhinhas and Baroncelli, 2021). Detailed descriptions of these major phylogenetic clades and the species within them have been provided by multiple studies (Cannon et al., 2012; Vieira et al., 2020; Talhinhas and Baroncelli, 2021; Damm et al., 2009, 2012, 2013, 2014; Weir et al., 2012).', 0.5218063592910767]]
Context 2: [['Phylogenetic analyses using molecular markers have revealed that many members of the genus Colletotrichum can be grouped into independent lineages with similar evolutionary histories (Cai et al. 2011). Several of these lineages have now been systematically classified as species complexes comprising closely related sibling species (Weir et al. 2012). Many species within the C. gloeosporioides species complex have previously been classified as C. gloeosporioides sensu lato, largely based on morphological characteristics and known host range (Hyde et al. 2009). Additionally, the study by Weir et al. (2012) showed that ITS sequences, which have long been used to classify fungal species, are not very reliable in distinguishing different species within this species complex. However, different species do not require the same level of control when encountered in the field (Prihastuti et al. 2009).', 0.5029429197311401]]
Context 3: [['A new approach to Colletotrichum systematics that utilizes metabolite profiling—bringing functional characters to the forefront—may enhance our understanding of species relationships within this genus. However, accurate identification of a species and its strains using ITS and other sequence data is essential before such studies can proceed. Research in chemotaxonomy in Colletotrichum is still in its early stages, and specific recommendations are not provided here.', 0.38324958086013794]]
Context 4: [['Weir, B. S., & Johnston, P. R. (2011). Towards a secondary fungal barcode for Colletotrichum [Sordariomycetes, Ascomycota]. Fourth International Barcode of Life Conference, Adelaide, Australia, 28 November – 3 December 2011.', 0.3750447928905487]]

query: How does anthracnose in strawberries compare to crown rot in asparagus in terms of disease progression and management strategies?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Anthracnose is an important disease of strawberry caused by Colletotrichum spp., which affects foliage, runners, crowns, and fruits (Howard et al., 1992). Three primary fungal pathogens—C. acutatum sensu lato, C. gloeosporioides sensu lato, and C. fragariae—are known to cause anthracnose disease in strawberries (Freeman and Katan, 1997). The crown rot syndrome is characteristic of infections from C. gloeosporioides sensu lato and C. fragariae, while fruit rot is mainly attributed to C. acutatum sensu lato, leading to significant yield losses (Howard et al., 1992). Currently, numerous species are classified under what is now known as the C. acutatum complex, with six species—C. acutatum sensu stricto, C. fioriniae, C. godetiae, C. nymphaeae, C. salicis, and C. simmondsii—identified as associated with strawberry anthracnose worldwide (Damm et al., 2012). Among these, C. nymphaeae is the most prevalent pathogen causing strawberry anthracnose globally, including in Iran (Baroncelli et al., 2015; Karimi et al., 2017; Wang et al., 2019). Currently, no effective chemical control methods exist for managing strawberry anthracnose; available options are limited to preventive treatments applied before fruit production (Denoyes-Rothan et al., 1999). Additionally, concerns about the toxic effects of chemical fungicides on the environment and the development of resistance in fungal strains highlight the need for alternative control strategies. Consequently, utilizing resistant cultivars appears to be the most efficient and practical approach for suppressing anthracnose development. In light of recent anthracnose outbreaks in strawberry fields in the Kurdistan province of Iran (Karimi et al., 2017), and the necessity for appropriate strategies to address this issue, the aim of this study was to evaluate the resistance of several commercial strawberry cultivars to the anthracnose fruit rot caused by C. nymphaeae under in vivo and greenhouse conditions.', 0.938086211681366]]
Context 1: [['From 2010 to 2016, we conducted surveys of anthracnose in strawberries in Miaoli County. More than 50% of diseased plants exhibited symptoms characteristic of anthracnose crown rot (ACR), as described by McInnes et al. (1992). ACR resulted in plant losses of up to 30-40% during the seedling stage and around 20% after transplanting. Initial symptoms in crown tissue included a marbled red and white appearance, which progressed to brown rot and eventual rapid wilting of the plant. Anthracnose symptoms also appeared on other parts of the plant, including leaves, petioles, runners, fruits, and roots. These symptoms manifested as circular black spots on leaves, withering and girdling on runners.', 0.8446313142776489]]
Context 2: [['Anthracnose crown rot, to which all currently cultivated strawberry (Fragaria ananassa Duch.) varieties are susceptible, represents a major disease affecting over 30% of nurseries and the post-transplanting stage in Korea (Nam et al., 2009). The causal pathogen, Colletotrichum gloeosporioides, was first reported by Kim et al. (1992).', 0.6948280930519104]]
Context 3: [['Smith, B. J. (1998). Anthracnose crown rot. In J. L. Maas (Ed.), Compendium of Strawberry Diseases (2nd ed., pp. 24-25). The American Phytopathological Society, St. Paul, MN.', 0.5747619867324829]]
Context 4: [['Smith, B.J. (1998a). Anthracnose crown rot. In J.L. Maas (Ed.), Compendium of Strawberry Diseases (2nd ed., pp. 46–48). American Phytopathological Society, St. Paul, MN.', 0.5663919448852539]]
Context 5: [['Introduction: The spread of strawberry anthracnose can be exacerbated by the use of infected runner plantlets (Hirayama et al. 2010). Effective management strategies must consider these factors to mitigate disease outbreaks.', 0.515062689781189]]
Context 6: [['Species of the fungal plant pathogen Colletotrichum are responsible for strawberry (Fragaria × ananassa Duch.) anthracnose, one of the major diseases affecting this crop. Major species that cause strawberry anthracnose include C. acutatum J.H. Simmons, C. fragariae Brooks, and C. gloeosporioides (Penz.) Penz. & Sacc. Symptoms of the disease manifest in various phases. Infection of mother plants with anthracnose may result in the collapse of the entire plant due to crown rot. In the nursery, lesions form on stolons that eventually girdle the runners, leading to wilting and death of unrooted daughter plants distal to the lesion. Death of daughter plants in the nursery and in field transplants can also be caused by crown rot. Infected transplants are capable of spreading the disease from the nursery to the field, and entire crops can be destroyed by anthracnose in strawberry fruit production fields under conducive environmental conditions.', 0.4849592447280884]]
Context 7: [['Smith, B.J. (1998a). Anthracnose crown rot, pp. 46–48. In J.L. Maas (Ed.), Compendium of strawberry diseases (2nd ed.). American Phytopathological Society, St. Paul, MN.', 0.4842078685760498]]
Context 8: [['Smith, B. J. 1998. Anthracnose crown rot. Pages 46-48 in: Compendium of Strawberry Diseases, 2nd ed. J. L. Maas, ed. The American Phytopathological Society, St. Paul, MN.', 0.46376824378967285]]

query: How does the strawberry production industry contribute to local economies in agricultural regions?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Strawberries (Fragaria×ananassa Duch.) are a widely cultivated hybrid species within the Rosaceae family, renowned for their fruit. They are increasingly significant for the agricultural economic development of countries like Iran, particularly in the Kurdistan province, which leads in strawberry production, predominantly under open-field conditions (Tehranifar and Sarsaefi, 2002). Various biotic and abiotic factors contribute to the decline in strawberry production globally. Notably, over 100 fungal species can invade strawberry plants, with approximately one-third causing serious diseases on different plant parts (Martin and others).', 0.8652880191802979]]
Context 1: [['Although strawberries are considered a minor crop, they provide a significant source of income for many fruit and nursery growers. In the United States, strawberries were cultivated on nearly 20,000 hectares in 1989, yielding a total production of 555,000 tons valued at $520 million. Florida ranks second only to California in the production of fresh-market strawberries. For U.S. winter production (December through March), strawberries are grown on approximately 2,400 hectares. The major cultural problems faced by the Florida strawberry industry include: 1) anthracnose diseases, 2) yearly infestations of the two-spotted spider mite (Tetranychus urticae Koch), and 3) variability in the quality of nursery transplants. Commercial fields are established annually, similar to California practices. Freshly dug transplants are sourced from nurseries in Florida or from northern states and Canada. The use of transplants from northern nurseries is crucial to avoid anthracnose disease issues and to ensure that plants have undergone sufficient natural chilling to induce floral bud initiation.', 0.240522563457489]]
Context 2: [['Strawberry (Fragaria ananassa Duch.) is a popular small fruit crop known for its high economic and nutritive value, and it is in high demand globally. From 2008 to 2018, the annual worldwide cultivation of strawberries increased from approximately 400 to 483 thousand hectares. Although strawberries are native to temperate regions, they can also be grown in tropical and subtropical regions, sometimes under high-altitude conditions. The land areas devoted to strawberry cultivation in Colombia, Peru, Guatemala, Bolivia, and Taiwan in 2018 were 1,482 ha, 1,453 ha, 690 ha, 522 ha, and 506 ha, respectively.', 0.22177718579769135]]

query: Why is a multi-gene approach more reliable for Colletotrichum systematics?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Colletotrichum systematics should utilize a multiple-gene phylogeny alongside a study of type specimens to establish correlations between genotype and phenotype. The phenotype should be broadened to encompass a polyphasic approach, including morphology, physiology, pathogenicity, infection processes, cultural characteristics, and secondary metabolites (Frisvad, 2004; Samson and Varga, 2007). The genotypes within Colletotrichum appear to correlate with a combination of traits rather than a single characteristic. These criteria are clearly demonstrated by Crouch et al. (2009b), Damm et al. (2009), and Prihastuti et al. (2009). Crouch et al. (2009b) correlated well-defined phylogenetic groupings with a combination of appressoria and host ranges. Prihastuti et al. (2009) established new taxa within the C. gloeosporioides complex that form distinct phylogenetic lineages with unique morphological, cultural, and physiological characteristics.', 0.9970099925994873]]
Context 1: [['A polyphasic approach combining multilocus phylogenetic analysis with recognizable phenotypic characteristics is recommended for accurate species identification within the Colletotrichum genus. According to Weir et al., internal transcribed spacer (ITS) sequences alone are not reliable for distinguishing different species within the C. gloeosporioides species complex. Additional loci recommended for identifying Colletotrichum species include actin (ACT), calmodulin (CAL), chitin synthase-1 (CHS-1), glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate dehydrogenase (GAPDH), and β-tubulin (TUB2).', 0.9953225255012512]]
Context 2: [['A similar set of six genes (ITS, ACT, CHS, GPDH, histone 3, and beta-tubulin) was used by Damm et al. (2009) to study Colletotrichum species with curved conidia from herbaceous hosts, which included six different clades. The best separability of the species was observed using both GPDH and histone 3 genes, which were superior to ITS, ACT, CHS, and beta-tubulin. The most appropriate gene for barcoding Colletotrichum must be selected during the species delimitation process since we can only choose one or more barcoding genes when we know which taxa need to be distinguished. A good approach would be to test and establish a selection of loci used by different groups involved in Colletotrichum systematics to work towards identifying the best barcoding gene.', 0.9922025203704834]]
Context 3: [['A new approach to Colletotrichum systematics that utilizes metabolite profiling—bringing functional characters to the forefront—may enhance our understanding of species relationships within this genus. However, accurate identification of a species and its strains using ITS and other sequence data is essential before such studies can proceed. Research in chemotaxonomy in Colletotrichum is still in its early stages, and specific recommendations are not provided here.', 0.9808411002159119]]
Context 4: [['Disentangling species complexes within the Colletotrichum genus presents a significant challenge for taxonomists. Given the global importance of this genus, primarily consisting of plant pathogens, it is critical to accurately identify species and/or pathotypes to enhance biosecurity and disease control efforts. Traditional methods of species identification have relied on morphological, cultural, and host-preference criteria. However, these methods often prove unreliable, leading to unresolved taxonomic issues. As stated by Sutton (1992), relying solely on morphology is insufficient for improving the systematics of species complexes like C. gloeosporioides.', 0.974801242351532]]
Context 5: [['The identification of Colletotrichum species has long been challenging due to limited morphological characteristics. Single-gene phylogenetic analyses have also proven unsuccessful in clearly delineating species, partly due to the high number of erroneous names in GenBank. This paper reviews the taxonomic problems associated with Colletotrichum and the difficulties in identifying taxa at the species level. We advocate for epitypification and the use of multi-locus phylogenetic methods to better delimit species and understand the genus.', 0.9707285165786743]]
Context 6: [['One of the problems with accurately identifying Colletotrichum species using multigene analysis or barcoding is that many existing sequences in GenBank are incorrectly named. Crouch et al. (2009) revealed a high frequency of misidentification (86%) based on rDNA-ITS sequence similarity comparisons in GenBank within the C. graminicola species complex. Cai et al. (2009) analyzed 343 rDNA-ITS sequences of C. gloeosporioides in GenBank (accessed September 6, 2009) and found that an astounding 86% of these sequences showed considerable evolutionary divergence from the epitype of C. gloeosporioides, most likely representing other species. These error rates are remarkably high and indicate that accurate identification of Colletotrichum species using rDNA-ITS sequence data currently available in GenBank is impossible.', 0.9655888080596924]]

query: How does the anthracnose pathogen survive between strawberry growing seasons?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Anthracnose is an important disease of strawberry caused by Colletotrichum spp., which affects foliage, runners, crowns, and fruits (Howard et al., 1992). Three primary fungal pathogens—C. acutatum sensu lato, C. gloeosporioides sensu lato, and C. fragariae—are known to cause anthracnose disease in strawberries (Freeman and Katan, 1997). The crown rot syndrome is characteristic of infections from C. gloeosporioides sensu lato and C. fragariae, while fruit rot is mainly attributed to C. acutatum sensu lato, leading to significant yield losses (Howard et al., 1992). Currently, numerous species are classified under what is now known as the C. acutatum complex, with six species—C. acutatum sensu stricto, C. fioriniae, C. godetiae, C. nymphaeae, C. salicis, and C. simmondsii—identified as associated with strawberry anthracnose worldwide (Damm et al., 2012). Among these, C. nymphaeae is the most prevalent pathogen causing strawberry anthracnose globally, including in Iran (Baroncelli et al., 2015; Karimi et al., 2017; Wang et al., 2019). Currently, no effective chemical control methods exist for managing strawberry anthracnose; available options are limited to preventive treatments applied before fruit production (Denoyes-Rothan et al., 1999). Additionally, concerns about the toxic effects of chemical fungicides on the environment and the development of resistance in fungal strains highlight the need for alternative control strategies. Consequently, utilizing resistant cultivars appears to be the most efficient and practical approach for suppressing anthracnose development. In light of recent anthracnose outbreaks in strawberry fields in the Kurdistan province of Iran (Karimi et al., 2017), and the necessity for appropriate strategies to address this issue, the aim of this study was to evaluate the resistance of several commercial strawberry cultivars to the anthracnose fruit rot caused by C. nymphaeae under in vivo and greenhouse conditions.', 0.8416844606399536]]
Context 1: [["Anthracnose fungi can attack various parts of the strawberry plant, including crowns, petioles, leaves, fruit trusses, flowers, buds, and fruit. The fungi's ability to attack multiple plant parts, coupled with the involvement of several pathogen species, contributes to the complex nature of strawberry anthracnose. Brooks reported in 1931 that C. fragariae caused spotting and girdling of runners, and later indicated that it also caused spotting of petioles and crown rot in a summer nursery, leading to wilting and death of the plants. Researchers in Louisiana observed all these symptoms and noted that crown rot also occurred in the fruit production field.", 0.8329395055770874]]
Context 2: [['From May to September 1995, a severe outbreak of strawberry anthracnose was observed in several strawberry-growing nurseries in Israel. Following transplantation to production fields during September and October, entire beds of strawberry plants collapsed. Typical anthracnose symptoms observed from November 1995 to June 1996 included crown rot, flower blight, and green and ripe fruit rot. This marked the first record of strawberry anthracnose in Israel. Furthermore, in at least four production fields in the same region, hundreds of plants developed symptoms of stunting and chlorosis, which are atypical of strawberry anthracnose. When these plants were uprooted, most of their roots were dark brown and decayed. Colletotrichum was readily isolated from these samples.', 0.3892863690853119]]
Context 3: [['Howard CM, Albregts EE. Anthracnose. In: Compendium of Strawberry Diseases. American Phytopathological Society: Paul St, ed. Maas JL, USA; 1984. pp. 85-87.', 0.37450507283210754]]
Context 4: [['Numerous reports indicate that strawberry anthracnose pathogens may originate from weed species. For instance, C. fragariae was found attacking the weed Cassia obtusifolia L. (sicklepod, coffeweed) in Florida, causing typical disease symptoms. Inoculation of strawberry with the Cassia isolates resulted in typical anthracnose symptoms, while isolates from strawberry were equally virulent on Cassia. Similarly, inoculation of Duchesnea indica (Andr.) Focke (wild strawberry), F. virginiana Duch. (Virginia wild strawberry), and Potentilla canadensis L. with C. fragariae induced anthracnose disease on these hosts, suggesting that strawberry anthracnose pathogens have a broad host range.', 0.3535884618759155]]
Context 5: [['Brooks, A.N. 1931. Anthracnose of strawberry caused by Colletotrichum fragariae, n. sp. Phytopathology 21: 739—744.', 0.34197041392326355]]

Context 1: [['Strawberry (Fragaria ananassa Duch.) is a popular small fruit crop known for its high economic and nutritive value, and it is in high demand globally. Context 8: [['Although strawberries are considered a minor crop, they provide a significant source of income for many fruit and nursery growers. In the United States, strawberries were cultivated on nearly 20,000 hectares in 1989, yielding a total production of 555,000 tons valued at $520 million. Florida ranks second only to California in the production of fresh-market strawberries. For U.S. winter production (December through March), strawberries are grown on approximately 2,400 hectares. The major cultural problems faced by the Florida strawberry industry include: 1) anthracnose diseases, 2) yearly infestations of the two-spotted spider mite (Tetranychus urticae Koch), and 3) variability in the quality of nursery transplants. Commercial fields are established annually, similar to California practices. Freshly dug transplants are sourced from nurseries in Florida or from northern states and Canada. The use of transplants from northern nurseries is crucial to avoid anthracnose disease issues and to ensure that plants have undergone sufficient natural chilling to induce floral bud initiation.', 0.19523309171199799]]

query: How do fungal populations evolve in response to fungicide application?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Past failures of fungicides to control anthracnose epidemics may have stemmed from the development of resistance in the Colletotrichum population. In the early 1970s, benomyl effectively reduced anthracnose crown rot incidence (Horn et al., 1972; Howard, 1971) and was widely used by strawberry growers for years. However, anthracnose pathogens developed resistance to it and other benzimidazole fungicides, rendering benomyl ineffective. In vitro and greenhouse trials have been conducted to identify fungicides to which Colletotrichum pathogens have developed resistance (LaMondia, 1993, 1995; McInnes et al., 1992a, 1992b; Smith and Black, 1991, 1992, 1993). Current fungicide labels address pathogen resistance by restricting the number of consecutive and total applications of a product per season. For instance, the fungicides Abound (azoxystrobin, Syngenta, Greensboro, NC), Cabrio (pyraclostrobin, BASF, Research Triangle Park, NC), and Pristine (pyraclostrobin and boscalid, BASF) are limited to four or five applications per season, with no more than two consecutive applications before alternating with a fungicide that has a different mode of action. Natural products have also been evaluated as alternative fungicides, offering different modes of action, lower toxicity, and increased efficacy (Abril et al., 2008).', 0.4113521873950958]]
Context 1: [['Nursery surveys confirmed the intensive use of QoI fungicides. Single-site fungicides, such as QoIs, have frequently been used in nurseries to control anthracnose and other diseases, ensuring the delivery of symptom-free stock material. Along with commercial products containing only azoxystrobin or pyraclostrobin, premixes with QoI fungicides were also utilized. This has led to an increased selection rate for QoI-resistant populations as early as the nursery phase. Since transplants produced in large nurseries are sold to smaller ones, plants may be exposed to multiple QoI applications throughout each propagation phase. Consequently, during the fruit production phase, growers face challenges in controlling anthracnose outbreaks with limited effective chemical options.', 0.3823363184928894]]
Context 2: [['The document also references a study on the in vitro effectiveness of these fungicides, noting that Difenoconazole, Tebuconazole, and Mancozeb effectively inhibited fungal growth, likely due to their ability to interfere with sterol biosynthesis and enzyme activity. Furthermore, a negative cross-resistance phenomenon is discussed, indicating that the selection for resistance to one fungicide may lead to increased susceptibility to others with different mechanisms.', 0.22365716099739075]]
Context 3: [['Additional keywords: phosphonate fungicides, phosphorous acid.', 0.20592783391475677]]
Context 4: [['FRAC. 2017. FRAC Code List 2017: Fungicides sorted by mode of action (including FRAC code numbering). www.frac.info, Fungicide Resistance Action Committee.', 0.15405380725860596]]
Context 5: [['Spence, E. Y. 1977. History of fungicides. Pages 1-17 in: M. R. Siegel and H. D. Sisler, eds. Antifungal Compounds. Marcel Dekker, Inc., New York. 600 pp.', 0.14727336168289185]]
Context 6: [['The sensitivity ranges of the isolates to various fungicides were 0.2 to 1.6 mg/ml and 0.002 to 0.2 mg/ml, respectively, with average values of 6.5 to 6.9 mg/ml, 1.5 to 0.6 mg/ml, 0.9 to 0.4 mg/ml, and 0.1 to 0.05 mg/ml, respectively. All isolates were more sensitive to difenoconazole, flusilazole, and carbendazim than to tebuconazole (P < 0.01). However, sensitivities to the same fungicide varied among isolates. Specifically, isolates SL-31 and TS-09 were the least sensitive to carbendazim and tebuconazole, with resistance ratios of 87.3 and 51.6, respectively. Sensitivities to difenoconazole and flusilazole were largely consistent across all isolates, with resistance ratios ranging from 1 to 4.6 and from 1 to 7, respectively. Therefore, difenoconazole and flusilazole could be recommended for disease control. Notably, differences in pathogenicity and fungicide sensitivity were not correlated with geographic regions. These findings indicate a high level of intraspecific diversity within the populations of Colletotrichum gloeosporioides s.s. responsible for walnut anthracnose. For effective management, a targeted control strategy should be developed based on different geographic regions.', 0.14531899988651276]]

query: What are the long-term effects of repeated anthracnose outbreaks on strawberry farms?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Anthracnose is an important disease of strawberry caused by Colletotrichum spp., which affects foliage, runners, crowns, and fruits (Howard et al., 1992). Three primary fungal pathogens—C. acutatum sensu lato, C. gloeosporioides sensu lato, and C. fragariae—are known to cause anthracnose disease in strawberries (Freeman and Katan, 1997). The crown rot syndrome is characteristic of infections from C. gloeosporioides sensu lato and C. fragariae, while fruit rot is mainly attributed to C. acutatum sensu lato, leading to significant yield losses (Howard et al., 1992). Currently, numerous species are classified under what is now known as the C. acutatum complex, with six species—C. acutatum sensu stricto, C. fioriniae, C. godetiae, C. nymphaeae, C. salicis, and C. simmondsii—identified as associated with strawberry anthracnose worldwide (Damm et al., 2012). Among these, C. nymphaeae is the most prevalent pathogen causing strawberry anthracnose globally, including in Iran (Baroncelli et al., 2015; Karimi et al., 2017; Wang et al., 2019). Currently, no effective chemical control methods exist for managing strawberry anthracnose; available options are limited to preventive treatments applied before fruit production (Denoyes-Rothan et al., 1999). Additionally, concerns about the toxic effects of chemical fungicides on the environment and the development of resistance in fungal strains highlight the need for alternative control strategies. Consequently, utilizing resistant cultivars appears to be the most efficient and practical approach for suppressing anthracnose development. In light of recent anthracnose outbreaks in strawberry fields in the Kurdistan province of Iran (Karimi et al., 2017), and the necessity for appropriate strategies to address this issue, the aim of this study was to evaluate the resistance of several commercial strawberry cultivars to the anthracnose fruit rot caused by C. nymphaeae under in vivo and greenhouse conditions.', 0.9548445343971252]]
Context 1: [['From May to September 1995, a severe outbreak of strawberry anthracnose was observed in several strawberry-growing nurseries in Israel. Following transplantation to production fields during September and October, entire beds of strawberry plants collapsed. Typical anthracnose symptoms observed from November 1995 to June 1996 included crown rot, flower blight, and green and ripe fruit rot. This marked the first record of strawberry anthracnose in Israel. Furthermore, in at least four production fields in the same region, hundreds of plants developed symptoms of stunting and chlorosis, which are atypical of strawberry anthracnose. When these plants were uprooted, most of their roots were dark brown and decayed. Colletotrichum was readily isolated from these samples.', 0.650724470615387]]
Context 2: [['So far, anthracnose epidemics have affected strawberry nurseries and production fields worldwide. Reports on Colletotrichum spp. associated with strawberries, curated from literature in PubMed and Clarivate combined with fungal database searches (Farr and Rossman, 2022), were compiled to understand the global diversity and occurrence of the causal agents of strawberry anthracnose. From our findings, since 1931 until July 9, 2022, there have been over 220 citations and 310 records related to the identification of causal agents of strawberry anthracnose at the genus level of Colletotrichum in 36 countries across six continents, with 282 records providing pathogen identification at the species or species complex level.', 0.4364582598209381]]
Context 3: [["Anthracnose fungi can attack various parts of the strawberry plant, including crowns, petioles, leaves, fruit trusses, flowers, buds, and fruit. The fungi's ability to attack multiple plant parts, coupled with the involvement of several pathogen species, contributes to the complex nature of strawberry anthracnose. Brooks reported in 1931 that C. fragariae caused spotting and girdling of runners, and later indicated that it also caused spotting of petioles and crown rot in a summer nursery, leading to wilting and death of the plants. Researchers in Louisiana observed all these symptoms and noted that crown rot also occurred in the fruit production field.", 0.37563610076904297]]
Context 4: [['Howard CM, Albregts EE. Anthracnose. In: Compendium of Strawberry Diseases. American Phytopathological Society: Paul St, ed. Maas JL, USA; 1984. pp. 85-87.', 0.36626961827278137]]

query: What molecular techniques were employed in the study to identify Colletotrichum species?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Despite significant developments over the last ten years, the taxonomy of Colletotrichum is in a state of flux. Many uncertainties exist in the systematics of fungal pathogens from this genus; depending on the taxonomic "guides," the number of species can range from 29 to over 700 (von Arx, 1957; Sutton, 1992). One of the most confusing species is C. gloeosporioides. For example, 594 species of Colletotrichum were reclassified by von Arx as synonyms of C. gloeosporioides. Identification has primarily relied on morphological characteristics of conidia, vegetative and sexual structures, as well as host specificity and cultural characteristics (von Arx, 1957). Unfortunately, conidial morphology and colony characteristics vary even within isolates. Consequently, classical methods have been supplemented with biochemical and molecular technologies to differentiate Colletotrichum species (J. W. Kronstad, ed., Fungal Pathology, 127-148. © 2000 Kluwer Academic Publishers). For a more complete discussion of this topic, see Sherriff et al. (1994).', 0.991897463798523]]
Context 1: [['In a drastic move, von Arx (1957) reduced the number of recognized Colletotrichum species from several hundred to 11 based on morphological characteristics, with many taxa treated as synonyms of C. gloeosporioides and C. dematium. Several additional species have since been accepted based on morphological criteria (Sutton, 1980; 1992). The difficulties in recognizing Colletotrichum species can be attributed to: 1) the limited and variable morphological characters; 2) an extensive host range and variability in pathogenicity (Bailey and Jeger, 1992; Freeman et al., 2000; Latunde-Dada, 2001; Du et al., 2005; Thaung, 2008); 3) type specimens that are often missing or in poor condition, making them unsuitable for molecular studies; and 4) numerous rDNA ITS sequences of Colletotrichum strains in NCBI that are often misidentified (Crouch et al., 2009d; Damm et al., 2009).', 0.9816368222236633]]
Context 2: [['Citation: Cai, L., Hyde, K.D., Taylor, P.W.J., Weir, B.S., Waller, J., Abang, M.M., Zhang, J.Z., Yang, Y.L., Phoulivong, S., Liu, Z.Y., Prihastuti, H., Shivas, R.G., McKenzie, E.H.C., Johnston, P.R. (2009). A polyphasic approach for studying Colletotrichum. Fungal Diversity, 39: 183-204.', 0.9184632897377014]]
Context 3: [['Cano, J., Guarro, J., and Gene, J. (2004). Molecular and morphological identification of Colletotrichum species of clinical interest. Journal of Clinical Microbiology 42: 2450-2454.', 0.9133049249649048]]
Context 4: [['Photita, W., Taylor, P. W., Ford, R., Hyde, K. D., and Lumyong, S. (2005). Morphological and molecular characterization of Colletotrichum species from...', 0.903449296951294]]
Context 5: [['The genus Colletotrichum is considered one of the top ten important genera of fungal pathogens globally (Dean et al., 2012). Colletotrichum is an ancient fungus that has co-evolved with flowering plants. Plant microfossils of Protocolletotrichum preserved on angiosperm leaf cuticles suggest that the diverse pathogenic strategies of Colletotrichum spp. have been established since the Late Cretaceous period (Kar et al., 2004). Different complexes within the genus may have diverged between 4.8 and 32.2 million years ago (MYA) (Bhunjun et al., 2021). The emergence of agricultural cultivation and the intensive disturbance of natural environments have further driven the diversification of Colletotrichum species. These fungi have adapted to thousands of hosts and can be found as endophytes, pathogens, and saprobes (Freeman et al., 1998; Dean et al., 2012; Hirayama et al., 2018; da Silva et al., 2020; Jayawardena et al., 2020). Currently, a total of 257 Colletotrichum species grouped into 15 complexes and 13 additional singletons have been accepted in this genus.', 0.619985818862915]]
Context 6: [['Jayawardena, R. S., Hyde, K. D., Damm, U., Cai, L., Liu, M., Li, X. H., Zhang, W., Zhao, W. S., and Yan, J. Y. (2016). Notes on currently accepted species of Colletotrichum. Mycosphere, 7, 1192-1260.', 0.5467532873153687]]
Context 7: [['The name Colletotrichum was first introduced by Tode (1790) under the genus Vermicularia. The genus Colletotrichum itself was established by Corda (1831) and is now recognized as comprising “coelomycetes” with a Glomerella teleomorph stage (Sutton, 1992; Shenoy et al., 2007a; Hyde et al., 2009). This genus includes species with endophytic, epiphytic, saprobic, and phytopathogenic lifestyles (Kumar and Hyde, 2004; Photita et al., 2001a,b).', 0.5032817721366882]]
Context 8: [['Hyde, K.D., Cai, L., Cannon, P.F., Crouch, J.A., Crous, P.W., Damm, U., Goodwin, P.H., Chen, H., Johnston, P.R., Jones, E.B.G., Liu, Z.Y., McKenzie, E.H.C., Moriwaki, J., Noireung, P., Pennycook, S.R., Pfenning, L.H., Prihastuti, H., Sato, T., Shivas, R.G., Tan, Y.P., Taylor, P.W.J., Weir, B.S., Yang, Y.L., Zhang, J.Z., 2009. Colletotrichum – names in current use. Fungal Diversity 39: 147–182.', 0.5017390847206116]]
Context 9: [['Hyde, K.D., Cai, L., Cannon, P.F., Crouch, J.A., Crous, P.W., Damm, U., Goodwin, P.H., Chen, H., Johnston, P.R., Jones, E.B.G., Liu, Z.Y., McKenzie, E.H.C., Moriwaki, J., Noireung, P., Pennycook, S.R., Pfenning, L.H., Prihastuti, H., Sato, T., Shivas, R.G., Tan, Y.P., Taylor, P.W.J., Weir, B.S., Yang, Y.L., and Zhang, J.Z. query: How might the classification of Colletotrichum isolates into 13 species enhance our understanding of mango diseases?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Based on morphological characteristics and a concatenated five-gene phylogenetic analysis, the 128 Colletotrichum isolates from mango in southern China were classified into 13 species: C. asianum, C. cliviicola, C. cordylinicola, C. endophytica, C. fructicola, C. gigasporum, C. gloeosporioides, C. karstii, C. liaoningense, C. musae, C. scovillei, C. siamense, and C. tropicale. Four species complexes (C. acutatum, C. boninense, C. gigasporum, and C. gloeosporioides) were associated with mango.', 0.9909188747406006]]
Context 1: [['This study has enhanced our understanding of the diversity of Colletotrichum species associated with mango anthracnose in China. Further research is required to determine the differences in biological and infection characteristics among various Colletotrichum species affecting mango, as well as the molecular mechanisms responsible for these differences and their effects on mango anthracnose disease in the field. There have been few studies on the etiology and epidemiology of Colletotrichum species on mango. Therefore, future work on pathogenic mechanisms could be helpful for the prevention and control of mango anthracnose disease.', 0.9907172322273254]]
Context 2: [['Based on morphological observations and multilocus sequence analysis, 128 mango Colletotrichum isolates obtained in China can be classified into 13 species: 38 isolates (29.7%) of C. assianum, 38 isolates (29.7%) of C. siamense, 32 isolates (25.0%) of C. fructicola, five isolates (3.9%) of C. karstii, four isolates (3.1%) of C. endophytica, three isolates (2.3%) of C. scovillei, two isolates (1.6%) of C. cliviicola, and one isolate each of C. cordylinicola, C. gigasporum, C. gloeosporioides, C. liaoningense, C. musae, and C. tropicale. This is the first report of C. cliviicola, C. cordylinicola, C. endophytica, C. gigasporum, C. gloeosporioides, C. karstii, C. liaoningense, C. musae, and C. tropicale associated with mango anthracnose in China. Furthermore, this study also marks the first report of C. cordylinicola, C. endophytica, C. gigasporum, C. liaoningense, and C. musae linked to mango anthracnose worldwide.', 0.9904520511627197]]
Context 3: [['Our results indicated that the most common fungal isolates associated with mango in southern China included 13 species: Colletotrichum asianum, C. cliviicola, C. cordylinicola, C. endophytica, C. fructicola, C. gigasporum, C. gloeosporioides, C. karstii, C. liaoningense, C. musae, C. scovillei, C. siamense, and C. tropicale. The dominant species were C. asianum and C. siamense, each accounting for 30%, followed by C. fructicola at 25%. Of these, only C. asianum, C. fructicola, C. scovillei, and C. siamense have previously been reported on mango, while the other nine species listed are reported here for the first time in association with mango in China. This study also marks the first report of five species worldwide on mango: C. cordylinicola, C. endophytica, C. gigasporum, C. liaoningense, and C. musae.', 0.9445698857307434]]
Context 4: [['Abstract: Anthracnose caused by Colletotrichum spp. is one of the major problems in mango production worldwide, including Thailand. All mango cultivars are susceptible, but Nam Dok Mai See Thong (NDMST) is the most vulnerable. Through a single spore isolation method, a total of 37 isolates of Colletotrichum spp. were obtained from NDMST showing anthracnose symptoms. Identification was performed using a combination of morphological characteristics, Koch’s postulates, and phylogenetic analysis. The pathogenicity assay and Koch’s postulates on leaves and fruit confirmed that all Colletotrichum spp. tested were causal agents of mango anthracnose. Multilocus analysis using DNA sequences of internal transcribed spacer (ITS) regions, β-tubulin (TUB2), actin (ACT), and chitin synthase (CHS-1) was performed for molecular identification. Two concatenated phylogenetic trees were constructed using either two loci (ITS and TUB2) or four loci (ITS, TUB2, ACT, and CHS-1). Both phylogenetic trees were indistinguishable and showed that these 37 isolates belong to C. acutatum, C. asianum, C. gloeosporioides, and C. siamense. Our results indicated that using at least two loci of ITS and TUB2 was sufficient to infer Colletotrichum species complexes. Of the 37 isolates, C. gloeosporioides was the most dominant species (19 isolates), followed by C. asianum (10 isolates), C. acutatum (5 isolates), and C. siamense (3 isolates). In Thailand, C. gloeosporioides and C. acutatum have been reported to cause anthracnose in mango; however, this is the first report of C. asianum and C. siamense associated with mango anthracnose in central Thailand.', 0.9260704517364502]]
Context 5: [['The morphological descriptions of these isolates aligned with previous descriptions of Colletotrichum species, although cultural characteristics may vary due to differing cultural conditions. Conidial morphology alone could not distinguish all species within these complexes. Currently, 13 Colletotrichum species have been reported worldwide on mango: C. asianum, C. cliviicola, C. dianesei, C. endomangiferae, C. fructicola, C. gloeosporioides, C. grossum, C. kahawae, C. karstii, C. scovillei, C. siamense, C. theobromicola (syn. C. fragariae), and C. tropicale. Prior studies by Mo et al., Liu et al., and Qin et al. identified four Colletotrichum species (C. asianum, C. fructicola, C. scovillei, and C. siamense) prevalent on mango in China. In this study, in addition to the aforementioned species, nine other Colletotrichum species (C. cliviicola, C. cordylinicola, C. endophytica, C. gigasporum, C. gloeosporioides, C. karstii, C. liaoningense, C. musae, and C. tropicale) were reported for the first time on mango in China.', 0.9223255515098572]]
Context 6: [['Pardo-De la Hoz et al. (2016) reported some level of host preference among Colletotrichum spp. associated with mango anthracnose in Colombia, which included C. asianum and C. gloeosporioides. Both species have also been reported as common mango anthracnose pathogens by Rojas et al. (2010) in Panama and Krishnapillai and Wijeratnam (2014) in Sri Lanka. Many reports published in India, the largest mango producer in the world, point out C. gloeosporioides as the main causative agent of mango anthracnose; however, this might not always be accurate. Based on restriction analysis and sequencing of the ITS region, Chowdappa and Kumar (2012) reported that C. gloeosporioides associated with mango anthracnose in India comprises diverse subgroups. Pathogenicity tests demonstrate variation in the degree of virulence among C. gloeosporioides isolates, suggesting the existence of more than one species causing the disease. Using multigene phylogenetic analysis, Sharma et al. (2013) later identified four phylogenetic species: C. fragariae sensu stricto, C. fructicola, C. jasmine-sambac, and C. melanocaulon. Additionally, five Colletotrichum lineages without species names were associated with mango anthracnose in India. Sharma et al. also reported that none of the Colletotrichum isolates obtained from mango samples grouped with C. gloeosporioides sensu stricto, aligning with findings previously documented by Phoulivong et al. (2012).', 0.910959780216217]]
Context 7: [['Fungal Isolations: In 2016 and 2017, leaves, fruits, and branches of mango with anthracnose symptoms were collected from six mango-growing provinces in China for fungal isolation. Based on morphological observation and ITS sequences, a total of 205 Colletotrichum isolates were obtained from all investigated mango-growing regions, with 128 representative isolates selected for further study (one isolate from each orchard, and more than one from larger orchards: 34 from Yunnan, 23 from Hainan, 18 from Guizhou, 13 from Sichuan, 16 from Guangdong, and 24 from Fujian Province). The selected isolates are listed in Supplementary Table S1. Isolated species in other genera include Alternaria, Phomopsis, Botryosphaeria, and Pestalotia, which were retained for further study.', 0.900287389755249]]
Context 8: [['Fungal Isolations: In 2016 and 2017, all leaves, fruits, and branches of mango with anthracnose symptoms collected from the six mango-growing provinces in China were used for fungal isolation. Based on morphological observations and ITS sequences, a total of 205 Colletotrichum isolates were obtained from all investigated mango-growing regions, and 128 representative isolates were selected for further study (one isolate from each orchard, and more than one from some large orchards; 34 from Yunnan, 23 from Hainan, 18 from Guizhou, 13 from Sichuan, 16 from Guangdong, and 24 from Fujian province). The selected isolates are listed in Supplementary Table S1. Isolated species from other genera included Alternaria, Phomopsis, Botryosphaeria, and Pestalotia, which were retained for further study.', 0.8999238610267639]]
Context 9: [['Colletotrichum gloeosporioides sensu lato is a significant pathogen responsible for mango anthracnose globally. In some cases, C. acutatum sensu lato has also been linked to the disease. Phylogenetic analyses based on internal transcribed spacer (ITS) sequences reveal that C. gloeosporioides comprises diverse groups or sub-populations, suggesting that other Colletotrichum species may also be associated with mango anthracnose. Studies indicate that Colletotrichum isolates from mango can consist of pathogenically and genetically distinct populations of C. gloeosporioides. According to Ploetz (1999), the C. gloeosporioides population on mango has a restricted host range and is highly virulent solely on mango. Following the phylogenetic analyses of the Colletotrichum genus by Phoulivong et al. (2012) and Weir et al. (2012), several species within the C. gloeosporioides and C. acutatum complexes, including C. gloeosporioides, have been associated with mango anthracnose.', 0.8996384739875793]]

Context 0: [['During the 2001–2002 season, isolates were grouped into four categories based on their average aggressiveness toward the four cultivars tested (as detailed in Table 5). Isolate 97-15A was identified as the most aggressive, while isolates 95-63A, 97-45A, and 97-47C displayed relatively high and comparable levels of aggressiveness. Isolates 98-285 and 97-63 were less aggressive, with 97-63 being the least aggressive of the two. In the following season, 2002–2003, these isolates were re-evaluated alongside others, resulting in the formation of four isolate clusters based on aggressiveness. The rankings among isolates remained consistent, although 98-285 and 97-63 were not significantly different from each other. Isolates 00-59 and 96-83R were found to be highly aggressive, while 96-83H, a non-strawberry isolate, was the least aggressive. For the 2003–2004 season, isolate 00-59 was again identified as highly aggressive, with isolate 02-172 being more aggressive than isolate 96-15A and ascospore isolate 00-117. In separate analyses comparing inoculated plots to uninoculated controls, all isolate treatments exhibited significantly more crown rot than the controls (data not shown).', 0.9924584031105042]]

query: Are heat treatments effective in controlling strawberry anthracnose across various environmental conditions, according to the research by Wang, Turechek, and Peres (2017)?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Anthracnose is an important disease of strawberry caused by Colletotrichum spp., which affects foliage, runners, crowns, and fruits (Howard et al., 1992). Three primary fungal pathogens—C. acutatum sensu lato, C. gloeosporioides sensu lato, and C. fragariae—are known to cause anthracnose disease in strawberries (Freeman and Katan, 1997). The crown rot syndrome is characteristic of infections from C. gloeosporioides sensu lato and C. fragariae, while fruit rot is mainly attributed to C. acutatum sensu lato, leading to significant yield losses (Howard et al., 1992). Currently, numerous species are classified under what is now known as the C. acutatum complex, with six species—C. acutatum sensu stricto, C. fioriniae, C. godetiae, C. nymphaeae, C. salicis, and C. simmondsii—identified as associated with strawberry anthracnose worldwide (Damm et al., 2012). Among these, C. nymphaeae is the most prevalent pathogen causing strawberry anthracnose globally, including in Iran (Baroncelli et al., 2015; Karimi et al., 2017; Wang et al., 2019). Currently, no effective chemical control methods exist for managing strawberry anthracnose; available options are limited to preventive treatments applied before fruit production (Denoyes-Rothan et al., 1999). Additionally, concerns about the toxic effects of chemical fungicides on the environment and the development of resistance in fungal strains highlight the need for alternative control strategies. Consequently, utilizing resistant cultivars appears to be the most efficient and practical approach for suppressing anthracnose development. In light of recent anthracnose outbreaks in strawberry fields in the Kurdistan province of Iran (Karimi et al., 2017), and the necessity for appropriate strategies to address this issue, the aim of this study was to evaluate the resistance of several commercial strawberry cultivars to the anthracnose fruit rot caused by C. nymphaeae under in vivo and greenhouse conditions.', 0.8401806354522705]]
Context 1: [['Strawberry anthracnose can affect plants at any lifecycle stage, but plants are particularly susceptible at the seedling stage and immediately after planting (Wang et al. 2008). The disease primarily affects strawberry roots, petioles, and stolons, but can also infect flowers and fruit, leading to severe outbreaks (Mertely and Legard 2004). Symptoms include irregular ulcer-like lesions, reddish-brown stolons during initial stolon development, black spindle-shaped lesions on leaves and petioles, wilting, and dead roots (Debode et al. 2009; Freeman and Katan 1997). In Zhejiang, nearly 50% of seedling deaths and over 40% of production losses in nurseries are attributed to this disease (Xie et al. 2010). If environmental conditions are favorable, anthracnose can reduce strawberry yield by up to 80%. Transplants are considered the main source of primary inoculum, but the complete epidemiology of Colletotrichum spp. on strawberries in China remains unclear.', 0.6385630965232849]]
Context 2: [['Wang, C. H. (2013). Occurrence and control of strawberry anthracnose in Donggang area.', 0.26180949807167053]]
Context 3: [['Overall, the study highlights the importance of cultural practices and genetic resistance in managing strawberry anthracnose effectively.', 0.18487107753753662]]
Context 4: [['The term "anthracnose" was first used to describe a new disease of strawberries caused by Colletotrichum fragariae Brooks. "Strawberry anthracnose" continues to be used as a general term to identify all diseases of strawberries caused by species of Colletotrichum. Strawberry anthracnose diseases have been reported to be caused by C. acutatum J.H. Simmonds, C. gloeosporioides (Penz.) Penz. & Sacc. in Penz. (the teleomorph of Cromereilla cingulata (Stoneman) Spauld. & H. Schrenk), and C. dematium (Pers.) Grove. The latter species only occasionally causes strawberry fruit rots and will not be discussed here.', 0.16858351230621338]]
Context 5: [['Smith, B.J. 2007. Developmental stage and temperature affect strawberry flower and fruit susceptibility to anthracnose, p. 55–57. In: F. Takeda, D.T. Handley, and E.B. Poling (eds.). Proc. 2007 North American Strawberry Symposium. North American Strawberry Growers Association, Kemptville, ON, Canada.', 0.1616225391626358]]
Context 6: [['Strawberry (Fragaria × ananassa) is a major crop cultivated in China (Xie et al. 2010). The production of strawberries has rapidly expanded in recent years, positioning China as one of the world’s largest producers and exporters. As of 2013, strawberry cultivation covered 100.5 × 10^3 hectares, yielding 2.8 million tonnes (The Ministry of Agriculture of the People’s Republic of China 2014). However, with increased production, many fungal diseases have emerged as significant challenges, negatively impacting fruit yield and quality (Mass 1998, Smith 2008). Among these, anthracnose, caused by species of Colletotrichum, is one of the most critical diseases affecting strawberries.', 0.15783941745758057]]
Context 7: [['Strand, L. L. 2008. Integrated Pest Management for Strawberries, 2nd Ed. University of California, Oakland.', 0.1463761329650879]]
Context 8: [['The modern strawberry, Fragaria × ananassa Duchesne, is of relatively recent origin. It was not until the North American F. virginiana and the South American F. chiloensis were brought together and hybridized in Europe around 1750 that the progenitor of the strawberry we know today was developed. The high degree of genetic heterozygosity in Fragaria spp. has facilitated the creation of strawberry cultivars adapted to a wide range of environmental conditions and resistant to several diseases and pests. Today, cultivars are available that can survive the bitterly cold winters of Alaska, as well as those that thrive in the long, hot seasons of Pretoria, South Africa.', 0.1437360942363739]]
Context 9: [['Strawberries (Fragaria×ananassa Duch.) are a widely cultivated hybrid species within the Rosaceae family, renowned for their fruit. They are increasingly significant for the agricultural economic development of countries like Iran, particularly in the Kurdistan province, which leads in strawberry production, predominantly under open-field conditions (Tehranifar and Sarsaefi, 2002). Various biotic and abiotic factors contribute to the decline in strawberry production globally. Notably, over 100 fungal species can invade strawberry plants, with approximately one-third causing serious diseases on different plant parts (Martin and others).', 0.12831556797027588]]

Context 5: [['Species of the fungal plant pathogen Colletotrichum are responsible for strawberry (Fragaria × ananassa Duch.) anthracnose, one of the major diseases affecting this crop. Infection of mother plants with anthracnose may result in the collapse of the entire plant due to crown rot. In the nursery, lesions form on stolons that eventually girdle the runners, leading to wilting and death of unrooted daughter plants distal to the lesion. Death of daughter plants in the nursery and in field transplants can also be caused by crown rot. Infected transplants are capable of spreading the disease from the nursery to the field, and entire crops can be destroyed by anthracnose in strawberry fruit production fields under conducive environmental conditions.', 0.41536059975624084]]
Context 6: [['Anthracnose is an important disease of strawberry caused by Colletotrichum spp., which affects foliage, runners, crowns, and fruits (Howard et al., 1992). The crown rot syndrome is characteristic of infections from C. gloeosporioides sensu lato and C. fragariae, while fruit rot is mainly attributed to C. acutatum sensu lato, leading to significant yield losses (Howard et al., 1992). Currently, numerous species are classified under what is now known as the C. acutatum complex, with six species—C. acutatum sensu stricto, C. fioriniae, C. godetiae, C. nymphaeae, C. salicis, and C. simmondsii—identified as associated with strawberry anthracnose worldwide (Damm et al., 2012). Among these, C. nymphaeae is the most prevalent pathogen causing strawberry anthracnose globally, including in Iran (Baroncelli et al., 2015; Karimi et al., 2017; Wang et al., 2019). Currently, no effective chemical control methods exist for managing strawberry anthracnose; available options are limited to preventive treatments applied before fruit production (Denoyes-Rothan et al., 1999). Additionally, concerns about the toxic effects of chemical fungicides on the environment and the development of resistance in fungal strains highlight the need for alternative control strategies. Consequently, utilizing resistant cultivars appears to be the most efficient and practical approach for suppressing anthracnose development. In light of recent anthracnose outbreaks in strawberry fields in the Kurdistan province of Iran (Karimi et al., 2017), and the necessity for appropriate strategies to address this issue, the aim of this study was to evaluate the resistance of several commercial strawberry cultivars to the anthracnose fruit rot caused by C. nymphaeae under in vivo and greenhouse conditions.', 0.38627493381500244]]
Context 7: [['Therefore, we aimed to examine the effects of irrigation systems, mulching materials, and genetically based resistance, as well as their interactions, on the incidence of strawberry anthracnose caused by Colletotrichum acutatum.', 0.3390786051750183]]
Context 8: [['Howard CM, Albregts EE. Anthracnose. In: Compendium of Strawberry Diseases. American Phytopathological Society: Paul St, ed. Maas JL, USA; 1984. pp. 85-87.', 0.28933095932006836]]
Context 9: [["Anthracnose fungi can attack various parts of the strawberry plant, including crowns, petioles, leaves, fruit trusses, flowers, buds, and fruit. The fungi's ability to attack multiple plant parts, coupled with the involvement of several pathogen species, contributes to the complex nature of strawberry anthracnose. Brooks reported in 1931 that C. fragariae caused spotting and girdling of runners, and later indicated that it also caused spotting of petioles and crown rot in a summer nursery, leading to wilting and death of the plants. Researchers in Louisiana observed all these symptoms and noted that crown rot also occurred in the fruit production field.", 0.2615582048892975]]

query: How can MEGA X be applied in the analysis of sequence alignments for phylogenetic studies?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['The Molecular Evolutionary Genetics Analysis (MEGA) software implements various analytical methods and tools for phylogenomics and phylomedicine. We report a transformation of MEGA to enable cross-platform use on Microsoft Windows and Linux operating systems. MEGA X does not require virtualization or emulation software and provides a uniform user experience across platforms. Additionally, MEGA X has been upgraded to utilize multiple computing cores for many molecular evolutionary analyses. MEGA X is available in two interfaces (graphical and command line) and can be downloaded free of charge from www.megasoftware.net.', 0.8687790036201477]]
Context 1: [['Multiple sequence alignment (MSA) plays a crucial role in the evolutionary analysis of biological sequences. MAFFT is an MSA program first released in 2002 (Katoh et al. 2002). Due to its high performance (Nuin et al. 2006; Golubchik et al. 2007; Dessimoz and Gil 2010; Letsch et al. 2010; Sahraeian and Yoon 2011; Sievers et al. 2011), MAFFT has gained popularity in recent years. Following the review of the previous version (version 6) by Katoh and Toh (2008b), we have continuously enhanced its accuracy, speed, and utility in practical applications. These improvements and techniques have been documented in various papers (Katoh et al. 2009; Katoh and Toh 2010; Katoh and Frith 2012; Katoh and Standley 2013).', 0.39599132537841797]]
Context 2: [['The MAFFT profile program is not suitable for certain applications. There are two types of misapplications to consider. The first type involves the following steps: 1) convert an existing alignment to a profile, 2) align new sequences and convert them to a profile, and 3) align the two profiles. This procedure is inappropriate for adding new sequences because it assumes a phylogenetic relationship, as illustrated in Figure 1A.', 0.3405851721763611]]
Context 3: [['Key Words: multiple sequence alignment, metagenome, protein structure, progressive alignment, parallel processing.', 0.25274932384490967]]
Context 4: [['According to a recent comparative study based on the MetAl metric (Blackburne and Whelan 2012a, 2012b), there are two significantly different classes of multiple sequence alignment (MSA) methods: similarity-based and profile-based methods. MAFFT has a subprogram, mafft-profile, to align two existing alignments. This method separately converts the first alignment (alignment1) and the second alignment (alignment2) into profiles and then aligns the two profiles. This means that the two input alignments are assumed to be phylogenetically isolated from each other, as shown in Figure 1A. Careless application of this method can result in serious misalignments, as discussed in a later section.', 0.25132206082344055]]
Context 5: [['MEGAX now generates a configuration file that specifies analysis options for user-desired analyses in MEGACC, which many researchers utilize for high-throughput and iterative analysis across Windows, Linux, and macOS environments (Kumar et al. 2012). The "Save Settings" button provides this functionality (see Fig. 2H). Furthermore, MEGAX can now be used in prototype mode (see Fig. 1, lower right corner), if desired. This eliminates the need to distribute and maintain a separate application for generating the configuration file needed for running MEGA CC, so MEGA-Proto is no longer required or supported.', 0.20890414714813232]]
Context 6: [['Thompson, J. D., Gibson, T. J., Plewniak, F., Jeanmougin, F., & Higgins, D. G. (1997). The Clustal X windows interface: Flexible strategies for multiple sequence alignment aided by quality analysis tools. Nucleic Acids Research, 24, 4876–4882.', 0.1764325499534607]]
