Context 9: [['MEGA was first developed for MS-DOS in the early 1990s, with tools like Alignment Explorer, Sequence Data Explorer, and Tree (Kumar et al. 1994). It was later upgraded for use in MS Windows. The internal control code across Windows versions, from MEGA 1 to MEGA 6, was adapted for the MS Windows system application programming interface (API), with advancements made for cross-platform compatibility in MEGA-CC and MEGA-MD (Kumar et al. 2001, 2016). Some MEGA releases have been packaged for Linux systems using the WINE compatibility layer for POSIX-compliant operating systems and the Wineskin tool (built on WINE) for macOS systems. These versions have been downloaded over 200,000 times. However, the ad hoc Windows emulation solution is sluggish and relatively unstable compared to the native application.', 0.14496970176696777]]

query: Why is it important to identify the specific Colletotrichum species causing anthracnose in a region?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Disease Etiology and Host Specificity Determining the specific species of Colletotrichum responsible for anthracnose is critical for effective disease management. Relying solely on the species-host combination can be misleading. Therefore, taxonomic identification and characterization of subpopulations are essential to establish a clear understanding of disease dynamics.', 0.9959636926651001]]
Context 1: [['Colletotrichum is one of the most important genera of plant pathogenic fungi worldwide, causing disease symptoms commonly known as anthracnose on a wide range of important crops, fruits, and ornamental plants (Bailey et al., 1992). Notable species include Colletotrichum lindemuthianum, C. gloeosporioides, C. acutatum, C. falcatum, C. nupharicola, and C. nymphaeae. Some plant pathogenic species are significant for quarantine because they could be introduced into regions where the disease is not present (Farr et al., 2006). The taxonomy and phylogeny of the genus Colletotrichum remain confusing (Hyde et al., 2009; Cai et al., 2009). Historically, if anthracnose was found on a host for which there were no prior records of that fungus-host relationship, the species was interpreted as new and formally described (Cannon et al., 2000). This practice was later rejected (von Arx, 1957; Sutton, 1980; Baxter et al., 1983), yet new species are still occasionally described in Colletotrichum (Sivanesan et al., 1993; Nakanura et al., 2006; Liu et al., 2007). Currently, more than 688 epithets are listed in Index Fungorum (www.indexfungorum.org/names/names.asp). Based on a morphological study, von Arx (1957) included more than 600 synonyms under C. gloeosporioides and 84 synonyms under C. dematium. Sutton (1992) listed 39 accepted species in Colletotrichum, each with a brief description. In recent years, molecular tools have been used to infer the evolutionary relationships of Colletotrichum species. Some species have been segregated from the C. gloeosporioides complex based on nu-rDNA ITS sequence data and morphological characteristics, such as C. boninense.', 0.9952076077461243]]
Context 2: [['Colletotrichum spp. often cause anthracnose disease in herbaceous or woody plants in tropical and subtropical regions (Cannon et al. 2012). The genus Colletotrichum is one of the eight major plant pathogens worldwide (Dean et al. 2012). Three species or species complexes of Colletotrichum have been reported to cause anthracnose in strawberries: the Colletotrichum gloeosporioides complex, Colletotrichum fragariae, and the Colletotrichum acutatum complex (Denoyes-Rothan et al. 2003). The C. gloeosporioides complex is found worldwide and has a wide range of hosts, whereas C. acutatum and C. fragariae have narrower host ranges (MacKenzie et al. 2008). Although a few C. acutatum infections in Chinese strawberries have been reported, the primary species affecting strawberries in China are believed to be C. gloeosporioides and C. fragariae (Buddie et al. 1999; Han et al. 2016).', 0.9911094903945923]]
Context 3: [["Three species have been documented as causal agents of strawberry anthracnose: Colletotrichum gloeosporioides, C. fragariae, and C. acutatum (Denoyes-Rothan et al. 2003). The anthracnose disease caused by Colletotrichum spp. impacts a wide variety of woody and herbaceous plants, particularly tropical and subtropical crops and fruit trees (Cannon et al. 2012; Freeman et al. 1998; Hyde et al. 2009; Sutton 1992; Wikee et al. 2011). The genus has recently been recognized as the world's eighth most important group of plant-pathogenic fungi due to its scientific and economic significance (Dean et al. 2012). However, the identification of Colletotrichum spp. has historically been challenging. Single-gene phylogenetic analyses have often failed to accurately delineate species (Hyde et al. 2009). Ko Ko et al. (2011) emphasized the need to resurvey plant pathogens like Colletotrichum spp. using molecular methods, as previous morphological and internal transcribed spacer data are likely to be incorrect. Understanding of Colletotrichum spp. has significantly advanced through these molecular approaches.", 0.9859578013420105]]
Context 4: [['Various studies highlight the significance of Colletotrichum species in agriculture. Crouch et al. (2009) discussed anthracnose disease caused by the novel species Colletotrichum navitas, while Damm et al. (2013) addressed the Colletotrichum orbiculare species complex, which affects field crops and weeds. Other works by Damm et al. (2012) explored the Colletotrichum acutatum and Colletotrichum boninense species complexes.', 0.9666906595230103]]
Context 5: [['A significant effort has been dedicated to identifying which species of Colletotrichum are involved in various anthracnose-type diseases of plants and developing tools for their identification and differentiation. Multiple hosts can be affected by a single species, while multiple species can impact a single host. Simmonds was the first to describe C. acutatum as a new species, distinct from others.', 0.9329274892807007]]
Context 6: [['Many species belonging to the genus Colletotrichum are associated with plant diseases, commonly referred to as anthracnose. Colletotrichum spp. can affect a wide range of hosts, and these pathogens are characterized by global distribution. Virtually every cultivated botanical family is susceptible to one or more species of Colletotrichum, making it one of the most studied plant pathogenic fungi (Prusky et al., 2000; Latunde-Dada, 2001; Dean et al., 2012). Common hosts include many dicotyledonous plants such as strawberry, apple, citrus, and stone fruits, as well as major cereals such as maize and sorghum. Members of this genus can cause crop losses of up to 100% in many staple foods (Bailey and Jeger, 1992; Prusky et al., 2000; Talhinhas et al., 2005; Cannon et al., 2012).', 0.9114388823509216]]
Context 7: [['Bailey JA, Nash C, Morgan LW, O’Connell RJ, TeBeest DO (1996). Molecular taxonomy of Colletotrichum species causing anthracnose on the Malvaceae. Phytopathology 86: 1076–1083.', 0.7259552478790283]]
Context 8: [['Y.-Z. Diao et al.: Colletotrichum causing anthracnose disease.', 0.6626428365707397]]
Context 9: [['Diao, Y.-Z., et al. (2014). Colletotrichum causing anthracnose disease.', 0.551539957523346]]

Schrenk) causes anthracnose disease on various fruits, including peach (Bernstein et al. 1995; Kim and Hong 2008; Ramsey et al. 1951), blueberry (Hartung et al. 1981; Smith et al. 1996), strawberry (Denoyes and Baudry 1995; Freeman et al. 2002; Smith and Black 1990), almond (Ogawa and English 1991), avocado (Stanley et al. 1996), apple (Bernstein et al. 1995; Shi et al. 1996), papaya (Gamagae et al. 2003), and citrus (Alahakoon and Brown 1994; Liyanage et al. 1992). The disease can develop on stems, twigs, leaves, and fruit of host plants. On peach, the pathogen often occurs in areas and during seasons with high rainfall and warm temperatures (Ogawa et al. 1995). Symptoms include sunken lesions with circular rings, where conidia of the fungus are produced in acervuli. Anthracnose disease can occasionally cause yield loss in commercial peach orchards in the southeastern United States, especially during wet and warm summers.', 0.8843331336975098]]
Context 8: [['Colletotrichum gloeosporioides Penz. var. minor J. H. Simmonds (Queensland Journal of Agriculture and Animal Science 22: 437-459, 1965).', 0.6913822293281555]]

query: What methods are used to differentiate Colletotrichum species?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Despite significant developments over the last ten years, the taxonomy of Colletotrichum is in a state of flux. Many uncertainties exist in the systematics of fungal pathogens from this genus; depending on the taxonomic "guides," the number of species can range from 29 to over 700 (von Arx, 1957; Sutton, 1992). One of the most confusing species is C. gloeosporioides. For example, 594 species of Colletotrichum were reclassified by von Arx as synonyms of C. gloeosporioides. Identification has primarily relied on morphological characteristics of conidia, vegetative and sexual structures, as well as host specificity and cultural characteristics (von Arx, 1957). Unfortunately, conidial morphology and colony characteristics vary even within isolates. Consequently, classical methods have been supplemented with biochemical and molecular technologies to differentiate Colletotrichum species (J. W. Kronstad, ed., Fungal Pathology, 127-148. © 2000 Kluwer Academic Publishers). For a more complete discussion of this topic, see Sherriff et al. (1994).', 0.9965207576751709]]
Context 1: [['In a drastic move, von Arx (1957) reduced the number of recognized Colletotrichum species from several hundred to 11 based on morphological characteristics, with many taxa treated as synonyms of C. gloeosporioides and C. dematium. Several additional species have since been accepted based on morphological criteria (Sutton, 1980; 1992). The difficulties in recognizing Colletotrichum species can be attributed to: 1) the limited and variable morphological characters; 2) an extensive host range and variability in pathogenicity (Bailey and Jeger, 1992; Freeman et al., 2000; Latunde-Dada, 2001; Du et al., 2005; Thaung, 2008); 3) type specimens that are often missing or in poor condition, making them unsuitable for molecular studies; and 4) numerous rDNA ITS sequences of Colletotrichum strains in NCBI that are often misidentified (Crouch et al., 2009d; Damm et al., 2009).', 0.9514157772064209]]
Context 2: [['The genus Colletotrichum is considered one of the top ten important genera of fungal pathogens globally (Dean et al., 2012). Colletotrichum is an ancient fungus that has co-evolved with flowering plants. Plant microfossils of Protocolletotrichum preserved on angiosperm leaf cuticles suggest that the diverse pathogenic strategies of Colletotrichum spp. have been established since the Late Cretaceous period (Kar et al., 2004). Different complexes within the genus may have diverged between 4.8 and 32.2 million years ago (MYA) (Bhunjun et al., 2021). The emergence of agricultural cultivation and the intensive disturbance of natural environments have further driven the diversification of Colletotrichum species. These fungi have adapted to thousands of hosts and can be found as endophytes, pathogens, and saprobes (Freeman et al., 1998; Dean et al., 2012; Hirayama et al., 2018; da Silva et al., 2020; Jayawardena et al., 2020). Currently, a total of 257 Colletotrichum species grouped into 15 complexes and 13 additional singletons have been accepted in this genus.', 0.9258448481559753]]
Context 3: [['Citation: Cai, L., Hyde, K.D., Taylor, P.W.J., Weir, B.S., Waller, J., Abang, M.M., Zhang, J.Z., Yang, Y.L., Phoulivong, S., Liu, Z.Y., Prihastuti, H., Shivas, R.G., McKenzie, E.H.C., Johnston, P.R. (2009). A polyphasic approach for studying Colletotrichum. Fungal Diversity, 39: 183-204.', 0.8603184223175049]]
Context 4: [['The name Colletotrichum was first introduced by Tode (1790) under the genus Vermicularia. The genus Colletotrichum itself was established by Corda (1831) and is now recognized as comprising “coelomycetes” with a Glomerella teleomorph stage (Sutton, 1992; Shenoy et al., 2007a; Hyde et al., 2009). This genus includes species with endophytic, epiphytic, saprobic, and phytopathogenic lifestyles (Kumar and Hyde, 2004; Photita et al., 2001a,b).', 0.6718631386756897]]
Context 5: [['Cai, L., Hyde, K.D., Taylor, P.W.J., Weir, B., Waller, J., Abang, M.M., Zhang, J.Z., Yang, Y.L., Phoulivong, S., Liu, Z.Y., Prihastuti, H., Shivas, R.G., McKenzie, E.H.C., and Johnston, P.R. (2009). A polyphasic approach for studying Colletotrichum. Fungal Diversity 39: 183-204.', 0.6623261570930481]]
Context 6: [['Photita, W., Taylor, P. W., Ford, R., Hyde, K. D., and Lumyong, S. (2005). Morphological and molecular characterization of Colletotrichum species from...', 0.5685378909111023]]
Context 7: [['Much has been written about various individual species of Colletotrichum, yet in many cases, the name used represents a species complex, and it is unclear which actual species is involved. In the following section, we review three species of Colletotrichum to highlight the problems associated with inadequate knowledge of the species and potential incorrect or inaccurate naming.', 0.5290094614028931]]
Context 8: [['Cano, J., Guarro, J., and Gene, J. (2004). Molecular and morphological identification of Colletotrichum species of clinical interest. Journal of Clinical Microbiology 42: 2450-2454.', 0.5125823616981506]]
Context 9: [['Jayawardena, R. S., Hyde, K. D., Damm, U., Cai, L., Liu, M., Li, X. H., Zhang, W., Zhao, W. S., and Yan, J. Y. (2016). Notes on currently accepted species of Colletotrichum. Mycosphere, 7, 1192-1260.', 0.5112658739089966]]

query: What are the potential risks of fungicide resistance in managing anthracnose?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Present and Future Management of Anthracnose: Fungicides, including chemicals such as benzimidazoles (e.g., thiabendazole, benomyl, and carbendazim) and sterol inhibitors (e.g., imazalil, prochloraz, and propiconazole), have been used effectively to control anthracnose disease in banana, mango, papaya, and avocado plants [140]. Benzimidazoles are commonly applied as dips or sprays to inhibit the anthracnose-causing fungus, Colletotrichum spp. [141], but the large-scale and continuous use of fungicides has led to the development of fungal resistance. For instance, benzimidazole-resistant Colletotrichum has been detected in mangoes and bananas [140]. Additionally, the excessive use of fungicides negatively impacts human health and the environment, as chemical residues often contaminate soil and water [142]. Biocontrol offers an alternative, non-toxic method for managing fruit crop anthracnose. Biocontrol agents, such as antagonistic microbes including yeast, bacteria, and filamentous fungi (particularly Trichoderma spp.), have shown promising results and are gaining popularity for their direct application to fruit surfaces post-harvest [143].', 0.9813397526741028]]
Context 1: [['Until highly resistant cultivars are available, growers must rely on chemical applications and cultural practices to reduce losses due to anthracnose. The failure of fungicides to control anthracnose epidemics may be due to the development of fungicide resistance in the Colletotrichum spp. population. For example, benomyl effectively reduced the incidence of anthracnose crown rot (Horn et al., 1972; Howard, 1971) and was used intensively by strawberry growers for years to control anthracnose and other diseases. However, the anthracnose pathogens, C. acutatum and C. fragariae, developed resistance to it and other benzimidazole fungicides (LaMondia, 1995; McInnes et al., 1992a; Smith and Black, 1992, 1993), rendering benomyl ineffective for anthracnose control in strawberry fields.', 0.9623141884803772]]
Context 2: [['There is an urgent need for multi- and single-site fungicide alternatives effective against anthracnose in strawberry nurseries and production fields. The antifungal antibiotic natamycin, widely used as a natural mold inhibitor in food products, has shown promise in controlling anthracnose root and crown infections caused by C. acutatum on strawberry transplants (Cordova et al. 2017; Haack et al. 2018). Similarly, fluazinam, a single-site respiration inhibitor fungicide from FRAC group 29, has demonstrated significant control of anthracnose fruit rot (Mertely et al. 2018). A request has been submitted through the Interregional Research Project Number 4 for its registration for nursery use only. Reducing the overlap of the same modes of action used during nursery and fruit production phases could help extend the lifespan of single-site fungicides at high risk of resistance.', 0.9575707316398621]]
Context 3: [['For the management of anthracnose crown rot, water washing or fungicide treatments of bare-root transplants have been utilized in the nursery or immediately before planting in production fields (Daugovish et al., 2009; Freeman et al., 1997). Running water effectively removes soil from root and crown tissues, potentially eliminating inoculum, but it does not control any infections already present (Koike et al., 2008). Pre-plant fungicide dips have been shown to decrease anthracnose crown rot; however, only two products are currently registered for this use in the United States. The single-site mode of action quinone outside inhibitor (QoI), azoxystrobin, has been widely used as a preplant dip and as a foliar treatment for managing anthracnose and other fungal diseases (Bartlett et al., 2002; Koike et al., 2008; Turechek et al., 2006). Resistance has been reported against this fungicide group in Colletotrichum acutatum populations from strawberries in Florida (Forcelini et al., 2016). During the 2015-16 California nursery crown rot outbreak, growers reported reduced efficacy of azoxystrobin dips, suggesting that resistance may also be present in California (K. Ivors, unpublished). A premixed product of the anilinopyrimidine cyprodinil and the phenylpyrrole fludioxonil is also registered, but phytotoxicity and stunting of plants have been reported under certain environmental conditions or following off-label exposure (G. Holmes, unpublished).', 0.9549835324287415]]
Context 4: [['Until highly resistant cultivars are available, growers must rely on chemical applications and cultural practices to reduce losses due to anthracnose. The failure of fungicides to control anthracnose epidemics may be attributed to the development of fungicide resistance in the Colletotrichum species population. For example, benomyl was shown to effectively reduce the incidence of anthracnose crown rot (Horn et al., 1972; Howard, 1971) and was used intensively by strawberry growers for years to control anthracnose and other diseases. However, the anthracnose pathogens, C. acutatum and C. fragariae, developed resistance to it and other benzimidazole fungicides (LaMondia, 1995; McInnes et al., 1992a; Smith and Black, 1992, 1993), leading to the ineffectiveness of benomyl for anthracnose control in strawberry fields.', 0.9372610449790955]]
Context 5: [['Past failures of fungicides to control anthracnose epidemics may have stemmed from the development of resistance in the Colletotrichum population. In the early 1970s, benomyl effectively reduced anthracnose crown rot incidence (Horn et al., 1972; Howard, 1971) and was widely used by strawberry growers for years. However, anthracnose pathogens developed resistance to it and other benzimidazole fungicides, rendering benomyl ineffective. In vitro and greenhouse trials have been conducted to identify fungicides to which Colletotrichum pathogens have developed resistance (LaMondia, 1993, 1995; McInnes et al., 1992a, 1992b; Smith and Black, 1991, 1992, 1993). Current fungicide labels address pathogen resistance by restricting the number of consecutive and total applications of a product per season. For instance, the fungicides Abound (azoxystrobin, Syngenta, Greensboro, NC), Cabrio (pyraclostrobin, BASF, Research Triangle Park, NC), and Pristine (pyraclostrobin and boscalid, BASF) are limited to four or five applications per season, with no more than two consecutive applications before alternating with a fungicide that has a different mode of action. Natural products have also been evaluated as alternative fungicides, offering different modes of action, lower toxicity, and increased efficacy (Abril et al., 2008).', 0.9099065661430359]]
Context 6: [['Anthracnose crown rot of strawberry, caused by Colletotrichum acutatum, is an important disease affecting California nursery and fruit production. Preplant dip treatments of transplants with fludioxonil-cyprodinil or azoxystrobin are industry standards for managing the disease and have been used extensively. Following reports of reduced efficacy of azoxystrobin in the field, high levels of quinone outside inhibitor (QoI) resistance were detected in California isolates of the pathogen. Resistance was associated with the G143A mutation in the cytochrome b gene, similar to a previous report from Florida, and there were no detected fitness penalties in pathogenicity or virulence. Therefore, several alternative fungicides were investigated in laboratory and field studies. Subsequently, the new biofungicide natamycin was identified. Baseline sensitivities of 74 isolates of C. acutatum to natamycin were determined to be unimodal, with a range from 0.526 to 1.996 mg/ml (mean 0.973 mg/ml).', 0.8808204531669617]]
Context 7: [['In-vitro trials have been used to screen fungicides for their ability to control anthracnose (LaMondia, 1993; McInnes et al., 1992b; Smith and Black, 1992). Smith and Black (1993) reported that all 16 C. acutatum, 14 out of 18 C. fragariae, and both C. gloeosporioides isolates tested in vitro were resistant to benomyl, and all benomyl-resistant isolates were also resistant to carbendazim, which belongs to the same class of fungicides as benomyl. In a greenhouse study, plants treated with propiconazole exhibited lower disease severity ratings than those treated with captafol or benomyl (Smith and Black, 1991). However, the propiconazole-treated plants were shorter, with dark green leaves that appeared thicker than the leaves of untreated plants.', 0.6468988656997681]]
Context 8: [['In-vitro trials have been used to screen fungicides for their ability to control anthracnose (LaMondia, 1993; McInnes et al., 1992b; Smith and Black, 1992). Smith and Black (1993) reported that all 16 C. acutatum, 14 out of 18 C. fragariae, and both C. gloeosporioides isolates tested in vitro were resistant to benomyl, and all benomyl-resistant isolates were also resistant to carbendazim, which is in the same class of fungicides as benomyl. In a greenhouse study, plants treated with propiconazole had lower disease severity ratings than did plants treated with captafol or benomyl (Smith and Black, 1991). However, the propiconazole-treated plants were shorter with dark green leaves that appeared thicker than the leaves of untreated plants.', 0.6328296661376953]]
Context 9: [['As our understanding of the anthracnose pathogens and the epidemiology of anthracnose diseases has improved, so has our capacity to control these diseases. Changes in cultural practices have led to reduced levels of disease. Additionally, the development and registration of more effective fungicides for use on strawberries have significantly decreased losses due to anthracnose crown rot and fruit rot. The introduction of partially resistant cultivars has also helped mitigate economic losses due to these diseases. Nonetheless, growers may still experience severe losses when environmental conditions are highly conducive to anthracnose development.', 0.5466620922088623]]

query: How does Colletotrichum spp affect the root system of strawberry plants?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Abstract: Three Colletotrichum species—Colletotrichum acutatum J.H. Simmonds (teleomorph Glomerella acutata J.C. Guerber & J.C. Correll), Colletotrichum fragariae A.N. Brooks, and Colletotrichum gloeosporioides (Penz.) Penz. & Sacc. in Penz. [teleomorph Glomerella cingulata (Stoneman) Spauld. & H. Schrenk]—are major pathogens of strawberry (Fragaria × ananassa). Strawberry anthracnose crown rot has been a destructive disease in commercial strawberry fields in the southeastern United States since the 1930s. The causal fungus, C. fragariae, can infect all aboveground plant parts; however, the disease is most severe when it infects the crown, leading to crown rot, wilt, and death.', 0.9840050935745239]]
Context 1: [['Anthracnose caused by Colletotrichum species is one of the most destructive diseases affecting strawberry production worldwide. Fungi of the genus Colletotrichum, which are ancient and co-evolved with flowering plants, rank eighth among the ten most economically important fungal pathogens and have diversified to adapt to various hosts. Since its first report in the United States in 1931, strawberry anthracnose has spread globally, resulting in devastating economic, social, and ecological consequences. In many ways, producing organic strawberries is largely impractical because of this disease. Colletotrichum species pathogenic to strawberries have been extensively characterized. This review aims to provide an accurate inventory of these species by revisiting their discovery history over the past 90 years. A total of 23 Colletotrichum species, clustered into five species complexes and two singleton taxa, have been accepted as strawberry pathogens with a global occurrence illustrated. The relative prevalence of distinct Colletotrichum species associated with strawberries has been systematically analyzed in China. Finally, the host range of the two prevailing species, C. fructicola and C. siamense, which cause significant damage globally, is summarized, with the goal of improving diagnostic accuracy and anthracnose management in agricultural ecosystems.', 0.926185667514801]]
Context 2: [['Three species of Colletotrichum—Colletotrichum acutatum J.H. Simmonds (teleomorph: Glomerella acutata J.C. Guerber & J.C. Correll), Colletotrichum fragariae A.N. Strawberry anthracnose crown rot has been a destructive disease in commercial strawberry fields in the southeastern United States since the 1930s. query: What is the risk of replanting strawberries in a field with a history of anthracnose?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Species of the fungal plant pathogen Colletotrichum are responsible for strawberry (Fragaria × ananassa Duch.) anthracnose, one of the major diseases affecting this crop. Major species that cause strawberry anthracnose include C. acutatum J.H. Simmons, C. fragariae Brooks, and C. gloeosporioides (Penz.) Penz. & Sacc. Symptoms of the disease manifest in various phases. Infection of mother plants with anthracnose may result in the collapse of the entire plant due to crown rot. In the nursery, lesions form on stolons that eventually girdle the runners, leading to wilting and death of unrooted daughter plants distal to the lesion. Death of daughter plants in the nursery and in field transplants can also be caused by crown rot. Infected transplants are capable of spreading the disease from the nursery to the field, and entire crops can be destroyed by anthracnose in strawberry fruit production fields under conducive environmental conditions.', 0.7805584073066711]]
Context 1: [['Anthracnose is an important disease of strawberry caused by Colletotrichum spp., which affects foliage, runners, crowns, and fruits (Howard et al., 1992). Three primary fungal pathogens—C. acutatum sensu lato, C. gloeosporioides sensu lato, and C. fragariae—are known to cause anthracnose disease in strawberries (Freeman and Katan, 1997). The crown rot syndrome is characteristic of infections from C. gloeosporioides sensu lato and C. fragariae, while fruit rot is mainly attributed to C. acutatum sensu lato, leading to significant yield losses (Howard et al., 1992). Currently, numerous species are classified under what is now known as the C. acutatum complex, with six species—C. acutatum sensu stricto, C. fioriniae, C. godetiae, C. nymphaeae, C. salicis, and C. simmondsii—identified as associated with strawberry anthracnose worldwide (Damm et al., 2012). Among these, C. nymphaeae is the most prevalent pathogen causing strawberry anthracnose globally, including in Iran (Baroncelli et al., 2015; Karimi et al., 2017; Wang et al., 2019). Currently, no effective chemical control methods exist for managing strawberry anthracnose; available options are limited to preventive treatments applied before fruit production (Denoyes-Rothan et al., 1999). Additionally, concerns about the toxic effects of chemical fungicides on the environment and the development of resistance in fungal strains highlight the need for alternative control strategies. Consequently, utilizing resistant cultivars appears to be the most efficient and practical approach for suppressing anthracnose development. In light of recent anthracnose outbreaks in strawberry fields in the Kurdistan province of Iran (Karimi et al., 2017), and the necessity for appropriate strategies to address this issue, the aim of this study was to evaluate the resistance of several commercial strawberry cultivars to the anthracnose fruit rot caused by C. nymphaeae under in vivo and greenhouse conditions.', 0.7366616725921631]]
Context 2: [['From May to September 1995, a severe outbreak of strawberry anthracnose was observed in several strawberry-growing nurseries in Israel. Following transplantation to production fields during September and October, entire beds of strawberry plants collapsed. Typical anthracnose symptoms observed from November 1995 to June 1996 included crown rot, flower blight, and green and ripe fruit rot. This marked the first record of strawberry anthracnose in Israel. Furthermore, in at least four production fields in the same region, hundreds of plants developed symptoms of stunting and chlorosis, which are atypical of strawberry anthracnose. When these plants were uprooted, most of their roots were dark brown and decayed. Colletotrichum was readily isolated from these samples.', 0.5435103178024292]]
Context 3: [["Anthracnose fungi can attack various parts of the strawberry plant, including crowns, petioles, leaves, fruit trusses, flowers, buds, and fruit. The fungi's ability to attack multiple plant parts, coupled with the involvement of several pathogen species, contributes to the complex nature of strawberry anthracnose. Brooks reported in 1931 that C. fragariae caused spotting and girdling of runners, and later indicated that it also caused spotting of petioles and crown rot in a summer nursery, leading to wilting and death of the plants. Researchers in Louisiana observed all these symptoms and noted that crown rot also occurred in the fruit production field.", 0.4666459262371063]]
Context 4: [['Madden, L.V., Wilson, L.L., Ellis, M.A. 1993. Field spread of anthracnose in strawberry. Plant Disease. 77:861–866.', 0.46432986855506897]]
Context 5: [['From 2010 to 2016, we conducted surveys of anthracnose in strawberries in Miaoli County. More than 50% of diseased plants exhibited symptoms characteristic of anthracnose crown rot (ACR), as described by McInnes et al. (1992). ACR resulted in plant losses of up to 30-40% during the seedling stage and around 20% after transplanting. Initial symptoms in crown tissue included a marbled red and white appearance, which progressed to brown rot and eventual rapid wilting of the plant. Anthracnose symptoms also appeared on other parts of the plant, including leaves, petioles, runners, fruits, and roots. These symptoms manifested as circular black spots on leaves, withering and girdling on runners.', 0.4552491009235382]]
Context 6: [['The establishment of transplants in the field is a critical phase in strawberry production in Israel. Plants affected by strawberry anthracnose during this stage face significant mortality rates.', 0.4346989691257477]]
Context 7: [['So far, anthracnose epidemics have affected strawberry nurseries and production fields worldwide. Reports on Colletotrichum spp. associated with strawberries, curated from literature in PubMed and Clarivate combined with fungal database searches (Farr and Rossman, 2022), were compiled to understand the global diversity and occurrence of the causal agents of strawberry anthracnose. From our findings, since 1931 until July 9, 2022, there have been over 220 citations and 310 records related to the identification of causal agents of strawberry anthracnose at the genus level of Colletotrichum in 36 countries across six continents, with 282 records providing pathogen identification at the species or species complex level.', 0.37137776613235474]]
Context 8: [['Howard CM, Albregts EE. Anthracnose. In: Compendium of Strawberry Diseases. American Phytopathological Society: Paul St, ed. Maas JL, USA; 1984. pp. 85-87.', 0.35324591398239136]]
Context 9: [['Introduction: The spread of strawberry anthracnose can be exacerbated by the use of infected runner plantlets (Hirayama et al. 2010). Effective management strategies must consider these factors to mitigate disease outbreaks.', 0.3319876194000244]]

query: What are the risks of introducing new plants into a field with known anthracnose issues?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Additional Keywords: anthracnose, disease spread, Fragaria × ananassa, models, quantitative epidemiology.', 0.24646815657615662]]
Context 1: [['Anthracnose spreads within a field by splashing water, and living mulches (such as wheat, rye, or ryegrass) in row middles have been shown to reduce disease spread within a field. Sublethal doses of grass-specific herbicides, such as sethoxydim, may be used to prevent excessive growth of ryegrass (Gupton, 2000). Organic mulches, such as wheat straw or pine needles, also reduce splash and result in a lower incidence of anthracnose compared to rows mulched with plastic (Madden, 1992; Smith and Spiers, 1986). Additionally, anthracnose is less severe when water is supplied to plants using drip irrigation rather than overhead irrigation (Madden, 1992; Smith and Spiers, 1986). Anthracnose crown rot was observed to be less severe in commercial fields when strawberries were grown in soils with low nitrogen fertility (Howard et al., 1992). In greenhouse studies, Smith (1987, 1989) determined that strawberries grown in soils with high levels of nitrogen, especially from ammonium sources, are more susceptible to anthracnose than plants grown in soils with lower nitrogen levels or those with high levels of calcium nitrate.', 0.2061273753643036]]
Context 2: [['Hemmi, T. (1920). Kurze Mitteilung über drei Fälle von Anthracnose auf Pflanzen. Annals of the Phytopathological Society of Japan, 1(3), 13–21.', 0.19057658314704895]]

Additionally, anthracnose is less severe when water is supplied to plants using drip irrigation rather than overhead irrigation (Coelho et al., 2008; Madden, 1992; Smith and Spiers, 1986).', 0.1894514560699463]]

query: What role does MEGA X play in understanding the evolutionary history of pathogens?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [["Over the past decade, genome sequencing has become an efficient and potent means to investigate a broad array of biological systems, from large-scale studies of biological diversity to tracking the evolution and origin of pathogenic microbes. The numerous steps required to glean interpretable and actionable results from raw sequence data invariably require comparative analysis of molecular sequences to discover functional and adaptive genome differences. The Molecular Evolutionary Genetics Analysis (MEGA) software provides tools to conduct such analyses. MEGA includes a large repertoire of programs for assembling sequence alignments, inferring evolutionary trees, estimating genetic distances and diversities, inferring ancestral sequences, computing timetrees, and testing selection. Over the last 25 years, MEGA's use in evolutionary analysis has been cited in over one hundred thousand studies in diverse biological fields.", 0.8392084240913391]]
Context 1: [['The Molecular Evolutionary Genetics Analysis (MEGA) software implements various analytical methods and tools for phylogenomics and phylomedicine. We report a transformation of MEGA to enable cross-platform use on Microsoft Windows and Linux operating systems. MEGA X does not require virtualization or emulation software and provides a uniform user experience across platforms. Additionally, MEGA X has been upgraded to utilize multiple computing cores for many molecular evolutionary analyses. MEGA X is available in two interfaces (graphical and command line) and can be downloaded free of charge from www.megasoftware.net.', 0.4114741086959839]]
Context 2: [['Kumar, S., Stecher, G., Li, M., Knyaz, C. & Tamura, K. MEGA X: molecular evolutionary genetics analysis across computing platforms. Mol. Biol. Evol. 35, 1547–1549 (2018).', 0.2994410991668701]]

query: How does the geographical origin of strawberry transplants affect the prevalence of C. fragariae infections in the southeastern United States?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Colletotrichum fragariae, the original anthracnose fungus, was first identified in Florida in 1931 (Brooks, 1931). It spread throughout the southeastern United States, causing crown rot and the death of many plants in strawberry nurseries during the 1970s (Horn et al., 1972). This pathogen has a narrow host range, infecting only strawberries and a few weed hosts, and is rarely found outside the southeastern U.S. Generally, C. fragariae causes more severe petiole and crown symptoms than C. acutatum, and some researchers consider it to be a host-specific or con-specific form of C. gloeosporioides (Howard, 1983; Howard et al., 1992; Sutton, 1992).', 0.922752857208252]]
Context 1: [['From a historical perspective, identifying the causal agents of strawberry anthracnose has faced considerable confusion at the species level for a long time. This process has gradually evolved from coarse estimates to precise identifications, as noted by Ji et al. in Phytopathology Research (2022). The first report of strawberry infection by C. fragariae occurred over 90 years ago in the southeastern USA (Brooks 1931). Morphological observations make it difficult to distinguish C. fragariae from C. gloeosporioides, the latter of which was described in the nineteenth century for a pathogen isolated from citrus in Italy (Penzig 1882). Consequently, early-stage strawberry anthracnose was often attributed to either C. fragariae or C. gloeosporioides.', 0.6831451058387756]]
Context 2: [['Smith BJ, Black LL. Resistance of strawberry plants to Colletotrichum fragariae affected by environmental conditions. Plant Dis. 1987;71:834–7. https://doi.org/10.1094/PD-71-0834.', 0.2432175576686859]]
Context 3: [['Colletotrichum fragariae and Colletotrichum acutatum are known to cause anthracnose diseases in strawberries. C. fragariae was initially assumed to be the causal agent of strawberry anthracnose in the United States until 1986, when Smith and Black reported the presence of C. acutatum on strawberries in the United States. This fungus had previously been documented as causing anthracnose fruit rot of strawberries in Queensland, Australia (Simmonds, 1965); however, it had likely existed in the United States for some time under the name Gloeosporium spp. (Maas, 1984).', 0.22645485401153564]]

Context 6: [['The fungi Colletotrichum fragariae and Colletotrichum acutatum cause anthracnose diseases in strawberries. C. fragariae was originally assumed to be the sole causal agent of strawberry anthracnose in the United States until 1986, when Smith and Black reported the presence of C. acutatum on strawberries in the U.S. This fungus had previously been reported to cause anthracnose fruit rot in Queensland, Australia (Simmonds, 1965); however, it may have been present in the U.S. for some time under the name Gloeosporium spp. (Maas, 1984).', 0.20586729049682617]]
Context 7: [['The name C. fragariae was originally applied to isolates associated with a disease affecting strawberry (Fragaria × ananassa) runners (stolons) and petioles in Florida (Brooks 1931). Although it was placed in synonymy with C. gloeosporioides by von Arx (1957), it has continued to be referenced in the literature for strawberry-associated Colletotrichum isolates. Sutton (1992) accepted it as distinct, although he noted the confusion surrounding the application of the name. The designation of one of Brooks’s cultures (CBS 142.31 = IMI 346325) as the epitype of C. fragariae by Buddie et al. (1999) has provided a modern genetic basis for this name. The ex-epitype culture of C. fragariae is positioned in a strongly supported clade containing isolates from a diverse range of hosts worldwide, including the ex-epitype culture of C. theobromicola, which is regarded as an earlier name for C. fragariae as accepted in this paper.', 0.20454084873199463]]
Context 8: [['Smith, B. J., and Black, L. L. 1987. Resistance of strawberry plants to Colletotrichum fragariae affected by environmental conditions. Plant Disease 71:834-837.', 0.20330499112606049]]
Context 9: [['Acutatum (Gunnell and Gubler, 1992). Since host origin was deemed less important, von Arx (1957) placed C. fragariae in synonymy with C. gloeosporioides. However, researchers have generally retained the name C. fragariae when dealing with the pathogen on strawberries (Howard and Albregts, 1984; Mass and Howard, 1985; Sutton, 1992). Gunnell and Gubler (1992) reported that C. fragariae could be clearly distinguished from C. acutatum and C. gloeosporioides by its morphology on strawberry leaf agar. Delimitation of these species remains problematic because literature references to C. acutatum and C. gloeosporioides may actually refer to other species (Shivas and Tan, 2009; Sreenivasaprasad et al., 1994).', 0.20146922767162323]]

query: How does MEGA X facilitate phylogenetic analysis in evolutionary biology?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['The Molecular Evolutionary Genetics Analysis (MEGA) software implements various analytical methods and tools for phylogenomics and phylomedicine. We report a transformation of MEGA to enable cross-platform use on Microsoft Windows and Linux operating systems. MEGA X does not require virtualization or emulation software and provides a uniform user experience across platforms. Additionally, MEGA X has been upgraded to utilize multiple computing cores for many molecular evolutionary analyses. MEGA X is available in two interfaces (graphical and command line) and can be downloaded free of charge from www.megasoftware.net.', 0.9829922318458557]]
Context 1: [["Over the past decade, genome sequencing has become an efficient and potent means to investigate a broad array of biological systems, from large-scale studies of biological diversity to tracking the evolution and origin of pathogenic microbes. The numerous steps required to glean interpretable and actionable results from raw sequence data invariably require comparative analysis of molecular sequences to discover functional and adaptive genome differences. The Molecular Evolutionary Genetics Analysis (MEGA) software provides tools to conduct such analyses. MEGA includes a large repertoire of programs for assembling sequence alignments, inferring evolutionary trees, estimating genetic distances and diversities, inferring ancestral sequences, computing timetrees, and testing selection. Over the last 25 years, MEGA's use in evolutionary analysis has been cited in over one hundred thousand studies in diverse biological fields.", 0.6901463866233826]]
Context 2: [['We have also enhanced MEGA’s computational core by increasing the number of methods that can utilize multiple processors and cores on the same machine. This improvement will significantly reduce the runtime for computationally demanding inferences. Users can specify the maximum number of cores to deploy in the Analysis Preferences dialog box (FIG. 2G). By default, MEGA X uses all available cores, minus one, ensuring that no more than 80% of RAM is consumed. Computational methods benefiting from calculation parallelization include those for selecting the best model for nucleotide or amino acid substitutions and bootstrap tests of molecular phylogenies employed with distance-based and parsimony-based methods. Users can already utilize multiple cores during the heuristic search for the Maximum Likelihood (ML) tree in MEGA.', 0.3951544761657715]]
Context 3: [['In conclusion, the cross-platform MEGAX will benefit many existing users and encourage others to consider using MEGAX in their research and teaching endeavors. The consistency of user experience across platforms should be particularly useful in facilitating collaborative analyses within and among research groups, as well as in teaching diverse groups of students. In the near future, we aim to complete the development of a macOS version to make MEGAX available on all major operating systems.', 0.26188334822654724]]
Context 4: [['Tamura, K., Stecher, G., Peterson, D., Filipski, A., & Kumar, S. (2013). MEGA6: Molecular evolutionary genetics analysis version 6.0. Molecular Biology and Evolution, 30, 2725–2729.', 0.22120071947574615]]
Context 5: [['Waterhouse AM, Procter JB, Martin DM, Clamp M, Barton GJ. 2009. Bioinformatics.', 0.22026759386062622]]
Context 6: [['Tamura, K., Stecher, G., Peterson, D., et al. (2013). MEGA6: Molecular Evolutionary Genetics Analysis version 6.0. Molecular Biology and Evolution.', 0.21536165475845337]]
Context 7: [['Key Words: multiple sequence alignment, metagenome, protein structure, progressive alignment, parallel processing.', 0.21371711790561676]]
Context 8: [['Multiple sequence alignment (MSA) plays a crucial role in the evolutionary analysis of biological sequences. MAFFT is an MSA program first released in 2002 (Katoh et al. 2002). Due to its high performance (Nuin et al. 2006; Golubchik et al. 2007; Dessimoz and Gil 2010; Letsch et al. 2010; Sahraeian and Yoon 2011; Sievers et al. 2011), MAFFT has gained popularity in recent years. Following the review of the previous version (version 6) by Katoh and Toh (2008b), we have continuously enhanced its accuracy, speed, and utility in practical applications. These improvements and techniques have been documented in various papers (Katoh et al. 2009; Katoh and Toh 2010; Katoh and Frith 2012; Katoh and Standley 2013).', 0.20221196115016937]]
Context 9: [['Altschul, S. F., Gish, W., Miller, W., Myers, E. W., and Lipman, D. J. (1990). Basic local alignment search tool. J. Mol. Biol., 215, 403-410.', 0.17750154435634613]]

query: What makes rDNA analysis a reliable tool for Colletotrichum research?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['One of the problems with accurately identifying Colletotrichum species using multigene analysis or barcoding is that many existing sequences in GenBank are incorrectly named. Crouch et al. (2009) revealed a high frequency of misidentification (86%) based on rDNA-ITS sequence similarity comparisons in GenBank within the C. graminicola species complex. Cai et al. (2009) analyzed 343 rDNA-ITS sequences of C. gloeosporioides in GenBank (accessed September 6, 2009) and found that an astounding 86% of these sequences showed considerable evolutionary divergence from the epitype of C. gloeosporioides, most likely representing other species. These error rates are remarkably high and indicate that accurate identification of Colletotrichum species using rDNA-ITS sequence data currently available in GenBank is impossible.', 0.8863882422447205]]

Context 4: [['DNA barcoding aims to establish an accurate, rapid, cost-effective, and universally accessible identification system for organisms by using short and standardized segments of the genome (Herbert et al., 2003, 2004; Summerbell et al., 2005). query: How do environmental factors like humidity and temperature influence disease development?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Our model is weather-driven, accounting for the effects of temperature, wetness duration, and rainfall on the epidemiological components leading to disease development. It operates with an hourly time step to better account for fluctuations in temperature, as well as in wetness duration and interruptions that directly influence the epidemiological processes. This ensures more accurate and robust predictions compared to models that operate with a daily time step (Scherm and Van Bruggen, 1994; Narouei-Khandan et al., 2020). However, to be incorporated into our model, new information must be provided at an hourly time step.', 0.3145134449005127]]
Context 1: [['Disease spread in the field is expectedly associated with rain events. However, as discussed previously (Madden, 1992; Madden et al., 1996), efforts to quantify properties of rain in relation to disease outbreaks or rates of disease development have yielded mixed results. Even when rain occurs, other weather variables, such as temperature, may correlate with disease variables just as strongly or even more so than rain itself. Given the complex effects of rain intensity, it is unsurprising that predicting disease increases based solely on rainfall is challenging.', 0.25558528304100037]]
Context 2: [['Huber, L. & Gillespie, T. J. Modeling leaf wetness in relation to plant disease epidemiology. Annu. Rev. Phytopathol. 30, 553–577 (1992).', 0.16285249590873718]]
Context 3: [['Hourly progress of IP depending on temperature: The hourly change in infection progress based on temperature.', 0.15903960168361664]]
Context 4: [['Correction factor for diseased sites: Adjustment factor for evaluating diseased locations.', 0.15483812987804413]]
Context 5: [['The moisture required for sporulation is provided by the host plant. The infection rate also depends on a correction factor (CF) for diseased sites (i.e., stages L, V, I, and R) and a multiplication factor (Rc), representing the proportion of daughter lesions generated per mother lesion, which is influenced by temperature (RcT) and wetness duration (RcWD). Infection occurs during the period of host susceptibility (HS), which is regulated by the plant growth stage and varies among hosts. Latent sites become visible at the end of an incubation period (IP), and visible sites become infectious at the end of a latency period (LP). Both periods depend on temperature; the progression of IP and LP is determined by an incubation rate (INCR) and a latency rate (LATR), respectively. Infectious sites produce secondary conidia (CON) during the infectious period (iP) and are eventually removed at a removal rate (REMR).', 0.14678141474723816]]
Context 6: [['Latent sites: Locations where disease symptoms are not visible.', 0.14442549645900726]]
Context 7: [["The results of the predicted and observed disease progress for various crops are summarized in the table mentioned. Each entry includes the type of crop, the specific clade involved, the location and year of the study, and the corresponding weather variables, such as air temperature, relative humidity, rainfall, and wetness duration. Additionally, the table details the predicted infection severity, predicted disease severity, and the observed disease incidence over the monitoring period. This structured approach allows for a clear comparison between model predictions and actual observations, highlighting the model's accuracy and utility in predicting disease outbreaks across different plant species and environments.", 0.1433740109205246]]
Context 8: [['Duration of infectious period in optimum conditions: The time period during which an infectious site can spread disease under ideal conditions.', 0.136586993932724]]
Context 9: [['The experimental period involved light intensities ranging from 40% to 80%, with daylight intensity fluctuating between 550 and 1200 µmol m−2 s−1. The inoculated plants were treated with a solution containing 2 mL−1 of the inoculum and subsequently placed in a dew chamber set at 30 °C and 100% relative humidity (RH) for 2 days. Following this incubation, they were moved to a glasshouse maintained at temperatures between 24 and 28 °C (Gupton & Smith, 1991). After 17 days, the disease severity on each plant was assessed and rated on a disease index (DI) scale of 0 to 4, defined as follows: 0 for healthy plants; 1 for less than 50% of petioles affected; 2 for 50% or more petioles affected; 3 for wilted plants; and 4 for complete necrosis.', 0.1361294537782669]]

retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['In the soybean pathogenicity bioassay, the efficiency of infection was determined for C. truncatum pathotype F8-3B pAA1 transformants, lacking cutinase, five days after inoculation (DAI). Cutinase silenced transformants exhibited different percentages of reduction in infection efficiency on soybean leaves. The mean percentage of infection reduction was normalized against the wild type, with different letters above the bars indicating significant differences based on the analysis.', 0.9950264096260071]]
Context 1: [['The phytopathogenic fungus Colletotrichum truncatum infects and colonizes chili fruit through direct penetration of the cuticle. The cutinase gene of C. truncatum (CtCut1), a cutin-degrading enzyme, was identified, cloned, and shown to be essential for breaching the cuticle of chili fruit. The expression of the CtCut1 gene was studied through RNA-mediated gene silencing, and its impact on fungal pathogenicity was demonstrated. A vector, pAA1, encoding a hairpin RNA of GFP and CtCut1 was constructed and transformed into the virulent strain of C. truncatum, pathotype F8-3B. The F8-3B-pAA1 transformants exhibited reduced patterns of infection, with one isolate showing a 45.8% reduction in cutinase activity (reduction in CtCut1 transcript) compared to the wild type. Importantly, CtCut1-deficient strains were unable to infect detached chili and soybean hosts as efficiently as the wild type, showing a delay in the infection period. However, artificial wounding of the cuticle allowed these F8-3B-pAA1 transformants to infect and colonize host tissues, resulting in typical anthracnose disease lesions. Coupled with microscopy, these data suggested that the defect in pathogenicity was likely due to a failure in penetrating the host cutin. This research contributes to the understanding of plant-fungal interactions through the development of a fungal transformation system for C. truncatum and the implementation of RNAi technology, which provides an alternative genetic tool for studies of gene function, particularly for essential pathogenicity genes.', 0.9942254424095154]]
Context 2: [['The soybean pathogenicity bioassay revealed varying levels of soybean leaf infection when inoculated with various selected F8-3B-pAA1 transformants. These observations confirmed that the disturbance of the CtCut1 gene via RNA-mediated gene silencing (knockdown) altered the pathogenicity of the transformants. Indeed, the relative expression of the five selected F8-3B-pAA1 transformants showed different levels of CtCut1 transcription compared to the control wild type in the qRT-PCR assay. Lower levels of CtCut1 transcripts translated to reduced infection. Similar observations were noted in the Pyrenopeziza brassicae-Brassica napus system, where mutants lacking cutinase transcript expression failed to penetrate.', 0.949621319770813]]
Context 3: [['The study, published in the Journal of Plant Pathology and Microbiology (ISSN: 2157-7471, Volume 6, Issue 3), examined the role of cutinase and its impact on the pathogenicity of Colletotrichum truncatum (Auyong et al., 2015, doi:10.4172/2157-7471.1000259). It was likely that the only gene affected by the pAA1 hairpin was CtCut1. The pAA1 plasmid was versatile, containing restriction enzyme sites that facilitated the creation of a hairpin cassette for silencing any gene, provided the primers used were designed with compatible restriction enzyme sites. The success of this silencing was predicted to be partially enhanced by the relatively short 57-bp intron sequence in the pAA1 plasmid, as short intron sequences have been reported to provide stable and high silencing frequencies in Magnaporthe oryzae, sometimes leading to complete silenced phenotypes.', 0.9406245350837708]]
Context 4: [['The infection and colonization by F8-3B-pAA1 transformants on detached chili and soybean hosts were less efficient compared to the wild-type F8-3B, further suggesting the involvement of the gene during pathogenesis. Transformed strains were unable to infect normally, and there was a delay in infection, as indicated by the extremely slow development of anthracnose symptoms on chili fruits. It is suggested that direct penetration through the host cuticle during the infection process of C. truncatum was largely governed by the presence of cutinase in the fungus.', 0.9389491081237793]]
Context 5: [['In a soybean leaf bioassay, differences in the severity of infection were noted between the F8-3B-pAA1 transformants and the wild type at 5 days after inoculation (DAI). The transformed strains were categorized into two levels of pathogenicity: high (transformants F2, F5, and F8) and low (transformants F1, F4, F7, F9, and F10), indicating a reduction in infection efficiency. This was clearly illustrated by the varying degrees of anthracnose symptoms in the in planta soybean bioassay. The lesion regions on soybean leaves demonstrated that transformants with reduced expression of the cutinase gene (F2, F5, and F8) exhibited lower pathogenicity compared to the wild type.', 0.8880658745765686]]
Context 6: [['Taken together, these results demonstrate that the pAA1 plasmid is efficient and applicable for inducing gene silencing in most genes and Colletotrichum species. The observation indicated that the silencing of the cutinase gene may have altered the pathogenicity of the transformants. More durable and novel forms of disease control can be implemented when knowledge of the pathogenicity genes that trigger resistance is made available through this alternative genetic tool approach.', 0.7619175910949707]]
Context 7: [['In the pathogenicity bioassays, the fruit of C. annuum genotype Bangchang, which is susceptible to C. truncatum pathotype F8-3B [31], was used. Leaves of G. max genotype Bragg, a susceptible leguminous host of C. truncatum [42], were alternately used to verify the infection characteristics of the fungus. Successful transformants were identified by the absence of GFP expression. For this assessment, all specimens were placed on a glass slide in a water droplet, covered with a cover slip, and observed under a microscope. Images were captured using a Leica DC300F digital camera with Leica IM50 v.4 software. Wild-type F8-3B and transformants expressing GFP [30] were used as controls.', 0.5986155271530151]]
Context 8: [['In contrast, Skamnioti et al. [53] reported the existence of multiple cutinase families in Magnaporthe grisea, Fusarium graminearum, Botrytis cinerea, Aspergillus nidulans, and Neurospora crassa. They achieved RNA-mediated gene silencing in C. truncatum using a hairpin plasmid, specifically pAA1, which incorporated a short fragment of sGFP along with CtCut1 as the silencing target. This method allowed for variable but efficient knockdown of the cutinase gene in C. truncatum.', 0.4930102527141571]]
Context 9: [['Table Description: Table 2 provides consensus ratings of disease severity based on the scale proposed by Montri et al. It compares the severity of infections caused by both pAA1-transformed and wild type Colletotrichum truncatum on Capsicum annuum genotype Bangchang. The table lists various categories of disease severity, showing how the transformed strains and the wild type differ in terms of their impact on the plants. It emphasizes the significance of cutinase gene expression levels in determining pathogenicity, with marked differences in disease severity ratings reflecting the performance of the different transformants.', 0.4349943697452545]]

query: What measures can be taken to improve the resistance of strawberry plants to anthracnose?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Anthracnose is an important disease of strawberry caused by Colletotrichum spp., which affects foliage, runners, crowns, and fruits (Howard et al., 1992). Three primary fungal pathogens—C. acutatum sensu lato, C. gloeosporioides sensu lato, and C. fragariae—are known to cause anthracnose disease in strawberries (Freeman and Katan, 1997). The crown rot syndrome is characteristic of infections from C. gloeosporioides sensu lato and C. fragariae, while fruit rot is mainly attributed to C. acutatum sensu lato, leading to significant yield losses (Howard et al., 1992). Currently, numerous species are classified under what is now known as the C. acutatum complex, with six species—C. acutatum sensu stricto, C. fioriniae, C. godetiae, C. nymphaeae, C. salicis, and C. simmondsii—identified as associated with strawberry anthracnose worldwide (Damm et al., 2012). Among these, C. nymphaeae is the most prevalent pathogen causing strawberry anthracnose globally, including in Iran (Baroncelli et al., 2015; Karimi et al., 2017; Wang et al., 2019). Currently, no effective chemical control methods exist for managing strawberry anthracnose; available options are limited to preventive treatments applied before fruit production (Denoyes-Rothan et al., 1999). Additionally, concerns about the toxic effects of chemical fungicides on the environment and the development of resistance in fungal strains highlight the need for alternative control strategies. Consequently, utilizing resistant cultivars appears to be the most efficient and practical approach for suppressing anthracnose development. In light of recent anthracnose outbreaks in strawberry fields in the Kurdistan province of Iran (Karimi et al., 2017), and the necessity for appropriate strategies to address this issue, the aim of this study was to evaluate the resistance of several commercial strawberry cultivars to the anthracnose fruit rot caused by C. nymphaeae under in vivo and greenhouse conditions.', 0.9632675647735596]]
Context 1: [['Ballington, J.R., J.L. Shuman, B.J. Smith, and S.C. Hokanson. 2002. Breeding strawberries (Fragaria × ananassa) for resistance to anthracnose caused by Colletotrichum acutatum. Acta Horticulturae 567:89–92.', 0.9222878217697144]]
Context 2: [['Ballington, J.R., J.L. Shuman, B.J. Smith, and S.C. Hokanson. 2002. Breeding strawberries (Fragaria × ananassa) for resistance to anthracnose caused by Colletotrichum acutatum. Acta Hort. 567: 89—92.', 0.9130485653877258]]
Context 3: [['Introduction: The spread of strawberry anthracnose can be exacerbated by the use of infected runner plantlets (Hirayama et al. 2010). Effective management strategies must consider these factors to mitigate disease outbreaks.', 0.7629250884056091]]
Context 4: [['In the early 1980s, anthracnose became a significant disease affecting strawberries in the southeastern United States. In response, the USDA-ARS established a breeding program to develop anthracnose-resistant cultivars suited to the strawberry-growing regions of this area. This initiative was conducted at the Small Fruit Research Station in Poplarville, MS, and the Fruit Laboratory in Beltsville, MD, in collaboration with state experiment stations in Florida, Louisiana, and North Carolina (Galletta et al., 1997; Smith and Spiers, 1982).', 0.7585875988006592]]

Context 6: [['Ye, Z. W., Zheng, H. Q., & Tong, Y. M. (1997). First report on species of strawberry anthracnose pathogen in Shanghai suburbs and resistance of some strawberry cultivars to anthracnose. Acta Agriculturae Shanghai, 13, 75–80.', 0.6655624508857727]]
Context 7: [["Anthracnose fungi can attack various parts of the strawberry plant, including crowns, petioles, leaves, fruit trusses, flowers, buds, and fruit. The fungi's ability to attack multiple plant parts, coupled with the involvement of several pathogen species, contributes to the complex nature of strawberry anthracnose. Brooks reported in 1931 that C. fragariae caused spotting and girdling of runners, and later indicated that it also caused spotting of petioles and crown rot in a summer nursery, leading to wilting and death of the plants. Researchers in Louisiana observed all these symptoms and noted that crown rot also occurred in the fruit production field.", 0.5948440432548523]]

Context 9: [['Overall, the study highlights the importance of cultural practices and genetic resistance in managing strawberry anthracnose effectively.', 0.5576358437538147]]

query: Can harvesting ferns in wet weather conditions affect the movement of fungal spores between various farms?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Fern harvesting occurs throughout the year and in all weather conditions, including rain. Harvesters are contracted to work in various ferneries and may harvest from multiple fields and farms within the same day. The transport of conidia on clothing, tools, and equipment is believed to be a major mechanism by which the fungus spreads rapidly within and between ferneries. Wet clothing can easily absorb hydrophilic spores that are later transferred to the surfaces of susceptible leaves. Our results demonstrate that conidia can persist on clothing for periods that create a significant potential for long-distance transport and introduction into uninfested ferneries.', 0.9958447813987732]]

query: Do ap-PCR and restriction digest analyses of rDNA offer complementary insights into the genetic diversity of Colletotrichum species affecting crops like strawberries?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['rDNA genes exist as multiple copies in the genome. Due to the lesser conservation of sequence, the non-transcribed and internal transcribed spacer (ITS) regions between the small and large nuclear rDNA subunits are suitable for detecting recent evolutionary divergence within Colletotrichum. In our study, limited restriction digest analyses of PCR-amplified rDNA were utilized to differentiate representative isolates of C. gloeosporioides from a diverse range of hosts, as well as from rDNA of C. acutatum sourced from strawberry. Species-specific primers have been designed based on the dissimilarities in the sequences of the ITS regions from various Colletotrichum species. We employed such primers to differentiate between C. acutatum and C. gloeosporioides. As shown in Figure 5A, a single PCR-amplified fragment of 490 bp was evident in isolates of C. acutatum from a broad host range but was absent in C. gloeosporioides isolates. Similarly, primers specific for C. gloeosporioides and C. fragariae amplified a specific 450-bp fragment, allowing these two species to be distinguished from C. acutatum. This method also facilitated the differentiation between C. acutatum from almond, apple, peach, and strawberry, and C. gloeosporioides from papaya and citrus. These findings indicate that rDNA analysis serves as an effective taxonomic tool for species identification and diagnostic pathogen detection in plants, although it may not reveal subpopulations within a species.', 0.9722352623939514]]
Context 1: [['Random Amplified Polymorphic DNA (RAPD), or ap-PCR, has been extensively utilized for the identification and characterization of isolates in Colletotrichum. We employed ap-PCR using primers derived from minisatellite or repeat sequences (CAGCAGCAGCAGCAG, TGTCTGTCTGTCTGTC, GACACGACACGACAC, GACAGACAGACAGACA) to compare Colletotrichum species from almond, avocado, strawberry, and other fruits. Unique band patterns were observed among the clonal populations of C. acutatum from strawberry and C. gloeosporioides from almond, while avocado isolates exhibited polymorphisms.', 0.8400970101356506]]

query: What strategies can mitigate the risk of cross-resistance among different fungicide classes in agricultural pathogens?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['The document also references a study on the in vitro effectiveness of these fungicides, noting that Difenoconazole, Tebuconazole, and Mancozeb effectively inhibited fungal growth, likely due to their ability to interfere with sterol biosynthesis and enzyme activity. Furthermore, a negative cross-resistance phenomenon is discussed, indicating that the selection for resistance to one fungicide may lead to increased susceptibility to others with different mechanisms.', 0.37509819865226746]]
Context 1: [['Past failures of fungicides to control anthracnose epidemics may have stemmed from the development of resistance in the Colletotrichum population. In the early 1970s, benomyl effectively reduced anthracnose crown rot incidence (Horn et al., 1972; Howard, 1971) and was widely used by strawberry growers for years. However, anthracnose pathogens developed resistance to it and other benzimidazole fungicides, rendering benomyl ineffective. In vitro and greenhouse trials have been conducted to identify fungicides to which Colletotrichum pathogens have developed resistance (LaMondia, 1993, 1995; McInnes et al., 1992a, 1992b; Smith and Black, 1991, 1992, 1993). Current fungicide labels address pathogen resistance by restricting the number of consecutive and total applications of a product per season. For instance, the fungicides Abound (azoxystrobin, Syngenta, Greensboro, NC), Cabrio (pyraclostrobin, BASF, Research Triangle Park, NC), and Pristine (pyraclostrobin and boscalid, BASF) are limited to four or five applications per season, with no more than two consecutive applications before alternating with a fungicide that has a different mode of action. Natural products have also been evaluated as alternative fungicides, offering different modes of action, lower toxicity, and increased efficacy (Abril et al., 2008).', 0.24962472915649414]]
Context 2: [['Additional keywords: phosphonate fungicides, phosphorous acid.', 0.20766793191432953]]
Context 3: [['FRAC. 2017. FRAC Code List 2017: Fungicides sorted by mode of action (including FRAC code numbering). www.frac.info, Fungicide Resistance Action Committee.', 0.18949908018112183]]
Context 4: [['The sensitivity ranges of the isolates to various fungicides were 0.2 to 1.6 mg/ml and 0.002 to 0.2 mg/ml, respectively, with average values of 6.5 to 6.9 mg/ml, 1.5 to 0.6 mg/ml, 0.9 to 0.4 mg/ml, and 0.1 to 0.05 mg/ml, respectively. All isolates were more sensitive to difenoconazole, flusilazole, and carbendazim than to tebuconazole (P < 0.01). However, sensitivities to the same fungicide varied among isolates. Specifically, isolates SL-31 and TS-09 were the least sensitive to carbendazim and tebuconazole, with resistance ratios of 87.3 and 51.6, respectively. Sensitivities to difenoconazole and flusilazole were largely consistent across all isolates, with resistance ratios ranging from 1 to 4.6 and from 1 to 7, respectively. Therefore, difenoconazole and flusilazole could be recommended for disease control. Notably, differences in pathogenicity and fungicide sensitivity were not correlated with geographic regions. These findings indicate a high level of intraspecific diversity within the populations of Colletotrichum gloeosporioides s.s. responsible for walnut anthracnose. For effective management, a targeted control strategy should be developed based on different geographic regions.', 0.16209810972213745]]

It likely includes specific concentrations (EC50 values) for each fungicide tested, categorized by the type of isolate, highlighting the differential effectiveness of various fungicides against the pathogen based on its resistance profile.', 0.1135200783610344]]

query: What are the implications of finding multiple Colletotrichum species in a single strawberry field?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Based on published data, we discussed the prevalence of Colletotrichum species in strawberry fields in China. C. siamense and C. fructicola from the C. gloeosporioides sensu lato complex are currently the most prevalent. The prevalence of certain Colletotrichum species in strawberry fields in specific regions is influenced by the entire agricultural ecosystem, particularly through interconnections with neighboring plants and climate changes. The relative prevalence of different Colletotrichum species varies with geographic region and changes dynamically in certain areas. For example, in Shanghai, C. acutatum was identified before 2005 (Dai et al. 2006) but has not been detected since 2016 (Zhang et al. 2020). Similarly, an early report indicated that strawberry anthracnose caused by C. gloeosporioides was incidental, while C. acutatum was frequently detected (Kikuchi et al. 2010). However, a later study identified C. fructicola as the dominant virulent species on strawberries in Japan (Gan et al. 2017). Such shifts have also occurred in Korea (Nam et al. 2008, 2013). This shift in the prevailing Colletotrichum species associated with strawberries in various regions may be linked to global warming, changes in cultivation patterns—from open fields to protected cultivation or soilless elevated cultivation—and the substitution of strawberry varieties.', 0.9851868748664856]]
Context 1: [['Smith BJ, Black LL. Morphological, cultural, and pathogenic variation in Colletotrichum species isolated from strawberry. Plant Dis. 1990;74(1):69–76. https://doi.org/10.1094/PD-74-0069.', 0.7362478971481323]]
Context 2: [['Despite intensive research that has contributed to the understanding of the Colletotrichum genus pathogenic to strawberries, there is still a lack of an accurate inventory of these causal agents. The population and prevalence of strawberry-virulent Colletotrichum species have not been systematically investigated in major producers such as China. To address these gaps, this review aims to summarize the biodiversity of Colletotrichum species pathogenic to strawberries by examining the global discovery history. Subsequently, the prevalence of Colletotrichum species pathogenic to strawberries in China was analyzed using available data. Finally, we categorized the host range of the two predominant species responsible for strawberry crown rot. This knowledge has important applications for biosecurity risk management (e.g., proper risk estimation in strawberry seedling trade), accurate diagnosis, and anthracnose control. It further lays the groundwork for systematically managing Colletotrichum genera in agricultural ecosystems, not only for the strawberry industry.', 0.7226434350013733]]
Context 3: [['Ji et al. (2022) reported that a total of 11 Colletotrichum species have been identified as pathogens of strawberries in China, which will be comprehensively introduced later. In Europe, strawberry anthracnose is largely attributed to the C. acutatum complex. Strains of C. godetiae infectious to strawberries have been documented in Ireland and Norway (Baroncelli et al. 2015; Chethana et al. 2016). In Denmark, C. nymphaeae is the only Colletotrichum species reported as a strawberry pathogen (Braganca et al. 2016), with similar reports from Bulgaria (Bobev et al. 2002; Jelev et al. 2008; Jayawardena et al. 2016b), Switzerland, and Portugal (Baroncelli et al. 2015). Both C. godetiae and C. nymphaeae were identified as strawberry pathogens in the Netherlands (Baroncelli et al. 2015; Jayawardena et al. 2016b) and Spain (Damm et al. 2012; Baroncelli et al. 2015).', 0.7042124271392822]]

query: How can MEGA X be used to infer genetic distances between populations?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [["Over the past decade, genome sequencing has become an efficient and potent means to investigate a broad array of biological systems, from large-scale studies of biological diversity to tracking the evolution and origin of pathogenic microbes. The numerous steps required to glean interpretable and actionable results from raw sequence data invariably require comparative analysis of molecular sequences to discover functional and adaptive genome differences. The Molecular Evolutionary Genetics Analysis (MEGA) software provides tools to conduct such analyses. MEGA includes a large repertoire of programs for assembling sequence alignments, inferring evolutionary trees, estimating genetic distances and diversities, inferring ancestral sequences, computing timetrees, and testing selection. Over the last 25 years, MEGA's use in evolutionary analysis has been cited in over one hundred thousand studies in diverse biological fields.", 0.5961828827857971]]
Context 1: [['We have also enhanced MEGA’s computational core by increasing the number of methods that can utilize multiple processors and cores on the same machine. This improvement will significantly reduce the runtime for computationally demanding inferences. Users can specify the maximum number of cores to deploy in the Analysis Preferences dialog box (FIG. 2G). By default, MEGA X uses all available cores, minus one, ensuring that no more than 80% of RAM is consumed. Computational methods benefiting from calculation parallelization include those for selecting the best model for nucleotide or amino acid substitutions and bootstrap tests of molecular phylogenies employed with distance-based and parsimony-based methods. Users can already utilize multiple cores during the heuristic search for the Maximum Likelihood (ML) tree in MEGA.', 0.39667364954948425]]
Context 2: [['Kumar, S., Stecher, G., Li, M., Knyaz, C. & Tamura, K. MEGA X: molecular evolutionary genetics analysis across computing platforms. Mol. Biol. Evol. 35, 1547–1549 (2018).', 0.37396183609962463]]
Context 3: [['The Molecular Evolutionary Genetics Analysis (MEGA) software implements various analytical methods and tools for phylogenomics and phylomedicine. We report a transformation of MEGA to enable cross-platform use on Microsoft Windows and Linux operating systems. MEGA X does not require virtualization or emulation software and provides a uniform user experience across platforms. Additionally, MEGA X has been upgraded to utilize multiple computing cores for many molecular evolutionary analyses. MEGA X is available in two interfaces (graphical and command line) and can be downloaded free of charge from www.megasoftware.net.', 0.2639378607273102]]
Context 4: [['Tamura, K., Peterson, D., Peterson, N., Stecher, G., and Nei, M. 2011. MEGA5: Molecular evolutionary genetics analysis using maximum likelihood, evolutionary distance, and maximum parsimony methods. Mol. Biol. Evol. 28:2731-2739.', 0.19296149909496307]]
