query: Why is integrated pest management (IPM) recommended for controlling anthracnose?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Bergstrom, G. C., and Nicholson, R. L. 1999. The biology of corn anthracnose: Knowledge to exploit for improved management. Plant Dis. 83:596-608.', 0.1760920286178589]]
Context 1: [['Additional Keywords: anthracnose, disease spread, Fragaria × ananassa, models, quantitative epidemiology.', 0.15331332385540009]]
Context 2: [['As our understanding of the anthracnose pathogens and the epidemiology of anthracnose diseases has improved, so has our capacity to control these diseases. Changes in cultural practices have led to reduced levels of disease. Additionally, the development and registration of more effective fungicides for use on strawberries have significantly decreased losses due to anthracnose crown rot and fruit rot. The introduction of partially resistant cultivars has also helped mitigate economic losses due to these diseases. Nonetheless, growers may still experience severe losses when environmental conditions are highly conducive to anthracnose development.', 0.14881910383701324]]
Context 3: [['Key words: anthracnose, Ascomycota, Colletotrichum acutatum, Gloeosporium, Glomerella, phylogeny, systematics.', 0.1487503945827484]]
Context 4: [['Strandberg, J. O., Stamps, R. H., and Norman, D. J. 1996. Fern Anthracnose: A Guide for Effective Disease Management. University of Florida, Agricultural Experiment Station Technical Bulletin 900.', 0.14485140144824982]]
Context 5: [['As our knowledge of the anthracnose pathogens and the epidemiology of anthracnose diseases has increased, so has our ability to control these diseases. Changes in cultural practices have resulted in reduced levels of disease. Additionally, the development and registration of more effective fungicides for use on strawberries have significantly reduced losses from both anthracnose crown rot and fruit rot. Anthracnose-resistant cultivars have also diminished economic losses due to these diseases. Nevertheless, growers may still experience severe losses when environmental factors are highly favorable for anthracnose development.', 0.14461997151374817]]
Context 6: [['Anthracnose is a significant disease affecting grape crops (Dowling et al., 2020). Beyond causing severe yield losses, anthracnose epidemics can diminish the quality of the produce (Waller et al., 2002; Dowling et al., 2020). The most economically damaging symptoms often include blossom blight and fruit rots; however, necrotic lesions may also develop on leaves, stems, and twigs, leading to plant deterioration and reduced fruit quality (Dowling et al., 2020).', 0.13238374888896942]]
Context 7: [['Crouch J, Beirn LA. 2009. Anthracnose of cereals and grasses. Fungal Diversity 39:19–44.', 0.12745554745197296]]
Context 8: [['Erregers der Anthraknose an Bergenien. Nachrichtenblatt des Deutschen Pflanzenschutzdienstes 52: 1–4.', 0.12684158980846405]]
Context 9: [['Until highly resistant cultivars are available, growers must rely on chemical applications and cultural practices to reduce losses due to anthracnose. The failure of fungicides to control anthracnose epidemics may be due to the development of fungicide resistance in the Colletotrichum spp. population. For example, benomyl effectively reduced the incidence of anthracnose crown rot (Horn et al., 1972; Howard, 1971) and was used intensively by strawberry growers for years to control anthracnose and other diseases. However, the anthracnose pathogens, C. acutatum and C. fragariae, developed resistance to it and other benzimidazole fungicides (LaMondia, 1995; McInnes et al., 1992a; Smith and Black, 1992, 1993), rendering benomyl ineffective for anthracnose control in strawberry fields.', 0.1255153864622116]]

query: Which assay revealed the least incidence of crown infection among strawberry cultivars?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [["Strawberry anthracnose fruit rot (AFR) is one of the main limiting factors for the strawberry production industry worldwide, including Iran. Due to restrictions associated with fungicide applications, their adverse environmental effects, and the potential development of resistance among fungal strains, the use of resistant cultivars is considered the most effective method for managing this disease. This study evaluated the reactions of 25 commercial strawberry cultivars against the fungus Colletotrichum nymphaeae, which causes AFR, using fruit, leaf, and crown-based assays. Results indicated that the cultivars exhibited varying reactions to the disease, depending on the inoculation of their leaves, fruits, and crowns with C. nymphaeae PET1 under in vivo and greenhouse conditions. The fruit-based assay was determined to be a better indicator of susceptibility to AFR due to the nature of the disease. Overall, 'Blakemore' and 'Kurdistan' cultivars showed significantly higher resistance compared to others, except for 'Aliso', 'Mrak', 'Diamant', 'Yallova', 'New Kurdistan', 'Mac Donance', and 'Ten Beauty'. Conversely, the 'Gaviota' cultivar was found to be significantly the most susceptible, aside from 'Camarosa'. The commonly grown commercial cultivars in Iran, including 'Camarosa', 'Paros', 'Pajaro', and 'Queen Eliza', were categorized as susceptible to highly susceptible in this study. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first study evaluating the reaction of commercial strawberry cultivars to C. nymphaeae causing strawberry AFR.", 0.9790908694267273]]
Context 1: [["Previous studies examining variation in strawberry resistance to C. fragariae found a wide range of susceptibility among cultivars and aggressiveness among isolates. One study identified a significant cultivar by isolate interaction. Host resistance studies using homothallic G. cingulata isolates were less conclusive due to the limited number of isolates tested. Significant variation in cultivar susceptibility and isolate aggressiveness was observed, along with a significant cultivar by isolate interaction in one study. In a later study using a different set of isolates, only cultivar susceptibility varied. For C. acutatum, a specific interaction between strawberry cultivars and isolates was noted, with a single dominant gene appearing to be responsible for this interaction. This gene results in either an incompatible reaction with cultivars carrying it or an intermediate degree of compatibility. Assays used to evaluate resistance to C. fragariae and C. acutatum were based on symptom development on petioles or foliage and did not specifically assess the plants' ability to resist necrosis of crown tissue. Variation in cultivar susceptibility to C. gloeosporioides isolates from Florida has not yet been investigated.", 0.7692007422447205]]
Context 2: [['Pathogenicity Assay: The susceptible cultivar "Taoyuan No. 1" was used for all inoculation tests in this study. The pathogenicity of Colletotrichum spp. (one isolate from each species) was examined following Koch\'s postulates. Following inoculation, the seedlings were covered with plastic bags to maintain >90% relative humidity for 3 days at 30°C, then incubated in a growth chamber for 11 days at 30°C and 70% relative humidity under a 12-h light/12-h dark photoperiod. Context 3: [['On inoculated strawberry plants, isolates of C. fructicola and C. murrayae exhibited strong pathogenicity, affecting both leaves and petioles, with plant mortality observed 30 days post-inoculation. Under suitable environmental conditions, anthracnose can lead to significant yield losses (Henz et al. 1992). Infected strawberries may develop lesions on the petiole and crown, potentially resulting in plant collapse and death. In nurseries, lesions can form on stolons, leading to the wilting and death of unrooted daughter plants (Freeman and Katan 1997). Context 3: [['The germination and sporulation of Colletotrichum acutatum were characterized over time on strawberry leaves (cv. Tristar) and plastic coverslips incubated at 26°C under continuous wetness. Conidia germinated within 3 hours after inoculation and formed melanized appressoria with pores by 9 hours after inoculation. Host penetration was not observed up to 7 days after inoculation. Production of secondary conidia on conidial surfaces began within 6 hours after inoculation. Secondary conidiation was responsible for up to a threefold increase in the total number of conidia within 7 days after inoculation. Primary conidia and hyphae began to collapse 48 hours after inoculation, whereas melanized appressoria remained intact. These findings suggest that appressoria and secondary conidia of C. acutatum produced on symptomless strawberry foliage may be significant sources of inoculum for fruit infections.', 0.8770158886909485]]
Context 4: [['Leandro, L. F. S., Gleason, M. L., Nutter, F. W., Jr., Wegulo, S. N., and Dixon, P. M. 2003. Strawberry plant extracts stimulate secondary conidiation by Colletotrichum acutatum on symptomless leaves. Phytopathology 93:1285-1291.', 0.8029960989952087]]

Context 6: [['Our evidence suggests that Colletotrichum acutatum inoculum can survive and multiply on symptomless strawberry leaves, and that the production of secondary conidia may increase inoculum when susceptible tissue is not available. Greater awareness of the surreptitious fungal dynamics on symptomless plants may also justify changes in currently recommended control strategies. For instance, early fungicide applications might effectively reduce initial inoculum production on developing plants, thereby decreasing subsequent epidemic development on fruit.', 0.7437773942947388]]
Context 7: [['Eastburn and Gubler (1990) monitored the survival of Colletotrichum acutatum in strawberry tissue over a 7-week period at three temperatures (11°C, 25°C, and 40°C) and three soil moisture conditions (flooded, moist at 10.6%, and air dry). Recovery of C. acutatum from infected tissue declined rapidly under flooded soil conditions at soil temperatures of 25°C or higher. In contrast, recovery from tissue samples was 100% after 7 weeks at both 10°C and 25°C. Similar results were observed in our study regarding the survival of conidia and sclerotia in infected leatherleaf fern debris under varying soil moisture levels.', 0.7014694213867188]]
Context 8: [['Colletotrichum acutatum appears to compete poorly as a saprophyte but can survive in soil and on inanimate surfaces for various periods, depending on the conditions. Eastburn and Gubler found that mycelium in strawberry tissue survived in air-dried soil for at least seven weeks, even at temperatures up to 40°C, and it remained viable in moist soil for seven weeks at both 10°C and 25°C. Freeman et al. reported that conidia of C. acutatum survived for at least one year in air-dry soil; however, in soil at field capacity, conidia survived for less than two weeks. At 11% soil moisture, the time required for 95% loss of viability was between 70 and 75 days. C. acutatum could not be recovered from strawberry crowns that were naturally infected and buried in either methyl-bromide fumigated or untreated soil after five months. In Florida, C. acutatum could no longer be recovered from buried infected crowns after 56 days.', 0.6096396446228027]]
Context 9: [['Secondary conidiation of Colletotrichum acutatum on strawberry leaves 24 hours after inoculation was observed by scanning electron microscopy. In the images, a primary conidium with a secondary conidium attached to the conidial phialide is shown, highlighting the mucilage surrounding the primary conidium and appressorium. The primary conidium was seen with a secondary conidium detaching from the hypha, with detached secondary conidia potentially produced by a partially visible conidial phialide. Initially, appressoria were hyaline but then became melanized, developing basal pores on both leaves and coverslips. Many sessile appressoria did not become melanized but instead formed a germination tube at the tip where another melanized appressorium developed. By 48 hours after inoculation, the primary conidia used for inoculating plants began to collapse and disintegrate, while several hyphal segments and conidial cells became melanized.', 0.5825093984603882]]

Common hosts encompass many dicotyledonous plants, including strawberries, apples, citrus, and stone fruits; serious diseases have also been reported on leatherleaf ferns and pines. query: What research methods are employed to study the impact of Colletotrichum on citrus plant physiology?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [["The citrus industry is one of the most significant fruit sectors globally. The Mediterranean countries rank second only to China in fruit production and are the largest fruit exporters after South Africa (FAO 2016). Therefore, understanding all pathogens affecting this crop is imperative. The current study aimed to investigate the major citrus production areas in Europe through large-scale sampling and to identify isolates using a polyphasic approach. This method revealed many cryptic and new Colletotrichum species associated with citrus, classified into four modern taxonomic species complexes. Surveys conducted in 2015 and 2016 across commercial nurseries, orchards, gardens, and plant collections aimed to determine the occurrence of Colletotrichum spp. related to citrus and allied genera (Atlantia, Fortunella, Microcitrus, Murraya, Poncirus). The study's specific objectives included conducting extensive sampling of fresh plant materials, cultivating Colletotrichum isolates, subjecting these isolates to DNA sequence analyses alongside morphological characterization, comparing results with other phylogenetic studies, and evaluating the pathogenicity of Colletotrichum species on citrus fruit. Major diseases of citrus caused by Colletotrichum species include postbloom fruit drop (PFD), petal necrosis, and key lime anthracnose (KLA), with C. abscissum and C. gloeosporioides being significant agents. Extensive investigations across several citrus-producing regions revealed varying associations of these pathogens with different citrus species.", 0.9804056882858276]]

query: How can molecular markers, such as arbitrarily primed PCR (ap-PCR) and rDNA analysis, be applied to distinguish between C. gloeosporioides and C. acutatum populations from different geographical regions?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['In this study, we successfully identified isolates as C. siamense, C. fructicola, or C. acutatum using our new PCR-based assay. Additional C. acutatum isolates from our collection, previously characterized by Schnabel et al. (2006), were also accurately identified (data not shown). We do not know the composition of species within the C. gloeosporioides complex from other peach production areas; therefore, this PCR assay may need validation with isolates from different geographic regions. Additionally, this identification method may not effectively distinguish C. gloeosporioides and C. acutatum isolates from other hosts at the species level since both species belong to complexes that include more than 20 different species each (Damm et al. 2012a; Weir et al. 2012).', 0.861433207988739]]
Context 1: [['rDNA genes exist as multiple copies in the genome. Due to the lesser conservation of sequence, the non-transcribed and internal transcribed spacer (ITS) regions between the small and large nuclear rDNA subunits are suitable for detecting recent evolutionary divergence within Colletotrichum. In our study, limited restriction digest analyses of PCR-amplified rDNA were utilized to differentiate representative isolates of C. gloeosporioides from a diverse range of hosts, as well as from rDNA of C. acutatum sourced from strawberry. Species-specific primers have been designed based on the dissimilarities in the sequences of the ITS regions from various Colletotrichum species. We employed such primers to differentiate between C. acutatum and C. gloeosporioides. As shown in Figure 5A, a single PCR-amplified fragment of 490 bp was evident in isolates of C. acutatum from a broad host range but was absent in C. gloeosporioides isolates. Similarly, primers specific for C. gloeosporioides and C. fragariae amplified a specific 450-bp fragment, allowing these two species to be distinguished from C. acutatum. This method also facilitated the differentiation between C. acutatum from almond, apple, peach, and strawberry, and C. gloeosporioides from papaya and citrus. These findings indicate that rDNA analysis serves as an effective taxonomic tool for species identification and diagnostic pathogen detection in plants, although it may not reveal subpopulations within a species.', 0.8179784417152405]]
Context 2: [['Fig. 7. Interspecies band patterns of arbitrarily primed polymerase chain reaction (AP-PCR) amplified genomic DNA from isolates of Colletotrichum obtained from various hosts using primers (A) (CAG)5 and (B) (GACA)4, represented as follows: CA (C. acutatum from strawberry, California); CF (C. fragariae from strawberry, Mississippi); CG-1 and CG-2 (C. gloeosporioides from strawberry, Florida); PCN-3 and PCN-4 (C. gloeosporioides from pecan, Louisiana); PCN-5 (C. acutatum from pecan, Alabama); PCH-13 (C. gloeosporioides from peach, South Carolina); SF-7 (C. acutatum from peach, South Carolina); STR-2 and STR-3 (C. acutatum from strawberry, South Carolina); APL-7 (C. gloeosporioides from apple, North Carolina); ALM-B, ALM-G, ALM-I, and ALM-K (C. gloeosporioides from almond, Israel); and AVO-1 and AVO-5 (C. gloeosporioides from avocado, Israel). Lanes M contain DNA size markers in kilobases.', 0.6132774353027344]]
Context 3: [['Overall, this study illustrates the significant contributions that the Apn2/MAT locus can make to the molecular systematics of the C. gloeosporioides complex. We report the development and application of a novel set of primers as valuable tools for generating sequence data that can clarify species and even population relationships. Based on our findings, we propose an alternative perspective on the evolutionary relationships among the studied species. Given our demonstration that gene-tree discordance can be problematic in recently diverged species, we emphasize that highly variable markers, such as the ApMAT, are better suited to resolve phylogenetic relationships. We hope this contribution will encourage further research into this complex, ultimately leading to a deeper understanding of its structure, evolution, and diversity.', 0.5462943911552429]]
Context 4: [['Species-specific primers have primarily been designed based on differences in the sequence of the internal transcribed spacer (ITS) regions of representative Colletotrichum isolates from different species. These primers have subsequently been used to differentiate between C. acutatum and C. gloeosporioides across a broad host range and to detect latent infections in plants.', 0.5333132743835449]]
Context 5: [['RAPD fragments specific to different genetic groups of C. acutatum, namely CA-clonal and CA-variable, may be very useful for designing specific PCR primers for rapid and reliable detection and differentiation between the subgroups pathogenic on strawberry. This is particularly important for the detection of C. acutatum and for identifying the genetic groups CA-clonal or CA-variable in epidemiological studies. Furthermore, using additional primers or other markers such as AFLPs would increase the likelihood of detecting avirulence genes associated with pathogenic variability. This approach could help discriminate between the two pathogenicity groups within the CA-clonal group and differentiate between the highly virulent United States isolates of C. gloeosporioides and the predominantly mildly virulent isolates in Europe.', 0.5171024203300476]]
Context 6: [['Using markers outside the range of the C. gloeosporioides complex is likely to fail due to their highly variable nature, even in priming sites. For instance, the markers developed by Crouch et al. (2009a) to amplify partial fragments of the Apn2 gene and intergenic regions in the same locus for gramini-colous Colletotrichum species could not be utilized for the isolates analyzed in this study (data not shown). After obtaining homologous sequences from isolates of the C. gloeosporioides complex, alignments revealed significant divergence between the two species groups. However, these markers are more suitable than barcode genes for accurately dissecting and unraveling the diversity and evolutionary relationships in a complex of closely related species. Moreover, as Cai et al. (2009) noted, the selection and decision regarding the most suitable barcode gene(s) can only occur during the species delimitation process, as that is when we understand which taxa need to be distinguished. Thus, we first need to fully resolve the C. gloeosporioides complex using a set of highly informative genes before adequately searching for and selecting a barcode gene.', 0.3228644132614136]]
Context 7: [['Recent analyses using CHEF gel and molecular markers on Australian isolates of C. gloeosporioides have revealed two distinct clonal populations. A sensitivity assay conducted on Colletotrichum acutatum isolates from almond in California and strawberry, alongside C. gloeosporioides isolates from almond and avocado in Israel, indicated that only the avocado isolate is sensitive to benomyl.', 0.28798478841781616]]
Context 8: [['The regional nature of most studies, along with often restricted genetic sampling across the global diversity of C. gloeosporioides, and minimal overlap between isolates treated and gene regions targeted, means that the relationships among newly described species are frequently poorly understood. While some authors have adopted a genetically restricted concept for C. gloeosporioides, many applied researchers continue to use the name broadly (e.g., Bogo et al. 2012; Deng et al. 2012; Kenny et al. 2012; Parvin et al. 2012; Zhang et al. 2012). In this paper, we accept both concepts as useful and valid. When used in a broad sense, we refer to the taxon as the C. gloeosporioides species complex or C. gloeosporioides s. lat.', 0.2752822935581207]]
Context 9: [['The recent epitypification of C. gloeosporioides marked an important milestone for taxonomic studies of the complex (Cannon et al., 2008). Since then, the availability of living ex-type strains and sequence data has provided a solid reference for comparison with isolates. However, criteria for species delimitation have been debated over the years, with Colletotrichum serving as a notable example (Cannon et al., 2008). Until recently, single-locus phylogenies dominated the molecular systematics of the C. gloeosporioides complex, despite their limited resolving ability (Sreenivasaprasad et al., 1993, 1996; Johnston and Jones, 1997; Nguyen et al., 2009; Polashock et al., 2009). Specifically, the internal transcribed spacers (ITS) flanking the 5.8S ribosomal RNA represent the most widely sequenced region in Colletotrichum phylogenetic studies. Consequently, ITS-based C. gloeosporioides specific primers (Mills et al., 1992) have been extensively utilized for identifying Colletotrichum fungi over the past 10 to 15 years. However, there are significant concerns regarding the resolving power of ITS for closely related species (Cai et al., 2009; Crouch et al., 2009b). Recognizing the limitations of ITS and similar markers has led to an increasing necessity for the development and use of more informative loci. Molecular phylogenetic analyses using multilocus datasets are now providing an objective approach to determining species boundaries.', 0.26096177101135254]]

query: What is the best way to stop strawberry plants from dying after transplanting?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['In Korea, strawberries (Fragaria × ananassa) are favored for winter cultivation when the production of other vegetables and fruits is relatively low. In 2003, strawberries were planted on a total area of 7,503 hectares in Korea, with plastic greenhouse cultivation comprising 7,172 hectares and a total production of 205,427 tonnes for the fresh market (Anonymous, 2004). Forcing, where strawberries are transplanted into greenhouses in mid-September and induced to fruit in December (Oda, 1991), is becoming more common in Korea. June-bearing cultivars such as Maehyang, Akihime, and Nyoho, used for forcing, have proven difficult to grow due to their susceptibility to anthracnose (Nam et al., 1998; Kim & Nam, 1999). Anthracnose is one of the most damaging diseases of strawberries, causing wilting and death of transplants in the nursery field. The pathogen responsible for the disease in Korea is Colletotrichum gloeosporioides, first reported in 1992 (Kim et al., 1992).', 0.4152081608772278]]
Context 1: [['Although strawberries are considered a minor crop, they provide a significant source of income for many fruit and nursery growers. In the United States, strawberries were cultivated on nearly 20,000 hectares in 1989, yielding a total production of 555,000 tons valued at $520 million. Florida ranks second only to California in the production of fresh-market strawberries. For U.S. winter production (December through March), strawberries are grown on approximately 2,400 hectares. The major cultural problems faced by the Florida strawberry industry include: 1) anthracnose diseases, 2) yearly infestations of the two-spotted spider mite (Tetranychus urticae Koch), and 3) variability in the quality of nursery transplants. Commercial fields are established annually, similar to California practices. Freshly dug transplants are sourced from nurseries in Florida or from northern states and Canada. The use of transplants from northern nurseries is crucial to avoid anthracnose disease issues and to ensure that plants have undergone sufficient natural chilling to induce floral bud initiation.', 0.30804890394210815]]
Context 2: [['Plant Maintenance: Strawberry plants (cv. New plants were planted weekly, and the plants were maintained in a greenhouse at the Ohio Agricultural Research and Development Center. Preliminary studies found that lesion appearance coincided with the timing of the first sporulation.', 0.28670674562454224]]
Context 3: [['The establishment of transplants in the field is a critical phase in strawberry production in Israel. Plants affected by strawberry anthracnose during this stage face significant mortality rates.', 0.24870143830776215]]
Context 4: [['Strawberry transplants are primarily produced in nurseries located in northern latitudes, such as Canada, or at higher altitudes in North Carolina and California (Brown 2003). query: What are the key lifestyle adaptations observed among members of the C. acutatum species complex, such as biotrophy, necrotrophy, and endophytism?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Members of the C. acutatum species complex have been well-documented from agricultural and natural hosts worldwide (Perfect et al., 1999; Peres et al., 2005; Sreenivasaprasad and Talhinhas, 2005). The scientific community has long studied the biomolecular processes regulating this lifestyle, especially those related to the switch from biotrophy to necrotrophy. The species complex has a very wide host range. Meta-analyses have revealed that C. acutatum s.l. strains are associated with infections in hundreds of species from over 90 genera of plants (Magnoliophyta: monocotyledons and dicotyledons, Pinophyta, and Pteridophyta), along with at least two insect species (Dufresne et al., 2000; Thon et al., 2002; Wharton and Diéguez-Uribeondo, 2004; O’Connell et al., 2012; Marcelino et al., 2008; Mascarin et al., 2016). In a few cases, associations have been noted with marine ecosystems (Manire et al., 2002; Namikoshi et al., 2002). There appears to be little to no evidence of co-evolution between host and pathogen, particularly in cultivated fruit systems like strawberry and olive, which are susceptible to many members of this species complex (Jayawardena et al., 2016).', 0.9933993816375732]]
Context 1: [['Although C. acutatum usually produces necrotic symptoms of various types on most hosts, the host–pathogen interaction appears to be more biotrophic compared to some other species, such as C. gloeosporioides. C. acutatum survives and competes poorly as a saprophyte in most cases. Nevertheless, it has been isolated from many plant species and is not always associated with disease. This species may colonize the surface of plant tissues as an epiphyte or endophyte under certain circumstances, on both hosts and non-hosts, without producing symptoms.', 0.4831434190273285]]
Context 2: [['Our research aims to present a comprehensive revision of the C. acutatum species complex. We thoroughly survey the constituent taxa and delineate additional species where needed. We have examined a large number of C. acutatum s. lat. strains, isolated from various hosts and geographic areas. Multi-locus molecular analysis serves as the basis for species recognition, although morphological and cultural characters allowing alternative means of species recognition are provided where possible.', 0.1810537427663803]]
Context 3: [['At this point, it was widely presumed that C. acutatum was a species complex containing several constituent taxa. However, there was substantial reluctance to recognize the clades involved as independent species due to the lack of distinctive morphological and cultural characters. For example, C. lupini was not formally recognized as separate from C. acutatum by Talhinhas et al. (2002) or by Sreenivasaprasad & Talhinhas (2005). Some attempts were made to address these concerns through the adoption of formae speciales, such as C. acutatum f. sp. pineum (Dingley & Gilmour 1972), C. acutatum f. sp. hakeae (Lubbe et al. 2004), and C. acutatum f. sp. fioriniae (Marcelino et al. 2008). However, this mechanism for recognizing pathology-related taxa is now rarely used.', 0.18044698238372803]]
Context 4: [['Recently, more focus has been placed on conidium morphology, particularly shape and dimensions. The acute conidial ends that contribute to the typical fusiform shape are considered critical morphological features of C. acutatum (Simmonds 1965). However, the name C. acutatum has been applied to various species exhibiting fusiform conidia, many of which are closely related to C. acutatum s. str. Moreover, conidial shape can show significant variation both within the species and among strains (Damm et al. 2012). Studies have shown that the fusiform conidial shape is not a consistent feature in the C. acutatum species complex. For instance, Talhinhas et al. (2002) noted that Colletotrichum isolates from Lupinus spp. (equivalent to C. lupini) displayed varying proportions of conidia with round ends or one round and one acute end, resulting in cylindrical or clavate shapes. In a recent investigation, many strains previously classified as C. gloeosporioides, based on typical cylindrical conidia (Cannon et al. 2008), were found to belong to different species within the C. acutatum complex (Damm et al. 2012). Additionally, there are species with acute-ended conidia that are phylogenetically distinct from the C. acutatum complex, such as C. pseudoacutatum and C. proteae (Cannon et al. 2012; Damm et al. 2012; Liu et al. 2013). The revision of the C. acutatum complex has recognized 31 species through a multilocus molecular approach, significantly advancing our understanding of these plant pathogens (Damm et al. 2012).', 0.1704297810792923]]
Context 5: [['The general disease cycles of C. acutatum from different hosts often share common attributes. All produce acervuli with abundant conidia on one or more host tissues, and conidia are splash-dispersed, serving as the primary inoculum source for most infections. Conidia can survive in a gelatinous matrix if conditions are appropriate; however, they typically germinate to produce appressoria and quiescent infections. The tissues on which sporulation and reproduction occur differ among various hosts, and the fate of appressoria and quiescent infections varies greatly. As far as is known, the sexual stage plays only a minor role in the life cycle of C. acutatum. Although the pathogen exhibits overlapping survival strategies, the disease cycles of C. acutatum on different hosts can be grouped according to four general lifestyles.', 0.16352660953998566]]
Context 6: [['In this study, the C. acutatum species complex was identified exclusively on the Aeolian Islands (Italy), a volcanic archipelago located north of Sicily.', 0.16145135462284088]]
Context 7: [['The C. acutatum species complex has undergone speciation more prolifically than previously suspected, indicating that it is likely still evolving rapidly. The emergence of new species is likely encouraged by modern global agricultural practices, which facilitate the mixing of gene pools, combined with imperfect phytosanitary regulations.', 0.16006693243980408]]
Context 8: [['Alternative lifestyles? Most reports of the natural recovery of C. acutatum have come from agricultural hosts. However, recent findings suggest that C. acutatum may inhabit a variety of unexplored niches. For instance, it has been isolated from an immunocompromised sea turtle. Additionally, a single isolate was found colonizing the leaves of a tree species in a native forest. Whether these isolates originated from agricultural ecosystems or represent a new source of pathogens remains largely unexamined.', 0.15639375150203705]]
Context 9: [['INTRODUCTION: As a significant pathogen, C. acutatum has been treated as a regulated organism for many years.', 0.14996658265590668]]

query: What are the specific roles of Colletotrichum fructicola and C. siamense in causing chili anthracnose in various climatic conditions in India?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Sharma G and Shenoy BD (2014) reported on the involvement of Colletotrichum fructicola and C. siamense in chili anthracnose in India, also found in Archives of Phytopathology and Plant Protection (47: 1179-1194).', 0.9969484210014343]]
Context 1: [['Sharma, G., & Shenoy, B.D. (2014). Colletotrichum fructicola and C. siamense are involved in chili anthracnose in India. Archives of Phytopathology and Plant Protection, 47, 1179–1194.', 0.99680495262146]]
Context 2: [['Colletotrichum siamense is reported for the first time causing anthracnose of Capsicum annuum in Indonesia and Sri Lanka. This is also the first report of C. fructicola causing anthracnose of chili in Taiwan and Thailand, and C. plurivorum in Malaysia and Thailand. Of the species with straight conidia, C. scovillei (acutatum complex) was the most prevalent throughout the surveyed countries, except for Sri Lanka, from where this species was not isolated. Colletotrichum siamense (gloeosporioides complex) was also common in Indonesia, Sri Lanka, and Thailand.', 0.9685644507408142]]
Context 3: [['Multigene phylogenetic analyses of Colletotrichum species causing anthracnose disease of Capsicum in Asia showed high species diversity, identifying 11 different Colletotrichum species, including three novel species. Although C. siamense has been reported to infect many plant species before, this is the first report of C. siamense causing anthracnose in chili in Indonesia and Sri Lanka. Additionally, this is the first report of C. fructicola infecting chili in Thailand and Taiwan. All three novel species are new additions to the Colletotrichum species causing anthracnose in chili. More surveys in countries in Asia and Oceania are needed to identify the diversity and prevalence of species causing chili anthracnose. Understanding the taxonomy and pathogenicity of Colletotrichum spp. has significant implications for fruit and vegetable industries, particularly regarding the serious biosecurity concerns associated with the introduction of exotic pathogens.', 0.9525867104530334]]
Context 4: [['The distribution of Colletotrichum species that cause anthracnose in chili varies across different countries that cultivate this crop. For instance, only six out of the 24 Colletotrichum pathogens of chili have been identified in Australia (De Silva et al. 2017a), while only three species have been reported in Thailand (Mongkolporn and Taylor 2018) and five in Malaysia (Noor and Zakaria 2018). In most previous studies, species identification relied solely on morphological data, leading to uncertainties in the taxonomy of Colletotrichum spp. responsible for anthracnose in chili-producing Asian countries. Accurate identification of these pathogens is crucial for mitigating the risk of new pathogen incursions, which could have devastating impacts on local industries. Additionally, precise species identification is vital for resistance breeding programs and understanding the host range of various species. Some Colletotrichum species, such as C. karstii, C. siamense, and C. truncatum, have broad host ranges (Cannon et al. 2012; Damm et al. 2012b). The main Colletotrichum species known to cause anthracnose in chili are primarily from the acutatum and gloeosporioides complexes. Recently, additional species from the boninense and orchidarium complexes have also been implicated (Diao et al. 2017; Damm et al. 2019). Therefore, understanding the taxonomy, diversity, pathogenicity, and distribution of Colletotrichum species affecting chili is essential.', 0.9511674046516418]]
Context 5: [['A collection of Colletotrichum species isolates was analyzed for their anthracnose severity scores on a 0–9 scale across seven chili cultivars at the ripe red fruit stage. The isolates included various species such as C. aenigma, C. cliviae, C. conoides, C. endophytica, C. fioriniae, C. fructicola, C. gloeosporioides, C. grossum, C. hymenocallidis, C. incanum, C. karstii, C. liaoningense, C. scovillei, C. truncatum, and C. viniferum.', 0.7607025504112244]]
Context 6: [['Colletotrichum fructicola, initially reported as a pathogen of coffee berries in Thailand, showed rapid growth and strong sporulation in hot, humid conditions. This species accounted for 52.7% of all samples in the study and was dominant in all regions sampled, suggesting it is the primary cause of strawberry anthracnose in Zhejiang. Pathogenicity experiments indicated that C. fructicola was more pathogenic than C. gloeosporioides or C. aenigma, in line with previous findings that noted C. murrayae as the dominant species in Hubei, China, although none were found in this study.', 0.7074997425079346]]
Context 7: [['Colletotrichum species causing anthracnose in chili have previously been identified as C. acutatum (characterized by straight conidia with acute ends), C. gloeosporioides (straight conidia with obtuse ends), and C. truncatum (falcate conidia) (Than et al. 2008; Mongkolporn et al. 2010). However, recent multigene phylogenetic analyses have revealed that C. acutatum is a species complex (the acutatum complex) consisting of 34 closely related species (Marin-Felix et al. 2017), with seven species identified as responsible for anthracnose in chili (Mongkolporn and Taylor 2018). Similarly, C. gloeosporioides has been found to be a complex of 38 closely related species (Marin-Felix et al. 2017), with nine species identified as pathogens of chili (Mongkolporn and Taylor 2018). Morphological traits are insufficient to differentiate many species with straight conidia, particularly those in the acutatum and gloeosporioides complexes affecting chili. Thus, multigene phylogenetic analyses are essential for accurate species identification (De Silva et al. 2017a).', 0.6824071407318115]]
Context 8: [['Chilli pepper fruits with blemishes have reduced marketability (Manandhar et al., 1995). Colletotrichum spp. are among the most significant plant pathogens globally, causing the economically important disease anthracnose in a wide range of hosts, including cereals, legumes, vegetables, and tree fruits (Bailey & Jeger, 1992). Among these hosts, Capsicum annuum is considered the most important vegetable in Thailand (Poulos, 2002) and is severely infected by anthracnose, with yield losses of up to 50% (Pakdeevaraporn et al., 2005). Typical anthracnose symptoms on chilli fruits include sunken necrotic tissues with concentric rings of acervuli. Accurate taxonomic identification is crucial for plant breeding and disease management (Freeman et al., 1998). Traditionally, identification and characterization of Colletotrichum species were based on morphological characteristics such as the size and shape of conidia and appressoria, the presence of setae or a teleomorph, and cultural characteristics like colony morphology.', 0.5682207942008972]]
Context 9: [['Than, P.P., Prihastuti, H., Phoulivong, S., Taylor, P.W.J., and Hyde, K.D. (2008c). Chilli anthracnose disease caused by Colletotrichum species. Journal of Zhejiang University: Science B, 9: 764-778.', 0.38339662551879883]]

query: What are the most effective strategies for managing anthracnose in strawberry production?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Anthracnose is an important disease of strawberry caused by Colletotrichum spp., which affects foliage, runners, crowns, and fruits (Howard et al., 1992). Three primary fungal pathogens—C. acutatum sensu lato, C. gloeosporioides sensu lato, and C. fragariae—are known to cause anthracnose disease in strawberries (Freeman and Katan, 1997). The crown rot syndrome is characteristic of infections from C. gloeosporioides sensu lato and C. fragariae, while fruit rot is mainly attributed to C. acutatum sensu lato, leading to significant yield losses (Howard et al., 1992). Currently, numerous species are classified under what is now known as the C. acutatum complex, with six species—C. acutatum sensu stricto, C. fioriniae, C. godetiae, C. nymphaeae, C. salicis, and C. simmondsii—identified as associated with strawberry anthracnose worldwide (Damm et al., 2012). Among these, C. nymphaeae is the most prevalent pathogen causing strawberry anthracnose globally, including in Iran (Baroncelli et al., 2015; Karimi et al., 2017; Wang et al., 2019). Currently, no effective chemical control methods exist for managing strawberry anthracnose; available options are limited to preventive treatments applied before fruit production (Denoyes-Rothan et al., 1999). Additionally, concerns about the toxic effects of chemical fungicides on the environment and the development of resistance in fungal strains highlight the need for alternative control strategies. Consequently, utilizing resistant cultivars appears to be the most efficient and practical approach for suppressing anthracnose development. In light of recent anthracnose outbreaks in strawberry fields in the Kurdistan province of Iran (Karimi et al., 2017), and the necessity for appropriate strategies to address this issue, the aim of this study was to evaluate the resistance of several commercial strawberry cultivars to the anthracnose fruit rot caused by C. nymphaeae under in vivo and greenhouse conditions.', 0.9973512887954712]]
Context 1: [['Overall, the study highlights the importance of cultural practices and genetic resistance in managing strawberry anthracnose effectively.', 0.8507513999938965]]
Context 2: [['In the early 1980s, anthracnose became a significant disease affecting strawberries in the southeastern United States. In response, the USDA-ARS established a breeding program to develop anthracnose-resistant cultivars suited to the strawberry-growing regions of this area. This initiative was conducted at the Small Fruit Research Station in Poplarville, MS, and the Fruit Laboratory in Beltsville, MD, in collaboration with state experiment stations in Florida, Louisiana, and North Carolina (Galletta et al., 1997; Smith and Spiers, 1982).', 0.49838384985923767]]
Context 3: [['So far, anthracnose epidemics have affected strawberry nurseries and production fields worldwide. Reports on Colletotrichum spp. associated with strawberries, curated from literature in PubMed and Clarivate combined with fungal database searches (Farr and Rossman, 2022), were compiled to understand the global diversity and occurrence of the causal agents of strawberry anthracnose. From our findings, since 1931 until July 9, 2022, there have been over 220 citations and 310 records related to the identification of causal agents of strawberry anthracnose at the genus level of Colletotrichum in 36 countries across six continents, with 282 records providing pathogen identification at the species or species complex level.', 0.453860342502594]]
Context 4: [["Anthracnose fungi can attack various parts of the strawberry plant, including crowns, petioles, leaves, fruit trusses, flowers, buds, and fruit. Brooks reported in 1931 that C. fragariae caused spotting and girdling of runners, and later indicated that it also caused spotting of petioles and crown rot in a summer nursery, leading to wilting and death of the plants. query: How are strawberries harvested and processed for commercial markets?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['A labor crisis in the 1960s in the Pacific Northwest spurred interest in breeding strawberry cultivars for machine harvesting. A portion of the cooperative USDA-Oregon State Experiment Station project was directed toward this goal, which included the Oregon State University Agriculture Engineering Department, responsible for building harvesting and capping equipment. Selecting strawberries with an erect fruiting habit that ripen most of their fruit at once and are easy to cap—important traits for machine harvesting—is feasible due to the variability in available strawberry germplasm. Inheritance patterns for simultaneous ripening of fruit indicated that early-season parents, such as ‘Sunrise’, could produce progeny with a high percentage of ripe fruit at one time (Lawrence et al., 1975). Semi-erect and easy-capping types could also be derived from parents such as ‘Hood’, ‘Benton’, and other selections from the Pacific Northwest and California. Additionally, selections that have over 80% of the fruit ripe at one time and possess the easy-cap character could also exhibit good processing qualities (Lawrence et al., 1975). The cultivar ‘Linn’ was introduced in 1975 as a machine-harvest processing berry; however, commercial machine harvesting did not materialize, and ‘Linn’ lost favor because it does not maintain berry size as plants age and is too tart for the fresh market. Currently, machine harvesting of strawberries for the commercial processing industry remains at an experimental stage in the Pacific Northwest.', 0.9620236754417419]]
Context 1: [['Although strawberries are considered a minor crop, they provide a significant source of income for many fruit and nursery growers. In the United States, strawberries were cultivated on nearly 20,000 hectares in 1989, yielding a total production of 555,000 tons valued at $520 million. Florida ranks second only to California in the production of fresh-market strawberries. For U.S. winter production (December through March), strawberries are grown on approximately 2,400 hectares. The major cultural problems faced by the Florida strawberry industry include: 1) anthracnose diseases, 2) yearly infestations of the two-spotted spider mite (Tetranychus urticae Koch), and 3) variability in the quality of nursery transplants. Commercial fields are established annually, similar to California practices. Freshly dug transplants are sourced from nurseries in Florida or from northern states and Canada. The use of transplants from northern nurseries is crucial to avoid anthracnose disease issues and to ensure that plants have undergone sufficient natural chilling to induce floral bud initiation.', 0.33731865882873535]]

Templeton, one of the early researchers on this pathogen (Daniel et al., 1973), is genetically distinct from TeBeest 3.1.3 and has been identified by Damm et al. (2012a, this issue) as C. godetiae, a member of the C. acutatum complex. The strain we examined (TeBeest 3.1.3) matches genetically with another strain often cited in the C. gloeosporioides f. sp. aeschynomenes literature (Clar-5a = ATCC 96723) (GenBank JX131331). It is possible that two distinct species, both highly pathogenic to Aeschynomene in Arkansas, have been confused. A survey of additional Colletotrichum isolates that are highly virulent to Aeschynomene in Arkansas would clarify the interpretation of past literature on this pathogen. For example, C. gloeosporioides “f. sp. aeschynomenes” was initially reported as specific to Aeschynomene virginica (Daniel et al., 1973), while later studies reported isolates, putatively of the same taxon, to have a wider host range (TeBeest, 1988).', 0.3991221785545349]]

query: How does exchangeable sodium relate to other cations like calcium and magnesium in terms of soil fertility and plant nutrition?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Many minerals in soils are negatively charged and can attract and retain cations such as potassium (K), sodium (Na), calcium (Ca), magnesium (Mg), and ammonium (NH₄). Cation exchange is a reversible process, allowing nutrients to be held in the soil and not lost through leaching, with the potential for subsequent release for crop uptake. Certain organic compounds contribute to cation exchange capacity (CEC). The presence of high concentrations of Ca, especially in the form of gypsum, can interfere with the determination of CEC, which is crucial for soil fertility and mineralogical characterization. Additionally, CEC is influenced by soil pH. A certain portion of the total negative charge is permanent, while a variable portion is pH-dependent.', 0.9191156029701233]]
Context 1: [['EDTA-disodium salt solution is used to chelate calcium and magnesium. Calcium is separately estimated using the versenate method with ammonium purpurate (Murexide) as an indicator, ensuring the pH is sufficiently high so that magnesium precipitates largely as hydroxide. Thus, magnesium can be calculated by subtracting calcium from the total calcium plus magnesium content. Both cations can also be estimated using atomic absorption spectrophotometry.', 0.18502213060855865]]
Context 2: [['Soil cation exchange capacity is near 100% base saturation.', 0.13744379580020905]]
Context 3: [['Rhoades, J. D., and Polemio, M. 1977. Determining Cation Exchange Capacity: A New Procedure for Calcareous and Gypsiferous Soils. Soil Science Society of America Journal 41: 524–530.', 0.12619061768054962]]
Context 4: [['The method is based on the principle that calcium, magnesium, and several other cations form stable complexes with versenate (ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid disodium salt, EDTA) at different pH levels. A known volume of standard calcium solution is titrated with a standard 0.01 N EDTA solution using Murexid (ammonium purpurate) indicator in the presence of sodium hydroxide (NaOH) solution.', 0.12146437913179398]]
Context 5: [['Soltanpour, P. N., and A. P. Schwab (eds.). 1977. A New Soil Test for Simultaneous Extraction of Macro- and Micro-Nutrients in Alkaline Soils. Communications in Soil Science and Plant Analysis 8: 195–207.', 0.11896234005689621]]
Context 6: [['Measure the micronutrient cations in the samples (soil extracts) using the Atomic Absorption Spectrophotometer, employing the appropriate lamp for each element.', 0.09918622672557831]]
Context 7: [['Calcium and magnesium can be determined in the di-acid digest of plant samples using either AAS or Versenate titration. When using AAS, lanthanum (La) must be added to the sample; the addition of 0.1-1.0% La prevents interference from Al, Be, P, Si, Ti, V, and Zn.', 0.0936068594455719]]
Context 8: [['Olsen, S. R., C. V. Cole, F. S. Watanabe, and L. A. Dean. 1954. Estimation of available phosphorus in soils by extraction with sodium bicarbonate. U.S. Department of Agriculture Circular 939, USA.', 0.08597909659147263]]
Context 9: [['Soils can be stored in an air-dry condition for several months without affecting the exchangeable K, Na, Ca, and Mg content.', 0.07798149436712265]]

query: What is the relationship between anthracnose severity and strawberry variety?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Anthracnose is an important disease of strawberry caused by Colletotrichum spp., which affects foliage, runners, crowns, and fruits (Howard et al., 1992). Three primary fungal pathogens—C. acutatum sensu lato, C. gloeosporioides sensu lato, and C. fragariae—are known to cause anthracnose disease in strawberries (Freeman and Katan, 1997). The crown rot syndrome is characteristic of infections from C. gloeosporioides sensu lato and C. fragariae, while fruit rot is mainly attributed to C. acutatum sensu lato, leading to significant yield losses (Howard et al., 1992). Currently, numerous species are classified under what is now known as the C. acutatum complex, with six species—C. acutatum sensu stricto, C. fioriniae, C. godetiae, C. nymphaeae, C. salicis, and C. simmondsii—identified as associated with strawberry anthracnose worldwide (Damm et al., 2012). Among these, C. nymphaeae is the most prevalent pathogen causing strawberry anthracnose globally, including in Iran (Baroncelli et al., 2015; Karimi et al., 2017; Wang et al., 2019). Currently, no effective chemical control methods exist for managing strawberry anthracnose; available options are limited to preventive treatments applied before fruit production (Denoyes-Rothan et al., 1999). Additionally, concerns about the toxic effects of chemical fungicides on the environment and the development of resistance in fungal strains highlight the need for alternative control strategies. Consequently, utilizing resistant cultivars appears to be the most efficient and practical approach for suppressing anthracnose development. In light of recent anthracnose outbreaks in strawberry fields in the Kurdistan province of Iran (Karimi et al., 2017), and the necessity for appropriate strategies to address this issue, the aim of this study was to evaluate the resistance of several commercial strawberry cultivars to the anthracnose fruit rot caused by C. nymphaeae under in vivo and greenhouse conditions.', 0.6732079386711121]]
Context 1: [['In November 2021, anthracnose symptoms were observed on strawberries (cv. Kingsberry) in Nonsan, Chungnam Province. These symptoms progress with the enlargement of lesions, which hinder proper fruit development and lead to the formation of orange-colored spores within the lesions. Similar symptoms were noted on the petioles, with sunken and blackened tissues similar to those on the fruit, accompanied by the formation of an orange conidial mass.', 0.5167345404624939]]

Context 3: [['The term "anthracnose" was first used to describe a new disease of strawberries caused by Colletotrichum fragariae Brooks. "Strawberry anthracnose" continues to be used as a general term to identify all diseases of strawberries caused by species of Colletotrichum. Strawberry anthracnose diseases have been reported to be caused by C. acutatum J.H. Simmonds, C. gloeosporioides (Penz.) Penz. & Sacc. in Penz. (the teleomorph of Cromereilla cingulata (Stoneman) Spauld. & H. Schrenk), and C. dematium (Pers.) Grove. Context 4: [['In the early 1980s, anthracnose became a significant disease affecting strawberries in the southeastern United States. query: Can the addition of various micronutrients such as CuSO₄·5H₂O and ZnSO₄·7H₂O significantly improve tomato seedling growth in contaminated rockwool?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Fig. 5. Influence of micronutrients on tomato seedling growth after 2 weeks in rockwool infested with Fusarium oxysporum f.sp. radicis-lycopersici. Amendments of (A) CuSO₄·5H₂O; (B) ZnSO₄·7H₂O; (C) MnSO₄; (D) MoO₃; (E) (NH₄)₆Mo₇O₂₄·4H₂O; and (F) Fe-EDDHA were provided at planting. Values represent the means per plant in three trials. Adjusted regression coefficients and line derivations were significant at P ≤ 0.0007 for all except A and F, where P = 0.0504 and 0.0091, respectively. Vertical bars represent ± standard error of the mean.', 0.9953153133392334]]
Context 1: [['Abstract: This study evaluates how host nutritional variables affect the severity of crown and root rot in tomatoes caused by Fusarium oxysporum f.sp. radicis-lycopersici. Tomato seedlings (Lycopersicon esculentum Mill., cv. Bonnie Best) were grown in a pathogen-infested, soilless rockwool system in a greenhouse, using a nutrient solution with varied macro- and microelement concentrations. Disease severity was assessed after two weeks with an index ranging from 0 to 4, and plant fresh weight was measured. Regression analysis showed that disease severity significantly increased with ammonium-nitrogen sources, including NH4Cl, (NH4)6Mo7O24, and (NH4)2SO4, along with NaH2PO4·H2O, Fe-EDDHA, and MnSO4. Conversely, nitrate-nitrogen (Ca(NO3)2·4H2O) and CuSO4·5H2O reduced disease severity. Low rates of NH4NO3 (39 to 79 mg·L–1 N) were beneficial, but levels above 100 mg·L–1 N exacerbated the issue. MgSO4·7H2O had no impact on disease. Notably, plant growth was inversely related to disease severity, and mineral fertilizers did not alter the pH of the nutrient solution. This information provides insights into the environmental factors influencing plant-pathogen interactions and can guide management strategies for Fusarium crown and root rot through host nutrition.', 0.9835102558135986]]
Context 2: [['The form of nitrogen significantly influenced both the severity of Fusarium crown and root rot and the growth of tomato seedlings in a soilless rockwool system (Fig. 1). Increasing concentrations of nitrate-N reduced disease severity and improved plant growth compared to ammonium forms. Both ammonium sulfate and ammonium chloride produced similar responses, indicating that NH4+ was the harmful component (Fig. 1). Ammonium nitrate has been reported to either have no effect on Fusarium diseases or to increase disease severity, similar to ammonium-N (Jones et al., 1989; Schneider, 1985). While this was generally true for Fusarium crown and root rot, testing a range of concentrations revealed that at low concentrations (10 to 100 mg·L–1 N), ammonium nitrate reduced disease similarly to nitrate-N (Figs. 1D, 2D). However, the negative influence of the NH4+ ion became apparent at concentrations above 125 mg·L–1 N (Figs. 1D, 2D). At higher concentrations, seedlings might have lacked sufficient available carbohydrates to convert the excess ammonium, which is toxic for tomato seedlings (Woltz et al., 1992), into nontoxic amino acids (Pate, 1973). Nitrates have long been recognized for their role in reducing seedling diseases caused by Rhizoctonia solani (Huber and Watson, 1974); however, contradictory results have been reported for Fusarium crown and root rot. Mihuta-Grimm et al. (1990) noted that nitrogen supplied as a 20N–20P–20K fertilizer had no effect on the growth of F. oxysporum f.sp. radicis-lycopersici in rockwool compared to non-fertilized treatments. Jarvis and Thorpe (1980) found no effect of nitrogen form (with total N applied unspecified) on disease or yield when adequate lime was provided to counteract potential pH effects. In fact, the differential effect of nitrogen form on pH is a significant mechanism for suppressing many soilborne pathogens (Huber and Watson, 1974). In contrast, Woltz et al. (1992) reported differences between nitrate and ammonium-N (each at 225 mg·L–1).', 0.710992157459259]]
Context 3: [['The influence of various mineral nutrients on Fusarium crown and root rot was evaluated in a non-circulating hydroponics system. Pregerminated tomato seeds (cv. Bonnie Best), which were 2-3 days old and had sprouted primary roots measuring 2-4 mm in length on 0.85% water agar at 24 °C, were planted in rockwool cubes (3.5 cm in diameter and 4 cm deep; one seed per cube; Grodania A/S, Hedehusene, Denmark) placed in square plastic trays (5.5 cm deep). The rockwool was saturated with 800 mL of a dilute (1/4 strength) Knop nutrient solution containing the following concentrations (in mg·L–1): calcium nitrate (Ca(NO₃)₂·4H₂O) at 250; potassium phosphate (KH₂PO₄), potassium chloride (KCl), and magnesium sulfate (MgSO₄·7H₂O) at 62.52 each; and F2 e-EDDHA (ethylenediamine-di(o-hydroxyphenylacetic acid)).', 0.6176682710647583]]
Context 4: [['Fig. 4. Influence of micronutrients on the severity of Fusarium crown and root rot of tomato. Amendments of (A) CuSO₄·5H₂O; (B) ZnSO₄·7H₂O; (C) MnSO₄; (D) MoO₃; (E) (NH₄)₆Mo₇O₂₄·4H₂O; or (F) Fe-EDDHA were provided at planting. Values represent the means per plant in three trials. Adjusted regression coefficients and line derivations were significant at P ≤ 0.0008. Vertical bars represent ± standard error of the mean.', 0.6003081202507019]]
Context 5: [['In contrast, little is currently known about how plant nutrition influences crown and root rot of tomato. Previous studies have only tested single concentrations of nitrogenous fertilizers and sodium chloride (Jarvis and Thorpe, 1980; Woltz et al., 1992), without examining the potential influence of other critical mineral nutrients, particularly microelements. The objective of our study was to compare the effects of several macro- and microelements (including various ammonium-N sources, nitrate-N, sodium phosphate, iron, molybdenum, and copper-, magnesium-, manganese-, and zinc-sulfates) on disease severity and the growth of tomato seedlings. Mineral nutrients were tested across a range of concentrations to provide more information for developing a fertilizer-based management strategy and for integrating mineral fertilizers with other control approaches (e.g., biocontrol) that may be sensitive to mineral levels.', 0.34822168946266174]]
Context 6: [['Determining whether applied nutrients have been absorbed by the plant.', 0.22849877178668976]]
Context 7: [['Abstract: Media and nutrient variables were investigated to develop methods for reducing the incidence and severity of Fusarium crown rot caused by Fusarium oxysporum Schlecht. f. sp. radicis-lycopersici Jarvis & Shoemaker (FORL), which poses a significant challenge for tomato (Lycopersicon esculentum Mill.) cultivation. Root-dip inoculated seedlings were transplanted into trays filled with a 1:1 mixture of Canadian peat and vermiculite. These media were prepared using factorial combinations of calcium carbonate (CaCO₃) at rates of 0.75 or 3.0 kg·m⁻³, calcium nitrate [Ca(NO₃)₂] or ammonium sulfate [(NH₄)₂SO₄] (each providing 225 mg N/liter), and sodium chloride (NaCl) at either 0 or 2000 mg Na/liter as experimental treatments.', 0.17793917655944824]]
Context 8: [['Wilcox, G. E. 1993. Tomato. Pages 137-141 in: Nutrient Deficiencies and Toxicities in Crop Plants. W. Bennett, ed. American Phytopathological Society, St. Paul, MN.', 0.17399737238883972]]
Context 9: [['Two-week-old seedlings of the ‘Walter’ tomato variety were root-dip inoculated in Fusarium oxysporum f.sp. radicis-lycopersici (FORL) inoculum prepared by blending potato glucose agar cultures in sterile deionized water, diluting to a final concentration of 5 × 10^6 spores per milliliter. The root dip also involved crowns and a portion of the hypocotyl. The inoculated seedlings, 15 per container, were transplanted into plastic trays measuring 18.5 × 24.5 × 2.5 cm, containing approximately 0.002 m³ of a mix of 1 part Canadian peat to 1 part vermiculite. The medium was amended with 1.5 kg of a Perk micronutrient mix (Vigoro Industries, Fairview Heights, Ill.) and 3.0 kg of single superphosphate per cubic meter. Factorial combinations of powdered CaCO3 (0.75 or 3.0 kg·m³), solutions of Ca(NO3)2 or (NH4)2SO4 (each at 225 mg N/liter), and NaCl at either 0 or 204 mg Na/liter were used as experimental treatments. Calcium carbonate was included in the dry mix, while 200 ml of solutions of the nitrogen sources and NaCl were applied to the trays before planting the inoculated or non-inoculated seedlings. This application was repeated weekly until the end of the experiment.', 0.16029703617095947]]

query: How does the rate of appressorial production compare to the rate of conidial germination when exposed to temperatures between 17.6°C and 26.5°C?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Appressoria production was favored by cooler temperatures than conidial germination and secondary conidiation. The optimum for appressorial production ranged from 17.6 to 26.5°C and decreased over time after inoculation. For instance, although appressorial production was faster at 23 to 26°C six hours post-inoculation, the largest number of appressoria was observed at 17.6 to 20.8°C after 132 hours. The least favorable temperature for appressorial production was 35°C.', 0.9954903721809387]]
Context 1: [['Intermittent wetness affected conidial germination, secondary conidiation, and appressorial development at 25°C. Germination increased with the duration of wetness, and never occurred in the continuously dry treatment. The highest number of germinated conidia was observed one day post-inoculation in all treatments with eight hours of wetness per day, decreasing over time. Production of secondary conidia mainly occurred within one day after inoculation and was rare at later times. Total conidia were greater under continuous wetness than any other treatment one day post-inoculation, but tended to decrease over time.', 0.621937096118927]]
Context 2: [["Primary inoculum consists of fresh conidia produced in acervuli under favorable conditions of temperature (10 to 30°C for most clades) and moisture (e.g., wetness periods longer than 6 hours) from overwintered sources throughout the cropping season (Moral and Trapero, 2012; Stensvand et al., 2017; Everett et al., 2018). Conidia are splash-dispersed by rain (Denham and Waller, 1981; Chakraborty and Billard, 1995; Madden et al., 1996; Madden, 1997; Guyot et al., 2005; Buirchell et al., 2006), deposited on plant surfaces, and germinate. The germ tubes then produce appressoria, which form infection pegs that penetrate the host cuticle and epidermal cell walls (Perfect et al., 1999). Penetration through stomata or wounds by germ tubes without appressoria formation is rare (Zulqarnain et al., 1996). Infection of epidermal and mesophyll cells occurs after a symptomless biotrophic phase, leading to a necrotic phase in which host cells are killed and secondary hyphae grow both intra- and inter-cellularly (O'Connell et al., 2012). In some cases, the pathogen has a quiescent phase (Peres et al., 2005; Prusky et al., 2013), with the switch to the necrotrophic phase occurring only when host tissue and environmental conditions favor the continuation of the infection cycle. Except for a few species that exist entirely as endophytes, most Colletotrichum species develop a necrotrophic stage at some point in their life cycle (Prusky et al., 2013).", 0.3169611692428589]]
Context 3: [['Description: Leaf lesions are elliptical or circular, reddish-brown (Fig. 6E). On the host, acervuli are subepidermal, disrupting the outer epidermal cell wall, with no setae present, and salmon-pink conidia masses (Fig. 5A). Conidiophores are hyaline, 1-2 celled, not branching or branching at the base, measuring 9-20 × 3-4.5 µm (x = 14.7 ± 3.1 × 3.8 ± 0.5, n = 20) (Fig. 5D). Conidia are 9.5-15 × 3.5-5.5 µm (x = 13.1 ± 1.4 × 4.8 ± 0.4, n = 50), one-celled, smooth-walled, hyaline, straight, occasionally slightly curved, fusiform, and gradually tapered at the ends (Figs. 5E, F). Colonies on PDA reach 6-6.4 cm in diameter (x = 6.2 ± 4.4, n = 10) in 6 days at 25°C, with a growth rate of 8.8-11 mm per day (x = 9.9 ± 0.8, n = 10). Initially white, they become pale grey with concentric zones as they age, dense, with a pale white reverse that becomes greenish-black from the center with age, and a white margin (Figs. 5B, C). Sclerotia and setae are absent. Conidia are formed in orange-pink conidial masses, measuring 14-20 × 5-6.5 µm (x = 15.9 ± 1.1 × 5.1 ± 0.40, n = 100), one-celled, smooth-walled, hyaline, fusiform, straight, guttulate, occasionally constricted at the center, and obtuse at the ends (Figs. 5G-I). Appressoria are dark brown, ovate, irregular, with entire margins or crenate to lobed, occasionally forming secondary appressoria from the first but not complex (Figs. 5J-L), measuring 7-11 × 5-7.5 µm (x = 8.5 ± 0.9 × 6.6 ± 0.6, n = 40).', 0.3056849539279938]]
Context 4: [['The average mycelial growth rate was 9.8 mm per day at 25°C on PDA, exhibiting cottony aerial growth and a pale yellowish to pinkish hue. The conidia were hyaline, cylindrical with rounded ends, measuring 14.90 - 18.19 µm × 4.05 - 6.20 µm (average ± SD: 16.22 ± 1.20 × 5.90 ± 0.84 µm, n = 30). Appressoria were brown, globose to cylindrical, lobed, and measured 7.50 - 12.70 µm.', 0.28300225734710693]]
Context 5: [['For coverslip inoculation, conidial germination was also studied on plastic coverslips (22 × 22 mm). A 0.1-ml droplet of conidial suspension (5 × 10^3 conidia per ml) was deposited in the center of each of four coverslips placed on moistened filter paper in glass petri dishes. Each petri dish was sealed with Parafilm to maintain 100% relative humidity and incubated at 26°C in darkness. Coverslips were sampled at intervals similar to those for inoculated leaves and prepared for microscopic observation by mounting on slides and staining with a drop of 0.1% aniline blue in lactophenol. Conidial germination and appressorium development were quantified at ×250 magnification as described for leaf disks. Four coverslips were counted for each sampling time, and the experiment was repeated once.', 0.2790273427963257]]
Context 6: [['Morphological Characterization: Before morphological examination, isolates were cultured under continuous fluorescent light on PDA for one week at 25°C. Mycelial plugs (5 mm in diameter) were cut from colony margins and placed in 9-cm diameter Petri dishes, with four plates per isolate. The colony characteristics (color of upper and lower surfaces) and growth rate (measured in two perpendicular directions) were recorded after 3, 5, 7, and 10 days. Hyphal growth rate (cm/day) was calculated based on colony diameter. Conidial production, shape, and size were examined up to three weeks on PDA incubated at 25°C. Conidia (120 per isolate) from three-week-old PDA cultures were measured for length and width. Appressoria were produced from conidia placed on glass slides inside moist chambers. They were also produced from hyphae using a slide culture technique described by Cai et al. PDA plugs (1 cm × 1 cm) were placed in clean Petri dishes, treated with conidia, and covered with a cover slip. After 7 days, the shape and size of the appressoria were recorded. For each isolate, at least 30 appressoria were examined, and photographs were taken using a Nikon Eclipse Ni-E microscope.', 0.2463025003671646]]
Context 7: [['Temperature significantly influenced the production of secondary conidia on the surface of symptomless leaves. The optimum temperature for secondary conidiation ranged from approximately 21.3 to 32.7°C between 12 and 36 hours after inoculation. Secondary conidiation was rare at 10°C and at sampling times beyond 36 hours. Production of secondary conidia increased the total number of conidia on symptomless leaves, particularly at 25 and 30°C, where total conidia more than doubled during the experiment. Although the number of germinated conidia began to decrease by 60 hours, this was counterbalanced by high numbers of ungerminated conidia produced by secondary conidiation at these temperatures.', 0.24434277415275574]]
Context 8: [['Germination process: Conidia began to germinate on leaves and coverslips within 3 hours after inoculation (Fig. 1). Most conidia developed a central transverse septum and germinated at one or both ends by forming a germination tube or a sessile appressorium. Some conidia, however, did not become septate. Appressoria also developed at the distal ends of the elongated germination tubes, which were sometimes branched.', 0.196432426571846]]
Context 9: [["Appressorial production increased with daily wetness duration at each sampling time, and unlike conidia, did not decrease over the experiment's duration. Wetness also affected appressorial melanization, with no melanization occurring with four hours of wetness, while treatments with 12 hours showed 90% melanization.", 0.19271652400493622]]

query: How does Colletotrichum affect the roots of strawberry plants?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Abstract: Three Colletotrichum species—Colletotrichum acutatum J.H. Simmonds (teleomorph Glomerella acutata J.C. Guerber & J.C. Correll), Colletotrichum fragariae A.N. Brooks, and Colletotrichum gloeosporioides (Penz.) Penz. & Sacc. in Penz. [teleomorph Glomerella cingulata (Stoneman) Spauld. & H. Schrenk]—are major pathogens of strawberry (Fragaria × ananassa). Strawberry anthracnose crown rot has been a destructive disease in commercial strawberry fields in the southeastern United States since the 1930s. The causal fungus, C. fragariae, can infect all aboveground plant parts; however, the disease is most severe when it infects the crown, leading to crown rot, wilt, and death.', 0.9926517605781555]]
Context 1: [['Species of the fungal plant pathogen Colletotrichum are responsible for strawberry (Fragaria × ananassa Duch.) anthracnose, one of the major diseases affecting this crop. Major species that cause strawberry anthracnose include C. acutatum J.H. Simmons, C. fragariae Brooks, and C. gloeosporioides (Penz.) Penz. & Sacc. Symptoms of the disease manifest in various phases. Infection of mother plants with anthracnose may result in the collapse of the entire plant due to crown rot. In the nursery, lesions form on stolons that eventually girdle the runners, leading to wilting and death of unrooted daughter plants distal to the lesion. Death of daughter plants in the nursery and in field transplants can also be caused by crown rot. Infected transplants are capable of spreading the disease from the nursery to the field, and entire crops can be destroyed by anthracnose in strawberry fruit production fields under conducive environmental conditions.', 0.9835166335105896]]
Context 2: [['Anthracnose caused by Colletotrichum species is one of the most destructive diseases affecting strawberry production worldwide. Fungi of the genus Colletotrichum, which are ancient and co-evolved with flowering plants, rank eighth among the ten most economically important fungal pathogens and have diversified to adapt to various hosts. Since its first report in the United States in 1931, strawberry anthracnose has spread globally, resulting in devastating economic, social, and ecological consequences. In many ways, producing organic strawberries is largely impractical because of this disease. Colletotrichum species pathogenic to strawberries have been extensively characterized. This review aims to provide an accurate inventory of these species by revisiting their discovery history over the past 90 years. A total of 23 Colletotrichum species, clustered into five species complexes and two singleton taxa, have been accepted as strawberry pathogens with a global occurrence illustrated. The relative prevalence of distinct Colletotrichum species associated with strawberries has been systematically analyzed in China. Finally, the host range of the two prevailing species, C. fructicola and C. siamense, which cause significant damage globally, is summarized, with the goal of improving diagnostic accuracy and anthracnose management in agricultural ecosystems.', 0.9788548350334167]]
Context 3: [['Three species of Colletotrichum—Colletotrichum acutatum J.H. Simmonds (teleomorph: Glomerella acutata J.C. Guerber & J.C. Correll), Colletotrichum fragariae A.N. Brooks, and Colletotrichum gloeosporioides (Penz.) Penz. & Sacc. in Penz. (teleomorph: Glomerella cingulata (Stoneman) Spauld. & H. Schrenk)—are major pathogens of strawberry (Fragaria × ananassa). Strawberry anthracnose crown rot has been a destructive disease in commercial strawberry fields in the southeastern United States since the 1930s. The causal fungus, C. fragariae, can infect all aboveground plant parts; however, the disease is most severe when it infects the crown, leading to crown rot, wilting, and plant death.', 0.9725399017333984]]
Context 4: [['Colletotrichum spp. infect many other hosts, so it is sometimes assumed that the primary infection in strawberry fields comes from infected plants of these hosts growing nearby. To test the hypothesis that Colletotrichum spp. may move from other fruit or vegetable crops to strawberries, Smith (2002) wound-inoculated the leaves and stems of strawberry, blueberry, blackberry, muscadine grape, tomato, and pepper with 37 Colletotrichum isolates, representing nine species collected from 12 hosts. Isolates of Colletotrichum fragariae were the most aggressive, causing lesions at an average of 38% of inoculation sites on all hosts except pepper. The percentage of infection for the other eight Colletotrichum species ranged from 5% to 25%. Strawberry was the most susceptible host, with 58% of petiole and 14% of leaf infections resulting in lesion development from all isolates. Conversely, pepper was the most resistant host, showing no symptom development on leaves or stems following inoculation with any isolate. These results suggest that primary anthracnose infections in strawberry production fields most often arise from infected strawberry transplants and only rarely from anthracnose-infected fruit or vegetable crops adjacent to the strawberry fields. However, C. acutatum and C. gloeosporioides have both been shown to move from infected host plants near the fields to strawberry production fields (Freeman et al., 2000b).', 0.9664332866668701]]
Context 5: [['Species of the fungal plant pathogen Colletotrichum collectively cause anthracnose on strawberry (Fragaria × ananassa Duch.), which is a major disease of this crop worldwide. Principal pathogens responsible for the disease include Colletotrichum acutatum J. H. Simmonds, C. fragariae Brooks, and C. gloeosporioides (Penz.) Penz. & Sacc. in Penz. (teleomorph: Glomerella cingulata (Stoneman) Spauld. & H. Schrenk).', 0.9300762414932251]]
Context 6: [['Freeman, S., & Katan, T. Identification of Colletotrichum species responsible for anthracnose and root necrosis of strawberry in Israel. Phytopathology 87, 516-521 (1997).', 0.8566916584968567]]
Context 7: [['Freeman, S., and Katan, T. (1997). Identification of Colletotrichum species responsible for anthracnose and root necrosis of strawberry in Israel. Phytopathology. In press.', 0.8422616720199585]]
Context 8: [['Freeman, S., and Katan, T. 1997. Identification of Colletotrichum Species Responsible for Anthracnose and Root Necrosis of Strawberry in Israel. Phytopathol., 87: 516-521.', 0.8154105544090271]]
