query: How does Colletotrichum miaoliense differ from other Colletotrichum species?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Three isolates of C. miaoliense were collected from Miaoli County and Nantou County, Taiwan. Multi-locus analysis revealed that C. miaoliense forms a robust clade distinct from other known species in the C. acutatum species complex. Among the six Colletotrichum species in this complex (C. acutatum, C. fioriniae, C. godetiae, C. nymphaeae, C. salicis, and C. simmondsii) identified as anthracnose pathogens of strawberry, C. miaoliense is most closely related phylogenetically to C. nymphaeae and C. simmondsii. Morphologically, C. miaoliense differs from C. nymphaeae (CBS 515.78) in conidial size (16.1 × 2.3 – 4.9 × 0.7 μm versus 14.2 × 1.1 – 4.1 × 0.34 μm), conidial shape (one end round and the other rounded to acute, contrasting with the new species where both ends are acute), and appressoria size (8.7 × 2.5 – 5.5 × 1.0 μm versus 7.5 × 1.0 μm).', 0.991486668586731]]
Context 1: [['Based on morphological traits and multilocus phylogenetic analysis, the 52 isolates were assigned to five Colletotrichum species, which included one new taxon (C. miaoliense sp. nov.) (Fig. 4; described in detail below), one newly recorded taxon in strawberry (C. karstii), and three species known to be associated with strawberry anthracnose.', 0.8103966116905212]]
Context 2: [['Colletotrichum miaoliense sp. nov. P. C. Chung & H. Y. Wu. MycoBank number MB835424. Etymology: The epithet "miaoliense" specifically refers to Miaoli County, Taiwan, where the new taxon was discovered.', 0.7972654700279236]]
Context 3: [['Species of Colletotrichum represent anamorphic stages of Glomerella. Under the International Code of Nomenclature for algae, fungi, and plants, anamorph and teleomorph names of fungi will have equal status with the deletion of Article 59, which takes effect on January 1, 2013. This decision includes a stipulation that the uptake of names of anamorphic genera that predate well-known competing teleomorphic names must be ratified by a committee of the International Commission for the Taxonomy of Fungi. The name Colletotrichum (Corda 1831) predates Glomerella (Spauld. & H. Schrenk 1903) and is more commonly used. Consequently, we name the new holomorphs as species of Colletotrichum without naming the new sexual morphs separately. Furthermore, G. phyllanthi is combined in Colletotrichum as C. phyllanthi. There is precedent for this, as Rojas et al. (2010) described Colletotrichum ignotum as having a teleomorph (see Rojas et al. 2010: figs 44–47, table III), although the teleomorphic structures were not included in the formal species diagnosis.', 0.6620292067527771]]

However, Johnston & Jones (1997) confirmed it as a member of the C. acutatum complex. Notably, Colletotrichum paxtonii does not appear to produce setae at all, while C. musae rarely does, which may have contributed to past confusion between the two species.', 0.6555753946304321]]
Context 5: [['The name Colletotrichum was first introduced by Tode (1790) under the genus Vermicularia. query: Are there any biological control options for anthracnose?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Until highly resistant cultivars are available, growers must rely on chemical applications and cultural practices to reduce losses due to anthracnose. The failure of fungicides to control anthracnose epidemics may be due to the development of fungicide resistance in the Colletotrichum spp. population. For example, benomyl effectively reduced the incidence of anthracnose crown rot (Horn et al., 1972; Howard, 1971) and was used intensively by strawberry growers for years to control anthracnose and other diseases. However, the anthracnose pathogens, C. acutatum and C. fragariae, developed resistance to it and other benzimidazole fungicides (LaMondia, 1995; McInnes et al., 1992a; Smith and Black, 1992, 1993), rendering benomyl ineffective for anthracnose control in strawberry fields.', 0.3915986120700836]]
Context 1: [['Until highly resistant cultivars are available, growers must rely on chemical applications and cultural practices to reduce losses due to anthracnose. The failure of fungicides to control anthracnose epidemics may be attributed to the development of fungicide resistance in the Colletotrichum species population. For example, benomyl was shown to effectively reduce the incidence of anthracnose crown rot (Horn et al., 1972; Howard, 1971) and was used intensively by strawberry growers for years to control anthracnose and other diseases. However, the anthracnose pathogens, C. acutatum and C. fragariae, developed resistance to it and other benzimidazole fungicides (LaMondia, 1995; McInnes et al., 1992a; Smith and Black, 1992, 1993), leading to the ineffectiveness of benomyl for anthracnose control in strawberry fields.', 0.38810333609580994]]
Context 2: [['As our knowledge of the anthracnose pathogens and the epidemiology of anthracnose diseases has increased, so has our ability to control these diseases. Changes in cultural practices have resulted in reduced levels of disease. Additionally, the development and registration of more effective fungicides for use on strawberries have significantly reduced losses from both anthracnose crown rot and fruit rot. Anthracnose-resistant cultivars have also diminished economic losses due to these diseases. Nevertheless, growers may still experience severe losses when environmental factors are highly favorable for anthracnose development.', 0.3778780698776245]]
Context 3: [['As our understanding of the anthracnose pathogens and the epidemiology of anthracnose diseases has improved, so has our capacity to control these diseases. Changes in cultural practices have led to reduced levels of disease. Additionally, the development and registration of more effective fungicides for use on strawberries have significantly decreased losses due to anthracnose crown rot and fruit rot. The introduction of partially resistant cultivars has also helped mitigate economic losses due to these diseases. Nonetheless, growers may still experience severe losses when environmental conditions are highly conducive to anthracnose development.', 0.36935529112815857]]
Context 4: [['Bergstrom, G. C., and Nicholson, R. L. 1999. The biology of corn anthracnose: Knowledge to exploit for improved management. Plant Dis. 83:596-608.', 0.28005972504615784]]
Context 5: [['Increased losses due to anthracnose fruit and crown rots may be related to the shift from matted-row culture to the annual plasticulture production system in the United States. Breeding for genetic resistance to anthracnose and the development of resistant cultivars are primary means for reducing economic losses due to this disease. This approach is environmentally sound because it results in reduced fungicide use. As our knowledge of the anthracnose pathogens and the epidemiology of anthracnose diseases has increased, so has our ability to control these diseases. Changes in cultural practices have resulted in reduced levels of disease. Simultaneously, the development of more effective fungicides and their registration for use on strawberries have significantly reduced losses due to both anthracnose crown rot and fruit rot. Anthracnose-resistant cultivars have also decreased economic losses caused by these diseases. query: What are the key symptoms of strawberry anthracnose that indicate an infection by Colletotrichum acutatum?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['The anthracnose pathogen, Colletotrichum acutatum J. H. Simmonds, poses a serious threat to strawberry production worldwide. All parts of the strawberry plant are susceptible to infection; however, fruit rot is particularly damaging in production fields, leading to significant yield losses. Anthracnose development in strawberry nurseries not only reduces daughter plant production but also has serious consequences for pathogen dissemination on contaminated transplants. Once C. acutatum is introduced into production fields, managing disease outbreaks becomes challenging, as available control measures are only partially effective. Consequently, the use of pathogen-free propagation material is highly desirable, though implementation is difficult due to the lack of adequate detection and certification schemes for C. acutatum on symptomless plants.', 0.9577419757843018]]

Context 1: [['Additionally, we review the clinical aspects of the genus and the use of Colletotrichum species in biotransformations. We emphasize the importance of accurate identification, achievable through comparisons with type specimens and molecular data. We propose the need for consensus on protocols for the description and naming of Colletotrichum species and make predictions for developments in the next five years. This review highlights the critical need for correct strain identification prior to commencing scholarly research.', 0.7502331733703613]]
Context 2: [['Despite significant developments over the last ten years, the taxonomy of Colletotrichum is in a state of flux. Many uncertainties exist in the systematics of fungal pathogens from this genus; depending on the taxonomic "guides," the number of species can range from 29 to over 700 (von Arx, 1957; Sutton, 1992). One of the most confusing species is C. gloeosporioides. For example, 594 species of Colletotrichum were reclassified by von Arx as synonyms of C. gloeosporioides. Identification has primarily relied on morphological characteristics of conidia, vegetative and sexual structures, as well as host specificity and cultural characteristics (von Arx, 1957). Unfortunately, conidial morphology and colony characteristics vary even within isolates. Consequently, classical methods have been supplemented with biochemical and molecular technologies to differentiate Colletotrichum species (J. W. Kronstad, ed., Fungal Pathology, 127-148. © 2000 Kluwer Academic Publishers). For a more complete discussion of this topic, see Sherriff et al. (1994).', 0.7007232308387756]]

query: What role did the Aleppo workshop in 1986 play in promoting soil testing in the WANA region?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['This brings attention to the West Asia – North Africa (WANA) region, supported by the International Center for Agricultural Research in the Dry Areas (ICARDA). The establishment of the Soil Test Calibration Network at ICARDA has been a key catalyst for promoting soil testing and optimizing soil and fertilizer resource use in the region. The evolution and potential impact of this initiative can be observed through papers presented at various workshops, including those in Aleppo (1986, Soltanpour, 1987), Ankara (1987, Matar et al., 1988), Amman (1988, Ryan and Matar, 1990), Agadir (1991, Ryan and Matar, 1992), and finally in Aleppo (1995, Ryan, 1997).', 0.9980059266090393]]
Context 1: [['Soltanpour, P. N. (ed.). 1987. Proceedings of the First West Asia – North Africa Soil Test Calibration Workshop, June 23–25, 1986. ICARDA, Aleppo, Syria.', 0.9242234826087952]]
Context 2: [['The idea of having a common laboratory manual for the WANA region was based on the understanding that the soils in this arid to semi-arid area share a common suite of properties, which leads to similar nutritional problems in crops. Collaborative research in the Soil Test Calibration Network in the Mediterranean zone also revealed that several soil tests for assessing nutrient availability have regional applicability (Ryan and Matar, 1990, 1992). Furthermore, there was a lack of laboratory manuals on plant analysis relevant to the crop nutritional problems in the region.', 0.5526377558708191]]
Context 3: [['Various publications address management considerations in the design and operation of soil testing (e.g., Walsh and Beaton, 1973). While the benefits of standardized laboratory designs are clear, many laboratories in the WANA region exhibit apparent deficiencies in this regard (Ryan, 2000; Ryan et al., 1999). Too often, soil samples are stored, or worse, ground in wet chemistry laboratories. Similarly, many laboratories are arranged in ways that inadvertently hinder efficient use of staff resources.', 0.38718220591545105]]
Context 4: [['Subsequently, the First Edition of the manual (Ryan, J., S. Garabet, K. Harmsen, and A. Rashid, “A Soil and Plant Analysis Manual Adapted for the WANA Region”) was published in 1996 by ICARDA and distributed widely among soil and plant analysis laboratories throughout the region. The response was very encouraging, with most laboratory managers appreciating the initiative, particularly for compiling all the needed methodologies in a single, easy-to-use volume for laboratory technicians.', 0.17706911265850067]]
Context 5: [['Source: Soil and Plant Analysis Council (1992).', 0.17289191484451294]]
Context 6: [['A common soil, plant, and water analysis manual is also fundamental to the success of the WANA soil fertility network. To address the existing gap, a comprehensive manual on all essential soil, plant, and water analyses was developed. This manual was intentionally designed in a “cookbook” format for the ease of laboratory technicians. Upon completion, the manual draft was reviewed and endorsed at the Soil Fertility Meeting in Tel Hadya in 1995 (Ryan, 1997).', 0.16404636204242706]]
Context 7: [['Sources: FAO (1980), Soltanpour (1985), Ludwick (1995), Martens and Lindsay (1990), Johnson and Fixen (1990), Soil and Plant Analysis Council (1992), Matar et al. (1988).', 0.1359194666147232]]

query: Was the USDA strawberry breeding program more successful in developing disease-resistant varieties or in improving strawberry flavor and texture?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['The USDA strawberry breeding program was initiated with clear, definable objectives aimed at developing cultivars adapted to the environmental conditions of different regions, and it continues to maintain these objectives.', 0.8732249736785889]]
Context 1: [['The development of cultivars resistant to red stele has been a primary objective of the USDA program. Various resistant cultivars have been introduced, including ‘Surecrop’, ‘Midway’, ‘Sunrise’, ‘Guardian’, ‘Earliglow’, and more recently, ‘Scott’, ‘Allstar’, ‘Lester’, and ‘Lateglow’. In the Pacific Northwest, Waldo introduced ‘Siletz’ in 1955, marking the first red stele-resistant strawberry for this region. Since then, two other significant red stele-resistant cultivars, ‘Hood’ and ‘Benton’, have emerged from the cooperative USDA-Oregon State strawberry breeding program. Furthermore, the first day-neutral cultivars with multiple resistances to red stele, ‘Tristar’ and ‘Tribute’, were released from Beltsville in 1981 (Galletta et al., 1981).', 0.8646612763404846]]
Context 2: [['Galletta, G.J., J.L. Maas, C.E. Finn, B.J. Smith, and C.L. Gupton. 1997. The United States Department of Agriculture strawberry breeding program. Fruit Varieties Journal 51:204–210.', 0.8136818408966064]]
Context 3: [["The U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) strawberry breeding program is now in its 69th consecutive year. Although it is not the oldest program in the United States, it holds the record for the longest continuous strawberry breeding program. The USDA's efforts began in 1920 under the direction of George M. Darrow, who had conducted a survey from 1914 to 1917 of the commercial strawberry regions across the country. This survey revealed significant deficiencies in berry quality for various markets (Darrow et al., 1933).", 0.8133828043937683]]
Context 4: [['Galletta, G.J., J.L. Maas, C.E. Finn, B.J. Smith, and C.L. Gupton. 1997. The United States Department of Agriculture strawberry breeding program. Fruit Varieties J. 51: 204—210.', 0.8121545314788818]]
Context 5: [['Galletta, G.J., A.D. Draper, and D.H. Scott. 1981. The U.S. Department of Agriculture strawberry breeding program. HortScience 16:743-746.', 0.7149966359138489]]
Context 6: [['During the 1920s, more than 130 strawberry cultivars and 20 selections of Fragaria species were utilized in the breeding program, with 44 of these parents originating from Europe (Darrow et al., 1934). Thousands of seedlings were evaluated, resulting in the naming of several cultivars (Darrow, 1937). The two most significant cultivars from this early work were ‘Blakemore’ and ‘Fairfax’. ‘Blakemore’ quickly became a leading cultivar, setting a standard for firmness that allowed successful long-distance shipping of fruit. This cultivar demonstrated wide adaptability in the southern and south-central regions of the U.S. and continues to be commercially grown in some areas. Both ‘Blakemore’ and ‘Fairfax’, along with other USDA selections such as 253, 543, and 634, became widely used as parent plants in subsequent breeding programs (Darrow, 1966). ‘Fairfax’ was particularly valued for its excellent fruit quality and resistance to leaf spot (Darrow, 1962).', 0.457261860370636]]

query: How does the impact of crown rot in strawberries compare to root rot in soybeans in terms of plant mortality and yield losses?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Black root rot is a complex root disease of strawberry (Fragaria × ananassa Duchesne) that causes root death and reduces plant vigor, productivity, and winter hardiness. Certain rapidly growing gram-negative rod bacteria have also been implicated in strawberry black root rot.', 0.417802631855011]]
Context 1: [['The combined effects of rotation crops and nitrogen fertilizers were examined on the strawberry black root rot disease complex. In July 1995, microplots were filled with soil that had a history of strawberry black root rot and seeded with two types of oats (Avena strigosa ‘Saia oats’ or A. sativa ‘Garry oats’) or with sorgho-sudangrass (Sorghum bicolor × S. sudanense ‘Triple S’). Microplots planted with 1-year-old ‘Honeoye’ strawberry crowns served as controls. In May 1996, the crops were chopped and incorporated into the soil. The soil was then replanted with 1-year-old ‘Honeoye’ strawberry crowns and fertilized with (NH4)2SO4 or Ca(NO3)2 at equivalent nitrogen rates. Two months later, (NH4)2SO4-treated plants exhibited 36% more leaf area and 41% more runners than strawberries treated with Ca(NO3)2. Strawberries that had been precropped with ‘Saia’ oats produced 135% more runners and 38% more early fruit yield compared to those grown in control microplots. Total fruit yield was not affected by the treatments.', 0.25710922479629517]]
Context 2: [['Strawberry anthracnose can affect plants at any lifecycle stage, but plants are particularly susceptible at the seedling stage and immediately after planting (Wang et al. 2008). The disease primarily affects strawberry roots, petioles, and stolons, but can also infect flowers and fruit, leading to severe outbreaks (Mertely and Legard 2004). Symptoms include irregular ulcer-like lesions, reddish-brown stolons during initial stolon development, black spindle-shaped lesions on leaves and petioles, wilting, and dead roots (Debode et al. 2009; Freeman and Katan 1997). In Zhejiang, nearly 50% of seedling deaths and over 40% of production losses in nurseries are attributed to this disease (Xie et al. 2010). If environmental conditions are favorable, anthracnose can reduce strawberry yield by up to 80%. Transplants are considered the main source of primary inoculum, but the complete epidemiology of Colletotrichum spp. on strawberries in China remains unclear.', 0.24182827770709991]]
Context 3: [['Hildebrand, A. A., and West, P. M. 1941. Strawberry root rot in relation to microbiological changes induced in root rot soil by the incorporation of certain cover crops. Can. J. Res. Sect. C 19:183-198.', 0.21068735420703888]]
Context 4: [['Combining Saia oats as a single-season rotation with (NH4)2SO4 fertilization produced larger strawberry plants, more early yield, and less damage from black root rot than if Saia oats were combined with Ca(NO3)2 or if another rotation crop was paired with the (NH4)2SO4 treatment. Rotating strawberries with sorgho-sudangrass and fertilizing with (NH4)2SO4 reduced lesion nematodes but did not affect disease severity or yield. Similarly, Garry oats reduced disease severity and root colonization by R. fragariae but did not increase plant growth or yield.', 0.16752299666404724]]

Context 1: [['Much attention is given to laboratory procedures, but the process of obtaining soil for analysis—soil sampling—is often overlooked or poorly considered. A good sampling plan should provide a measure of the average fertility level of a field and indicate its variability. If a sample is not representative of the field or is incorrectly taken, the resulting analytical data are either meaningless or difficult to interpret. The error in field sampling is generally much greater than that due to chemical analysis. Thus, obtaining a representative soil sample from a field is the most crucial step for making a meaningful soil analysis.', 0.1797333061695099]]

query: How do variations in temperature and light conditions affect the conidial production and morphological characteristics of fungal isolates?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Morphological Characterization: Before morphological examination, isolates were cultured under continuous fluorescent light on PDA for one week at 25°C. Mycelial plugs (5 mm in diameter) were cut from colony margins and placed in 9-cm diameter Petri dishes, with four plates per isolate. The colony characteristics (color of upper and lower surfaces) and growth rate (measured in two perpendicular directions) were recorded after 3, 5, 7, and 10 days. Hyphal growth rate (cm/day) was calculated based on colony diameter. Conidial production, shape, and size were examined up to three weeks on PDA incubated at 25°C. Conidia (120 per isolate) from three-week-old PDA cultures were measured for length and width. Appressoria were produced from conidia placed on glass slides inside moist chambers. They were also produced from hyphae using a slide culture technique described by Cai et al. PDA plugs (1 cm × 1 cm) were placed in clean Petri dishes, treated with conidia, and covered with a cover slip. After 7 days, the shape and size of the appressoria were recorded. For each isolate, at least 30 appressoria were examined, and photographs were taken using a Nikon Eclipse Ni-E microscope.', 0.726974368095398]]
Context 1: [['Morphological Characterization: Isolates were cultured on PDA plates at 25 °C under continuous fluorescent light for 5 days. Plugs (6 mm in diameter) from colony margins were placed in the center of each 90-mm-diameter plate, with four replications. Colony color and culture diameters (measured in two perpendicular directions) were recorded after 3, 7, and 10 days at 25 °C. These diameters were used to calculate the hyphal growth rate (mm/day). Isolates were incubated at 25 °C for 21 days on PDA plates to assess conidial production, as well as the shape and size of conidia. Context 9: [['Colony Characteristics: Colonies grown from single conidia on Difco PDA reach 70–85 mm in diameter after 10 days. query: Can anthracnose be controlled by adjusting planting density?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Additional Keywords: anthracnose, disease spread, Fragaria × ananassa, models, quantitative epidemiology.', 0.1988113522529602]]
Context 1: [['For the management of anthracnose crown rot, water washing or fungicide treatments of bare-root transplants have been utilized in the nursery or immediately before planting in production fields (Daugovish et al., 2009; Freeman et al., 1997). Running water effectively removes soil from root and crown tissues, potentially eliminating inoculum, but it does not control any infections already present (Koike et al., 2008). Pre-plant fungicide dips have been shown to decrease anthracnose crown rot; however, only two products are currently registered for this use in the United States. The single-site mode of action quinone outside inhibitor (QoI), azoxystrobin, has been widely used as a preplant dip and as a foliar treatment for managing anthracnose and other fungal diseases (Bartlett et al., 2002; Koike et al., 2008; Turechek et al., 2006). Resistance has been reported against this fungicide group in Colletotrichum acutatum populations from strawberries in Florida (Forcelini et al., 2016). During the 2015-16 California nursery crown rot outbreak, growers reported reduced efficacy of azoxystrobin dips, suggesting that resistance may also be present in California (K. Ivors, unpublished). A premixed product of the anilinopyrimidine cyprodinil and the phenylpyrrole fludioxonil is also registered, but phytotoxicity and stunting of plants have been reported under certain environmental conditions or following off-label exposure (G. Holmes, unpublished).', 0.18478937447071075]]

Context 1: [['Strawberry anthracnose can affect plants at any lifecycle stage, but plants are particularly susceptible at the seedling stage and immediately after planting (Wang et al. 2008). The disease primarily affects strawberry roots, petioles, and stolons, but can also infect flowers and fruit, leading to severe outbreaks (Mertely and Legard 2004). Symptoms include irregular ulcer-like lesions, reddish-brown stolons during initial stolon development, black spindle-shaped lesions on leaves and petioles, wilting, and dead roots (Debode et al. 2009; Freeman and Katan 1997). In Zhejiang, nearly 50% of seedling deaths and over 40% of production losses in nurseries are attributed to this disease (Xie et al. 2010). If environmental conditions are favorable, anthracnose can reduce strawberry yield by up to 80%. Transplants are considered the main source of primary inoculum, but the complete epidemiology of Colletotrichum spp. on strawberries in China remains unclear.', 0.22891917824745178]]

query: Which species of Colletotrichum are identified as causing strawberry anthracnose in Taiwan?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Kikuchi M, Ogawara T, Hashimoto Y, Miyamoto T, Kaneda M, and Tomita Y identified Colletotrichum species causing strawberry anthracnose and investigated the distribution of fungal strains resistant to certain fungicides in Ibaraki Prefecture (Bull Hortic Inst Ibaraki Agric Cent. 2010; 17: 35-42).', 0.9975752234458923]]
Context 1: [['The term "anthracnose" was first used to describe a new disease of strawberries caused by Colletotrichum fragariae Brooks. "Strawberry anthracnose" continues to be used as a general term to identify all diseases of strawberries caused by species of Colletotrichum. Strawberry anthracnose diseases have been reported to be caused by C. acutatum J.H. Simmonds, C. gloeosporioides (Penz.) Penz. & Sacc. in Penz. (the teleomorph of Cromereilla cingulata (Stoneman) Spauld. & H. Schrenk), and C. dematium (Pers.) Grove. The latter species only occasionally causes strawberry fruit rots and will not be discussed here.', 0.9972508549690247]]
Context 2: [['Ji et al. (2022) reported that a total of 11 Colletotrichum species have been identified as pathogens of strawberries in China, which will be comprehensively introduced later. In Europe, strawberry anthracnose is largely attributed to the C. acutatum complex. Strains of C. godetiae infectious to strawberries have been documented in Ireland and Norway (Baroncelli et al. 2015; Chethana et al. 2016). In Denmark, C. nymphaeae is the only Colletotrichum species reported as a strawberry pathogen (Braganca et al. 2016), with similar reports from Bulgaria (Bobev et al. 2002; Jelev et al. 2008; Jayawardena et al. 2016b), Switzerland, and Portugal (Baroncelli et al. 2015). Both C. godetiae and C. nymphaeae were identified as strawberry pathogens in the Netherlands (Baroncelli et al. 2015; Jayawardena et al. 2016b) and Spain (Damm et al. 2012; Baroncelli et al. 2015).', 0.9971776008605957]]
Context 3: [['Diversity and Pathogenicity of Colletotrichum Species Causing Strawberry Anthracnose in Taiwan and Description of a New Species, Colletotrichum miaoliense sp. nov.', 0.9970807433128357]]
Context 4: [['Species of the fungal plant pathogen Colletotrichum collectively cause anthracnose on strawberry (Fragaria × ananassa Duch.), which is a major disease of this crop worldwide. Principal pathogens responsible for the disease include Colletotrichum acutatum J. H. Simmonds, C. fragariae Brooks, and C. gloeosporioides (Penz.) Penz. & Sacc. in Penz. (teleomorph: Glomerella cingulata (Stoneman) Spauld. & H. Schrenk).', 0.9963322281837463]]
Context 5: [['Anthracnose caused by Colletotrichum species is one of the most destructive diseases affecting strawberry production worldwide. Fungi of the genus Colletotrichum, which are ancient and co-evolved with flowering plants, rank eighth among the ten most economically important fungal pathogens and have diversified to adapt to various hosts. Since its first report in the United States in 1931, strawberry anthracnose has spread globally, resulting in devastating economic, social, and ecological consequences. In many ways, producing organic strawberries is largely impractical because of this disease. Colletotrichum species pathogenic to strawberries have been extensively characterized. This review aims to provide an accurate inventory of these species by revisiting their discovery history over the past 90 years. A total of 23 Colletotrichum species, clustered into five species complexes and two singleton taxa, have been accepted as strawberry pathogens with a global occurrence illustrated. The relative prevalence of distinct Colletotrichum species associated with strawberries has been systematically analyzed in China. Finally, the host range of the two prevailing species, C. fructicola and C. siamense, which cause significant damage globally, is summarized, with the goal of improving diagnostic accuracy and anthracnose management in agricultural ecosystems.', 0.995913565158844]]
Context 6: [['Jayawardena RS, Huang JK, Jin BC, Yan JY, Li XH, Hyde KD, Bahkali AH, Yin SL, Zhang GZ. 2016. An account of Colletotrichum species associated with strawberry anthracnose in China based on morphology and molecular data. Mycosphere 7(8): 1147–1163. DOI 10.5943/mycosphere/si/2c/6.', 0.9950785636901855]]
Context 7: [['Based on published data, we discussed the prevalence of Colletotrichum species in strawberry fields in China. C. siamense and C. fructicola from the C. gloeosporioides sensu lato complex are currently the most prevalent. The prevalence of certain Colletotrichum species in strawberry fields in specific regions is influenced by the entire agricultural ecosystem, particularly through interconnections with neighboring plants and climate changes. The relative prevalence of different Colletotrichum species varies with geographic region and changes dynamically in certain areas. For example, in Shanghai, C. acutatum was identified before 2005 (Dai et al. 2006) but has not been detected since 2016 (Zhang et al. 2020). Similarly, an early report indicated that strawberry anthracnose caused by C. gloeosporioides was incidental, while C. acutatum was frequently detected (Kikuchi et al. 2010). However, a later study identified C. fructicola as the dominant virulent species on strawberries in Japan (Gan et al. 2017). Such shifts have also occurred in Korea (Nam et al. 2008, 2013). This shift in the prevailing Colletotrichum species associated with strawberries in various regions may be linked to global warming, changes in cultivation patterns—from open fields to protected cultivation or soilless elevated cultivation—and the substitution of strawberry varieties.', 0.9946059584617615]]
Context 8: [['The difficulty in controlling anthracnose crown rot arises from the fact that Colletotrichum spp. can kill strawberry plants after aggressively invading crown tissue, with a long latent period during which no symptoms are visible. Additionally, there are no long-term effective fungicides available, and the diverse origins of the causal agents are unpredictable (Peres et al., 2017; Forcelini and Peres, 2018; Hirayama et al., 2018). Furthermore, Colletotrichum spp. can be dispersed from asymptomatic plants over long distances, while relevant quarantine measures for strawberry trade are lacking in China. Recognizing the causal agents is a prerequisite for disease control. Initially, identification largely depended on morphological observation and virulence tests. Repeated in vitro subculturing of microbes can alter both their morphology and virulence. The fact that morphological characteristics can vary based on host choice or environmental conditions poses a significant concern for fungal identification. Strawberry anthracnose was first reported nearly a century ago (Brooks, 1931). Through PCR and DNA sequencing techniques, researchers have clarified the genetic distinctions among Colletotrichum spp. associated with strawberries, categorizing pathogens of worldwide origin into C. acutatum, C. fragariae, and C. gloeosporioides (Martínez-Culebras et al., 2000, 2003). However, ambiguously annotated data for Colletotrichum species frequently appear in GenBank, leading to confusion (Nilsson et al., 2006; Hyde et al., 2009). The emergence of multi-locus phylogeny has significantly aided in the identification of fungal species. Many pathologists and biologists have greatly expanded knowledge of Colletotrichum systematics (Cannon et al., 2012; Damm et al., 2012a, b; Weir et al., 2012), providing a solid foundation for future research. A landmark study corrected many synonymous names and offered a valuable reference for understanding Colletotrichum pathogens (Hyde et al., 2014). The delineation of Colletotrichum species and the description of new species continue to progress with the advent of novel technologies such as whole genome sequencing (Jayawardena et al., 2020, 2021; Bhunjun et al., 2021; Talhinhas and Baroncelli, 2021).', 0.9942560791969299]]
Context 9: [['Jayawardena RS, Huang JK, Jin BC, Yan JY, Li XH, Hyde KD, et al. An account of Colletotrichum species associated with strawberry anthracnose in China based on morphology and molecular data. Mycosphere. 2016a;7(8):1147-1163. https://doi.org/10.5943/mycosphere/si/2c/6.605.', 0.9930793642997742]]

query: How does crop rotation help in managing anthracnose in strawberry fields?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Anthracnose is an important disease of strawberry caused by Colletotrichum spp., which affects foliage, runners, crowns, and fruits (Howard et al., 1992). Three primary fungal pathogens—C. acutatum sensu lato, C. gloeosporioides sensu lato, and C. fragariae—are known to cause anthracnose disease in strawberries (Freeman and Katan, 1997). The crown rot syndrome is characteristic of infections from C. gloeosporioides sensu lato and C. fragariae, while fruit rot is mainly attributed to C. acutatum sensu lato, leading to significant yield losses (Howard et al., 1992). Currently, numerous species are classified under what is now known as the C. acutatum complex, with six species—C. acutatum sensu stricto, C. fioriniae, C. godetiae, C. nymphaeae, C. salicis, and C. simmondsii—identified as associated with strawberry anthracnose worldwide (Damm et al., 2012). Among these, C. nymphaeae is the most prevalent pathogen causing strawberry anthracnose globally, including in Iran (Baroncelli et al., 2015; Karimi et al., 2017; Wang et al., 2019). Currently, no effective chemical control methods exist for managing strawberry anthracnose; available options are limited to preventive treatments applied before fruit production (Denoyes-Rothan et al., 1999). Additionally, concerns about the toxic effects of chemical fungicides on the environment and the development of resistance in fungal strains highlight the need for alternative control strategies. Consequently, utilizing resistant cultivars appears to be the most efficient and practical approach for suppressing anthracnose development. In light of recent anthracnose outbreaks in strawberry fields in the Kurdistan province of Iran (Karimi et al., 2017), and the necessity for appropriate strategies to address this issue, the aim of this study was to evaluate the resistance of several commercial strawberry cultivars to the anthracnose fruit rot caused by C. nymphaeae under in vivo and greenhouse conditions.', 0.9434313178062439]]
Context 1: [['Madden, L.V., Wilson, L.L., Ellis, M.A. 1993. Field spread of anthracnose in strawberry. Plant Disease. 77:861–866.', 0.33822351694107056]]
Context 2: [['Introduction: The spread of strawberry anthracnose can be exacerbated by the use of infected runner plantlets (Hirayama et al. 2010). Effective management strategies must consider these factors to mitigate disease outbreaks.', 0.3224288821220398]]
Context 3: [["Anthracnose fungi can attack various parts of the strawberry plant, including crowns, petioles, leaves, fruit trusses, flowers, buds, and fruit. The fungi's ability to attack multiple plant parts, coupled with the involvement of several pathogen species, contributes to the complex nature of strawberry anthracnose. Brooks reported in 1931 that C. fragariae caused spotting and girdling of runners, and later indicated that it also caused spotting of petioles and crown rot in a summer nursery, leading to wilting and death of the plants. Researchers in Louisiana observed all these symptoms and noted that crown rot also occurred in the fruit production field.", 0.2952108085155487]]

Context 7: [['Smith, B. J. 1998. Anthracnose leaf spot, irregular spot, anthracnose fruit rot (black spot), and anthracnose crown rot. In: Compendium of Strawberry Diseases. J. L. Mass, ed. American Phytopathological Society, St. Paul, MN. Pages 24-25, 31-33, and 46-48.', 0.24522218108177185]]
Context 8: [['From May to September 1995, a severe outbreak of strawberry anthracnose was observed in several strawberry-growing nurseries in Israel. Following transplantation to production fields during September and October, entire beds of strawberry plants collapsed. Typical anthracnose symptoms observed from November 1995 to June 1996 included crown rot, flower blight, and green and ripe fruit rot. This marked the first record of strawberry anthracnose in Israel. Furthermore, in at least four production fields in the same region, hundreds of plants developed symptoms of stunting and chlorosis, which are atypical of strawberry anthracnose. When these plants were uprooted, most of their roots were dark brown and decayed. Colletotrichum was readily isolated from these samples.', 0.23945501446723938]]

retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Anthracnose is an important disease of strawberry caused by Colletotrichum spp., which affects foliage, runners, crowns, and fruits (Howard et al., 1992). Three primary fungal pathogens—C. acutatum sensu lato, C. gloeosporioides sensu lato, and C. fragariae—are known to cause anthracnose disease in strawberries (Freeman and Katan, 1997). The crown rot syndrome is characteristic of infections from C. gloeosporioides sensu lato and C. fragariae, while fruit rot is mainly attributed to C. acutatum sensu lato, leading to significant yield losses (Howard et al., 1992). Currently, numerous species are classified under what is now known as the C. acutatum complex, with six species—C. acutatum sensu stricto, C. fioriniae, C. godetiae, C. nymphaeae, C. salicis, and C. simmondsii—identified as associated with strawberry anthracnose worldwide (Damm et al., 2012). Among these, C. nymphaeae is the most prevalent pathogen causing strawberry anthracnose globally, including in Iran (Baroncelli et al., 2015; Karimi et al., 2017; Wang et al., 2019). Currently, no effective chemical control methods exist for managing strawberry anthracnose; available options are limited to preventive treatments applied before fruit production (Denoyes-Rothan et al., 1999). Additionally, concerns about the toxic effects of chemical fungicides on the environment and the development of resistance in fungal strains highlight the need for alternative control strategies. Consequently, utilizing resistant cultivars appears to be the most efficient and practical approach for suppressing anthracnose development. In light of recent anthracnose outbreaks in strawberry fields in the Kurdistan province of Iran (Karimi et al., 2017), and the necessity for appropriate strategies to address this issue, the aim of this study was to evaluate the resistance of several commercial strawberry cultivars to the anthracnose fruit rot caused by C. nymphaeae under in vivo and greenhouse conditions.', 0.958784818649292]]
Context 1: [['The term "anthracnose" was first used to describe a new disease of strawberries caused by Colletotrichum fragariae Brooks. "Strawberry anthracnose" continues to be used as a general term to identify all diseases of strawberries caused by species of Colletotrichum. Strawberry anthracnose diseases have been reported to be caused by C. acutatum J.H. Simmonds, C. gloeosporioides (Penz.) Penz. & Sacc. in Penz. (the teleomorph of Cromereilla cingulata (Stoneman) Spauld. & H. Schrenk), and C. dematium (Pers.) Grove. The latter species only occasionally causes strawberry fruit rots and will not be discussed here.', 0.8651688694953918]]
Context 2: [["Anthracnose fungi can attack various parts of the strawberry plant, including crowns, petioles, leaves, fruit trusses, flowers, buds, and fruit. The fungi's ability to attack multiple plant parts, coupled with the involvement of several pathogen species, contributes to the complex nature of strawberry anthracnose. Brooks reported in 1931 that C. fragariae caused spotting and girdling of runners, and later indicated that it also caused spotting of petioles and crown rot in a summer nursery, leading to wilting and death of the plants. Researchers in Louisiana observed all these symptoms and noted that crown rot also occurred in the fruit production field.", 0.7393631935119629]]

Context 9: [['Numerous reports indicate that strawberry anthracnose pathogens may originate from weed species. For instance, C. fragariae was found attacking the weed Cassia obtusifolia L. These methods and models for combining ability analysis were selected because of the characteristics of the experiments in this study (i.e., a reduced number of parents were used without reciprocal crosses). When a limited number of parents are evaluated (<10) and the selection of these parents cannot be considered random, then a fixed model is recommended (Baker, 1978; Christie and Shattuck, 1992). Context 5: [['Anthracnose spreads within a field by splashing water, and living mulches (such as wheat, rye, or ryegrass) in row middles have been shown to reduce disease spread within a field. Sublethal doses of grass-specific herbicides, such as sethoxydim, may be used to prevent excessive growth of ryegrass (Gupton, 2000). Organic mulches, such as wheat straw or pine needles, also reduce splash and result in a lower incidence of anthracnose compared to rows mulched with plastic (Madden, 1992; Smith and Spiers, 1986). Additionally, anthracnose is less severe when water is supplied to plants using drip irrigation rather than overhead irrigation (Madden, 1992; Smith and Spiers, 1986). Anthracnose crown rot was observed to be less severe in commercial fields when strawberries were grown in soils with low nitrogen fertility (Howard et al., 1992). In greenhouse studies, Smith (1987, 1989) determined that strawberries grown in soils with high levels of nitrogen, especially from ammonium sources, are more susceptible to anthracnose than plants grown in soils with lower nitrogen levels or those with high levels of calcium nitrate.', 0.1801759898662567]]

Context 7: [['Figure 1 illustrates the anthracnose disease cycle in tropical fruit crops, drawn by Latiffah Zakaria. Anthracnose pathogens infect not only fruits but also other plant organs, including leaves, flowers, twigs, and branches. The conidia and spores formed in these infected tissues are released and dispersed during rainy days or periods of high humidity, becoming the primary inoculum for fruit infection at the preharvest stage. The most visible anthracnose symptoms are black or dark brown sunken lesions that contain conidial masses on the surface of infected fruits. Small individual lesions can merge to form larger lesions. These dark lesions on the fruit surface are unattractive to consumers and significantly reduce the market value of the affected fruits. Figures 2A–E display anthracnose lesions on several tropical fruit crops.', 0.17626722157001495]]
Context 8: [['Urdaneta, L., Sanabria, M., Rodríguez, D., & Pérez de Camacaro, M. (2013). Antracnosis causada por Colletotrichum spp. Investigación Agraria, 20(1), 38-50.', 0.1744154542684555]]
Context 9: [['Increased losses due to anthracnose fruit and crown rots may be related to the shift from matted-row culture to the annual plasticulture production system in the United States. Breeding for genetic resistance to anthracnose and the development of resistant cultivars are primary means for reducing economic losses due to this disease. This approach is environmentally sound because it results in reduced fungicide use. As our knowledge of the anthracnose pathogens and the epidemiology of anthracnose diseases has increased, so has our ability to control these diseases. Changes in cultural practices have resulted in reduced levels of disease. Simultaneously, the development of more effective fungicides and their registration for use on strawberries have significantly reduced losses due to both anthracnose crown rot and fruit rot. Anthracnose-resistant cultivars have also decreased economic losses caused by these diseases. Nevertheless, growers may still face severe losses when environmental conditions are highly favorable for anthracnose development.', 0.1713903844356537]]

query: How does MEGA X contribute to the study of functional and adaptive genome differences?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [["Over the past decade, genome sequencing has become an efficient and potent means to investigate a broad array of biological systems, from large-scale studies of biological diversity to tracking the evolution and origin of pathogenic microbes. The numerous steps required to glean interpretable and actionable results from raw sequence data invariably require comparative analysis of molecular sequences to discover functional and adaptive genome differences. The Molecular Evolutionary Genetics Analysis (MEGA) software provides tools to conduct such analyses. MEGA includes a large repertoire of programs for assembling sequence alignments, inferring evolutionary trees, estimating genetic distances and diversities, inferring ancestral sequences, computing timetrees, and testing selection. Over the last 25 years, MEGA's use in evolutionary analysis has been cited in over one hundred thousand studies in diverse biological fields.", 0.9929303526878357]]
Context 1: [['The Molecular Evolutionary Genetics Analysis (MEGA) software implements various analytical methods and tools for phylogenomics and phylomedicine. We report a transformation of MEGA to enable cross-platform use on Microsoft Windows and Linux operating systems. MEGA X does not require virtualization or emulation software and provides a uniform user experience across platforms. Additionally, MEGA X has been upgraded to utilize multiple computing cores for many molecular evolutionary analyses. Context 1: [['Strawberries (Fragaria×ananassa Duch.) are a widely cultivated hybrid species within the Rosaceae family, renowned for their fruit. They are increasingly significant for the agricultural economic development of countries like Iran, particularly in the Kurdistan province, which leads in strawberry production, predominantly under open-field conditions (Tehranifar and Sarsaefi, 2002). Various biotic and abiotic factors contribute to the decline in strawberry production globally. Notably, over 100 fungal species can invade strawberry plants, with approximately one-third causing serious diseases on different plant parts (Martin and others).', 0.3525489866733551]]
Context 2: [['The modern strawberry, Fragaria × ananassa Duchesne, is of relatively recent origin. It was not until the North American F. virginiana and the South American F. chiloensis were brought together and hybridized in Europe around 1750 that the progenitor of the strawberry we know today was developed. The high degree of genetic heterozygosity in Fragaria spp. has facilitated the creation of strawberry cultivars adapted to a wide range of environmental conditions and resistant to several diseases and pests. Today, cultivars are available that can survive the bitterly cold winters of Alaska, as well as those that thrive in the long, hot seasons of Pretoria, South Africa.', 0.24652403593063354]]

query: What challenges exist in identifying Colletotrichum species based on morphology alone?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['In a drastic move, von Arx (1957) reduced the number of recognized Colletotrichum species from several hundred to 11 based on morphological characteristics, with many taxa treated as synonyms of C. gloeosporioides and C. dematium. Several additional species have since been accepted based on morphological criteria (Sutton, 1980; 1992). The difficulties in recognizing Colletotrichum species can be attributed to: 1) the limited and variable morphological characters; 2) an extensive host range and variability in pathogenicity (Bailey and Jeger, 1992; Freeman et al., 2000; Latunde-Dada, 2001; Du et al., 2005; Thaung, 2008); 3) type specimens that are often missing or in poor condition, making them unsuitable for molecular studies; and 4) numerous rDNA ITS sequences of Colletotrichum strains in NCBI that are often misidentified (Crouch et al., 2009d; Damm et al., 2009).', 0.9965523481369019]]
Context 1: [['Traditionally, Colletotrichum species are identified based on morphological characteristics, including conidial and appressorial size and shape, the presence of acervuli, setae, or sclerotia, sexual structures, and cultural traits such as growth rate and colony color. Distinguishing Colletotrichum species morphologically has been challenging due to their phenotypic similarities and the influence of variable environmental factors on the expression of morphological traits. Consequently, all available morphological characteristics are often combined and used for systematic species discrimination.', 0.9951925277709961]]
Context 2: [['Despite significant developments over the last ten years, the taxonomy of Colletotrichum is in a state of flux. Many uncertainties exist in the systematics of fungal pathogens from this genus; depending on the taxonomic "guides," the number of species can range from 29 to over 700 (von Arx, 1957; Sutton, 1992). One of the most confusing species is C. gloeosporioides. For example, 594 species of Colletotrichum were reclassified by von Arx as synonyms of C. gloeosporioides. Identification has primarily relied on morphological characteristics of conidia, vegetative and sexual structures, as well as host specificity and cultural characteristics (von Arx, 1957). Unfortunately, conidial morphology and colony characteristics vary even within isolates. Consequently, classical methods have been supplemented with biochemical and molecular technologies to differentiate Colletotrichum species (J. W. Kronstad, ed., Fungal Pathology, 127-148. © 2000 Kluwer Academic Publishers). For a more complete discussion of this topic, see Sherriff et al. (1994).', 0.9754820466041565]]
Context 3: [['Before the molecular era, the taxonomy of Colletotrichum species was primarily based on morphological and cultural characteristics, including conidia size and shape, presence or absence of setae, colony color, and growth rate (von Arx 1957; Sutton 1980, 1992). However, these characteristics can be unreliable for species differentiation due to variability under changing environmental conditions (Cai et al. 2009).', 0.9096722602844238]]
Context 4: [['Cano, J., Guarro, J., and Gene, J. (2004). Molecular and morphological identification of Colletotrichum species of clinical interest. Journal of Clinical Microbiology 42: 2450-2454.', 0.6638073325157166]]

(2009). A polyphasic approach for studying Colletotrichum. Fungal Diversity, 39: 183-204.', 0.4358464777469635]]

Context 2: [['Many species belonging to the genus Colletotrichum are associated with plant diseases, commonly referred to as anthracnose. Colletotrichum spp. can affect a wide range of hosts, and these pathogens are characterized by global distribution. Virtually every cultivated botanical family is susceptible to one or more species of Colletotrichum, making it one of the most studied plant pathogenic fungi (Prusky et al., 2000; Latunde-Dada, 2001; Dean et al., 2012). Common hosts include many dicotyledonous plants such as strawberry, apple, citrus, and stone fruits, as well as major cereals such as maize and sorghum. query: What is the importance of molecular phylogenetic analysis in identifying Colletotrichum species?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['The shift towards multi-gene phylogenetic analysis has significantly changed the classification and species concepts within the Colletotrichum genus (Cannon et al. 2012, Damm et al. 2012a, b, 2013, 2014, Weir et al. 2012). Many Colletotrichum species are classified as latent plant pathogens, endophytes, epiphytes, or saprobes, and may adopt a pathogenic lifestyle when host plants are stressed (Damm et al. 2009, Cannon et al. 2012). Systematic studies of nearly all recognized species have identified several complexes, revealing that some Colletotrichum species historically considered as causal agents of significant plant diseases are actually different species. For example, C. alienum is now recognized as a key species in Proteaceae cultivation (Liu et al. 2013), while C. acutatum s.lat. was found in Mediterranean countries causing diseases in various hosts, such as Fragaria × ananassa (Garrido et al. 2008), Arbutus unedo (Polizzi et al. 2011), and Olea europaea (Talhinhas et al. 2011). Given the economic losses in citrus orchards, understanding these species interactions is crucial.', 0.9875137209892273]]
Context 1: [['To address the inadequacies of traditional identification methods, molecular techniques have been employed to characterize and identify taxa within Colletotrichum (Sreenivasaprasad et al., 1996; Abang et al., 2002; Moriwaki et al., 2002; Peres et al., 2002; Guerber et al., 2003; Photita et al., 2005; Du et al., 2005; Shenoy et al., 2007b; Whitelaw-Weckert et al., 2007; Peres et al., 2008; Than et al., 2008a-c). Cannon et al. (2000) noted that nucleic acid analyses provide a reliable framework for classifying Colletotrichum, as DNA characters are not directly influenced by environmental factors. The combined use of molecular diagnostic tools alongside traditional morphological techniques is currently an effective approach for studying Colletotrichum species complexes (Cannon et al., 2000; Cai et al., 2009).', 0.987354576587677]]
Context 2: [['In the past, common identification systems for Colletotrichum included traditional morphological taxonomy, molecular classification based on ITS sequences, and the presence of secondary metabolites, among other traits. However, these methods alone or in combination were insufficient to fully resolve the species identity of individual Colletotrichum isolates. Additional characteristics, including other aspects of morphology and multi-gene phylogenetic analyses, are necessary for accurate identification of Colletotrichum species.', 0.9816083312034607]]
Context 3: [['The identification of Colletotrichum species has long been challenging due to limited morphological characteristics. Single-gene phylogenetic analyses have also proven unsuccessful in clearly delineating species, partly due to the high number of erroneous names in GenBank. This paper reviews the taxonomic problems associated with Colletotrichum and the difficulties in identifying taxa at the species level. We advocate for epitypification and the use of multi-locus phylogenetic methods to better delimit species and understand the genus.', 0.9810711741447449]]

query: Can the patterns observed in vegetative compatibility among Colletotrichum species be generalized to other fungal genera?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['The genus Colletotrichum is considered one of the top ten important genera of fungal pathogens globally (Dean et al., 2012). Colletotrichum is an ancient fungus that has co-evolved with flowering plants. Plant microfossils of Protocolletotrichum preserved on angiosperm leaf cuticles suggest that the diverse pathogenic strategies of Colletotrichum spp. have been established since the Late Cretaceous period (Kar et al., 2004). Different complexes within the genus may have diverged between 4.8 and 32.2 million years ago (MYA) (Bhunjun et al., 2021). The emergence of agricultural cultivation and the intensive disturbance of natural environments have further driven the diversification of Colletotrichum species. These fungi have adapted to thousands of hosts and can be found as endophytes, pathogens, and saprobes (Freeman et al., 1998; Dean et al., 2012; Hirayama et al., 2018; da Silva et al., 2020; Jayawardena et al., 2020). Currently, a total of 257 Colletotrichum species grouped into 15 complexes and 13 additional singletons have been accepted in this genus.', 0.6818026304244995]]

query: What is the significance of accurate species identification in managing strawberry anthracnose?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Anthracnose is an important disease of strawberry caused by Colletotrichum spp., which affects foliage, runners, crowns, and fruits (Howard et al., 1992). Three primary fungal pathogens—C. acutatum sensu lato, C. gloeosporioides sensu lato, and C. fragariae—are known to cause anthracnose disease in strawberries (Freeman and Katan, 1997). The crown rot syndrome is characteristic of infections from C. gloeosporioides sensu lato and C. fragariae, while fruit rot is mainly attributed to C. acutatum sensu lato, leading to significant yield losses (Howard et al., 1992). Currently, numerous species are classified under what is now known as the C. acutatum complex, with six species—C. acutatum sensu stricto, C. fioriniae, C. godetiae, C. nymphaeae, C. salicis, and C. simmondsii—identified as associated with strawberry anthracnose worldwide (Damm et al., 2012). Among these, C. nymphaeae is the most prevalent pathogen causing strawberry anthracnose globally, including in Iran (Baroncelli et al., 2015; Karimi et al., 2017; Wang et al., 2019). Currently, no effective chemical control methods exist for managing strawberry anthracnose; available options are limited to preventive treatments applied before fruit production (Denoyes-Rothan et al., 1999). Additionally, concerns about the toxic effects of chemical fungicides on the environment and the development of resistance in fungal strains highlight the need for alternative control strategies. Consequently, utilizing resistant cultivars appears to be the most efficient and practical approach for suppressing anthracnose development. In light of recent anthracnose outbreaks in strawberry fields in the Kurdistan province of Iran (Karimi et al., 2017), and the necessity for appropriate strategies to address this issue, the aim of this study was to evaluate the resistance of several commercial strawberry cultivars to the anthracnose fruit rot caused by C. nymphaeae under in vivo and greenhouse conditions.', 0.9575278162956238]]
Context 1: [['From a historical perspective, identifying the causal agents of strawberry anthracnose has faced considerable confusion at the species level for a long time. This process has gradually evolved from coarse estimates to precise identifications, as noted by Ji et al. in Phytopathology Research (2022). The first report of strawberry infection by C. fragariae occurred over 90 years ago in the southeastern USA (Brooks 1931). Morphological observations make it difficult to distinguish C. fragariae from C. gloeosporioides, the latter of which was described in the nineteenth century for a pathogen isolated from citrus in Italy (Penzig 1882). Consequently, early-stage strawberry anthracnose was often attributed to either C. fragariae or C. gloeosporioides.', 0.9322248101234436]]
Context 2: [['So far, anthracnose epidemics have affected strawberry nurseries and production fields worldwide. Reports on Colletotrichum spp. associated with strawberries, curated from literature in PubMed and Clarivate combined with fungal database searches (Farr and Rossman, 2022), were compiled to understand the global diversity and occurrence of the causal agents of strawberry anthracnose. From our findings, since 1931 until July 9, 2022, there have been over 220 citations and 310 records related to the identification of causal agents of strawberry anthracnose at the genus level of Colletotrichum in 36 countries across six continents, with 282 records providing pathogen identification at the species or species complex level.', 0.8332588076591492]]
Context 3: [['Strawberry anthracnose was first reported in China in 1990 (Hu, 1990). Shao (1992) documented the first instance of strawberry anthracnose in Shanghai, identifying the pathogen as Colletotrichum acutatum (Dai et al., 2006). Zhang et al. (2007) expanded on these findings by identifying C. gloeosporioides and C. fragariae (syn. C. theobromicola) as causal agents based on morphological characteristics. Ren et al. (2008, 2011) concluded that these three species are the main pathogens causing anthracnose in strawberries in China. Crown rot represents the most severe disease issue in many strawberry-producing regions of China (Ren et al., 2008). In the Zhejiang region, nearly 50% of seedling deaths in nurseries and over 40% yield losses in strawberry fields have been recorded (Xie et al., 2010). In 2009, the yield of greenhouse-cultivated strawberries in Donggang City, Liaoning Province, was reduced by over 10% due to crown rot (Wang, 2013). The average incidence of crown rot in greenhouses in Hubei Province was 41.7% in 2011 (Xiang et al., 2012). However, most studies conducted in China regarding this disease have primarily relied on morphological and single-gene (mainly ITS) analysis (Dai et al., 2006; Ren et al., 2008, 2011). Due to overlapping characteristics, species delimitation based solely on morphology is challenging in this genus. Employing multi-gene analysis alongside morphology can provide better resolution (Cai et al., 2009; Hyde et al., 2014). Therefore, the objective of this study was to identify the pathogens responsible for strawberry anthracnose in China using a morphological and multi-gene approach.', 0.8296349048614502]]
Context 4: [['The term "anthracnose" was first used to describe a new disease of strawberries caused by Colletotrichum fragariae Brooks. "Strawberry anthracnose" continues to be used as a general term to identify all diseases of strawberries caused by species of Colletotrichum. Strawberry anthracnose diseases have been reported to be caused by C. acutatum J.H. Simmonds, C. gloeosporioides (Penz.) Penz. & Sacc. in Penz. (the teleomorph of Cromereilla cingulata (Stoneman) Spauld. & H. Schrenk), and C. dematium (Pers.) Grove. The latter species only occasionally causes strawberry fruit rots and will not be discussed here.', 0.6840807199478149]]
Context 5: [['In the United Kingdom, five species, including C. nigrum (Liu et al. 2013), the more aggressive C. nymphaeae and C. fioriniae, as well as the less aggressive C. godetiae and C. aenigma (Baroncelli et al. 2015), have been reported as strawberry pathogens. Notably, C. nigrum and C. aenigma are outside the C. acutatum complex. In Belgium, four species of the C. acutatum complex—C. fioriniae, C. godetiae, C. nymphaeae, and C. salicis—were identified as strawberry pathogens (Grammen et al. 2019). Both C. fioriniae (Baroncelli et al. 2015) and C. nymphaeae (Jayawardena et al. 2016b) were also isolated from diseased strawberries in France. In Italy, pathogens causing strawberry anthracnose include C. simmondsii (Faedda et al. 2011), C. nymphaeae (Damm et al. 2012), C. acutatum sensu stricto (Vitale and Infantino 2014), and C. siamense (Jayawardena et al. 2016b). Additionally, there have been reports of the C. acutatum complex causing strawberry anthracnose rot without species-level identification in four other European countries: Germany (Nirenberg et al. 2002), Czech Republic (Novotný et al. 2007), Finland (Lilja et al. 2011), and Montenegro (Latinovic et al. 2012). Overall, Colletotrichum species infectious to strawberries outside the C. acutatum complex have only been reported in the United Kingdom and Italy.', 0.5275750160217285]]
Context 6: [['Baroncelli, R., Zapparata, A., Sarrocco, S., Sukno, S.A., Lane, C.R., Thon, M.R., Vannacci, G., Holub, E., and Sreenivasaprasad, S. 2015. Molecular Diversity of Anthracnose Pathogen Populations Associated with UK Strawberry Production Suggests Multiple Introductions of Three Different Colletotrichum Species. PLOS ONE, 10(6): e0129140.', 0.46129319071769714]]
Context 7: [['Numerous reports indicate that strawberry anthracnose pathogens may originate from weed species. For instance, C. fragariae was found attacking the weed Cassia obtusifolia L. (sicklepod, coffeweed) in Florida, causing typical disease symptoms. Inoculation of strawberry with the Cassia isolates resulted in typical anthracnose symptoms, while isolates from strawberry were equally virulent on Cassia. Similarly, inoculation of Duchesnea indica (Andr.) Focke (wild strawberry), F. virginiana Duch. (Virginia wild strawberry), and Potentilla canadensis L. with C. fragariae induced anthracnose disease on these hosts, suggesting that strawberry anthracnose pathogens have a broad host range.', 0.41582241654396057]]
Context 8: [['Ye, Z. W., Zheng, H. Q., & Tong, Y. M. (1997). First report on species of strawberry anthracnose pathogen in Shanghai suburbs and resistance of some strawberry cultivars to anthracnose. Acta Agriculturae Shanghai, 13, 75–80.', 0.41447409987449646]]
Context 9: [['Nam MH, Yoo JH, Yun TS, Kim HH, Kim HG. Anthracnose of strawberry: Etiological and ecological characteristics and management. Res Plant Dis 2023;29:205-19.', 0.41183581948280334]]

query: Are there any sprays or chemicals that work against Colletotrichum?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['The fact that Colletotrichum species differ in their sensitivity to certain fungicides, such as benomyl, is critical for chemical pathogen control. This variability should be taken into account when implementing a spray program, especially in mixed populations like C. acutatum and C. gloeosporioides, which affect several hosts, including apple, citrus, mango, peach, pecan, and strawberries. Differential sensitivity among these species may result in shifts in population ratios.', 0.9179225564002991]]
Context 1: [['Integrated pest management (IPM) strategies for Colletotrichum spp. encompass cultural, biological, and chemical control measures. Cultural control practices include producing disease-free propagating materials, avoiding overhead irrigation, minimizing rain splashing through mulching, and managing weeds (Coelho et al., 2008; Saxena et al., 2016). It is also recommended to remove infected crop residues and any mummified or rotten fruits to reduce inoculum sources and disease spread.', 0.8418964147567749]]
Context 2: [['Templeton, G. E. 1992. Use of Colletotrichum strains as mycoherbicides. Pages 358-380 in: Colletotrichum: Biology, Pathology and Control. J. A. Bailey and M. J. Jeger, eds. CAB International, Wallingford, UK.', 0.4222348630428314]]
Context 3: [['Watson, A.K., Gressel, J., Sharon, A., & Dinoor, A. (2000). Colletotrichum strains for weed control. In: Colletotrichum: Host Specificity, Pathology and Host-Pathogen Interaction (Prusky, D., Freeman, S., & Dickman, M.B., eds). APS Press, St. Paul, USA: 245–265.', 0.3881779909133911]]
Context 4: [['In Colletotrichum: Biology, Pathology and Control (eds. J.A. Bailey and M.J. Jeger). CAB International: Wallingford.', 0.37177035212516785]]
Context 5: [['Bailey, J.A., & Jeger, M.J. (1992). Colletotrichum: biology, pathology, and control. Tropical Plant Pathology, 40, 265–274.', 0.3361884355545044]]
Context 6: [['Host Range and Specificity Some Colletotrichum species exhibit extensive host ranges, while others are more specific. Certain strains, such as C. gloeosporioides and C. acutatum, infect a broad range of hosts, whereas others, like C. dematium, may have more restricted host interactions. These characteristics are vital for the development of commercial mycoherbicides aimed at controlling specific weeds like northern jointvetch.', 0.33495092391967773]]
Context 7: [['Many species belonging to the genus Colletotrichum are associated with plant diseases, commonly referred to as anthracnose. Colletotrichum spp. can affect a wide range of hosts, and these pathogens are characterized by global distribution. Virtually every cultivated botanical family is susceptible to one or more species of Colletotrichum, making it one of the most studied plant pathogenic fungi (Prusky et al., 2000; Latunde-Dada, 2001; Dean et al., 2012). Common hosts include many dicotyledonous plants such as strawberry, apple, citrus, and stone fruits, as well as major cereals such as maize and sorghum. Members of this genus can cause crop losses of up to 100% in many staple foods (Bailey and Jeger, 1992; Prusky et al., 2000; Talhinhas et al., 2005; Cannon et al., 2012).', 0.3252984881401062]]
Context 8: [['He, L. F., Li, X. X., Gao, Y. Y., Li, B. X., Mu, W., and Liu, F. (2019). Characterization and fungicide sensitivity of Colletotrichum spp. from different hosts in Shandong, China. Plant Disease, 103, 34-43.', 0.3245610296726227]]

query: At 29 DAI, how did the use of plastic mulch compare to grass mulch in terms of flower blight reduction across different plant cultivars?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['The first symptoms of flower blight in this experiment were observed at 23 DAI, when a significantly lower percentage of blighted flowers was found in the plots treated with grass mulch (Figure 3a, P < 0.05). No effects of genetic resistance or interactions between mulching material and cultivar were detected at this point in the epidemics. By 29 DAI, the incidence of blighted flowers in the plots treated with plastic mulch was greater than in the plots with grass mulch.', 0.9957297444343567]]
Context 1: [['Several studies (e.g., 720 et al. 1990a, 1990b, 1992; Madden et al. 1992, 1993; Ntahimpera et al. 1998) have noted a significant reduction in the incidence of flower blight in treatments using grass mulch compared to plastic mulch, particularly with natural or simulated precipitation. These effects are observed under common irrigation practices in Brazil. The most likely explanation for this reduction is the decreased dispersal of Colletotrichum acutatum conidia, which relies heavily on water splash. While no spatial pattern analyses were conducted, the observed decrease in disease levels with increasing distance from the inoculum source in grass-mulched plots suggests reduced pathogen dispersal in these areas.', 0.9953261613845825]]
Context 2: [['A second experiment compared the effects of grass mulch, pine (Pinus elliottii) mulch, and plastic mulch with overhead sprinkler irrigation on two strawberry cultivars: ‘Dover’ (partially resistant) and ‘Campinas’ (susceptible). Both organic mulches reduced flower blight and diseased fruit incidence by up to 76% compared to plastic mulch, especially during the early stages of the epidemics. ‘Dover’ showed a 70% lower incidence of flower blight than ‘Campinas’, with organic mulch effects being more pronounced in ‘Campinas’.', 0.9945876598358154]]
Context 3: [['At the later stages of the epidemics (55 DAI), the interaction between irrigation systems and mulching material became significant (P < 0.01): for overhead-irrigated plots, the use of plastic mulch increased the incidence of flower blight more than threefold, while no significant effect of mulching material was observed for the drip-irrigated or plastic tape-irrigated plots (Figure 1b). No significant interactions between irrigation and mulching materials were found for the area under the disease progress curves (AUDPCs) of the incidence of blighted flowers. The average AUDPC values for drip, plastic tape, and overhead irrigation were significantly different (P < 0.01), while AUDPCs between plastic and grass mulch were similar (P > 0.05, Table 1).', 0.993391752243042]]
Context 4: [['The single and combined effects of mulching materials and partial host resistance on the incidence of flower blight were studied under overhead sprinkler irrigation conditions. Three mulching materials were compared: (a) 0.03-mm black, non-permeable polyethylene plastic, (b) sun-dried grass mulch (Brachiaria sp.), and (c) sun-dried pine mulch (Pinus elliottii) collected from a nearby reforestation area to a depth of approximately 4 cm. The mulches were applied to the plots 25 days after transplanting (DAT).', 0.9428855776786804]]
Context 5: [['Despite lower flower blight incidence, a higher percentage of diseased fruit was found in plots of cultivar Dover (33%) compared to Campinas (17.4%). This is likely due to the intense destruction of flowers in Campinas early in the season, resulting in fewer fruits available for later infection. Because more flowers of cultivar Dover survived earlier, more healthy fruit tissue was available for infection later in the season. Diseased fruit incidence was significantly affected by the interaction between mulching material and cultivar genotype (P < 0.05). The effect of mulching material varied for each cultivar: while the incidence of diseased fruit for Dover was unaffected by mulching material, plastic mulch increased the incidence of damaged fruit for Campinas compared to either pine or grass mulch treatments.', 0.9402154684066772]]
Context 6: [['Localized low-pressure overhead tape irrigation was applied 20 days after inoculation (DAI) (Figure 1a). Disease occurrence in the drip-irrigated treatment was only observed very late in the season at 47 DAI, albeit at a low incidence of 0.2%. In the early stages of the epidemics (20 DAI), the interaction between irrigation systems and mulching materials was significant (P < 0.05), indicating that the effects of the mulches were influenced by the irrigation system used. The highest incidence of flower blight was found in the combination of overhead irrigation and plastic mulch (Figure 1a). Later in the epidemics (27–47 DAI, not shown), significant interactions between irrigation and mulching materials were no longer observed (P > 0.05). The lack of significant interactions between the main factors allowed for separate comparisons of the irrigation systems and mulch types (Figure 2). Disease levels were lower in low-pressure tape-irrigated plots than in those irrigated by overhead sprinklers, regardless of the mulch material applied (Figure 2a, Table 1). Similarly, disease levels in plots covered with grass mulch were lower than in those using plastic mulch (Figure 2b).', 0.9385208487510681]]
Context 7: [['In Figure 3, the single main effects of mulch type on flower blight incidence are illustrated for 23 DAI (above) and 29 DAI (below). No significant interactions between mulching material and cultivar genotype were detected at these times during the epidemics. Differences among cultivars remained significant later in the epidemics at 37 and 44 DAI (P < 0.01), although the effect of mulching material ceased to be significant (P > 0.05). Lower percentages of blighted flowers were observed on cultivar Dover (always below 15%), while disease incidence on cultivar Campinas ranged between 45% and 50%.', 0.9375474452972412]]
Context 8: [['The effect of genetic resistance was significant at 29 days after inoculation (DAI) (P < 0.05). The disease incidence on cultivar Campinas reached 23.3% of flowers, while cultivar Dover had only 7.5% of blighted flowers. No interaction between mulching material and cultivar was observed in the early stages of the epidemics.', 0.8729910850524902]]
Context 9: [['A third experiment, combining all three irrigation systems with inoculated and non-inoculated plots, estimated yield effects due to disease and irrigation method. All plots were covered with plastic mulch in a completely randomized design (CRD) with six treatments. Results confirmed that sprinkler irrigation led to higher incidences of flower blight and fruit rot. In inoculated treatments, fruit yield was significantly reduced in tape-irrigated plots, more so in sprinkler-irrigated plots, while drip-irrigated plots experienced only a 1% reduction in yield.', 0.8095301985740662]]

Context 5: [['Huber, L., Fitt, B. D. L., and McCartney, H. A. 1996. The incorporation of pathogen spores into rain-splash droplets: A modeling approach. Plant Pathology 45:506-517.', 0.04935681074857712]]

Context 7: [['It is well established that surface topography (e.g., surface random roughness) significantly influences rain-splash dispersal of fungal plant pathogens. Increased surface roughness can often counteract the effects of increased rain quantity or intensity on spore dispersal. For example, straw mulch, commonly used in perennial strawberry production, substantially reduces disease spread in the field. In this study, increasing plant density produced a qualitatively similar effect to increased surface roughness, although the impact of plant density changes was less pronounced. While altering density alone may not suffice to manage diseases like anthracnose, it could be combined with other practices to enhance disease control. Moreover, density effects are directly relevant to the use of cultivar mixtures for controlling anthracnose and other diseases.', 0.04543904587626457]]

query: How does the use of plasticulture benefit strawberry production?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['In Korea, strawberries (Fragaria × ananassa) are favored for winter cultivation when the production of other vegetables and fruits is relatively low. In 2003, strawberries were planted on a total area of 7,503 hectares in Korea, with plastic greenhouse cultivation comprising 7,172 hectares and a total production of 205,427 tonnes for the fresh market (Anonymous, 2004). Forcing, where strawberries are transplanted into greenhouses in mid-September and induced to fruit in December (Oda, 1991), is becoming more common in Korea. June-bearing cultivars such as Maehyang, Akihime, and Nyoho, used for forcing, have proven difficult to grow due to their susceptibility to anthracnose (Nam et al., 1998; Kim & Nam, 1999). Anthracnose is one of the most damaging diseases of strawberries, causing wilting and death of transplants in the nursery field. The pathogen responsible for the disease in Korea is Colletotrichum gloeosporioides, first reported in 1992 (Kim et al., 1992).', 0.7428790330886841]]
