query: Are there specific environmental conditions that could affect the band patterns of C. acutatum?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Varying band patterns indicate that C. acutatum isolates from diverse hosts—including anemone, almond, apple, peach, pecan, and strawberry—represent three genotypes, showcasing considerable overall heterogeneity within this species.', 0.46614840626716614]]
Context 1: [['C. acutatum, as noted by various studies (Peres et al. 2008; Lee et al. 2007; Talhinhas et al. 2011; Polashock et al. 2009; Wharton & Schilder 2008), has a well-known morphological feature: the shape of its conidia, which are characterized by acute ends (Simmonds 1965). However, other conidial shapes are frequently encountered, particularly cylindrical forms with only one acute end. These variations are often observed in strains that have been repeatedly subcultured, as well as in the “terminal crook” disease of pine (Dingley & Gilmour 1972) and in the anthracnose affecting leather leaf fern (Schiller et al. 2006). There are also reports of disseminated infections in sea turtles (Manire et al. 2002) and infections in scale insects (Marcelino et al. 2008). Differentiating between C. acutatum (s. lat.) and C. gloeosporioides (s. lat.) is challenging due to the existence of many intermediate strains that exhibit a limited number of typical fusiform conidia alongside numerous cylindrical ones (Van der Aa et al. 1990).', 0.357235848903656]]
Context 2: [['Morphology of C. acutatum. C. acutatum is an Ascomycete classified in the Pyrenomycetes and included in the family Phyllachoraceae. Colonies of C. acutatum are usually white initially but later become covered with pink to orange conidial masses. Cultures from certain hosts are highly chromogenic and excrete red and pink pigments into the culture media. The primary production of conidia occurs in acervuli; however, C. acutatum can also form secondary conidia on the surfaces of living leaves. Conidia are typically ellipsoid and fusiform at least at one end, differing from C. gloeosporioides, which generally has both ends rounded. Setae are usually sparse or not produced at all. Pigmented appressoria form upon germination of the conidia and vary in shape and size.', 0.25384652614593506]]
Context 3: [['The results from this study, along with previous research, may explain the increasing significance of C. acutatum in northern regions (15, 20). Once introduced in an area, C. acutatum could possess distinct advantages over other strawberry-infecting species of Colletotrichum at cooler temperatures, which are typical for northern climates. Two of these advantages include a shorter latent period for C. acutatum and a greater production of spores at lower temperatures.', 0.22145713865756989]]
Context 4: [['INTRODUCTION: As a significant pathogen, C. acutatum has been treated as a regulated organism for many years.', 0.1988048553466797]]
Context 5: [['In inoculations conducted under controlled greenhouse conditions, C. acutatum from strawberry was isolated from inoculated plants that did not exhibit disease symptoms but maintained virulence on strawberry. The fungus was detected by a plating method both on and inside inoculated leaves at various time points after plant inoculation. The authenticity of the isolates as C. acutatum was validated by PCR using C. acutatum-specific primers. The PCR technique proved accurate and sensitive enough to detect the pathogen in inoculated tissues within 24 hours post-inoculation. This method is valuable for detecting C. acutatum in the tissues of various plant species, indicating that the fungus can exhibit both epiphytic and endophytic lifestyles without causing visible disease symptoms. PCR and fungal isolation data indicate that the pathogen can remain viable for extended periods within the tissues of various plant species without inducing disease symptoms. Although the experiments were concluded after three months for technical reasons, the final levels of inoculum in the examined tissues and the decay curves suggest that the pathogen had the potential to inhabit the infected plants for much longer periods. Furthermore, it has been shown that C. acutatum from strawberry can survive for nine months within plant debris in soil.', 0.17836235463619232]]
Context 6: [['The sexual stage of certain genetic subgroups of C. acutatum has been characterized under laboratory conditions and designated as Glomerella acutata. Research indicates that many isolates from diverse hosts can mate and form mature perithecia in culture. Crosses within isolates in group C, as well as some intergroup crosses, exhibit high fertility, while others show weak fertility or infertility. However, mating compatibility in C. acutatum and other Colletotrichum species is complex.', 0.17233262956142426]]
Context 7: [['Although C. acutatum isolates from tropical fruits can cross-infect under laboratory conditions, the extent of cross-infection in nature and the degree to which disease cycles operate on individual hosts require further investigation.', 0.1716744601726532]]
Context 8: [['In this study, the C. acutatum species complex was identified exclusively on the Aeolian Islands (Italy), a volcanic archipelago located north of Sicily.', 0.16459138691425323]]
Context 9: [['C. acutatum was first described as a separate species by Simmonds. Many isolates now identified as C. acutatum were either classified under C. gloeosporioides or considered species of Gloeo sporium. C. acutatum affects hosts that are also targeted by other Colletotrichum species, possibly leading to its earlier misidentification. For instance, strawberries can be affected by C. acutatum, C. gloeosporioides, and C. fragariae. The latter two typically cause petiole and stolon lesions, as well as crown rot on strawberries.', 0.16042374074459076]]

query: How do diseases spread from one strawberry plant to another?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['In the traditional system of strawberry production, plants are grown in the ground, and crop rotation is essential. However, in recent cultivation systems, plants are continuously cultivated on elevated benches to improve production efficiency. This continuous cropping system usually increases weed populations and necessitates intensive herbicide applications, which can also enhance the risk of disease dissemination from weeds to strawberries. The present study demonstrated that an increase of C. fructicola in weeds heightened the incidence of anthracnose in strawberries during the following cultivation season. While there are numerous sources of C. fructicola that lead to disease during subsequent strawberry cultivations, the increase of pathogens on herbicide-treated weeds can be a significant source.', 0.5737783312797546]]

query: What were the main findings of the laboratory studies on the ED50 of different fungicides against Colletotrichum acutatum?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Various fungicides and a heat treatment were assessed for their ability to control strawberry anthracnose caused by the fungus Colletotrichum acutatum under laboratory, greenhouse, and field conditions. The effective dose causing 50% inhibition of mycelial growth (ED50) was measured at 30.5, 12.2, 0.2, 0.15, 0.05, 0.07, and 0.05 µg/ml for the fungicides folpet, captan, propiconazole, difenoconazole, combined prochloraz-Zn/folpet, prochloraz-Zn, and prochloraz-Mn, respectively.', 0.9884850978851318]]
Context 1: [['Table 1 presents the effective doses of various fungicides that resulted in 50% inhibition (ED50) of Colletotrichum acutatum in vitro. The table includes entries for captan, propiconazole, difenoconazole, prochloraz-Zn combined with folpet, prochloraz-Zn alone, and prochloraz-Mn, listing the specific concentrations needed for each to achieve the inhibition. This data highlights the comparative efficacy of these fungicides in controlling the pathogen in laboratory settings.', 0.9838705062866211]]
Context 2: [['Anthracnose crown rot of strawberry, caused by Colletotrichum acutatum, is an important disease affecting California nursery and fruit production. Preplant dip treatments of transplants with fludioxonil-cyprodinil or azoxystrobin are industry standards for managing the disease and have been used extensively. Following reports of reduced efficacy of azoxystrobin in the field, high levels of quinone outside inhibitor (QoI) resistance were detected in California isolates of the pathogen. Resistance was associated with the G143A mutation in the cytochrome b gene, similar to a previous report from Florida, and there were no detected fitness penalties in pathogenicity or virulence. Therefore, several alternative fungicides were investigated in laboratory and field studies. Subsequently, the new biofungicide natamycin was identified. Baseline sensitivities of 74 isolates of C. acutatum to natamycin were determined to be unimodal, with a range from 0.526 to 1.996 mg/ml (mean 0.973 mg/ml).', 0.9634806513786316]]
Context 3: [['De los Santos García de Paredes, B., and Romero Muñoz, F. (2002). Effect of different fungicides on the control of Colletotrichum acutatum, the causal agent of anthracnose crown rot in strawberry plants. Crop Prot., 21:11-15.', 0.9570519328117371]]
Context 4: [['Table 2 Description: Table 2 presents the effective concentrations of fungicides required to inhibit 50% of mycelial growth or conidial germination for both QoI-sensitive and -resistant isolates of Colletotrichum acutatum. It likely includes specific concentrations (EC50 values) for each fungicide tested, categorized by the type of isolate, highlighting the differential effectiveness of various fungicides against the pathogen based on its resistance profile.', 0.9506771564483643]]
Context 5: [['In a study on the control of Colletotrichum acutatum in infected strawberry plants, it was found that a 200- to 500-fold concentration of captan and folpet, along with a 750-fold concentration of azole fungicides, was necessary to achieve 50% fungal growth inhibition compared to prochloraz fungicides.', 0.9472940564155579]]
Context 6: [['In vitro inhibition of C. acutatum was evaluated in the Sharon region in 1995 and in the Lev Hasharon region in 1996. Transplants were submerged for 10 minutes in tap water (untreated control) or in aqueous solutions of various fungicides: captan (2.5 g/liter), prochloraz-Zn (1 g/liter), folpet (4 g/liter), combined prochloraz-Zn/folpet, and others. The effective dose causing 50% inhibition (ED50) was calculated for these fungicides. Prochloraz-Zn and prochloraz-Mn, either alone or in combination with folpet, were identified as the most effective fungicides in inhibiting C. acutatum in vitro.', 0.9116451740264893]]
Context 7: [['LaMondia, J.A. (1993). In vitro evaluation of fungicides against Colletotrichum acutatum isolates from strawberry. Advances in Strawberry Research, 12, 34–37.', 0.8694913983345032]]
Context 8: [['Forcelini BB, Peres NA. Widespread resistance to QoI fungicides of Colletotrichum acutatum from strawberry nurseries and production fields. Plant Health Prog. 2018;19:338-341. https://doi.org/10.1094/PHP-08-18-0050-RS.', 0.8529742956161499]]

query: What precautions should be taken when applying treatments for anthracnose?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Until highly resistant cultivars are available, growers must rely on chemical applications and cultural practices to reduce losses due to anthracnose. The failure of fungicides to control anthracnose epidemics may be attributed to the development of fungicide resistance in the Colletotrichum species population. For example, benomyl was shown to effectively reduce the incidence of anthracnose crown rot (Horn et al., 1972; Howard, 1971) and was used intensively by strawberry growers for years to control anthracnose and other diseases. However, the anthracnose pathogens, C. acutatum and C. fragariae, developed resistance to it and other benzimidazole fungicides (LaMondia, 1995; McInnes et al., 1992a; Smith and Black, 1992, 1993), leading to the ineffectiveness of benomyl for anthracnose control in strawberry fields.', 0.2033669501543045]]

query: Which fungal pathogens are primarily associated with anthracnose in strawberries?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['Anthracnose is an important disease of strawberry caused by Colletotrichum spp., which affects foliage, runners, crowns, and fruits (Howard et al., 1992). Three primary fungal pathogens—C. acutatum sensu lato, C. gloeosporioides sensu lato, and C. fragariae—are known to cause anthracnose disease in strawberries (Freeman and Katan, 1997). The crown rot syndrome is characteristic of infections from C. gloeosporioides sensu lato and C. fragariae, while fruit rot is mainly attributed to C. acutatum sensu lato, leading to significant yield losses (Howard et al., 1992). Currently, numerous species are classified under what is now known as the C. acutatum complex, with six species—C. acutatum sensu stricto, C. fioriniae, C. godetiae, C. nymphaeae, C. salicis, and C. simmondsii—identified as associated with strawberry anthracnose worldwide (Damm et al., 2012). Among these, C. nymphaeae is the most prevalent pathogen causing strawberry anthracnose globally, including in Iran (Baroncelli et al., 2015; Karimi et al., 2017; Wang et al., 2019). Currently, no effective chemical control methods exist for managing strawberry anthracnose; available options are limited to preventive treatments applied before fruit production (Denoyes-Rothan et al., 1999). Additionally, concerns about the toxic effects of chemical fungicides on the environment and the development of resistance in fungal strains highlight the need for alternative control strategies. Consequently, utilizing resistant cultivars appears to be the most efficient and practical approach for suppressing anthracnose development. In light of recent anthracnose outbreaks in strawberry fields in the Kurdistan province of Iran (Karimi et al., 2017), and the necessity for appropriate strategies to address this issue, the aim of this study was to evaluate the resistance of several commercial strawberry cultivars to the anthracnose fruit rot caused by C. nymphaeae under in vivo and greenhouse conditions.', 0.9979627132415771]]
Context 1: [['Strawberry anthracnose was first reported in China in 1990 (Hu, 1990). Shao (1992) documented the first instance of strawberry anthracnose in Shanghai, identifying the pathogen as Colletotrichum acutatum (Dai et al., 2006). Zhang et al. (2007) expanded on these findings by identifying C. gloeosporioides and C. fragariae (syn. C. theobromicola) as causal agents based on morphological characteristics. Ren et al. (2008, 2011) concluded that these three species are the main pathogens causing anthracnose in strawberries in China. Crown rot represents the most severe disease issue in many strawberry-producing regions of China (Ren et al., 2008). In the Zhejiang region, nearly 50% of seedling deaths in nurseries and over 40% yield losses in strawberry fields have been recorded (Xie et al., 2010). In 2009, the yield of greenhouse-cultivated strawberries in Donggang City, Liaoning Province, was reduced by over 10% due to crown rot (Wang, 2013). The average incidence of crown rot in greenhouses in Hubei Province was 41.7% in 2011 (Xiang et al., 2012). However, most studies conducted in China regarding this disease have primarily relied on morphological and single-gene (mainly ITS) analysis (Dai et al., 2006; Ren et al., 2008, 2011). Due to overlapping characteristics, species delimitation based solely on morphology is challenging in this genus. Employing multi-gene analysis alongside morphology can provide better resolution (Cai et al., 2009; Hyde et al., 2014). Therefore, the objective of this study was to identify the pathogens responsible for strawberry anthracnose in China using a morphological and multi-gene approach.', 0.9967225193977356]]
Context 2: [['So far, anthracnose epidemics have affected strawberry nurseries and production fields worldwide. Reports on Colletotrichum spp. associated with strawberries, curated from literature in PubMed and Clarivate combined with fungal database searches (Farr and Rossman, 2022), were compiled to understand the global diversity and occurrence of the causal agents of strawberry anthracnose. From our findings, since 1931 until July 9, 2022, there have been over 220 citations and 310 records related to the identification of causal agents of strawberry anthracnose at the genus level of Colletotrichum in 36 countries across six continents, with 282 records providing pathogen identification at the species or species complex level.', 0.989168643951416]]
Context 3: [['Baroncelli, R., Zapparata, A., Sarrocco, S., Sukno, S.A., Lane, C.R., Thon, M.R., Vannacci, G., Holub, E., and Sreenivasaprasad, S. 2015. Molecular Diversity of Anthracnose Pathogen Populations Associated with UK Strawberry Production Suggests Multiple Introductions of Three Different Colletotrichum Species. PLOS ONE, 10(6): e0129140.', 0.9769357442855835]]
Context 4: [['Numerous reports indicate that strawberry anthracnose pathogens may originate from weed species. For instance, C. fragariae was found attacking the weed Cassia obtusifolia L. (sicklepod, coffeweed) in Florida, causing typical disease symptoms. Inoculation of strawberry with the Cassia isolates resulted in typical anthracnose symptoms, while isolates from strawberry were equally virulent on Cassia. Similarly, inoculation of Duchesnea indica (Andr.) Focke (wild strawberry), F. virginiana Duch. (Virginia wild strawberry), and Potentilla canadensis L. with C. fragariae induced anthracnose disease on these hosts, suggesting that strawberry anthracnose pathogens have a broad host range.', 0.9715908169746399]]
Context 5: [["Anthracnose fungi can attack various parts of the strawberry plant, including crowns, petioles, leaves, fruit trusses, flowers, buds, and fruit. The fungi's ability to attack multiple plant parts, coupled with the involvement of several pathogen species, contributes to the complex nature of strawberry anthracnose. Brooks reported in 1931 that C. fragariae caused spotting and girdling of runners, and later indicated that it also caused spotting of petioles and crown rot in a summer nursery, leading to wilting and death of the plants. Researchers in Louisiana observed all these symptoms and noted that crown rot also occurred in the fruit production field.", 0.961229681968689]]
Context 6: [['The term "anthracnose" was first used to describe a new disease of strawberries caused by Colletotrichum fragariae Brooks. "Strawberry anthracnose" continues to be used as a general term to identify all diseases of strawberries caused by species of Colletotrichum. Strawberry anthracnose diseases have been reported to be caused by C. acutatum J.H. Simmonds, C. gloeosporioides (Penz.) Penz. & Sacc. in Penz. (the teleomorph of Cromereilla cingulata (Stoneman) Spauld. & H. Schrenk), and C. dematium (Pers.) Grove. The latter species only occasionally causes strawberry fruit rots and will not be discussed here.', 0.8211694359779358]]
Context 7: [['Howard CM, Albregts EE. Anthracnose. In: Compendium of Strawberry Diseases. American Phytopathological Society: Paul St, ed. Maas JL, USA; 1984. pp. 85-87.', 0.6902703046798706]]
Context 8: [['Brooks AN (1931). Anthracnose of strawberry caused by Colletotrichum fragariae n. sp. Phytopathology 21: 739–744.', 0.5973290801048279]]
Context 9: [['Howard, C.M., Maas, J.L., Chandler, C.K., & Albregts, E.E. (1992). Anthracnose of strawberry caused by the Colletotrichum complex in Florida. Plant Disease, 76, 976–981.', 0.5775089263916016]]

query: What methods are used to study preharvest and postharvest diseases in fruits?
retrieved_context:
Context 0: [['On certain fruits, such as apple and blueberry (Vaccinium spp.), members of the C. acutatum species complex cause both pre-harvest and post-harvest diseases (Milholland, 1995; Jones et al., 1996; Shi et al., 1996). On these plants, asymptomatic, quiescent infections occur on unripe fruit, developing into necrotic lesions as the fruit ripens (Alkan et al., 2015). There are many other examples of post-harvest decay in fruits like peaches (Prunus persica), almonds (Prunus dulcis), avocado (Persea americana), mango (Mangifera indica), papaya (Carica papaya), and guava (Psidium guajava) that stem from quiescent infections that began in the field (Agostini et al., 1992; Freeman and Shabi, 1996; Smith, 1998; Afanador-Kafuri et al., 2003).', 0.970683753490448]]
Context 1: [['Two distinct types of diseases occur: those affecting developing fruit in the field (preharvest) and those damaging mature fruit during storage (postharvest). The ability to cause latent or quiescent infections has categorized Colletotrichum among the most important postharvest pathogens. Species of the pathogen predominantly appear on aboveground plant tissues; however, belowground organs, such as roots and tubers, may also be affected.', 0.8305487632751465]]
Context 2: [['Coates, L.M.; Johnson, G.I.; Dale, M. Postharvest pathology of fruit and vegetables. In Plant Pathogens and Plant Diseases; Brown, J., Ogle, H., Eds.; Rockvale Publications: Burlington, MA, USA, 1997; pp. 533–547.', 0.4625799357891083]]
Context 3: [['Alternative methods to reduce post-harvest fruit crop losses are being actively researched. Biocontrol agents, edible fruit coatings, Generally Recognized as Safe (GRAS) salts, cold plasma, and nanomaterial treatments have shown promising results, although they come with challenges. The effectiveness of these methods varies among different fruit crops, and further investigation is needed regarding their formulations and costs. Additionally, some methods are combined to enhance efficacy, leading to other issues such as public and industry acceptance, product registration, and commercial viability.', 0.41468483209609985]]
Context 4: [['Snowdon AL (1991). A Colour Atlas of Post-Harvest Diseases and Disorders of Fruit and Vegetables. Volume 2. Vegetables. Wolfe Scientific.', 0.2973295748233795]]
Context 5: [['The fruits used in this study included apple (Malus domestica Borkh., cvs. Granny Smith, Golden Delicious, and Starking), pear (Pyrus communis L., cv. Spadona), peach (Prunus persica L., cv. Hermosa), and nectarine (P. persica L. Batsch var. nectarina, cv. Flamekiss), which were purchased at a local supermarket. The fruit were thoroughly washed with detergent to remove possible remnants of post-harvest applied chemicals. The strawberry fruit (cv. Tamar) were obtained from untreated greenhouse plants at the Agricultural Research Organization. The various fruits were surface sterilized by submerging in 3% sodium hypochlorite (Sigma, Rehovot, Israel) for 2 minutes, washed extensively with sterile water, dried in a laminar flow hood, and either non-wound inoculated or wound inoculated by pinpricking.', 0.27508780360221863]]
